Researchers conducted a genomic survey of transcript ends in lymphoblast cells from genetically distinct human individuals to investigate the role of RNA 3'-end processing in gene regulation. They found that transcript positions did not fall randomly in untranslated regions, but rather preferentially flanked locations of 3' regulatory elements, including miRNA sites. The usage of transcript forms and motifs varied across individuals, and polymorphisms in polyadenylation signals and 3' motifs were significant predictors of gene expression levels. Single-gene experiments confirmed the effects of polyaden variants on steady-state expression and validated the regulatory function of 3 cis-regulatory elements. The study focused on the immune regulator IRF, establishing the effect of variation in RNA 3-end on response to antigen stimulation. The results highlight the importance of mechanisms in genetics of 3-end variation: usage of distinct 3-processing signals and 3 elements determining transcript fate. The study suggests integrating 3-positions with 3 motifs will be a tool in interpreting human variation.
Researchers have investigated the mechanisms behind the effectiveness of the SIVΔne vaccine, a live attenuated simian immunodeficiency virus vaccine that provides strong protection against wild-type lentiviral challenge. Using deep sequencing and CD8 cell epitope mapping, they analyzed the CD8 T cell response in SIVne-vaccinated animals, identifying regions of immune pressure and viral escape. The initial CD8 response in the acute phase of SIVne infection targeted variable epitopes, followed by widespread viral sequence evolution and escape. Epitope escape expanded the CD8 repertoire to target conserved epitopes, defined by anropic specificity, and generated new responses to escaped variants during vaccination. These findings correlate SIVne-induced protection with anropic specificity and increased response depth.
Interleukin-1 (IL-1) plays a crucial role in coordinating the neutrophil response to Candida albicans in oral mucosal infections. In a mouse model of oropharyngeal candidiasis (OPC), IL-1 receptor (IL-R) signaling is essential for controlling the onset of infection through its impact on neutrophils at two levels: recruiting circulating neutrophils to the site of infection and mobilizing newly generated neutils from the bone marrow. IL- deficient mice display impaired chemokine production at the site of infection and defective secretion of granocyte-colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) in circulation in response to C. albicans. Endothelial cells are the primary source of G-CS during OPC, responding to IL-α released from keratinocytes in infected tissue. IL-dependent crosstalk between hematopoietic subsets confirmed in vitro using a murine-derived kerocyte line and endothelial line. This establishes a link between IL and granopoies in fungal infection context. Two mechanisms coordinating neutil response in mucosa critical for preventing growth dissemination and host disease protection identified.
Between 2000 and 2007, the Global Programme to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis (GPELF) administered over 1.9 billion treatments to nearly 600 million individuals annually via mass drug administration of anti-filar drugs (albendazole, iverectin, diethylcarazine) to at-risk for 4-6 years. The economic benefits of this achievement were quantified by calculating the number of clinical manifestations averted and associated with disease prevention in the context of direct costs, indirect labor, and healthcare costs to affected individuals. Reviewing multiple sources, including the World Health Organization, International Fund, and Labour Organization, estimated $21.8 billion in economic benefits over 31.4 million treated during the first 8 years of GLEF. $2.3 billion was realized by protecting nearly 3 million from lymphatic filariasis due to being born in areas of transmission. Additionally, 28 million infected with LF benefited from GELF halting disease progression, resulting in $19.5 billion lifetime benefit. At-risk individuals decreased services with LF morbidity saved health systems $2.2 billion. The Programme offers significant economic benefits, with favorable implementation largely due to donated drugs from the pharmaceutical industry. The return on GLEF is high, proving an excellent investment in global health.
Researchers have created a mouse model of neuronopathic Gaucher disease by introducing a nonsense mutation in the glucocerebrosidase (GBA) gene, leading to a complete deficiency in glucocerebrosidase (GCase) activity. In contrast to humans and mice lacking GCase activity, these mice survived for months, allowing for the study of disease progression. The model displayed phenotypes of human neuronopathic Gaucher disease, including infiltration of Gaucher cells into the brain, progressive neuronal loss, and microgliosis. Detailed analysis revealed lysosomal abnormalities in neurons and accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-s) in axonal swellings containing autophagosomes. Unexpectedly, disruption of α-syn did not improve lifespan, axonal swellings, neuronal loss, or neuroinflammation in the model.
Listeria monocytogen, a facultative intracellular pathogen, induces a robust cell-mediated immune response upon sublethal infection. However, its ability to escape the phagosome and enter the host cytos is crucial for long-lived CD8 T cellmediated immunity. Research reveals that the T response to L monocogen confined within a phag is not solely due to inefficient antigen presentation, but direct suppression of the adaptive response. This suppression affects not only the response to vacole-confined L monocogen, but also negates the response to within cytosolic infection. Co-infection with phosome-confined and cytos L monocogen prevents acquired immunity and antigen-specific T cell expansion relative to cytos L monocogen alone. Bacteria confined phag suppress pro-inflammatory cytokine production, leading to MyD-dependent IL-10 production. Blocking IL-10 or MyD during primary infection restores immunity.
Researchers have identified six variants in the SIX gene associated with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG), a leading cause of blindness worldwide. Genome-wide association studies previously linked the SIX locus to POAG, with a significant odds ratio of 1.32 and a p-value of 3.87×10^-11. The SIX gene plays a role in ocular development and optic nerve morphology. The study sequenced SIX coding and regulatory regions in 262 PO cases and 256 controls, identifying six nonsynonymous variants, five rare and one common, AsnHis (rs12345), associated with PO (OR=1.27, p=4.2×10^-10) in the NEIGHBOR/GLUGEN datasets. Variants were tested in vivo Danio rerio (zebrafish) complementation to evaluate ocular metrics such as eye size and optic structure. Five variants, primarily in PO cases, were hypomorphic or null, while the sixth, only in controls, was benign. One variant in SIX enhancer increased SIX expression and disrupted regulation. The study found a clinical feature in PO patients dependent on SIX genotype: those homozygous for SIX risk allele (His) have a thinner retinal nerve layer than homozyg for non-risk (As). Results, combined with previous SIX work, suggest SIX variants disrupt retina development, reducing retinal ganglion cells, increasing glcoma vision loss risk.
Researchers have identified a genetic switch, known as the "flagellar switch," that controls the production of flagella and glucosyl toxins in Clostridium difficile, a human intestinal pathogen. The flagella facilitate adherence to intestinal epithelial cells, while glucosyl toxins contribute to diarrheal disease. The flag switch, located upstream of the flB operon containing early flagellar genes, is a 154 base pair invertible sequence flanked by 21 base pairs of inverted repeats. Bacteria with the switch in one orientation express flagellar genes, produce flagella, and secrete toxins (fl phase ON), while those with the inverse orientation are attenuated for flagellar and toxin expression, aflagellate, and show decreased toxin secretion (fl OFF). The switch orientation is reversible in vitro. Gene regulation via the flag switch occurs post-transcriptionally and requires a C. difficile specific factor to destabilize or degrade early flagellar mRNA when the switch is OFF. Mutagenesis and characterization of flag phase locked isolates revealed tyrosine recombinase RecV, which catalyzes inversion at cV switch, is also responsible for inversion at flag switch in both directions. Phase flagellar motility and toxin production suggest these virulence factors have both advantageous and detrimental effects during infection.
Researchers investigated the sporulation pathway in Clostridium difficile, an obligate anaerobic pathogen that relies on endospores for infection. In contrast to the model organism Bacillus subtilis, where sporulation is governed by cell-specific RNA polymerase subunits σF in the forespore and σE in the mother cell, Clostridium difficile's sporulation is regulated by σF, σE, σ, and σK. Using morphological characterization and fluorescence reporter gene expression analysis, the researchers found deviations from the B. subtilis paradigm. While σ periods of activity are conserved, σE is partially independent of σ, σ is dependent on σ, and σ does not require σ. σ is not required for heat-resistant spore formation. The results indicate reduced temporal segregation between early and late sigma factors and reduced requirement for σ-to-σ, σ-to-σ, and σ-to-cell signaling pathways. However, the study supports conservation of the sporulation network with sigma factors as key regulators, established 2.5 billion years ago in the Firmicutes Phylum.
Researchers have developed a framework to model the response of allosteric multisite proteins using a single variable, which closely replicates the steady-state behavior of detailed multisite systems such as the Monod-Wy-Change allosteric model and Hill-based models. Optimal ultrasensitivity is achieved when alloster protein activation by individual sites is concerted and redundant. This reduction makes the framework useful for modeling and analyzing biochemical systems where multisite proteins interact simultaneously.

The framework was applied to a newly discovered checkpoint pathway in yeast, proposed to measure cell growth by monitoring signals at plasma membrane growth sites. Components of this pathway form a hysteretic switch, incorporating a signal proportional to bud size, a mechanism to read the signal, and an-or response triggered when signal reaches threshold indicating sufficient growth.
Researchers have employed a combination of experimental and mathematical approaches to investigate the quorum sensing (QS) system in E. coli, specifically focusing on the autoinducer-2 (AI-2) quorum sensing circuit. The study aimed to elucidate the mechanistic underpinnings of genetic switching phenomena in QS, which enable bacterial populations to communicate and gain a selective advantage. The researchers separated the network into sub-networks to examine negative and positive feedback mechanisms, revealing a previously unreported negative feedback interaction. A mathematical model was developed to test the hypothesis, and the importance of the Lsr regulator and its role in the E. coli QS switch was uncovered, previously masked by regulatory loops. The model provided a mechanistic understanding of the interplay among regulatory substructures and their contributions to the overall network functioning. This "bottom-up" approach to understanding gene regulation is expected to unravel complex QS architectures and lead to the coordination of emergent behaviors.
In a study conducted in rural areas of Gabon, researchers investigated the effect of Schistosoma haematobium, a soil-transmitted helminth (STH), on Plasmod falcum infection in school-age children. The study found that 30.23% of children were infected with S. haobium, 23.9% with P. falcum, and 9% co-infected with both parasites. Results showed that S. haob infection increased the risk of P. falc infection, especially when combined with Trichuris trichi or hookworm infection. The incidence of malaria was 0.51 per-year in S-infected children compared to 0.43 in non-infected, with a significant delay in time to first malaria event in children aged 6-10 years infected with S. haob. The study suggests that STH enhances risk for P. falc infection in S-inf children and increases susceptibility to malaria in young children but not older children.
IRF-5-Mediated Inflammation Limits CD8+ T Cell Expansion by Inducing HIF-1 and Impairing Dendritic Cell Function during Leishmanial Infection

Infection with Leishmania donovani triggers an inflammatory response mediated by the transcription factor IRF-5, which activates genes encoding pro-inflammatory cytokines such as IL-6 and TNF. This study investigates the role of IRF-5-mediated inflammation in regulating CD8+ T cell responses during L. donani infection. Results show that IR-5-induced inflammation limits CD8 T cell expansion and induces HIF-1 in dendritic cells. Blocking HIF-1 in dendritic cells leads to increased frequency of short-lived effector cells, CD8 T expansion, and IL-12 expression by splenic dendritic cells. Mice with H-1-depleted dendritic cells have lower splenic parasite burden, suggesting H-1 induction may be an immune evasion mechanism used by L. donani to establish persistent infection.
A systematic review was conducted to identify prognostic factors for adverse outcomes in American visceral leishmanias (VL) in Latin America. Fourteen studies met the inclusion criteria and were analyzed for methodological quality using a research tool. Prognostic variables were synthesized through meta-analysis, grouped by strength of evidence, heterogeneity, and multivariate analysis. The strongest predictors were jaundice, thrombocytopenia, hemorrhage, HIV coinfection, diarrhea, age <5 and >40 years, neutropenia, dyspnea, and bacterial infections. Edema and low hemoglobin concentration were also associated with unfavorable outcomes. The main limitation was the absence of validation for prognostic models. Integration of studies over 10 years identified consistent prognostic variables for recognizing patients at risk of unfavorable outcomes. Development of externally validated prognost models is prioritized in future research.
Researchers in Algeria investigated the susceptibility of Leishmania isolates to antimony over a 30-year period. The study aimed to determine the level of antimony susceptibility amongst Leish transmitted in Algeria, which is crucial for public health policy development. A total of 106 isolates were analyzed, including 88 collected between 1976-2013 from humans, dogs, rodents, and phleomines, and 18 from dogs in France. All Algerian isolates were from endemic areas. The 50 inhibitory concentrations (IC50) of potassium antimony tarate (Sbivalent) and sodium stiboglucon (pentavalent) were determined in promastigotes and intramacroph amastigotes, respectively. The epidemiological cutoff (EFCO) differentiated Leish species causing cutaneous or visceral leishmanias susceptible (S+) or insusceptible (S) to trivalent antimony. The IC50 values were 23.83μg/mL and 15.91μg for VL and CL, respectively. A trend of increasing antimony susceptibility in VL isolates was observed over the 30-year period. In contrast, an increase in S-phenotypes isolates causing CL was noted during the same period. The emergence of S-phenotypes correlated with L. kili (L. tropica) isolates causing cutaneous leishiasis, which emerged in Algeria last decade. The study provides insight into spatiotemporal Leish antimony dynamics in Algeria, highlighting the need for effective methodology to detect ant susceptibility and prevent dissemination of resistant strains.
Crohn's disease (CD) is a chronic inflammatory condition with a complex etiology. Research has shown that exposure to foodborne pathogens causing acute gastroenteritis increases the risk of developing CD in the post-infectious period, but the underlying mechanisms are unclear. To investigate this relationship, two models were developed to study the comorbidity of acute gastroenteritis caused by Salmonella Typhimurium or Citrobacterium in mice colonized with adherent-invasive Escherichia coli (AIE), a bacterium linked to CD. The study found that disease activity in the post-infect period after gastroenteritis is driven by the expansion of resident IE in the tissue, accompanied by increased immunology defects, barrier defects, and delayed mucosal restitution following pathogen clearance. This was due to IE resistance to host defense peptides and amin inflammatory response to enteric pathogen. The results suggest individuals colonized by IE at the time of acute gastroenteritis may be at higher risk for CD onset. The study identifies IE as a tractable disease modifier, a finding that could inform therapeutic interventions following gastroenter in at-risk individuals.
In flowering plants, the female gametophyte of Arabidopsis is composed of two gametic cells, the egg and central cell, surrounded by five accessory cells, all of which are essential for fertilization. However, the mechanisms governing the formation of gametic versus accessory cell fate are unclear. A screen for regulators of egg cell fate led to the identification of the lach (lis) mutant, which produces supernumerary egg cells. In lis mutants, accessory cells adopt gametic fate, indicating LIS is involved in a mechanism preventing accessory cells from adopting gametic fate. LIS expression is temporally and spatially restricted to gametic cells, suggesting this mechanism is generated in gametic cells. LIS is homologous to yeast splicing factor PR4, indicating components of the splice apparatus participate in cell fate decisions.
A qualitative study was conducted in a rural highland Ethiopian community to explore the barriers to footwear use and its implications for neglected tropical disease (NTD) control. The PRECE-PRO model was used to assess social, behavioral, environmental, and educational, and ecological factors influencing shoe-wearing among children. Data was collected from 242 respondents through focus groups, semi-structured interviews, and case studies. The study found that shoe-wearing norms were changing, with going barefoot increasingly seen as shameful, and shoes associated with dignity and protection against injury and cold. However, practical and social barriers prevented the desire to wear shoes from being translated into practice. Limited financial resources meant people could not purchase more than one pair of shoes, ensuring longevity or afford quality shoes. As a result, shoes were reserved for special occasions and not provided for children until a certain age. Some barriers, such as fit and fear of labeling, were specific to certain diseases, while structural barriers like poverty, price, unsuitability, and low perception were relevant to multiple NTDs. Using health behavior adoption models, several barriers to shoe-wearing amenable to intervention were identified, which could benefit NTD prevention through shoe distribution.
Pseudorabies virus (PRV) Us protein plays a crucial role in targeting viral glycoproteins to axons of dissociated sympathetic neurons, with Us null mutants defective in anterograde transmission in vivo. The mechanism of Us-mediated axonal sorting of viral proteins is unclear. Glycoproteins B, C, D, and E are associated with lipid microdomains on infected cells and directed into axon in Us-dependent manner. This study investigated Us association with lipid rafts and its role in viral protein sorting. Non-polarized and polarized PC12 cells, a ratheochromocytoma line with sympathetic characteristics in NGF, were used. Us is enriched in detergent-resistant membranes (DRMs). Reducing Us lipid raft affinity inhibited antograde transmission from neurons to epithelial cells in vitro. Association of Us with lipid rafts is key for targeting structural proteins to axons and directional PR spread from pre-synaptic to postyn neurons in mammalian nervous system.
Saccharomyces cerevisiae exhibits phenotypic variation under constant conditions, a phenomenon known as nongenic heterogeneity, which has clinical implications in tumors and microbial infections. This study investigates the genetic basis of nenic heterogeneity in growth rate and stress tolerance in yeast. Researchers used genetic perturbations and high-throughput single-cell assays to show that heterogeneity in intracellular cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels through the conserved Ras/cAMP/protein A (PKA) pathway and target factors M2 and M4 underlies nenic heterogeneity. Lower cAMP levels correspond to slower growth, as shown by direct comparison of cAMP in subpopulations enriched for slower vs faster cells. A reporter of pathway activity correlates with growth in cells. Paralogs M2 and M4 differ in nenic heterogeneity roles, demonstrating slow growth and stress are not linked. M2 is required for heterogeneity growth, whereas M4 is for expression of T1, a subunit trehalose synth contributing to acute stress. Perturbing nenic heterogeneity by mutating pathway genes or culturing with cell-perme cAMP 8-bromoAMP or PK inhibitor H89 impacts acute stress survival. Perturbations increase cAMP reduce slower subpopulation and increase acute stress, whereas PK slows growth and decreases stress. Loss M2 reduces but not eliminates correlation between growth and stress, suggesting M2 role inenic heterogeneity with residual slow growth.
Researchers conducted a whole-genome sequencing analysis of the Chikungunya virus (CHV) during the 2013 outbreak in the Caribbean to understand its genetic diversity and evolution. CHV, an alphavirus of the Togaviridae family, causes severe fever in humans and rapidly spread from Asia to the Americas in 2013. The study focused on infected individuals in Guadeloupe and Martinique, central to the epidemic, using deep-sequencing and bioinformatics pipelines. The analysis revealed changes in consensus sequences and minority variants at different levels, with reduced diversity after cell passages. An infectious clone was constructed from the outbreak and a novel 3' untranslated region (UTR) structure was identified, increasing replication in insect cells. Intrahostasis analysis of the new CHV outbreak in the Caribbean found novel variants and 3'UTR, indicating rapid evolution in a short time in the naive population.
Researchers have identified a previously unannotated gene, UOR, as a functional regulator of the mTOR signaling pathway, which plays a crucial role in cell growth and is involved in multiple human diseases. In cultured hippocampal neurons and PC12 cells, reducing UOR function promotes neurite outgrowth. Conversely, UOR depletion activates mTOR signaling and enhances cell growth, while UOR overexpression suppresses colony formation in cancer cell lines. Studies in zebraf models show that UOR inhibits mTOR by stabilizing the m complex component DEPT, and UOR disruption results in higher m activity and aggravates HRAS G12-induced neoplas. In zraf. Furthermore, UOR depletion promotes tumor growth and m signaling in xenograft mouse models.
Researchers have created a comprehensive map of protein interactions in the procyclic stage of Trypanosoma brucei, a parasite responsible for African trypanosomiasis. Using biochemical fractionation, they identified 128 high-confidence complexes involving 716 proteins, including 635 with unknown functions. These complexes correlate with known pathways and co-expressed proteins across the T. brucei life cycle, providing insights into previously uncharacterized proteins. Novel proteins associated with RNA editing machinery were validated, including a candidate involved in post-transcriptional regulation of T. bruce. The study provides an unprecedented view of T. bruce protein complex and serves as a resource for further characterization of tryosomatid proteins.
Lymph nodes (LN) are a common sites of extrapulmonary Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection, with thoracic LNs frequently infected in humans. However, the dynamics of Mtb infection in LN and its effect on structure and function are understudied. This study analyzed thoracic LNs from M-infected cynolgus andhes macques using PET scans, bacterial burden, LN structure, and immune function. FDG avidity correlated with live bacteria presence in LNs at necropsy. Results show that LNs have different trajectories (increasing, decreasing PET activity over time) within same animal. Rhes macques are more susceptible to M infection than cynolg macques due to extensive LN pathology. Mtb grows to same level in cynolg andhes mac LNs, but cynolg mac control M at later post-infection whilehes do not. LNs are poor at killing M, even with treatment, compared to lung granulomas. Granulomas in L lack B-rich lymphoid structures, disrupt LN structure, push out T and B cells, introduce macrophages as M niches, destroy vasculature. Data indicate L are not only antigen presentation and immune activation sites, but also significant M persistence.
Researchers have identified 47 new species of microsporidia, a type of fungus that infects animals, and studied their interactions with the nematode Caenorhabdis elegans and other related nematodes. Microsporidia are intracellular pathogens that can infect virtually all animals, but are poorly understood. Caenorhabdis elegans has been used as a model to study microidia through its natural pathogen Nematida paris. However, the prevalence and diversity of microidia in Caenorhabdis and other nematodes in the wild were unclear. The study isolated and cultured 47 nematodes with microidian infections, finding Nematida to be the most common infecting Caenor in the wild. Six new species in the Nemat genus were described, and phylogenetic analysis identified two subclades distinct from Nemat, named Entersect and Ptospora. Unlike Nemat, these genera belong to the clade of microidia that includes human pathogens. All microidia are horizontally transmitted and infect intestinal cells, except Ptos that replicates in epidermis of Caenorhost. At the cellular level, infected spores of Entersect show apical distribution and exit via budding, unlike Nemat that exit via exocytosis. Host specificity varies among microidia, with some broad and others narrow. Some microidia infect Osche but not Os, and vice versa. Naus fails to induce Caenor transcription of genes induced by Nemat species, suggesting mechanisms to prevent host response.
Chemokine receptors, a subclass of G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs), play crucial roles in the human immune system and are involved in cancer metastasis as well as HIV infection. Studies have shown that homo- and heterodimers of chemokine receptors CXCR, CCR, and C2 modulate receptor function. Cholesterol also affects chemokine receptor activity. However, structural information on homo and heterodimers formed by chemine receptors and their interaction with cholesterol is limited. This study reports homodimer and heterod configurations of chemine receptors CXCR, C, and C at atomic detail from molecular simulations. Homodimer patterns were similar for closely related chemine receptors, yet differed between CCR and CX4. Cholesterol modulated homod interfaces in subtype-specific manner. Chemine heterod display distinct dimer patterns CX4/5 and CX/2. Associations between CX and C reveal increased cholesterol-sensitivity compared CX/ heterodimer patterns. This study provides comprehensive overview interaction between chemine and indicates heterod and interaction with environment diversifies function related GPC.
Systemic leishmaniasis, a parasitic disease caused by Leishmania parasites, typically presents with symptoms such as fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and wasting. However, a subclinical and atypical forms have been identified, characterized by the absence of one or two of these symptoms, replaced by lymphadenopathy and anemia. This study reports a new, unsuspected form of systemic leishiasis, referred to as "atypical". Patients with suspected immune deficiency were referred to an immunology laboratory for specialized tests, including microscopic examinations and cultures of biopsies on specialized media. 19.4% of 160 patients had normal laboratory profiles, but macrophages laden with Leish parasites. Findings revealed presence of atypical systemic leishias, presenting as masquerading condition with non-functional immune system. This predisposes patients to recurrent infections with various signs and symptoms. Findings indicate systemic leishias presents wider spectrum of symptoms than suspected and is more common than diagnosed. Among 31 patients, adults were included, showing systemic leishias not limited to pediatric group. Diagnosis of atypical systemic leishias recommended in patients with unexplained immunity and no obvious immunologic defect.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide analysis to investigate the relationship between disease-causing variants and their locations in paralogous proteins. They analyzed a collection of known disease-causing variants from the Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man (OMIM) and Human Genome Mutation Database (HGMD) to identify pairs of variants occurring at homologous positions within paralog proteins. The study found that locations of variants in paralog proteins are correlated, and if one member of a variant pair is disease-causing, its partner is likely to be disease-causing as well. This suggests that information about variant pairs can be used to identify potentially disease-causing variants, extend existing procedures for polymorphism prioritization, and provide candidates for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.
Researchers analyzed the transcriptome of Plasmodium falciparum, the parasite responsible for malaria, in patients with severe and uncomplicated malaria in Papua. The study aimed to understand how the parasite responds to or is selected by the host environment in severe malaria. They used RNA sequencing (RNAseq) to analyze gene expression in 44 parasite isolates from patients with severe and uncomplicated malaria. The results showed that parasite isolates associated with severe malaria had decreased glycolysis and activation of compensatory pathways, altered chromatin structure and transcriptional regulation through histone methylation, reduced expression of PfEMP1 surface antigens, and downregulated chaperone proteins. The study also identified novel associations between disease severity and Pf1 transcripts, domains, and sequence segments, and confirmed previous associations between expressed Pf1 sequences and disease.
Researchers used an adeno-associated virus (AAV) vector to deliver anti-SIV monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) intramuscularly to rhesus monkeys. The goal was to achieve long-term delivery of broadly-neutralizing antibodies for HIV-1 prevention. High levels of delivered mAb (up to 270 μg/ml) were achieved, but host responses to the delivered antibody were observed in 9 of 12 monkeys, limiting the concentration. This resulted in a wide range of delivered mAb concentrations (1-270 μg). After repeated intravenous challenge with the difficult-to-neutralize SIVmac, the AAV-Delivered IgG1Ab group showed protective effects despite no detectable neutralizing activity against the virus. Effects included lower peak viral load, lower viral set point, and delay in time to peak load from exposure. All were statistically significant. The monkey with highest delivered m resisted six SIVmac challenges, including a final 10 i.v. units. The study demonstrates continued promise for HIV-1 prevention. However, antibody responses need to be understood for this approach to be effective.
Researchers have challenged the long-held assumption that protein molecules respond linearly to thermal or structural perturbations, such as ligand binding or detachment, by analyzing the conformational motions of two motor proteins: myosin and kinesin KIF1. Using a coarse-grained elastic network approximation, they found that this linearity is deficient for ligand-induced conformation motions and even thermal fluctuations. The nonlinearity is pronounced in KIF1, where normal mode description fails to describe mechanochemical motions. The study suggests reevaluation of protein dynamics theory assumptions, as neither single mode nor superposition of modes approximates nonlinear dynamics accurately.
Researchers have investigated the interactions between clathrin-independent endocytic pathways and identified caveolae, specialized domains involved in endocytosis. They found that specific caveolar proteins, cavin-1 and cavin-3, but not cavin-2 or cavin-4, act as negative regulators of the clathrin-independent/GPI-AP enriched endosomal (CL/GEE) endytic pathway. This regulation occurs independently of caveola formation. Caveolin-1 and cavin-3 inhibit the CL/GEE pathway through overexpression. Electron microscopy analysis revealed reduced CL/GEE carrier formation upon caveolar expression. Conversely, the CLEE pathway is upregulated in cells lacking cavin-1/cavin-1 or reduced cavin-3. Caveolin inhibition can be mimicked by the caveolin scaffolding domain, associated with perturbed lipid diffusion, as shown by fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP) studies. Without caveins and caveae, cavin-1 is endocytosed through the CLEE pathway, but loses polarization and sorting, affecting membrane and endytic dynamics in migrating cells and muscle tissue. Non-caveolar cavin-1 modulates the activity of the CLEE regulator, Cdc42. This study reveals regulation of non-cave clrin endocyt by caveolar proteins, illustrating crosstalk between pathways.
Two-component signaling systems are widespread in bacteria and archaea, playing crucial roles in sensing and responding to environmental stimuli. These systems typically employ a histidine kinase that phosphorylates a conserved aspartate (Asp) residue on a Receiver (REC) domain. However, some REC domains lack this residue, raising questions about the number of divergent REC domains, their functions, and regulation in the absence of the conserved aspart. This study compiled REC domains missing the phosphorylatable aspartate, renaming them Aspart-Less (AL) domains. Results show AL domains are common and enriched with rare effector outputs. Analysis of informatics and AL structures, combined with biochemical and genetic data on AL archetype Rit from Streptococcus pneumoniae, suggest AL reorganized active sites for constitutive regulation or accommodate signals other than phosphorylation, while retaining canonical post-phosphorylation mechanisms and dimer interface. This defines AL as atypical REC subclass, providing insights into activation mechanisms between AL and REC domains.
Researchers have developed a new type of oncolytic herpes simplex virus (HSV) that is fully virulent and specifically targets cancer cells with the human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) expression. Unlike previous oncolytic HSVs, this virus does not have deletions or mutations that make it less effective against the host immune response. Instead, it selectively replicates in cancer cells with HER2 expression while sparing other cells in the tumor. The study investigated the efficacy of this new virus in immunocompetent mice with HER2-positive lung cancer. Both the unarmed and IL-12-armed versions of the virus inhibited the growth of the primary tumor, with the IL-12-armed version being more effective. All mice that survived the primary tumor treatment were protected from growth of contralateral tumors. Long-term survivors were also protected from a second contral tumor, indicating an abscopal therapeutic effect. Analysis of the response showed that the IL-12-armed virus unleashed an immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment, inducing immunomulatory cytokines and promoting Th1 polarization. Tumor-infiltrating cells, such as CD4+ and CD335, were increased in all responders, while CD8, Foxp, CD, and CD11 were increased in IL-12-treated mice. The response included break of tolerance to both HER2 and wt cells, indicating a systemic immunotherapeutic response.
Researchers investigated the susceptibility of CD4 T cells induced by different HIV vaccines to HIV infection, following concerns raised by excess infections in Ad5-based vaccine trials. They found that Ad5-specific CD4 cells were susceptible to HIV, but ALV-specific CD4 cells from the RV144 trial were less susceptible to R5 and X4 HIV in vitro. Lower susceptibility was associated with reduced CCR5 and CXCR4 expression on ALV-specific CD4 cells. Phenotypic analysis showed ALV-specific CD4 cells had a Th1 phenotype with high IFN-γ and CCL4, but low IL-17. ALV and Ad vectors induced distinct CD8 and CD4 responses, with ALV inducing CD8 and Ad CD4 proliferation. Depletion of ALV CD8 cells increased HIV infection of AL-specific CD4 cells, suggesting a protective role of ALV CD8 cells. The study highlights distinct susceptibility of CD4 cells by different vectors and the importance of evaluating anti-vector responses in HIV vaccination.
X-chromosome inactivation, the process of silencing one X chromosome in female somatic cells, is a universal among therian mammals. However, the choice of which X to silence varies among species. X-inactivation strategies range from paternal X-inherited inactivation (PX), rendering females haploid for maternal alleles, to random X-inactivation (RX), equalizing expression of maternal and paternal alleles in each tissue. A theoretical population genetic analysis of X-inactivation evolution was conducted, considering conditions of dominance, linkage, recombination, and sex-differential selection. Results indicate a critical interaction between allelic dominance and sexifferential can select a broad range of X-in strategies, including unequal inactivation between maternal and paternal X. RX is favored over PX as long alleles deleterious to females are recessive, and criteria for RX evolution is more restrictive when variation is sexually antagonistic. Evolution from PX to RX increases female fitness at expense of male. A framework for predicting chromosome-wide expression of X-linked genes is provided, leading to predictions for future studies of allele-specific expression variation.
Researchers investigated the antiviral potential of the host protein ZAP against three flaviviruses, specifically Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), dengue virus (DENV), and Zika virus (ZIK). They found that overexpression of ZAP blocked JEV infection, but not DENV or ZIK, and depletion of endogenous Z enhanced JEV replication. Z hampered JEV translation and targeted viral RNA for 3-5 exosome-mediated degradation. The zincinger motifs of Z were essential for RNA targeting and anti-JEV activity. The 3-UTR, particularly the region with dumbbell structures and high content of dinucleotide, was mapped to bind Z and confer sensitivity to Z.
Rift Valley fever virus (RVV) is a significant human and animal pathogen causing severe disease, including hemorrhagic encephalitis. The virus is endemic in parts of Africa and the Arabian Peninsula, but there is concern regarding its introduction into non-endemic regions and potential devastating effects on livestock and human populations. This study investigated the host response to wild-type and vaccine strains of RVV and its correlation with pathogenesis. C57/6 mice were infected with live-attenuated MP12 or wild-type Z501. Animals with MP12 survived productive infection with minimal disease and cytokine response. In contrast, Z501 infection was lethal, causing lymphocyte and platelet depletion and strong cytokine response correlating with high virus titers and tissue pathology. Lymphopenia and platelet depletion indicated disease onset, with lymphocyte recovery correlating G-CS production. RVV is hepatotropic, with significant clinical and histological data supporting findings. However, a pro-inflammatory response in the liver was not apparent, instead a chemokine response indicating neutrophil infiltration, supported by histological data. Brains of Z501 infected mice showed chemokine and pro-inflammatory response with little pathology meningoencephitis. Data suggest RVV pathogenesis in mice is associated with liver loss due to necrosis and hepatitis, yet long-term disease is neurologic, supported by human and BAL/c model.
Chemotherapy resistance in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) poses a significant challenge to improving patient survival rates. Researchers investigated the mechanisms of taxane chemoresistance in TNBC and found that C motif chemokine ligand 20 (C20) was significantly elevated in patients with non-pathologic response to taxane-containing chemotherapy. C20 promoted self-renewal and maintenance of breast cancer stem cells (BCS) through protein kinase Cζ (PKζ) or 38 mitogen-activated protein (MAP)-mediated activation of 65 factor B (NF-κ) pathway, increasing taxane resistance of BC. Additionally, C20-promoted NFκ activation ATP-binding subfamily member 1 (ABCB1)/multidrug 1 (DR) expression, leading to extracellular efflux of taxane. Chemotherapy-induced C20 mediated chemoresistance via upregulation of AB1. Furthermore, NF-κ activation C20 increased, forming a positive loop between NFκ and C pathways, sustaining chemores in cancer cells. The study suggests C20 as a predictive marker for taxane response and blockade of C or its pathway may reverse tax resistance in breast cancer.
Toxoplas gondii, an obligate intracellular parasite, infects nucleated cells in warm-blooded animals by transporting "GRA" proteins from dense granules into host cells. GRA proteins manipulate host functions, such as cell cycle and p38 MAP kinase. Some GRAs, like GRA16 and GRA24, are secreted into the parasitophorous vacuole (PV) and transported across the PV membrane (PVM) into the host, but the process is not understood. TMY1, cleaved by T5, localizes to PVM and is essential for GRA transport into host. To identify additional effectors, Toxopla mutants were screened for ability to export GRA16 and GRA24 to host. Novel MY2 and MY3 play role in GRA transport into host. MY2 and MY3 are secreted into PV and co-localize with PVM. Consistent with transmembrane domains, all are membrane-associated, MY3 but MY2 stably with MY1, N-terminal and C-terminal disulfide. Fusing intrinsically disordered effectors to structured DH domain blocks transport, consistent translo model effector.
Human papillomavirus (PV) and bovine papillomavirus (BPV-1) E2 proteins bind to the origin recognition complex (ORC) component ORC2, but OR2 is not detected at the viral origin of replication. Depletion of OR2 enhances PV replication in a transient replication model in keratinocytes, maintaining episomal viral genomes, while having no effect on copy number in a cell line with integrated HPV genomes. Occupancy of E1 and E at the viral origin increases following OR2 silencing. This suggests OR2 is not necessary for activation of the PV origin by E and E, but suppresses E replicative function. Over-expression of HPV2 decreases OR2 occupation at known mammalian origins of replication, indicating E restricts pre-OR assembly that could compete for host replication necessary for viral amplification. The OR2 complex with E restricts viral replication in the maintenance phase of the viral program and elevated E levels occur during differentiation amplification subvert OR loading and DNA synthesis at cellular origins.
A study was conducted to investigate the presence of Brucella in bovine milk in the urban and periurban area of Dush, Tajikistan. Bruc DNA was detected in 10.3% of 564 milk samples using IS-based real-time PCR. This is concerning due to the common consumption of unpasteurified dairy products in the region. Bruc DNA was found in the milk of seropositive cows, but also in 8.3% of seronegative cows. Sequence analysis of the rB gene revealed one cow infected with B. abortus and another likely infected with B. melensis. Discrepancies between serology and real-time PCR highlight the need for complementary diagnostic strategies to detect false negatives in Bruc surveillance and control. Vaccination of cattle with S and small ruminants with Rev may be necessary to control Bruc infections, but further research on Bruc isolation is needed to understand circulating species in the region.
Researchers investigated the role of histone H3 lysine methylation in maintaining chromosome stability in the pathogenic fungus Zoseptoria trici, which has eight accessory chromosomes that are unstable during meiosis and mitosis and transcriptionally repressed. They deleted the genes encoding methyltransferases responsible for H3me9 and H27, Kmt1 and K6, respectively, and generated a double mutant. Experimental and genomic analyses were used to determine the impact of these deletions on chromosome and genome stability in vitro and in planta. Whole genome sequencing, ChIP-seq, and RNA-seq were used to compare changes in genome and chromatin structure and differences in gene expression between mutant and wild-type strains. In H9-deficient strains, chromatin reorganization was observed, with H27me mostly localized to regions enriched in H9 in wild-type. Genome rearrangements and new chromosome formation were found in the absence of H9, accompanied by activation of transposable elements. In contrast, loss of H27 increased stability of accessory chromosomes under normal conditions in vitro, without large changes in gene activity. H9 is crucial for maintaining genome stability by preventing H27 in constitutive heterochromatin. In this system, H27 reduces overall stability of accessory, creating a metastable state for quasi-essential genome regions.
Evaluation of Cost-Effective Strategies for Rabies Post-Exposure Vaccination in Low-Income Countries

Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is a crucial in preventing the onset of rabies in individuals exposed to the virus. However, life-saving rabies vaccines and biologicals are often inaccessible and unaffordable, particularly to the poorest sectors of society who bear the largest burden of rabies. To address this issue, we analyzed post-exposure vaccination regimens and their costs and benefits to victims and healthcare providers. Results show PEP is an extremely cost-effective intervention, with a cost of less than $60 per death averted. Switching from intramuscular (IM) to intradermal (ID) administration of P regimens resulted in significant savings in vaccine volume required to treat patients, mitigating shortages and reducing costs. We propose financing mechanisms to make P more accessible, subsidize costs for those in need, and support existing rabies prevention programs. A universal switch to ID delivery would improve affordability and accessibility of P, reducing human rabies deaths and costs for healthcare providers.
Toxoplas, an obligate intracellular parasite, replicates within mammalian cells in a parasitophorous vacuole (PV) that does not fuse with host organelles. One mechanism for nutrient acquisition is attraction of host organelles to PV. Toxoplas exploits host lipid droplets (LD), ubiquitous fat organelles, for nutrient acquisition. Tooplas replication is reduced in cells depleted of LD or impaired lipolysis or fatty acidolysis. In infected cells, LD number and host-associated genes (ADRP, DG2) increase until parasite replication onset. PV are surrounded by LD. Tooplas accesses LD lipids, incorporating them into membranes and LD. Exogenous oleic acid stimulates LDogenesis, resulting in large LD accumulation inside parasite. To access LD lipids, Toop intercepts and internalizes LD within PV, some associated with Rab7, wrapped by intravacolar network (IV) membranes. Mutants impaired IV display diminished lipid uptake from LD. Parasites lacking IV-localized phospholipase2 are less proficient in salvaging lipids from LD PV. IV contributes to LD processing and lipid release. Lipid gavage reveals endocytic structures containing lipid material from PV. This study highlights Tooplas reliance on LD for intracellular development and lipid scavenging from LD.
Researchers investigated a library of flavonoid derivatives to identify inhibitors of Fasciola hepatica cysteine proteases, specifically Fh3 and Fh1. Chalcones with phenyl and naphthyl groups emerged as potent inhibitors, interacting with two putative binding sites within the active site of the enzymes. One compound, C34, bound to juvenile Fh3 with an IC50 of 5.6 μM. C34 is a slow-reversible inhibitor that interacts with the Cys catalytic dyad and S2 and S3 residues, determinants of substrate specificity for this cystine protease family. In vitro, C34 induced a reduction in the ability to migrate through the gut and loss of motility, leading to death within a week, without cytotoxicity to bovine cells. This is the first report of non-peptide inhibitors of Fasciola hepatica catheps in vitro. Chalcones were identified as novel inhibitors of the main catheins secreted by juvenile and adult liver flukes. Compound C34 is highly active against the juvenile, reducing larval ability to penetrate the gut and decreasing viability in vitro. These findings open avenues for novel agents to control fluke infection and helminthic diseases.
In the visual system, information about fast and slow changes in light intensity are transmitted through distinct neural pathways. Researchers used in vivo imaging to investigate how bipolar cells convey these signals to the retina. They found that the volume of the synaptic terminal is an intrinsic property that contributes to temporal filtering. Bipolar cells transmit signals through terminals of varying sizes, with smaller terminals generating faster and larger calcium transients to trigger vesicle release with higher gain, followed by more adaptation. Smaller terminals transmit higher frequencies more effectively. Modeling calcium dynamics of vesicle release indicated that variations in presynaptic compartments directly contribute to differences in response. These results show how neurons can transmit different temporal components of the signal through terminals with varying geometries and adaptation properties.
Researchers have developed a novel probabilistic method for detecting synapses from fluorescence microscopy (FM) images, which complements electron microscopy (EM) in studying the brain's synaptic networks. FM offers high-speed and low-cost molecular discrimination, but struggles with distinguishing synaptic and non-synaptic signals. In contrast, EM provides reliable synapse identification but limited molecular discrimination and is slow and costly. To address this, the researchers used correlative array tomography (CAT), combining FM and EM images of individual synapses. They proposed an unsupervised probabilistic method for synapse detection from multiplex FM (mux) data, evaluated against EM-annotated data and cortical syn distributions. The probabilistic synapse detector accepts morphological models, delivering a volumetric probability map of synapse presence. Using EM-annotated CAT data as ground truth, the algorithm detected synapses from FM data as accurately as human annotators, reproducing known cortical syn features. This approach enables data-driven discovery of new synapse types and density. The probabilistic detector is also applicable to standard and super-resolution FM, where EM-validation is impractical.
Zinc is an essential trace element crucial for the proper functioning of approximately 3,000 cellular proteins, involved in various physiological processes such as nucleic acid metabolism, gene regulation, signal transduction, cell division, immune and nervous functions, and wound healing. Impairment of zinc homeostasis disrupts cellular functions, leading to various pathologies. Mammalian zinc transport occurs via two transporter families, ZnT and ZIP. However, the mechanism of ZnT, responsible for vesicular zinc accumulation and secretion during lactation, is unknown. This study investigated the mechanism of ZnT and demonstrated computationally and experimentally that ZnT is a proton-coupled zinc antiporter. Bafilomycin A, a vacuolar ATPase inhibitor, abolished ZnT-dependent transport into intracellular vesicles. Lyso Red and Ly-pfluorin showed that ZnT overexpression in intracellular vesicles and exogenous zinc caused vesicular alkalization, due to proton-zinc antiport, reversed by TP, a specific chelator. Computational calculations propose Zn functions as an antiporter with 2+/Zn+ stoichiometry, driven by proton force, concentrating zinc in vesicles at expense of cytoplasmic proton extrusion.
14-3 Proteins Regulate Exonuclease 1-Dependent Processing of Stalled Replication Forks

Replication fork integrity is crucial for maintaining genome stability, and is monitored by checkpoint-mediated phosphorylation events. 14-3 proteins, which bind to phosphorylated proteins, have been shown to play a role in DNA replication stress. Exonuclease 1 (Exo) processes stalled forks in checkpoint-defective yeast cells. This study identifies 14-3 proteins as in vivo partners of Exo, in yeast and mammalian cells. Yeast 3-3-deficient cells fail to induce Mec1-dependent Exo hyperphosphorylation and accumulate Exo-dependent ssDNA gaps at forks, revealed by electron microscopy. This leads to persistent checkpoint activation and recovery defects. DNA bi-dimensional electrophoresis shows 3 proteins promote fork progression under limiting nucleotide concentrations. This suggests 3 proteins assist controlling phosphorylation of Exo and unknown targets, promoting fork stability and restart in response to replication stress.
Researchers investigated the role of plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDC) in human immunodeficiency type 1 (HIV-1) infection and pathogenesis using a humanized mouse model. HIV-1 infection led to persistent infection and immunopathogenesis, including type I interferon (IFN) induction, immune activation, and depletion of leukocytes, including CD4 T cells. A monoclonal antibody was developed to deplete pDC in lymphoid organs of humanized mice. When pDC were depleted prior to HIV-1, induction of IF and interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs) were abolished during acute HIV-1 infection with either highly pathogenic CCR5/CX4-tropic or standard C5ropic HIV-1 isolate. Consistent with antiviral role of IF, HIV-1 replication was upregulated in p-depleted mice. Cell death by highly pathogenic HIV-1 was reduced in p-de mice. During chronic HIV-1, depletion p also reduced induction of IF and IS, associated with elevated HIV replication. Surprisingly, HIV depletion of human cells in lymphoid, not blood, was reduced despite increased replication. Increased in lymphoid was associated with reduced HIV-induced death human leukocytes, including CD T cells. p play opposing roles in suppressing HIV replication and promoting immunogenesis. Findings suggest p-depletion and IF blockade provide novel strategies for treating HIV non-responsive patients with persistent activation despite antiretrov treatment.
Sulforaphane (SF) Inhibits HIV Infection in Macrophages through Nrf2

Researchers have investigated the impact of Sulforane (SF) on HIV infection in macrophages, a type of immune cell that plays a crucial role in the body's defense against pathogens. SF, a compound found in cruciferous vegetables, has been shown to mobilize nuclear erythroid-related factor 2 (Nrf2) to reprogram cellular gene expression. This study found that SF blocks HIV infection in primary macrophages, but not in primary T cells. SF also inhibits HIV infection in differentiated promonocytic cell lines, but not in other cell lines. RNA-mediated depletion of Nrf increased HIV infectivity in macrophages and reduced the anti-viral effects of SF treatment. This suggests that SF's anti-viral activity is mediated through Nrf mobilized by SF. SF treatment blocks HIV infection after entry, but before formation of 2-L circles, similar to type interferon-induced antiiral proteins SAM1 and MX. However, SAM and MX were not upregulated. This study demonstrates that Nrf can potently block HIV infection, highlighting a novel mechanism for inhibition.
A cross-sectional study was conducted in rural western Kenya to investigate geohelth infections among pregnant women. The study found that 76.2% of 390 participants who provided a stool sample were infected with at least one geelth species, with Ascaris lumicoid (52.3%), hookworm (39.5%), and Trichuris trichi (29%) being the most common. Infection with at least geel species was associated with use of unprotected water source (adjusted odds ratio 1.8, 95% CI 1.1-3) and lack of treated drinking water (adjusted ratio 1.8, 95 CI 1.1-3). Geelth infections were not associated with clinical symptoms or body mass index. Hookworm infection was associated with lower upper arm circumference (adjusted decrease 0.7 cm, 95 CI 0.3-1). Hookworm infection with egg count ≥100/gram was associated with lower hemoglobin (adjusted decrease 1.5 g/dl, 95 0.3-2.7). Among gravid 2 and 3 women, Ascaris lumicoid was less likely to have malaria (OR 0.4, 95 CI 0.2-0.8) compared to without Asis lumic.
Mycolone, a macrolide produced by the pathogen Mycobacterium ulcerans, has been shown to possess cytotoxic, analgesic, and immunomodulatory properties. This study investigated its effects on the inflammatory responses of nervous cell subsets involved in pain perception and transmission, as well as neuroinflammation associated with chronic pain. Sensory neurons, Schwann cells, and microglia were isolated from mice for ex vivo assessment of mycolone cytotoxicity and immunomod activity. Prolonged (>48h) exposure to myone induced cell death at concentrations >10ng/ml, while nanolar concentrations suppressed pro-inflammatory mediator production without affecting viability. Notably, myone prevented pro-inflammatory polarization of microglia, which contribute to neuroflammation. In a rat model of neuropathic pain induced by sciatic nerve constriction, myone was injected daily in the spinal canal for 3 days. This treatment failed to prevent injury-induced neuroflamm but decreased local inflammatory cytokine production without cytotoxicity. The study demonstrates myone suppresses inflammatory responses of sensory neurons, Schw cells, and microia without affecting viability.
A study was conducted to investigate the association between candidate gene polymorphisms and the clinical outcomes of African trypanosomiasis (AT) in populations from Guinea. The disease, caused by Trypanosoma brucei gambense, has varying outcomes in humans in West Africa, ranging from acute to chronic forms and spontaneous regulation of parasitemia at low levels. Samples from 425 individuals, including 232 AT cases, 79 long-term seropositive but parasitology negative, and 114 controls, were analyzed. 28 SNPs in eight genes passed quality control and used for association analysis. Results showed that IL6 rs1819 allele was associated with lower risk of progressing from latent to active disease (p=0.001, OR=0.39, CI[0.24-0.63], BF=0.003). MIF36071 allele seemed associated with increased risk (p=0.023, OR=1.65, CI[1.07-2.53], BF=0.669) but not significant after Bonferr correction. MIF459 allele associated latent infections (p=0.007, OR=1.86, CI[1.18-2.95], BF=0.215). AP1G2 allele DEL associated higher risk (p=0.001, OR=2.70, CI[1.49-4.91], BF=0.01) and AP1 polymorphism lower risk (p=0.000, OR=0.45 CI[0.29-0.7], BF=0.012). No associations found with other genes. The study shows host genes modulate Tryosoma bruce gambense infection in infected individuals from Guinea, with IL6 rs1819 associated lower risk progressing to AT.
Researchers conducted whole-genome sequencing on 38 individuals from the South Asian population in Singapore, descendants of Dravid-language-speaking states in India, as part of the Singapore Sequencing Indian Project (SSIP). The genetic diversity of these samples was compared to the Sequencing Malay Project and Phase 1 of the 1,000 Genomes Project (KGP) populations. Results showed higher intra-population genetic diversity and heterozygous-to-homozygous ratio in SSIP compared to other Asian populations. The genetic makeup of SSIP samples was closely related to South Indians, but distinct from Europeans in autosomal SNPs. Eight samples belonged to mitochondrial haplogroups predominantly found in Europeans and had higher European admixture than others. Analysis of relatedness to archaic homins (Denisovan, Neanderthal) showed higher ancient admixture in East populations than SSIP.
Researchers investigated the molecular basis of aminoglycoside susceptibility in Burkholderia pseudallei isolates from Thailand, specifically strains 708, 218a, and 379a. These strains are intrinsically resistant to aminoglycos and macrolides due to the expression of the AmrAB-OA efflux pump. Quantitative PCR revealed the absence of amr transcripts in 708 and reduced levels in 218 and 379. Increasing gentamicin concentrations led to the emergence of resistant mutants in 218 and 379, but not 708. Transcript analysis showed resistance in 218 and 379 was due to upregulation of amr-opA expression by unknown mechanisms. PCR revealed the amr-opA operon was missing in 708, associated with a 70 kb deletion. Rescue of the amr-opB region from a 708 fosmid library showed a 131-141 kb deletion in 708 compared to K43 and 10. This deletion removed amr-op, malleactin, and cobal synthesis genes, anaerobic arginine deiminase, type 1 fimbria, and secreted chitinase. Whole genome sequencing confirmed absence of these genes in 708. Despite missing virulence genes, 708 was virulent in murine model. Strain 708 may be a candidate for genetic manipulation with antibiotic selection and validation of Δamr-opA mutants.
Researchers investigated the early differentiation of naive CD4 T helper (Th) cells into Th1 and Th2 states by analyzing single-cell transcriptomics and immunofluorescence data. Contrary to the expectation of mutually exclusive expression of antagonistic transcription factors, they found co-expression of these factors in individual cells at high levels distinct from basal levels during priming. Cytokines were expressed in a small subpopulation of cells, independent of transcription factor expression in these cells. Cell-to-cell variation in cytokine expression during early T cell differentiation was larger than in fully differentiated state. Inhibition of cytok signaling led to mutual exclusion of antagonistic transcription factors, revealing an intracellular network overruled by extracellular signals. This suggests CD4 T cells acquire a mixed Th1/2 state early, instructed by extracellular cytokines. The interplay between extracellular and intracellular components in Th2 differentiation may be a strategy to buffer cytokine expression.
C. elegans PAQR-2, a homologous to mammalian insulin-sensitizing adiponectin receptors, plays a crucial role in adaptation to 15°C, a low temperature for the organism. Screening for PAQR-2 suppressors revealed mutations in genes involved in phosphatidylcholine synthesis (cep-1, cpt-1, and s-1) and fatty acid metabolism (ech-7, hac-1, m-15, n-49 and sb-1). The study demonstrates that PAQR-2, phosphatidcholines, and Δ9-desaturases form a cold adaptation pathway regulating increase in unsaturated fatty acids to maintain membrane fluidity at low temperatures. This is supported by observations that PA-2 suppressors normalize saturated fatty acid levels, and low detergent concentrations that increase fluidity rescue PA-2 mutant.
Researchers have studied the structure of Herpes Simplex Type-1 (HSV-1) virus, a common human pathogen, to better understand how its genome is packaged and released from the virus capsid. Although much remains unknown about this process, similar mechanisms are well understood in bacteriophages, which share a common origin with Herpesviruses. Bacterophages release their genome through a portal and a tail apparatus at the vertex. Using electron cryo-microscopy, researchers found a new feature at the HSV-1 vertex, connecting the capsid to the viral membrane through the tegument layer. This structure suggests it plays a role in releasing the genome into the nucleus and maintaining virion architecture.
Researchers investigated the effects of Schistosoma mansoni soluble egg antigen (SEA) and recombinant Omega-1 (r-1) on HIV-1 infection in vitro. They found that SEA, specifically kappa-5, potently binds to DC-SIGN, blocking DC-S mediated HIV-1 transfection. DCs exposed to SEA under Th2 conditions induced T-cells that were less susceptible to HIV-1 R5 infection compared to unexposed DCs, while HIV-4 infection was unaffected. This was not observed in DCs exposed under Th1 or Th/Th2 conditions. T-cells induced by SEA-exposed DCs showed reduced IFN-γ and M-β production. The infection profile of T-cells with HIV-1 R was not associated with downmodulation of CCR5 surface expression. Recombinant r-1 demonstrated similar functions to natural-1, inducing T-cells less susceptible to HIV-5 infection, but not X virus. This was associated with reduced IF-γ and M-β, and CCR expression. The study suggests that parasite antigens, specifically r-1, modulate HIV-1 infectivity, potentially influencing disease course in coinfected individuals.
Researchers have investigated the phenomenon of neural activity-induced shrinkage of the extracellular space (ECS) between neurons and astrocytes in grey and white matter. They found that neuronal stimulation causes a 30% shrinkage of the ECS under experimental conditions. A dynamic model was developed to account for this phenomenon in wild-type and gene knockout individuals. The model suggests that neuronal release of potassium and uptake of sodium during stimulation, astrocyte uptake of potassium, sodium, and chloride, and action of the Na+/K+ pump, and osmotically driven water transport through the astrocyte membrane are sufficient for ECS shrinkage. However, considering ECS and astrote ion concentrations with neuronal stimulation, the actions of Na+/Cl (NK1) and NaH (NBC) cotransporters are critical for achieving observed ECS shrinkage levels. The model is sufficiently detailed and constrained to guide future experiments and pave the way for comprehensive astroglia-neuron models in normal and pathophysiological situations.
Arabidopsis thalian genomes contain significant amounts of transposons and repetitive DNA elements, which, if transcribed, can be detrimental to the organism. The expression of these elements is suppressed by the establishment of repressive chromatin modifications. In Arabidopsis thalian, they are silenced by the siRNA-mediated transcriptional gene silencing pathway, where non-coding RNAs (ncRNAs) produced by RNA Polymerase V (Pol V) guide ARGONA4 (AGO) to chromatin and attract enzymes that establish repressive chrom modifications. It is unknown how chrom modifying enzymes are recruited to chromatin. Researchers used chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) to show that SPTLTF1, a silencing factor and homolog of SPT elongation factors, binds chromatin at loci subject to transcription silencing. SPTLTF binding occurs downstream of Polymer V but independently of the presence of 24-nt siRNA. SPTLTF and AGO are recruited to chrom in parallel and independently of each other. Using methylation restriction enzymes, binding of AGO and SPTLTF is required for DNA methylation and repressive histone modifications of loci.
Researchers have investigated the role of the Rpo regulon in the tick-to-mamm transmission phase of Borrelia burgdorferi, the causative agent of Lyme disease. The Rpo-dependent genes have been extensively studied in the mammalian host, but their contribution to the tick phase of the Borrelia burgorferi life cycle has not been examined. This study demonstrates that Rpo-dependent gene expression is necessary for spirochete transmission by nymphs. In the absence of Rpo, spirochetes are confined to the midgut lumen and transform into an unusual morphotype, round bodies during the later stages of the blood meal. Round body formation is reversible and appears to be partly due to reduced Coenzyme disulf reductase levels, which provides NAD for glycolysis. Data suggest spirochet default to an Rpo-independent program for round formation when transmission energetics are unfavorable.
Researchers investigated the relationship between gibberellin (GA) and jasmonate (JA) in controlling stamen development in Arabidopsis. They found that GA-dependent stamen-enrich genes, MYB21, MY24, and MY57, are involved in stamen filament growth. Loss-of-function of DELLA and RGL2 restored the expression of these MY genes and stamen growth in GA-deficient plants. The myb21my24my57 triple mutant exhibited a short stamen phenotype and male sterility. Genetic analysis showed that GA suppresses DEL to mobilize the expression of JA biosynthesis gene DAD, consistent with lower JA content in GA-deficient flower buds. The study established a hierarchical relationship between GA and JA, where GA promotes JA biosynthesis to control MY21, MY24, and MY57 expression, a prerequisite for normal stamen development in Arabidopsis.
Researchers investigated the role of hypoxia inducible factor-1 (HIF-1) in modulating lifespan extension due to dietary restriction (DR) in Caenorhabditis elegans. They found that H-1 deficiency resulted in extended lifespan, similar to inhibition of the RSK-1/S6 kinase, a component of the target of rapamycin (TOR) pathway. A modified DR method using varying bacterial concentrations on agar plates showed that H-1 modulated longevity in a nutrient-dependent manner. H- loss-of-function mutants extended lifespan under rich conditions but failed to show extension under DR. Conversely, a mutation in egl-9, increasing H- activity, diminished lifespan under DR. This effect was rescued by tissue-specific expression ofegl-9 in neurons and muscles. Increased lifespan by H- was dependent on the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress regulator inositol-requiring-1 (I-1) and associated with lower ER stress levels.
Human epidermal keratinocytes, a type of skin cell, can transition between two states: differentiation and migration. Researchers investigated how chromatin, the complex of DNA and proteins, changes during these transitions. They found that when keratinocytes differentiate or migrate, new enhancers and super-enhancers form, unique to each state. Enhancers are linked to genes that confer specific functions to each state. These enhancers are enriched with genetic variants associated with skin diseases. GR3, a transcription factor, promotes differentiation and migration, binds to enhancers in differentiating keratinocytes, but to promoters with REST during migration, repressing migration inhibitors. Epidermal differentiation factors, including GR3, are in enhancers and bind to regulate them. GR3 represses formation of progenitor and non-keratin superenhancers in differentiating keratinocytes. Chromatin GR3 binding and enhancers regulate irreversible commitment to differentiation and reversible migration of keratinocytes.
Endogenous retroviruses (ERVs) are remnants of ancient retroviral infections that are transmitted vertically from generation to generation in the host genome. Research suggests that some ERVs may be used by the host as factors to block the infection of pathogenic retroviruses, with some ERs efficiently interfering with the replication of exogenous retroviruses. However, evidence that these mechanisms have influenced the coevolution of endogenous and exogenous retroviruses and their hosts has been difficult to obtain. Sheep are an interesting model to study retrovirus coevolution due to the coexistence in this species of exogenous (horizontally transmitted) oncogenic retroviruses, Jaags sheep retrovirus and enzootic tumor virus with related and biologically active endogenous retrovir (enSRVs). This study isolated and characterized the evolutionary and molecular virology of 27 enSRV proviruses. SRVs have been in the host genome for 5-7 million years. Two SR proviruses, SR1 and SR20, which entered the genome within 3 million before and during speciation of genus Ovis, acquired distinct G polyprotein resulting in dominant phenotype block replication of exogenousviruses. Both dominant proviruses fixed in genome before or sheep domestication 9,000 ago. A provirus escaping dominant SR has emerged recently, likely within 200. This study indicates distinct events during evolution antagonism between endogenous exogenous retrovir.
Researchers evaluated the effectiveness of real-time PCR (polymerase chain reaction) for diagnosing schistosomiasis, a parasitic disease caused by Schistosoma mansoni and Schistosoma haematobium. Current diagnosis relies on microscopic examination of stool or urine samples and serological assays, but these methods have low sensitivity. The study tested two in-house real-time PCRs targeting S. mansoni and S. haematobium in urine, stool, biopsy, and serum samples from 412 patients suspected of having schistosiasis before antiparasitic treatment. Results were compared to microscopic examination and serological assays (enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, indirect hemagglutination, and Western blot). Real-time PCRs increased sensitivity from 4.5% to 10.5% and 33.7 to 48.8% for S. haobium and S. mansoni in urine and stool, respectively. Serum PCR sensitivity was 72.7 and 94.1% in patients with positive microscopy. Specificity was 98.9%. After treatment, PCR positivity declined from 93.8% at 30 to 8.3% at 360 days, while antibodies remained positive 1 year. Real-time PCRs outperformed microscopy in stool and urine and could be used with Western blot-based serology, the gold standard for diagnosis. When serology is positive and microscopy negative, PCRs provide information for further exploration. DNA and antibodies are limited for early monitoring, but PCR useful 1 year post-treatment to confirm cure.
Researchers have applied machine learning techniques to estimate the conformational energies of large, structurally complex molecules, such as the natural product Archazolid, a potent inhibitor of vacuolar-type ATPase from the myxobacterium Archium gephy. This approach leverages information from previous calculations via Gaussian process regression to predict energies of new conformations. Predictive variance is used to determine if a conformation is within the interpolation region, allowing a balance between accuracy and computational speed. Results show mean absolute errors of less than 1 kcal/mol for energies of relaxed conformations at the density functional theory level (DFT/BP-disp/2-TZVP). This demonstrates the feasibility of machine learning models for structurally complex, pharmaceutically relevant compounds, enabling significant speed-ups in simulations of larger structures.
Researchers have developed a non-invasive method to detect antibodies against Ebola virus (EBOV) in wild ape feces, enabling the identification of gorillas with antibodies to EBO at a prevalence rate of 10%. This suggests that EBO exposure or infection is not uniformly lethal in this species. Evidence of antibodies was also found in gorillas previously thought to be unexposed to EBO, protected by geographical barriers of transmission. The new approach will aid in protecting apes from future EBO infections by detecting increased incidence of exposure, identifying immunologically naïve at-risk populations for vaccination, and tracking vaccine efficacy. Since human Ebola virus disease (EVD) is linked to contact with infected carcasses, identifying ape outbreaks may impact public health in local communities where EBO causes 88% case-fatality rates.
Researchers have identified a novel type III effector protein, XopL, from the plant pathogen Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicatoria, which exhibits E3 ubiquitin ligase activity in vitro and in planta. This activity induces plant cell death and subverts plant immunity. The E3 ligase activity is associated with the C-terminal region of Xop, which interacts with E2 ubiquitin conjugating enzymes and mediates K11-linked polyubiquitin formation. The crystal structure of the Xop C-terminal domain revealed a novel fold, termed XL-box, not present in any characterized E3 ligases. Mutation of amino acids in the central XL-box disrupts E ligase activity and prevents Xop-induced cell death. The XL-box lacks cysteine residues, suggesting non-thioester ubiquitin-E ligase intermediates and a non-catal mechanism. The N-terminal region of Xop contains a leucine-rich repeat (LRR) domain, potentially a protein-protein interaction module for target recognition. While E ligase is required for cell death, suppression of PAMP responses depends solely on N-terminal RR.
Researchers investigated the role of circulating follicular helper T (cTfh) cells in HIV infection and the impact of antiretroviral treatment (ART) on T and B cell function in a cohort of HIV-infected individuals in early (stage 1 and 2) and late (stage 3). The study found impaired cT cell function in individuals in stage 3 compared to stage 1/2, with lower B cell survival and IgG secretion in cT/B cocultures. This coincided with increased IL-10 and RANT and TN-α, suggesting inflammation altered cT and B responses. Elevated viral load in stage 3 correlated with decreased cT-mediated B Ig production, indicating viremia's role in cfh impairment and humoral response. Phenotypic perturbations were observed in the B compartment, with decreased resting cells in stage 3 compared stage 1/2, coinciding higher viremia. The coculture assay suggested intrinsic B defects contributed to impaired response despite lower level. cfh B responses were significantly altered in stage 3 compared stage 1/, coinciding increased inflammation and reduction B cells. Data suggest early ART for HIV-infected individuals could prevent dysregulation while preserving cfh function and cell memory.
Researchers have developed a miniaturized screen for a Schistosoma mansoni serergic protein-coupled receptor (Sm5-HT) to identify novel parasite-selective inhibitors for the treatment of schistosomiasis, a disease affecting over 200 million people worldwide. Current therapy relies on a single drug, praziquantel, with suboptimal features, necessitating next-generation anthelmintics. Despite 25% of human therapeutics targeting G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs), no Schistosoma GPCR library has been reported. This study pharmacologically profiled Sm-HT as a modulator of praziquel efficacy in a miniaturized assay with high-content screening. A luciferase-based biosensor measured cellular cAMP levels, resolving proximal GPCR kinetics in intact. Data showed divergent pharmacological signature between Sm-HT and human homolog H-HT, supporting parasitic pharmacores optimization. New ligands and series with potency and selectivity for Sm-HT over H-HT were identified in vitro and validated in vivo against schistosules and adult worms. Sm-HT displayed irreversible inactivation, enhancing its appeal as a target for anthint ligand design. These data demonstrate feasibility of flatworm GPCRs in high-throughput screening to resolve GPCR modulators and Sm-HT as a chemotherapeutic node for next-generation anthint development.
During embryonic development, the formation of the three primary germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm) is crucial for the organization of the metazoan body.
