In some organisms, such as flies, fish, and amphibians, the ectodermesoderm boundary not only separates the layers but also serves as a substrate for mesoderm migration, requiring compatibility with cell attachment and detachment. This study reveals that contact-induced detachment at the boundary is key to ectodermeserm segregation. Cells alternate between adhesion and detachment, mediated by Ephrin/Eph signaling. Multiple Ephrin ligands and Eph receptors are expressed on both sides of the boundary, with separation dependent on forward signaling in both directions, involving redundant ligands and receptors and activation of Rac and Rho.
Researchers analyzed blood samples from 83 individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) and 76 age-matched neurotypical peers to identify biochemical markers of the disorder. Metabolite concentrations of folate-dependent one-carbon and transulfuration pathways were measured. Discriminant analysis classified participants as ASD or neurotypical, correctly identifying 96.1% of neurotyp and 97.6% of ASD. Partial least squares regression predicted adaptive behavior, measured by Vineland Adaptive Composite score, using 5 metabolites, with R2 of 0.45 after cross-validation.
Researchers applied Bayesian geostatistical modeling to analyze the incidence of cutaneous and visceral leishmanias in Brazil over a 10-year period (2001-2010). The study focused on spatial and temporal patterns of the diseases, which are endemic in 98 countries and affect approximately 350 million people, with 2 million cases annually. Brazil is one of the most affected countries. The models used integrated Laplace approximations for fast Bayesian inference and variable selection to identify climatic, environmental, and socioeconomic predictors. Results showed precipitation and socioeconomic factors were significant for both cutaneous and visceral leishiasis. Predicted cases for 2010 were 30,189 (SD:7,676) for cutaneous and 4,889 (SD:288) for visceral. Maps identified Minas Gerais and Para as high-risk states for visceral and cutaneous leishias, respectively. Spatial maps highlighted areas for targeted control efforts to reduce incidence.
A study of 1,528 deng cases admitted to a hospital in southern Vietnam found differences in clinical features between adults and children. Adults had more severe thrombocytopenia and bleeding manifestations, while children had more vascular leakage and shock. Adults also had more organ involvement. Thrombocytopenia was associated with secondary infection and serotype, but age had a smaller effect. Adults had lower platelet counts than children both during and after recovery.
Researchers identified a novel CCR5 mutation in sooty mangabeys (SM) that results in a truncated protein not expressed on the cell surface and unable to support SIV entry in vitro. This mutation, denoted as CCRΔ2, was found at 26% frequency in a large SM colony, alongside 3% for CCR5Δ24, which also ablates surface expression. 8% of animals were homozygous for defective C5 alleles and 41% were heterozygous. The mutation was also present in wild SM in West Africa. CD8 and CD4 T cells showed a C5 expression gradient across genotype, significant for CD8 cells. Notably, SIVm infection prevalence was not different in animals lacking C5 compared to heterozygous and wild-type. Animals lacking C5 had robust viral loads, modestly lower than wild-type. SIV primary isolates infected homozyg mutant and wild PBMC in C5-independent manner, and Envs from C-null and wild used CX6, G15, G1 in addition to C5 transfected cells. These data indicate Ssm relies on C-independent pathways in SM homo for C5, while alternative use in SM with C5 is uncertain, suggesting S tropism and cell targeting in vivo defined by distribution and use of pathways in addition C5. S entry through alternative in vivo raises possibility of C-negative cells may be more expendable C+ and enable virus replicate without disease in face restricted C expression SM and other natural species.
Researchers have investigated the role of the transcription factor MEF2 in cancer development and found that it can have both pro-oncogenic and tumor-suppressive activities depending on its interactions with co-activators or co-repressors. MEF2 influences histone modifications associated with gene activation or repression, such as H3 methylation and H3 acetylation. Class II histone deacetylases (HDACs) are critical for generating a repressive M2 environment. In leiomyosarcoma (L), a type of cancer, M2 has a dual role in tumor aggressiveness. Class II HDs are overexpressed in 22% of L, where high levels of M2, HD4, and HD9 inversely correlate with overall survival. Knocking out HD9 suppresses the transformed phenotype of L cells by restoring transcriptional proficiency of M2-target loci. HD9 coordinates demethylation of H3me3 at promoters of M2 genes. Class II HDs do not bind regulatory elements bound by M2. M2-target genes can be both transcribed and repressed. However, repressed M2-targets are poised in chromatin signature.
Hydrophins are a class of proteins produced by filamentous fungi that play a crucial role in their interaction with their environment and have potential applications in biotechnology. This study used a combination of protein docking, molecular dynamics, and cryo-electron microscopy to investigate the atomic structure of films composed of two class II hydrophins, HFBI and HFB, produced by Trichoderma rei. The results suggest a unit cell composed of six proteins, with computational simulations indicating P6 symmetry and experimental results showing P symmetry with a unit size of 56 Å. An alternate structure with three protein cell P symmetry and smaller unit size was also proposed computationally possible. A Monte Carlo simulation of a spin model representing the hydroph film showed the alternate structure may increase the rate of surface coverage by hydrophin films, suggesting a mechanism relevant to both biology and nanotechnology.
Researchers have identified and characterized the threonine tRNA synthetase (LThrRS) enzyme of Leishmania donovani, a protozoan parasite causing visceral leishmaniasis. Recombinant LThr (rThr) was expressed in E. coli and purified, and its kinetic parameters were determined. Immunofluorescence analysis revealed subcellular localization of Thr to both cytosol and mitochondria. Heterozygous mutants of Thr were generated in Leish promastigotes, which showed restrictive growth and attenuated infectivity, and increased sensitivity to the Thr inhibitor borid. An in silico structural model of LThr was compared to human Thr, displaying considerable similarity. Recombinant Thr displayed aminoacylation activity and was inhibited by borid with IC50 0.06 μM. Borid also inhibited promastig stage parasites with IC50 21 μM. Data suggests Thr is essential for L donani survival and a potential target for drug discovery.
Hepatitis C virus (HCV) RNA is recognized as non-self by the innate immune receptor RIG-I through the presence of a 5'-triphosphate (5'-pp) on viral RNA associated with a 3' poly-UUC tract. The study defines the HCV pathogen-associated molecular pattern (PAMP) and criteria for R-I non-discrimination of HCV by examining RNA-function attributes that impart PAMP to the poly-UUC tract. A 34 nucleotide polyuridine core of the sequence is essential for R-I activation, and interspersed ribosine nucleotides between poly sequences in RNA are required for optimal R-I induction. 5-pp poly-U RNA variants stimulate R-I efficiently and bind purified R protein in vitro, and interaction with repressor and helicase domains of R is required for signaling. Appended to 5-pp RNA lacking P activity, the-U core sequence confers non-recognition and innate signaling by-I. Importantly, H poly-U variants strongly activate-I triggered potent responses in vitro and hepatic immune in vivo using a mouse model. These studies define a multi-mot P signature of non-recognition-I that incorporates 5-pp with uridine composition and length. The H motif drives potent-I to induce the response to infection.
Eosinophils and IL-4 Support Larval Growth Coincident with Innate Response to Tissue Injury

Eosinophils, previously known for their roles in host defense and allergy, have been found to play a significant role in tissue regeneration and metabolism. This study investigated the mechanism by which eosophils promote growth of Trichella spiralis larvae in skeletal muscle. Results show that IL-4 and eosophils are necessary for normal larval growth, and eosoph from IL-4 competent mice are sufficient to support growth. The eosophil effect operates in the absence of adaptive immunity. Following invasion by larvae, host gene expression in muscle is consistent with a regenerative response and shift in energy source in infected tissue. The presence eosoph suppresses local inflammation and influences nutrient homeostasis in muscle. Redistribution of glucose transporter 4 (GLUT4) and phosphorylation of Akt are observed in cells, consistent with enhancement of glucose and glycogen storage by larvae. Data indicate eosoph promote larval growth by IL-4 mechanism that limits interferon-driven responses that alter metabolism in muscle. A novel interaction between parasite and host is documented, where worms co-opt an innate cell response to facilitate growth.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide analysis of DNA replication kinetics in human cells, contradicting the view that mammalian chromosomes consist of megabase domains of coordinated origin firing separated by large originless regions. In HeLa cells, sorted into four temporal phases of S, replication origins were found to be spaced 40 kilobases apart, firing in small clusters with increasing synchrony during S phase, and replication velocity remaining constant at 0.7-2 kilobases per minute. Multi-scale analysis of genome-wide replication profiles revealed broad timing gradients with no regions larger than 100 kilobases replicating at less than 2 kilobases per minute. HeLa cells lacked large regions of unidirectional fork progression. Temporal transitions were replicated by sequential activation of origins at increasing rate during S, and timing set by delay between successive firings rather than single fork velocity. Activation of internal origins in a temporal region was demonstrated by combing the IGH locus in HeLa. Analysis of origin maps in He and published timing comb data in other cell types corroborated findings, except embryonic cells with unidirectional fork regions more abundant.
Researchers investigated how the "temporal stability" or "slown" approach, which enables the nervous system to recognize objects despite changes in contextual variables such as perspective or lighting, can be implemented using biologically realistic learning rules. They proposed a slow feature analysis algorithm based on slown, which can be implemented in continuous neurons using a modified Hebbian learning rule, linking it to the trace rule, another implementation of slown learning. For Poisson neurons, slown can be implemented by spike-timing-dependent plasticity (STDP) with a specific window. Analyzing STDP, they found that the learning window alone is not sufficient, but the convolution of the window with postsynaptic potential is crucial. They derived STDP windows implementing slow analysis and the trace rule, compatible with physiological data in shape and timescale. The analysis showed the window can be split into reversible and irreversible components sensitive to input statistics. Irreversible statistics favor oscillatory weight dynamics, not stable distributions. The study offers a novel interpretation of ST's functional role in neurons.
Researchers have identified a new mechanism of resistance to chemotherapy in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCL) called cooperative adaptation therapy (CAT), where cancer cells induce resistant phenotypes in neighboring cells when exposed to therapy. Using a CRISPR/Cas9 toolkit, they engineered phenotypically diverse NSCL cells with mutations in Dicer, a type III cytoplasmic endonuclease involved in non-coding RNA genesis. In a three-dimensional growth dynamics, fluorescently-labeled mutant and wild-type cells were cultured individually or co-cultured in a substrate-free system under stimulated or drug conditions. Mathematical modeling with flow cytometry characterized growth patterns of mono- and co-cultures using a model of intra- and interspecies competition. Parameters were estimated from flow cytometry data, revealing co-cultures allowed growth in previously sensitive cells despite drug pressure via cell transitions described by cooperative game-theoretic change in fitness. An ex vivo human tumor model predicted clinical response through drug sensitivity, correlating cellular heterogeneity to prognostic failure of multiple-approved and off-label drugs in NSCL patient samples.
A cross-sectional seropreval study was conducted in the Mbeya region of South Tanzania to estimate the serrevalence of IgG antibodies against Spotted Group (SFG) ricketiae and assess socioeconomic and environmental risk factors. A total of 1,228 participants aged 5 years were randomly selected from nine communities, stratified by age, altitude, and ownership of domestic mammals. Serology (indirect immunofluorescence) was performed at a dilution 1:64. SFG-serositivity in the cohort was 67.9% (range 42.8-91.4%). Multivariable analysis revealed associations with age (PR 1.08; 1.06-1.10), warmer temperatures (1.38;1.11-1.71), male (1.08;1-1.16), and lower population density (0.96;0.94-0.99). At higher elevations, cattle density was associated with higher serreval. SFG ricketial infection is common in rural Mbeya population. Spread limited by temperature and elevation. Examination of S contribution to febrile illnesses warranted in prospective study to estimate disease burden and causative pathogens.
Researchers have identified a crucial role for the monounsaturated fatty acid oleate in the innate immune response of the nematode Caenorhabdis elegans. Through an RNA interference (RNAi) screen of regulators of innate defense genes, two stearoy-coenzyme desaturases were found to synthesize oleate in C. elegans. The synthesis of oleate is necessary for pathogen-mediated induction of defense genes, as C. elegans deficient in ole production are hypersusceptible to infection with diverse pathogens, which can be rescued by addition of exogenous oleate. However, oleate is not sufficient to drive immune activation on its own.
Researchers have identified a novel compound, pyrimidine (PC), which selectively inhibits guanine-related metabolic pathways in bacteria by binding to guanine ribwitches, a regulatory elements that modulate gene expression in response to specific metabolite binding. Guanine ribwitches are involved in purine transport and biosynthesis, crucial for nucleotide cellular pools. Upon guanine binding, these ribwitches stabilize 5'-untranslated mRNA, causing transcription attenuation of downstream reading frames. Targeting guanine ribwitch with agonists can repress gene expression when cells are starved for guanine. Antibiotics binding ribwitches provide novel compounds that can be rationally designed from ribwitch structures. PC binds guanine ribwitch, showing bactericidal activity against a subgroup of bacterial species, including nosocomial pathogens. Selective killing is achieved when guA, coding GMP synthase, is under ribwitch control. Multiple drug-resistant strains were inhibited, suggesting PC targets different pathway. A mouse model demonstrated direct correlation between PC administration and Staphylococcus aureus infection reduction in mammary glands. This establishes possibility using existing knowledge to design gu ribwitch-targeting antibiotics as antimicrobial compounds. A new gu ribwitch target is crucial as community-acquired infections emerge.
Researchers investigated how gaze influences the construction of mental space during navigation in primates by examining behavior, visual exploration, and hippocampal activity in macaque monkeys navigating a virtual reality maze for a reward. The study found that cells sensitive to place responded to one or more variables like direction of head, point of gaze, or context. Many cells fired at the sight and in anticipation of a landmark in viewpoint or task-dependent manner, encoding the animal's situation within a set of actions leading to the goal. Hippocampal activity was best described by a fine-grained space comprising current position, view, and context. The results indicate that place cells in primates embody multidimensional task-situated knowledge to the target of gaze, supporting self-awareness in construction of space.
Researchers have conducted a spatial analysis of gene expression patterns at the mid-hind boundary (MHB) in vertebrate development to understand the regulatory network of transcription and secret factors involved in its establishment and maintenance. They employed Boolean logic minimization of functions to identify key interactions in the network and found that fibroblast growth factor 8 (Fgf8) has a maintaining rather than inducing effect on Wnt1 expression, contrary to previous data. Using mouse neural plate explant cultures, they confirmed that F8 maintains but does not induce ectopic W1 expression. Combining this with previously validated interactions, they constructed a regulatory network of key transcription and secret factors at the MHB. Analysis of Boolean and reaction-diffusion models of this network showed it can explain the stable maintenance of M as well as expression patterns under wild-type and knockout conditions. The study demonstrates that spatial expression patterns can be used to infer regulatory networks, revealing the maintenance of M boundary on a systems level.
Theileria annulata, an apicomplex parasite, infects host cells, inducing uncontrolled proliferation and clonal expansion of the parasitized population. After sporozoite entry, the host cell membrane dissolves and an array of host microtubules (MTs) surrounds the parasite, transforming into a schizont. The schizont remains tethered to host MTs during mitosis and cytokinesis, engaging cell's astral and central MTs for distribution between daughter cells. The mechanism of schizont stabilizing host MTs is unknown. MT minus ends are anchored at the organizing center, while plus ends explore space, switching growth and shrinkage phases (dynamic instability). The schizont recruits schizont end-binding protein 1 (EB1), a key regulator of host MT dynamics. 

In vitro experiments show T. annata p104, a polymorphic antigen on schizont surface, functions as EB-binding protein, recruiting EB without other parasite proteins. Binding depends on a consensus SIP motif in disordered C-terminal p104. Interaction with host EB is cell cycle regulated. This is first pathogen-encoded protein interacting with EB via SIP. Findings provide insight into Theia-host cytoskeleton interaction.
In yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, broken replication forks are typically repaired through homologous recombination or break-induced replication (BIR). However, a mutation in the replicase Cdc9 gene leads to a population of cells with persistent DNA damage, likely due to broken forks, and constitutive activation of the DNA damage checkpoint. This results in longer telomeres. Telomere length requires functional telomerase, the DNA damage signaling cascade Mec1-Rad-Rad53, and BIR pathway components Rad51, Rad52, Pol32, and Pif. The Mec-Rad53 phosphorylation of Pif, necessary for inhibiting telomerase at double strand breaks, is also crucial for Pif's role in BIR and telomere elongation in cdc-1 cells. Mutants c44 and r3, with impaired replication, exhibit a similar long telom phenotype dependent on Pif phosphorylation. Passage of B forks through telomeres promotes telom activity, leading to telom lengthening.
Researchers investigated the use of luciferase immunoprecipitation systems (LIPS) as a rapid and specific diagnostic tool for Onchocerca volulus infection. Four recombinantly produced Onocerca volulus antigens (Ov-AR-1, Ov-1, Ov-MS-1, and OvPI-1) were tested on a large cohort of sera from uninfected controls and patients with proven parasitic infections, including Onoc volulus, Wuchereria bancrofti, Loa loa, and Strongloides steralis. Antibody responses to the four antigens allowed differentiation between infected and uninfected sera with 100% sensitivity and 100 specificity. Analysis of antibody titers to each antigen in infected sera revealed they were different and did not correlate with each other. Compared to infected, patients with W, L, S, and other conditions had lower geometric mean antibody titers to each antigen. A mixture of the four antigens in standard or 15-minute format showed 100 sensitivity and specificity distinguishing infected from unected sera. The 15-minute format had best performance with sensitivity and specificity for distinguishing from W, L, and S-infected sera. The multi-antigen IPS can be used as rapid, high-throughput tool to diagnose individual infections and sensitive point-of-care for early detection recrudescence in areas control and new transmission.
A 54-month iron-folic acid supplementation and deworming program was implemented in a rural population of women in northern Vietnam to evaluate its effectiveness in reducing anemia, iron deficiency anemia, and soil-transmitted infections. The study used a prospective cohort design and enrolled 389 participants prior to the intervention. After 54 months, 76% of participants were taking ironolic acid supplements and 95% had received deworming treatment. Hemoglobin levels increased from 122 g/L to 131 g and anemia prevalence fell from 38% to 18, with significant differences between ethnic groups. Iron deficiency decreased from 23% to 8 and iron deficiency anemia from 4%. Hookworm infection prevalence reduced from 76 to 11 and moderate to heavy soil-transmitted helth infestation to less than 1.
Epstein-Barr Virus Glycoprotein gp150 Forms an Immune-Evasive Glycan Shield at the Surface of Infected Cells

Epstein-B virus (EBV), a prototypic herpesvirus, encodes a novel immunoevasion protein, gp150, expressed during the late phase of viral replication. This protein inhibits antigen presentation by HLA I, H II, and non-class lipid-presenting CD1 molecules. The mechanism of gp150-mediated T-cell escape does not depend on degradation of antigen-presenting molecules nor does it require gp's cytoplasmic tail. Through abundant glycosylation, gp creates a shield that impedes surface antigen presentation. This is an unprecedented immune evasion mechanism for herpesviruses. EB gp has a broader target range and could impact beyond T-cell activation. B cells infected with a gp-null EB displayed rescued levels of antigen presentation by H I, II, and CD, indicating an important role for NKT cells in fighting EB infection. The results indicate EB gp prolongs the lifespan of viral offspring at the most vulnerable stage of the life cycle.
Researchers have identified a conserved actin-binding domain in the translocated actin recruiting protein (Tarp) among pathogenic Chlamydial species. Previous studies have shown that a specific proline-rich domain in Chlamydia trachomatis' Tarp is required for actin nucleation. A peptide antibodies targeting the Tarp actin-binding domain inhibited actin polymerization in vitro and Chydia trachatis entry in vivo, indicating Tarp's essential role in Chlamydial pathogenesis. Sequence analysis of Tarp orthologs from additional Chydial species and Chydia serovars revealed multiple putative actin-binding sites. To determine if the identified actin domains are functionally conserved, GSTarp fusions from Chydial species were tested for their ability to bind and nucleate actin. Results showed that Chyd Tarp harbored variable numbers of actin sites and promoted actin nucleation in vitro. The study suggests that T-mediated actin binding and nucleation is a conserved among Chyd species and plays a critical role in bacterial invasion of host cells.
A novel procedure for precise quantification of Schistosoma japonicum eggs in bovine feces has been developed. Schistosomiasis japon is a zoonosis with multiple mammalian hosts, including buffaloes, which contribute to 75% of human transmission in the People's Republic of China. Determining prevalence and intensity of Schosoma japon in mammalian hosts is crucial for calculating transmission and environmental contamination. A new technique, formalin-ethylate sedimentation-digestion (F-SD), is described for visualizing S japon eggs in bovine fec. It involves filtration, sedimentation, potassium hydroxide digestion, and centrifugation prior to microscopy. This technique removes 70% debris from fecal samples, rendering remaining debris translucent, allowing microscopic visualization of S japon eggs and accurate estimation of infection in boines and ruminant hosts. The F-SD technique is valuable for surveillance of S japon reservoirs, particularly in areas with low to high intensity or suspected schos elimination.
Mutations in the genes encoding cartilage-associated protein (CRTAP) and proly 3-hydroxylase 1 (P3H1), encoded by LEP1, were first identified as causes of recessive osteogenesis imperfecta (OI). These proteins, along with cyclophilin (encoded PPI), form a complex that 3-hydroxylates a proline on the α1(I) chain (Pro986) and has cis-trans isomerase (Pase activity essential for collagen folding. Recent data suggest proly 3-hydrolation of Pro is not required for collagen stability; however, absence of post-translational modification may disrupt protein interactions for proper folding and lead to collagen overmodification. PH and CRTAP stabilize each other, and absence one results in degradation of other. Hypomorphic or loss of function of either gene causes loss of complex and associated functions. The contribution of this complex's 3-hydrolysis versus Pase and chaperone activities to OI phenotype is unknown. To distinguish, knock-in mice carrying single amino substitution in catalytic site PH (Lep1H662) were generated. This abolished PH activity but retained ability form complex CRT and chaper function. Knock mice showed absence proly 3ydrolation Pro of α(I) and α(I) collagen but significant overmodification other residues. They normal appearance, no growth and cartilage plate histology normal but trabecular bone mass decreased. This model recapitulates O bone but not cartilage phenotypes caused loss proly 3ydrolation complex. Observations suggest tissue consequences selective inactivation PH versus ablation proly 3ydro complex.
Researchers have identified a phenomenon of hybrid dysgenesis in Drosophila simulans, a species closely related to Drosila melanogaster, caused by the invasion of the P-element, a selfish genetic element. This element was horizontally transferred from a distant species to D. melanogaster, causing hybrid dysgenesis, a syndrome of abnormal phenotypes including sterility, and spread globally in a few decades. Until recently, its sister species, D simul, remained P-element free. However, a survey of 181 D simul strains shows 20% induce dysgenesis. Genomic and transcriptomic data reveal dys-inducing phenotype associated with P-element invasion. To characterize temporally and geographically, 631 D simul strains on three continents over 27 years were surveyed for P-element presence. Results show D simul P-element occurred rapidly and simultaneously in regions, with strains containing P-elements rare in 200 and common by 201. Strains from latter invasion phase have adapted to suppress P-element effects, evidenced by resistance to dys phenotype.
Researchers have developed a method to use rhodamine B to mark the bodies and seminal fluid of male Aedes aegypt for mark-release experiments and estimate the efficacy of sterile male releases. Rhodamine, a thiol-reactive fluorescent dye, was administered via sugar-feeding to stain the tissue and seminal fluid of the insects. The study adapted this technique for Ae. aegypt to assess mating success during field releases. Marking was achieved by feeding males on 0.1, 0.2, 0.4, or 0.8% rhamine (w/v in 50% honey solutions during flight. All concentrations >95% transferred to females and marked the body after 4 days, with 0.4 and 0.8 solutions producing the longest marking. Rhamine had no effect on male competitiveness. Field releases demonstrated transfer of marked fluid to females and recapture of marked males. Rhamine is a potentially useful method for male-based S/I control and a viable marking technique for male-release experiments without negative effects of traditional methods. It is less expensive than PCR paternity analysis and stable isotope labelling and less time-consuming than fertility assays to assess sterilized males.
Bacterial superantigens, a diverse family of toxins, induce an inflammatory cytokine storm that can lead to lethal shock. The CD28 homodimer, expressed on T cells, functions as the principal costimulatory ligand in the immune response through interaction with its B ligands. However, superantigens must bind directly to the dimer interface of CD28 to elicit inflammatory cytokine expression and toxicity. Preventing superigen access to CD28 suffices to block lethality. Mice were protected from superigen challenge by peptide mimetics of the CD28 dimer and peptides competing with superigen for binding site CD. Superigens use a conserved β-strand/α-helix domain to engage CD28. Mutation of superigen domain abolished cytokine induction and lethality. Structural analysis showed superigen binds to T receptor on T and major histocompatibility class II on antigen-presenting cell, CD28 accommodated as superigen receptor in ternary complex, with CD dimer oriented towards β-str/α domain superigen. Our findings identify CD28 interface as critical for superigens. The role of28 as receptor for microbial pathogens, superigens, broadens pathogen recognition mechanisms.
Embryonic stem cells (ESCs) have a fast cell cycle with a short G1 phase due to the lack of cell cycle inhibitors, maintaining naïve pluripotency and preventing differentiation. The Wnt/β-caten pathway controls ESC pluripotency via Wnt-effector T3, but its role in cell cycle regulation is unknown. This study reveals that W-eff Tcf1 is recruited to activate the Ink/Ar tumor suppressor locus, restoring G1 phase and reducing ESC proliferation without affecting pluripotency. T1, not T3, is recruited to palindromic motifs in p15k, p16, and p19 promoters, mediating Wnt anti-proliferative effect in ESCs. βaten or T1 ablation impairs W-dependent cycle regulation. W signaling controls ESC pluripotency and proliferation through distinct T functions.
Researchers investigated the role of plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs) in the immune response to deng virus (DENV) infection. pDCs are innate immune cells that secrete interferon-alpha (IF-α) and express tumor necrosis factor-related apoptosis-inducing ligand (TRAIL) in response to virus exposure. The study aimed to characterize pDC activation in deng patients and their function under DENV-2 stimulation in vitro. Flow cytometry analysis revealed that pDC from mildeng patients had higher frequencies of TRAIL expression compared to severe cases or healthy controls. Plasma levels of IF-α and soluble TRAIL were increased in mild compared to severeeng patients, correlating with p activation. In vitro exposure to D-2 induced TR expression on p. Three-dimensional microscopy showed TR was relocalized from intracellular to plasma membrane. Chloroquine inhibited D- induced TR localization and IF- production by p. Endosomal degradation by chloro allowed viral detection inside p. Data suggest endocyt pathway activation by D in p. Coculture p/D- infected monocytes showed antigen reduction by flow cytometry. Antigens in monocytes were also observed after exogenous IF- treatment. p effect on viral load was dependent on IF- production This study characterizes DENV infection of p in vivo and antiral in vitro. TR-expressing p may have role in disease outcome.
Researchers have investigated the role of tumor necrosis factor (TN) in the immune response to Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection. TN plays a crucial role in host defense against Mtb in both active and latent phases of infection. TN-neutralizing drugs, used to treat inflammatory disorders, have been linked to increased risk of tuberculosis (TB) in animal studies. This study used a computational approach to characterize TN's role in protection against the tubercle bacillus in active and latent infection, extending previous models to investigate soluble (sTN) and transmembrane TN (TN) production. The effects of anti-TNF therapy in clinical trials were simulated, analyzing two commonly used therapies, anti-T antibody and TN receptor fusion, to predict differences in TB reactivation rates. The study found that bioavailability of TN following anti-T therapy is the primary cause of latent infection reactivation and that even low levels of sTN are essential for infection control. A mathematical model distinguished the mechanisms of action of anti-T treatments and TN's role in TB pathology. The study suggests a TN-modulating agent could balance reduction of inflammation with resistance to infection and disease. Alternatively, anti-T therapy dose and timing could be modified. Anti-T therapy may lead to primary TB incidents in areas with high exposure.
Recent studies have revealed the presence of retroduplication variations (RDVs), a class of polymorphisms where a retrocopy is present or absent in individual genomes, resulting from recent retroduplications. This study investigates variation in loss of ancestral retrocopies among human populations using Phase 1 data from the 1000 Genomes Project and RNA-Seq data from Illumina Body project and lymphoblast cell lines from Geuvis Consortium. A new approach was developed to detect novel retrocopies absent from the human reference genome, experimentally confirmed in 17 populations, detecting 193 RDVs, mostly from retro deletion. Most were previously unreported. Expression of 11 ancestral retrogenes deleted in individuals was experimentally confirmed, with low frequency, except one. Conservation and low deletion rate of remaining retro suggest functionality. Aside from presence/absence of retrocopies, differences in expression levels between populations were searched, finding 9 retro statistically differentially expressed.
Researchers investigated the relationship between the location of Taenia solium cysticerci in the brain and the inflammatory response to praziquel treatment in porcine neurocysticercosis. The study analyzed 196 histological specimens from 11 pigs infected with Taenia solium cysterci, sacrificed at 2 and 5 days after a single dose of prazantel, and 3 without treatment. Pigs were intravenously injected with Evans blue to assess blood-brain barrier disruption. The degree of inflammation was estimated using a histological score (ISC) based on pericyst inflammation in photomicrographs at 40 amplification. Results showed that parenchymal cystic provoked higher peric inflammation (ISC) after antiparas treatment compared to meninge and corteningal cystic. Mingeal cystic ISC was not affected by treatment. Corteningal cystic ISC increased with cyst extent adjacent to parenym. Blood-brain disruption associated with treatment in parenym tissue. Inflammatory response meningeal cystic decreased compared parenymal.
A cross-sectional study was conducted in two districts of Ghana where azithromycin mass administration for trachoma control had previously taken place. The study aimed to investigate the presence of yaws, caused by Treponema pallidum subspecies perten, following mass distribution of azithrom at a lower dose for trach control. A total of 90 children aged 5-17 years with ulcerative lesions compatible with yaws were enrolled from 30 communities. Treponemal serology and PCR samples were collected from all children, and syphilis serology was negative in all. PCR for T. pallum subspecies perten was negative in all, but Haemophilus duyi DNA was detected in 9 lesions. The study found no evidence of ongoing y transmission in communities previously treated for trach. H. duyi was associated with a proportion of skin lesions, but majority remained unexplained.
Researchers have identified a novel mechanism to inhibit the seeding and maintenance of the HIV reservoir, a major challenge in HIV treatment, by targeting the Jak-STAT pathway, a key regulator of T cell homeostasis. This pathway is crucial for memory T cells, the hub of the HIV reservoir. Two FDA-approved Jak inhibitors, tofacitinib and ruxitin, were evaluated for their ability to block reservoir seeding and maintenance in vitro. Results show that Jak inhibitors reduce the frequency of CD4+ T cells harboring integrated HIV DNA and block viral production from infected cells, inhibiting IL-15-induced reactivation of latent virus and transmission to bystander T cells. The study demonstrates the Jak-STAT pathway's role in HIV persistence in vivo, ex vivo, and in vitro, with STAT5 correlating with integrated viral DNA levels. Inhibitors also reduce the magnitude of HIV in all CD4 T subsets in vitro and ex vivo. Dysregulation of the Jak-STAT pathway is associated with viral persistence, and inhibitors target key events downstream of cytokine (IL-2, IL-7, IL-15) receptor ligation, impacting the reservoir. These findings suggest Jak inhibitors as a therapeutic modality to prevent key T cell activation events regulating persistence and may be integrated into future curative strategies.
Researchers investigated the effects of baculovirus infection on the immune response of Spodoptera exigua larvae using microarray analysis. Contrary to the expected transcriptional shutdown during baculirus infection, S exigua cells exhibited a balanced up- and down-regulation of genes in the first 36 hours post-infection. Immune-related genes, including pattern recognition proteins, signaling pathways, and effectors, and melanization proteins were down-regulated. This downregulation was confirmed in the larval gut, affecting immune gene expression in the gut, which influences gut microbiota, responsible for growth and development. The study hypothesized that downregulation after baculirus infection increased gut microbiota. An increase in bacterial load was observed, attributed to viral infection. Subsequent experiments with baculirus in presence and absence of microbiota revealed bacteria enhanced bacul virulence and pathogenicity.
Researchers have identified a novel gene that regulates the transition from meiosis to mitosis in apomix, a form of asexual reproduction in plants. This gene, when mutated in combination with others affecting meiotic processes, resulted in a genotype Mi, where meiosis is replaced by mitosis. Plants with this genotype produce diploid gametes identical to their mother.
Researchers have developed a new approach to prioritize disease-causing genes by incorporating tissue-specific information into protein-protein interaction (PPI) networks. Current methods rely on the observation that genes causing similar diseases are close to each other in P networks, but use a static view of human PIs. This study integrates tissue-specific gene expression data with P information to create tissue-specific P networks for 60 tissues and assesses their prioritization power. Tissue-specific networks improve prioritization results compared to generic networks and predict novel disease-tissue associations, indicating subclinical effects that may be missed.
Researchers have developed a two-locus model to study the evolution of insecticide resistance in mosquito species that transmit human diseases such as malaria. The model accounts for differential exposure of males and females to high or low concentrations of insecticide and varying selection pressures and dominance values based on insecticide concentration. The model was applied to investigate the effectiveness of sequential versus mixed insecticide deployment to minimize resistance spread. Results showed that in 56% of runs, resistance spread to high levels by 500 generations, while 44% favored mixed and 24% sequential use. Mixture favored when insecticide effectiveness is high and exposure is low. If insecticides do not kill homozygous genotypes, sequential is more robust. Resistance spreads slower with mixture, but may not outperform sequential. For example, mixture lasts 5 years while individual insecticides last 3 and 4, giving 7 years lifespan for sequential.
Rhodnius neglectus, a species of triatomine bug, is a hematophagous insect vector of Chagas disease, a significant public health concern in the Americas. The insect's saliva contains bioactive molecules that modulate host hemostatic, inflammatory, and immune responses. To investigate the composition of R. neglectus saliva, next-generation sequencing and mass spectrometry-based protein identification were employed. A total of 4,230 DNA sequences were deposited in GenBank, and 636 coding sequences of putative secretory proteins were extracted from assembled reads, 73 confirmed by proteomic analysis. Characterization of R. neglectus saliva revealed serine protease transcripts and presence of ubiquitous protein families, including lipocalins, serine protease inhibitors, antigen-5 metalloproteases, disintegrins, and odorant binding proteins. These findings enhance understanding of hematophagous arthropod saliva and interplay among vectors and vertebrate hosts.
Researchers used Caenorhabditis elegans as a model organism to study the interaction between nematodes and soil bacteria. They employed transcriptional profiling to identify genes differentially expressed in response to bacteria isolated from grassland nematodes and grass soils. The study aimed to determine if differential expression is predictive of functional importance in the environment where induced. Candidate genes were predicted to affect metabolism and immunity, suggesting influence on nemode community dynamics. Mutations in 21 identified genes showed contribution to lifespan and fitness in specific bacterial environments. Although bacteria are not a natural food source for C. elegans, changes in food source due to environmental disturbance affected gene expression and fitness. Regression analysis demonstrated that degree of differential expression between environments predicted magnitude of gene loss of function on life traits in those environments.
A critical event in mammalian embryo development is the formation of an inner cell mass surrounded by a trophoblast, a shell of cells that later form extraembryonic structures. Researchers used multi-scale modeling to investigate the principles responsible for robust establishment of these structures. The study made three predictions, supported by quantitative imaging data. First, stochastic gene expression of critical genes promotes cell plasticity in the developing blastocyst. Second, asymmetry in levels of Cdx2 and Oct4 expression variation provides a means to benefit from noise-mediated plasticity while reducing detrimental effects of stochasticity. Third, the embryo temporally modulates plasticity by controlling timing and pace of cell specification, creating a window for cells to continually read environment and adjust fate.
Researchers have investigated the ability of germline-encoded antibodies to bind to diverse antigens and their potential for polyspecificity. They found that germl-encoded antibodies can bind to multiple antigens due to structural flexibility in the germl gene, which allows for promiscuous binding. The affinity and specificity for a particular epitope increases as the antibody acquires somatic mutations in antigen-stimulated B cells. To determine the basis for recognition of diverse antigens by germl-encoded antibodies, researchers computationally redesigned antibodies encoded by VH segments to bind multiple antigens. The Rosetta multi-state process predicted antibody sequences for the entire heavy chain region, including framework, CDR, and CDR mutations. The predicted sequences matched germl gene to a remarkable degree, revealing residues that enable polyspecific binding. In contrast, designing antibodies to bind a single antigen returned a similar sequence to mature sequence, mimicking natural maturation. The computational algorithm captures aspects of antibody-antigen recognition. The CDR region often mediates specificity, but VH CDR, CDR, and immunoglobulin framework contribute to polyspecificity in germl antibodies. Designing antibodies to bind multiple antigens may allow rational design of polyspecific for diverse epitope binding.
Locusts exhibit two distinct behavioral phases: solitar and gregar. Solitar individuals are repelled by other locusts, while gregar insects are attracted to conspecifics and form large aggregations, such as marching hopper bands. Biological experiments at the individual level have shown that crowding biases towards the gregar form. To understand hopper band formation, we study phase change at the collective level, using a quantitative framework. A partial integrodifferential model is constructed, incorporating interplay between phase and spatial movement at the individual level to predict hopper dynamics at the population. Stability analysis reveals conditions for an outbreak, characterized by a large transition to gregar. The model enables quantification of temporal dynamics of each phase, proportion of the population that gregarizes, and time for this to occur. Numerical simulations describe aggregation's structure, revealing transient clumps of gregar insects.
Researchers have characterized an intermediate structure in the fusion process of flaviviruses, a type of virus that causes diseases such as tick-borne encephalitis. The fusion process involves conformational changes in viral glycoproteins, called fusion proteins. High-resolution images of these proteins in their initial and final stages are available, but the intermediate steps in between have been difficult to define due to their transient nature. Flaviruses have a class II fusion protein (E) that mediates fusion at acidic pH, changing from a dimer to trimer with a hair-like structure during fusion. Exposing tick-borne encephal virus particles to alkaline instead of acidic pH traps them in an intermediate state where dimers dissociate and interact with membranes via fusion peptide without merging. Further exposure to low pH leads to fusion, indicating these monomers correspond to an elusive intermediate converting prefusion dimer to postfusion trimer. Using non-physiological conditions, researchers dissected the flavivirus process and identified two steps: membrane insertion of multiple E monomers precedes formation of hair-like trimers. This sequence provides new insights into viral membrane fusion dynamics.
The study investigates the drivers of extinction risk in plants, focusing on the Cape of South Africa, a global biodiversity hotspot, and compares Red List data for British and South African floras. The results show that taxonomic distribution of extinction risk differs between regions, inconsistent with a trait-based model of extinction. A phylogenetic analysis of the Cape flora reveals a phylogenetic signal in extinction distribution, but most threatened species cluster at the tips of the phylogeny, opposite to mammals. The distribution of threatened species across 11 exemplar clades suggests mode of speciation explains the phylogenetic structure of risks. The study finds that extinction risk is higher for young and fast-evolving plant lineages, not explained by simple biological traits, and most vulnerable species are marching towards extinction at a rapid pace, independently of anthropogenic effects. The results have implications for conservation and question the utility of Red List criteria in regions with rapid speciation, aiming to preserve the tree-of-life.
Researchers have identified two new proteins, Bruton's Tyrosine Kinase (TK) and Vav, that interact with the phagocytic receptor Dectin-1 in macrophages to facilitate the phagocytosis of Candida albicans, an opportunistic fungal pathogen. Dect-1 is crucial for anti-fungal immunity. TK and Vav are recruited to phagocytic cups containing C. albicans yeasts or hyphae, but absent from mature phagosomes. TK and V localize to regions surrounding hye while Dect- lines phag phosome. TK and V colocalize with lipid (3,4,5)P3 and actin at phag cup, not diacylglycerol (DAG) marking mature phag membranes. Using a TK inhibitor, TK contributes to DAG synthesis at phag cup and PKC recruitment. TK or V-deficient peritoneal macrophages display defect in C. alb phocytosis. Bone-derived macrophages lacking TK or V show reduced C. alb uptake, similar toect-1 deficient. TK or V-deficient mice are more susceptible to systemic C infection than wild-type mice.
In Madagascar, Rift Valley Fever (RV) is a vector-borne disease affecting ruminants and humans, with a significant outbreak occurring in 2008-2009. To optimize resource allocation for RV surveillance, identifying at-risk environments is crucial. This study aimed to identify environmental and human factors favoring RV transmission in cattle and humans. Environmental characteristics of Malagasy communes were analyzed using Multiple Factor Analysis (FA), while cattle and human serological data were analyzed using Generalized Mixed Models, with serological status as response and FA and risk factors as explanatory variables. Results showed cattle and human seroprevalence positively associated with humid environments (p<0.001) and high cattle density (p<0.01, OR=2.6). Frequent contact with raw milk contributed to human infection (OR=1.6). Eastern, western, and northwestern areas were high-risk for RV transmission in cattle. The study integrated analysis of environmental and human datasets provided new insights into RV transmission patterns in Madagascar. The association between serrevalence, humid, and high cattle density suggests conitant and direct transmissions are critical for RV enzootic transmission. In at-risk environments, western, northwestern, and eastern areas, suitable Cule and Anophe mosquitoes vector transmission occurs in cattle and humans.
Researchers have investigated the transmission of prions, self-propagating protein conformations, between non-identical proteins, such as between homologous proteins from different species, and found that transmission is frequently inefficient. This inefficiency is attributed to differences in the prion protein sequence, but the underlying mechanisms are unclear. A yeast Rq1[PIN]-based system was used to explore the nature of transmission barriers. Rq1[PIN, the prion form of R1, is common in wild and laboratory yeast strains, facilitating the appearance of other prions. R1's prion domain contains four Q-rich regions. The study found that R1 encompasses multiple prion determinants that independently drive amyloid formation in vitro and transmit the R1[P] prion in vivo. Analysis of R[P] transmission between R1 fragments with different prion determinants revealed that one Q-rich region is required and sufficient for transmission, but transmissions are impeded by barriers of different strength. The existence of transmission barriers in the absence of amino mismatches in regions indicates that prion multiple determinants cooperate to attain the prion conformation, and transmission is determined by cooperative fold.
Researchers have developed a novel, likelihood-free framework for inferring complex genetic models from genomic data using deep learning, a powerful machine learning technique. This approach leverages multilayer neural networks to learn a feature function mapping from input data (e.g., hundreds of summary statistics) to output (e.g., genetic parameters of interest). The method is demonstrated to be effective for population inference and feature learning from data. A concrete application focuses on jointly inferring natural selection and demography (population size history) in Drosila melanogaster. The method separates global demography from local selection without sequential steps for these factors. Demography and selection are studied jointly motivated by Drosila, where selection confounds demographic analysis. The method is applied to 197 Dila melanogaster genomes from Zambia to infer demography and regions of genome under selection. Results show many regions experienced hard sweeps and soft or balancing selection. Sweeps and balancing occur more frequently closer to chromosome centers. Demographic inference suggests previously estimated bottlenecks for Dila melanaster are extreme.
High-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) oncogenes disrupt the Fanconi anemia DNA repair pathway by impairing FANCD2 localization and deubiquination.

 Persistent expression of high-risk HPV oncogenes is necessary for the development of anogenital and orophngeal cancers. Research has shown that E6/E7-expressing cells are hypersensitive to DNA-damaging agent cisplatin and have defects in repairing interstrand crosslinks (ICL). This study elucidates how E6/E disrupts the Fanconi anemia (FA) DNA repair pathway. E6 activates the FA pathway by increasing FAN2 monoubiquination and foci formation, but inhibits completion of repair through multiple mechanisms. E impairs FAN2 localization with double-strand breaks (DSB), hindering downstream protein Rad51 recruitment to DS in E cells. Further, E causes delayed F2 deubiquination, crucial for effective ICL repair. Delayed F2 deubination is associated with chromatin retention of F, hindering US1 deubiquinating activity and persistently activating ATR/CHK-1/pS F signaling. E mediated p53 degradation does not affect cell cycle-specific F2 modifications but abrogates repair by disrupting F deubination. Additionally, E reduces Pal2 expression and foci formation, a protein downstream of F2. These findings reveal mechanisms by which HPV oncogenes contribute to genomic instability and response to cisplatin therapies.
In the Southern Chiapas region of Mexico, one of the major onchocerciasis foci in Latin America, 559 communities have undergone semi-annual ivermectin treatment since 1998. In 50 communities, iverectin frequency was increased to twice a year in 2003, and an additional 113 communities were added to the quarterly regimen in 2009 to achieve rapid suppression. Epidemiologic and entomologic assessments were conducted in six communities with 2 rounds of iverectin per year and three with 4 rounds per year. No Simulium ochraceum s.l. collected during the 201 dry season were found to contain parasite DNA by PCR-ELISA, with an upper bound of the 95% confidence interval of infectivity of 0.06/2,000 examined. Serological testing on 4,230 children under 5 revealed 2/4,230 exposed to O. volulus (0.05%). The epidemiologic and entomologic findings meet the criteria for interruption of transmission by the international community.
Listeria monocytogen, a Gram-positive facultative intracellular pathogen, invades mammalian cells and escapes from membrane-bound vacuoles to replicate within the host cytos. The transcription activator PrA regulates gene products for intracellular growth and bacterial spread to adjacent cells. However, the signal stimulating PrA activation has not been defined. This study identifies L monocytogen secretion of a peptide pherone, pPpl, enhancing escape from host vacoles and facilitating PrA activation. Ppl is generated via proteolytic processing of P lipoprotein signal. P is dispensable for pathogenesis, but bacteria lacking P are attenuated in virulence and reduced vacole escape efficiency in nonphagocytic cells. Mutational PrA restores virulence and eliminates P-dependent signaling. Experimental evidence suggests P may signal monocogen presence within vacole, stimulating expression contributing to escape and PrA promoting cytos growth.
Researchers investigated how the bacterium Vibrio cholera, which causes cholera, adapts to the hostile environment of the host's small intestine and combats reactive oxygen species (ROS) during infection. They used whole-genome transposon sequencing (T-seq) to compare gene requirements for colonization in mice with and without antioxidant N-acetyl cystine treatment. Mutants of the methyl-directed repair system, such as MutS, showed advantages in untreated, ROS-rich mice but not in N-treated mice. Further analysis revealed accumulation of catalase-producing and rugose variants in N-treated mice was due to Mut mutant enrichment by oxidative stress during infection. Rugose variants reverted to smooth colonies in aerobic in vitro. Mutation rate of wildtype colonized in N-treated mice was higher than in N+ mice. These findings suggest Vibrio employs a temporal strategy to battle ROS during infection, resulting in enriched phenotypes. ΔS passage and complementation can model hypermutation in diverse pathogens to identify stress mechanisms.
Researchers investigated the role of Mlh3 in meiotic recombination and mismatch repair (MMR) in baker's yeast by analyzing 60 new Mlh alleles. Five alleles disrupted MMR, while one (Mlh-32) specifically disrupted meiotic crossover. Mlh-3 representatives from each class were purified and characterized. Both Mlh-3-32 (MR+, crossover-) and Mlh-45 (MR-, crossover+) displayed wild-type endonuc activities in vitro. M2SH, an M complex that acts with Mlh in M, stimulated the enduc activity of M-32 but not M-45, suggesting M-45 is defective in interactions. Whole-genome recombination maps were constructed for wild-type MR+, MR-, MR+, enduc defective and M mutants in S288/Y789 background. Compared to wild-type, all M mutants showed increases in number of nonc events, consistent with recombination intermediates resolved through alternative pathways.
A study investigated the impact of host population structure on the reversion to drug sensitivity after discontinuation of antibiotic treatment for diseases such as tuberculosis, Staphylococcus aureus, and gonorrhea. The use of intense antibiotics has led to increasing drug resistance, necessitating a switch to new drugs and discontinuation of older ones, which often results in slow or persistent resistance decline. Researchers found that host population heterogeneity, particularly in the number of contacts, influences reversion dynamics. During treatment, host structure leads to non-random distribution of resistant strains among infected individuals, and after drug discontinuation, affects competition dynamics, mitigating fitness advantages. This results in lower reversion rate and probability on population level after treatment stopped. Simulations showed host heterogeneity's impact is maximal in biologically plausible range when resistance costs are small.
Autism spectrum disorders (ASD) are highly heritable and characterized by deficits in social interaction and communication, as well as restricted and repetitive behaviors. Although several highly penetrant ASD variants have been identified, there is evidence supporting a role for combinatorial effects from contributions of multiple loci. Researchers examined synaptic and circadian phenotypes resulting from dosage variants of human-fly orthologs in Drosophila, observing synergistic interactions between pairs of candidate genes orthologs affected by de novo copy number (CN) variants. These CNs were found in genomes of individuals with autism, including one carrying 22q11.2 deletion. Dosage alterations of Dophila orthologs of candidate genes from CNs with single gene display neurological defects similar to previously reported Doph models of ASD variants. Pairwise changes of ortholog candidate genes affected by single CN showed significant synergistic effects following simultaneous change. Phenotypic variation at Dophila synapse results from interacting variants supports concordant outcome across interacting pairs gene direction human copy change. Specificity and transitivity observed between interactors within and between CN candidate sets shared distinct genetic etiologies. Interactions divergent synaptic processes demonstrate molecular etiologies. Study illustrates synergistic effects large variation contribute human disease.
Researchers have investigated the role of brain-infiltrating CD8 T cells in the development of experimental cerebral malaria (ECM) caused by Plasmodium berghei AN infection in C57/6 mice. They found that these cells accumulate in the perascular spaces of the brain during both ECM-inducing (P. berghei AN) and non-inducing (P. berghei NK) infections. However, perascular CD8 T cells displayed arrested behavior specifically during P. berghei AN infection, despite comparable activation phenotypes of brain-accumulating CD8 T cells during both infections. The cells formed long-term interactions with CXCR1-bearing antigen-presenting cells within the brain during P. berg AN infection, but depletion of these cells did not prevent ECM development. Pathogenic CD8 T cells localized with apoptotic cells expressing CD31, a marker of endothelial cells, within brain during ECM. Apoptosis was rare and did not result in loss of vasculature or disruption.
A cross-sectional study was conducted in 21 villages in 3 sub-locations of Viga County, Kenya to determine the burden of tungias, a parasitic disease caused by the sand flea Tungaans. A total of 437 participants aged 5 years and above were clinically examined for the presence of tungias after consenting to participate. Diagnosis was made using standard methods and a semi-structured questionnaire assessed socio-demographic factors, housing, presence of animals, and knowledge related to tungias. The overall prevalence was 21.5% (95% CI 17.7-25.3). Cases were visualized in a map. Multivariate analysis showed occurrence of tungias associated with low economic status (monthly income ≤ Ksh 100, adjusted OR 27.85, 95% CI 4.13-187.59), floor (0.36, 0.13-1.024), lack of toilet facilities (4.27,0.82-22.34), age ≤14 (27.414,10.02-74.99), no use of closed footwear (1.98,0.987-3.97), and resting inside house (1.93,0.96-3.89).
Researchers have developed a computational model to study the interaction between auxin and cytokinin hormones in Arabidopsis root patterning. Auxin is positioned along the xylem axis, and its pattern depends on feedback between aux and cytokinin, mediated by PIN and AHP proteins. The model considers hormonal regulation of aux transport in a spatial context, accounting for cell shape and polarity and walls. Analysis reveals that cytokinin pattern by diffusion is unlikely and not required for auxin patterning. Instead, aux modifies cytokinin response, not levels, allowing feedback that amplifies and stabilizes auxin. Simulations show importance of aux efflux regulation for robustness. PIN's role in patterning is established, but AUX and LAX aux influx transporters' involvement is predicted and verified. Local PIN generates an aux circuit stabilizing aux in xylem and allowing accumulation in xylem-pole cells, an early lateral initiation step. Pericycle cells on xyle poles compete for aux accumulation, consistent with lateral roots not initiated opposite each other.
In a study on the migratory locust Locusta migratoria, researchers have identified a key mediator in the neuropeptide F (NPF)/nitric oxide (NO) signaling pathway that regulates phase-related locomotor plasticity. The conserved transcription factor cAMP response element-binding protein B (CRE-B) plays a crucial role in this pathway, mediating the transition between solitary and gregarious phases of locomotor activity. CRE-B directly activates brain nitric oxide synthase (NOS) expression by interacting with its promoter region. Phosphorylation of serine 110 on CRE-B changes in response to population density and is negatively controlled by N2. RNA interference and behavioral assays validate CRE-B involvement in N2-regulated locomotor plasticity. Protein kinase mediates the effects of N on CRE-B phosphorylation and OS transcription.
Researchers investigated the role of the zinc-finger protein Zelda (Z) in the early development of Drosophila melanogaster embryos, specifically during the maternal-to-zyotic transition (MT), a period when the zygotic genome is transcriptionally activated after fertilization. Chromatin immunoprecipitation coupled with high-throughput sequencing (IP-Seq) was used to map regions bound by Z before, during, and after the MT. Prior to mitotic cycle 10, only a few genes are transcribed, but thousands of regions are bound by Z, most of which remain through mitotic 14. Early Z-bound regions include promoters and enhancers of transcribed at this stage, as expected. Unexpectedly, Z is also bound to promoters of approximately 1,000 genes first transcribed at the MT and virtually all known enhancers bound by cycle 14 transcription factors that regulate gene activation during MT. The association between Z binding and MT is strong, allowing Z to identify active promoters and regulatory sequences with specificity. This early association suggests Z is not only required for earliest transcription but also plays a role in activating genome at MT.
Researchers have identified 109 novel protein-protein interactions (PPI) among circadian clock proteins using a yeast-two-hybrid approach. The interaction between protein phosphatase 1 and CLOCK/BMAL resulted in BMAL1 destabilization. A dynamic circadian protein-protein interaction network was constructed using circadian expression data to predict PI timing. Systematic circadian phenotyping via RNAi and overexpression revealed crucial roles for components in dynamic interactions. Analysis of the global network in liver showed interacting proteins are expressed at similar times, restricting interactions to specific phases. Circadian PIs dynamically connect many cellular processes, including signal transduction, cell cycle, contributing to temporal organization of physiology in an unprecedented manner.
Researchers have solved the three-dimensional structure of ABA-1, a repeating unit of the nematode polyallergen protein (NPA) from Ascaris su, using nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. The protein adopts a novel seven-helical fold, consisting of a central helix surrounded by two four-hel bundles on either side. Two discrete hydrophobic ligand-binding sites are located in the N-terminal and C-terminal bundles, with specific amino acid residues involved in fatty acid binding identified. Recombinant A-BA1 contains a tightly bound ligand of bacterial origin in one of its binding sites. This is the first structurally characterized, post-translationally processed unit of a tandemly repetitive protein from any source, belonging to a new class. Nematode polyallergens are unique lipid-binding proteins found in nematodes, synthesized as large, repetitive polyproteins cleaved into small binding proteins with identical fatty acid and retin (A) characteristics. They play roles in transport and distribution of hydrophobic compounds, nutrient scavenging, immunomodulation, and IgE responses. In some species, units are diverse, but in ascar and filarial nematodes, many are identical or near-ident. A-1 is common unit of NPA Ascar su, similar to Ascar lumicoid, large roundworm of humans. Immune responses NP associated with acquired resistance in humans, under genetic control.
Between 1998 and 2008, a significant number of cases of ciguatera poisoning were reported in the Pacific Island Countries and Territories (PITCs). Ciguatoxin-contaminated fish consumption led to acute neurologic, gastrointestinal, and cardiac symptoms in individuals, with some experiencing chronic neuro symptoms lasting weeks to months. A questionnaire was sent to health and fisheries authorities in PCs to quantify the extent of cigater. Data analysis revealed 39,677 reported cases from 17 PCs, with a mean annual incidence of 194 per 100,000 people across the region, compared to 104/100,000 from 1973-1983. There was a 60% increase in annual cigater incidence between the two periods in PCs. Accounting for underreporting, an estimated 500,000 islanders may have suffered cigater in the last 35 years. This incidence exceeds global and local cigater estimates, elevating its status to a major public health concern.
A study investigated the impact of benznidazole treatment on the functional response of Trypanosoma cruzi-specific CD4+CD8+ T cells in Chagas disease patients. Thirty-eight patients with chronic Chagas disease (20 asymptomatic and 18 symptomatic) and twelve healthy controls were enrolled. Peripheral blood mononuclear cells were stimulated with soluble T cruzi antigens to analyze cytokine and cytotoxic molecule production by CD+CD+ cells before and after benidazole treatment. Expression and co-expression of inhibitory receptors in patients after treatment were studied using multiparameter flow cytometry. CD+CD+ cells were higher in Chagas patients compared to healthy donors, with higher ratio CD+CD/CD+ subpopulations. CD+ cells expressed co-expressed higher inhibitory receptors in proportion to pathology severity. Benidazole reduced CD+CD cells and decreased ratio CDCD/CD subpop. Co-expression inhibitory was reduced after treatment with multifunctional capacity CD+ cells. Treatment increased frequency T cruzi-specific CD+CD expressing IL-2 and TN-α. CD+ cells produced effector molecules for parasite control. Benidazole partially reversed T cruz infection exhaustion in cells with improved T cruz-specific CD+CD response.
Researchers have identified Arabidopsis thalian phosphoinide-specific phospholipase 2 (AtPLC2) as the primary enzyme responsible for phosphoinide metabolism and its role in seedling growth and endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress responses. Lipid profiling of PLC2 mutants revealed increased levels of its substrates phosphatidylinositol 4-phosphate and phosphidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate, indicating impaired phosphide metabolic pathway. PLC2 displayed distinct tissue-specific expression and localization at the plasma membrane in various cell types where phosphide signaling occurs. Seedlings of PLC2 mutants showed growth defects complemented by heterologous expression of PLC, indicating phosphide-specific phospholipase activity by PLC is required for seedling growth. The PLC2 mutant exhibited hypersensitive response to ER stress, evidenced by changes in phenotypes and gene expression profiles. This study reveals the primary enzyme in phosphide metabolism, its involvement in seedling, and a link between phosphide and ER stress.
Researchers challenge the assumption of reductionism in causation, which posits that causation occurs at the micro level, excluding emergence at the macro level. They employ a measure of intrinsic cause-effect power-integrated information (Φ) to demonstrate that macro-level causation can surpass micro-level causation. Systems are evaluated across spatial and temporal scales, considering all possible "black boxes" consisting of one or more micro elements over one or more updates. Cause power is evaluated based on inputs and outputs of boxes, ignoring internal elements supporting input-output functions. Results show that black boxes can have more inputs and outputs than micro elements, revealing emergent mechanisms and constraints not apparent at micro. Macro-box systems can have higher Φ than constituents with more mechanisms and interconnected. For a given system, local maxima of Φ can be identified across spatial-temporal scales. The framework is demonstrated on a biological system, the Boolean model of fission yeast cell cycle, identifying local maxima during simulated function. These max correspond to levels of organization where emergent cause properties come into focus, providing a vantage for scientific inquiry.
Reactive oxygen species (ROS) produced in the mitochondrial respiratory chain (RC) play a dual role in modulating cellular adaptation to the environment and causing damage under conditions of hypoxia/reoxygenation relevant to various diseases. To investigate the role of ROS in cell survival, a detailed understanding of ROS production mechanisms and determinants is required. An extended model of complex III was developed to account for electron transport in the RC coupled to proton translocation, transmembrane electrochemical potential, TCA reactions, and substrate transport to mitochondria. Measurements of respiratory flux in rat mitochondria fueled by succinate, pyruvate, and malate, and dynamics of NAD+ reduction by reverse transport from succinate through complex I were analyzed. Fitting of measured data provided insight into mechanisms governing free radical formation and superoxide generation. Analysis revealed association of ROS with specific electron transporters and combinations in complexes I and III. Bistability of complex III was found to be valid for the whole RC. Conditions for high radical content in III were predicted and confirmed. These findings provide insight into ROS production mechanisms in RC.
Motor proteins play a crucial role in intracellular transport by converting chemical energy into kinetic energy, enabling unidirectional and bidirectional transport of cargo over long distances. Disruptions in transport mechanisms, often caused by mutations altering motor characteristics, lead to neurodegenerative diseases. Phosphorylation of the kinesin motor domain at serine residue is implicated in Huntington's disease, with phosphorylated phosphim serine residues lowering motor stalling forces. This study investigates the effects of mutations on transport properties of cargo carried by wild-type and mutant motors. Results show that mutants with altered stalling forces determine average velocity and run-length, even when outnumbered by wild-type motors in the ensemble. Mutants gain a competitive advantage and increase run-length when the load is near the mutant's stalling or multiple of stalling. A semi-analytical method is developed to analyze transport by multiple motors of types, determining transition rates between configurations using transition rates. This enables computation of biologically relevant quantities, such as velocity and run-length, without Monte Carlo simulations. The method allows introduction of single parameter alterations to model mutation and deduce effects on transport by multiple motors. The method is implementable and a software package is provided for use.
Researchers investigated the role of the CAC1 gene in operant learning by selectively ablating the gene in mice and analyzing their behavior on an operant discrimination task. The study found that CAC1 knockout did not impair learning in general, but had a specific effect: most knockout mice increased reward across trials by adapting an outcome-based strategy, while controls adopted the experimentally intended cue-association. This suggests a specific role of the CAC1 gene in learning and highlights the importance of examining response patterns in a repertoire of behavioral strategies. The study used a detailed individual-level analysis of learning and Bayesian computational models to estimate data, showing that C1 knockout mice used a different strategy than intended by the experimenter. The results may have implications for treating psychiatric disorders associated with altered expression of Cav1.2 channels and CAC1 gene, which are linked to synaptic plasticity and calcium influx through high-voltage-gated Ca+ channels.
Aedes aegypt mosquitoes infected with Wolbachia bacteria are being released worldwide for arbovirus suppression. Their ability to invade and persist in populations depends on interactions with environmental conditions, particularly temperature fluctuations. Researchers reared Ae. aegypt larvae with different types of Wolbach (wMel, wAlB and wMel-CLA) under diurnal temperatures. Results showed that rearing Mel and wMel-CLA-infected larvae at 26-37°C reduced cytoplasmic incompatibility, a reproductive manipulation by Wolbach, and Wolbach density in adults. Mel and wMel-CLA infections were not transmitted to next generation when exposed 26-37°C across life stages. In contrast, wB infection maintained high density, exhibited cytoplasm incompat, and transmitted to offspring with high fidelity under this cycle.
Researchers isolated and characterized adenoviruses from the gastrointestinal tracts of non-human primates, including great apes (chimpanzees, bonobos, gorillas, and orangutans) and macaques. The study aimed to understand the natural history of adenirus infections in these species and found that healthy populations shed substantial quantities of infectious adeniruses in their stool. In contrast, asymptomatic shedding in humans was less frequent compared to previous reports. Thirty adeniruses were purified and sequenced from apes and three from macques. Analysis of the new adenirus sequences, along with previously reported chimpanzee adenirus and 22 adenirus genomes, revealed that ape adeniruses corresponded to human adenirus species B, C, and E. Intraspecies recombination between adeniruses was also observed. The high phylogenetic relatedness of adeniruses across primate hosts suggested cross-species transmission events in the history of B and E viruses. Asymptomatic shedding of adenirus in non-human primates and zoonotic transmissions warrant caution for primate handling. Persistent and latent adenirus infections in the gut should be considered in human and non-primate adenirus vector studies.
Researchers have investigated the process of unwrapping the outer helical turn of nucleosomal DNA using molecular dynamics simulations with enhanced sampling. The nucleosome, the fundamental unit of chromatin, is a protein-DNA complex where 146-147 base pairs of DNA wrap 1.75 times around a histone core. To function in cellular processes, nucleosomal DNA must be unwrapped, but the details of this process at an atomic level were not well understood. The simulations calculated a free energy change of 11.5 kcal/mol for unwrapping the outer helical turn, consistent with values from single molecule experiments. The study revealed various conformational states indicating multiple paths to unwrapping the outer helical turn, with a dominant asymmetric path. Unwrapping initiated at one end of DNA with five base pairs unwrapping, followed by a second five base unwr at the same end with increased energy. Unwrapping then started at the other end of DNA with ten base unwr. Further unwrapping 15 base, unwr progressed at one end, then the other end unwr completed the unwrapping the outer helical turn.
Researchers have identified a new mechanism by which protects lysosomes from damage caused by oxidative stress. Lysosomes are sensitive to damage due to their dependence on acidic pH and membrane gradients. Lipocalin Apolipoprotein D (ApoD), an antioxidant protein, is secreted by astrocytes to help neurons cope with oxidative stress. The role of Apo is known at cellular and organismal levels, but its mechanism was unknown. This study analyzed Apo's intracellular traffic and role in lysosomal homeostasis during paraquat-induced stress. Single-lysosome pH measurements and immunodetection showed Apo is endocytosed and targeted to vulnerable lysosomes in a stress-dependent manner. Apo is stable in acidic environment and necessary for lysosomes to recover from oxidation-induced alkalin in astrocytes and neurons. Apo prevents lysosomal permeabilization. Two lysosomal processes, myelin phagocytosis by astrocytes and neurodegeneration-triggered autophagy in Drosophila model, require Apo-related lipocalins.
