Results uncover a new Apo function, member of conserved extracellular lipocal family. Lipoprotein regulation of lysosomal integrity is a mechanism for cellular functions in neurodegenerative diseases.
This study investigated the biology and susceptibility of Phlebotus orientalis sandflies to Leishmania donovani, the causative agent of visceral leishmaniasis, from two geographically distant localities in Ethiopia. Two colonies of P. orientalis were obtained from a non-endemic site in the lowlands of Melka Wer (MW) and an endemic focus of human visceral leishmanias in the highlands of Addis Z (AZ). Life cycle parameters differed between the two colonies, with distinct requirements for larval food and humidity during pupation. However, genetic analysis using Random Amplified Polymorphic DNA (RAP) PCR and DNA sequencing of cytB and COI genes revealed no genetic differences. F1 hybrids exhibited higher fecundity than parental colonies. Susceptibility of P. orient to L. donani was studied by experimental infection. Even the lowest infective dose (2x10^3 per ml) was sufficient for successful establishment of L. donani infections in 50% of P. orient females. Using higher infective doses, infection rates were 90% for both colonies. Leish development in P. orient was fast, with metacyclic promastigotes in thoracic midgut and stomal colonization by homonads recorded in P orient females by day 5 post-feeding. Both MW and AZ colonies of P orient were highly susceptible to Ethiopian L. donani strains. Average blood-meals taken by P orient females were 0.7µl, infective dose lowest was one or two L promastigotes per sand-meal. Development of L don was similar in P orient colonies, hence absence visceral leishias non-endemic Mel Wer attributed to susceptibility local orient populations donani.
Researchers conducted a study to quantify the quality of life and disability of patients with advanced schistosomiasis japonica in a schistosoma japonicum-endemic county in the People's Republic of China. The study aimed to provide data for the Global Burden of Disease (GBD) study, as schistosiasis is listed as a priority by the Chinese government due to its significant health and economic impacts. A patient-based quality of life evaluation was performed on suspected and confirmed cases of schistosias japonica using a questionnaire and physical examination. Disability and morbidity were assessed using the European Quality of Life questionnaire with additional dimension (EQ-5D), ultrasonography, and laboratory testing. Age-specific disability weights for schosias japonica were estimated from patients' self-rated scores on a visual analogue scale. Relationships between health status, morbidity, and disability were explored using multivariate models. Of 506 candidates, 215 cases were confirmed as schias japonica and evaluated. Most patients reported impairments in at least one health dimension, such as pain or discomfort (90.7%), usual activities (87.9%), and anxiety or depression (80%). Overall disability weight was 0.447, and age-specific weights ranged from 0.378 among 30-44 years to 0.510 ≥60 years. Disability was associated with loss of work capacity, psychological abnormality, ascites, and hepatitis B virus, while splenectomy and albumin were protective for quality of life.
In sub-Saharan Africa, Human African Trypanosomiasis (HAT) and Animal Trypanosomiasis (AT) are prevalent parasitic diseases caused by the tset fly-borne protozoan Trypanosoma brucei (Tb). spp. spp. Humans acquire H through tset bites, with T. b. gambiense in West and Central Africa and T. rhodesiense in East and Southern Africa. A retrospective study used 1999 census data to estimate vulnerability and disability in Kenya's tset belts, assessing H infection potential in areas. A multilevel design estimated disability likelihood in individuals, households, and tset fly habitats with varying poverty levels. Residents and migrants aged 15-49 were studied. Tset's impact was conceptualized through two pathways: direct bites leading to H infection or indirect, A affecting agricultural production and livestock, leading to morbidity and mortality, nutritional deficiencies. Tset belts with increased disability prevalence were identified, direct and indirect pathways evaluated. Incorporating census data, surveillance may enhance H programs in sub-Saharan Africa. H and A burdens, and agricultural costs contribute to disability in tset areas. Future research will assess relationships between tset infestation and disability post-2009 census.
Hexamethylene bisacetamide (HMBA) is a potent inducer of cell differentiation and HIV production in chronically infected cells. Researchers investigated the mechanism of action of HMBA and found that it activates the PI3/Akt pathway, leading to the phosphorylation of HEXIM protein. This phosphorylation results in the release of positive transcription elongation factor (PTEF) from its transcriptionally inactive complex with HEXIM and 7 small nuclear RNA (snRNA). The released PF is then recruited to the HIV promoter to stimulate transcription and viral production. However, the released PF rapidly reassociates with 7snRNA and HEXIM in the presence of HM. A mutant HEX protein that cannot be phosphorylated and released PF and 7sn via PI/Akt pathway antagonizes HM-mediated induction of viral production.
Researchers have identified a link between the presence of Leishmania virus (LRV) and aggressive forms of cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL), including mucosal (ML) and disseminated cutaneous (DCL). LRV is associated with elevated parasitemia, hyperinflammation, and disease exacerbation. Studies on LRV in other Leish strains and species would benefit from improved detection and quantitation methods, independent of viral sequence knowledge. This study presents techniques for LRV detection, including an anti-dsRNA monoclonal antibody J, which recognizes dsRNA sequence-independently. Applications of J include immunofluorescence, ELISA, and dot blot, complementing nucleic acid purification and real-time PCR. Methods were evaluated and demonstrated LRV detection by J in several strains, patient samples, and infected mouse biopsies.
Enteropathogenic and enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EPEC and EHE) are closely related pathogens that adhere to intestinal epithelial cells, efface microvilli, and induce cytoskeletal rearrangements into protrusions called actin pedestals. PEC employs the tyrosine phosphorylated transmembrane receptor Tir, while EHE relies on the multivalent scaffolding protein EspF. The formation of pedestals correlates with bacterial colonization in animal models, but the function of pedest in infection is unclear. This study investigated the colonization of PEC and ECE during polarized epithelial cell infection. Both formed distinct bacterial communities, "macrocolonies", encompassing multiple host cells. Tir and EspF, as well as the Arp2/3 complex, were critical for colony expansion over time. Unexpectedly, EspF accelerated colony formation compared to PEC, as Esp-mediated actin assembly drove bacterial motility to junctions, where bacteria formed a pedestal on a neighboring cell and divided, allowing one daughter to disengage and infect the second. Data reveal Esp enhances epithelial colonization by actin-based motility and efficient cell-to-cell transmission.
Researchers compared two methods for purifying extracellular vesicles (EVs) from the excretory-secretory products of the helminth pathogen Fasciola hepatica: differential centrifugation (DC) and size exclusion chromatography (SEC). DC is the most commonly used method for EV purification, but SEC has been used for other pathogens. The study found that EVs purified by SEC were smaller and less diverse than those by DC, as shown by transmission and atomic force microscopy. Protein quantification and Western blotting showed SEC yielded a higher purity of EV to excretory-secretory protein (ESP) ratio compared to DC, with reduced soluble cathepsin proteases in SEC EV. Proteomic analysis revealed DC contamination from ESP, with increased protein identifications and peptide hits in DC EV compared to SEC. SEC EV contained less tegument proteins than DC EV. The study suggests DC and SEC do not isolate equivalent EV populations and caution is needed when choosing purification methods, with DC including free proteins and tegument artefacts. SEC is proposed for EV purification before downstream studies.
Researchers employed a reverse engineering approach to study post-transcriptional regulation in Drosophila melanogaster, focusing on the gap genes Krpp, knir, and giant. This method involves fitting models to data to infer and analyze regulatory mechanisms, requiring rigorous methods to determine parameter identifiability in complex biological contexts. Quantitative datasets of mRNA and protein expression were used to fit a post-transcription regulation model, establishing its structural and practical identifiability. Results show post-transcription is not required for patterning in this system, but necessary for protein control levels. The study demonstrates model uniqueness and specificity can be rigorously determined in spatio-temporal formation, increasing reverse engineering potential for development and complex biological processes.
Researchers investigated the age-dependent mechanisms of the intestinal epithelial immune response to rotavirus infection in a mouse model. They found that Toll-like receptor 3 (TLR3) expression was low in the epithelium of suckling mice but increased during the postnatal period, inversely correlating with rotavirus susceptibility, viral shedding, and histological damage. Adult mice deficient in TLR3 or the adaptor molecule TRIF (TRIFL2) exhibited higher viral shedding and decreased epithelial pro-inflammatory and antiviral gene expression compared to wild-type animals. In contrast, neonatal mice deficient in TLR or TRIF did not display impaired stimulation or enhanced rotavirus susceptibility. Using chimeric mice, a major contribution of non-hematopoietic cell in TRIF-mediated antiral response was detected in adult. A significant age-dependent increase of TLR expression was also detected in human intestinal biops. Upregulation of epithelial TLR during infancy might contribute to age-dependent rotavirus susceptibility.
Researchers conducted a whole-exome sequencing (WES) analysis of 1,039 individuals with autism spectrum disorders (ASD) and 870 controls from the National Human Genome Repository (NH) with similar ancestry to the cases. Two sequencing centers used different methods to produce and call variants from the data. To ensure similar distribution of rare variation, variants were filtered by fraction of missing data, read depth, and balance of alternative reads. Seven samples were sequenced at both centers, and results were evaluated by association study. The goal was to determine how to combine data and results from centers. Gene-based association analysis was chosen, but whether to combine statistics across centers (meta-analysis) or data and then analyze (mega) was debated. Due to many gene-based tests, mega-analysis was shown to have better power than meta-analysis. Before analysis, the impact of population structure on rare variants in data was explored. Population structure was found to confound case-control studies by clustering variants in ancestry, but principal-based analyses controlled for ancestry and produced appropriate distributions. Using gene tests and both meta and mega-analysis, no new ASD risk genes were found. Results suggest gene tests require larger samples and controls for discovery, even for a disorder like ASD.
Researchers conducted a retrospective study to investigate the association between polymorphisms in the chitriosase gene and the risk of mycetoma due to Madure myetatis in a Sudanese population. Madure myet is the most prevalent causative agent of eumetoma in Sudan, characterized by the formation of grains, but only a small number of exposed individuals develop infection. The fungus contains chitin in its cell wall, which can trigger the human immune response. Polymorphisms in genes encoding chitin-degrading enzymes chitriosase and AMCase were identified, resulting in altered chitin activity. The study analyzed 112 eetoma patients and 103 controls for polymorphisms, including a 24-b insertion in the chitrios gene (rs1317) leading to impaired chitin activity and single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) in AM (617) resulting in decreased AM activity. Additionally, SNPs (41292) and 10-b insertion in 5'UTR of AM (143) were studied, resulting in increased AM activity. DNA from blood was isolated and genotypes determined using PCR-RP. Histological staining confirmed chitin presence in fungal grains. The polym resulting in decreased chitrios activity was associated with increased eoma risk (odds ratio 2.9; p=0.004). No association was found for polymorphisms in genes AM (all>0.05).
Herpes simplex virus (HSV) has traditionally been studied as a model for viral latency with distinct acute and latent phases. However, recent evidence suggests that the latent phase may not be as quiescent as previously thought, with lytic genes being transcribed during this state. Immunological studies have shown that activated T cells persist in the nervous system during latency, but translation of these transcripts has not been confirmed. This study uses a highly sensitive Cre-reporting model to show that lytic and latent phases are not as distinct as previously thought. Firstly, half of the viral spread to latently infected sites occurs beyond the initial infection. Secondly, direct evidence shows that lytic promoters drive protein expression during latency.
Misfolding and aggregation of proteins are key features of neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, frontotemporal dementia, and prion diseases, where misfolded proteins accumulate through seeded polymerization. In prion diseases, host protein misfolds to a pathogenic, protease-resistant PrP, which accumulates in neurons, astroglia, and microglia in the CNS. A study using dual-staining immunohistochemistry compared PrSc accumulation in early post-infection in three scrapie strains differing in brain pathology. Pr from each strain had distinct cell specificity: Strain 22 with astroglia, ME with neurons and neurop in thalamus and cortex, and RML similar to 22 in substantia nigra. Expression of neuroinflammatory genes was studied using mRNA from thalamus pre-infection. Surprisingly, despite PrSc differences, upregulated genes were similar for all strains, with small differences correlating with disease tempo. Gene upregulation correlated with astrogl and microia activation before vacu pathology or clinical signs. Prion profile differed from viral CNS diseases Larosse and polytropic retroirus with similar gliosis levels.
Researchers have developed a new approach to model the 3D organization of chromosomes using coarse-grained models of self-avoiding polymers on a lattice. Chromosomes are long, densely packed, and topologically constrained polymers, making it challenging to investigate their multi-spatio-temporal scales. The proposed strategy accounts for polymer entanglement and volumic density, capturing steady-state and dynamical properties, as well as dynamics at different coarse-graining scales. This method offers a significant numerical efficiency gain and a systematic way to define coarse-grained models for chromosomes, overcoming current limitations by studying chromosomes over extended periods with good statistics. The approach was used to investigate the 3D organization of chromosome 3 (20 Mbp) in Drosophila during a cell cycle (20 hours). A combination of coarse-graining with a one-parameter copolymer model integrating epigen-driven interactions quantitatively reproduces experimental data at chromosome-scale and predicts chromatin is dynamic during the cycle.
Researchers conducted an integrative analysis of expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) and cis-regulatory elements to elucidate the mechanisms underlying cell specificity of QTL. They analyzed QTL data from 11 studies across 7 cell types and integrated it with cis-regulatory element (CRE) data from the ENCODE project. A set of classifiers was built to predict cell specificity of QTL, revealing associations with hundreds of cell-specific CRE classes, including enhancers, promoters, repressive chromatin marks, open chromatin, and DNA-binding proteins. These associations provide insight into molecular mechanisms generating cell specificity of QTL and regulation. A random forest classifier with CRE-SNP overlap features demonstrated predicting cell specificity QTL feasibility. CRE from trait-associated cell types were used to annotate GWAS in absence of QTL data for that type. The study aims to improve understanding mechanistic basis of human phenotypic variation through integrative predictive modeling of specificity.
Researchers have developed a Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cell line that limits glycosylation to mannose-5 (Man5) or earlier intermediates using the CRISPR/Cas9 gene editing system. This was achieved by inactivating the Mannosyl Alpha-1,3-Glycoprotein Beta-2-N-Acetylglucosyltransferase (MGAT1) gene. The resulting cell line, MG1-CHO, produces monomeric gp120 with improved binding to glycan-dependent broadly neutralizing monoclonal antibodies (NAb) directed to the V1/V domain (e.g. PG9) and V3 stem (e.g. PGT and 10-107) while preserving glycan-independent epitopes (e.g. V01). The MG-CHO cell line's ability to limit glycosylation to early intermediates without impairing doubling time or growth at high cell densities suggests it will be useful for biopharm production of HIV-1 immunogens. The development of this cell line addresses the challenge of producing vaccine immunogens displaying glycan epitopes that are intermediates in the N-linked glycosylation pathway. This pathway alters the mass and net charge of envelope proteins compared to those with mature, sialic-containing carbohydrates. Many broadly neutralizing monoclonal antibodies to HIV-1 envelope protein gp120 recognize epitopes consisting of both amino and glycan residues, with glycans required for binding being intermediates in the N-linked glycosylation pathway. Cell lines suitable for biopharm production that limit glycosylation to Man5 or earlier intermediates are not readily available.
Researchers have identified trehalose-6-phosphatase (TPP) from the parasitic nematode Brugia malayi as a potential target for anthelmintic drugs. This enzyme is essential for the nematode's survival, as accumulation of trehalose-6-phosphate is toxic in the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans. T6 has also been shown to be essential in Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The X-ray crystal structure of T from B. malayi revealed a stabilizing N-terminal MIT domain and a catalytic C-terminal C2-type H phosphatase fold. Structure-guided mutagenesis and kinetic analyses with competitive inhibitor trehal 6-sulf identified five residues crucial for binding and catalysis. A model of the T6-trehalose-phosphate complex was proposed, indicating a substrate-binding mode driven by shape complementarity and van der Waals interactions. This differs from sucrose-6-phosphatase, which relies on extensive hydrogen-bond interactions. The results suggest high-affinity inhibitors will bind by exploiting substrate-like binding to the phosphoryl pocket while utilizing non-native binding to trehal pocket. Conservation of key residues enforcing the substrate shape in TPP enzymes implies broad-range anthelmic and antibacterial therapeutics may be developed using this platform.
Researchers have developed a computational framework to simulate blood and interstitial fluid transport in heterogeneous tumors, taking into account their unique vascular architectures. The model combines Poiseuille and Darcy equations to describe vascular and interstitial flow, respectively, and incorporates spatially heterogeneous vessel and interstitial permeabilities to accurately predict tumor fluid dynamics. This platform enables controlled experiments to investigate how tumor vascular heterogeneity affects fluid transport. The model was applied to an orthotopic murine glioma and human colorectal carcinoma, and sensitivity analysis revealed key mechanisms determining fluid transport. Modifying vascular and interstitial parameters showed that realistic vasculature is crucial for contrasting fluid response between tumors. Contrary to literature, reducing interstitial pressure does not increase perfusion; instead, therapies should target interstitial pressure gradient. Stabilizing vessel diameters and permeabilities are not responses to normalization, but may alter conductivity. Normalizing interstitial environment may increase perfusion within tumors.
Researchers investigated the role of cell-to-cell transmission in HIV-1 infection and its susceptibility to neutralizing antibodies and entry inhibitors. They developed experimental strategies to distinguish between cell-free and cell-to-cell transmission and found that the efficacy of neutralizing monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) and entry inhibitors varied depending on their mode of action. Monoclonal antibodies targeting the gp41 region remained active against cell-to-cell transmission, while those targeting the CD4 binding site (CDbs), including the potent neutralizing mAb VRC01, showed reduced potency. This suggests that CDbs mAbs preferentially block free virus transmission, allowing HIV to spread through cell-cell contacts.
Researchers have proposed a new model to explain the diverse effects of attention on neural firing rates and receptive field structure in the visual system. The model suggests that top-down attentional modulation on higher visual areas, such as V4 and MT, can produce the observed effects on neural responses. The model requires the existence of feedback connections between areas and short-range inhibition within each area. Feedback redistributes top-down modulation to lower areas, altering inputs to higher cells, including those not initially modulated. This produces firing rate modulations and receptive shifts. Simultaneously, short-range inhibition between neighboring cells produces competitive effects scaling receptive field size. The model reproduces attentional effects on rates (response gain, input, gain, competition scaled receptive size) and receptive structure (shifts, resizing spatial, feature) without modifying parameters. It also predicts attentional response curves shift from gain to contrast as focus drifts from cell.
In Drosophila, a group of specialized cells called the posterior signalling centre (PSC) plays a crucial role in controlling blood cell homeostasis in the larval hematopoietic organ, the lymph gland, similar to the microenvironment of hematopoietic stem cells in vertebrates. The SC acts non-autonomously to maintain janus tyrosine kinase/signal transducers and activators (J/STAT) signalling in hematietic progenitors (proocytes), preserving their multipotency for differentiation into lamlocytes, a dedicated immune cell type required to fight specific threats such as wasp parasism. A study using a knockout generated by homologous recombination found that a type I cytokine-related receptor CG142/Lat is required to switch off J/STAT signalling in proocytes, a prerequisite for lamlocyte differentiation upon wasp parasism. In vivo and cell assays showed Lat forms heteromers with Domeless, a Doph type cytokine signalling related to mammalian GP130, and antagonizes Dome activity in a dose-dependent manner. Analysis revealed a primary response to wasp parasism is a decrease in cytok mRNA in the gland, followed by an increase in Lat/Dome ratio. This sequence culminates in complete inhibition of J/STAT by Lat. J/STAT is associated with human diseases including leukaemia, while knockout mice studies indicate a central role in hematopoies and immune regulation. Doph Lat function is the first in vivo example of a nonsignalling controlling a dedicated response, raising whether nonsign also control vertebrate cellular immunity.
Genetic recombination is a significant process in the evolution of various species, particularly among begomoviruses in the single-stranded DNA family Geminiridae. Non-random recombination distributions within begovirus genomes sampled from nature result from variations in basal recombination rates across genomes and overall viability of recombinant genomes. Factors influencing basal recombination include sequence similarity between recomb genomes, nucleic acid structures, and genomic sensitivity to nucleases. Viability of recombinant genomes is influenced by co-evolved protein-protein and nucleotide interactions disrupted by recombination. This study investigates recombination patterns in 120-day experimental infections of tomato plants with begoviruses Tomato yellow curl virus and Tomato curl virus. Sequence exchange between viruses is complex, with evidence that local sequence similarity, not genomic structure, influences recombination breakpoints. Selection against recombinants with disrupted intra-gen interactions, such as protein and nucleic folding, is observed. Strong selection preserves co-evolved protein-protein and DNA interactions, allowing identification of sequence tracts involved in interactions.
Nucleosomes, the fundamental units of eukaryotic chromatin, have been implicated in the evolution of eukotic genomes through their influence on DNA mutation propensity and selection. Contrary to the notion that nucleosomes are unique to eukotes, histone proteins have been found in archaeal genomes. However, archaeal nucleosomes differ significantly from eukotic counterparts in histone composition and assembly. This study investigates the relationship between nucleosome footprints and evolution in humans and the archaeon Haloferaxii. Despite differences in nucleosome structure, the association between nucleosome footprints and sequence is conserved between the two species. The study examines whether mutation or selection can explain concord substitution patterns, but finds neither model sufficient to explain the observed association. Instead, nucleosome substitution patterns are consistent with a model where sequence divergence leads to frequent nucleosome repositioning during evolution. Nucleosome reposition is shown to be both necessary and sufficient to explain the association between current nucleosome positions and biased substitution. This finding highlights the importance of considering causality between genetic and epigenetic change.
Researchers have investigated the role of conformational diversity in protein function and its modulation by ligand binding. They propose that different ligands shift the conformation equilibrium through high-affinity conformers, and intramolecular vibrational dynamics facilitate conformation transitions, which may be associated with evolutionary conserved traits. A novel method was developed to identify key positions sustaining conformation associated with ligand binding, applied to a dataset of 188 protein structures in bound and unbound forms. Normal modes involved in conformation change were selected based on overlap with ligand-induced distortions, and a subspace defined to analyze mutation effects on conformation diversity. A negative correlation was found between mutation effects on normal subspaces and ligand-binding and evolutionary conservation. Positions altering these subspaces were identified as key, mediating ligand-conformation change, mostly conserved, buried aliphatic residues in regular regions like β-sheets and α-helix.
Researchers investigated the role of fructose-1,6-bisphosphate aldolase (FBA) in Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) by engineering a strain with regulated FBA levels using anhyrotacycline. Depletion of FBA led to clearance of M in both acute and chronic phases of infection in vivo and loss of viability in vitro when cultured on single carbon sources. However, consistent with M's ability to co-catabolize multiple sources, viability could be restored when cultured on mixtures of glycolytic and gluogenic sources, enabling generation of F knockout (Δ). In vitro studies of Δ revealed lack of F could only be compensated by specific balance of glucose and butyrate, with butyrate metabolism determined by M's ability to coatabol glucose. These findings evaluate F as a potential target in both replicating and persistent M, and expand understanding of conditions defining M's F in vivo.
Researchers investigated the role of the mitochondrial 2-cysteine peroxiredoxin (TXNPx) in Leishmania infantum, a parasite that lacks catalase and selenium-glutathione peroxidases. A gene replacement strategy was used to create TXNP null mutants (txn−), which were indistinguishable from wild-type promastigotes, but unable to thrive in a murine infection model. Unexpectedly, the avirulence of txn− was not due to lack of peroxidase activity, as TXx behaved like controls when exposed to exogenous oxidants or generated by macrophage phagocytosis in vivo. txn− were also avulent in hosts unable to mount an oxidative phagocyte response (B6.47ox/− and B.R2/−IF− mice). The perase activity of TXx is not required for parasite survival in mice was shown by rescuing the non-infect phenotype of txn with a peraseinactive version of the protein. A novel function is proposed for TXx as a molecular chaperone, which explains impaired infectivity of mutants. This is based on suppression of citrate synthase aggregation in vitro. txn− were more sensitive to temperature shift from 25°C to 37°C, reminiscent of organisms lacking chone genes. The findings change the paradigm of trypanoid 2-cyste peroxins as peroxide-eliminating devices and demonstrate 2-cyst peroxins can be determinant for pathogenic independently of perase activity.
Researchers conducted a multicenter, prospective diagnostic study to evaluate the accuracy of Histoplas urine antigen (HAg) for diagnosing disseminated histoplasis (PD) in HIV patients. The study included 288 patients with suspected PD from two secondary and tertiary care facilities in Mexico. The reference standard for diagnosis was Histlas capsulatum growth in blood, bone marrow, and tissue cultures or histopathologic examination. Results showed that 29.5% of patients had PD. The sensitivity of HAg was 67.1% and specificity was 97.5.5. The positive likelihood ratio was 27.2. In 10.5% of patients with PD, a co-infection was diagnosed, mostly disseminated Mycobacterium complex. The study found high specificity but low sensitivity of HAg. The test may be useful for starting antifungal treatment, but a culture-based approach is necessary since co-infections are frequent and a negative result does not rule out PD.
Diarrhea is a leading cause of significant morbidity and mortality in children worldwide, with approximately 1.8 million deaths annually and millions of non-fatal episodes. In up to 40% of cases, the etiologic agent remains unidentified. Metagenomic analysis offers a systematic and unbiased characterization of microbial populations, enabling the detection of novel viruses in stool specimens. This study employed a metagenomic approach to characterize viral communities in diarrhea specimens from 12 children using a "micro-sequencing" strategy requiring minimal sample quantity (<100mg), minimal purification, and limited sequencing (384 reads/sample). Known enteric viruses were detected, as well as multiple putatively novel sequences with limited similarity to GenBank.
A comparative analysis of Zika and deng outbreaks in the Dominican Republic was conducted using national surveillance data. The study aimed to investigate the transmission dynamics of these flaviviruses following a large deng epidemic in the country. Retrospective datasets were used to collect information on populations at risk, and descriptive statistics were applied to describe the outbreaks on a national scale. Results showed that 75% of deng cases were reported in individuals under 20 years old, while Zika infections were more dispersed among the population. Dengue rates were higher among males (25.9 per 10,000 population) compared to females (21.5 per 10,000). Zika infections were highly clustered among females (73.8%, 95% CI 72.6, 75.0; p<0.05), with adjusted rates 7.64 per 10,000 among females and 2.72 per 10,000 among males. Stratification by sex revealed higher rates among females (1.84, 1.82,1.87; p<0.05) compared to males (1.72 1.69,1.75; p0.05). However, GBS rates stratified by sex showed higher risk in males (0.62) compared to females (0.57 per 10,000). The study found little impact of existing deng immunity on Zika attack rates at the population level. Confounding of R and incident calculations by sex-specific reporting may alter reliability of epidemiological metrics, which could be addressed using proxy syndromes or conditions to explore sex-skewed incidence. Findings suggest awareness campaigns influencing short-term health behavior increased reporting among women of reproductive age, although biological susceptibility cannot be ruled out. Media and screening are recommended for women of reproductive age during Zika outbreaks. Future research should focus on Zika outcomes among deng seropositive individuals.
Poly(ADP-ribose) polymerases (PARs) are enzymes that catalyze the transfer of poly(ADP-ri) units onto target proteins. In Arabidopsis thaliana, PAR2 (Atg0230) is the predominant poly(ADP-ri) polymerase in response to DNA damage and genotoxic stresses caused by bleomycin, mitomycin, or gamma-radiation. In contrast to humans, where PAR1 accounts for 90% of cellular PAR activity, PAR2 makes the greatest contribution to PAR activity and organismal viability in Arabidopsis. PAR2 has SAP binding motifs rather than zinc finger domains common in plant and animal PAR1 proteins. PAR2 contributes more than PAR1 to plant immune responses, including restriction of Pseudomonas syringae growth and reduction of infection-associated DNA-strand breaks. Poly(AD-ri)glycohydrolase (PARG) enzymes show Arabidopsis P1 and not P2 are major contributors to poly(AD-ri) removal from acceptor proteins. PAR2 activity is influenced by PAR1 and P1, and PAR2 and PAR physically interact with P1 and P2, suggesting regulatory interactions among mediators of poly(AD-rib). Plant PAR and P proteins are structurally distinct from animal counterparts, indicating substantial differences in regulation.
In Caenorhabditis elegans, the PHR protein RPM-1 regulates synapse formation and axon termination through its ubiquitin ligase activity, inhibiting the DLK-1 and MLK-1 MAP kinase pathways. Research has identified a new MAP kinase pathway that suppresses synapse formation defects in mechanosensory neurons of rpm-1 mutants, but not axon termination defects. This pathway includes M-15 (MAPK), NSY-1 (MAPK), JKK-1 (MAPK), and JNK-1 (MAP) kinases. Overexpression of these kinases in the M-15/J-1 pathway impairs synapse formation in wild-type animals. The M-15/J-1 pathway functions autonomously in mechanensory neurons and localizes to presynaptic terminals, indicating a role in synapse development. Loss of M-15/J-1 signaling suppresses habituation to repeated mechanical stimuli in rpm-1 mutants, a behavioral deficit linked to impaired glutamatergic synapse formation. Habituation is consistent with M-15/J-1 functioning as a parallel pathway to RPM-1, indicating M-15/J-1 restricts glutamateric synapse and short-term learning.
Researchers investigated the evolutionary changes in the bipotential switch that controls the sperm/oocyte decision in hermaphroditic nematodes. They confirmed that the sex-determination protein TR-1 (TRA-1) is bipotential, capable of activating or repressing the same target gene in response to upstream signals. A co-factor was identified and used to explore the structure of the bipot switch during evolution. Null mutants revealed that C. brigae TR-1 is required for spermatogenesis, and RNA interference showed it works as part of the Histone Acetylase complex. RT-PCR data demonstrated it promotes C-f-3, a gene needed for spermatogenesis. Epistasis tests showed TR-1 works through TR-1 to activate C-f and control the sperm/oocyte decision. Since TR-1 can also repress-f, these observations demonstrate it bipotential. TR- regulates the male tail development. C-tra C-tr- double mutants resemble C-null mutants, two branches control TR- activity. Differences in the relationship between branches have arisen during evolution. C brigae TR- null prevent hermroditic sperogenesis, but C-f null, which disrupt the other half. On the other hand, C null prevent spermatogenesis but C-tr. Synthetic interactions confirm both halves exist each species.
Researchers have proposed two new measures, ΦE and ΦAR, to quantify the integrated information generated by a system as it transitions between states, addressing the limitations of the existing measure ΦDM, which is defined for discrete Markov systems and rarely applicable in biology. The new measures can be applied to time-series data. Simulations demonstrate their practicality and explore properties. The results provide opportunities to examine integration in real and model systems, and implications for relations between integrated information, consciousness, and neurocognitive processes. The findings challenge theories attributing physical meaning to measured quantities.
Researchers conducted a study to investigate the spread of Rhodesian African trypanosomiasis (HAT) in Uganda, focusing on environmental and climatic factors influencing its distribution. A previous study used logistic regression to examine the relationship between HAT prevalence and social, environmental, and climatic variables in two affected districts, suggesting the disease spread was due to infected, untreated livestock movement. This study extended the analysis to account for spatial autocorrelation, uncertainty in data and model parameters, and predictive mapping of future H prevalence. A Bayesian generalized linear geostatistical model was used to account for spatial autocorrelation and uncertainty, resulting in more accurate parameter estimates and increased predictive accuracy. The analysis supported the theory that H was introduced via untreated, infected livestock movement from endemic areas. Health care accessibility and land temperature effects on H distribution were also confirmed. Predictive mapping showed increased H risk in areas surrounding livestock markets, highlighting the importance of trading in disease spread.
In the 1970s, the consensus that complexity leads to stability in ecosystems was challenged by ecologically-inspired approaches, which assumed the existence of a feasible equilibrium with positive abundances. However, this assumption has not been tested. Analytical results and simulations show that equilibrium vanishes in species-rich systems, leaving the existence of a feasible equilibrium in stability criteria far from granted. The study extends the analysis by changing interaction structure and intensity, finding that feasibility and stability are warranted regardless of species richness with weak interactions. Dynamical behavior of ecologically-inspired architectures differs from unstructured systems. Results suggest understanding ecosystem dynamics requires interplay between interaction strength and architecture.
A cross-sectional study was conducted in Western Kenya to assess the epidemiology of Coxiella burnetii, the causative agent of Q fever, in humans and cattle. Serum samples from 204 humans and 955 cattle in 416 households were analyzed for C. burnii antibodies, along with questionnaires on demographic, socio-economic, and husbandry information. Data were linked to environmental datasets on geographical locations, such as land cover. Correlation and spatial correlation analyses were applied to assess the link between cattle and human seroprevalence. Multilevel regression was used to assess relationships between socio-economic, demographic, and environmental factors and seropositivity in humans and animals. The overall seroprevalence of C. burnii was 2.5% in humans and 10.5% in cattle. No correlation was found between cattle and human serreval within households or spatial proximity to other households. Multile modelling indicated several factors for exposure to organism cattle from market as opposed to homestead and residing areas with lower precipitation had highest serreval. For humans, the youngest age group had highest odds of serositivity, variations between ethnic groups, and frequent livestock contact (grazing and dealing material) was a factor.
Researchers have sequenced the genomes of the blood flukes Schistosoma japonicum, S. mansoni, and S. haematobium, and used functional approaches to identify the role and importance of newly described schistosome genes. A genetic model system for Schistosoma has been established, enabling gain-of-function and loss-of-function, vector-based RNA interference, and forward genetics for insertional mutagenesis screens. To expedite routine transgenesis in Schistosomes, germ cells need to be reliably cultured. Vasa, a member of the ATP-dependent DEAD-box helicase family, is a primordial germ cell marker in Metazoa. Bioinformatics identified 33 putative DEAD-box helicases in S. mansoni with conserved motifs. Three helicases exhibited Vasa-like sequences, phylogenetic analysis confirmed three Vasa-like genes Smv1, Sm2, and Sm3 as members of the Vasa/10 DEAD subfamily. Transcripts Sm1, Sm2, and Sm3 were cloned from adult cDNAs, and real-time PCR showed presence in S. mans stages with elevated expression in sporocysts, females, eggs, miracidia, and undeveloped eggs. Whole-mount in situ hybridization (WISH) revealed Sm1, Sm, and Sm3 transcribed in the ovary oocytes. Germ-specific expression of schist Vasa-like genes provides a landmark for Schist germ line transgenesis, etiologic agents of major tropical diseases.
Heart valve disease is a significant clinical concern worldwide, necessitating precise regulation of cardiac valve development and homeostasis. The Hippo signaling pathway is crucial for organ and tissue development, but its role in valve formation and maintenance is unclear. VGL4, a transcriptional coactivator in vertebrates, is predominantly expressed in valve interstitial cells at the post-embryonic stage and persists into adulthood. Tissue-specific knockout of V4 in cell lineages revealed that loss of V4 in endothelial cells resulted in valve malformation and increased expression of YAP targets. Further, semi-knockout of Y in V4-ablated hearts constrained hyperproliferation of valve interstitial cells.
Recent studies have reported the presence of soft sweeps in various organisms, including humans, Drosophila, and HIV, with large-scale analyses suggesting their pervasiveness across different population sizes and mutation rates. However, others have questioned the relevance of these models to natural populations and their identifiability from other processes, suggesting sweeps are likely rare. This study reconciles opposing results by evaluating three recent studies and their methodologies. Using population theory and simulation, it is found that all three are prone to high false-positive rates, incorrectly identifying sweeps under both hard and neutral models. Additionally, it is demonstrated that demographic histories combined with hard sweeps provide a more parsimonious explanation. The findings address the tendency to invoke parameter-heavy, assumption-laden models of positive selection, neglecting proper demographic model construction.
Female Aedes aegypt mosquitoes, the primary vector for dengue fever, exhibit inhibited host-seeking behavior for three days following a blood meal due to a hemolymph-borneal factor, Peptide. The mechanism of this suppression and the receptor involved are unknown. Peptide shows similarity to Neurope-F (NPF) peptides, which signal through Neurope Y (PY)-Like Receptors (PYLR). Eight PYRs were identified in the Ae. aegyti genome and screened in a cell-based assay for sensitivity to a panel of peptides. Four PYRs responded to one or more ligands, with NYR1 responding to Peptide and NPF. Two PYR homologs in the Lyme disease vector Ix scularis were also sensitive to Peptide. Injection of synthetic Peptide and NPF inhibited host-seeking in non-fed females, while buffer or inactive Pe[C10 had no effect. To determine if PY1 is necessary for host-seeking inhibition, zinc-fingerases generated five npy1 mutants, which displayed normal behavior in locomotion, egg, sugar, feeding, blood, and host-seeking, but not host-seeking after meal. This study identified four Ae.egi PYRs and PY1 as a candidate NPF receptor sensitive to Pe. However, PY1 is not required for host-seeking, suggesting other receptors, peptides, or both regulate this behavior.
A study was conducted to model the risk of schistosomiasis transmission in Akure Local Government Area, Ondo State, Nigeria, using satellite-derived environmental data. The research aimed to identify areas with suitable conditions for schistosomias transmission based on physical and environmental factors from satellite imagery and spatial analysis. A multicriteria evaluation (CE) using Sa's Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP) was employed to determine the weight of importance of each schosiasis factor. Temperature, drainage, elevation, rainfall, and land use/cover were identified as controlling factors in schosias incidence in the area. These factors were reclassified and overlaid to identify areas vulnerable to schosias. Weighted analysis was done after each factor was given weight through the hierarchical process. The prevalence of schias in the area was determined by parasitological analysis of urine samples through random sampling. Results showed varying schias risk, with 82% of the area falling under high and very risk category. Community O I had the lowest schias risk, while risk increased in communities I, Igoba, It Ogb, and Ogb. Predictions by the model correlated with observations from study. High zones corresponded to endemic communities. Environmental factors were used in identifying and predicting schias transmission as well as monitoring disease in rural and agricultural communities.
Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumoc) meningitis, a bacterial infection of the brain, is characterized by the presence of cholesterol-dependent cytolys pneumolys, a key factor in determining neuropathogenic potential of pneumoc. Post-mortem brain samples from individuals with pneumoc meningitis show selective loss of synapses in superficial layers of frontal cortex. Similar effect observed in mice with pneumoc meningitis when bacteria express pore-form cholesterol cytol pneumolys. Mouse brain slices exposed to pore-compet pneumol at disease-relevant concentrations exhibit dendritic swelling, spine elimination, and synaptic loss. NMDA glutamate receptor antagonists MK801 and DAP reduce this pathology. Pneumolys increase glutamate levels in brain slices. In astrocytes, pneumol initiate glutamate release in calcium-dependent manner. Pneumol play significant role in pneumoc mening by initiating glutamate release from astrocytes, leading to glutamate-dependent synaptic damage.
Human papillomaviruses (HPVs) are DNA viruses associated with major human cancers, and developing new prevention methods such as vaccines and microbicides requires understanding their life cycle. The HPV life cycle is linked to the state of the stratified epithelium it infects, with progeny virus made in the terminally differentiating supasal compartment. It has been recognized that HPV first establishes infection in the basal layer of stratified epithelium, but the reason is not understood. This might reflect specificity of entry receptors, but not fully explain differentiation of infection, as many cells can be infected in monolayer culture. We used biology to reveal that cell progression through mitosis is critical for HPV. Using HPV16 particles with intact genome, synchronized human keratinocytes as hosts, and viral expression as read for infection, cells must enter M phase for infection to take place. Late phase inhibitors had no effect, whereas G, S, G, and M phase inhibitors prevented infection. Cells need to pass prophase for successful transcription of encapsated genes. These provide reason HPVs establish in basal compartment of epithel. Only this compartment contains cells through cycle, and only in these HPVs can establish. Defining susceptibility to HPV, results have implications for control.
Researchers have identified microRNA-like RNAs (milRNAs) in the dimorphic fungus Penicillium marffei, a common cause of systemic mycosis in China and Southeast Asia. While miRNAs play a crucial role in gene regulation in animals and plants, their function in fungi is less understood. Using high-throughput sequencing, milRNAs were found to be more abundant in mycelial than yeast phase, with 24 potential candidates identified, including 17 in mycel and 7 yeast. Two genes, d-1 and d-2, encoding Dicer-like proteins, and q-2 encoding Argonaute, were found in P. marffei. Phylogenetic analysis showed d-2 of P. marffei is closely related to homologs in other dimorphic pathogenic fungi, suggesting co-evolution. d-2 among thermal fungi. d-2 demonstrated higher expression in mycel than yeast by 7-fold (p<0.001). Northern analysis confirmed expression of milRN PMil-M and PMil-M only in mycel. Deletion mutants showed biogenesis of milRN dependent on d-2 but not d- or q-. mRNA levels of predicted targets of PMil-M were upregulated in knockdown PMilKD, supporting regulatory function milRN. This study provides first evidence for differential mil expression in growth phases of dim fungi and sheds light on evolution of proteins in mil biogenesis and post-transcriptional control in dimorphism.
Zika virus (ZIK) emerged in French Polynesia in 2013 and spread through the Pacific region between 2013 and 2017. Several Aedes mosquitoes may have contributed to ZIK transmission, including Aedes aegypt, the main vector in the region, and Aedesynensis, vector of lymphatic filariasis and secondary vector dengue. This study analyzed the ability of these vectors to transmit ZIK at a regional scale by comparing the competence of Ae aegi and Aynesis populations from Pacific islands for ZIK strain circulated during 2013-2017 outbreak. Field Aeegi (three populations) and Ayn (two) from Pacific were collected. Female mosquitoes were exposed to ZIK (107 TCID/mL) isolated in 2014. At 6, 9, and 21 post-infection, bodies, thorax, abdomen, and heads were analyzed for infection, dissemination, transmission, and transmission rates, respectively. Results showed ZIK infection rates were heterogeneous between Aeeg populations, but dissemination rates were moderate and homogenous between these. For Ayn, infection rates were less heterogeneous between two populations. Transmission efficiency revealed low competence for ZIK of different Ae populations. Results indicated low Z transmission by Aeeg and Ayn from Pacific. This suggests other factors, such as vector density, lifespan, or immunologically naive fraction of population, contributed to rapid spread of ZIK in Pacific during 201-2017.
Researchers have developed a new method called Targeted StructureSeq to study the structure of the long non-coding RNA (lnc) Xist, a key regulator of X-chromosome inactivation in mammalian cells. Xist and other lncRNAs rely on thermodynamically stable secondary and higher-order structures formed in cells. Targeted StructureSeq combines chemical probing of RNA in cells with massively parallel sequencing, enriching for signals from the RNA of interest to achieve high coverage with few reads, providing a scalable approach to analyze RNA conformation in cells. This method was used to probe full-length Xist lRNA, revealing new models for functional elements within Xist, including the A element in the 5'-end of X. Analysis also identified conserved structural elements Xist, a new proximal to repeats important for X function.
Researchers have identified numerous genetic variants associated with complex diseases, raising questions about the clinical utility of risk prediction based on genomic profiles. To evaluate the performance of genetic prediction models, appropriate statistical measures are needed. Previous studies primarily used the area under the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve (AUC) curve, but it has limitations and should be complemented by other measures. This study develops a unifying framework connecting various predictive indices. Given disease probability and heritability explained by genetic variants, it is possible to analytically estimate multiple metrics, including AUC, mean difference between cases and non-cases, net reclassification improvement, proportion of cases by specific population percentile, variance of predicted risks, and risk at any percentile. The framework also enables visualization of model performance through ROC curve, risk density, and predictiveness curve. Simulations match theoretical estimates. The methodology is applied to nine diseases, evaluating predictive power of genetic tests on known variants for each trait.
Researchers evaluated the accuracy of a new rapid diagnostic test for Trypanosoma brucei gambiense infection, the parasite causing African trypanosomiasis, using recombinant antigens. The study compared the new test, SDOL HAT 2.0, with a rapid test using native antigens, SDOLAT, and the traditional Card agglutination Test for Trypanosomias (CATT). A total of 57,632 individuals were screened in the Democratic Republic of Congo, with 260 cases confirmed by parasitology. SDOLAT 2.0 had the highest sensitivity at 71.2%, followed by CATT 62.5% and SDAT 59%. CATT had the highest specificity at 99.2%, while SDOLAT and SDOL 2.0 had 98.9% and 98.1% respectively. Sensitivity was lower than expected due to cases from overlapping populations. All tests were more sensitive in passive than active screening. Combining tests increased sensitivity: SDAT with SDOL 2.0 reached 98.4% in passive and 83% in active. The recombinant-based test was as sensitive and specific as SDAT, but less specific than CATT.
In a region of Guatemala with persistent Triatoma infestation, Chagas disease, a neglected tropical disease affecting millions of Latin Americans, has been effectively controlled through multiple rounds of indoor insecticide spraying (IRS). However, a few foci remain, including the municipality of Comapa, Department of Juti, where interventions appear less effective. Three cross-sectional entomological and serological surveys were conducted in Comapa to evaluate a decade of vector control activities. Baseline serological (1999) and entomological (2001-2) surveys were followed by three rounds of insecticide applications (2003-2005) and intermittent spraying of infested houses until 2012. Household inspections determined entom indices and materials in 200, 2007, and 201. Serological surveys were conducted in school-age children 199, 2007, and 201, and women of child-bearing age 15-44 in 201. After IRS, infestation decreased from 39% (200-2) to 27 (201). Household materials predicted <10% infested houses. Chagas seropreval in school children declined 10-fold from 10 (199) to 1 (201). However, serreval in women of child age remained >10. A decade of control in Comapa shows reduced transmission, but continued risk vector-borne and congenital transmission threatens the 202 Chagas elimination goal.
Citrobacterium is a natural pathogen that causes attaching and effacing (A/E) lesions in mice, sharing virulence strategies with human pathogens Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) and Enterohaemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC). The complete genome of Citrobacterium strain ICC168 was previously sequenced, revealing characteristics of a newly evolved pathogen. This study used PFGE sequencing of isolates, whole-genome transcript analysis, and mobile genetic elements to confirm the hypothesis that Citrobium's genome is unstable due to repeat-mediated large-scale recombination and active transposition of mobile elements, such as prophages. An additional Citrobium strain EX-33 was sequenced, revealing that ICC168 is representative of the species and most inactivating mutations common to both isolates occurred early in the pathogen's evolution.
Researchers have developed a computational framework to analyze stochastic fluctuations in gene expression, which result in varying protein levels across cell populations. Despite existing theoretical models, a robust and assumption-free approach to infer underlying mechanisms was lacking. The proposed method infers biochemical constants for chromatin modification, transcription, translation, RNA, and protein degradation from stochastic protein expression. It was determined if these rates can be estimated from protein distributions without assumptions. The approach involved: (1) deriving analytical solutions for protein distribution moments, (2) showing moments capture distribution shape, and (3) developing an algorithm for inferring rate constants from moments. The algorithm found most distributions consistent with multiple rate sets. Despite degeneracy, the constant space always informs mechanism. For example, it distinguished transcription bursting from constitutive production. The method agreed with standard approach in restrictive regime and identified previously unobtainable rates. Without assumptions, estimates were obtained in 91% of cases, and all constants in some cases. The framework will deduce molecular contributions to gene expression patterns.
Researchers have developed a new vaccine strategy to protect against monkeypox, a viral disease caused by the monkeypox virus (MPV), using a recombinant bovine herpesvirus 4 (Bo-4) vector. MPV is an emerging zoonotic disease in tropical Africa, primarily in the Congo Basin and sporadically in West Africa, with no FDA-approved therapies and limited vaccines due to safety concerns. The study aimed to investigate the efficacy of Bo-4 vectors expressing MPV glycoproteins A29, M1, and B6 in protecting against lethal MPV challenge in STAT1 knockout mice. Three recombinant Bo-4 vectors, Bo-4-CMV-A29g106ΔTK, Bo-4-E1-MR106TK, and Bo-4-E-BR106TK, were constructed and demonstrated to express their transgene. A small-scale study showed no adverse effects after intraperitoneal administration. Bo-4-E1-MR106TK alone or in combination with Bo-4-C-A29 and Bo-4-BR protected 100% and 80% of STAT- mice from mortality and morbidity, respectively. This demonstrates the efficacy of Bo-4 vectors as a vaccine platform.
In trypanosomes, the major mRNA decay pathway is 5'-3' decay, which involves deadenylation followed by decapping and 5'-3' exonuclease activity. Unlike other eukaryotes, trypanosomes lack homologs of the decapping complex subunits. This study identifies ApH-like phosphatase TbPH1 (AL1) as the major mRNA decapping enzyme in trypanosomes. AL1 was previously identified as a trypan stress granule protein involved in mRNA binding, and co-localizes with 5'-3 exonuclease X to a granule at the cell's posterior. RNAi depletion of AL1 is lethal, causing increased deadenylated mRNAs without 5'- decay. This suggests AL acts downstream deadenylation and upstream degradation, consistent with decapping function. In vitro, recombinant N-terminally truncated AL1, but catalytically inactive, sensitizes capped trypan spliced RNA to X1, but only with 5' polyphosphase. This indicates decapping mechanism differs from D2, leaving more than one phosphate at 5' end. This is the first eukotic ApH phosphatase function, a bacterial-derived class in all eukotic phylogenetic groups. Eukotic ApH phosphat substrates unknown, but bacterial Ap diadenine tetraphosphate resembles eotic cap.
Researchers have discovered that inactivating the Arx gene in pancreatic α-cells triggers their conversion into β-like cells. Using a combination of conditional loss-of-function and lineage tracing approaches, they found that inhibiting Arx in α-cells promotes the conversion of adult α-cells into β-like cells at any age. This process involves the mobilization of ductal precursor cells to adopt an endocrine fate, with glucagon cells being converted into β-like cells upon Ar inhibition. Analysis of Arx and Pax4 double mutants revealed that Pax4 is dispensable for these processes, indicating Ar as the main trigger for α-cell β-cell neogenesis. Loss of Ar in α-cells regenerates functional β-cell mass and reverses diabetes-induced β-cell depletion.
In eukaryotic cells employ a range of mechanisms to prevent the initiation of DNA replication at thousands of origins in their genome, as uncontrolled initiation can lead to genomic alterations. These global mechanisms reduce the activity of replication proteins, suggesting that all origins are inhibited identically. However, origins initiate with diverse efficiencies when these mechanisms are disabled, and this cannot be explained by differences in efficiency or timing of initiation during S phase. This suggests an additional layer of control regulating initiation at distinct origins. Novel elements are necessary for preferential initiation of two origins and sufficient to confer preferential initiation on heterologous origins when control is partially deregulated. These elements do not enhance S phase or efficiency of adjacent origins, acting as initiation promoters (RIPs). Two RIPs are mapped to ∼60 bp AT-rich sequences acting in distance-dependent manner. During replication, Mc2 associates with origins that preferentially initiate and those that do not, indicating RIPs can overcome initiation block imposed by Mc2 association. Our findings reveal a level of control to initiation. This control creates a genomic landscape of replication potential when global mechanisms are compromised. If replication contributes to alterations, as speculated in cancer, some regions may be more susceptible than others.
Invasive amebias caused by Entamoeba histolytica is a growing concern among men who have sex with men and co-infection ameba and HIV-1 in East Asian countries. A study of 170 HIV-1-infected patients with invasive amebias was conducted to characterize clinical and epidemiological features. Clinical presentation of invasive amebias in HIV-1 patients was similar to non-HIV hosts, with fever, leukocytosis, and high CRP associated with extraintestinal ameb diseases. Two patients died from amebic colitis due to intestinal perforation and bleeding, and three from unrelated causes. Metronidazole or tinazole treatment was successful in 165 cases. Luminal treatment was provided to 83 post-metronidazole tinazole, but amebias recurred in 6, similar to non-luminal patients. Recurrence was more frequent in HCV-antibody positive and syphilis acquired during follow-up. Various E histolytic genotypes were identified, no correlation with clinical features. Metronidazole tinid treatment of uncomplicated amebias was excellent in HIV-1 individuals. Luminal post-metronid tinazole did not reduce recurrence in high-risk populations due re-infection.
In the Mandouli area of South Chad, a persistent focus of Gambian sleeping sickness (African trypanosomiasis) caused by Trypanosoma brucei gambiense, a global efforts aim to eliminate the disease as a public health problem by 2020 and stop transmission by 203. Prior to 2014, control relied solely on case detection and treatment, resulting in a gradual decrease in cases due to annual screening. To assess the impact of adding vector control to detection and treatment, 'tiny' targets' that attract and kill tset were deployed in riverine habitats in 2014, 2015, and 2016. A census of the population and settlements was conducted, and pre-intervention surveys of tse distribution and abundance were implemented. The population of 74 inhabitants lived in the vicinity, with Glossina fuscipes fipes and a mean catch of 0.7 tset/trap/day. After deployment, catch declined to 0.005set/trap. Modelling attributed 70.4% (95%:51-95) of reduction in cases 2015 to vector control, 62.8% (95:59-66) to tset control, and 8.5 (95:8-9) to passive detection. Predictions anticipate elimination by 2018 if control and screening continue, with virtually no transmission since 201.
A retrospective observational study was conducted on 124 cases of strongyloidiasis registered in the +IV Collaborative Network from 2009 to 2017. The study aimed to describe the epidemiological, clinical, and microbiological characteristics of patients with imported strongloidis in Spain. The majority of patients (66.9%) were immigrants, with South America being the most frequent area of origin. Detection of larvae in stool samples was observed in 21.9% of patients, while serological tests made the diagnosis in the remaining cases. Eosinophilia was present in 82.2% of cases. Treatment with ivermectin compared to albendazole was the most strongly associated factor to achieve cure (OR 2.34).
Researchers have investigated the impact of the inoculum dose, or amount of antigen or attenuated pathogen, on host immunity and morbidity in vaccine design. A higher inoculum doses stimulate a stronger immune response but may cause more severe side effects and limit vaccine availability during shortages. Determining the optimal inoculum dose is crucial for rational vaccine design. A combination of mathematical models and experimental data can determine the inoculum's impact. The study used a mathematical model to fit data from influenza A virus (IAV) infection in mice and human parainfluenza (HIV) infection in rats at different inoculum doses. The model mapped inoculum to immune protection and morbidity levels, exploring a framework for determining optimal inoculum. The framework combines models with data to study inoculum's impact on outcomes like protection and morbidity. Findings show inoculum's impact on protection and morbidity depend on the pathogen, and protection and morbidity don't increase monotonically with inoculum. Once protection and morbidity levels are specified, the framework helps rational vaccine design and optimal inoculum determination.
Researchers investigated the expression of the HetR gene, a transcription factor essential for heterocyst differentiation in the cyanobacterium Anabaena, under nitrogen-rich and nitrogen-deprived conditions. Using a chromosomally-encoded translational hetR-gfp fusion, they analyzed fluctuations of HetR expression at the individual cell level in wild-type and mutant filaments. Results showed that HetR fluctuations in nearby cells are coupled, with a spatial range of circa two to three cells, indicating cellular interactions along the filament. Correlations arise from intercellular molecular transfer and less cell division. Fluctuations after nitrogen-down build on those under nitrogenplete conditions. Under nitrogen-rich conditions, basal HetR expression is influenced by the septal protein Sep and Het auto-regulation. A comparison of Het-gfp expression under nitrogen-rich and nitrogen-poor conditions highlights differences between Het inhibitors Pat and Het, as well as sept proteins Sep and Fra/Fra. Activation and cell communication are key to developmental processes. Results show that proteins involved in these mechanisms combine with stochasticity in expression to control fluctuations, giving rise to a one-dimensional pattern in this organism.
Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) genotype has shifted from genotype III (GIII) to I (GI) in China, as demonstrated by molecular epidemiological surveillance. A serological survey in non-vaccinated pigs confirmed this shift at the seroepidemiological level, with an average GI/GIII ratio of 1.87, indicating co-circulation of GI and GIII infections, with GI being more prevalent. To investigate this shift, replication kinetics of seven isolated JEV isolates, including three GI and four GIII strains, were compared in C6/36 cells, chicken fibroblast (DF-1), and porcine artery endothelial (PIE) cells. GI strains replicated more efficiently in DF-1 and PIE cells, with titers 22.9-225.3 fold higher than GIII in DF-1 cells. This suggests enhanced replication of GI in avian cells. In vivo, young ducklings were inoculated with GI and GIII at 2 days post-hatching. GI-inoculated ducklings developed higher viremia and displayed longer vmic duration than GIII-inoc ducklings. These results support enhanced efficiency of GI in birds. Thirty-six amino acids differ between GI and GIII, some may be responsible for replication efficiency of GI in birds. Enhanced replication of GI in birds may result in higher exposure and infection in mosquitoes, increasing transmission in birds-mosquito-bird enootic cycle, contributing J genotype shift.
Candida albicans biofilm formation is a critical aspect of its pathogenicity and is regulated by a complex network of transcription factors, including Crz1, Brg1, Efg1, N80, Rob1, and Tec1. To elucidate how these factors interact to regulate biofilm formation, researchers generated all possible double heterozygous mutants of the network and quantitatively analyzed genetic interactions between them. The network is highly susceptible to genetic perturbation, with six heterozygous mutants showing alterations in biofilm formation (haploinsufficiency). Many double heterozygous mutants are as severely affected as homozygous deletions. The network exhibits a highly interconnected "small-world" topology, being efficient but not robust. Genetic data indicate Tec1 is a component whose expression is sensitive to perturbations in other TF functions. Rob1 expression is dependent on auto-regulation and cooperative interactions with other TFs. N80 heterozygous deletion is hyperfilous under bio and hypha-inducing conditions in Tec-dependent manner. This study provides insights into individual TF functions and overall network topology in function.
Researchers investigated the role of asparagine synthase A (AS) in Leishmania infantum, a parasite that causes leishmaniasis, a disease. AS is an enzyme responsible for converting aspartate to asparagine using ammonia or glutamine as a nitrogen source. There are two types of AS: AS-A, which uses ammonia, and AS-B, which uses glutamine. AS-A is absent in humans but present in trypanosomatids, making it a potential drug target. A previous study suggested AS-A is essential in Leishmania donani, a related parasite. This study found that Leishmania infant AS can use both ammonia and glutamine as nitrogen sources, similar to Trypanosoma spp. and Leish donani. The researchers created AS-A null mutants in Leish infant by gene replacement and found no significant growth or infectivity defects. However, severe growth impairment was observed in aspar limiting conditions. The results show that while AS is important under aspar limitation, it is not essential for parasite survival or infectivity in normal in vitro and in vivo conditions. Therefore, AS is not a suitable target against Leish infant parasites.
A systematic review and meta-analysis was conducted to investigate the association between toxocariasis and epilepsy. The review included 11 case-control studies from 13 countries, totaling 474 participants (215 with epilepsy and 259 without epilepsy). The pooled odds ratio (OR) was 1.69 (95% CI 1.42-2.01), indicating a positive association between Toxara spp seropositivity and epilepsy. A positive association was consistently reported in subgroup analyses of confirmatory diagnostic tests, younger populations, and population-based studies. Meta-regression showed no significant association between covariates and outcome. The meta-analysis provides epidemiological evidence of a positive association between Toara seropitivity and epilepsy, mainly supported by population studies.
ATM-dependent miR-335 targets CtIP and modulates the DNA response to double-strand breaks (DSBs). Irradiation (IR)-induced DSBs activate ATM, leading to the downregulation of miR-335, a microRNA that targets CtIP, a trigger of homologous recombination repair (HRR). CREB is responsible for a large portion of mi-335 expression by binding to the promoter of mi-335. CREB binding is reduced after IR, consistent with previous studies that IR-activated ATM phosphorylates CRE to reduce its activity. Overexpression of mi-335 in HeLa cells results in reduced CtIP and post-IR survival and BRCA foci formation. In patient-derived lymphoblast cell lines with post-IR survival radiosensitive phenotype, mi-335 is elevated, Ct reduced, and BRCA foci. Colony survival, BRCA, and Ct are partially rescued by mi antisense oligonucleotide-mi-335 treatment. ATM-dependent CRE-mi-335-CtIP axis influences selection of HRR for DSB repair.
Researchers investigated the role of mentalizing, or attributing mental states to others, in learning during social interactions. Participants played games against artificial agents with varying levels of mentalizing sophistication, including recursive beliefs such as "I think you think I think." Results showed that participants performed better against sophisticated mentalizing agents in a social context, but not in a non-social context. In the social context, participants' choices were best explained by sophisticated mentalizing models, but not in the non-social context. The study demonstrates the added value of mentalizing in social learning and shows that deciphering behavior requires attributing mental states to others.
Researchers have developed a new algorithm called FastGM for inferring Gaussian Graphical Models (GM) in biological networks. GM is a statistical model that describes the conditional relationships between a set of random variables as a graph, useful for analyzing biological networks, such as inferring interactions or comparing networks. Current methods are either statistically unsound or inefficient for high-dimensional data with thousands of variables. FastGM is based on a recent proposal by Ren et al. (2015) and estimates GM and p-values with confidence intervals for each edge in the graph. Simulations show FastGM is faster by several orders of magnitude than the current algorithm by Ren et al without loss of accuracy. FastGM is applied to real data: transcriptomics from childhood asthma and proteomics Alzheimer's disease studies, estimating gene and protein networks for disease and healthy samples. Results reveal interesting interactions and differential networks between cases and controls relevant to diseases. FastGM is a computationally efficient and statistically sound procedure for GM inference with high-dimensional biological data, implemented in R package "FastGM".
Researchers investigated the optimal balance of striatal medium spiny neuron (MSN) network activity in the basal ganglia, a structure crucial for learning and executing movement sequences. They found that MSN population firing rates vary coherently on behaviorally relevant timescales. A model of the MSN network with realistic connectivity and inhibitory post-synaptic potentials (IPs) showed emergent activity. The study examined how MSN population activity interacts with temporally varying cortical activity, as in a behavioral task. At high connectivity, a "winner-takes-all" regime was found, where activity separates into stimulus-dependent firing and quiescent components, with few population rates interacting with cortical variations. Around this, a transition to a more dynamic regime occurred, where cells switch between activity and quies. In this regime, MS components wander and are independent of cortical variations. Only in this regime, cortical changes interact with many components, allowing sequential assemblies to be reproducibly activated for hundreds of milliseconds after stimulus onset. Peristimulus histograms display strong stimulus specificity. This activity is maximized at striatal realistic connectivities and IP sizes. The MS network is neither too stable to respond dynamically to cortical variations nor too unstable to respond consistently. It is optimized to generate stimulus-dependent patterns long after cortical excitation.
Polarized exocytosis, a process that transports membrane components to specific locations on the cell cortex, and endocyt, which retrieves these components before they can diffuse, are generally considered separate events. However, research reveals a link between the two pathways. Yeast GTPase Sec4 couples polarized exocyt with cortical actin polymerization, inducing endocyt. After polar exocyt to the plasma membrane, Sec4 binds Las17/Bee1 (yeast WASp) in complex with S1 and S2 during actin assembly. Mutations in Sec4 or its guanine nucleotide exchange factor (GEF) Sec2 inhibit actin formation, while activating Sec4L accelerates assembly. In vitro assays, Arp3-dependent actin polymerization shows GTP-Sec4 overrides S1 inhibition of Lasp actin nucleation. These results support a model where Sec4 relocates along the membrane from polar exocytic sites to endocytic sites. Activated Sec4 promotes actin polymer and triggers compensatory endyt, controlling surface expansion and refining cell polarization.
Acetamin-induced liver injury in mice is a model for drug-induced liver injury in humans, and understanding the underlying mechanisms is crucial for developing strategies to prevent or reverse damage. The phenomenon of necrosis in mice begins near the central vein (CV) of the liver lobule and progresses outward, but the mechanism remains elusive. Research suggests that differences in NAPQ (reactive metabolite) formation within hepatic lobules (NQonation) are necessary and sufficient to explain this phenomenon, proposing the NZech hypothesis. However, this hypothesis is challenging to test in mice due to uncontrolled variables and the need for intracellular measurements at different locations within the same mouse.

Virtual hepatocytes exhibit location-dependent behaviors using peri-portal-CV gradients, and employing NZ-mech achieved validation for acetamin clearance but not the phenomenon. To achieve the phenomenon, at least one additional feature exhibiting zonation in the CV direction is required. Two alternatives were explored: glutathione depletion in the CV direction and mitochondrial damage repair in the CV. Including one feature failed, but including both enabled achieving the phenomenon. The merged mechanism provides a multile, multiscale explanation of acetamin hepatotoxicity in mice. Variants of the mechanism explain variation in 24-hour necrosis among 37 diverse mouse strains after a single acetamin dose.
Researchers investigated the diagnosis of Trypanosoma cruzi infection in congenitally infected children, focusing on the relationship between conventional diagnosis methods and quantitative DNA amplification. According to Chagas congenital transmission guidelines, diagnosis relies on detecting parasites by microscopy or specific antibodies at 10-12 months of age. Parasite levels were quantified by PCR in T cruz-infected children, grouped by one-year follow-up diagnosis results. Three groups were identified: A) neonates diagnosed by microscopy at birth (n=19) with median parasitemia 1,700/mL, B) infants requiring second parasitological diagnosis at 6 months (n=10) with median parasitem 20/mL and 500/mL at 1 and 6 months, and C) undetectable parasitem by microscopy but diagnosed by specific T cruz serology at 1 year (n=22) with parasitem 5/mL 800/mL and 20/mL. T cruz parasites were isolated by hemoculture from 19 congenally infected children, 18 genified as DT Tc (lineage TId) and 1 as Tc.
