Researchers investigated the cognitive and neural processes underlying human decision-making by examining when and how people choose, not just what they choose. Sequential sampling models (SSMs) have advanced the field by assuming decisions emerge from a bounded accumulation process, making response times (RTs) predictable. However, these models fail when individuals are not forced to respond immediately but allowed to sample sequentially, as the decision-maker may delay choice and terminate the process, unaccounted for by standard SS approach. New SS models predicting RTs from electroencephalography (EEG) and functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) studies were developed. Participants bought or rejected fictitious stocks based on sequentially presented cues, free to respond at any time. Standard SS did not adequately describe RT distributions, but adding a mechanism for postponing decisions improved fit. Time-frequency EEG analysis revealed alternating states of de- and increasing oscillatory power in beta frequencies (14-30Hz), indicating responses prepared and inhibited, supporting decision to not decide. The extended model accounted for adapted paradigm where participants pressed button for more information. Results demonstrate computational modeling decisions and RT support understanding hidden cognition dynamics.
Researchers identified a genetic mutation in the SUVH2 gene in Labrador Retrievers with Hereditary Nasal Parakeratosis (HN), a rare autosomal recessive skin disorder characterized by crusts and fissures on the nasal planum. A genome-wide association study (GWAS) of 13 HN cases and 23 controls revealed a strong association on chromosome 2 (p=4.4×10-14). Haplotype analysis defined a 1.6 Mb interval with 25 genes. Resequencing of one case genome at 38 coverage detected 3 non-synonymous variants in the interval. Genotyping these variants in larger cohorts identified one associated with HN in over 500 dogs. The causative variant is a missense in SUVH encoding histone lysine 9 (H3) methyltransfer, mediating chromatin silencing. The c.972G>T variant changes conserved asparagine to lysine in catalytically active domain (p.NK). Histopathological studies in vivo suggest HN not caused by hyperproliferation, but delayed differentiation of kerocytes. Data provide evidence SUVH involved in epigen regulation of kerocyte ensuring stratification and sealing mammalian epidermis.
Researchers investigated the emergence of transmissible reassortant viruses in swine during co-infection with avian and swine influenza A viruses (IAV). Reassort between IAVs is a key factor in the emergence of pandemic strains, and sw are proposed as a "mixing vessel" for generating reassortants of avian and mammalian IAV that pose a risk to mammals, including humans. The study analyzed 571 isolates from nasal wash and respiratory tract samples of co-housed pigs (influenza-negative, av H1N1 IAV-infected and sw H3 IAV-infected pigs) identified 30 distinct genotypes of reassortant viruses. Viruses from lower respiratory tissues had the largest genomic diversity, while those from turbinate and nasal fluids had the least. Reassants from lower tracts showed largest variations in growth in respiratory epithelial cells, and temperature in sw nasal cells selected the type of reassant shed by pigs. One reassant in nasal samples was consistently found in upper, middle, and lower tracts, and was efficiently transmitted between pigs. Findings suggest that during av and sw I co-infections, reassort occur in lower tracts, and tropism is a factor for transmissible reassant.
A study was conducted to investigate the effects of prazantel treatment of Schistosoma mansoni during pregnancy on the prevalence and immune responsiveness of offspring to Schistoma infection at age five years. The study used data from a trial (ISRCT32847) in Uganda, where offspring of women treated with prazantel or placebo during pregnancy were examined for Schoma infection and cytokine and antibody responses to SWA and SEA, as well as T cell expression of FoxP at age five. Of 134 children examined, 32 (2.4%) had Schoma infection at five years based on a single stool sample. Infection prevalence did not differ between children of treated or untreated mothers. Cytokine (IFγ, IL-5, IL-10 and IL-13) and antibody (Ig, Ig and IgE) responses to SW and SEA, and FoxP expression were higher among infected than uninfected. Prazel treatment of Schoma during pregnancy had no effect on responses, with exception IL-10 to SW which was higher in offspring of women received prazel during pregnancy than those did. No evidence found that Schoma infection and treatment during pregnancy influence prevalence and intensity Sch infection or effector response Sch infection offspring five years, but observed IL-10 SW suggest Schoma and treatment during pregnancy may affect immunoreg responsiveness childhood schos.
Macrophages play a crucial role in the clearance of pathogens following an infectious challenge. However, the relationship between macrophage activation and clearance remains poorly understood. This study reveals that inflammatory stimuli induce a reprogramming of the macrophage endocytic machinery, shifting from receptor-mediated phagocytosis to macinocytosis, allowing for rapid transfer of internalized cargo to lysosomes in a receptor-independent manner. This reprogramming is mediated by protein C-mediated phosphorylation of macrophage protein coronin 1, activating phosphoinositol (PI)-3-kinase necessary for macinocytic uptake. Expression of a phosphomim form of coron 1 is sufficient to induce PI-kin activation and macinocytosis in the absence of inflammatory stimuli.
Researchers conducted a qualitative study in Arua District, North Uganda to assess community acceptance of tset baits (insecticide-treated targets) in areas where tset control had not been previously conducted. The study aimed to understand knowledge and perceptions of tse baits in villages where they were being deployed for the first time. Focus group discussions were held with 16 male and female participants in eight villages across Arua District, with discussions recorded and transcribed. Thematic analysis was used to compare views of both groups and identify salient themes. Villagers who had never seen baits before expressed fear and anxiety, associating them with witchcraft and "ghosts from the river", linked to illness, death, and misfortune. In contrast, villagers in areas where ba had been used previously had positive attitudes and were aware of their purpose and benefits. They reported similar negative perceptions when tset control started a decade ago. Results show acceptance varies between villages, related to duration of experience with tset programs. Success of community-based interventions against tset depends on community engagement and sensitization, especially in areas new to interventions.
Researchers have conducted a comprehensive study on the recombination landscapes of Drosophila melanogaster, a species of fruit fly, to investigate the fundamental biological process of recombination and its implications on evolution. They analyzed 5,860 meioses, genotyping 139 million SNPs and mapping 106,964 recombination events at a resolution of 2 kilobases. This allowed for the creation of whole-genome maps of crossing over (CO) and gene conversion (GC) recombination, as well as detailed variation in recombination among individuals. The study found extreme and punctuated variation in CO rates along chromosomes, with hotspots and coldspots, and intra-specific variation associated with hotspots at low frequency. Gene conversion rates were more uniformly distributed across the genome, detectable in regions with reduced or absent CO. At local scale, recombination events were associated with sequence motifs, occurring within transcript regions, suggesting chromatin accessibility favors double-strand breaks. The study highlights the importance of accounting for recombination variation across and among individuals in population genetic analyses to assess selection and linkage.
Researchers have identified ID2 (ID2) as a component of the RNA-directed DNA methylation (RdDM) machinery in Arabidopsis thalian, but its function in RDM remained unclear. Through affinity purification of ID2, they co-purified two ID paralogs, ID1 and ID2 (ID PARAL1 and 2). The coiled domain between the XS and X domains of ID2 is essential for ID homodimerization, while the ID C-terminal X domain but not coiled domain is required for ID interaction with ID1 and ID2. Complementation testing with wild-type ID2 and mutated derivatives in the id2 mutant showed that the uncharacterized ID X domain is required for ID-ID1/ID2 formation and function. ID1 is required for de novo methylation, siRNA accumulation, and transcriptional silencing, while ID2 has overlapping roles with ID1. Unlike ID, ID and ID are incapable of double-stranded RNA binding, suggesting different roles in the ID-ID/ID complex and essential for functioning RDM.
Researchers investigated the interaction between neutrophils and Leishmania braziliensis, a parasite that causes leishmaniasis. Neutrophils are the first line of defense against invading pathogens and are rapidly recruited to sites of infection. Infection with L. braziliensis led to a significant depletion of neutrophils, increasing parasite load. However, co-culturing neutils with L. brazili had the opposite effect, inducing parasite killing. The study focused on neutil response to L. brazili, exploring activation and apoptotic fate. Inoculation of serum-opsonized L. braziliastigotes in mice induced neutil accumulation in vivo, peaking at 24 hours. In vitro, exposure of thioglyateelic inflammatory bone marrow neutils to Lili modulated expression of surface molecules CD18 and CD62, and induced oxidative burst. Using mCh-expressing Lili, effects were mainly observed in infected not bystander cells. Neutil activation with Lili was confirmed by release of TN-α and neutilase. Neutils infected Lili but not L major displayed markers of early apoptosis. Lili induces neutil recruitment in vivo and neutils exposed to parasite in vitro through activation and release of inflammatory mediators, impacting parasite elimination at early stages of infection.
Bovine tuberculosis (TB) vaccination is not currently used in international control programs, including the EU, due to interference with the tuberculin skin test, used to determine TB-free status. New diagnostic tests, Differentiated Infected from Vaccinated Animals (DIV), offer potential for vaccination introduction in eradication programs. Using herd transmission models from Great Britain (GB), the feasibility of supplemental vaccination is explored. The economic impact of bovine TB on farmers is dominated by testing and movement restrictions costs. Farmers' willingness to adopt vaccination requires reduced infection burden and restriction risk. In GB, the DIV test specificity, not sensitivity, is the barrier to herd benefit vaccination. Relaxing testing could mitigate negative effects, but increase hidden infection in TB-free herds. Models explore DIV characteristics for herd benefit vaccination. A DIV specificity of 99.85% and sensitivity >40% is required for benefit with no increased risk. Data from infected animals suggest a cocktail of DIV antigens can achieve 99.85% specificity and 73.3% sensitivity (61.9, 82.9%) relative to post-mortem detection.
Researchers have identified a new class of compounds called dihydroben[e][1,4]azin-2(H)ones that exhibit anthelmint activity against the parasitic worm Trichuris, which infects over 500 million people worldwide, causing physical and educational damage. Trichuris mur, a model for T. trichi, was used to screen a library of 480 drug-like molecules for paralysis of adult parasites, leading to the identification of dihydroben[e1,4]azin-2(H)ones. Further screening and synthesis of related compounds resulted in 20 active dihydrobenoxazinones, not previously implicated in nematode control, with EC50 values around 25-50μM, comparable to existing anthelmint levamis. These compounds showed low cytotoxicity against murine epithelial cells, demonstrating selectivity for the parasite. A novel oral treatment for a neglected disease is challenging, but dihydroazepin O029 reduced embryonated T. mur eggs ability to establish infection in mouse in vivo, complementing development as an oral anthint. This supports an alternative strategy of a therapeutic acting in environment, via spray, interrupting parasite lifecycle. Results show dihydroazinones as new anthint against both egg and adult Trichis stages, demonstrating selectivity and scope for optimisation to improve potency and pharmacokinetic for clinical agent.
Researchers have revisited the concept of "date" and "party" hubs" in protein-protein interaction networks, where "date" hubs" have low co-expression with their partners and "party" hubs have high-expression. Initially, it was proposed that "party" hubs are local coordinators and "date" are global connectors. However, this study found that the importance of "date" hubs to network connectivity can be attributed to a small subset of them, which do not display low expression, contradicting the idea of a link between quantity and function. The date/party distinction was motivated by a bimodal distribution of co-expression, but this feature is not robust to methodological changes. Topological properties of hubs do not correlate with co-expression, but there is a significant correlation between centrality and functional similarity of interacting proteins. The study suggests that thinking in terms of date/party dichotomy for protein networks is not meaningful and it may be more useful to consider roles-protein interactions rather than individual proteins.
Researchers have developed methods to reconstruct transmission trees of infectious diseases from whole genome sequences, but a limitation is the need for genetic diversity to occur on epidemiological timescales. The position of individuals in a transmission tree can only be resolved if mutations have accumulated between pathogen genomes. To compare genetic diversity in outbreaks, the concept of "transmission" is introduced, defined as the number of mutations separating sequences from transmission pairs. Literature values were used to simulate scenarios with sequence evolution models to describe transmission of major pathogens. Results show that mean transmission varies between pathogens, but is generally low, with many outbreaks having genetically identical pairs. The impact of transmission on reconstruction was tested with tools R and phy, demonstrating that rapidly evolving pathogens like viruses provide information on individual events. Conversely, pathogens with lower transmission, such as Streptoccus, Shigella, and Clostrid, provide little to no information. This highlights limitations of genetic data in certain scenarios and the need to expand tools to integrate other epidemiological data.
Researchers investigated the process of X chromosome inactivation (XCI) in female mammals, where one X chromosome is silenced, but some genes escape silencing. They analyzed allele-specific expression and chromatin structure of X-linked genes in mouse tissues and cells with skewed X inactivation using single nucleotide polymorphisms. A binomial model showed a continuum between complete silencing and expression from the inactive X chromosome (Xi). RNA-seq results were verified with RT-PCR and Sanger sequencing. Common and tissue-specific genes were identified, which may contribute to sex differences. Only 3-7% of genes escape CI in mouse tissues, indicating strict silencing control. In contrast, embryonic kidney-derived Pki cell line showed 21% escape, representing kidney-specific and cell-specific genes. Allele RNA polymerase II and DNase hypersensitivity at Xi promoters correlated with escape, suggesting open chromatin structure. Alle CTCF binding on Xi was denser in brain compared to Pki cell, possibly due to compartmentalized Xi structure and fewer brain escape genes compared to cell with larger domains.
Researchers have characterized a novel cysteine protease, Plasmod viv-4 (VXV-4), from the malaria parasite Plasmod vivax. This protease is involved in maintaining parasite homeostasis and egress from the host erythrocyte. Unlike its orthologs in Plmod falcum, VX-2 and VX-3, VX-4 exhibits differential substrate specificity and pH-dependent activity. Recombinant VX-4 hydrolyzes benzyloxycarbonyl-Le-Arg-ethyl-m-cmary-7-amide (Zu-ArgCA) and Z-Arg-MCA at acidic pH 5.5, whereas Z-Arg-MCA at neutral pH 6.5-7.5.5. VX- prefers positively charged amino acids at the P1 position, with less specificity at P3 and P4, and pH-dependent preferences for Leu at 5.5 and Arg at 7.5. Three amino acids in the S pocket differ from VX-2 and VX-3 (Ala, Gly, and Glu). Glu180 is crucial for pH-dependent substrate preference. VX- is localized in the vacuoles and cytoplasm of erythrocytic P. viv, with maximal activity at neutral pH, and against P. viv plasm 4 and hemoglobin at neutral/acidic and acidic pH, respectively. VX demonstrates pH-dependent substrate switching, allowing for efficient cleavage of different substrates in intracellular environments. VX might function as hemase in acidic foodu, mase P viv plasm 4 at neutral/acid, and cytoskeleton-degrading in erythrocytos.
Researchers have developed a novel genome-scale model of metabolism and macromolecular synthesis (ME-model) for the acetogen Clostridium ljungahli, a Gram-positive bacterium capable of fermenting a broad range of substrates, including H2:CO or syng (a mixture of H2/CO2). This model captures major metabolic, amino acid, nucleotide, lipid, cofactor, and vitamin synthesis pathways, as well as RNA and protein synthesis necessary for catalyzing reactions. The ME-model significantly broadens predictability of acetogen physiology and reveals how protein and media composition influence metabolic pathways and energy conservation. It accurately predicts secretion of multiple fermentation products, including glycerol, a novel product for C. ljungahli, expanding its metabolic capability. Predicting overflow metabolism enables new strategies, such as glycerol formation. The model also predicts changing secretion rates based on metal availability, opening fermentation optimization and knowledge about proteome and carbon flux in acetogens.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) using a panel of human osteoblast (HO) cell lines to investigate the genetic control of transcript variation in osteoblasts. The study aimed to assign biological relevance to genetic signals identified in GWAS studies using large cohorts of primary cell lines. A transcriptomic survey was performed to identify cell-type specific genes and functionally relevant pathways in HO and lymphoblast cell (L) lines. Cis-association analysis with SNP genotypes was used to identify genetic variations in transcript isoforms, indicating differential expression in HO is partly controlled by cis-regulatory genetic variants. These isoforms are regulated by variants in both tissue-specific and tissue-independent manners, confirmed by RT-PCR validation. The study suggests multiple isoforms are present in both tissues and genetic may affect relative expression of one iso to another, rather than an all-or effect. Examination of top SNPs from GWAS of bone density showed overlap with probeset associations in this study, corresponding to the FAM118 gene. This was tested in additional clinical studies, revealing a novel isoform variant. The approach to examining transcriptome in multiple types is useful for detecting variation common to cell types and identifying cell-specific isoforms functionally relevant, a follow-up for GWAS.
Saccharomyces eayan, a non-S cerevisiae parent of the lager-brew hybrid S pastorian, is unable to utilize α-tri-glucide maltotose, a major carbohydrate in brew's wort, unlike most S cerevis and Froberg Sorian strains. The utilization of maltose in Saccharomy yeasts is encoded by the subtelomeric MAL gene family and requires transporters for maltose uptake. S eayan strain CBS 57 harbors SeALT genes for α-di-glucide maltose uptake but lacks maltose genes. S cere sequence indicates maltose and maltose transporters likely evolved from shared ancestral. To study evolv maltose in e CBS57, maltose-assim mutants after UV mutagenesis were subjected to evolution in carbon-limited chemostat on maltose-enriched wort. An evolved strain showed improved maltose and maltose fermentation in 7 ferment experiments on industrial w. Whole-genome sequencing revealed novel SeM413, resulting from gene introgress by non-recipro trans of at least Se genes. The tertiary ofM was comparable to original but overexpression sufficed to enable growth on maltose, indicating neofunction. The structure resembles Sorian maltose-transport gene SpY, with high to MAL1, MAL1 and Se3. Evolution maltose landscape in Sorian lagerrew likely involved similar mechanisms.
Influenza virus variants continue to cause significant morbidity and mortality worldwide, necessitating timely and accurate assessment of their impact on human mortality to inform public health planning. Current methods rely heavily on intensive surveillance, which can be biased and time-consuming. A novel host-virus interaction model was developed to establish a correlation between excess mortality caused by distinct viral strains and their antigenic distances to previous strains for each seasonal influenza subtype. This relationship was used to create a method for rapid estimation of mortality of influenza A (H1N) virus by predicting antigenic distance between A(H1 strains. The study found a positive correlation between excess mortality and antigenic variation, enabling rapid assessment of mortality burden for new strains. This approach can inform cost-effective control and prevention strategies for influenza.
Researchers have identified a small cysteine-rich protein, Pp23, from the Asian soybean fungus Phakora pachyri, which plays a role in suppressing plant immunity. The fungus, an obligate biotrophic pathogen, causes severe soybean epidemics and its interaction mechanisms with host plants are not well understood. The fungus genome encodes many small secreted cystine-rich proteins (SCRPs), but their functions are unknown. This study characterizes P. pachy effector 23 (PEC), a SCP that suppresses plant immunity. PEC23 interacts with soybean transcription factor GPL12 and soy plants with GPL12 silenced have constitutively active immunity, identifying GPL12 as a negative regulator of soybean defenses. Data suggest a virulence function of SCP and PEC suppresses soy immune responses and interacts GPL12, a negative regulator.
Chlamydia trachatis, an obligate intracellular bacterium, invades host cells and replicates within a membrane-bound vacuole called an inclusion. Multiple host proteins are recruited to the inclusion to support chlamial development. Chydia induces activation of the PI3 kinase (PIK) pathway for efficient replication. The EphA receptor, a cell surface tyrosine kinase, is identified as a chlamial adherence and invasion receptor that activates PIK, promoting chlam replication. Interfering with C trachitis serar2 (C) binding to EphA, downregulation of EphA, or inhibition of Eph activity reduced C infection. C interacts with and activates Eph on the surface, resulting in receptor internalization. During chlam replication, Eph remains active around the inclusion and interacts with the p85 subunit of PIK to activate the PI/Akt pathway required for chlam development. Overexpression of full-length Eph, but not mutant lacking the cytoplasmic domain, enhanced PI activation and C infection. Despite Eph depletion from the surface, C induces Eph upregulation through ER activation, keeping the cell in an apoptosis-resistant state. The significance of Eph as entry and intracellular receptor was observed with trachitis serar D. Our findings provide evidence for a host surface receptor exploited for invasion and intracellular signaling to facilitate chlam replication. Engagement of a surface receptor at the membrane is a mechanism Chy subverts the host and induces resistance.
Researchers have found that neurons exhibit dendritic excitability through the expression of voltage-gated ion channels, but the role of this excitability in dendritic computation has remained unclear. A model of an active dendritic tree shows that its output is a highly non-linear function of afferent rate, resulting in extremely large dynamic ranges of up to 50 dB. This non-linearity yields double-sigmoid responses observed in retinal ganglion cells. The study suggests that the enhancement of dynamic range is the primary role of active dendritic conductances. Neurons with larger dendritic trees are predicted to have larger dynamic ranges, while blocking active conductances are expected to decrease dynamic.
Researchers have investigated the inference of quantitative models of bacterial promoters from time-series gene data, a crucial for drug discovery, cancer research, and biotechnology. Current methods rely on assumptions that mRNA abundance in transcriptomics data represents protein concentrations and changes in gene expression are solely due to transcription factors and regulators, neglecting global effects and physiological changes. This study systematically examines the importance of these biases and corrections using a combination of models and experiments. In vivo activity of genes in the FliFliM module of E. coli motility was measured, estimating protein concentrations and global effects using kinetic models of expression. Results show that correcting these assumptions improves model quality, and simulations indicate stronger improvements for systems with longer protein half-lives and varying gene machinery activity. The proposed approach is applicable to time-series transcript data for regulatory network structure and dynamics. In the FliFliM module, results highlight global effects and regulation of Fli and FlM halfives for Fli promoter dynamics.
Researchers investigated the spatial-temporal distribution of Oligyomys fulcens, a rodent species that serves as a reservoir for zoonotic pathogens, in the Agua region of Panama. A longitudinal study of rodent populations in the Agua community between April 2006 and December 2009 was analyzed using non-spatial and spatial statistical methods. The study area was divided into a 90-node grid with a 0.09 km2 cell size, covering 6.43 km2 (2.39 x 2.69 km). Temporal data was divided into four periods: dry season, rainy season, and two transitional months. Results showed heterogeneous population densities and dispersion of O. fulcens across seasons and years, with local absence during late transitional months and re-establishment in subsequent years. Populations recurred in same area first three years, then re-established further south in final year. Spatial autocorrelation indicated local populations within 300-600 m. Suitable and unsuitable habitats were sharply demarcated over short distances. O. fulens showed a spatial pattern evolving over time, leading to changing aggregation. Hotspots of abundance showed shifting, explaining intermittent transmission risk by this species. Variation was associated with seasonality and anthropogenic pressures from agricultural activities. These factors define occurrence, timing, intensity, and duration of synanthropic populations affected by humans, and possible human exposure.
Researchers have developed a method to infer antigenic trees for the major surface protein hemagglutinin of human influenza A H3 viruses, assigning antigen weights to branches to resolve the antigenic impact of amino acid changes. This technique accurately predicts antigenic distances comparable to antigen cartography and identifies both known and novel amino acid changes with antigenic impact in the evolution of H3 viruses from 1968 to 2003. The method can be applied to infer phenotype and genotype-phenotype relationships from other types of pairwise distances.
A high-throughput RNA interference (RNAi) screen was conducted to identify host factors required for human papillomavirus type 16 (HPV16) infection. The analysis revealed a cluster of mitotic genes involved in a previously unknown mechanism for viral DNA import into the nucleus. In interphase cells, viruses were endocytosed and routed to the perinuclear area, but DNA failed to enter the nucleus. Nuclear envelope breakdown during interphase enabled HPV16 infection. During mitosis, viral DNA associated with host chromatin on the metaphase plate. This suggests HPV requires nuclear envelope breakdown during mitosis for DNA access to the nucleoplasm.
Black Sigat or black streak disease, caused by the Dothideomyc fungus Pseudocospora fiji (formerly Mycosphaella fiji), is the most significant foliar disease of banana worldwide. Due to the lack of effective resistance, management, this disease requires frequent fungicide applications, increasing economic and environmental costs in banana production. Weekly applications in plantations lead to rapid evolution of fungicide-resistant strains, causing disease failures globally. To combat this threat, two strains of P. fiji were sequenced and assembled with a new genetic map. The 74-Mb genome of P. fiji is expanded by LTR transposons, making it largest in Dothideycetes. Mel-curve assays suggest related members of Sigat complex, P. eumae and P. mus, are also expanded. Electrophoretic karyotyping and molecular markers in P. fiji populations showed chromosome polymorphisms and high diversity. Genetic differentiation was detected using neutral markers, suggesting selection with limited flow at geographic scale. Frequencies fungicide in treated plantations were higher than untreated P. fiji populations. A homologue Cladospor fulum Avr effector, PfAv4, was identified in P. fiji genome. Infiltration purified PfAV4 into leaves resistant variety Calcut 4 resulted hypersensitive response. This suggests Cal 4 carries unknown gene recognizing Pf4.
Researchers have proposed a novel framework to study the evolution of lineage-specific transcription factor binding sites without relying on detailed cross-species sequence alignments. This approach, based on a birth-death model, aims to identify regulatory elements contributing to species-specific traits. The method was applied to analyze ChIP-seq data for six transcription factors (GATA1, SOX2, CTCF, MYC, MAX, E1, TS) along the human-mouse common ancestor lineage. Results show that a substantial fraction of binding sites (58-79% for each factor) in humans originated since divergence from mouse. Approximately 15% of all sites are unique to hominids. These elements are often near genes associated with specific pathways and harbor more SNPs than older sites in the human genome. The study demonstrates the method's ability to identify lineage-specific regulatory elements and their roles in gene regulation variation across species.
Researchers have investigated the mechanism by which light regulates the expression of the zebraf period2 (per) gene, a key component of the circadian clock, in zebraf. They identified a Light-Responsive Module (LRM) within the per promoter, which is necessary and sufficient for light-driven expression and circadian regulation. The LRM is conserved in vertebrate per genes, even in species lacking light-sensitive peripheral clocks. The human LRM can substitute the zraf LRM to confer light-regulated transcription in zraf cells. The LRM contains E-box and D-box elements, critical for its function. The E-box mediates circadian regulation through BMAL1/CLOCK activity, while the D-box drives light expression. The zraf homolog of thyroid transcription factor binds to the L D-box and activates expression. t mRNA levels are light-inducible and t knockdown attenuates light transcription from the per promoter in vivo.
Researchers have discovered that the actin-binding protein coronin plays a crucial role in regulating the motility of Plasmodium berghei sporozoites, the highly motile forms of a rodent malaria-causing parasite transmitted by mosquitoes. The study found that parasites lacking coronin exhibit motility defects, specifically impairing colonization of the salivary glands but not migration in the skin, resulting in decreased transmission efficiency. Non-motile sporozoites have low concentrations of actin and mediate coronin localization to the periphery. Engagement of extracellular ligands triggers intracellular calcium release followed by act-dependent localization of coron to the rear and initiation of motility. Mutational analysis and imaging suggest coron organizes actin filaments for motility. Using coronin-Cherry as a marker for actin filaments, protein A was found to contribute to actin disassembly. The study suggests that calcium and cAMP signaling regulate a switch from parasite motility to host invasion by differentially influencing actin dynamics.
Researchers have identified four Leishmania mexicana lines resistant to amphotin B, a drug used to treat leishiasis. These lines exhibit altered sterol biosynthesis and increased sensitivity to pentamidine. Genome sequencing revealed a mutation in the sterol biosynthesis gene ster C-desaturase in one line, while RNA-seq showed loss of expression of ster C-methyltransferase (SMT) in three lines. MT is responsible for drug resistance and altered sterol biosynthesis. Loss of milteine transporter was also associated with one line. MT is encoded by two genes with different expression levels. Reduced expression is linked to loss of 3 untranslated region of dominant gene due to structural variations at locus. Local sequence homology between genes and presence SIDER retrotransposons promote these variations. In one case, loss MT expression not associated with loss virulence in macrophages in vivo. Sequence instability known in Leish genomes, associated with major drug resistance without fitness costs, a concern.
Researchers investigated how attention and prediction interact to modulate information processing in the brain during sensory encoding. Two processes, prediction and attention, contribute to perception and cognition, but their interaction remains unclear. Predictive coding theory suggests attention optimizes prediction precision by modulating synaptic gain of prediction units, implying attention increases selectivity for surprising information. Alternative models propose attention increases activity of prediction neurons, suggesting synergistic selectivity for feature information. This study used EEG to record neural activity in humans performing a visual task to test attention's effect on mismatch and feature information in response to surprising stimuli. Participants attended or ignored gratings with predictable, surprising, or unpredictable orientations. Surprising stimuli evoked responses encoded difference between predicted and observed features, and attention facilitated encoding of this information.
Trypanosoma brucei, a pathogen of sub-Saharan Africa, has three subspecies: T. b. brucei, T. rhodesense, and T. gambense. T. b. brucei is unable to infect humans due to sensitivity to trypanolytic factors (TLF) 1 and 2 in human serum. T. rhodesense and T. gambense are resistant to lysis by TLF. T. gambense has two distinct subgroups differing genetically and in human serum phenotypes. Group 1 T. gambense has an invariant phenotype, while group 2 shows variable resistance. Previous studies indicated group 1 T gambense is resistant to TLF1 due to reduced uptake of TLF mediated by reduced expression of TLF receptor, the haptoglobin-hemoglobin receptor (Hb) gene. This study investigates if true for group 2 parasites. Isogenic resistant and sensitive group 2 T gambense were derived and compared to T bruce parasites. Both express Hb gene at similar levels and internalized fluorescent labeled T1 similar to T. bruce. Both resistant and sensitive group 2, as well as group 1 gambense, internal recombinant AP1, only sensitive group parasites lysed. Data indicate group T gambense avoiding T1 is resistant to main lytic AP1. Group 2 gambense innately resistant AP1, possibly same mechanism. Group 2 gambense variably displays phenotype, expression does not correlate with Hb change or expression. Differences in human resistance mechanism between T gambense groups 1 and 2.
Researchers have investigated the role of DNA methylation in controlling HIV-1 latency, a state in which the virus remains dormant and hidden from the immune system and antiretroviral drugs. They found that CpG methylation of the HIV-1 5' long terminal repeat (LTR) is an epigenetic mechanism that restricts reactivation of latent HIV-1 and determines its stability. This methylation occurs late in the establishment of latency and is not required for initial provirus silencing. In latent reservoirs of aviremic patients, high proportions of non-methylated 5 LTR were found, indicating that latency is controlled by transcriptional interference and chromatin mechanisms without significant DNA methylation, which is leaky and easily reactivable. In patients without detectable viremia, HIV-1 promoters and enhancers were hypermethylated and resistant to reactivation, contrasting with hypomethyl 5 L in vire patients. However, dense methylation of HIV-1 5 LTR did not confer complete resistance to reactivation with histone deacetylase inhibitors, protein C agonists, TN-α, and combinations with 5-aza-2deoxycytidine. The densely methylated promoter was most efficiently reactivated in absence T cell activation by suboylanide hydroamic acid. The study suggests that CpG methylation controls HIV-1 latency and has implications for strategies to eradicate HIV infection.
Researchers have created a comprehensive genomic map of the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster, identifying over 3.6 million genetic variants, including 800,000 insertions, deletions, and complex variants up to 6,000 base pairs in length. Using a local assembly-based approach, they found that single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) are denser than other variants, but not due to mutagenic or mutation-prone regions. Instead, the high SNP density is attributed to population-level processes. The study also investigated gene expression variation in adult flies by mapping cis-quantitative trait loci (cisQTL) for over 2,000 genes. Insertions comprise 10% of all cisQTL and show larger effects than SNPs. CisQTL. More associations were found in males than females, and most cisQTL are sex-specific, indicating decoupling of genomic architecture between sexes and importance of genetic factors in sex-based expression. RNA-seq-based allelic imbalance in offspring of sequenced lines validated most cisQ in heterozygous individuals.
Researchers investigated the impact of amplitude cancellation on the association between neural drive and rectified electromyography (EMG) signals. Rectified EMG is commonly used to estimate neural drive to muscles and infer synaptic input to motor neurons, but amplitude loss due to overlapping motor unit potentials may distort its spectrum and correlation with neural drive. Analytical derivations and computational models of motor activity, force, and EM signal were used to examine this effect. Rectified EM without cancellation (EMnc) was found to be a superior estimator of neural drive compared to actual rectified EM. Simulations showed that the coefficient of determination (r^2) between neural drive and EMnc (0.59±0.08) matched rectified EM and drive only at low cancellation levels (<40%) and low contraction (<5% maximum voluntary force). Correlation decreased linearly with cancellation (r=-0.83) to r<0.2 at >60% cancellation and >15% contraction. Simulations also showed stronger neural drive implied stronger correlation between rectified EM and drive, with cancellation distorting mainly low-frequency (<5Hz) components. Results indicate amplitude distorts rectified EM spectrum, suggesting valid use of rectified EM as drive estimator requires low levels and strong synaptic input to motor neurons.
Researchers investigated the molecular mechanism of auxin-mediated root growth inhibition in response to aluminum (Al) stress in Arabidopsis. They found that YUC, a flavin monooxygenase-like protein, regulates local auxin biosynthesis in the root transition zone (TZ) in response to Al stress. Al stress upregulates YUC3/5/7/9 in the rootTZ, leading to aux accumulation and root growth inhibition. This regulation is dependent on ethylene signaling, as disrupting ethylene signaling either enhanced or reduced YUC expression in the rootTZ in response to Al. Ethylene also enhanced root inhibition under Al was alleviated in yuc mutants or by co-treatment withucas, an inhibitor of Y activity. Eth-insensitive 3 (E3) is involved in regulating Y9 transcription. Additionally, PHYTOCHROMEACTING FACTOR 4 (P4) acts as a transcriptional activator for Y5/9, promoting Al-inhibited root growth by regulating local Ys and aux in the rootTZ. Al-induced P4 in theTZ acts downstream of eth signaling. The study reveals a regulatory cascade for Y-regulated aux biosynthesis in theTZ mediating growth response to Al.
Natural Killer (NK) cell responses in primates are regulated by interactions between killer-cell immunoglobulin-like receptors (KIR) on NK cells and major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I ligands on target cells. Research has shown that certain simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV) peptides can bind to the MHC class I molecule Mamu-A*002 in rhes mac, stabilizing its interaction with the inhibitory receptor Mamu-K3DL05. This study investigated the functional implications of these interactions by testing SIV peptides bound to Mam-A* for their ability to modulate Mam-K3+ NK cell responses. Twenty-eight of 75 SIV peptides bound to Mam* suppressed the cytolytic activity of Mam-K+ NK cells, including immunodominant CD8 T cell epitopes previously shown to stabilize Mam-A* tetramer to Mam-K05. Substitutions at C-terminal positions changed inhibitory peptides into disinhibitory, and vice versa, without altering binding to Mam*. The effects of these variants on NK responses corresponded to their effects on Mam-A tetramer to Mam-K. Assays with mixtures of inhib and disinhib peptides, low concentrations inhibited NK responses. Consistent with inhibition Mam-K cells by epitopes presented Mam*, SIV replication was higher in Mam* CD+ lymphocytes co-cultured Mam-K NK than Mam-K cells.
Bacterial pathogens must adapt to dynamic environmental stressors to survive and thrive. A study investigated the evolution of Haemophilus influenza (NTH) in response to transient nutrient limitation, hypothesizing that adapted strains would be better suited for colonization and long-term survival. Mutations in the 3',5'-cyclic adenosine monophosphate phosphodiesterase gene (icc) were detected, leading to decreased activity in TH. In a preclinical model of TH-induced otitis media (OM), the icc mutant showed reduced recovery from infected ears. Clinically, OM resolution coincided with middle ear fluid clearance. In contrast, the ic mutant formed more intracellular bacterial communities (IBCs) than the parental strain early in OM, while the parental strain's IBC increased at later stages, coinciding with middle ear fluid absence. This study provides insight into TH evolution during nutrient limitation and demonstrates IBC in a preclinical OM model.
Burkholderia pseudomalle, the causative agent of meloidosis, modulates host iron homeostasis to facilitate iron availability and intracellular survival. Infection of primary macrophages with B. pseudalle results in downregulation of ferroport expression, leading to increased iron availability within macrophages. Exogenous modification of hepcid function or iron supplementation with ferric ammonium citrate increases intracellular iron, stimulating B pseudalle growth, whereas iron chelation with deferoxamine reduces bacterial survival. Iron-loaded macrophages exhibit reduced NADPH oxidase, iNOS, lipocalin 2, cytokine, and caspase-1 activation. Infection of mice with the pathogen diminishes hepatic ferport expression, increases liver iron retention, and lowers serum iron levels (hypofermia). In vivo administration of ferric ammonium citrate promotes bacterial growth and inflammation, while limiting iron availability ameliorates bacterial clearance, attenuates cytokine levels, and improves survival in infected mice. The study suggests that modulation of cellular iron balance is a strategy for B pseudalle to acquire iron and restrict antibacterial effector mechanisms, promoting intracellular growth. Changes in iron homeostasis influence susceptibility to meloidosis, and iron chelation may be a therapeutic option.
Researchers have developed a novel technique called "functional mode analysis" to identify collective motions in proteins that are directly related to their biological functions. This method uses an ensemble of structures and a "functional quantity" that measures the protein's functional state to detect the most correlated motion. The functional quantity can be geometric, electrostatic, chemical, or any variable relevant to the protein's function. The technique estimates the motion most likely to cause a significant change in the quantity from the ensemble. Two correlation measures are used: the Pearson coefficient, which measures linear correlation, and mutual information, which assesses any interdependence. Detecting the most correlated motion allows deriving a model for the functional in terms of a single coordinate. The approach is demonstrated on several biomolecules: polyalanine helix, T lysozyme, Trpase, and leucine-binding protein.
Researchers investigated the removal of conventional and non-conventional introns from the nuclear transcripts of Euglena gracilis, a unicellular eukaryote. Euglenids and diplonids harbor non-conventional introns, distinct from those found in other eukaryotes. Non-conventional introns lack conserved characteristics of spliceosomal introns and U1 snRNA complementarity at the 5' end, yet form stable secondary structures at exon-intron junctions. In contrast to conventional introns, non-conventional introns insert at novel positions, whereas conventional introns are conserved or lost. This study examined the order of intron removal from Euglena gracilis transcripts of tubA and gap genes, containing both non-conventional and spliceosomal introns. The relative order of excision was compared for pairs of introns from different types. Intermediate splicing products were analyzed using PacBio Next Generation Sequencing. Results showed non-con introns removed faster than spliceosomal introns. Accumulation of transcripts with conventional intr removed non-con present suggests a time gap between splicing types.
Researchers investigated the effects of Coxsackievirus B3 (CVB) infection on cardiac progenitor cells and postnatal heart development in a mouse model. CVB is an enterovirus that typically causes self-limiting febrile illness in infants, but severe cases can manifest as acute myocarditis. Chronic consequences of mild CV infection are unknown, but there is an association between early subclinical infections and late heart failure, suggesting potential for subtle damage leading to late-onset dysfunction or chronic injury due to inflammatory reactions during latent infection. Mice were infected with a subclinical dose of CVB3 at juvenile stage, showing no symptoms immediately post-infection or in adulthood. However, following physiological or pharmacologically-induced cardiac stress, infected mice underwent hypertrophy and dilation indicative of progression to heart failure. Evaluation of vasculature in hearts of stressed mice showed compensatory increase in CD31+ vessel formation, suppressed in infected mice. CV3 efficiently infected c-kit+ cells, cardiac progenitor numbers reduced in hearts of infected mice. Results suggest exhausted progenitor pool following CV3 infection impairs heart's ability to increase capillary density adapt to load.
Burkholderia pseudomalle, the causative agent of glanders, regulates IL-1 and IL-18 production through NOD-like receptor NLRP and pyroptosis via NLRC. However, the downstream pathways and cell mechanisms of death induced by B. pseudalle during infection have not been fully elucidated. This study investigated the role of B. pseudalle factors in inflamome activation and cell death pathways. Caspase-1 and pyptosis were found to be dependent on NLRC, not NLRP, in the early phase of macrophage infection, while later caspase-1 activation and cell death were NLRC-independent. An early pathway involving casp-9, -7, and PAR was identified downstream of NLRC and casp-1. Caspase-1 deficient macrophages showed strong apoptosis, dependent on apoptotic initiator and effector caspases. Early casp-1 activation in macrophages was reduced or abolished with B. pseudalle flagellin FliC or TSS3B mutant. TSS effector protein BE was shown to play a role in casp-1 processing. TSS inner protein BK mutant failed to activate casp-1, with higher intracellular counts, reduced death and IL-β secretion. Intranasal infection of BAL/c mice with BK mutant showed decreased mortality, lower bacterial loads, IL-β, myeloperoxidase, and neutrophils in bronchoveolar lavage. Results indicate a major role of TSS in NLRC-mediated casp-1 activation pyptosis and contribution of casp-dependent and -independent cell death in B.alle pathogenesis.
Arabidopsis KINγ, a subunit of the SNF1-related kinase complex, plays a crucial role in plant development. In Arabidopsis, KINγ is localized in the cytoplasm and nucleus of vegetative pollen cells. The Arabidopsis kinγ mutant pollen fails to germinate on the stigma, but germinates normally in vitro. Hydration of the mutant pollen on the stigma is compromised, but adding water promotes germination in vivo, suggesting hydration defect leads to germination. Mitochondria and peroxomes in kinγ mutant pollen are destroyed and reduced in number compared to wild type. kinγ mutant has reduced reactive oxygen species (ROS) in pollen. Adding H2O2 in vitro partially compensates for reduced hydration, and overexpressing Arabid CATAL 3 reduces ROS, impairing hydration on stigma.
In the bacterium Bacillus subtilis, the enzyme RNase III plays a crucial role in protecting the cell from the expression of toxin genes carried by two prophages, Skin and SPβ, through antisense RNA. Unlike in other organisms, where RNase is not essential, in B. subtilis, its presence is vital for survival. Two toxin-encoding mRNAs, txA and yT, of Skin and SP are sensitive to RNase. The mechanism of RNase-mediated decay of txA mRNA paired with its antisense RNA, Rat, is explored in vivo and in vitro.
Researchers have investigated the release of extracellular vesicles (EVs) by the parasitic nematode Brugia malayi, the causative agent of Lymphatic Filariasis. EVs are small particles containing bioactive proteins and RNA that allow parasites to secrete effector molecules and transport them to host tissues. The study analyzed EV release across all life stages of B. malayi: microfilariae, L3, L4, adult male and female worms. Nanoparticle tracking revealed discrete EV populations and a conserved secretory process. EVs were internalized by murine macrophages with no preference for stage, suggesting uniform effector trafficking mechanism. Chemical inhibitors showed all stages internalized by phagocytosis. Proteomic profiling of adult and female EVs using nano LC/MSMS described quantitative and qualitative differences in adult proteome, defining Brug EV biogenesis and sexual dimorphic immunomodulatory cargo. Ivermect inhibited EV release by all B. mal stages, also observed in related nematode Dirofilar imitis, but not in iverect-unresponsive isolate, suggesting drug mechanism and new screening platforms for anti-filar development.
A population-based study was conducted in the Western Province of the Solomon Islands to investigate the prevalence of scabies and impigo. Ten rural villages were included in the study, with 190 participants enrolled. The total unweighted prevalence of scabies was 19.2% (95% CI 17.5-21.0) and age and gender prevalence 19.2% (95 CI 16.7-21.9). Adult prevalence was 10.4% (95 CI 8.2-13.2), with highest in infants <1 year (34.1, OR 3.6, 95 CI 2.2-6) and children 1-4 years (25.7, OR 2.6, CI 1.7-3.9). Scabies affected two or more body regions in 80.9% of participants and 4.4% classified as severe. Total prevalence of impigo was 32.7 (95 CI 30.6-34.8) and age and gender 26.7 ( CI 24.2-29.5). Highest in children 1-4 (42.6, OR 4.1, CI 2.9-5.8). Scabies associated with impigo (OR 2.0, CI 1.6-2.6); 41.1 of impigo also had scabies.
In adult mice, neurogenesis in the subgranular zone of the dentate gyrus in the hippocampus continues throughout life, but its function remains unclear. Researchers measured cellular proliferation in the hippocampus of 719 outbred stock mice and found a significant correlation between the proportions of CD8+ and CD4 T lymphocyte subsets. This correlation reflected shared genetic loci, with the exception of the H-2a locus, which had a dominant influence on T subsets but no impact on neurogenesis. Analysis of knockouts and repopulation of Tα-deficient mice subsets of T cells confirmed the influence of T on adult neurogenesis, indicating CD+ T cells or subpopulations mediate the effect. Our results reveal an organismic impact, broader than hitherto suspected, of the genetic variation that controls T development and homeostasis.
Researchers investigated the efficacy of a multi-component DNA-prime/protein-boost vaccine (TVac2) against Trypanosoma cruzi, the parasite responsible for Chagas disease, a major health problem in Latin America and emerging in the US. The vaccine, composed of selected antigens and cytokines IL-12 and GM-CSF expression plasmids, was tested in a murine model C57/6 mice. Mice were immunized with antigen-encoding plasmids plus cytokine adjuvants, followed by recombinant proteins, and challenged with T. cruzi trypastigotes two weeks later. ELISA and flow cytometry measured humoral (antibody isotypes) and cellular (ymphocyte, CD+ and CD+ T phenotype and cytokine responses. Myocardial pathology was evaluated by H&E and Masson's trich staining. TVac induced strong antigen-specific antibody (Ig2>Ig1) and moderate lymphocyte proliferation in mice. Upon challenge, TVac-vaccinated mice expanded Ig2/Ig1 and elicited CD+ T response with type 1 cytokines IF-γ and TN-α, controlling acute parasite burden. During chronic phase, response persisted, splenic CD+ cells and IFγ/TNF- cytokines subsided, and IL/IL cytok became dominant in vaccinated. Tissue parasitism, inflammation, fibrosis in heart and muscle of TVac-vacc chronic were undetectable by histological techniques. In contrast, injected vector or cytokines only responded T. cruz by elicitation mixed type 1/type 2 antibody, cell and cytok response, exhibiting persistent burden and immunopath in myocardium. TVac-induced type 1 and lymphocyte responses provided resistance to T. cruz infection, preventing evolution immunopath associated parasite in chasic hearts.
Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have been successful in identifying susceptibility loci for complex diseases, but a remaining challenge is quantifying individual disease risk based on genotype for personalized prevention and treatment. Previous studies have failed to achieve satisfactory performance due to limited confirmed loci use. This study proposes using machine learning approaches with multiple markers to improve disease assessment. A Support Vector Machine (SVM) algorithm was applied to a GWAS dataset on Affymetrix genotyping for type 1 diabetes (T1D), optimizing a risk model with hundreds of markers. The model was tested on an independent Illumina-genotyped dataset (1,008 cases, 1,000 controls) and a separate Affymrix-genotyped dataset (1,529,1,458), achieving an area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC) of 0.84 in both. In contrast, poor performance was seen with limited loci in the model or logistic regression. The study suggests disease assessment can be improved with algorithms accounting for interactions between multiple markers. Genotype-based risk may be feasible for diseases with notable risk captured by arrays.
Memory CD8+ T cells play a crucial role in providing immunity against viral infections by rapidly infiltrating non-lymphoid tissues such as the skin. However, the fate of these cells after entering non-lymphoid tissues is not well understood. CD62 is often used to identify central memory CD8 T cells, but its role in lymph node homing versus other functions is unclear. This study shows that memory CD8 T cells enter the skin independently of CD62-mediated lymph node reactivation and provide protection against Vaccinia virus (Vac) infection. Central memory (TCM) but not effector (TEM) CD8 T cells differentiate into CD69+/CD- tissue residents after viral clearance, dependent on local antigen recognition in the skin environment. Memory CD8 cells express granzyme after entering the skin and utilize cytotoxicity to protect against Vac infection.
Myosin VI, a minus-directed motor protein, plays a crucial role in the localization of proteins to the surface of axons in neurons. In contrast to Myosin Va, which targets transmembrane proteins to dendrites, Myos VI facilitates the enrichment of proteins on the axonal surface. Non-neuronal proteins that interact with Myos VI become highly concentrated at the axonal surface in dissociated rat neurons. Disruption of Myos VI function or expression leads to aberrant dendritic localization of axonal proteins. Myos VI mediates the enrichment of proteins on the axonal surface by stimulating dendrite endocytosis, a mechanism underlying localization of many axonal proteins. Additionally, a Channelrhodopsin 2 engineered to bind to Myos VI is concentrated at the axonal surface of cortical neurons in mice in vivo, suggesting a potential tool for probing circuit and function.
Researchers have identified two Doublesex (Dsx) genes in Daphnia magna, a freshwater branchiop crustacean, which exhibits environmental sex determination (ESD) by producing males in response to environmental cues. One of these genes, DmaD1, is responsible for male development during ES and its organization is similar to Dsx from insects, a sister group of branchiop crustans. Unlike insects, DmaD1 exhibits sexually dimorphic differences in transcript abundance rather than sex-specific pre-mRNA splicing in the coding region. During embryogenesis,maD1 is increased in males and primarily detected in male structures. Knocking downma1 in males results in female traits and ovarian maturation, while ectopic expression in females results in male-like phenotypes. Another Dma gene,ma2, has similar expression patterns but silencing and overexpression do not induce clear phenotypic changes. These results establishma1 as a key regulator of the male phenotype. The study reveals how ES is implemented by selective expression of a conserved component in genetic sex determination (GSD) and infers an ancient link between ES and SD.
Researchers have developed a trivalent HSV-2 vaccine that targets glycoproteins C, D, and E (gC, D, g2, E) to block virus entry and immune evasion by g2 and g2. The vaccine was tested in rhes macaques and guinea pigs. Inhes macques, the trivalent vaccine induced plasma and mucosa neutralizing antibodies, blocking g2 and g2 immune evasion, and stimulated CD4 T cell responses. After intravaginal challenge, a selfimited vaginal infection was detected by histopath and immunohisto in naïve, but not trivalent immunized macques. Vaccine efficacy was evaluated in guinea pigs. Animals were mock, immunized with g2, trivalent, or trivalent + g2. The tr and tr +2 groups were 97% and 99% efficacious in preventing genital lesions, outperforming g2 alone. Vaginal swabs were evaluated for HSV-2 DNA and replication between five and seven weeks after challenge. HSV-2 DNA was reduced in all groups compared to mock. Shedding of replication virus occurred fewer days in tr than g2 immunized, while tr +2 had no shedding replication virus. The tr group had <1% genital lesions and 0.2% shedding replication virus.
Researchers have developed a new method called Permseq to map protein-DNA interactions in segmental duplications and highly repetitive regions of genomes. These regions play a significant role in cellular regulatory programs. Next-generation sequencing enabled genome-wide profiling of protein-DNA interactions through chromatin immunoprecipitation followed by high-throughput sequencing (ChIP-seq). However, interactions in highly repetitive regions have been difficult to map due to short reads (50-100 base pairs) mapping to multiple locations in the genome. Standard methods discard multi-mapping reads and those that can accommodate are prone to false positives and negatives. Permseq is an enhanced read allocation method for Ch-se experiments that allocates multiapping in repetitive regions with high accuracy. It was comprehensively evaluated and found to significantly improve multi-read accuracy over approaches not utilizing additional data. The underlying statistical framework facilitates multi-read allocation with various data including histone Ch-se. Permseq was applied to 64 ENCODE Ch-se datasets from GM78 and K562 cells, identifying novel protein-D interactions in segmental regions. Analysis revealed protein-D interactions are evolutionarily conserved in repetitive, sharing characteristics with non-repet regions.
A nested case-control study was conducted in Tanzania to investigate the effects of schistosomiasis on susceptibility to HIV-1 infection and HIV-1 viral load at HIV-1 seroconversion. Approximately 40% of the population had Schistosoma mansoni infection and 2% had S. haematobium. The study found that women with schistosome infections had a higher odds of HIV-1 acquisition compared to those without, with an adjusted odds ratio of 2.8 (1.2-6.6, p=0.019). In contrast, schist-infected men did not have an increased odds of HIV-1 acquisition. The study also compared HIV-1 RNA levels in post-serconversion blood in HIV-1 serconverters with schosias versus those without, and found a significantly higher median HIV-1 RNA level in serconverters with schias: 4.4(3.9-4.6) log copies/mL versus 3.7(2.3-4) p=0.017. The study confirms that pre-existing schist infection increases HIV-1 susceptibility in women and raises HIV-1 viral load at serconversion in an area with S. mansoni. This is the first study to demonstrate the effect of schist infection on HIV-1 susceptibility and control and differentiate by gender.
Researchers investigated ribosomal DNA (rDNA) copy number and sequence variation in human and mouse genomes using computational and droplet digital PCR approaches. They found that rDNA copy number and sequence can change in cancer genomes. Contrary to expectations, human cancer genomes exhibit a loss of rDNA copies accompanied by global copy number variation. The sequence is also more variable in cancer genomes. Genomes with lower rDNA copies show evidence of mTOR pathway activation. The PTEN phosphatase, a tumor suppressor and mTOR pathway regulator, is critical for genome stability. In a mouse model of leukemia, hematopoietic stem cells lacking PTEN have lower rDNA number than normal tissue, despite increased rRNA and protein production. Loss occurs early and is associated with hypersensitivity to DNA damage. rDNA loss is a feature in cancers with mTOR activation.
Researchers have developed a novel approach to study the spatiotemporal dynamics of bacterial growth, death, and spread within mammalian hosts by analyzing the behavior of tagged Salmonella enterica populations in wild-type and isogenic strains in mice. These strains are phenotypically identical but can be distinguished by quantitative PCR, enabling the estimation of bacterial death rates based on strain disappearance over time. A multidisciplinary approach was used to establish the timing, occurrence, and control of key infection parameters in host-pathogen combinations. Results show that shortly after infection, concomitant death and rapid replication lead to establishment of bacterial subpopulations in different organs, controlled by host antimicrobial mechanisms. Later, decreased mortality leads to exponential increase in bacteria spread locally, with mixing between organs via bactemia and stochastic selection.
Researchers have investigated the inverse problem of binocular 3D motion perception and found that existing schemes such as interocular velocity difference and changing disparity over time, as well as joint motion and disparity encoding, do not provide a general solution to the problem. A new framework combining local velocity with binocular disparity and other cues is proposed as a more flexible solution. In the context of the aperture problem, two strategies are derived: (1) normal preferring slow motion in 3D and (2) cyclopean based on slow in 2D motion. Perceived motion direction for ambiguous motion allows distinguishing between these 3D processing strategies. Theoretical results indicate velocity and disparity from tracking are necessary to solve 3D perception. It is suggested that motion and disparity are processed in parallel and integrated in the visual hierarchy.
Researchers investigated the structure and function of AlgJ, a protein involved in O-acetylation of alginate, a polysacchar produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa during lung infections in cystic fibrosis patients. The structure of Alg was determined to 1.83 Å resolution, revealing it as a SGN hyrolase-like protein with a distinct electrostatic surface compared to the N-terminal domain of AlgX. A conserved catalytic triad of D190, H192 and S288 was identified, and Alg exhibited acetylester activity in vitro. Residues in Alg signature motifs formed a network critical for alginate O-acetylation in vivo. Two electrospray ion mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) assays compared Alg and Alg binding to alginate, showing Alg weak or no binding while Alg bound polymannonic acid in a length-dependent manner. Additionally, Alg utilized surrogate acetyl donor 4-nitrophenyl acetate to catalyze alginate Oetylation. The results suggest Alg and Alg have separate roles in alg Oetylation, with Alg as terminal transferase.
Candida albicans is a common cause of human fungal infections and a significant source of mortality. It evades detection by the innate immune system through masking its cell wall with a layer of heavily glycosylated mannans. However, mutations or drugs that disrupt the cell wall can lead to exposure of β (1,3)-glucans, enhancing detection by immune cells like Dectin-1, C-type lectin. Our lab previously showed that phosphatidylserine synthase plays a role in β(1,3)-uc masking. A homozygous synthase mutant, choΔ, exhibits increased β(1)-uc exposure. Mitogen-Activated Protein Kinase (MAP) pathways and upstreamho small Gases regulate cell biogenesis and remodeling. In choΔ, both C1 and M1 MAPs are constitutively activated, acting downstream of Gases C42 andho, respectively. C42 activity is upregulated inΔ. It was hypothesized that activation C42 orho and their kinases cause unmasking. Disrupting M1 does not unmask inΔ, and hyperactivatingho in wild-type increases unmask and activates C1 and M. Moreover, hyperactivating kinase in wild-type leads to C1 activation and β(1)-uc exposure. Upregulation the C1 MAP causes unmask, responsible for unmask inΔ.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide association study of genetic loci for Alzheimer's disease (AD) and related dementias using neuropathologic data from 4,914 brain autopsies. The study aimed to gain insight into the molecular pathogenesis of AD and related dement. Neuropath data were used to define clinico-path AD or controls, assess neuropath features of AD (neuritic plaques, NPs; neurofibr tangles, NFT), and evaluate co-mor neuropath changes: cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA), Lewy body disease (LBD), hippocampal sclerosis of the elderly (HS), and brain injury (BI). Genome-wide significance was observed for clin-path AD, NPs, NFT, CAA, and L with variants in the apolipoprotein E (APO) gene, Galc transferase 7 (GAL7), ATP-binding cassette subfamily G member 1 (ABCG1), and intergenic region on chromosome 9 associated with NP score. Potassium conductance calcium-activated subfamily member 2 (KCN2) was associated with HS. Twelve of 21 nonAPO genetic loci for clinically-defined AD were confirmed in clin-path sample: CR1, BIN, CL, MS4A, PICAL, ABC, CD, P2, SOR, M, EF, ZW, and C with 9 of 12 showing odds ratio in clin-path. Correlation effect sizes for AD with NFT or N showed positive, while for VBI showed negative. Co-mor neuropath features showed nominal association with known loc. The study discovered new associations with neuropath features and aligned genetic AD with neurop changes in the largest autopsy of AD and dement.
Researchers have investigated the role of urea in protein unfolding using molecular dynamics simulations on 30 proteins with diverse native folds. Contrary to expectations, urea does not induce unfolding but rather stabilizes the unfolded state by concentrating in the protein's first solvation shell with lower density than the fully unfolded state. Urea does not alter protein vibrations, instead reducing their magnitude and slowing atomic motions opposing unfolding. However, urea's stickiness and diffusion are crucial for unfolding. Long urea molecules near hydrophobic cores stabilize partially open structures generated by thermal fluctuations. Simulations show ure does not favor open microstates but is not a passive unfolding spectator, displacing the folded-unfolded equilibrium. Instead, ure actively unfolds by selecting and stabilizing partially unfolded microstates, driving the conformation away from native and thermal conformations.
A systematic review was conducted to describe the epidemiology of deng disease in Colombia from 2000 to 2011. Literature searches were conducted using the terms "deng", "epemiology", and "Colia" in English and Spanish, yielding 225 citations, of which 30 met the inclusion criteria. The epidemiology of deng disease in Colombia was characterized by a stable annual number of deng fever cases, with outbreaks in 2001-2003 and 2010. Geographical spread of deng cases increased, with most of the country affected by 2010. The majority of deng cases were among those under 15 years old. Asymptomatic d virus infection, primary versus secondary infections, and under-reporting of disease were identified as gaps in knowledge areas for future research. Understanding factors determining disease expression is crucial for improved control and management.
Leishmaniasis (TL) is a disease caused by Leishmania parasites that affects skin and mucosal tissues. Patients with TL may concurrently carry other pathogens that influence the disease outcome. This review examines the frequency of TL coinfections in populations, interactions between Leishmania and other pathogens in animal and human models, and implications for clinical practice. TL is defined as cutaneous, localized, disseminated, or mucocutaneous forms. HIV coinfection, superinfection, and skin manifestations of visceral lemanias are excluded. A literature search yielded 73 records: 21 studies in animals and 52 in humans (mainly cross-sectional and case studies). Trypanosoma cruzi coinfection was reported in 41% of TL patients in Argentina and helminthias in 15-88% in Brazil. Mechanisms of interaction between microorganisms are unclear, possibly involving innate immunity and regulatory networks affecting acquired responses. Diagnostic challenges arise when concurrent infections cause similar lesions (e.g., TL and leprosy), pathogens in same lesions (e.g., Leish and Sporothrix schenii), or phylogenetically close pathogens affect tests (e.g., serology leishias and Chagas). Some coinfections (e.g., helminias) reduce antileman treatment effectiveness and combinations cause adverse effects. In TL patients, coinfection is frequent, leading to diagnostic delays and treatment effectiveness and safety issues.
Researchers investigated the impact of genetic variation in the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) on CD4:CD8 lineage commitment and MHC expression in rats. They used two genetic models to assess the contribution of specific genes in the MHC region and whether they regulate MHC expression and T cell selection. Quantitative Trait Loci (QTL) associated with MHC I and II protein expression and CD:CD T ratio were mapped in outbred heterogeneous rats, identifying 10 QTL across the genome. QTL for individual traits colocalized within a region spanning MHC. To identify underlying genes, M-recombinant congenic strains were generated, refining QTL to intervals ~0.25 Mb in M-I and II regions. An interaction between intervals affected M class I expression and negative lineage commitment CD8-positive (SP) thymocytes. The effect was mapped to transporter associated antigen 2 (Tap) in M-II and classical M class (RT-A) in-I. A recombination between RT-A and Tap occurred in 0.2% of rats. Variants Tap influence antigenicity M class molecules by altering M ligandome. Results show restricted repertoire M class molecules to negative CD8 cells. This is the first study showing recombination natural alleles M influences T lineage.
A retrospective study was conducted using the Spanish National Health System's Hospital Discharge Database (CMB) to analyze the evolution of Chagas disease in Spain from 1997 to 2011. The study included 172 hospitalizations for Chagas disease, divided into two periods: 199-2004 and 2005-201. Hospitalization rates and clinical characteristics were described, and multivariable logistic regression was used to calculate adjusted odds ratio (OR) for association between conditions and hospitalization with organ damage. Hospitalization rates were 18.2/100,000 and 24.8/100,000 for the two periods, respectively. Median age was 35 (0-87), 74, with 74% female and 16-45 age group represented 69.8%. 23.4% hospitalizations included Chagas diagnosis with complications. Being male (OR 1.3, 1-1.77), aged 45-64 (OR 2.59, 1.42-4.71), and hospital cost above 3,065 (OR 2.03, 3.73.7) were associated with hospitalization complications. Since 2005, detected infections increased in Spain. Asymptomatic patients, women, fertile age, and conditions with complications highlight the need for early detection of T cruzi.
Researchers have identified hundreds of genetic markers associated with various diseases, yet a significant portion of the heritability remains unexplained. Combinatorial interactions are thought to contribute to this missing heritability, but have been challenging to discover due to computational complexity and genetic heterogeneity. To address this, a novel approach called Blocuster was developed to construct genome-wide, allele-specific networks that segregate homogeneous combinations of genetic factors and test their associations with phenotypes. Blocuster employs a correlation measure tailored for single nucleotide polymorphisms and captures genetic heterogeneity through a multifaceted collection of values. It was applied to psoriasis, discovering a combinatorial pattern with an odds ratio of 3.64 and a Bonferr-corrected p-value of 5.01×10−16. This pattern was replicated in independent data, validating the method's robustness. Blocuster improves disease susceptibility prediction and understanding of psoriasis pathogenesis, demonstrating its potential for discovering combinatorial genetic associations in genome-wide data.
Researchers conducted a large-scale chromosomal copy number variation (CN) study in 255 patients with agenesis of the corpus callo (ACC), 220 with cerebellar hypoplasia (CBL), and 147 with polymicrogyria (PM), and 2,349 controls to investigate the genetic causes of these congenital brain malformations. The study found that significantly more ACC patients had rare copy number variants (CNVs) over 1 megabase compared to controls (p=1.48×10-3, odds ratio=3.19, 95% confidence interval=1.89-5.39), but not CBL or PM patients. Rare CNVs impacted at least 1% of genes in patients and controls. Additionally, more ACC patients had CNVs over 20 genes compared to controls (p=0.01, odds ratio=2.95, 95% CI=1.69-5.18). Independent PCR confirmation showed 9.4% of ACC patients had de novo CNVs, which preferentially overlapped with de novo CNs in patients with autism spectrum disorders (p=3.06×10-4, odds=7.55, 95 CI=2.40-23). The study also confirmed and refined known CNs, including the 8p23.1-p11 duplication in 2% of the ACC cohort. Novel CNs were identified in single patients, including deletions 1p.31.3-p31.1, 1.31.2-31.3, 5.23.1, and 15.11-q13.1, and duplications 2.11-q13 and 11.14-p.2. One patient with microcephaly had paternally inherited 16.11 deletion including N1. Exome sequencing revealed recessive matally inherited nonsense mutation in non-deleted N1 allele. This study is the first systematic CN investigation in congenital brain malations, showing higher large gene-rich CN in ACC than CBL and PM.
Researchers investigated the role of Yorkie, a key effector of the Hippo signaling pathway, in planarian regeneration and its response to injury. The freshwater planarian Schmidtea mediterranea was used as a model organism due to its high regenerative capacity. Yorkie RNA interference (RNAi) animals showed hyperactivated wound responses, characterized by increased stem cell proliferation and prolonged transcriptional wound program. This led to the identification of novel wound-induced genes repressed in Yorkie RNAi animals compared to controls. Additionally, Yorkie RNAi animals exhibited expanded epidermal and muscle populations, hypothesized to be sources of wound-induced genes. Furthermore, Yorkie RNAi animals failed to sense the size of an injury by the eyes, pharynx, brain, and gut, and midline, failing to remodel correctly scale to the regenerating fragment. These findings suggest Yorkie integrates multiple aspects of injury response, including proliferation, apoptosis, injury transcription, and patterning.
Exosomes secreted by cells infected with Enterovirus 71 (EV71) contain viral RNA and microRNA-146, which facilitate viral replication in recipient cells by suppressing the type I interferon response. EV71 infection leads to increased exosome secretion and differential packaging of viral RNA and microRNA-146. MicroRNA-146 is preferentially packaged in exosomes, while viral RNA is retained in infected cells. Exosomes contain replication-competent EV71 RNA complexed with microRNA-146, Ago2, and GW182 and mediate EV transmission independent of virus-specific receptors. Exosomal RNA is transferred to and replicates in new cells while exosomal micro-146 suppresses type I interferon response, facilitating viral replication. IFN-stimulated gene (ISGs), BST2/tether, regulate EV-induced exosome secretion. In vivo study, exosomal RNA accumulates differentially in tissues compared to free virus.
Researchers investigated the relationship between PTEN kinase 1 (PINK) and Parkin, two genes associated with early-onset Parkinson's disease, in Drosophila. PINK is a serine/threon kinase with a predicted mitochondrial sequence and transmembrane domain, while Parkin is a RING finger protein with ubiquitin ligase activity.
