A time-dependent model of molecular adaptations is used to analyze the dynamics of changes in biological systems during treatment. This approach identifies necessary changes in model parameters to describe transitions between different stages of treatment, providing insight into affected biological systems and molecular events. ADAPT captures interactions between proteome and transcriptome levels, often less understood, through time-dependent parameter descriptions. The method was applied to investigate adaptations induced by pharmacological activation of liver receptor X (LXR), a potential target for atherosclerosis treatment. Trajectories showed a cascade of adaptations, revealing a counterintuitive function of scavenger receptor B1 (SR1), facilitating hepatic cholesterol uptake. Although LXR activation promotes cholesterol efflux and excretion, analysis showed reduced hepatic capacity to clear cholesterol upon prolonged treatment, confirmed by immunoblot measurements of SR1 in hepatic membranes. Additionally, ADAPT was used to identify potential side effects and design interventions to prevent them.
Researchers have investigated the processing of multi-dimensional sensorimotor information in the spinal and cerebellar neuronal circuitry, focusing on why sensory and motor signals are combined in the neurons of the spinocerebell pathways and how granule cells receive this input with respect to their output. A new hypothesis is proposed on how the spinerebell systems and cerebell cortex interact to support coordination of multi-segment limbs and bodies. The recombination of signals to the spinerebell neurons can approximate spatial and temporal dependencies between limb segments, necessary for coordination. However, random recombination of sensory and motor signals is limited by the number of granule cells, which restricts the number of recombinations. Instead, the spinal circuit provides useful recombinations described as linear projections of multi-dimensional input space. Granule cells, aided by Golgi cells, enhance these projections allowing Purkinje cells to approximate non-linear functions. The hypothesis provides a novel view on spinal and cerebell gran layer function, illustrating cerebell coordination supported by spinere recombinations.
Researchers employed next-generation sequencing to investigate the regulation of microRNAs (miRNAs) during Chikungunya virus (CHV) development in the mosquito vector Aedes albopictus. The study identified 88 known and 79 miRNAs in uninfected and CHV infected Ae. albictus cell lines, respectively, and nine novel miRNAs in Ae. albict. Comparison of the two libraries revealed differential expression of 77 miRN between CHV infection. Specifically, CHV altered the mi profile of eight miRN. The putative targets of these miRN were classified into pathways. This study identified and described mi profiles upon CHV in Ae. albict, providing insight into cellular modification by mi during CHV infection and potential candidates for vector-based antiviral strategies.
A study was conducted to determine the economic burden of Cysticercosis (CE) in Iran. CE is a parasitic disease affecting humans and livestock, with significant medical and economic importance in developing countries, including Iran. Data on epidemiology, including prevalence and incidence in humans and animals, were obtained from hospitals, literature, and government reports. Economic data on human and animal disease, including treatment costs, productivity, and livestock losses were from national and international datasets. Monte Carlo methods represented uncertainty in parameters. Estimated 1,295 surgical cases per year 2000-2009, and 635,232 asymptomatic individuals (95%CI 149,466-1,120,998). Annual CE cost in Iran was $232.3 million (95% CI $103.1-397.8), including direct and indirect costs. Human cost was $93.3 million (95 CI $6.1-222.7) and livestock $132 million (95 CI $61.8-246.5). Per case was $1,539. CE has considerable impact on Iran, approximating 0.03% of country's domestic product. A surveillance system and control program are necessary to reduce burden. Cost-benefit analysis programs recommended incorporating losses in Iran.
Mousepolyomavirus (MPV) is a lytic virus that infects mouse cells, transforms cell culture, and is highly oncogenic in rodents. Researchers used deep sequencing to analyze MPV infection of NIH3T cells at various times post-infection and analyzed both viral and cellular transcriptomes. The analysis revealed a transcriptional profile of early-to-late switch with both early-strand and late-strand RNAs transcribed at all times. Novel insights into viral expression emerged, including widespread RNA editing of transcripts late in infection. By late infection, 359 host genes were significantly upregulated and 857 downregulated. Gene ontology indicated transcripts involved translation, metabolism, RNA processing, DNA methylation, and protein turnover upregulated, while extracellular adhesion, cytoskeleton, zinc binding, SH domain and GTP activation downregulated. Noncoding RNAs levels altered, noncoding MAL1, involved splicing and marker late cancers, downregulated, while others strongly upregulated.
Hundreds of thousands of runners attempt to complete a marathon each year, with over two-fifths experiencing severe performance-limiting depletion of physiologic carbohydrate reserves, known as "hitting the wall", resulting in thousands dropping out before the finish. Analyses of endurance physiology have suggested that glycogen reserves are insufficient to fuel a marathon, making "hitting the wall" inevitable, or that maximal glycogen loading is required to complete a marathon without "hitting the wall". A computational study demonstrates that energetic constraints on runners are more subtle, depending on physi variables including muscle distribution, liver glycogen density, and running intensity as a fraction of aerobic capacity. The study estimates distance at which runners exhaust glyc stores as a function of intensity, providing a basis for ensuring safety and optimizing performance by setting paces and prescribing mid-race fueling to avoid "the wall". The analysis sheds light on standards in running that have remained empirically defined, such as Boston Marathon qualifying times.
Researchers conducted a transcriptional analysis of murine macrophages infected with different Toxoplas strains to identify novel regulation of host signaling pathways. Toxoplas from Europe and North America belong to three distinct genetic lineages (I, II, and III), whereas South American isolates are rare and diverse. T. gondii strains exhibit various phenotypes in mice, such as virulence, persistence, oral infectivity, migratory capacity, cytokine induction, and host gene expression modulation. Toxoplasis outcomes vary, and the parasite genotype is hypothesized to play a role besides host and environmental factors. Macrophages are crucial in early immune response against T. gondii and preferentially infected in vivo. To determine non-canonical Tooplas interactions, murine macrophages were infected with 29 Tooplas strains representing diversity, and RNA-sequencing analyzed host and parasite transcriptomes. Large differences were found in parasite effector expression and chromosomal variation in some strains. Novel strain-specific host pathways were identified, including type I interferon regulation by atypical strains. IFβ production was associated with parasite killing, independent of interferon gamma, dependent on endosomal Toll-like receptors in macroph and cytoplasmic receptor retic-inducible gene 1 (RIG) in fibroblasts.
Researchers have investigated the process of recombination in enteroviruses, a mechanism that allows for the acquisition of new genetic material and is crucial for the emergence of novel pathogenic variants of poliovirus. Despite its importance, the recombination process remains poorly understood. A novel genetic approach was used to isolate chimeric interic poliruses with duplicated sequences at the recombination junction. Serial passage of viruses with imprecise junctions yielded progeny with increased fitness, which lost the duplicated sequences. Mutations affecting polymerase fidelity or replication complexes altered recombination yield, but not non-recombination. This suggests recombination is replicative and can be enhanced or reduced. The study proposes that recombinants result from a biphasic process: initial recombination followed by resolution, deleting extraneous sequences and optimizing fitness. This has implications for understanding evolution in positive-strand RNA viruses.
Researchers have identified a new catecholamine clearance route in adipocytes, specifically in white adipose tissue, mediated by the organic anion transporter 3 (Oct3, also known as Slc22a3). This route is distinct from previously reported mechanisms involving sympathetic neurons or pro-inflammatory macrophages in adipose tissues. Oct3 is highly expressed in white adipose tissue and displays the highest uptake rate of norepinephrine (NE) compared to other routes. Adipocytes express high levels of degradation enzymes monoamine oxidase A (Mao), monoamine oxidase B (Mob), and catechol O-methyltransferase (Comt), enabling NE clearance by adipocytes and reuptake Oct3. Administration of Oct ablation induces higher thermogenesis and lipolysis compared to littermate controls. After prolonged cold challenge, inguinal white adipose adipose tissue (WAT) in Oct-deficient mice shows stronger browning and elevated thermogenic gene expression than littermates, involving β-adrenergic receptor (β-AR)/protein kinase (PKA)/cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)-responsive element binding (CRE) pathway. Glycolytic genes are reprogrammed to compensate for ATP loss in adip-specific Oct knockout (KO) mice. Inhibition β-AR abolishes lipolytic and thermogenic activities in Oct-deficient WAT, indicating NE overload in vicinity adipocytes OctKO. Reduced alleles in OCT are associated with increased basal metabolic rate (BMR). Oct governs β-activity as NE transporter in adipocytes, offering therapeutic potential for metabolic disorders.
Heterochromatin-enriched HP proteins, specifically HP1, play a crucial role in regulating gene expression by binding to histone H3 tails methylated on lysine 9 via their chrom-domain. However, their affinity for methylated chromatin is poor in vivo and in vitro, and chromatin opening during replication facilitates their binding to nucleosomes. This led to the investigation of additional histone binding activities of HP proteins. The chromadow-domain of HP interacts with histone H3 in a region inside the nucleosomal barrel, the entry/exit point of the nucleosome. This region is also contacted by the catalytic subunits of the SWI/SNF complex. In vitro, SW/SNF remodeling requires this contact and is inhibited by HP proteins. Antagonism between SW/SNF and HP is observed on interferon-regulated genes. SW/S activity loads HP to chromatin in vivo and vitro. Our data suggest HP chromadow-domains benefit nucleosomal opening to bind chromatin and HP use this to arrest chrom remodeling.
Researchers investigated the property of self-containment in RNA structures, which refers to the tendency of an RNA sequence to maintain its optimal secondary structure regardless of its surrounding nucleotide context. They defined self-containment using a scoring method called the self-containment index and found that microRNAs (miRNAs) exhibit high self-containment, consistent with the requirement for structural invariance imposed by the miRNA biogenesis pathway. In contrast, most other structured RNAs do not display self-containment. Further analysis revealed a trend towards higher self-containment among conserved miRNAs, suggesting that self-containment may be a characteristic of miRN acquiring new genomic contexts. The study also found that miRNAs display enhanced self-containment compared to other functional RNAs and a trend towards natural selection for self-cont in functional classes. The authors propose that self-cont arises from selection for robustness against perturbations during biogenesis and modular composition of function.
Researchers have identified four transcription factors (TFs) in Arabidopsis that play a crucial role in limiting the spread of necrotrophic fungal pathogens, including Botrytis cinerea and Plectphaella cucumeria. Mutations in these TFs result in increased susceptibility to these pathogens and activation of non-immune host processes that contribute to disease. Transcriptome analysis revealed a common transcriptional signature of 77 up-regulated genes in mutants. Several of these up-regulated genes encode secreted peptides, named PROIR (provirulence factors), which are important for disease susceptibility to necrophic pathogens.
Researchers have identified the transcription factor Forkhead Box 1 (FOX1) as a critical regulator of endometrial receptivity for embryo implantation. In a study using the progesterone receptor (PGR) Cre mouse model, uterine ablation of Fox1 resulted in infertility due to altered epithelial cell polarity and apoptosis, preventing embryo penetration of the luminal epithelium. Analysis of the utine transcriptome after Fox1 ablation revealed changes in gene expression for cell activation, invasion, molecular transport, apoptosis, β-caten (CTN1) signaling, and increased progesterone receptor (PGR) signaling. Increased PGR signaling was due to PGR retention in the utine epithelium during the window of receptivity. Constitutive expression of epithelial P during this period inhibited FOX1 in the nucleus of utine epithelium. Reciprocal expression of P and FOX1 was observed in human endrial samples during proliferative and secretory phases. The study demonstrates FOX1 and loss of P during receptivity are interrelated for implantation.
Researchers developed a statistical model to map the spread of deng cases in Bangladesh, accounting for underreporting due to zero-inflation. They analyzed district-level monthly deng cases from 2000 to 2009, using a negative binomial generalized linear mixed model with spatial and temporal effects. Bayesian inference was performed using the integrated Laplace approximation. The study found that mean temperature and its interaction with mean diurnal range, lagged by two months, were significantly associated with deng incidence. Mean rainfall two months prior was positively associated with deng. Densely populated districts and those bordering India or Myanmar had higher incidence than others. The model estimated 92% of annual deng cases occurred between August and September. Cases were reported across the country, with 94 in the capital Dhaka, located centrally. Less than half of reported cases were observed from surveillance data. The proportion varied by month, with higher in high-incidence districts, decreasing towards the end of transmission.
In a novel environment, mice exhibit a preference for a specific location marked by the highest number of visits and cumulative time spent, which serves as a reference point for exploratory behavior. Examination of this "home" base" highlights its organizational features. Researchers investigated other types of marked places in exploratory behavior and their influence on overall behavior, discovering "knots" in a large arena. Knots are circumscribed areas with tortuous paths of twists and turns, characterized by high inbound speed and low outbound speed. Typically, one knot per session, with distinct boundaries, maintained within and across sessions, situated away from walls. Knots differ from "home" features, except for high inbound speed and low outbound speed. Knot establishment is enhanced by saline injection and placement in exposed arena, suggesting stress and arousal consolidate long-term contingency between locale and knot-scribling. In a cue-free environment, mice mark locale with twisting and turning, creating a self-generated, centrally located landmark. Knotcribling implies multiple views of the environment, allowing recalibration of locale and compass. Vestibular input from scribling improves scene interpretation.
High-Resolution Genetics Identifies Lipid Transfer Protein Sec14 as Target for Antifungal Compound NG04

Invasive fungal infections caused by pathogens result in over 1.6 million deaths worldwide annually. A high-throughput screening identified the ergoline compound NG04 as an antifungal agent with selectivity over mammalian cells. High-resolution chemogenomics revealed lipid transfer protein Sec14 as the target of NG04, with resistant mutations in Sec14 defining compound interactions in the protein's binding pocket. Beyond its lipid transfer function in pathogenic fungi, Sec14 is involved in secretion of virulence determinants essential for pathogenicity of fungi such as Cryptococcus neoformans, making Sec14 an attractive antif target. Consistent with dual function, NG04 inhibits growth of clinical isolates C neo and NG04-related compounds show equal potency against neo. NG04 analogues exhibit fungicidal activity against fluconazole-resistant neo strain. We present genetic evidence NG04 inhibits Sec14, supporting NG as novel antif starting point.
Researchers have identified mefloquine, an antimalarial drug, as a potential treatment for schistosomiasis, a neglected tropical disease that exacerbates poverty. Current treatment relies on a single drug, prazantel, which may lead to drug-resistant parasites, necessitating new antischosomal compounds. Mefloquine was tested in mice infected with Schistoma mansoni and S japonicum, resulting in significant worm burden reductions (72.3-100%) after a single oral dose of 200-400mg/kg. High reductions were also observed in young stages of S mansoni and japon in mice. Both meflo enantiomers showed comparable worm reductions in subpatent and patent S mans infections. These findings suggest a novel antischosomal drug based on aminoal functionality. Further in vitro and in vivo studies aim to elucidate meflo's mechanism and effect on S haobium and other trematodes.
A study was conducted in Cameroon to map the geographical distribution of podoiosis, a non-filar elephantias characterized by massive swelling of the lower legs. Podoiosis was identified as a neglected disease by the World Health Organization in 2011. A multi-stage sampling design stratified the country by environmental risk of podoiosis, sampling 76 villages from 40 districts in 10 regions. All individuals 15 years or older in villages were surveyed and screened for lymphedema. A clinical algorithm diagnosed podoiosis excluding filarial lymphema. Individuals with lymphema were tested for Wuchereria bancrofti antigen and IgG using Alere Filasis Strips (F) test and Standard Diagnostics (SD) BIOL lymphatic filariasis Ig4 (W123) tests, and thick films. 10,178 individuals from 4,603 households participated, 83 with lymphema were identified, 2 were F positive and negative W123. No microfilar W bancft were found in blood individuals with lymphema. None were positive W bancft using PCR. Two F positive cases were positive Mansonella perst DNA and Loa loa microilar.52 podoiosis were identified applying clinical algorithm. Prevalence podoiosis 0.5% (95% CI 0.4-0.7). At least one podo in every region except Adamawa. 40 districts no cases, 15 mean 0.2-1%, remaining 8 mean 1.2-2.7%. Investigation demonstrated low nationwide podo in Cameroon. Designing podo program vital health response burden podo through surveillance morbidity services.
Notch Signaling Mediates the Age-Associated Decrease in Adhesion of Germl Stem Cells to Niche

In Drosophila female germline stem cells (GSCs), Notch signaling is increased with age, leading to their removal from the niche. Low levels of Notch signaling in GSCs result in increased adhesion to the niche, outcompeting neighbors with higher levels of Notch. Adhesion is regulated by E-cadherin expression. Notch signaling in Gs hastens age-dependent loss from niche, partially mediated by Sex. Disruption of Not signaling in Gs does not delay G loss during aging, nor affects BMP, which promotes self-renew of Gs. In contrast, niche Not activation maintains niche integrity, mediating G retention, is reduced with age, indicating Not regulates niche occupancy both intrinsically and extrinsically.
Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) UL97 protein, a kinase, phosphorylates the retinoblastoma (Rb) tumor suppressor and lamin A proteins, which are also substrates of cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs). A functional complementation assay showed UL97 has CDK-like activity. Seven human herpesviruses encode a kinase with sequence homology to UL97, termed conserved herpesvirus kinases (CHPs). To determine if UL97 CDK-like activity was shared by all CHPs, each protein was expressed in human cells to test R phosphorylation, lamin A phosphorylation, and nuclear disruption, or S. cerevisiae cdc-13 to assay CD function. All beta and gamma-herpes CHPs phosphorylated R and lamin, disrupted nuclear, while alpha-herpes did not. Similarly, all but one beta and gamma CHPs displayed CD activity in S. cerevisiae, while alpha did not. This identified virally CD-like kinases, abbreviated v-CDKs. Non-CD activities of UL97, promyelocytic leukemia protein bodies (PMLBs) and cytoplasmic nuclear aggres, showed conservation among CHPs, not segregating specific families. Genomic conservation not maintained at functional level. Data indicate related kinases, some antiviral drugs targets, serve overlapping functions during infections.
A systematic review was conducted to determine the global distribution of Burkholderia pseudallei, a Tier 1 select agent and cause of melioidosis, in the environment. The study aimed to update the risk map of meloidosis and propose international guidelines for soil sampling. A working group, the Detection Environmental Burkholder pseudalle Working Party (DEBP), was formed during the 6th Meloidosis Congress in 2010. PubMed was searched from January 2012 to 2011 using MeSH terms pseudalle and meloidosis. Bibliographies were searched for secondary references. The geographical distribution of pseudalle in the environment was categorized as definite, probable, or possible. The methodology for detecting pseudalle was extracted and collated. Global coverage was patchy with a lack of studies in areas where meloid is suspected. Sampling and bacterial methods were variable and not robust. Consensus guidelines were developed to reduce false-negative results and provide affordable, low-tech methods for developed and developing countries. The guidelines provide a basis for an accurate global pseudalle map.
Researchers have identified peptides that inhibit the entry of denguevirus by targeting a late-stage intermediate in the fusion process. The mechanism of membrane fusion by class II viral proteins involves large-scale rearrangements of the envelope glycoprotein E, transitioning from dimers to trimers. This rearrangement occurs through the outward rotation of the ectodomain after loss of the dimer interface, followed by reassociation into trimers. A 55-residue membrane-proximal stem then zips up domain II, bringing the transmembrane segments of the C-terminus and fusion loops of domain II together. Peptides derived from the stem of deng-virus bind to E stem-less trimer, a conformation intermediate in vitro. Assays show these peptides block viral fusion and infectivity with potency proportional to their affinity for the conformation intermediate, even when peptide is removed from preincubated inoculum before infecting cells. The peptides bind virions before attachment and are carried into endosomes, where acidification initiates fusion. Binding depends on dynamics, as there is no inhibition if preincation and separation at 4°C rather 37. A two-step model for the mechanism of inhibition is proposed. Targeting viral entry can block infection effectively. Data support proposed mechanisms how conformation change promotes fusion and suggest inhibiting flavivirus entry.
Researchers have developed a method to sequence the whole genome of Vibrio cholera directly from dried filter paper, enabling molecular analysis of the bacterium in resource-limited settings. Cholera causes approximately 4 million cases and 95,000 deaths annually, with recent outbreaks in Haiti and Yemen highlighting its global health concern. Specimens preserved on paper allow for rapid, low-cost, and safe sequencing, providing data on circulating strains, contributing to policy on cholera control and elimination. Whole genome sequencing (WGS) recovered a complete V. cholera O genome from stool enriched alkaline peptone water (AP) and V. cholera culture, spotted on filter, with 0.02 ng/μL DNA concentration. GS confirmed presence/absence of genes, including cholera toxin and pilus loci. GS identified diarral pathogens from AP-enriched specimen, highlighting potential for gut microbiome exploration and co-infections impacting disease severity. GS placed specimens in global cholera phylogenetic tree, identifying 7th pandemic El Tor. GS mapped reads from AP-enrich and culture isolate filter papers, providing epidemiological information on V. cholera strains in remote settings. This identified co-infecting pathogens and rare V. cholera strains in choleraemic areas.
Researchers have identified a protein called Dyne that plays a crucial role in regulating epithelial polarity in Drosophila follicle cells. Epithelial polarity is essential for the proper organization and function of epithelial tissues, and is maintained by the precise localization of apical and basolateral determinants. However, little was known about how these determinants are localized within the cell. A genetic screen for epithelial defects in Drosila follicle cells revealed that Dyne is essential for apico-basal polarity. Dy acts through the cytoplasmic scaffolding protein Stardust (Sdt) to localize the transmembrane protein Crumbs, by targeting specific dt mRNA isoforms to the apical region. The mRNA localization signal was mapped to an alternatively spliced exon. The presence or absence of this exon corresponds to a developmental switch in dt mRNA localization, with apical transcripts found in early stages of epithelial development and unlocalized in mature epithelia. This is the first demonstration of Dyne's role in epithelial polarity and suggests mRNA localization may regulate ap-basal organization. Alternative splicing of a coding exon controls mRNA localization during development.
Researchers have investigated the mode of reproduction in Leishmania infantum, a parasite that causes leishmaniasis, and found evidence of intraclonal genetic exchange in the natural vector. Previous studies suggested a clonal reproduction, but genetic analysis of populations and co-infections in sand flies proposed a non-obate sexual cycle in the extracellular stage. To test this, transgenic L. infant lines were developed expressing drug markers linked to green and red fluorescent reporters. The hypothesis was that cells with identical genotypes could recognize and mate. In a study, individuals of Phlebotus periciosus were fed a mixture of parental clones, and both markers were exchanged in the sand midgut of the vector. Using yellow and drug markers, genetic exchange in L. infant was confirmed. Progeny were triploid based on DNA analysis. The hybrid was stable throughout the parasite cycle. Infections by the hybrid in BAL/c mice showed reduced parasite loads in spleen and liver, and weight similar to uninfected mice. Sple argin activity was lower than parental strains. A L. infant hybrid was obtained from intraonal exchange, suggesting the parasite can recognize same genotype and mate. The hybrid was stable but less virulent, correlating with lower argin activity in vitro and vivo.
Leishmaniasis (VL), caused by Leishmania donovani, is a significant health concern in Ethiopia. A study on VL transmission in HIV-VL co-infected patients in north and south Ethiopia characterized 63 L. donani strains. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was used to examine three regions: internal transcribed spacer 1 (ITS), cysteine protease (cp), and HASPB (k26). ITS and cp-PCR identified strains as L. donani, while k-PCR amplicon size varied by patient origin. Northwestern Ethiopia strains (36/40) produced 290bp, with minority (4/40) 410 amplicons, all from HIVL co-infections. Southwestern strains (20/23) produced 450bp, with smaller (290 or 360) for three. Sudanese strains had 290bp identical to northwestern, Kenyan 500-650. High-resolution (HR) analysis distinguished products. Sequence analysis showed k repeat in L donani comprised 13-14 amino motifs, 13 prevalent in don, rare in infantum. Order varies between regions. HAS repeat (k) shows considerable polymorphism among donani from East Africa regions. This should inform diagnostic and vaccine design based on antigen.
Researchers investigated the distribution of recombination breakpoints in HIV-1 genomes to understand how they contribute to the diversity of the HIV/AIDS pandemic. They developed a probabilistic model of HIV-1 recombination based on local sequence identity and compared it to the distribution of breakpoints in the HIV pandemic. The model accurately predicted the frequencies of inter-subtype recombination across much of the HIV genome, indicating that local sequence-dependent recombination is sufficient to explain breakpoint locations. In regions with significant overrepresentation of breakpoints, such as the env gene, and underrepresentation, like gag and pol, natural selection was inferred to influence recombination. The paucity of breakpoints in the envelope gene suggests recombinants in this region are less successful. Breakpoints at higher than predicted were found near env, indicating selection for recombinants due to this region or part of it being recombined as a unit. The findings indicate a portion of the genome deviates from a probabilistic recombination model, suggesting only a minority of recombination events contribute to HIV-1 evolution.
A hierarchical Bayesian inference (HBI) framework is proposed for concurrent model comparison and parameter estimation at the population level, addressing the interdependence between model parameter estimation and model comparison. This framework combines previous approaches to estimate individual variation in parameters over a population of subjects, leveraging population distributions, and compare candidate models by individual variation in expressed according to fits to each subject. The population parameters for estimating a model depend on subjects that express the model. HBI has advantages for both estimation and comparison theoretically and experimentally. Estimated parameters by H show smaller errors compared to other methods. Model comparison by H is robust against outliers and not biased towards simplistic models. The fully Bayesian approach enables inference on group parameters by performing H-test. This framework integrates estimation and comparison into a single step, reducing computational complexity and improving accuracy. HBI is applied to simulated and real data, demonstrating improved performance over separate methods. Theoretical analysis shows that H minimizes bias and maximizes efficiency. H is robust to model misspecification and outliers, providing accurate inference on population parameters and model comparison.
Researchers have investigated the role of rhombomeres and Hox genes in the development of the auditory circuitry in the mouse brainstem. Rhomberes contribute to the formation of brainstem nuclei, including the ventral nucleus of the lateral lemniscus, ventral cochlear nuclei (VCN), and olivocochlear neurons, which are functionally linked to sensory and motor components of the auditory system. The assembly of these r-derived components is crucial for sound perception and relies on interactions between Hox1 and H2 genes. In mice lacking Hox1 and H2, transmission of low-level auditory stimuli is impaired, leading to hearing impairments. In contrast, H2 regulates Rig1 axon guidance and contralateral projections from the VC to the nucleus of the trapezoid, a circuit involved in sound localization. The study demonstrates that individual rhomeres and their associated H codes control distinct, functionally segregated circuits in the developing brainstem.
Researchers have sequenced the genome of the marine bacterium Saccharagus degradans strain 2-40 (S2-40), a member of a newly discovered group of estuarine bacteria that specializes in breaking down complex carbohydrates. The genome analysis reveals an impressive array of enzymes capable of degrading over 10 different types of polysaccharides. Notably, many of these enzymes exhibit unique architectures, featuring novel combinations of catalytic and substrate modules. It is proposed that these features facilitate the depolymerization of complex polysacchar in the marine environment. This is the first sequenced genome of a marine bacterium capable of degrading plant cell walls, a component of the carbon cycle not well-characterized in the marine environment.
Japanese Encephalitis virus (JEV) is a zoonotic flavivirus that causes significant childhood neurological infections in Asia. Over the past 20 years, the dominant genotype of JE has shifted from III (GIII) to I (GI). The mechanism of this shift is unknown. Culex (C) mosquitoes are common in China and play a crucial role in JE transmission. This study used C. pipiens mosquitoes from China as an in vivo model to explore their potential role in JE genotype shift. Female C. pipiens were orally exposed to GI or GIII JE strains. Midgut, organs, and salivary glands of infected mosquitoes were collected at 7 and 14 days post-infection (dpi) and subjected to measure infection rate, replication, dissemination, and transmission of JE in C. pip by 50% tissue infective dose assay. C. pip was competent for both GI and GIII infection, with similar rates and kinetics. After establishment, C pip disseminated both genotypes to organs at similar rates. GI-infected saliv glands (16.2%) were positive for GI, while GIII was undetectable in GIII-infected saliv at 7dpi. However, 29.4(5/17) and 36.3(8) were positive for GI- and GIII-infected saliv at 14, showing increase in JE rate. No difference in transmission between GI and G-infected was detected. Data showed GI and GIII have similar infectivity in C. pip, suggesting C pip may not play critical role in JE shift.
A two-year retrospective review of dengue deaths in Malaysia from 2013 to 2014 was conducted to investigate demographics and clinical characteristics associated with deng mortality. A total of 322 deng deaths were reviewed, with a mean age of 40.7 ± 19.3 years and 72.5% were adults. The median duration of first medical contact and hospitalization was 1 and 3 days, respectively. Diabetes and hypertension were common comorbidities among adults and elderly. The most common symptoms reported were lethargy and vomiting, with lethargy being more common in children (p=0.038) and abdominal pain in adults (p=0.040). 22.4% had no symptoms. Only 34% were suspected of deng at initial presentation. Adults developed severe plasma leakage (p=0.018) and more than half suffered multi-organ involvement (54%) and 20.2 had no organ involvement. Deaths occurred at median 3 days post-admission. Dengue shock syndrome (DSS) contributed 70% of deaths, followed by organ involvement (69%) and bleeding (29.7%). In Malaysia, deng deaths primarily occurred in adults, with SS as leading cause regardless of age. Atypical presentation and progression of deng in this cohort prompts early recognition and intervention to prevent deaths.
In a study on the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster, researchers investigated the role of insulin signaling in mediating female attractiveness to potential mates. Insulin, a nutrient-sensing pathway governing investment in survival versus reproduction, was manipulated to assess its impact on sexual attractiveness. Results showed that insulin signaling in the body and ovarian follicle cells, integrated by pherone-producing cells called oocytes, affects attractiveness. Ovaries were required for global insulin effects on attractiveness, and manipulations of insulin specifically in follicle cells recapitulated global manipulations. Modulation of insulin in the body produced opposite effects on attractiveness, suggesting a competitive relationship with the ovary. Tissue-specific insulin manipulations changed attractiveness and fecundity in the same direction, indicating insulin activity as a link between fecity and attractiveness cues. Cues, cuticular hydrocarbons responded to body and follicle manipulations, independent of pathway activity from these tissues. The study describes a system where attractiveness results from connection between attractiveness and organism state of fecity, both created by insulin in the body and in follicle cells.
During the 2013-2015 Ebola virus disease (EVD) epidemic in West Africa, the transmission of the virus varied significantly across the hardest-hit countries of Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone. To investigate district-level transmissibility of EVD, a statistical approach was applied to estimate the basic reproduction number (R0) for each district and country using weekly incident numbers. The growth rates during the early outbreak's exponential phase were estimated using regression of case counts on the first eight weeks since onset. A mixed model was fitted to account for heterogeneity between countries, calculating R based on predicted growth rates and serial distribution. At the district level, R ranged from 0.36 (Dubka) to 1.72 (Bey) in Guinea, 0.53 (Maryland) to 3.37 (Margibi) in Liberia, and 1.14 (Kadugu) to 2.73 (Rural) in Sierra Leone. Nationally, an R of 0.97 (95% 0.77-1.18) was estimated for Guinea, 1.26 (95%0.98-1.55) for Liberia, and 1.66 (95 1.32-2) for Sierra. Socio-demographic factors such as urbanization, high population density, and wealth index were positively associated with R, suggesting urban growth in West may have contributed to EVD spread.
Researchers investigated the factors that influence protein evolution rates, focusing on the interplay between structural properties and age. A dataset of one-to-one orthologs between human and mouse proteins with mapped to PDB structures was used. The study found that previously observed correlations between structural properties and evolutionary rates held within each age group, including relationships between solvent accessibility, designability, and rates. However, age also played a role in modulating the relationship between solvent accessibility and rate. Younger proteins, despite being less designable, evolved faster than older ones. The previously reported relationship between age and rate could not be explained by structural biases among groups. A knowledge-based function was introduced to study protein stability through large-scale computation. Older proteins were found to be more stable in their native structure and robust to mutations than younger ones.
Polycomb-like 3 (P3) is a component of the Polycomb repressive complex 2 (PRC2) that promotes embryonic stem cell (ES) self-renewal. Mass spectrometry identified P3 as a Suz12 binding partner, and co-immunoprecipitation confirmed P3 interactions with PR2 core components. Knockdown of P3 in ES cells increases spontaneous differentiation, yet does not affect early differentiation as assessed in teratom and embryoid bodies. P3 has a specific role in regulating ES self-renew. Consistent with P3 promoting PR2 function, decreasing P3 reduces H3me3 levels while overexpressing P3 increases H3me levels. Chromatin immunrecipitation and sequencing (IP-q) reveal P3 co-localizes with PR core component Suz, and depletion of P3 decreases Suz binding at 60% of PR targets. Mutation of conserved residues within P Tudor domain, implicated in recognizing methylated histones, compromises H3me formation, suggesting the Tud domain is essential. P3 and its paralog P2 exist in different PR complexes but bind many same targets, particularly Cp islands regulated by P3. P is critical for ES selfnew, histone methylation, and PR recruitment to subset genomic sites.
Researchers investigated the regulation of a chemoreceptor gene, sr-234, in Caenorhabditis elegans, which is involved in chemosensory behavior. The gene expression of sr-234 in the AD sensory neuron is previously shown to be regulated by the MEF-2 transcription factor. This study found that MEF-2 acts together with basic helix-loop-helix (bHL) transcription factors to regulate sr-234 as a function of feeding state. A cis-regulatory M2 site is necessary and sufficient for starvation-induced downregulation of sr-234, while an E-box binds HL factors to drive sr- expression in AD. HL-2, HL-3, and HL-4 act in AD neurons to regulate sr-234. MX-3 and HL-30 in the intestine regulate sr- in AD neurons, dependent on insulin signaling in AD. Intestine-to-neuron regulation of sr- involves a subset of insulin peptides.
Researchers conducted a study to investigate the association between the detection of Mycobacterium ulcerans in mosquitoes and the risk of Buruli ulcer (BU) disease in southeastern Australia. Adult mosquitoes were trapped in seven towns on the Bellarine Peninsula, Victoria, from December 2004 to December 2009, and screened for M. ulcer using real-time PCR. The number of laboratory-confirmed BU cases in residents during the same period was tallied to determine cumulative incidence in each location. Pearson's correlation coefficient was calculated between proportion of M. ulcer-positive mosquitoes and incidence per town. A strong dose-response relationship was found between M. ulcer detection in mosquitoes and human disease risk (r = 0.99; 95% CI 0.92-0.99; p < 0.001). The study supports the hypothesis that mosquitoes are involved in M. ulcer transmission in southeastern Australia. This has implications for intervention strategies to control and prevent BU.
A mutation in the gene encoding the mitochondrial Mg2+ channel MRS2 results in demyelination in rats. The dmy mutation is a model for studying myelin maintenance, as it causes severe myelin breakdown in the central nervous system (CNS) after normal myelination completion. A G-to-A transition at 177 bp downstream of exon 3 of the MRS2 gene creates a novel splice site, inactivating the mutant allele. Transgenic rescue with wild-type M2DNA confirms this. M2 encodes a component of the Mg2 influx system in mitochondria of yeast and human cells. Dmy rats have mitochondrial deficits: elevated lactate in cerebrospinal fluid, 60% ATP reduction, and swollen mitochondria in oligodendrocy cytoplasm. M2-GFP transgenic rats show M2 expression in neurons, not oligodrocytes, and ultrastructurally in mitochondria inner membrane. Observations indicate dmy suffer mitochondrial disease, myelin maintenance differs from production. Mg2 homeostasis in mitochondria is essential for myelin maintenance.
Researchers analyzed eight publicly available clinical microarray studies to evaluate the consistency of gene expression signatures between internal and external studies. Current documentation standards for signatures do not allow for unambiguous application to external patients, hindering independent evaluation and clinical use. Study-internal classifications were based on documented information, while study-external classifications were based on documented signatures. The study found that exact specification of a classification rule alone does not define a signature unambiguously. Discrepancies between study-internal and studyexternal diagnoses were as high as 30% in the worst case and 18 in median. A proposed documentation strategy, which includes quantitative preprocessing information, reduced the discrepancy to 1. The process of bringing microarray gene expression signatures to clinical practice can be improved and made more reliable with better documentation of signatures.
Researchers have investigated the structure of curli amyloid fibrils, secreted by Enterobacteriaceae, which contribute to biofilm formation and bacterial resistance to environmental stress. Crystal structures of amyloid-forming segments from the major curli subunit, Csg, revealed a steric zipper-like fibrils of β-sheets, linking curli to human amyloids. Danti-meric peptides, designed to interfere with Alzheimer's disease amyloid-β, inhibited Csg fibrillation and biofilm formation in Salmonella typhim. Additionally, C fibrils seeded amyloidβ fibrillation, supporting structural resemblance and potential cross-species amyloid interactions. The study provides insights into amyloidogenic regions for cur formation, suggesting a strategy to disrupt amyloid biofilms and hypothesizes self-propagating prion species from microbial source influencing neurodegenerative diseases.
Japanese Encephalitis (JE) is a significant cause of encephal in Asia, characterized by high fatality rates and neurologic sequelae among survivors. In the Philippines, the epidemiology of JE is not well defined. A systematic review of literature and surveillance data from 2011-2014 was conducted to inform consideration of JE vaccine introduction into the national schedule. Searches were conducted on JE and the Philippines in four databases and library. Data from acute encephal syndrome (AES) and JE surveillance from the national laboratory from 2011-2014 were tabulated and mapped. Twenty-nine reports on JE in the Philippines were identified, including five serologic surveys, 18 clinical reports, and eight studies (two with both clinical and animal data). Eighteen studies reported 257 laboratory-confirmed JE cases from 1972-2013. JE virus (JEV) was the causative in 7-18% of cases meningitis and encephitis combined and 16-40% enitis. Predominantly affected children under 15 years, with 6-7% resulting in death. Surveillance from 2011-2014 identified 73 laboratory-confirmed JE of 497 tested. This review demonstrates endemicity and geographic range of JE in the Philippines, supporting vaccine use in the country. Continued surveillance with confirmation is needed to quantify JE burden, guide prioritization of high-risk areas and vaccine schedule, and measure preventive measures against this public health threat.
Researchers investigated the evolutionary origins of genetic robustness in bacteria by studying the metabolic networks of hundreds of species across various simulated environments. They found that variations in robustness levels among species reflect ecological adaptations. Robustness was decoupled into two components: environmental-dependent, responsible for 20% of non-essential reactions, associated with species' lifestyle (specialized/generalist), and environmental-independent, associated with intrinsic metabolic capacities (correlation=0.6), observed in fast growers or extensive secondary metabolite producers.
A randomized trial was conducted in Enteb, Uganda to investigate the effect of Schistosoma mansoni infection on antibody responses to measles catch-up immunization in pre-school children. The Immune Modulation and Childhood Immunization (IMChI) study enrolled 193 Schistoma-infected and 61 uninfected children aged 3-5 years. Infected children were randomized 1:1 to receive prazantel 2 weeks before, at the time of, or 1 week after measles immunization. Plasma-meas IgG was measured at enrollment, 1 and 24 weeks post-immun. Primary outcomes were IgG levels and percentage with protective levels. Anti-meas Ig increased post-immun, but at 1 post-imm Schoma-inf children had lower Ig (adjusted mean 0.4 [0.2-0.7] and percentage with protective levels lower (odds 0.1-0.9) compared to uninf. Among Schoma-inf, Ig post-imm was higher in those treated with prantel than not (treated before-imm, 2.3[1.5-4.8]; at-imm 1.8[1.1-3.5). At 24 post-imm, Ig did not differ between groups, but tended lower in previously-inf who remained Schoma-positive than became-negative. The study suggests Schoma infection in pre-school is associated with reduced response to measles immun, and prant treatment improves. Schoma may contribute to impaired responses in endemic populations; control may enhance vaccine efficacy.
Researchers have made significant progress in understanding bacterial evolution through large-scale sequencing of population samples, revealing that multiple gene sequences and broad population coverage are necessary for an unbiased view of genetic structure and ancestry patterns. However, traditional phylogenetic analysis faces challenges with extensive sampling, particularly with recombination. To address this, new statistical tools for recombination detection and population representation are introduced, along with a population model describing sequence space in terms of variability and affinity to other populations. These tools are combined with phylogenetic analysis on extensive data from Neisseria, demonstrating their potential. The introduced tools are available in BAPS 5.2 software, downloadable from http://web.ab.fiak.fi/matec/baps.html.
Researchers have investigated the role of cortical rhythms in cognitive abilities, specifically focusing on beta activity in the 20 Hz frequency band, which has been linked to neural correlates of attention. Studies suggest that top-down beta rhythms generated in higher cognitive areas and transmitted to sensory areas support attention modulation. A computational model of cortical sensory areas was developed to elucidate beta's functional roles and mechanisms. Results show that top-down beta activates ascending projections from L5 to L4 and L2/3, responsible for biased competition in superficial layers. Slow inhibitory interneurons resonate at 20 Hz and modulate activity in superficial layers in attention-related manner. Predicted roles of these cells in attention provide a mechanism for cholinergic drive to support selective attention.
Researchers have developed a new method, called Multiple Shooting for Stochastic Systems (MSS), to calibrate and predict stochastic compartmental models of epidemics. These models are useful for studying the emergence of new pathogens when the number of infected individuals is small. However, existing methods for estimating and predicting these models' parameters are limited. SS applies a linear approximation to describe the size of fluctuations and updates the belief about the epidemic state with each new observation. The method was tested on simulated outbreaks of a novel virus, using weekly diagnosed case counts as a proxy for incidence. Results show that SS accurately estimates key parameters (mean infectious duration, R0, and Reff) and the unobserved number of infected during an epidemic. It also predicts future hospitalizations and overall attack rate accurately. SS outperforms three benchmarks: 1) Poisson approximation, 2) particle filtering, and 3) Kalman filter in most scenarios. The method may improve current approaches for calibrating and predicting stochastic epidemics.
Human visual perception is shaped by two opposing forces: adaptation and past decisions. A series of experiments investigated the impact of previous stimuli and decisions on behavioral reports during forced-choice tasks. Multilevel modeling and cross-validation approaches revealed that perceptual reports are influenced by a hierarchy of serial processes. Low-level adaptation repels perception from previous stimuli, while decisional processes attract towards recent stimuli. This hierarchy of dependence arises from decision templates, not sensory processes. A two-process model explains persistence, where decision weights compensate for adaptation, leading to biases in perception. A unified account proposes distinct mechanisms promote differentiation and integration of visual information over time.
Researchers have investigated the role of the Clock-Cycle (CLK-CYC) heterodimer in circadian transcription in Drosophila. The CLK protein lacks an activation domain, but its partner CY has a DNA-binding domain and a glutamine-rich region that contributes to transcriptional activity. To study the role of CY in circadian timekeeping, a CY-viral 16 (VP) fusion protein was added to the CLK-CYC complex, enhancing transcriptional activity. This was observed in both CY-VP-expressing flies and S2 cells, with increased levels of CLK-C target mRNAs and short period. Reporter gene expression in CYVP-expressing flies showed the short period is due to rapid transcriptional phase. Behavioral effects require period (per) promoter and are not due to higher PER levels, indicating CLK-CVP effects are a consequence of increased transcription. This suggests timing of transcription activation, not activation, is key to behavioral effects in CYVP-express flies. The study indicates circadian transcription contributes to circadian function in Dophila.
Researchers investigated how horizontally acquired genes function in different species. They found that existing proteins in an organism can limit the functionality of a new gene if it interacts with an ancestral pathway. The study focused on the pmr gene in Salmonella and Escherichia. The pmr gene activates the Pmr/PB system in Salmonella but not in Escheria. The pmr protein binds to phosphorylated Pmr (mr-P), protecting it from dephosphorylation by mr. This leads to transcription of mr-dependent genes, including polymyxin resistance. However, the E pmr protein can activate the Pmr system in Salmonella, despite not in Esia, suggesting a difference in controlling mr levels. The E coli mr has higher phosphatase activity towards mr-P than Salmon mr, and a mr domain responsible for this was identified. Replacing the E coli mr with Salmon mr gene made coli resistant to polymin under mr-inducing conditions. The study shows that differences in biochemical activities of ancestral proteins dictate acquired gene functionality and suggest acquired genes can potentiate ancestral loci.
Researchers have developed a novel approach to identify differentially expressed genes during the early stages of embryonic stem cell differentiation. This process involves the loss of pluripotency-associated transcripts and induction of differentiation genes. Traditional methods of identifying differentially expressed genes by comparing cell types include a large portion of genes that respond to, rather than regulate, the process. The researchers used biological replicates and a statistical approach to analyze gene expression data without separating cell types, finding it informative for detecting differentially expressed genes. This method was applied to murine embryonic stem cell differentiation, identifying Smad1 as a novel regulator of pluripotency and self-renewal. The approach was formalized as a statistical test applicable to other differentiation processes.
Researchers have developed a new method to analyze genetic data from next-generation sequencing studies, called unbiased clustering of gene variants with phenotypic-link network. This method aims to identify functional relationships between genes from diverse data types, such as protein-protein interactions and gene-expression networks, and assess their significance by comparing interconnectedness with random gene sets. However, previous methods can be affected by confounding bias, leading to false positives. The study found that genes implicated by de novo variants tend to cluster together due to longer coding sequence length, resulting in inflated p-values in functional studies. To address this, the researchers created an integrative method that controls for this bias. They inferred associations between human genes from diverse data and assessed with a novel phenotype-based method, examining de novo gene variants while accounting for unexplored confounding in coding sequence. The method was tested on various data and networks, showing disease genes cluster more significantly in integrated phenotypic-link network than other networks. A tool was developed to identify functional associations among mutated genes in disease, accounting for sequencing bias, demonstrating suitability for clustering genes underlying polygenic disorders.
In January 2014, the Mexican government implemented an 8% tax on non-essential foods with energy density ≥275 kcal/100g and a peso-per-liter tax on sugar-sweetened beverages (SBs) to prevent obesity and diabetes. This study evaluated changes in volume of taxed and untaxed food purchases in response to these taxes, stratified by socioeconomic status (SES). Data from Nielsen's Consumer Panel (CPS) was used, including 6,248 households that participated for at least 2 months in 2012-2014, with average follow-up of 32.7 months. Volume of taxed and untaxed food purchases from January 2012 to December 2014 were analyzed using a longitudinal fixed model, adjusted for pre-existing trends to test if post-tax trend was different from pre-tax trend. Household characteristics and contextual factors like salary and unemployment were controlled. Taxed food purchases decreased by 5.1% in 2014 compared to expected based on pre-tax 2012-201 trends, with no change in untaxed purchases. Low SES households purchased 10.2% less taxed foods than expected, medium SES 5.8% less, while high SES did not change.
Researchers have proposed a biophysically plausible model to explain the properties of collision-sensitive neurons, which integrate information across a large part of the visual field. The model assumes that each channel is noisy and has a response threshold, and approximates a power law as a result of pooling these channels. This mechanism can predict many characteristics of the Lobula Giant Detector Neuron (LG), a type of collision-sensitive neuron. The model depends critically on noise in the inhibitory pathway, but is robust against noise in the excitatory pathway. The model reproduces the LG's response to various stimuli, including motion direction, speed, and contrast. It also captures the neuron's non-linearity and non-monotonicity. The authors suggest that this mechanism could be a common underlying principle for brain functions at multiple levels, from biophysics to psychophysics.
Cameroon is endemic for Buruli ulcer (BU), a disease caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans. In 2002, the National Buruli Ulcer Control Programme (NBPUC) was established to control the disease. This summary describes the evolution, achievements, and challenges of the NBP and suggests scaling up the programme. Data from 2001-2014 was analyzed, including reports from the NBP. Key indicators and case detection rates were plotted to determine trends. A linear regression analysis of detection from 2005-2014 was conducted, testing for statistical significance. In 14 years of control, 370 cases were reported. The detection rate decreased from 3.89 to 1.45 per 100,000 inhabitants. The number of endemic districts rose from 2 to 64. Five diagnostic and treatment centers are operational, with two planned for 2015. The health system has been strengthened, and research and education increased in Cameroon. The NBP began 30 years after first reported cases in 1969, but significant progress has been made.
Researchers investigated the influence of outcome valence (gains or losses) on confidence judgments in human learning through trial-and-error stimulus-outcome associations. Two experiments showed that participants were more confident in their choices when learning to gain compared to avoid losses, despite equal performance in both contexts. Computational modeling revealed that this bias is driven by context-value, a dynamic estimate of the average expected value of options, explaining performance in both gain and loss domains. The bias effect of context on confidence is domain-general and has significant implications. In volatile environments, individuals' flexibility in learning strategies differs when outcomes are framed as gains or losses.
Researchers have investigated the function of the non-structural protein 3 (ns3) of alphaviruses, a component of the viral replication complex, composed of a conserved amino-terminal domain involved in RNA synthesis and a poorly conserved carbox-terminal region. A carbox-terminal proline-rich motif shared among alphavirus ns3 proteins was identified as a target for Src-homology 3 (SH) domains of amphiphins 1 and 2. SH-dependent binding of amphins to ns3 was observed in Semliki Forest (SF), Sindbis (SINV), and Chikunya viruses. Upon alphavirus infection, intracellular amphin distribution was altered and colocalized with ns3. Mutations in ns3 disrupting amphin SH binding and RNA-mediated silencing of amphin2 resulted in impaired RNA replication in HeLa cells infected with SINV or SF. Infection of Bal/c mice with SF carrying SH binding-defective ns3 was associated with decreased mortality.
A study was conducted to investigate the molecular epidemiology of chromoblastycosis, a disease caused by fungi of the order Chaetothyales, in Brazil. The researchers analyzed 123 clinical strains of the disease using DNA sequencing of the internal transcribed spacer region and partial β-tubulin genes. The strains were grouped into three clusters within the family Herpotiaceae, known to cause the disease. The Fonca cluster contained the majority of strains, with Fonsepi being the most prevalent at 80%, followed by Fmonora at 13%, Fnica at 3%, and a single isolate of Fpnius. Two additional species, Rhinadiella and Cyphora, were also identified with frequencies of 3% and 1, respectively.
Listeria monocytogenes Infection Induces DNA Damage and Dampens the DNA Response

Listeria monocytogenes, a pathogenic bacterium, induces DNA breaks in host cells during infection. The host's DNA damage response (DDR) is a signaling pathway that detects and repairs DNA damage caused by endogenous or exogenous assaults, including infections. However, the impact of bacteria on the DDR is not well understood. This study found that Listeria monocogen infection causes DNA breaks in host cells. Notably, the response to these breaks is only moderately activated. The bacterium's toxin, listeriolysin O (LO), was found to block the DDR by degrading the sensor Mre11 protein. Knocking out or inactivating proteins involved in DDR promoted bacterial replication, highlighting the importance of this mechanism for infection control. The study shows that dampening the DDR is crucial for successful Listerial infection.
Researchers conducted an epigenetic library screen to identify compounds that influence human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1) and 2 (HSV-2) replication. They found that bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) plays a critical role in HSV infection. Treatment with a pan-BD inhibitor, JQ1, enhanced HSV infection. JQ acts through BR4, as knockdown of BR4 expression ablated J1's effect on HSV. BR4 regulates HSV replication through a complex involving CDK and RNA polymerase II; J1 promotes HSV-1 by allocating the complex to viral promoters. Suppression of BR4 or CD9 activity hindered infection. Data suggest J1 enhances HSV by switching BR4 to viral gene expression from chromatin. Transient BR4 or BR1/2 expression mimicked J1's effect. BR4 is a modulator for J's action on HSV and has an essential role in infection.
Researchers investigated the microbial communities in the mouths of children affected by noma, a disease that causes severe facial disfigurement and affects over 140,000 malnourished children annually. The cause of noma remains unknown, but a combination of microbial infection, poor oral hygiene, and weakened immune system may contribute to lesions that are entry points for gangrenous infections. A cross-sectional study analyzed 16S rRNA gene amplicons from gingival fluid samples of 12 healthy children, 12 with noma lesions, and 12 with Acute Necrotizing Gingivitis (ANG) lesions and healthy sites. Compared to healthy individuals, samples from diseased mouths were enriched with Spirocha and depleted Proteobacteria, while healthy sites from diseased had similar proportions of Spiro and Proteobacteria to controls. Samples from n mouths did not show higher Fusobacter abundance, casting doubt on its causative role. Microbial communities from n and AN lesions were dominated by Prevotella intermedia OT, less abundant in healthy sites. Multivariate analysis confirmed different bacterial communities in healthy and lesion sites. Several OTUs in Erysotrichales, Cloidales, Bacteriales, and Spirotales were identified as indicators of n, suggesting one or more microbes within these orders associated with noma development.
Bacillus thuringiensis, a bacterium that infects insects, uses a communication system called quorum sensing to adapt to its environment and commit to sporulation, a process of producing spores for survival. Researchers investigated the role of quorum sensing in the bacterium's life cycle within an insect host. They found that a specific regulator, Npr, part of the RNPP family, controls sporulation in the absence of its signaling peptide, Npr. N acts as a transcription factor, regulating genes for survival in the insect cadaver. However, in the absence of Npr, N negatively controls sporulation by inhibiting the expression of SpoA-regulated genes, preventing Kin-dependent phosphorylation of phosphotransferase SpoF, delaying the sporulation process. N displays similarities with Rap proteins, also in RN family, lacking DNA-binding domain, controlling expression via protein-protein interactions. Conservation of residues interacting with SpoF suggests common inhibition of sporulation pathway. The structure of N confirms a Rap-like structure. A regulatory mechanism proposes key residues of bifunctional N involved in two functions. N switches from dimer inhibitor sporulation to tetramer transcriptional activator in necrotrophic lifestyle. N tightly coordinates sporulation and necrophism, ensuring survival and dissemination during infection.
Researchers have developed a new computational model to predict the effectiveness of antiretroviral drugs in treating HIV infection. The model, called proteochem, combines genotypic and phenotyp data from a large clinical database of 300,000 drug-mut bioactivity points to identify optimal treatment regimens for individual patients. Unlike previous models, protechem considers chemical properties of drugs and their targets. The model achieved a prediction error rate below 0.5 log change and outperformed previous sequence-based models in resistance prediction and classification. It identified known and novel resistance-conferring mutations in HIV Reverse Transcriptase and Protease. The model was applied to a public HIV resistance database from Stanford University, achieving a correct prediction rate of 84% compared to 80% in a high-quality subset. The study demonstrates protechem models can accurately predict phenotyp resistance from genotyp data, including novel mutants and mixtures. Additionally, the model informs users about prediction reliability.
A computational model of cell movement and chemotaxis, based on pseudop autocatalysis, was developed to test the explanatory and predictive powers of pseudop-based mechanisms in chemotaxis. The model reproduced a wide range of existing data on cell movement and chemotaxis, simulating cell polarization, persistence, and pseudod selection in response to chemoattract gradients. It also predicted pseudod position bias in low chemo gradients and lateral pseudod initiation in high gradients. To test the model's predictive ability, untested predictions were made, including that the angle between successive pseudods at the cell front would increase with the difference between the cell's direction and the chemo gradient. This was measured in Dictyostelium cells under different conditions, with results agreeing with the model. The model and data suggest that pseudocycle lies at the heart of cell motility in rapidly moving cells like Dictyostel and neutrophils, implying chemaxis relies on pseud modification rather than generation or actin polymerization by chemo.
Fleas can transmit Yersinia pestis through two mechanisms: early-phase transmission (EPT) and bio-dependent transmission (BDT). However, the efficiency of transmission varies among flea species and results have been inconsistent. One complicating factor is the type of rodent blood used for the infectious meal. This study investigated the effect of host blood on EPT by feeding fleas bacteremic mouse, rat, guinea pig, or gerbil blood and assessing the location and characteristics of infection in the digestive tract and transmissibility of Y. pestis. Surprisingly, 10-28% of rodent fleas fed bacteremic rat or guinea blood regurgitated a portion of the infected meal into the esophagus within 24 hours. This phenomenon is termed post-infectional esophageal reflux (PIER). In contrast, PIER was rarely observed in fleas fed bacteremic or gerbil blood. PIER correlated with accumulation of dense aggregates of Y. pest, red blood cells, and hemoglobin in the proventriculus. At next feeding, fleas with PIER were 3-25 times more likely to appear blocked with blood retained in the esagus than fleas without P. Three days after feeding on bacteremic blood, Oropsa montana transmitted significantly more CFU than groups using mouse blood, and this transmission was bio-dependent. Data support a model where EPT results from regurgitation of Y. pest from obstructed foregut and E and BDT can temporally overlap. The insolubility of hemoglobin in rats and slower digestion of their blood promotes regitative transmission, which may explain why rodents are prominent in plague ecology.
Researchers have investigated the role of positive correlations in neuronal activity in the brain and found that they can significantly enhance coding performance. Contrary to previous studies suggesting they are detrimental or marginally beneficial, positive correlations can suppress probability of error by several orders of magnitude and increase the number of stimuli encoded, or capacity, by more than tenfold. These effects do not require unrealistically high correlation values and can occur in populations with tens of neurons. Heterogeneity in population activity is beneficial for these effects. Suppression of error and enhancement of capacity rely on a specific pattern of correlation. Tuning of one or several parameters can lead to perfect coding. The pattern of positive correlation leads to 'locking' of response, eliminating variability in subspace relevant for discrimination.
Researchers have developed a conjugate vaccine against cholera, a severe watery diarrhea caused by Vibrio cholera, by combining the O-specific polysaccharide (OSP) of Vibrio cholera O1 Inaba strain with a recombinant fragment of tetanus toxin heavy chain (rTHC). The conjugate vaccine was prepared via acid chemistry and tested in mice with varying doses (10-50 μg) and compositions of OSP to rTH molar ratio (3:1, 5:1, 10:1), adjuvant, and route of immunization. Immunized mice developed anti-OSP and anti-T serum IgG, vibriodal and memory cell responses following intramuscular or intrader vaccination. Intestinal lamina prop IgA responses targeting OSP occurred intrader. Comparable immune responses were found in mice immunized with variations, although memory and vibri responses were blunted in highest dose (50 μ). No change in responses occurred with or without adju. Administration of rTH resulted in 55% protective efficacy in mouse cholera model. The conjugate vaccine induces memory and protection against cholera in mice.
A cross-sectional study was conducted in 42 villages across three regions of Cameroon to investigate the cross-reactivity of immunochromatographic test (ICT) for lymphatic filariasis (LF) in areas with contrasting levels of Loa loa and Mansonella perst endemicity. The study aimed to assess the prevalence and intensity of Wuchereria bancrofti, Loa loa, and Mansonella perst, and clinical manifestations of LF. A total of 219 individuals participated, with 24 testing positive by ICT, with prevalence ranging from 0% in South-west to 2.1% in North. Lymphedema was diagnosed in 20 individuals, with majority in North-west, none tested positive by ICT. No Wuchereria bancft microfilariae were found in night blood of individuals with positive ICT or lymphedema. Positive ICT associated with high Loa microf intensity, 21 with over 8,000 Loa microf/ml blood (odds ratio 15.4; 95%CI 6.1-39.0; p<0.001). Strong association observed between Loa prevalence and ICT area (Spearman rho 0.900; p0.037), with 1% or more ICT in areas Loa above 15%. No association between ICT and Mansonella prevalence (Spearman -0.200; p0.747) or microf density (odds 1.8;95CI0.8-4.2; p0.192). The study confirmed association between ICT and Lo intensity (microf/ml) at individual level, and ICT with high Lo prevalence. Results suggest main confounding factor for ICT positive test are high Lo levels. Findings indicate Wucher bancft less prevalent in Central region Lo highly endemic than assumed, accurate re-mapping region useful shrinking LF map distribution.
SARS-CoV replication is supported by a reticular network of modified endoplasmic reticulum. Positive-strand RNA viruses, including SARS-CoV, replicate in the cytoplasm of host cells. Their replication complexes are associated with modified cell membranes, ranging from spher membrane invaginations to elaborate webs of vesicles. The ultrastructure, morphogenesis, and role in replication remain poorly characterized. Double-membrane vesicles (DMVs) were implicated in SARSV RNA synthesis. Cryo-electron tomography of infected cells revealed a three-dimensional imaging of coronavirus-induced membrane alterations at high resolution. A reticular network of modified endoplasmic reticulum was defined, integrating convol membranes, interconnected DMVs (200-300 nm), and vesicles from DM merger. Convoluted membranes were immunolabeled for viral subunits. Double-stranded RNA, presumably synthesis site, localized to DM interior. No connection between DM and cytosol was discerned, raising questions about DM formation and SARSV synthesis site. The virus reorganization of host membranes into a network organizes replication and possibly hides from antiviral mechanisms.
Researchers have investigated the role of suberin, a chemical compound found in plant roots, in regulating water and nutrient uptake from the soil. The current understanding of suberin's function is based on a model suggesting it forms a barrier limiting extracellular or apoplastic transport of water and solutes in roots. However, there is no direct genetic evidence to support this model. A study on Arabidopsis thaliana plants with enhanced suberin1 (es1) mutation showed a connection between suberin in roots and water movement through the plant and solute accumulation in shoots. Plants with increased suberin had reduced transpiration rates and increased water efficiency during growth. These changes in suberin and water transport were associated with decreased accumulation of Ca, Mn, and Zn, and increased accumulation of Na, S, K, As, and Mo in shoots. This study provides genetic evidence that suberin in roots controls water and ion transport to leaves. Changes in elemental accumulation in leaves indicate significant radial transport of Ca, Mn, and Zn occurs in apoplast.
Researchers investigated the kinetics of rhodopsin deactivation and its role in regulating the reproducibility of the single photon response (SPR) in vertebrate phototransduction. They developed a Continuous Time Markov Chain (CT) model based on the biochemistry of rhodin activation and deactivation, interfaced with a spatio-temporal model of phototransduction. The model was parameterized with data from photoresponse of wild-type and mutant mice with varying numbers of phosphorylation sites. The model reproduced both wild-type and mutant responses with a single set of parameters. Variability in the response was dissected into components: random number of turn-off steps, random sojourn time between steps, or both. Results showed that only randomness in sojourn times at each phosphorylated state contributed to Coefficient of Variation (CV) of response, while number of turn-off steps had negligible effect. This contradicts the view that more decay steps lead to more stable response. Rhodin shutoff was found responsible for response variability, while messenger diffusion acted as suppressor.
Researchers have developed a new mathematical framework to analyze stochastic reaction networks in fluctuating environments by decoupling the network from its extrinsic factors. These factors, such as fluctuations in ribosome numbers, affect gene network dynamics but are typically hard to model. The framework incorporates the environment's effect into a new network model, allowing for decoupling. Fluctuating extrinsic components, like chemical species, can be marginalized to obtain this decoupled model. Process and master equations are derived, enabling stochastic simulations. Case studies demonstrate the approach's significance.
Researchers have developed a novel brain-machine interface (BMI) architecture that utilizes optimal feedback modeling and adaptive processing to improve control and adaptability. Current BMI decoders, such as Kalman filters and closed-loop decoder adaptation (CLDA), do not directly model spikes, limiting processing speed and adaptation. A unified CL framework generalizing across setups is lacking. The proposed architecture integrates an infinite-hor feedback (OFC) model of the brain's behavior in closed-loop control and a point process model of spikes. The OFC infers user intention during CL, termed intention estimation. OF is used for autonomous and dynamic training. The point model enables neural processing and adaptation with every spike, faster than current decoders, and dynamic-event adaptation unlike batch-based methods. Experiments in a non-human primate over days dissociated effects of CL components. OF estimation improved performance compared to current techniques. OF assisted training enabled proficient control. Spike-event adaptation faster and consistent convergence than batch methods, robust initialization. The architecture extended beyond training tasks. This has implications for clinically viable neuroprosthetics.
Researchers investigated the effect of stimulus structure on redundancy in the retina by measuring responses from populations of retinal ganglion cells to natural and artificial stimuli with varying degrees of correlation. Simultaneous recordings are publicly available online. Responses to spatio-temporally structured stimuli, such as movies, showed modest correlations between ganglion cells, more than to white noise, but less than predicted by a non-adaptive model of retinal response. In contrast, responses to stimuli with purely spatial correlations, ganglion showed correlations consistent with static, non-adaptive receptive field nonlinearity. Ganglion cells responding to spatio-temporally correlated stimuli had faster temporal kernels and stronger surrounds. These properties, along with gain changes in contrast at gang cell input, explained pairwise correlations across receptive field measurements.
Researchers have developed an integrative multi-network and multi-classifier approach to predict genetic interactions, focusing on synthetic lethality, a type of genetic interaction where a combination of mutations results in a surprising phenotype. This approach improves upon existing methods by defining a large number of features characterizing relationships between gene pairs from various data sources, independent of known interactions.
