The study used a green-fluorescent protein-expressing molecular of HIV-1JR, an R5 clinical isolate, in combination with polyclonal HIV or mAbs to capture and neutralize HIV. TH-1 and U937 cells, as well as freshly isolated monocytes from healthy individuals, were used as phagytic effector cells, and uptake of virions was measured by cytometry. Surprisingly, minimal AD of virions was observed with any antibodies. However, coating virions with gp41 or gp-derived peptides gp41, but not gp120-specific m efficiently mediated phagocytosis. A minimum of hundred gp41 molecules were needed for successful phagytosis, similar to the number of envelope spikes on viruses phagosed, e.g. influenza virus. Fluorescence spectroscopy showed a clear association between virus aggregation and AD. In contrast, vir-decor cells were targets for AD orgocytosis in presence HIV-antibodies. Findings indicate AD of vir may not play role in preventing infection due paucity trimers and inability vir-bound to cross FRs phocytes. However, AD orocyt could play clearing HIV-infected cells verge infection.
Hookworm infection is a widespread in many countries worldwide, yet its global economic and health impact is not well understood. A computational model was developed to estimate the economic and health burden of hookworm infection in every country, region, and globally, in 2016 from a societal perspective. Globally, hook infection resulted in 2,126,280 Disability-Adjusted Life Years (DALYs) using 2009 disability estimates and 4,087,803 DALYs using 201 disability estimates (excluding cognitive impairment). The inclusion of cognitive impairment did not significantly increase DALs worldwide. Productivity losses varied with probability and anemia calculation method, ranging from $7.5 billion to $138.9 billion annually using gross national income per capita as proxy wages and from $2.5 to $43.9 billion using minimum wage as proxy wages. Hookworm is classified as a neglected disease, yet its economic burden exceeded estimates of diseases receiving more attention, such as rotavirus. Countries transitioning to higher income, like Brazil and China, still face significant hook burden.
Researchers investigated the effects of hypoxia on the developing vertebrate central nervous system, building on previous findings in in invertebrate Caenorhabditis elegans. They found that hypox disrupts axon pathfinding in forebrain neurons of zebraf (Danio rerio), leading to commissural axons failing to cross the midline. This was caused by activation of the hypox-inducible transcription factor (HIF) pathway, which was mimicked by chemical inducers of HIF or expression of constitutively active Hα. Blocking transcriptional activation of Hα prevented the defects. EphrinB2 was identified as a target of the H pathway, with knockdown of EphB rescuing the errors and EphA receptor expressed in a pattern complementary to misrouting axons. Constitutively active EphB targeted to neurons showed Eph mediating errors via reverse-signaling. Magnesium sulfate, used to improve neurodevelopment in preterms, protected against errors by upregulating EphB.
Researchers conducted a study to investigate pulmonary abnormalities in mice infected with paracoccidiomycosis (PCM), a fungal disease of pulmonary origin, using high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) and histopathological findings. Fifty male BALB mice were inoculated with Paracococidioides brasiliensis conidia (n=50) or PBS (n=50). HRCT scans were performed every four weeks to determine pulmonary lesions, quantify lung density, and reconstruct lung structure. Lungs were also analyzed by histology and histometry. Three patterns of lesions were observed: nodular-diffuse, confluent, and pseudo-tum. Lesions were mainly located around the hilus and affected the left lung more frequently. At four weeks post-challenge, 80% of infected mice had peri-bronial consolidations with increased lung density compared to controls (-263±25 vs -422HU, p<0.001). Consolidation progressed to middle regions at 8 and 12 weeks. Histology revealed consolidation as confl granulomatous reaction, nodules as compact granomas. At 16 weeks, confl granomas formed pseudooral masses obstructing bronchi. Discrete fibrosis was visible around granomas, evident by histology. This study demonstrated HRCT's utility in evaluating and quantifying pulmonary damage in PCM. The experimental design reduced animal sacrifice and allowed monitoring treatment efficacy through a more rational approach to lung disease study.
A proof-of-concept study investigated the use of an interferon-gamma release assay (IFN-γ) as a marker for latent Leishmania donovani (L. donani) infection in visceral leishmaniasis (VL) endemic areas. The study aimed to evaluate a modified commercial kit, QuFERON, with five Leishmania-specific antigens: H2, H2-PS2, H-Le12, crude antigen (CSA), and soluble Leish antigen (SL) from L. donani to detect cell-mediated immune response in VL. Venous blood samples from 13 active VL patients, 15 cured patients, 11 non-endemic controls, and 19 endemic controls were analyzed. The assay based on SL had a sensitivity of 80% (95 CI 54.81-92.95) and specificity of 100 (74.12-100). Results suggest a whole-blood SL-based QuFER assay can measure cell-mediated response in L. donani infection. Positive IF-γ response to Leish antigen in VL patients contradicts conventional non-proliferative antigen response of peripheral mononuclear cells.
Enteropathogenic Yersiniae, such as Yersinia pseudotuberculosis, can cause persistent gastrointestinal infections that may lead to relapsing enteritis and autoimmune disorders. To establish a persistent infection, the bacteria must navigate through the intestinal epithelium and colonize gut-associated lymphatic tissues, evading host immune responses. The mechanism by which they achieve this is not well understood. Research has shown that the CNFY toxin enhances the translocation of anti-phagocytic effectors, inducing inflammatory responses, leading to tissue destruction and alteration of the intestinal microbiota and bacterial clearance. Suppression of CNFY function, however, increases interferon-γ responses, comprising non-inflammatory antimicrobial activities and tolerogenesis. This process is accompanied by preprogramming the pathogen's transcriptional response towards persistence, giving the bacteria an advantage against host responses and facilitating a commensal lifestyle.
Researchers have identified a novel pathogenic gene, DES1, in the fungus Magnaporthe oryza, which plays a crucial role in suppressing the host plant's basal defenses to facilitate successful colonization and reproduction. The gene was discovered through screening for pathogenic-defective mutants in a T-DNA insertional library. Bioinformatic analysis revealed DES1 encodes a serine-rich protein with unknown biochemical properties, conserved in filamentous Ascomycetes. Targeted deletion of DES1 had no effect on developmental processes, including vegetative growth, conidial germination, appressium formation, and appressium-mediated penetration. However, conidial size of the mutant was smaller than wild-type, with no defects in cell wall integrity. The Δdes mutant was hypersensitive to oxidative stress, with decreased extracellular enzyme activity, including peroxidases and laccases, and ferrous ion leakage. In interaction with a susceptible rice cultivar, cells inoculated with Δdes exhibited strong defense responses: brown granules in infected cells, reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation, autofluorescent materials, and PR gene induction in neighboring tissues. Δdes displayed reduced hyphal extension, decreasing pathogenicity. Suppression of ROS by dipheniodium (DPI), an NAD oxidase inhibitor, reduced defense in plant tissues with Δdes. Furthermore, Δdes recovered normal growth in DPI-treated plant. These findings suggest DES functions as a pathogenic gene regulating ROS-mediated plant defense.
Researchers evaluated the accuracy of model-based statistics (MB) for predicting Schistosoma haematium infection in Ghana by comparing empirically determined prevalence values from 79 school surveys with predicted values from MB. Schools were categorized according to WHO guidelines to assess implications of differences. Using predicted values alone, 21 of 25 empirically determined 'high-risk' schools would have been undertreated, and 20% of remaining schools would have been treated despite empirically determined absence of infection. This would have resulted in 28% of children being undertreated and 12% receiving treatment without demonstrated need. The current predictive map for Ghana was inadequate for guiding national program when aggregated to district level. Assessing each school in potentially endemic areas is not feasible; modelling must be complementary to empiric assessments. Predictive mapping should not be a one-time exercise, but an iterative process incorporating empiric testing and refining to create updated versions meeting operational needs of disease control managers.
Researchers have investigated the mechanisms guiding sperm through the reproductive tract to oocytes in Caenorhabditis elegans. They found that oocytes synthesize sperm-guiding prostaglandins from polyunsaturated fatty acid (PUA) precursors in yolk lipoproteins. Using genetics and electrospray ion tandem mass spectrometry, they delineated F-series prostland metabolism pathways. Omega-6 and omega-3 PUFAs, arachidonic and eicosentaenoic acids, were converted into more than 10 structurally related F prostagland, which collectively and redundantly promote sperm guidance. Disrupting omega-3 PU synthesis triggered compensatory upregulation of prostagland from omega-6 PAs. C elegans prostland synthesis involves distinct mechanisms from mammalian cyclooxygenase pathways, yet PG2 stereoisomers are synthesized. A conserved cytochrome P450 enzyme, whose human homolog is implicated in Biet's Crystine dystrophy, regulates prostland synthesis. Results support multiple cyclooxygen-independent prostland function in promoting sperm motility for fertilization. This pathway may be conserved.
Researchers have identified a challenge in the development of biotherapeutics due to immunogenicity, which hinders widespread clinical application. To address this, improved deimmunization technologies are needed. An algorithm was developed to optimize proteins for reduced T cell epitope content and high function. In silico analysis revealed no single global optimum for deimmization, instead, mutagen epitope deletion yields a spectrum of designs with tradeoffs between immunogenicity and function. The Pareto frontier, undominated variants with no better performance in both criteria, was identified. A Pareto frontier for a therapeutic enzyme was constructed and experimentally evaluated. Measures of performance correlated with computational predictions, mapping a functional space. This is the first systematic assessment of the penalty for progressively deimmized biotherapeutic candidates. Algorithms may rapidly design tradeoffs between immunogenicity and functionality, augmenting, accelerating, and de-risking deimmization efforts.
Elevated temperature increases meiotic crossover frequency via the Type I pathway in Arabidopsis thalian.

Meiosis, a fundamental to sexual reproduction in eukaryotes, relies on reciprocal exchange of DNA between homologous chromosomes, known as crossover (CO), to ensure proper chromosome segregation. CO frequency and distribution are regulated by intrinsic and extrinsic factors, with more known mechanisms governing the former than latter. Elevated temperature induces meiotic hyper-recombination in Arabidopsis thalian, with genetic analysis of mutants in recombination pathways showing extra COs derive from Type I interference pathway. Heat-induced COs not result from increased double-strand breaks, hyperrecomant phenotype specific to thermal stress, not generalized response. Findings provide mechanistic insight into environmental modulation of meiotic recombination, practical applications.
A novel computational approach has been developed to address the challenge of navigating the vast and rapidly evolving landscape of biomedical literature, particularly in molecular biology. This approach, called Hanalyzer, is a knowledge-based system that combines reading, reasoning, and reporting to facilitate the analysis of experimental data. It extracts information from external resources, either by parsing structured data or using natural language processing to extract from unstructured data, and tracks provenance. Reasoning enriches the extracted knowledge by noting, for example, genes annotated to the same ontology or database entry. Reasoning also combines sources into a network representing all relationships between pairs of genes and calculates a reliability score. Reporting combines the network with congruent constructed from data and visualizes in a tool facilitating knowledge-based analysis of data. Hanalyzer was implemented on a large-scale expression dataset relevant to craniofacial development. The tool was critical in creation of hypotheses regarding four previously uncharacterized genes in craniofac development, each validated by further work.
Helminth parasites, specifically Fasciola hepatica, secrete extracellular vesicles (EVs) that can be internalized by host cells, modulating the host's immune response. However, the surface-exposed molecules involved in ligand-receptor interactions with host cells to initiate vesicle docking and internalization are poorly understood. This study used membrane-impermeable biotin reagent to capture proteins on outer surface of two EV subpopulations (15k and 120 EV) released by adult F. hepatica, identifying 380 proteins including virulence factors, membrane proteins, and molecules in EV biogenesis/trafficking. Proteomics and immunohistochemical analysis showed 120 EV have endosomal origin, released via protonephial excretory system, while 15 EV are from gastrodermal epithelial cells lining fluke gut. Lectin microarray profiled surface oligosaccharides of intact EV displayed to host, showing identical glycoconjugate profiles for 15 and 120 EV, distinct from parasite tegument, high mannose predominant. F hep EV resisted exo and endoglycosidase, glycosidase PNG remodelled surface oligosacides blocking uptake by macrophages. Pre-treatment with host antibodies or purified against EV surface proteins (DM9, CD63, myferlin) enhanced internalization.
Arabidopsis thaliana CDF2 plays a crucial role in the transcriptional and post-transcriptional regulation of microRNAs (miRNAs), which are essential for plant development. miRNAs are initially transcribed as stem-loop primary miRNAs (pri-miRNAs) by RNA polymerase II, then cleaved in the nucleus into mature miRNAs by Dicer-like 1 (DCL1). CDF2, a DOF transcription factor, interacts with D1 and regulates the accumulation of a subset of miRNAs. C2 binds directly to the promoters of some miRNA genes, acting as a transcriptional activator or repressor. C2 preferentially binds to pri-miRNAs regulated by itself and affects D1-mediated processing of these priiRN. Genetically, C2 functions in the same pathway as miR156 or mi172 to control flowering. C2 regulates a group of priiRNAs at both transcriptional and post-transcription levels to maintain proper levels of mature miRN, influencing plant development.
Researchers have identified a crucial role for geranylgeranyl diphosphate (GG) in the establishment of communication between oocytes and granulosa cells during folliculogenesis, a process essential for providing ova for reproduction. GG, a metabolic intermediate in protein geranylation, increases in oocytes during early follicular development. Depletion of GG in oocytes impairs granosa cell proliferation, primary follicle transition, and female fertility. Mechanistically, GG depletion inhibits Rho GTP geranylation and GTPase activity, leading to accumulation of junction proteins in oocyte cytoplasm and disrupted oocyte-granosa connection. GG also blocks Rab27 geranylation, affecting secretion of o materials such as G9. GG administration restores defects in o-granosa contact, granosa proliferation, and primary transition in GG depletion mice. This study demonstrates GG-mediated geranylation contributes to o-granosa communication and regulates primary follicle transition, a key follicogenesis phase for female function.
RNA polymerase II (Pol II) is a eukaryotic enzyme responsible for synthesizing messenger RNA from a DNA template. Despite extensive biochemical and biophysical studies, the route of nucleoside triphosphate (NTP) entry into the active site of the enzyme remains unclear. Crystallographic structures of Pol II have provided insight into the structural basis of transcription, but the conformation of the unpaired non-template part of the transcription bubble (TB) is unknown. The diffusion of NTP through the main channel may overlap with the TB region, making structural information on TB crucial for understanding Pol II transcription. This study presents a structural model of Pol with a complete transcription bubble based on existing data and Molecular Dynamics (MD) simulations, revealing NTP pathways. Results show both channels have space for N loading, but the percentage of conformations with space for N through the secondary channel is twice that of the main. Further MD simulations with N loaded channels indicate NTP diffusion through the main is disfavored by electrostatic repulsion between N and negatively charged backbone nucleotides in non-template DNA. The study suggests the secondary channel is major for N entry during II transcription.
Dengue is a reportable disease in Thailand and Cambodia, but the reported incidence may not accurately reflect the true burden of the disease. To estimate the magnitude of underreporting and establish accurate burden estimates, laboratory-confirmed outpatient and inpatient cases from prospective cohort studies were used. Two cohort studies were conducted among children under 15 years of age from a deng field site consortium over at least two deng seasons. Age-specific multipliers (MF) were calculated by comparing cohort data to national surveillance in the same province and year. In Thailand, 14,627 person-years of cohort data were obtained in two provinces and 14,493-years from one in Cambodia. The average incidence of laboratory-confirmed deng was 23/1,000 and 25/1,000 in Thailand, and 41/1,000 in Cambodia. Calculated MF varied by age and year (0.4-29). Average age-specific MF were applied to country-level data, indicating 229,886 (210,612-331,236) deng cases annually 2003-2007 in Thailand and 111,178 (80,452-357,135) in Cambodia. Underreporting of total inpatient deng was 8.7 and 2.6 in Thailand, and 9.1 and 1.4 in Cambodia. In 2007, over 95,000 children in Thailand and 58,000 in Cambodia were estimated hospitalized due to deng. Calculating MF by cohort to surveillance is an approach to accurately assess burden. These data indicate deng reported in many countries, surveillance under the true burden.
Researchers investigated the role of natural killer (NK) cells in promoting CD8 T cell responses against cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. They used congenic or mutant mice and genetically engineered viruses to examine the consequences of NK cell defects on antiviral CD8 responses. The study found that NK cells accelerate CD8 cell responses against viral infection in vivo for the first time. The mechanism involves NK limiting IFN-α/β production, which reduces immunosuppressive effects on the host. This is achieved by controlling cytomegalovirus, reducing plasmacyoid dendritic cell (pDC) cytokine production, preserving conventional dendritic (c) cell compartment, and accelerating antiral CD8 cell responses. Exogenous IF-α administration in animals ablates DCs and delays CD8 cell activation in face NK control viral replication. Data demonstrate NK cells' ability to respond early to cytgalovirus infection contributes to innate response balance, dampening immunopathology and promoting antiral CD8 cell initiation.
In Arabidopsis thalian, the 45S rRNA genes are organized in tandem arrays with varying in copy numbers from hundreds to thousands. While not all copies are transcribed under normal conditions, the regulation of specific rRNA expression is unclear. This study identifies four rRNA variants in Arabidopsis thalian. Transcription of one variant is induced, while others are repressed or unchanged in wild-type plants. Disruption of the nucleolin-like gene (AtNUC1) affects transcription of these variants. The most represented variant, inactive in wild-type plants, is reactivated in Atuc1 mutants. Pre-rRNAs originate from Pol I transcription and are accurately processed. Atuc1 disruption causes loss of symmetrical DNA methylation without histone epigenetic marks on r genes.
Researchers have identified human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) proteins UL38 and UL29 as interacting with the histone deacetylase 1 (HDAC1) protein, which plays a crucial role in regulating CMV gene expression. Using immunoprecipitation and mass spectrometry, potential interactors were identified, including multiple CMV-coded proteins. The interaction of UL38 and UL29 with HD1 was confirmed by reciprocal immunoprecipitation. HD1 is part of the nucleosome remodeling and deetylase complex (Nu), and UL38 and UL29 associated with the M2 component of Nu. Knockdown of Nu constituents RBP and CH4 inhibited CM immediateearly RNA and DNA accumulation, indicating multiple Nu components are needed for efficient CM replication. Treating cells with the deetyl inhibitor trichostatin did not rescue UL29 or UL38 deficient viruses, suggesting a positive role for Nu elements in replication. UL29 transiently expressed enhanced the CM major early promoter in a reporter assay, regardless of UL38 expression. Induction of the major early reporter by UL29 required Nu components, consistent with inhibition of early RNA accumulation after RBP and CH4 knockdown. UL29 modifies the Nu complex to stimulate early RNA accumulation.
Researchers investigated the antibody response to Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) in children following primary infection and its evolution through adolescence and adulthood. They used whole-genome fragment display libraries to identify epitopes in the RSV fusion (F) and attachment (G) proteins. The study found modest changes in anti-F epitope repertoire post-infection and a 100-fold increase in G-reactive epitopes spanning the N- and C-terminus of G ectodomain, with increased reactivity to the conserved domain (CCD). Panels of antigen sites were synthesized to evaluate sera from children, adolescents, and adults in real-time assays. A steady increase in RSV epitope repertoire from children to adults was observed using peptides and proteins. Novel epitopes were identified in pre-fusion and immunodominant in F27. Antibody binding to preusion was 2-3 times higher than postusion. R-G responses were high early in children but declined in adults using proteins or peptides. This study shows unlinked evolution of anti-F and G responses and evidence for immune-driven R-G evolution.
Researchers investigated the mode of action of emodeide, a veterinary anthelmint, against adult Brugia malayi, a species causing lymphatic filariasis. Emide potently inhibits parasite motility by activating voltage-gated potassium channels, with males being more sensitive than females. RNAi knockdown suggests emide targets S-1 channels. The slo-1 isoforms, with alternatively spliced exons at the RCK domain, were heterologously expressed in Xenopus lae oocytes. The slo-1 iso, found in males, is more sensitive to emide than slo-1a, found in females. Selective RNAi of slo-1 in females increased emide potency. In Oncherca volulus, causing river blindness, has two isoforms with homology to B-S-1 and B-F at R1. In silico modeling identified an emide binding pocket in the R1 region, affected by splicing variations. Emide has potent macrofidal effects and splicing in R1 affects potency.
The Global Program to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis (GPELF) relies on rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) to determine where mass drug administration for LF is required and when it can be stopped. These tests detect Wuchereria bancrofti glycoprotein in the blood of infected persons via a carbohydrate moiety recognized by monoclonal antibodies AD12 and DH5.5. Loa loa cross-reactivity with RDTs has been recognized as a serious obstacle to LF elimination in loa-endemic areas. To understand the nature of this cross-reactivity, the DH5 antibody was used to immunoaffinity purify Loa antigens from sera of individuals with positive RDT to loa. Immunlot analysis revealed many AD/DH5-reactive antigens and proteomic analysis identified multiple Lo proteins in RDT-positive loa sera. These included secreted and somatic proteins, suggesting they may be released by Loa adult and microfilar. Unlike the high molecular W bancft circulating antigen, Loa antigens appeared transiently present in blood of subset persons loa. Key differences between antigens W bancft and Lo can differentiate results by species and lead to improved tests LF and loa.
Researchers have identified a novel cilium-associated protein, RAB-28, in the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans, which is conserved in humans and associated with Bardet-Bied syndrome (BBS). Cilia are sensory and signalling organelles extending from eukaryotic cells, crucial for various physiological and developmental processes. Defects in cilia cause inherited disorders, such as retinitis pigmentosa and BBS, affecting multiple organs. Cil formation and function depend on intraflagellar transport (IFT), driven by kinesin-2 and IFT-dyne motors and regulated by the BBS cargo protein complex. Whole-organ RNA-Seq profiling in C elegans revealed a signature profile enriched for ciliary transcripts, including FAM161, CC104, and RP1, confirmed to be cilium-localised. From 185 candidate ciliary genes, orthologues of MAP, Y, CC149, and R28 were identified as conserved cilium components. C elegans R-28, linked to autosomal-recessive cone-rod dystrophy, is a small GTPase exclusively expressed in ciliated neurons, associating with IFT. GTP-bound R-28 concentrates at the periliary membrane in a BBS-dependent manner and undergoes bidirectional I. Functional analyses showed normal cil structure, sensory and I in a-28 null, but overexpression of GDP or GTP variants R-28 perturbed cil and sensory morphogenesis.
Researchers investigated how the brain represents the external world through neural responses, despite lacking direct access to external stimuli. Using hippocampal place cells as a model, they demonstrated that action potentials (spikes) from stereotyped but unknown receptive fields can be used to extract global features of the environment and construct an accurate representation of space, up to an overall scale, for tracking the animal's position. This approach differs from previous methods reconstructing position from place cell activity, which relied on knowing place fields or other neural responses related to position. By analyzing groups of cells firing together, a significant structure in the underlying stimulus space was revealed, enabling the brain to construct internal representations.
Researchers investigated the role of the NLRP inflamome and IL-1β in the pathogenesis of viral fulminant hepatitis (FH), a severe liver disease with high mortality due to excessive inflammation. Wild-type mice infected with murine hepatitis virus-3 (MHV-3) exhibited severe disease and high mortality associated with significant IL-1β elevation in serum and liver. In contrast, IL-1 receptor deficient (IL-1R-/-) or IL-1 antagonist (IL-Ra) mice showed reduced virus replication, disease progression, and mortality. IL-1R deficiency impaired virus-induced fibrinogen-like protein-2 (FGL) production in macrophages and CD45+Gr1 neutrophil infiltration in liver. Macrophages released reactive oxygen species (ROS) suggesting viral initiation of NLR3 inflamome activation. Mice deficient in p47phox, a NADPH oxidase subunit controlling ROS production, showed reduced NLR3 inflamome activation and IL-β secretion during infection, conferring resilience to FH. Viral animals deficient in NLR and Caspase-1, inflamome components, had reduced IL-β and ameliorated hepatitis. The ROS/NLR/IL-β axis is a critical pathway activated causing severe liver disease during infection.
Researchers conducted a study in Malawi to investigate the role of hookworm infections in severe anemia and iron deficiency in pre-school children. They used multiplex real-time PCR to assess hook species-specific prevalence, load, and their contribution to anemia and iron deficiency. Fecal samples from 830 pre-school children participating in a case-control study were analyzed. Hookworm infections were found in 34.1% of severely anemic cases and 27.0% non-severemic controls (p<0.05), while 5.6% were detected by microscopy. Ancylostoma duale and Necator american prevalence were 26.1% and 4.9%, respectively. Moderate to high A. duale infections were associated with severe anemia (adjusted odds ratio 2.49, 95%CI 1.16-5.33 and 9.04, 95CI 2.52-32.47). Iron deficiency through bone marrow examination was associated with A. duale intensity (odds ratio 3.63, 95CI 1.18-11.20, 16.98 95 3.88.74.35 and 44.91 5.23-385.77 for low, moderate, and high). This study is the first to assess hook load and species with anemia and bone iron deficiency. A. duale prevalence was higher than expected and associated with severe anemia and iron in pre-school in Malawi, indicating need for species-specific screening. Multiplex real PCR is a tool for public health to combat anemia and iron in resource settings.
Researchers have identified a protein called COM-1 in the nematode worm Caenorhabditis elegans that plays a crucial role in the repair of DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) during meiosis. Meiosis is a process of cell division that occurs in reproductive cells where genetic material is shuffled to produce offspring. DSBS can be repaired through two ways: homologous recombination (HR) or non-holog end joining (NHE). HR is necessary for the formation of interolog crossovers (COs) which are necessary for proper chromosome segregation. COM-1-deficient cells repair DS via the error-prone pathway NHE, resulting in lack of CO, chromosomal abnormalities, and embryonic lethality. In contrast to its yeast counterparts, COM1 is not required for Spo11 and initiation of meiotic DS repair, but promotes meiotic recombination by counteracting the NHE complex. COM1 acts parallel to the nuclease EX-1 to promote interolog HR at early pachytene stage of meiotic prophase, safeguarding CO formation. Both nucleases are dispensable for RAD51 recruitment at late pachene stage when hom-independent pathways predominate. This suggests redundancy and regulation of DNA resection during meiotic prophase. The study reveals the lethal consequences of NHE during meiosis and a critical role for COM1 in NHE inhibition and CO in germ cells.
Researchers investigated the humoral immune response to Burkholderia pseudallei antigens in a caprine model of acute meloidosis following aerosol exposure. The study aimed to characterize the humoral immune response to identify immunogenic proteins for diagnostics and vaccine candidates. Outbred goats were used to mimic human infection more accurately than inbred mouse models. B. pseudallei was delivered intratracheally, and antigen proteins were profiled from the infecting strain MSH511. Humoral responses were analyzed by ELISA and western blot, and antigens identified by mass spectrometry. Results showed a greater humoral response with IgG antibodies in breadth and quantity compared to IgM throughout infection. Pre-infection sera showed multiple immunogenic proteins reactive for IgG (7-20) and IgM(0-12) in goats despite no previous exposure to B.alle. After infection, IgG reactive proteins increased as disease progressed. Early infection (day 7) showed reaction to chaper proteins Gro, EL, EFu, and DK. These proteins detected in all samples post-infection with Gro immunodominant. Seven reactive antigens were selected for ELISA. Heat shock protein Gro1 elicited strongest antibody response compared other antigens. Most showed peak IgM reactivity day 14, IgG reactivity increased as disease progressed. MSH511 proteomic comparison between goat and human sera showed common reactive proteins between humans and goats meloid.
Cyclin B–cyclin-dependent kinase 1 (Cdk1) activation is a crucial for initiating mitotic entry, triggered by a positive feedback loop at the end of the G2 phase. During metaphase, the anaphase-promoting complex/cyclos-dependent destruction of cyclin B inactivates C1, allowing mitotic exit and cell division. Previous models describe C1 kinetics in mitosis, but experimental data on activation in mitotic cells have been lacking. Researchers used a novel approach to determine the temporal development of cyclin B–C1dk activity in single cells. By quantifying dephosphorylation of C1 and phosphorylation of the C1 anaphase-promoting complexyclos, they disclosed cyclin B–C1 continues to be activated after centrosome separation. Importantly, cytoplasmic cyclin B–1C1 activity can be maintained when cyclin B translocates to the nucleus in prophase. These data were fitted into a model describing cyclin B–1C1 in human, revealing a resemblance to bistable circuit. In line with kinetics, cyclin B–1C1 levels to enter mitosis are lower than cyclin B–1C1 for mitotic. Gradually increasing cyclin B–1C1 after centros separation is critical to coordinate mitotic progression.
Researchers investigated the neutralizing antibody (Nab) responses after HIV-1 superinfection (SI) in 21 Kenyan women exposed to subtypes A, C, and D, and superinfected after a median of 1.07 years following initial infection. Plasma samples were collected at a median 2.72 years post-SI. The study focused on 4 main epitopes on the HIV-1 envelope: CD4 binding site, V1/V glycan, N332 site in V3, and gp41 membrane proximal external region. Epitope mapping techniques showed SI did not induce a dominant response to any of these epitopes in the 21 women. Computational analysis suggested 20/21 superinfected women's responses could not be ascribed single specificity with confidence. These findings support a model where SI with subtypes promotes broad polyclonal Nab response, suggesting vaccine designs using multivalent immunogens to elicit diverse Nabs.
Congenital human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) infection is a leading cause of neurological disabilities in children worldwide, but the underlying mechanisms are not well-defined. Research has shown that CMV dysregulates the Notch signaling pathway in human neural progenitor cells (NPCs). Hairy and Enhancer of Split 1 (Hes) is a key regulator of NPC fate and brain development. This study found that CMV downregulates Hes protein levels in NPCs. The CMV 72Da immediate-early 1 protein (IE1) is involved in H degradation by assembling a ubiquitination complex and promoting H ubiquitination as a E3 ubiquitin ligase, followed by proteasomal degradation of H. SpA, a component of PML bodies, is another target of IE-mediated ubiquination. The C-terminal region of IE, amino acids 451-475, is required for IE/H interaction and IE-mediated ubiquination but not for IE/SpA interaction and ubiquination. This study reveals a mechanism linking downregulation of H to neurodevelopmental disorders caused by CMV infection and identifies IE as the first CM-encoded E ubiquitin ligase.
Researchers investigated transcription factor binding and gene expression in blastoderm embryos of four Drosophila species: D. melanogaster, D. yak, D. pseudoobscura, and D. virilis, to understand how regulatory sequence variation drives gene expression divergence. They compared gene expression levels measured by mRNA-seq to genome-wide binding measured by ChIP-seq of four transcription factors involved in anterior-posterior patterning. Results showed that mRNA levels are more conserved than individual factor binding events, and changes in gene expression were not explained by changes in factor binding. However, highly bound sites in regions bound by multiple factors and near genes were conserved more than other sites, suggesting weak or non-functional factor binding not subject to purifying selection.
Epidemiological Assessment of Eight Rounds of Mass Drug Administration for Lymphatic Filariasis in India: Implications for Monitoring and Evaluation

A large-scale epidemiological study was conducted in two primary health centers in Thanjavur district, India, a region endemic for bancroftian filariasis, which had undergone eight rounds of mass drug administration (MDA). The survey covered 70% of the 50,363 population and found a microfilaria (M) prevalence of 0.2% and intensity 0.004 per 60µl blood, while antigen (Ag) prevalence was 2.3% and 17.3 units. Ag prevalence ranged from 0.7 to 0.9% in children 2-10 years and 2.7 to 3.0 in adults. Despite M levels <1% and Ag <2 in sentinel sites, "residual" M prevalence ≥1 was found in children irrespective of Ag-status and "transmission" at least one Ag-positive child during M period hotspots were identified. Antigenemic persons were clustered at household and site levels. An Ag prevalence of 1% in children (0.4 community M prevalence) was proposed as a threshold for stopping MDA. The existence of hotspots and spatial clustering indicate the need for developing surveillance strategies detecting hotspots, evidence-based sampling and evaluation size for transmission assessment surveys.
A systematic review was conducted to assess the effectiveness of temeph, an organophosphate laricide, in controlling deng vectors and deng transmission when used as a single intervention or in combination with other methods. A comprehensive literature search of six databases and grey literature was performed, with 27 studies included in the review (11 single intervention, 16 combined). Single intervention studies showed temeph reduced entomological indices, while 11 of 16 combined studies showed tem with other chemical methods reduced entom indices, but this was not sustained in five. The effectiveness of temeph was dependent on factors such as delivery quality, water rate, type, debris, temperature, sunlight, and exposure. Timing and reapplication, reluctance, cost, supplies, time, and labour were limitations. When used alone, tem was effective in suppressing entom indices, but not when combined with other interventions. No evidence suggests tem use reduces deng transmission.
The cohesin complex plays a crucial role in holding sister chromatids together from the time of their duplication in S phase until separation during mitosis. In budding yeast, cohesin is found along the length of chromosomes, but is most abundant at the centromere surrounding region, the pericentere. Research has shown that the C19 kinetore complex and replication-associated factor, C3, are important mediators of perenteric cohesion, but act through distinct mechanisms. The C19 complex directs the association of cohes with the pericere, while C3 is dispensable for cohes enrichment in the perere but essential for its functionality in holding centromeres together. Cells lacking C3 exhibit cohesion defects in combination with mutants of the C19 complex. Delaying DNA replication rescues the defect in cells lacking C19 components, but not C3. This suggests the C19 complex ensures cohes loading at centrom prior to replication fork passage, ensuring incorporation through a process requiring C3.
Researchers conducted a comprehensive analysis of the serum metabolome and lipidome in adult patients with deng fever/deng hemorrhagic fever (DF) at three stages: early febrile, defervence, and convalescence. Using liquid chromatography and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry, they identified 60 differential metabolites in a sample of 44 patients. The main metabolite classes were fatty acids, acylcarnitines, phospholids, and amino acids, with perturbed pathways including fatty acid biosynthesis, β-oxidation, phosphid catabolism, and steroid pathway. These changes suggest a multifactorial host response to DENV infection. Analysis of phosphids and sphingids revealed temporal trends associated with lymphocytes and platelets, with significant perturbation during early stages and normalization at convalescence. These metabolites may serve as prognostic markers. DENV causes distinct serumome and lipidome changes, with many metabolites involved in inflammatory responses. The study found early anti-inflammatory responses modulating pro-inflammatory processes, preventing excessive or prolonged inflammation. This is the first example of omic approach revealing concurrent, dynamic host responses to DENV, providing insights into why DF is self-limiting.
Research on Neglected Tropical Diseases (NTDs) has increased in recent years, with significant gaps in diagnostic and treatment remaining. Analyzing bibliometric data from research publications is a powerful method for revealing research efforts and partnerships. This study aimed to map NTD research in Germany and its partners abroad to enable informed evaluation of German contributions to NTD research. A Scopus database search for articles with German affiliations published between 2002-2012 was conducted for kinoplast and helminth diseases. Open tools were used for data cleaning (OpenRefine), geocoding (OpenMaps) and creating (TableNet) to visualise and analyse co-author networks (Gephi). From 26,833 publications worldwide addressing 11 diseases, 1,187 (4.4%) had at least one German affiliation, and 972 were processed for the five most-published diseases. Of those, 4,007 authors and 863 institutions were extracted to construct co-author networks. The majority of co-authors outside Germany were from high-income countries, with collaborations on the African continent scattered. NTD research in Germany was distributed among 220 institutions. Strong performers were identified on individual level using parameters (publications, h-index) and network (between centrality). The network varied between diseases. The share of NTD publications with affiliations is half its share in other medical fields. This underlines the need to identify and expand Germany's strong research towards NTD. Spatial analysis of collaborations abroad supports strengthening research capacity, particularly in low-middle countries less involved than high. Identifying knowledge within researcher networks complements traditional indicators for collaboration opportunities.
In Haiti, the Ministry of Public Health and its international partners implemented a mass drug administration (MDA) program targeting lymphatic filariasis (LF) and soil-transmitted helminths (STH) since 2000. By 2012, the neglected tropical disease (ND) program had reached national scale, achieving high epidemiological coverage, allowing for treatment cessation of LF in most of the country. Key to this success was the detailed implementation of MDAs, which included: community awareness through evidence-based, multi-channel education facilitated by voluntary distributors; community trust through respected member recruitment, training, supervision, and motivation; directly observed treatment; accessible distribution and supply; and data-driven strategies. These strategies were effective, with 100% geographical coverage in 2012, exceeding targets for LF (65%) and STH (75%), and significant infection reduction, with 45 communes reaching LF treatment threshold. International support enabled Haiti's successful campaign, resulting in steady progress toward LF elimination and STH control. The described efforts established global best practices for ND control and address future challenges: maintaining STH control post-LF treatment and morbidity management for lymphatic patients.
Researchers investigated the role of the master regulator Ctr in Sinorhizobium meli, an alphaproteobacterium that forms a symbiotic relationship with legume hosts. The bacterium undergoes cellular differentiation within host cells, resulting in genome amplification, branching, elongation, and loss of reproductive capacity. Similar to Caulobacterus cresus, Ctr is linked to cell cycle regulation, but its function in S. meli is not well understood. Depletion of Ctr caused cell elongation, branching, and genome amplification, similar to nitrogen-fixing bacteroids. Cell cycle proteolytic degradation of Ctr is essential in S. mel, suggesting a mechanism for C depletion in differentiated bacteroids. ChIP-Seq and gene microarray analysis showed S. mel Ctr regulates similar processes as C cresus Ctr, but through different genes. C does not control Fts complex for cell division timing, but negatively regulates septum-inhibiting Min system.
Francisella tularens is a highly infectious bacterium that causes the zoonotic disease tularemia. Its ability to multiply and survive within macrophages is crucial for its virulence. Researchers screened a library of HimarFT transposon mutants of the F. tularens vaccine strain L to identify intracellular growth-deficient mutants, isolating one mutant in a gene encoding a putative glutamyl transpeptase (GT). This gene, F_076, was designated ggt. The ggt mutant showed impaired intracellular multiplication and attenuated virulence in mice. The study found that the GT activity of F. tulareis enables the utilization of glutathione (GSH, γ-glutylcystylglycine) and γ-glutylcyste dipeptide as cystine sources for intracellular growth. This is the first demonstration of the essential role of a nutrient acquisition system in intracellular F. tulareis multiplication. Glutathione is the most abundant source of cystine in host cytos. The capacity of this intracellular pathogen to utilize available GSH as cystine host cytos a paradigm of bacteria-host adaptation.
Researchers investigated the interaction between two species of Leishmania parasites, Leishmania amazonensis and Leishmania major, by infecting macrophages in culture. Leish amazonensis amastotes occupy large parasitophorous vacuoles (PVs) containing multiple parasites, while Leish major amastotes lodge in small, tight PVs that undergo fission as they divide. To determine if PVs of these Leish species can fuse, macrophages were infected with non-fluorescent Leish amazonensis amastotes and 48 hours later superinfected with fluorescent Leish major amastotes or promastigotes. Fusion was investigated by time-lapse imaging of living cells and colocalization of parasites in the same PVs. Results showed that PV containing Leish major promastigotes fused with established Leish amazon PVs, while PV containing Leish amastotes did not fuse. In chimeric vacuoles, Le major promigotes remained motile and multiplied but did not differentiate into amastotes. In contrast, doubly infected cells had unfused PV containing Leish promigotes, which were destroyed or differentiated into proliferating amastotes. This indicates PVs customized by Le majorast or promig differ in ability to fuse with Leish PV, and species-specific PV required for major differentiation.
Researchers investigated the ability of native membrane-expressed HIV-1 Env trimers to elicit tier 2 neutralizing antibodies (nAbs) in rabbits. Immunization with virus-like particles (VLPs) expressing trimers (trimer VLP) or DNA expressing Env trimer followed by protein (DNAimer) resulted in potent nAb titers in 2/8 and 1/20 rabbits, respectively. The sera neutralized quaternary epitopes and exploited gaps in the glycan defenses of the conserved region of JRFL gp120. Trimer VLP sera targeted the absence of a glycan residue at position 197, present in 98.7% of Envs. Removing this glycan made 50-67% of clade B tier 2 isolates sensitive to trimer VLP sera. Neutralizing epitopes overlapped with the CD binding site, suggesting the glycan acts as a "fence" limiting access. Bioinformatics analysis shared features of trimer VLP and monoclonal antibody 9. DNA trimer sera targeted absence of gly at 230, proximal to CD site, similar to monoclonal 8, albeit tier breadth. Data show strain-specific holes in gly fence allow tier 2 nAbs to native spikes. Cross-neutralization occurs without gly. Observations inform future nAb vaccine development.
Researchers investigated the use of immunohistochemistry to monitor wound healing in patients with Buruli ulcer (BU) treated with antibiotics. Traditionally, surgery has been the primary treatment for BU, but a combination of oral rifampicin and intramuscular streptomycin has improved outcomes and reduced recurrence rates. However, managing extensive lesions after successful therapy remains a challenge, particularly in African countries with high disease burden. Wound healing is delayed in some treated patients, but reasons are not fully understood. The study analyzed tissue specimens from eight BU patients with plaque lesions before and after chemotherapy using immunohistochemistry for markers of connective tissue neoformation, tissue remodeling, and epidermal activation. Several markers were found suitable for monitoring wound healing. α-smooth muscle actin positive myofibblasts were not present in untreated lesions but emerged during healing, producing extracellular matrix proteins like pro-collagen and tenascin in fibronectin areas. After treatment, cells including myiblasts showed activated phenotype with ribosomal S6 phosphorylation, a translation marker. Healing wounds showed dermal remodeling by apoptosis and cytokeratin 16 expression in epidermis.
Researchers investigated the relationship between impulse conduction and mitochondrial transport in adult mammalian peripheral nerves in vivo. They used confocal imaging of saphen nerves in anaesthetized mice to study mitochondrial trafficking in resting and electrically active axons. Electrical stimulation at low frequency increased anterograde and retrograde mitochondrial traffic in myelinated and unmyinated axons. Higher frequency conduction within physiological range (50 Hz) increased anterog, but not retro, mitochondrial traffic by increasing mobile mitochondria number and velocity. Capsaicin application to innervated saph nerve increased traffic in both myel and unmyinated axons. Mitochondria in axons conducting higher frequency became shorter, supplying additional mitochondria to population through fission. Recruited mitochondria did not accumulate at Nodes of Ranvier, continuing anterogradely. This pattern suggests peripheral terminals sensory ax represent high metabolic sites during high conduction. Most biogenesis occurs at body, antog mitochondrial may ensure uniform density along ax during high load, supporting sustained con.
Spondylacotarsal synostosis (SCT) is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by progressive vertebral fusions caused by loss-of-function mutations in Filamin B (FLNB). FLNB acts as a scaffold linking the actin cytoskeleton to signal transduction systems. Employing Fln knockout mice, we found morphological and molecular evidence that intervertebral discs (IVDs) of Fln-/- mice undergo rapid degeneration during postnatal development due to abnormal cell changes in IVD, particularly the annulus fibros (AF). In Fln-/- mice, AF cells lose fibroblast characteristics and acquire hypertrophic chondrocy phenotype. This is marked by endochond-like ossification: altered collagen expression, Collagen X, increased apoptosis, and inappropriate ossification. Conversion to chrocy coincides with upregulated TGFβ via Smad3 and BMP p38 signaling and activated canonical and non-canonical targets p21 and Ctg. FLNB attenuates Tβ/BMP signaling and influences AF fate. IVD disruptions in Fln/- mice resemble degenerative discs, revealing molecular causes vertebral and degeneration.
Researchers have identified a novel mechanism by which the orthomyxirus Thog virus (THOV) employs to evade antiviral immunity. The virus targets the general transcription factor TFI, which is crucial for the recruitment of RNA polymerase II (Pol II) to promoter sites. THOV achieves this by relocating TFI from the nucleus to the cytoplasm, creating a TFI-depleted environment. This would be expected to broadly impact gene expression, but surprisingly, only a limited number of genes are affected. The study found that TFI is essential for de novo recruitment of Pol II to promoters, but not for regulated expression from paused promoters. Many immune genes require de novo recruitment of Pol, making THOV's targeting of TFI a mechanism to modulate immune responses without disrupting other transcriptional activities. This suggests that interfering with TFI activity could be a therapeutic strategy to control undesirable inflammation.
Human parvovirus B19 (B19) infection of primary erythroid progenitor cells (EPCs) causes cell cycle arrest at both in the S and G2 phases of the cell cycle. The virus induces a DNA damage response (DDR) that facilitates viral replication, but is not required for cell cycle arrest in the G2 phase. A putative C-terminal activation domain (TAD) within the NS1 protein is responsible for G2 arrest. To understand the mechanism of B19 NS-induced G2 arrest, doxycine-inducible B19-permissive UT/E-S cell lines were established that express NS or NSmT2, and the function of T2 was examined during G arrest. The results confirm the NS T2 domain plays a role in NS-induced G arrest. Mechanistically, NS activates cellular expression through T, which is responsible for ATR activation. Activated A phosphorylates CDC25 at serine, which inactivates the cyclin/CDK complex without affecting nuclear import. The ATR-CHK-CDC25-CDK pathway is activated during B19 infection of PCs, and A plays a role in B19-induced G arrest.
Dengue virus (DENV) is a mosquito-borne virus that causes a range of diseases from uncomplicated to life-threatening, characterized by endothelial dysfunction and vascular leakage. Research has shown that the non-structural protein 1 (NS1) of DENV induces endothelial hyperperability in mice and human pulmonary endothelial cells by disrupting the endothelial glycocalyx layer. This study investigated the role of inflammatory mediators and endothelial-intrinsic pathways in DENV-induced vascular leakage. In vivo, DENV NS triggered vascular leakage in the dermis of wild-type C57/6 mice, but not the related West Nile virus NS. In vitro, human dermal endothelial cells exposed to DENV did not produce inflammatory cytokines (TN-α, IL-6, IL-8), and blocking these cytokines did not affect DENV-induced endothelial hyperability. Furthermore, DENV induced vascular in TLR- or TN-receptor-deficient mice at similar to wild-type levels. Finally, DENV-induced vascular was blocked using inhibitors targeting glycocal disruption. These findings indicate that DENV-induced endothelial vascular is independent of inflammatory but dependent on glycocal components.
In budding yeast, the assembly of a septin ring at the site of bud emergence is a critical for proper cytokinesis, spindle positioning, and the spindle position (SPO) checkpoint. The PO checkpoint delays mitotic exit and cytokinesis until the anaphase spindle aligns with the division axis. PO signalling requires Kin4 kinase and Kin4-regulating Elm kinase, which also controls septin dynamics. Two ubiquitin ligases, Dma1 and Dma2, control septin dynamics and PO by promoting Elm1 recruitment to the bud. Dma1 D2 mutant cells show reduced Elm levels at the bud and Elm-dependent Kin4 activation. Artificial Elm recruitment to the bud restores normal septin ring, spindle positioning, and PO response in Dma2 cells.
Humans inhabit a diverse range of environments, and natural selection has likely played a significant role in their ability to survive and thrive in extreme climates. This study scanned the human genome for signals of selection by identifying SNPs with strongest correlations to climate variables across 61 worldwide populations. Results show enrichment of genic and nonsynonymous SNPs relative to non-genic SNPs among those correlated with climate variables. Strongest signals overlap with GWAS, including pigmentation and autoimmune disease SNPs. Enrichment found in gene sets related to UV, infection, immunity, and cancer. Adaptations to climate shaped spatial variation in humans.
Short QT syndrome (SQ) is a genetically heterogeneous condition characterized by abbreviated QT intervals and increased susceptibility to arrhythmia and sudden death. This study investigates arrhythmogenic mechanisms in the delayed rectifier K+ current (IK)-linked SQT1 variant of SQ. Markov chain (MC) models were found to be superior to Hodgkin-Hux (HH) models in reproducing experimental data effects of the N588 mutation on KCNH-encoded hERG channel. Ionic models were incorporated into ventricular action potential (AP) models and 1D and 2 idealized and realistic transmural ventricular simulations and 3D anatomical model. In single cell models, the N588 mutation abbreviated ventricular AP duration at 90% repolarization (AP90) and maximal transm voltage heterogeneity (δ) during AP. This resulted in transm heterogeneity AP90 and effective refractory period (ERP) effects anticipated to be anti-arrhythmic rather than pro-arrhyth. However, considering transm heterogeneity IK density in intact tissue based on Tusscher-Noble-Noble-Pfil ventricular model, N588 mutation led to QT shortening and increased T-wave amplitude, but δ found augmented in local ventricular tissue regions, increasing vulnerability unidirectional conduction and predisposing reentrant excitation. In 2 and 3D models, N588 facilitated reentrant excitation due reduced substrate sustaining re-entry size. Thus, S1 N588-hERG mutation facilitates ventricular reentry, increasing lifespan reentrant waves and scroll 3D tissue stability.
Researchers have developed a deep network model to study the collective motion of zebraf (Danio rerio) that is both predictive and insightful. The model is composed of modules that allow it to capture the behavior of each individual in the collective. Simulated trajectories show that the model recovers the underlying rules used to generate them, including the number of interacting neighbors. Experiments on groups of 60 zraf show that interactions between pairs can be described as repulsive or attractive when moving slowly, but at high velocities, interactions are alignment or repulsion at close distances. The model reveals that each zraf decides where to move by aggregating information from neighbors, with higher weights for those close, in collision, or moving in frontal and lateral locations. The network also finds that the number of interacting individuals is dynamic, typically between 8-22, with 1-10 most important.
A study was conducted to quantify the fitness of HIV-1 drug resistance mutations in a Swiss cohort using a phylogenetic approach. The research aimed to understand the dynamics of transmitted drug resistance in antiretroviral treatment, as around 10% of ART-naive patients in Europe are infected with drug-resistant HIV-1. The study employed a stochastic birth-death process model to reconstruct the transmission tree of viral lineages among hosts infected by sensitive or resistant strains. The fitness was quantified as the ratio of transmission rates of resistant to sensitive strains. Six mutations in the reverse transcriptase and one in the protease gene were analyzed: 41L, 67,N,70,184,210,215,215,219 (RTI-related) and 103,108,138,181,190 (NNI) and 90 in the protease. The 90 mutation in protease was found to have higher fitness than sensitive strains. Reverse transcriptase mutations 67,70,184,219 were less fit than sensitive. Posterior intervals for remaining mutations included 1, indicating no significant effect on transmissibility. This is consistent with alternative fitness measures. A novel phyodynamic approach was developed to estimate transmission cost of resistance.
A study investigated the role of the Elong complex, specifically the histone acetylase Sin3/El3, in the translation of stress-induced mRNAs in fission yeast. The Elong complex was found to interact with RNA polymerase II and its deficiency led to transcriptional defects. However, Elong was also shown to modify tRNAs, affecting translation efficiency. The study revealed that Sin3/3p is crucial for oxidative stress survival, as the transcription program governed by the Sty1-Atf1-Pcr pathway was affected in mutant cells. Notably, cells lacking Sin3p could not modify the uridine wobble nucleotide of certain tRNAs, and other tRNA modifying activities, such as Ctu-C2, were also essential for normal tolerance to H2O. A plasm overexpressing tRNALUU complemented the stress-related phenotypes of Sin3p mutant cells. The study found that H2-dependent genes, including transcription factors At1 and P1, were highly expressed mRNAs with a biased lysine codon usage. These mRN were poorly translated in stress cells lacking Sin3 or C2, whereas mutated At1 with AAA-A lysine codons was efficiently translated in all backgrounds. The study demonstrated that lack of functional Elong resulted in stress phenotypes due to its contribution to tRNA modification and translation inefficiency of stress-induced mRN.
HIV-1 Nef protein plays a crucial role in the virus's ability to replicate and progress to AIDS in primates. To understand how Nef increases the infectivity of free virus particles, researchers investigated its link to Env protein. Since Nef did not affect the quantity of Env on virus particles, they looked for qualitative changes by examining if Nef alters HIV-1 sensitivity to neutralizing antibodies. Nef conferred up to 50-fold resistance to 2F and 4, two potent neutralizing monoclonal antibodies targeting the membrane-proximal region (MP) of gp41. In contrast, N had no effect on HIV-1 neutralization by MP-specific antibody Z13, peptide T20, or a panel of antibodies targeting gp120. Resistance to neutralization by 2 and 4 was observed in N from diverse HIV-1 and SIV isolates, as well as HIV-1 virions with Env from CCR- and CX4-tropic viruses, clade B and C, or primary isolates. Analysis of N mutants revealed this activity requires N myristoylation, but is separable from other N functions like enhancing infectivity and downregulating CD4. Glycosylated glycoprotein substituted Nef in conferring resistance 2 and 4, indicating this is conserved in retrovirus without N. Given MP-recognition by 2 and 4 dependence on membrane, in contrast to membrane-independence Z13, data supports a model where N alters MP in virion membrane context. N and Glyylated glycoprotein decreased virion capture by 2 and 4, not other antibodies. Studies show N protects lentiviruses from broadly-acting neutralizing antibodies. This N activity has implications for HIV immunity and AIDS pathogenesis.
Researchers investigated the gene expression changes in the snail host, Bithia siam gomphos, infected with the liver fluke Opisthoris vivini, which causes cholangiocarcinoma in the Greater Mekong region of Thailand. High-throughput sequencing and bioinformatics analysis revealed 7,655 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) between infected and uninfected snails, associated with 43 biological pathways, including immune mechanisms against parasites. Differentially expressed genes with immune functions showed proteases were downregulated in infected snails, while heat shock proteins and actin transcripts were upregulated in infected snails compared to uninfected counterparts. This study provides a foundation for functional analysis of genes and products involved in immune mechanisms allowing parasite colonization of snail host. Annotated dataset is a resource for discovery of susceptibility and resistance mechanisms in snail to parasite and comparative analysis with other snail hosts of platyhelmin, including schistosomes.
Researchers investigated the role of complement receptor 1 (CR1, also known as CD35) in the susceptibility to leprosy, a significant public health issue in Brazil. CR1 binds to complement fragments C3/C4 deposited on mycobacteria, facilitating its entry into macrophages. The study examined CR1 polymorphisms, gene expression, and soluble CR1 levels in a case-control study with 213 leprosy patients (47% multibacillary) and 297 controls. Nine polymorphisms were hapyped by multiplex PCR-PCR in 213 lepro patients and 297 controls. mRNA levels were measured by qPCR and CR1 by ELISA in 80 samples. Individuals with the most common recombinant haplotype harboring rs926*T in intron 21 and rs700*T in exon 26 (encoding p140Met of Yolk antigen) presented higher susceptibility to lepro (OR 2.43, p0.017). Paibacillary patients with these variants had lower CR1 levels, reducing anti-inflammatory response (p0.040 and 0.046). The most haplotype increased susceptibility to multacillary form (OR 3.04, 0) presented intronic rs343*G allele, associated higher gene expression (0.043), increasing parasite internalization. An inverse correlation was found between CR and mannose-binding lectin (initiator lectin pathway complement, recognized by1) (R-0.52 0.007).
Researchers conducted a study to investigate sex-specific differences in serum metabolite concentrations and their genetic determinants. They analyzed data from over 3,300 individuals from the KORA F3 and F cohorts, measuring 131 metabolites, including amino acids, phosphatidylcholines, sphingomyins, acylcarnines, and C-sugars. A linear regression analysis revealed significant differences between males and females for 102 out of 131 metabolites (p-value < 3.8×10^-4, Bonferr-corrected threshold). Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) showed genome-wide significant differences in beta-estimates for SNPs in the CPS1 locus (carbamyl-phosphate synthase 1, significance: p < 3.8×10^-10, Bonerr-correct threshold) for glycine. The study found that metabolite profiles of males and females are significantly different, and specific variants in metabolism-related genes depict sexual dimorphism.
Genome-scale metabolic networks are used to model genotype-phenotype relationships through flux simulations, but the large solution space of metabolic states requires optimization approaches. The objective function used in optimization is linked to the biological hypothesis underlying the model, making it a crucial parameter for successful modeling. Linear combinations of fluxes are used to formulate objective functions, but the optimization is sensitive to stoichiometry representation of the network, leading to different results with numerically equivalent but biochemically stoichiometric representations. This ambiguity makes biological interpretation subjective. A new method, Minimization of Metabolites (MiBl), decouples stoichiometry from objective formulation by using metabolite turnovers instead of fluxes. Simulations of perturbed networks show stoichi representation independence is essential for unambiguous modeling and biological interpretation. MiBl expands metabolic modeling scope, elucidating genetic interactions in Saccharomyces cerevisiae.
Researchers investigated the relationship between the distribution of plague (Yersinia pestis infection) and the genetic structure of the black rat (Rattus rattus) population in Madagascar, the primary reservoir of the disease. A comparative study of seroprevalence and genetic data (15 microsatellite markers) was conducted in four geographic areas with varying topography, each covering 150-200 km within the Madagas plague focus. Serrevalence levels in rat populations mirrored those reported in humans, with marked genetic structure increasing with relief. However, servalence and genetic data differed between areas, indicating plague distribution not solely dependent on rat dispersal. Genetic estimates suggested epizootics had weak impact on population sizes. In highlands, plague dissemination not solely by rat dispersal, human activities involved in spreading disease in rat and human populations.
Researchers investigated the human IgG responses to Schistosoma mansoni's surface proteins, specifically the Ly6 family members, following praziquel treatment. The study aimed to understand the host-parasite interactions by examining the tegument surface proteins and elicited immune responses. A comprehensive analysis of the Schistoma mansoni Ly family revealed eleven members, including three novel proteins, and confirmed Sm29 as a unique double PAR/Ly domain-containing protein. The presence of cysteine residues, signal peptides, and GPI sites suggest all Ly proteins are cell-bound. IgG and IgE responses to surface-bound LyA and LyB were measured in a cohort of S mansoni-infected Ugandan males before and after prazant treatment. Pre-treatment IgG prevalence for LyA and LyB were 7.4% and 25.3% respectively, higher than IgG for sub-surface antigen SmAL. Post-treatment IgG against surface LyA and Ly significantly dropped compared to rising Ig for sub-s SmAL. The study expands the number of Ly proteins in S mans and demonstrates surface LyA and Ly elicit immunological responses during infection in endemic communities.
Researchers have developed a computational model to simulate the morphogenesis of epithelial cells in the Drosophila retina, focusing on the role of the adhesion protein Cadherin. The model aims to minimize the interfacial energy between cells during tissue formation. Experimental data from normal and mutant cells lacking or misexpressing Cadin are explained by a model incorporating key features of morphogenesis, including Cadin expression timing and its relation to cell contact remodeling. Simulations replicate wild-type and mutant cell geometries, highlighting Cad dynamics and the importance of adhesion protein and its timing in cell remodeling. Additionally, the model suggests Cadin is recycled from inactive to active interfaces, modulating adhesion between cells.
Researchers have developed a computational model to study the role of MT1-MMP, a protease involved in cancer cell invasion, in degrading the extracellular matrix (ECM) at invadopodia. Previous studies suggested continuous supply of MT-M, but its turnover rate and contribution to degradation were unclear. Fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP) experiments with tagged MT-M at invadop showed rapid recovery, approximated by double-exponential plots with 26 and 259 seconds. Recovery depended on vesicle transport, not lateral diffusion. A computational model was constructed based on FR kinetics, reproducing experiments. Inhibiting ves transport blocked ECM degradation and simulation showed no degradation under inhibiting ves transport. ECM degradation reduction depended on MT-M turnover. Experiments and simulations established MT-M turnover's role in invadodia degradation. Simulations suggested synergy between proteolytic activity and MT-M turnover, with nonlinear reduction in degradation when both factors reduced. A computational tool was developed to evaluate cancer invasion strategies.
Researchers conducted a spatio-temporal assessment of simian/humanodeficiency virus (SHIV) evolution in macaques infected with RT-SHm027, a simian immunodef virus encoding HIV-1 reverse transcriptase, treated with RT inhibitors. The study aimed to understand how drug-resistant HIV-1 arises and spreads within an individual and how spatial structure impacts its emergence. Serial samples were taken from blood, including plasma and peripheral blood mononuclear cells, lymph nodes, gut, and vagina at four time points. Single-genome sequencing revealed a dynamic process where vRNA rapidly acquires drug resistance across compartments through multiple mutations. The same genotypes were present across compartments, but frequencies did not equilibrate immediately. Blood and lymph nodes were compartmentalized, while blood and lymph differed from mucosal tissues. The study suggests blood sampling does not capture viral dynamics in other body parts, especially gut, where vRNA turnover was faster and plasma retained fewer wild-type viruses than other compartments.
Researchers investigated the role of feedback regulation in cell lineage progression on tissue morphogenesis using mathematical modeling. They found that a specific feedback architecture, where both positive and negative diffusible signals act on stem and progenitor cells, leads to bistable or bimodal growth, ultrasensitivity to external cues, growth-driven budding, self-elongation, and self-organization in the form of lamellar patterns. These behaviors arise through control of stem/progenitor self-renewal, not cell cycle regulation. Spatial patterns result from interactions between diffus factors with antagonistic effects, but morphogenesis is not due to Turing instabilities.
Researchers conducted the largest genome-wide association study to date on myopia, a common eye disorder characterized by excessive elongation of the eye, in 4,771 European participants. The study aimed to elucidate the etiology of myopia, which is complex and poorly understood. A survival analysis of age of myopia onset identified 22 significant associations, 10 of which replicated earlier associations with refractive error. Ten novel associations were replicated in a separate cohort of 8,323 participants who developed myopia before age 10. These associations explain 2.9% of variance in myopia onset and suggest multiple mechanisms behind its development. One association is in PRSS56, linked to abnormally small eyes, one in LAMA, part of extracellular matrix, two in RGR and RDH, involved in regeneration of 11-cis-retinal, two in ZIC and SFRP, involved in retinal ganglion growth, and five in neuronal development.
Researchers investigated the role of curvature feedback in the energetics and dynamics of lamprey swimming using a closed-loop model. The lamprey, like other animals, have a central pattern generator (CPG) circuit that activates locomotion and adjusts to sensory inputs from the environment. This feedback system is crucial for responding to perturbations, but also active during unperturbed swimming, influencing the baseline pattern. The study evaluated different forms of body-based feedback and their effects on swimming energetics and kinematics, as little is known about curvature feedback form. The CP was modeled as coupled oscillators, pairs representing left and right body segments, activating muscles and moving the lamprey through a Navier-Stokes fluid. Body curvature served as input to the oscillators, closing the loop. Two feedback forms were considered, consistent with lamprey proprioceptive receptors. Directional feedback excited or inhibited oscillators on the same side, opposite on the other, depending on gain. It did not affect frequency, but changed activity duration. Magnitude feedback provided symmetric effect on both oscillators, increasing frequency and reducing cost when gain was high. Both feedback had similar curvature magnitude. Results indicate magnitude-based feedback on CP with different forms cause distinct performance.
Researchers investigated the dynamics of HIV epidemics in Africa, where local outbreaks are often dominated by a single subtype, indicating strong founder effects. They hypothesized that competition between viral strains may favor the strain that first colonized a population, slowing new strain invasion and epidemic diversification. A stochastic modeling framework simulated epidemics over contact networks, introducing a second strain into a population with established first strain. Simulations were parameterized with empirical data, testing scenarios with varying prevalence levels. Results showed the second strain spread slower than the first, even with equal transmission efficiency, unable to invade on pandemic timescale. A 25% transmission advantage over the first strain was needed to dominate in decades. The effect was weaker if introduced during growth phase. Interference mechanisms (inhibition, superinfection, hub depletion, peak infectiousness) were tested, confirming a strong first comer advantage in HIV competition, explaining global geography and influencing pandemic evolution.
Researchers have investigated the self-organization of muscle structure and function across multiple scales, from the sarcomere to the muscle bundle. To address this multiscale problem, they constrained muscle cells in microenvironments that facilitate intracellular organization. The study hypothesized that extracellular boundary conditions facilitate cytoskeletal organization for sarcomerogenesis. A model was developed for the cytoskeleton of neonatal ventricular myocytes in relation to extracellular matrix cues. Numerical results and in vitro assays showed distinct cytoskeletal architectures arise from temporally-ordered processes: interaction between actin fibers, myofibrils, and focal adhesions, as well as cooperative bundling of nascent myofils. A hierarchy of mechanisms regulates contractile cytoskeleton self-organization, with a positive feedback loop initiating symmetry break, potentiated by extracellular conditions, polarizing contractile cytoskeleton.
Researchers investigated the invasive potential of Wolbachia, a symbiotic bacterium being trialed as a biocontrol agent to reduce dengue transmission, in Brazilian Aedes aegypti mosquitoes. Wolia requires high maternal transmission rate, strong cytoplasmic incompatibility, and low host fitness costs to invade and spread within wild populations. However, differences in climate, field protocols, urbanization, and human density amongst deployment sites have limited comparison of Wolia's invasive potential. The study characterized the phenotypic effects of the Mel strain in Aedes aegi mosquitoes with Brazilian background to understand its invasive potential. Results showed Mel causes cytoplasm incompatibility, high maternal transmission rate, and no detrimental effect on host fecundity or fertility. To understand urban landscape effects on mosquito survival, mark-release experiments were conducted using Wolia-infected mosquitoes in Rio de Janeiro areas where Wolia will be deployed. Mosquito populations were characterized in relation to socio-demographic conditions at sites and future release areas. Mathematical models were constructed using laboratory and field data to describe urban conditions influencing Wolia infection reaching 100% following release. Invasion was predicted at all sites, with varying conditions between sites, influenced by local population size. Analysis of laboratory and field data showed Mel Wolia possesses characteristics to spread in urban-dem environments, including Eliminate Program sites.
Histone lysine methylation is a crucial epigenetic modification that regulates chromatin structure and gene expression. Histone H3 lysine 4 (H3K4) methylation, existing in mono-, di-, or tri-methyl states, plays a significant role in gene expression involved in plant development and stress responses. However, the mechanism of this epigenetic modification is not fully understood. Researchers identified a Jmj domain-containing protein, JMJ703, as a histone lysine demethylase that reverses all forms of H3K4 in rice. Loss-of-function mutation of the gene affects stem elongation and growth, possibly due to increased expression of cytokinin oxidase genes in the mutant. Crystal structure analysis of the catalytic core (cMJ703) revealed similarity with mammalian and yeast JMJD proteins, H3 and H3 demethylases, but specific features were observed. Key residues interact with cofactors Fe(II) and N-oxylglycine and methylated H3K peptide were identified, essential for demethyl activity in vivo.
