Genotyping was performed using the Affymetrix 6.0 microarray, and imputation was done for 2.8 million single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) using YRI and CEU Hap II phase panels. A strong signal was observed within the SCN5A gene, encoding the cardiac sodium channel, with genome-wide association (p<2.5×10^-8) in two cohorts and meta-analysis. The signal explained 2% of PR variability in African Americans (β=5.1 msec per allele, 95% CI=4.1-6.1, p=3×10^-23). This SNP was also associated with PR (β=2.4 per allele, 95 CI=1.8-3, p=10^-16) in individuals of European ancestry (n=14,042), but with smaller effect and explained 0.5%. Meta-analysis of cohorts identified genome-wide associations in SCN10 (rs801), ME1 (10855), and TB5 (725) that correlated with SNPs in European and Asian studies. African was associated with increased PR (13.3 msec, p=.009) in one cohort but not others.
Tomato mosaic virus (ToMV), a positive-strand RNA virus, replicates its genomic RNA in replication complexes formed on intracellular membranes. A previous studies showed that host seven-transmembrane protein TOM1 is necessary for efficient MV multiplication. This study reveals that small GTP-binding protein ARL, along with TOM, co-purifies with FLAG-tagged ToMV 180 replication protein from solubilized membranes of MV-infected Nicotiana tabacum cells. Solubilized MV-infected cells expressing FLAG-tagged A8 co-pur with TOM and MV180 replication proteins, and the fraction showed RNA-dependent RNA polymerase activity transcribing MV RNA. Uninfected cells TOM co-pur with FLAGged A8 less efficiently, suggesting complex containing MV proteins, TOM, and A8 formed on membranes in cells. Arabidopsis A8 consists four members. Simultaneous mutations two A8 genes inhibited MV multiplication. In vitro MV translation-replication system, lack TOM or A8 inhibited replicative RNA production, indicating TOM and A8 required for negative-strand synthesis. MV180 protein coexpressed with TOM and A8 in yeast, 5-capping activity detected in membrane. This activity undetect or weak when180 protein expressed alone or with TOM or A8. Results suggest TOM and A components of MV replication play crucial roles toward activation synthesizing and capping functions.
In the locust olfactory system, inhibitory interneurons play a crucial role in shaping the firing patterns of principal neurons, specifically Kenyon cells (KC). Two inhibitory motifs, feed-forward and feedback, have been identified, with distinct anatomical and functional differences. A subset of lateral interneurons (LHNs) provide feed-forward inhibition to KCs to maintain sparse firing, essential for olfactory learning and memory. However, a single inhibitory cell, the GABAergic neuron (GN), is the primary source of inhibition in the mushroom body, mediated by a feedback (FB) loop including KC and GN. A model of the locust olfactory system was used to compare the effects of feed-forward and feedback inhibition. Both motifs maintained KC responses and provided optimal odor discrimination, but only feedback inhibition produced a response consistent with in vivo data. This suggests that feedback inhibition is the primary source of inhibition to KCs. The study provides general rules for feed-forward versus feedback inhibition and highlights the GGN's potential as the primary source of inhibition. Understanding inhibitory motifs' impact on postsynaptic activity could reveal unknown inhibitory structures in biological networks.
A novel dual real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR) assay has been developed for the diagnosis of lyssavirus infection, including rabies in animals and humans. Traditional post-mortem diagnosis of rabies relies on immunofluorescence and virus isolation, but molecular techniques such as PCR-based methods are increasingly used for diagnosing rabies in humans and epidemiological analyses. However, achieving high specificity and sensitivity while accounting for lyavirus genetic diversity remains a challenge. The combo RT-q method combines two technologies: a probe-based TaMan-qPCR for detecting RAB species (pan-RV-qPCR) and a reaction using intercalating dye SYBR for other lyss species (panly-qPCR). The assay was evaluated with a large panel of animal samples covering all genetic variability and all lyss species characterized to date. It was also evaluated for human rabies diagnosis on 211 samples (76 positive and 135 negative), including saliva and brain biops. The method detected all human rabies cases and confirmed sensitivity of skin biopsy (91.5%) and saliva (54%) for intravital diagnosis of rabies. The method was implemented in two rab reference laboratories in endemic countries (Cambodia and Morocco). This RT-q method is a validated tool for rab diagnosis in humans and animals and a promising for lyavirus surveillance.
In the Eastern Region of Ghana, an outbreak of tset-transmitted trypanosomias resulted in over 50% losses of domestic pigs in 2007. To control the disease, a trial was conducted from May to October 2007 to assess the efficacy of insecticide-treated mosquito nets in controlling tset. Two villages were selected: one as control with 14 pigs and one experimental with 24 pigs protected by insecticide-treated nets. The 100 cm high, 150 denier polyester fences with 100 mg/m deltamethrin and UV protector were attached to timber poles and planks. Bi-monthly monitoring of tset densities with geo-referenced traps showed a 90% reduction in the protected village within two months, with further reductions exceeding 95% in subsequent months. The control village tset population remained unaffected, displaying seasonal variations. Fifty pigs from each village were ear-tagged and given curative treatment with diminazene acate 3.5 mg/kg after blood samples taken. Initial trypan prevalence was 76% in protected and 72% in control, decreasing to 16 in protected and 84 in control after three months. After six, 8% of protected were infected compared to 60 in control.
A growing movement to promote reproducibility and transparency in biomedical research has emerged, emphasizing access to raw data, protocols, replication of studies, systematic reviews, and documentation of funding and conflicts of interest. A survey of 441 biomedical articles published between 2000-2014 assessed reproducibility and transparency indicators. Results showed that only one study provided a full protocol and none made raw data directly available. Replication studies were rare (n=4) and 16 studies were included in systematic reviews or meta-analyses. Most studies lacked funding and conflict information. Disclosure of conflicts decreased from 94.4% in 2000 to 34.6% in 2014, while reporting increased from 0 in 200 to 15.4 in 201 and from 5.6 in 200 to 50 in 201. Clinical medicine articles were more likely to lack funding information and have private funding compared to other fields.
Inhalation of Yersinia pestis, the causative agent of primary pneumonic plague, results in a highly lethal disease with mortality rates approaching 100%. The disease progression of pneumonic plague is biphasic, consisting of an initial pre-inflammatory phase characterized by bacterial growth in the absence of host inflammation, followed by a pro-inflammatory phase marked by neutrophil influx, inflammatory cytokine storm, and tissue destruction. Research using a FRET-based probe to quantify effector protein injection by Y. pestis type III secretion system reveals that bacteria target alveolar macrophages early in infection of mice, followed by a shift in host preference to neutrophils. Neutrophil influx fails to limit bacterial growth in lung and is responsible for severe inflammation during lethal phase.
A study was conducted in an urban area of Southeast Brazil to evaluate the performance of serology in identifying asymptomatic Leishmaniasis (VL) infection in a cohort of 136 participants with a two-year follow-up period. Blood samples from 97 positive and 39 PCR-negative individuals were collected, and none progressed to disease from asymptomatic state. Controls included samples from 22 healthy individuals and 8 patients with kala-azar. Molecular techniques (PCR and hybridization) confirmed Leishmania presence in all kalaazar patients and 86% of cohort. Kala patients showed high reactivity in ELISA, whereas asymptomatic individuals low reactivity against tested antigens. Compared to molecular methods, L. amazon and L. infant antigens showed higher sensitivity (49.6% and 41%) than r39 (26.5%), but r39 had higher specificity (73.7%) than L. amazon (52.6) and L. infant (36%). Low agreement among antigens used (kappa0.10). Serological tests were inaccurate diagnosing asymptomatic infections compared to molecular methods, leading to misclassification in population studies. Studies using serology to estimate prevalence, evaluate programs or identify Leish infection risk factors may have compromised results.
Researchers have developed a method to analyze the expression of retrotransposons in mouse embryonic stem cells using Illumina and Affymetrix gene microarray data. This approach allowed them to identify histone deacetylase 1 (Hdac1) as a component of the retrotranson silencing machinery in these cells. They also found retrotransons targeted by other silencing mechanisms such as DNA methylation, E-mediated histone modification, and Ring1/Eed-containing polycomb repressive complexes in embryonic stem cells. The study suggests that multiple silencing mechanisms target different retroons in embryonic cells, and that different copies of the same retroon can be sensitive to different silencing mechanisms. The researchers also identified retroon sequence elements targeted by silencing machineries. The study highlights the complexity of retroon silencing in embryonic and germ cells.
Arabidopsis thaliana cryptochrome 2 (CRY) plays a crucial role in regulating flowering time. CRY-interacting bHL1 (C1) interacts with CRY in response to blue light to activate Flowering Locus T (FT) transcription. In vitro, C1 binds canonical E-box (CGT, also known as G-box) with higher affinity than non-canonical-box (CAN) sequences. However, in vivo, C1 binds chromatin region FT promoter containing non-canonical sequences. This study shows CRY also interacts with at least C5 in response blue, but not darkness or other wavelengths. Genetic analysis demonstrates C1, C2 C4, and C5 redundantly activate FT transcription and are positive regulators C2-mediated flowering. C1 and other C proteins form heterodimers, some heterodimers have higher affinity C homodimers non-canonical-box in vitro assays. This explains C1 and other bind canonical-box higher, associated noncanonical FT vivo. Consistent hypothesis C proteins similar roles C2-mediated blue signaling, C expression regulated by light. Study demonstrates C redundantly regulating C2-dependent, different C formodimers interact non-canonical vivo.
A study evaluated the economic impact of overseas and domestic treatment options for intestinal parasitic infections among US-bound refugees from Asia, where hookworm, Trichuris truria, Ascaris lumbricoid, and Strongloides stercalis are endemic. These infections are rare in the US and may be underdiagnosed or misdiagnosed, leading to serious consequences. An economic model was developed to estimate the cost and health impacts of four interventions on an annual cohort of 27,700 US-bound Asian refugees: 1) No program, 2) US domestic screening and treatment, 3) overseas albendazole and ivermect presumptive treatment, and 4) overseas albazole domestic for strongloides. The model estimated long-term effects of parasitic infections on health measures included outpatient cases, hospitalizations, deaths, and quality-adjusted life years (QALY). The "No" option was the least expensive ($165,923 per cohort) and least effective (145 cases, 4.0 hospitalizations, and 0.67 deaths over 60-year for one-year). Overseas albazole and iverect option ($418,824) was less expensive than domestic treatment ($3,832,572) or overseas albazole domestic for stronglo ($2,182,483). The most effective option was overseas alb and iverect, which reduced cases and hospitalizations by 80% at estimated cost $458,718 per death averted or $2,21924,036 per QY gained relative to No. Overse presumptive treatment for US-bound refugees is cost-effective and less expensive than domestic treatment. Addition of iverect to alb reduced prevalence stronglo and probability rare fatal disseminated.
Researchers have identified a new species of microsporidian parasite, Nematoda displere, that infects the nematode Caenorhabdis elegans and exhibits a unique tissue tropism compared to previously described parasites of this host. Nemat displere can invade and replicate in multiple tissues, including the epidermis, muscle, and intestine of C elegans, with the majority of replication occurring in the muscle and epider. In contrast, two closely related microidian pathogens, N parasii and N sp1, exclusively invade and replicate in the intestine. The Nemat displere genome diverges from N paras and sp1, with over 10% of its encoded proteins belonging to a species-specific family of R-domain containing proteins of unknown function. These proteins may mediate interactions with the host. The life cycle of Nematere includes pathogen entry, intracellular replication, and exit. This discovery provides a whole-animal model to investigate factors responsible for pathogen growth in different tissue niches.
The Cockayne syndrome complementation group B (CS) protein plays a crucial role in transcription-coupled DNA repair, and mutations in CS are associated with Cockayne syndrome, a disease characterized by premature aging, sun sensitivity, and neurological, and developmental defects. CS is a member of the SWI/SNF ATP-dependent chromatin remodeler family, but its chromatin remodeling activity and its role in DNA repair were unknown. This study demonstrates that CS repositions nucleosomes in an ATP-dependent manner in vitro, and this activity is enhanced by N1-like histone chaper, a new CS-binding partner. Functional analysis of CS domains and derivatives show chromatin remodeling by CS and N1-like chaper is required for transcription-cou DNA repair. Additionally, chromatin remodeling and repair mediated by CS are separable activities. The collaboration between CS and N-like histone chaper adds to understanding of ATP-dependent chromatin remodelers and histone chaper regulation of chromatin structure. This study provides insights into CS chromatin remodeling in transcription-c DNA repair and Cockayne syndrome mechanisms.
Researchers have created a comprehensive map of epigenetic variation in the human genome by identifying clusters of CpG sites with high inter-individual variation, termed Variably Methylated Regions (VMRs), in five purified cell types. VMRs preferentially occur at enhancers and 3' untranslated regions (UTRs). The majority of VMRs have high heritability, but a subset shows low herit, forming co-regulated networks that differ between cell types and are enriched for transcription factor binding sites and biological pathways relevant to each tissue. In T cells, a network of 95 co-regulated VMRs was defined, enriched for genes in T-cell activation; in fibroblasts, a network of 34-regulated VM comprising four HO gene clusters was enriched for growth control; and in neurons, a network of 18 VMRs was enriched for synaptic signaling. Experimentally, genetically-identical fibroblasts were cultured under varying conditions, demonstrating that some VM networks are responsive to environment, with methylation at loci changing in a coordinated fashion dependent on growth. Environmentally-responsive VMs showed strong enrichment for imprinted loci (p<10-80), indicating sensitivity to conditions. This study provides a detailed map of epigenetic variation, showing both genetic and environmental causes underlie variation.
Researchers evaluated the performance of a newly developed Panbio Dengue Early Rapid test, which detects deng virus nonstructural protein 1 (NS1), in combination with a commercial IgM/Ig rapid test for deng diagnosis. The study included 198 laboratory-confirmed positive and 100 negative samples from Vietnam and 263 positive and 30 samples from Malaysia. In Vietnam, the test sensitivity and specificity were 69.2% (95% CI 62.8 to 75.6) and 96% (95 CI 92.2 to 98.8), respectively. In Malaysia, performance was similar with 68.9% sensitivity (95 CI 61.8 to 76.1) and 96.7 specificity ( CI 82.8 to 99.9) compared to RT-PCR. Combining the Deng Early test with Ig/Ig test increased sensitivity to 93%. The tests were compared at each day post-illness, showing differentiation between antigen and antibody markers. This study demonstrates that using deng NS antigen in combination with anti-protein IgM and IgG serology increases sensitivity of acuteeng diagnosis, extends detection window to early samples, and enhances utility of rapid immunochatographic testing foreng.
Researchers have developed a new computational method, Trans, to predict the conserved helices of functional RNA structures, including transient, pseudo-knotted and alternative structures. Current RNA prediction methods assume a unique functional structure and do not account for features required for folding in vivo. To understand how RNA structures form in vivo, sophisticated or reliable methods are needed. There are few experimentally validated RNA structures, and existing computational programs predict co-transcriptional folding, but make simplifying assumptions and do not capture all influences on RNA folding. The method investigates if evolutionarily related genes fold similarly in vivo. Trans detects conserved helices of statistical significance and evaluates comprehensively. It predicts features of reference structures, including pseudo-kotted and alternative configurations, and identifies unstructured subsequences bound by molecules, providing evidence for new helices defining folding pathways. This supports that homous sequence not only assumes similar RNA structure but also folds similarly. Predicted features differ from thermodynamic equilibrium methods, unlike existing folding pathways. Trans works in a comparative way, not predicting function over time, but highlighting conserved features and not requiring cellular environment knowledge.
Plant immunity is a crucial for protecting plants from pathogenic microbes. The Arabidopsis immune network, which controls inducible immunity, must function effectively even when its components are targeted by pathogen effectors. To achieve this, the network relies on buffering, allowing different parts to compensate for each other's loss. This buffering is based on interactions within the network, which are challenging to study using genetic methods. A reconstitution of the Arabidopsis immune network, which mediates Pattern-Triggered-Immunity, was achieved by disassembling and reassembling it stepwise. This revealed systems-level mechanisms underlying the Arabid transcript response to flagellin-22 (fl22). The mechanisms show widespread interactions among sub-networks, called sectors, in the fl22 transcriptome. Many interactions result in buffering. Regulatory mechanisms show patterns for jasmonate (JA), ethylene (ET), phytoalexin4 (PAD), and salicylate (SA) sectors controlling transcription to fl22. These mechanisms are not detectable by traditional single-gene null-mut analysis. Similar pathogenic perturbations, nullut effects on signaling are buffered by the network.
In Drosophila, the central nervous system develops from a single-layered neuroepithelial sheets through a process of patterning mechanisms that subdivide the uniform epithelia into distinct domains, allowing for increased neuronal diversity in a controlled spatial and temporal manner. The embryonic neuroepith patterning of the optic placode gives rise to the larval eye primord, consisting of two photoreceptor (PR) types: primary and secondary, as well as the opticlobe primord, which develops into prominent ganglia during larval and pupal stages. A genetic network regulates the balance between larval eye and opticlobe precursors, as well as primary and secondary precursors. Proneural factor Aton (A) specifies larval precursors, while orphan receptor Tailless (T) is crucial for opticlobe specification. Hedgehog and Notch signaling act upstream of A and T to coordinate precursor specification in a timely manner. Spatial placement of A and T boundary is required for precise primary and secondary precursor numbers. Notch also controls binary cell fate, acting in a cascade of transcription interactions to define PR subtype.
Human ß-Defensin 1 (hBD) is a ubiquitously expressed endogenous antimicrobial peptide that exhibits distinct activities in its oxidized and reduced forms. Researchers investigated the antimicrobial mechanisms of hBD, discovering a previously unknown net-like structure surrounding bacteria treated with the reduced but not oxidized form of hBD. Transmission electron microscopy revealed a network-like structures surrounding bacteria treated with the reduced form of hBD, but not the oxidized form. A transmigration assay demonstrated that hBD-derived nets capture and inhibit bacterial transmigration, independent of killing. The presence of nets prevented migration of hBD-resistant pathogens and remained stable in human duodenal secretion with high protease amounts. In contrast, cysteine is necessary for net formation. The redox-dependent mechanism serves as an additional action for hBD, differing from net formation by other defensin, such as Paneth-derived human-defin 6 (HD). hBDred and hBDox have distinct antimicrobial profiles and functions, with only the reduced form providing additional protection by entrapping bacteria in extracellular structures preventing invasion.
Lowe syndrome and Dent-2 are genetic disorders caused by mutations in the OCRL gene, which encodes the inositol 5-phosphatase OCRL. Despite understanding the cellular functions of OCRL, the underlying cause of renal tubulopathy in both disorders, characterized by low molecular weight proteinuria, is unknown. Researchers investigated the role of OCRL in endocytosis in the zebraf pronephric tub, a model for mammalian renal tubule. They found that OCRL deficiency causes endocyt defect, coinciding with reduced megalin levels and accumulation in endytic compartments, indicating reduced recycling in endytic pathway. Early endytic compartments and vacuolar endosomes were reduced in sub-apical proneph cells. Cell polarity in proneph tub was unaffected in mutant embryos. OCRL-deficient embryos showed mild ciliogenesis, not accounting for endocyt defect. Catalytic activity of OCRL was required for tubular endyt, and endytic defect rescued by PIPK. Results indicate OCRL required endytic in vivo, supporting hypothesis endytic responsible for tubopathy in Lowe and Dent disease. PIPK revealed as potential target for Lowe and Dent disease treatment.
A cross-sectional survey was conducted in the Kilbero Valley, Tanzania, to investigate the presence and determinants of interepidemic Rift Valley Fever (RVF) transmission in livestock. The study took place approximately four years after the 2007 RV outbreak in Tanzania. Serum samples from 1,680 cattle and sheep were tested for RV virus (RVV) antibodies using ELISA kits, detecting IgM and IgG. Interviews with herd owners provided information on determinants. The overall seroprevalence was 11.3%, with 5.5% in animals born after the 2007 outbreak and 22.7% in present during the outbreak. A linear increase in prevalence was observed in postepid cohorts. Nine ELISA positive samples were also positive for RV IgM antibodies, indicating recent infection. Spatial distribution of serreval showed hotspots. No significant difference in serreval was found between sexes born after the epidemic (6.1% vs 4.6% for females and males, p=0.158), but was significant during the outbreak (26% vs.7.8 for females and males, p<0.001). Animals >15km from the floodplain were more likely to have antibodies than those <5km (OR 1.92, 95%CI 1.04-3.56). Species, breed, herd composition, and grazing practices were not associated with serositivity.
Trypanosoma cruzi, the etiologic agent of Chagas disease, conserves a contractile vacuole complex (CVC) to regulate osmolarity. This obligate intracellular pathogen also relies on surface proteins to invade hosts. Researchers used genetic and biochemical approaches to study VC's contribution to trafficking glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchored proteins to Trypanosoma cruzi's plasma membrane and host invasion. T. cruzi Rab11 (GFP-TR11) localized to VC, while a dominant negative mutant (DN) tagged GFP-TRDN localized to cytosol and epimastigotes were less responsive to hypo-osmotic and hyperosmotic stress. Mutant parasites differentiated into metacyc forms and infected cells. GPI-anch transialase (TTS), mucins 60-200K family, and trypastig small antigen (TSS II) co-localized GFP-TR to VC during intramastigotes to trypastogenesis. Muc 35/50 family co-localized VC during metacgenesis. Parasites GFP-TRDN prevented TS, not other proteins, reaching plasma and were less infect compared wild cells. Incubation mutants exogenous recombin active, not TS, sialic donor before infecting cells partially rescued infectivity trypast.
A Phase III clinical trial was conducted to compare the immunogenicity and safety of a purified chick-embryo rabies vaccine (PCV) administered according to a shortened post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) 4-site/1-week intradermal regimen with the currently recommended 2-site Thai Red Cross (TR) regimen. The study enrolled 443 healthy individuals aged ≥1 year, randomized into four groups to receive intradermal PCV according to one of the two regimens, with or without human rabies immunoglobulin (HR) administration at the first visit in adults. Rabies virus neutralizing (RV) antibody concentrations and percentages of participants with RV concentrations ≥0.5 IU/mL, considered adequate following PEP, were assessed up to day (D) 365 post-vaccination. Noninferiority of the 4-site/1 regimen to the 2/TR regimen was demonstrated at D49, with a lower limit of the 95% confidence interval (CI) for the difference in percentage of participants with RV concentrations >5%. Of 443 participants receiving the 4/1 regimen, 88 received HR; 442 received the 2/TR (88 HR). All achieved adequate RV concentrations by D14. At49, the difference between 4/1 and 2/TR was -1 (95CI: -4-0); noninferiority concluded. RV geometric concentrations 18 IU in 4/ and 12 IU in 2 at D, declined in all. Concentrations were lower with HR administration than without. The regimens had similar safety profiles. Of 15 events in 4/ and 19 in 2, none were vaccination-related. Data suggest the 4/ might alternative current, with benefits efficiency and compliance.
Researchers investigated the dynamic and spatial organization of the salience network (SN), a brain region crucial for detecting and attending to goal-relevant events, using high-resolution fMRI data from the Human Connectome Project and graph-theoretical techniques. The study found that the SN's large-scale dynamics are characterized by several distinct properties: high flexibility in time-vary connectivity with other networks, including the frontopetal network, cingulateopular network, ventral and dorsal attention networks, and spatial variability in functional interactions. The SN maintained high network centrality over time, indicating its role as a hub for facilitating cross-network interactions. Time-vary connectivity profiles of the SN differed from other prefrontal control systems. Temporal flexibility of the SN predicted individual differences in cognitive flexibility. These findings were replicated in a second dataset, demonstrating robustness. The study provides new insights into the SN's functional architecture and its unique ability to facilitate interactions with multiple systems, supporting various cognitive processes in the brain.
The study investigated the role of the SV40 protein VP4 in the release of non-enveloped virus SV40 from host cells. SV40 virions assemble in the nucleus and must be released without being encapsulated by cellular membranes. The process involves the controlled insertion of viral proteins into host membranes, making them permeable to large molecules. VP4 is a late-expressed gene product that corresponds to the time of cell lysis. Water-soluble VP4 was expressed and purified as a GST protein from bacteria. Purified VP efficiently bound and disrupted biological membranes. VP perforated membranes by interacting with the bilayer, demonstrated by flotation assays and release of fluorescent markers into unilamellar vesicles or liposomes. The hydrophobic domain of VP was essential for binding and disruption. VP preferred membranes with lipid composition similar to plasma over nuclear membranes. Phosphatylethanol inhibited membrane activity. Disruption by VP involved formation of ∼3 nm pores in mammalian cells, including permissive SV host.
Researchers have developed a DNA-based vaccine, pcANS, containing the NS1 antigen from the Dengue virus (DENV), which induced protection against DENV in mice. The study aimed to elucidate the role of cellular and humoral responses in this vaccine-induced immunity. pcANS elicited robust anti-NS antibodies and T cell responses, conferring protection against DENV. Passive immunization with anti-NS antibodies provided partial protection against low viral loads, but not high doses. pcANS also activated CD4 and CD8 T cells, with IF-γ production and cytotoxic activity by CD8 T cells, but CD4 cells' contribution to protection was not evident. Depletion of CD4 cells in immunized mice abolished protection. Transfer of CD4 cells with anti-NS serum from vaccinated mice showed similar survival rates to pcANS-immunized mice. The study demonstrates that pcANS-induced immunity requires cooperation between CD4 T cells and humoral immunity.
In Gram-positive bacteria, cell-to-cell communication primarily relies on extracellular signaling peptides that trigger responses through two-component systems or direct binding to cytoplasmic effectors. The latter comprise the RNPP family, including Rgg, Rap, Npr, Prg, and Plc, which regulate processes such as sporulation, conjugation, and virulence. RNPP proteins are targets for new antibacterial agents, characterized by a TPR peptide-binding domain and Rap proteins with an N-terminal H-type DNA-binding domain and transcription activity. This study elucidates the structure-function of ComR, a new RNPP member controlling natural transformation in Streptococcus. Com is activated by pheromone X, the mature form of ComS-inducing peptide. Crystal analysis of Com from Streptoccus thermus with mutational and in vivo assays reveal a molecular mechanism. XIP induces HTH domain release and Com dimerization for DNA binding. This mechanism is conserved and specific to Com orthologs, demonstrating Com is not a Rap but a new RNPP member. Identification of X and Com residues for activation is crucial for antagonistic control among streptocci.
Researchers have successfully characterized the pentameric ligand-gated ion channel ELIC, a member of a family of neurotransmitter receptors, through electrophysiology and X-ray crystallography. The study reveals that ELIC is activated by a class of primary amines, including the neurotransmitter GABA, at high to millimolar concentrations. These ligands bind to a conserved site, evoking currents that desensitize over time. The protein forms cation channels with properties similar to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor, characterized by high single channel conductance and comparably simple behavior.
Researchers have investigated the progression from eczema/atopic dermatitis (AD) to asthma, a process known as the "atopic march". They found that mice with skin-barrier defects develop AD-like inflammation and are susceptible to asthma, similar to humans with AD. Thymic stromal lymphopoietin (TSL) overexpressed by skin keratinocytes drives bronial hyperresponsiveness. In an AD model, mice with keratin-specific deletion of RBP showed high systemic TSL levels and severe asthmatic phenotype after allergen challenge. Elimination of TSL signaling blocked the atopic march, indicating high TSL levels sensitize lung to inflammation. Outbred K-TSLg mice with high TSL developed no skin pathology. Epidermal T was sufficient to trigger atopic, sensitizing lung to allergens without epicutaneous sensitization. The study suggests treating skin-barrier defects and inhibiting systemic TSL may prevent asthma in AD patients.
Researchers have developed an approach that integrates multiple omics data with bioinformatics tools to analyze the genome of Thermotoga marima, a hyperthermophilic bacterium. Whole-genome sequencing, transcription start site (TSS) determination, transcriptome, and proteome profiling data were generated and analyzed with bioinformatics tools to improve gene annotation, elucidate transcription units (TUs), identify putative non-coding RNAs (ncRNAs), and determine promoters and ribosome sites. This analysis revealed distinctive features of T. marima genome compared to other bacteria, including a high number of genes per TU (3.3), paucity of putative ncRNAs (12), and few TUs with multiple TSS (3.7%). Quantitative analysis of promoters and ribosome sites showed increased conservation relative to other bacteria. The 5'UTRs followed an atypical bimodal distribution of "short" 5'UTs (11-17) and "common 5'UTs (26-32). Transcription regulation was limited by lack of intergenic space for most TUs. A fraction of annotated genes were expressed independently of growth and a correlation of mRNA/protein was observed (Pearson r=0.63, p<2.2×10-16-test). These properties are hypothesized to reflect the organism's hypermophilic lifestyle.
A study investigated the influence of contextual information on visual perception, specifically on the perception of a target bar in a display. Observers judged whether a target bar was present at the center of a display, with either with or without contextual bars. Results showed that observers were more likely to perceive a target when context was weak rather than strong. When context perceptually grouped with the target, weak contextual bars biased observers to perceive target relative to no context, whereas high-contrast bars, regardless of grouping, biased to no target. A Bayesian model of visual inference accounted for the data, illustrating context influences perception in two ways: (1) biasing prior belief in target presence according to grouping principles, (2) biasing internal model of likely contrasts caused by target. Data suggest context does not influence perceived contrast despite influence on target presence, implying areas beyond primary cortex responsible for inferences.
Researchers have investigated the paradox of cooperation in the production of costly goods in nature, where cooperation is vulnerable to exploitation by defectors who benefit from the good without contributing. The depletion of the common good can lead to population collapse and destruction of cooperation. However, in a structured population with small size, cooperation is favored due to increased variability in cooperator frequency across locations. Cooperators in co-dominated locations grow more than defectors in def-dominated locations, allowing cooperators to outgrow defectors globally. This raises the possibility that defectors can lead to conditions that rescue cooperation from def-induced destruction. Using an individual-based model of birth, death, migration, and mutation, three mechanisms are demonstrated: 

First, defector-induced collapse leads to occasional cooperator extinction, allowing cooperators to grow. Second, empty locations, either pre-existing or created by defector extinction, favor cooperation as they allow cooperator but not defector migrants to grow. Third, resource limitation induced by defectors selects for adaptive mutations to limitation. These mutations, initially low or continuously generated, favor cooperation by reducing population size. In a structured population, small sizes precipitated by defectors provide a mechanism for cooperation persistence.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa, an opportunistic pathogen, poses a significant challenge to the mucosal barrier, particularly in patients with compromised epithelial barriers. Research has shown that P. aeruginosa interacts with polarized epithelium, adhering predominantly at multicellular junctions, where it attaches to extruded apoptotic or apoptotic bodies. This binding is independent of cell death type, as P. aerugin also binds to necrotic cells. Furthermore, P aerugin is internalized through efferocytosis, a process where epithelial cells engulf and dispose of extruded apoptotic cells. Intracellularly, apoptotic cell debris and P. aerugin inhabit an eocytic phagosome, which acquires lysosomal features and is ultimately killed. The study proposes elimination of P. aerugin through eocytosis as a host defense mechanism. Findings may be relevant to cystic fibrosis, characterized by increased apoptotic cells and ineffective eocytosis.
During Drosophila embryonic development, the gonad is formed from two distinct cell types: Primordial Germ Cells (PGCs) and somatic Gonadal Precursor (SG) cells. PGs form at the posterior of the blastoderm stage and are carried inside the embryo during gastrulation. To reach SG, PGs must traverse the midgut and migrate through meserm. A combination of repulsive and attractive cues from SG guide migration. The hedgehog (hh) pathway, specifically the shifted (sh) gene, plays a crucial role in directing PG migration. sh encodes a secreted protein facilitating long-distance transmission of hh through proteoglycan matrix after release from basolateral membranes of hh-expressing cells in wing disc. sh is expressed in gonadal meserm, loss and gain-of-function experiments show it is required for PG migration. The hmg-dependent isoprenoid biosynthetic pathway generates the PG attractant by SG and other tissues when hmg is ectically expressed. Production of this attract depends on sh and a second hh gene, g1. The PG attractant is linked to hh, as ectopic hmg in nervous system promotes release/transmission of hh from cells into mesermal layer, where hh contacts migrating PGs. Potentiation of hh by hmg depends on cholesterol.
Researchers investigated the effectiveness of a recombinant adenovirus type 5 (Ad5) HIV-1 vaccine in eliciting cytotoxic CD8+ T-cell responses in HIV-negative individuals and chronically infected patients, including long-term non-progressors (LTNP). The study measured granzyme B target activity and HIV-1-infected CD4 T-cell elimination in vaccine recipients and compared to HIV-negative individuals and chronically infected patients, including a group of LTNP. Results showed detectable HIV-specific CD8 T-cell recall responses in vaccinees at a median 331 days post-immunization. The magnitude of responses did not correlate with the number of vaccinations or cytokine-secreting T-cells by ICS assays. However, cytotoxic capacity of CD8 T-cells in vaccine group was significantly less than LTNP but overlapped with progressors. Significantly higher cytotoxic responses were observed in recipients with HLA class I alleles B*27, B57, or B58, associated with immune control HIV replication in chronic infection. These findings suggest HLA I alleles may lead to better outcomes in chronic infection and immunization due to efficient priming HIV-specific CD8 T cytotoxic responses.
Researchers have investigated the relationship between the emergence of shared intentionality and the advancement of cumulative culture in humans. A model was developed to study the co-evolution of intentional behavior and cumulative culture, revealing that rapid technological progress is linked to the emergence of joint intentional behavior. Conversely, in the absence of opportunities for significant technological improvement, the ability to engage in joint behavior is selected against. This suggests a unified mechanism for the emergence of shared intentions and collaborative behavior in humans, as well as a potential cause for species diversity in prevalence of such behavior. The model shows that shared intentionality and cumulative culture co-evolve together, with rapid technological advancements driving joint behavior. In the absence of technological opportunities, joint behavior is selected against. This indicates that shared intentions and collaborative behavior are linked to technological progress.
Oligoastoteratozoospermia and Infertility in Mice Deficient mi-34/c and mi-449 Loci

Male fertility relies on the production of high-quality, motile spermatozoa in abundance. Alterations in any of these metrics cause oligoastatozoospermia, a leading to human subfertility. Post-meiotic spermatogenesis, including meiotic and terminal spermiogenesis stages, are transcriptionally inert, indicating the importance of post-transcriptional microRNA (miRNA) gene regulation. The expression of the miRNA enzyme Dicer peaks in spermatogenesis and meiosis, with critical functions in spermatogenesis. An expression screen identified two miR loci of the mi-34 family, mi-34 and mi-449, highly expressed in post-meiotic male cells. Reduction of mi-34 in spermatozoa has been associated with reduced fertility in humans. Deletion of mi34 and mi449 resulted in oligoastatoospermia in mice. mi-34/449 deficiency impairs meiotic and terminal stages of sperm maturation. Analysis of mi-34-449- pachene spermatocytes revealed deregulated genes highly enriched for mi- family targets.
Escherichia coli Nle 191 (Ec) has been used therapeutically for over a century, but the determinants of its probiotic properties remain elusive. Ec produces two siderophore-microins (Mcc) responsible for antagonistic activity against other Enterobacteraceae and synthesizes genotoxin colactin encoded by pks island. Colactin is a virulence and putative proarcin compound. To decouple antagonistic activity of Ec from genotoxicity, we demonstrated p-encoded ClP, peptase that activates colact, is required for antagonistic activity of Ec. Analysis of ClP mutants revealed activity linked to transmembrane helices of ClP and periplasm peptase domain, indicating transmembrane domain involved in aspect Mcc biosynthesis or secretion. Single amino substitution in Cl inactivates genotoxic but maintains antagon activity. In vivo salmonelis model, this mutant reduced clinical signs and fecal shedding of Salmonella similarly wild type, whereas ClP mutant neither protected nor outcompeted path. ClP-dependent antibacterial effect observed with E coli strains carry truncated M gene cluster and p island. Siderore-M synthesis required glucosyltransferase IB in salochelin production. This interplay colact, saloch, and biosynthetic pathways suggests genomic islands co-selected played role evolution E coli phyroup B. Co-evolution Ec illustrates fine between pathogenic probiotic activity and need address effectiveness safety probiotics. Decouling antagon from genotoxic by inactivating ClP pease opens safe use Ec.
Cryptococcus neoformans, an opportunistic pathogen responsible for cryptococcal meningitis, causes hundreds of thousands of deaths annually. Glycans, essential for fungal survival and pathogenesis, are synthesized in the secretory pathway, while their precursors, nucleotide sugars, are produced in the cytosol. Nucleotide transporters solve this problem by exchanging nucleotides for nucleosides. The major virulence factor of C. neoans is the anti-phagytic polysaccharide capsule, composed of xylose, a monosacide absent in yeast. U1 and U2 transport UDPxy, a xylose donor, with distinct subcellular localization and kinetic parameters, also transporting UDPgalactose. U1 and U2 are necessary for xylose incorporation into capsule and C. neo disease in mice, but not fungal viability in infection.
Researchers have developed an open-access global database for mapping and surveillance of neglected tropical diseases (NTDs), aiming to support control and elimination efforts. Disease estimates are crucial for targeted interventions and monitoring, but a georeferenced global database for NTDs was lacking. The database was created by systematically searching literature, contacting Ministries of Health, and institutions in schistosiasis-endemic countries for location-specific data, extracting, geferencing, and storing in a MySQL database with a web interface. Initially, it contained over 12,000 geferenced schosomiasis surveys from 35 African countries (http://www.gd.org). It has expanded to a global repository including other NTDs, such as soil-transmitted helminiasis and lemanias. The database offers opportunities for disease modeling, targeting interventions, monitoring, and surveillance, as well as geostatistical analyses of distribution in space and time.
Researchers investigated whether chronic helminth infections exacerbate Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MT) infection in a rat model. Helminths induce a Th2 immune response and immunosuppressive environment, which can suppress Th1 immunity necessary for MT control. Studies were conducted in cotton rats, a natural host for Litomoides sigmodis and model for MT. Immunological, histological, and mycobacterial cultures were assessed two months after MT challenge in rats with and without L sigmodis infection. Sple cell proliferation and interferon gamma response to purified derivative were similar between coinfected and MT-only animals. Contrary to hypothesis, MT loads and lung granuloma size were not increased in coinf animals. These findings suggest filaria do not exacerbate MT in cotton model.
Researchers investigated the function of the DEG/ENa channel pp23 in Drosophila melanogaster, a large family of ion channels involved in responding to environmental cues, mating, feeding, and threats. They found that pp23 is expressed in a subset of sexually dimorphic gustatory chemosensory bristles, distinct from those related to feeding. Disrupting pp23 or inhibiting pp23-expressing neurons did not affect gustatory responses, but blocking pp23 neurons or mutating pp23 delayed and reduced male courtship initiation and intensity. Mutations in pp23 altered male response to female-specific pheromone (7,11)-heptadiene. These findings suggest pp23 and cells play a role in the sensory system determining sexual behavior in Dophila.
Researchers investigated the process of mitochondrial tRNA import in the unicellular green alga Chlamdomonas. Mitochondria from various phyla, including protozoa, fungi, plants, and humans, import tRNAs from the cytosol to ensure proper translation. However, the understanding of this process is incomplete, and questions about its regulation remain unanswered. A correlation was found between mitochondrial codon usage and the amount of imported tRN in Chlamdomonas. This led to the hypothesis that tRNA import might adapt to the mitochondrial genome. To test this, the Chlamdomas mitochondrial genome was modified with mutations to alter cod usage. Results showed that cod modification reduced translation levels and subsequent respiratory complex activities, linked to limited tRNA pool in mitochondria. This indicates tRNA import is not rapidly regulated in response to genetic changes, suggesting it is not a dynamic process. Instead, steady-state tRNA levels result from co-evolution between import mechanism and translation machinery requirements.
Researchers have identified new patterns of glucose dysregulation in individuals with diabetes and prediabetes using continuous glucose monitoring (CG). Current methods for quantifying glucose dysregulation are limited by relying on single-point measurements or average measures of overall glycemia, neglecting glucose dynamics. The study used CG to evaluate frequency, types, and patterns of postprand glucose elevations between individuals given identical nutrient challenges. Insulin resistance measurements highlighted variable physiology underlying glycemia between individuals. An analytical framework grouped individuals into specific glycemic patterns, called "glucotypes," revealing heterogeneity within traditional glucose regulation categories. Individuals considered normoglyc by standard measures exhibited high variability with CG, with glucose levels reaching predabetic and diabetic ranges 15% and 2% of the time, respectively. Glucose dysulation, characterized by CG, is more prevalent and heterogeneous than thought, affecting normlyc individuals. Specific glyc responses reflect underlying physiology. Interindividual variability in responses to standardized meals highlights glucose regulation's personal nature. Phenotyping developed a model for glucose dysulation mechanisms and a web tool for visualizing user-uploaded CG, classifying individual patterns into glucotypes.
Researchers have investigated the role of the Raf-like MAP kinase kinase (MAPK) EDR1 in regulating plant defense responses and cell death in Arabidopsis. They found that EDR1 negatively regulates the MK4/MK5-PK/MP6 kinase cascade, a key component of the mitogen-activated protein (MAP) kinase signaling pathway involved in plant defense. EDR physically interacts with MK4 and MK5, and this interaction requires the N-terminal domain of E1. This interaction leads to a decrease in MK4/M5 protein levels and reduced MP3/6 kinase activity in ed1 mutants compared to wild-type plants. Furthermore, ed1 mutants exhibit increased MP3/6 kinase activity and protein levels. Overexpression of MK4 or MK5 rescues ed1 resistance to mildew-induced cell death, while mutations in mp3, m4, and m5 suppress ed1-mediated resistance. These findings indicate that E1 associates with MK4/M5 and negatively regulates the MAP cascade to modulate plant innate immunity.
Researchers have developed a computational framework based on Gaussian processes to predict the spatiotemporal dynamics of infectious diseases, with a focus on Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever in Turkey between 2004-2015. The framework leverages the structure of similarity matrices to achieve an efficient implementation. In comparison with standard machine learning algorithms, random forests and boosted trees, the Gaussian process outperformed under temporal, spatial, and spatiemporal prediction scenarios. The study demonstrates the potential of the framework to inform public health policy decisions.
Rift Valley Fever (RV) is a mosquito-borne zoonotic disease prevalent in Africa and the Middle East, causing significant human deaths and economic losses due to high mortality rates among infected livestock. Outbreaks of RV are sporadic and influenced by seasonal and socioeconomic factors. A three-patch model was developed to investigate RVV transmission dynamics among ruminants with spatial movements. Findings indicate that in Northeast Africa, human activities associated with Eid al-Adha festival, combined with climatic factors such as rainfall and hydrological variations, contribute to disease transmission and dispersal. Sporadic outbreaks occur when two events coincide: 1) livestock influx into high-risk areas for RV due to festival demand and 2) abundant mosquitoes. These factors impact severity of RV outbreaks. Numerical results show disease dynamics over short and long periods, particularly during festival time. Patterns of outbreaks in each patch influenced by festival and seasonal factors: number of imported livestock, animal transportation speed between patches, and death from sacrifices. Simulations demonstrate increased risk of outbreaks when festival starts earlier than usual, particularly in patch where ceremony held.
In Azerbaijan, the incidence of human anthrax underwent significant changes from 1984 to 2010. An analysis of data on livestock outbreaks, vaccination efforts, and human anthrax cases during the Soviet and post-Sov governance periods revealed a notable shift in the spatio-temporal distribution of the disease. From 1984 to 1995, the annual incidence rate increased by 11.95%, followed by a decline of 35.24% after the initiation of preemptive livestock vaccination in 1996. Spatial analysis indicated geographic variation in reporting, with cases concentrated in the west initially and shifting eastward over time. The dissolution of the Soviet Union led to marked changes in the distribution of human anthrax in Azerbaijan. Despite decreased incidence, continued control measures in livestock are necessary to mitigate its occurrence.
Researchers have investigated the interaction between polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) and the Shaker voltage-gated potassium (KV) channel, a protein that regulates potassium ion flow across the cell membrane in response to changes in electrical potential. PUFAs have been shown to modulate the channel's voltage sensitivity, offering potential treatment for refractory epilepsy through a ketogenic diet. However, the exact mechanism of PUFA interaction with the channel remains unclear. This study used molecular dynamics simulations to examine the interaction between the Shaker channel in open and closed states and a PU-rich lipid bilayer. Results indicate a putative PU binding site in the open state at the protein-lip interface near the extracellular S3 and S4 helices of the voltage sensor domain. The PU tail interacts with non-specific hydrophobic interactions in the proteinip core, while the carboxyl head interacts with polar/charged residues at the extracellular S and S helices, including the S-S linker. In contrast, saturated fatty acids showed increased conformational flexibility in polyunsaturated tails compared to saturated chains, explaining specificity of PU action on channels.
Researchers have developed a pipeline to screen for anti-parasitic agents targeting Cryptosporidium parv's inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase (IMPDH). Cryptosporium parv causes significant disease in children in developing countries and severe enteritis in AIDS patients, with limited treatment options. The parasite's intractability has hindered drug development. Genome sequencing identified potential targets, including IMPDH, but testing has been challenging. A genetically engineered Toxoplas gondii was used as a model for C. parum infection to validate the first screen, providing a larger window than possible with C. par assays. A fluorescence-based host proliferation and C. par growth assay with automated imaging was established for throughput. The pipeline was used to evaluate C. par IMP inhibitors, identifying 1,2,3-triazole ethers with selectivity in T. gondii and anti-parasitic activity.
A genome-wide association study was conducted to investigate the genetic factors influencing tooth development in humans. Tooth development is a complex process linked to growth and development of the craniofacial complex, and abnormalities are common, with tooth agenesis being the most frequent anomaly. The study analyzed data from 4,564 individuals from the Northern Finland Birth Cohort (NF1966) and 1,518 from the Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children (ALSPC). Five loci associated with tooth eruption time and number at one year were identified at a significance level of P<5×10−8, and five at a suggestive level of P<5×10−6. The identified loci included genes related to tooth and organ development, such as KCNJ, DA, HOXB, RADL, IGF, HM, and MS. Four of the identified genes are implicated in cancer development. A variant in the HO gene was associated with occlusion defects requiring orthodontic treatment by age 31.
Researchers created two mouse models, Ts3Y and MsY, to study the effects of partial trisomy and monomy of the Hspa-App region on chromosome 21, which is associated with Down syndrome. TsY has a tandem duplication, while MsY has a deletion of the Hspa-App interval. The study found that trisomy and monomy of this region affect locomotion, muscle strength, and balance. Gene expression in skeletal muscles was altered, with changes in energetic metabolism, mitochondrial activity, and biogenesis. Genes were downregulated in TsY and upregulated in Ms. Shift in muscle metabolism correlated with change in mitochondrial proliferation, but not respiratory function. Mitochondrial ROS production decreased in MsY, while membrane permeability increased in Ts. The Hspa-App region controls metabolic and mitochondrial phenotypes in muscles due to changes in Gabpa, N1, and Atpj. Results indicate copy variation in Hspa-App impacts locomotor activity by altering muscle function.
A quantitative model of the GIRK1 channel reveals that basal and evoked activities are controlled by unequal stoichiometry of α and β subunits. GIRK channels, activated by β subunits from Gi/o proteins, regulate heartbeat and neuronal excitability and plasticity. Both neurotransmitter-evoked (evoked) and neurotransmitter-independent basal (bas) GIR activities are physiologically important, but mechanisms of bas and evoked are unclear. A quantitative model of GIR1 function was developed to unveil underlying mechanisms. Single-channel and macroscopic GIR1 currents and surface densities of GIR and β were characterized in Xenopus oocytes. The model accurately recapitulates bas and evoked in Xenopus, HEK cells and hippocampal neurons; predicts dose-dependent activation of GIR by coexpressed β and accounts for inverse bas-ev correlation. Modeling indicates 3-4 β dimers are available for each GIR channel, while G decreases from 2 to less than 1 per GIR as density increases. The persistent β/channel but not α ratio supports association of GIR with β, consistent with recruitment of β but not α by GIR to the surface. A stoichiometry of 4 β but only 1 α per GIR channel is suggested. The unequal association of GIR with subunits and cooperative gating by β underlie complex basal and agon-evoked activities, allowing GIR to act as bidirectional detector of β and α.
Researchers have developed a novel computational model, PredTALE, to predict the targets of transcription activator-like effectors (TALEs) secreted by plant-pathogenic Xanthomonas bacteria. TALEs are transcriptional activators that support bacterial virulence by binding to specific DNA sequences in host cells. Each TALE has a modular DNA-binding domain composed of tandem repeats with variable di-residues (RVDs) that determine target specificity by binding to contiguous nucleotides. The PredTA model accounts for recent findings on TALE targeting, including frame-shift by aberrant repeat lengths and flexible target orientation relative to transcription start sites. It also considers dependencies between adjacent RVD positions. Parameters were learned from quantitative data generated over the years. The model was benchmarked using RNA-seq data from Xanthas infection in rice, showing improved performance compared to previous approaches. PredTA predicted novel putative virulence targets, but also identified orphan TALEs not predicted by other tools. Orphan TALEs may be due to incomplete annotations, suggesting promoter-wide genome scans for boxes. Promoter-wide scans recovered known targets, but combined with RNA-seq detected putative independent of existing annotations.
Researchers have identified 24,189 non-synonymous amino acid changes in the human mitochondrial genome, but only a small subset has been functionally evaluated, while the majority's pathogenicity was assessed in-sil by software. These tools showed incongruent results, prompting the development of APOEE, a machine-learning algorithm that outperforms existing methods in estimating mitochondrial non-syn genome harmfulness. APOEE was trained on a manually curated set of variants and evaluated on a test set, demonstrating its ability to accurately predict pathogenicity.
Dengue virus (DENV) nonstructural protein 1 (NS1) plays a crucial role in the development of thrombocytopenia and hemorrhage during DENV infection. Thrombocytopenia is a characteristic of both mild and severe DENV disease and correlates with disease severity. Previous studies have shown that DENV NS1 can stimulate immune cells via Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4) and cause endothelial leakage. This study investigated whether DENV NS can directly induce platelet activation and thrombocytopenia. DENV, but not Zika virus culture supernatant, induced P-selectin expression and phosphatidserine (PS) in human platelets, which was abolished when NS1 was depleted. Recombinant NS from all four DENV serotypes showed similar effects, blocked by anti-NS F(ab)2, anti-TLR antibody, TLR antagonist (Rhodobacteroid lipopolysaccharide, LPS), and TLR inhibitor (AK242), but not polymyxin (LPS inhibitor). DENV NS activated platelets promoted adenosine diphosphate (ADP)-induced platelet aggregation, plate adhesion to endothelial cells, and phagocytosis by macrophages. DENV-induced thromocytopenia and hemorrhage were attenuated in TLR knockout and wild-type mice when NS was depleted from DENV.
Researchers conducted a mathematical analysis of the dynamic control mechanisms regulating blood pressure and volume homeostasis, focusing on the arginine vasopressin (AV), atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP), and renin-angiotensin-aldosterone (RA) systems. The study revealed two distinct regulatory mechanisms: one affecting blood pressure through vasoconstriction and the other through blood volume regulation. Both systems consist of negative feedback loops with a single equilibrium that can be stable or lead to oscillatory instability. A subsystem involving ANP and AV stimulation of vascular smooth muscle is a candidate for a monotone system with multiple feedback, showing oscillatory potential when all feedback delays are comparable.
Fibrin Networks Regulate Protein Transport during Thrombus Development

Thromboembolic disease is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Researchers have been investigating mechanisms to stop thrombus growth. This study identifies a novel mechanism related to thrombus formation, specifically protein transport through fibrin, a component of thrombus. Experiments and simulations showed that network permeability and diffusivity are key factors in protein transport through fibrin. In vivo studies in mice, non-occluding thrombi were covered by fibrin (fibr cap). Simulations using microfluid devices, accounting fibr cap permeability, demonstrated thrombin inside throm was washed through fibr network, limiting platelet exposure on throm surface throm. Fibr cap restricted platelet approach to throm core, limiting plate activation and throm growth. Fibr cap prevents small throm in 600 km vessels from developing into life-threatening events.
Researchers investigated the role of invariant natural killer T (iKT) cells in controlling Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection. They found that iKT cells are activated during infection, but their ability to limit microbial growth was previously unknown. The study showed that iKT activation, measured by CD25 upregulation and IFγ production, was primarily driven by IL-12 and IL-18 when co-cultured with infected macrophages. However, iKT control of M growth was CD1-dependent and did not require IL-12, IL-18, or IFγ. This indicates that conventional activation markers do not correlate with iKT effector function during M infection. iKT control of M replication was also independent of TNF and cell-mediated cytotoxicity. A novel mediator of iKT antimicrobial activity was identified: granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF). iKT produced GMF in vitro and in vivo in a CD1-dependent manner during M infection, and GMF was necessary and sufficient to control M growth. GMF is a novel iKT antimicrobial effector function and may play a role in cell immunity against M.
Candida albicans, an opportunistic fungal pathogen, is a common component of the human intestinal flora. To understand its colonization, researchers studied genes expressed by the fungus within the host. The EF1 gene, encoding a putative transcription factor, was highly expressed during C. albicans growth in the intestinal tract. Unexpectedly, an ef1 mutant exhibited increased colonization of the murine intestinal tract, a model of commensal colonization, whereas EF1 overexpressing strain reduced colonization of the intestinal and oral cavity of athymic mice, modeling mucosal candidiasis. When inoculated into the bloodstream, both ef1 and EF1 overexpress strains caused lethal infections. In contrast, mutants attenuated in virulence following intravenous inoculation exhibited normal intestinal colonization levels. Expression of several genes dependent on EF1 during laboratory growth was observed, but E1-independent expression during murine intestinal growth. Results show EF1 regulated colonizing level, favoring commensalism over candidias. Different genes required different niches and pathways regulating expression during host colonization differ from characterized laboratory growth.
Immunization with irradiated sporozoites is the most effective strategy against malaria liver stages, but the mechanisms behind its success are unknown. Researchers investigated the role of antigen presentation in CD8+ T cell responses against malaria liver parasites. Using TCR transgenic cells specific for the circumsporozoite protein, a vaccine candidate, they found sporozoite antigen persisted for 8 weeks after immunization, despite irradiated sporites' inability to replicate or differentiate beyond liver stages. Antigen was detected in lymphoid organs, dependent on CD11+ cells. Prolong antigen presentation enhanced CD8 T response in several ways: reduced primed cells' exposure time in vivo reduced memory population size, fully developed cells expanded in immunized mice but not transferred naïve, and antigen primed naïve cells, including thymic emigrants, to become effector cells eliminating parasites in liver. Optimal CD8 immunity against malaria liver stages requires prolonged sporite antigen presentation.
Researchers investigated the potential of polymyxin B (B) as a treatment for leishmaniasis, a disease caused by Leishmania amazonensis, by encapsulating it in biodegradable nanocarriers (PBCPs) to enhance its internalization in infected macrophages. PBCPs were fabricated through anionic polymerization and characterized by Dynamic Light Scattering (size, ζ-potential, Nanoparticle Analysis (size/concentration, vertical cell release rate, drug incorporation, and indirect protein determination, and in vitro viability. Nanoparticles coated with polymyxin B (PBC-pol) had a size of 261.5 ± 25.9 nm, low polydispersity index (PDI) of 1.79 ± 0.17, and were stable for 45 days. The drug release from PBC-pol was 6-7 times slower than free polymyx B, favoring a prolonged release profile. In vitro, polymyx B alone reduced amastigote infection in macrophages at 10 μg/mL, but not eliminating parasites at higher concentrations, limiting its application as adjuvant leishicidal therapy or antimicrobial coating. The nanocar PBC also showed leishicidal effect surpassing polym B activity, but no antimicrobial activity was detected. Polymyx B retained activity against E. coli, Pseudomonas, and Klebsiella, adding antimicrobial properties to nanoparticles. This delivery system demonstrated antileishial and antimicrobial properties for the first time, aiding concomitant prevention/treatment of secondary infections caused by cutaneous L. amazon, preventing disfiguring or disabling lesions.
A cohort study was conducted in Belo Horizonte, Brazil to investigate prognostic factors for death from visceral leishmaniasis (VL). The study analyzed data from the Reportable Disease System-SIN (Brazilian Ministry of Health) on clinical manifestations of the disease from 2002-2009. Due to changes in the SIN platform, two models were created: Model 1 (2002-2009, 111 deaths, 777 patients) and Model 2 (2007-2009, 49,327). Multivariate regression identified variables associated with death in each model. Model 1: weakness (OR 2.9, CI 1.3-6.4), Leishmaniasis-HIV co-infection (2.4, CI 1.2-4.8), and age ≥60 (2.5 CI 1.5-4.3). Model 2: bleeding (3.5 CI 1.2-10.3), other infections (3.2 CI 1.3-7.8), jaundice (10 CI 3.7-27), and age ≥60 (3 CI 1.4-7). A prognostic score was developed using Model 2 variables. Performance was evaluated by sensitivity 71.4, specificity 73.7, PPV 28.9, NPV 94.5, and AUC 75.6.
Plants rely heavily on receptor-like kinases (RLs) for perceiving and integrating external and internal stimuli. The Arabidopsis regulatory leucine-rich RL (L-RL) BAK is involved in hormone responses, innate immunity, and cell control. A novel allele of BAK, bak-1, regulates three BAK-dependent pathways differentially. Innate immunity mediated by BAK-dependent RKs FLS and EFR is severely compromised in bak-1 mutants. However, bak-1 mutants are not impaired in BR or cell control. FLS and E have low kinase activity and cannot phosphorylate BAK in vitro. Kinase activity is dispensable for ligand-induced heteromerization of F or E with BAK in planta. Specific suppression of F and E signaling in bak- is due to B interaction with ligand RK but requires B activity. Our results demonstrate phosphorylation-dependent control plant growth, immunity, and cell by RL BAK, revealing differences in mechanisms underlying ligand RD and non-RK regulation.
Researchers have developed a computational approach to model the heterogeneous response of cancer cells to anticancer treatments. This approach combines time-lapse cell microscopy and flow cytometry data to render the proliferative process through the cell cycle and subsequent generations during treatment. The model describes the functional activity of main pathways causing arrest, repair, and death in each phase. A framework was created to apply different modules in each phase and test at the complexity justified by data. The method was challenged with time-course measures in parallel with flow cytometry and time-lapse microscopy in X-ray treated human ovarian cancer cells, spanning a range of doses. A model of treatment including dose-response effect was built, combining modules with a strategy fitting all data different doses and platforms. The model provided the first complete in silico rendering of cycling following X exposure, providing quantitative measures of dose-dependence G1, S, and G2 checkpoint in generations, reconciling radiation effects and new insights.
Coenzyme Q (Co) is a crucial electron carrier in the mitochondrial respiratory chain, and its deficiency has been linked to various human diseases. The biosynthesis of Co involves polyisopren diphosphate production, requiring enzymes encoded by PD1 and PD2 genes. Homozygous mutations in these genes in humans lead to severe neuromuscular disease and nephrotic syndrome in PD2 deficiency. Research on mice with a missense PD2 mutation (Psskd) reveals a kidney disease attributed to Co biosynthetic defect. Co9 and Co10 levels in kidney homogenates from Psskd mutants are lower than controls. Disease originates in glomerular podocytes, as seen in Podin/Pss knockout mice, but not in tubular epithelium or hepatocyte knockouts. Liver conditional knockout mice have no disease despite undetectable Co levels, impaired respiration, and altered metabolism. Data suggest disease manifestations relate to tissue-specific respiratory capacity, with glomer podocytes most sensitive to PD2 impairment.
Researchers have investigated the relationship between developmental lineages and phenotypic robustness in organisms. Phenotypic robustness is the ability of an organism to maintain its form and function despite environmental and genetic perturbations. Development has been considered a key component of robustness, but the underlying mechanism was unclear. The study focused on determinative developmental lineages of protostomes and deuterostomes, finding that their cellular composition is only modestly affected by cell deaths. Several features of these lineages, including shallowness, topology, early ontogenic appearance of cells, and non-clonality of cell types, contribute to robustness. Simulations of lineage evolution demonstrated that robustness arose as an adaptation to random cell deaths during development. These findings reveal general principles of determinative developmental lineages and a new concept of phenotypic robust, with implications for development and evolution.
Researchers have developed a high-throughput platform for phenomics, called EmbryoPhen, to study embryonic development in aquatic species. The platform consists of an Open Video Microscope (OpenIM) that captures high-resolution videos of embryos under controlled conditions, and Embryo Vision (EmbCV), a Python package that extracts phenomic data on morphological, physiological, and behavioral traits during development. Embryoen was tested in experiments assessing responses to environmental changes in temperature and salinity in two species, the pond snail Radix bica and the amphipod Orchestia gammellus, using over 30,000 images of 600 embryos. The platform can capture functional, temporal, and spatial responses in the earliest life stages of development.
Malaria parasites (Plasium spp.) undergo significant changes in metabolism during their life cycle between mosquito and human hosts, adapting to different nutritional environments. This adaptation involves a shift from glycolytic metabolism in asexual stages to tricarboxylic acid (TCA) metabolism in mosquito stages. Researchers used stable isotope labeling, targeted metabolomics, and reverse genetics to study stage-specific changes in Plasium berghei carbon metabolism and its impact on survival in blood and mosquito stages. Glutamine serves as primary input for T metabolism in both asexual and sexual stages, crucial for gametogenesis. Glutamine catabolysis and key reactions in intermediary metabolism and CoA synthesis are essential for ookin toocyst transition in mosquito.
Researchers have identified a common motif in biological signaling pathways that enables the differentiation between pulsatile and sustained signals in gene regulation, known as the inherent feedforward loop (ILFIL). This motif consists of an input that simultaneously activates an output and an inhibitor of the output. With appropriate parameters, it exhibits temporal adaptation, desensitizing the system to sustained inputs. This property allows for distinguishing between signals with varying temporal profiles. A new study examines the IIL's ability to process oscillatory signals through quantitative modeling. The results show that the system's ability to translate pulsatile dynamics is limited by two constraints: the kinetics of IL components dictate the input range that can be decoded, and a match between network parameters and signal characteristics is required for optimal processing. The study elucidates one mechanism of information processing in natural networks and has implications for designing synthetic circuits for this purpose.
Researchers have developed improved methods for the quantification, propagation, purification, and long-term storage of Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus, a leading cause of serious febrile illness in Southeast Asia. This obligate intracellular bacterium can only be cultured in mammalian cells and requires specific methodologies for propagation and analysis. A clinical isolate of O. tsugamushi was grown in mouse embryonic fibroblast (L) cells, and bacterial growth was measured using an O. tsugushi-specific qPCR assay. Conditions for improved viability and growth were monitored in terms of bacterial number after cultured in mammalian cells. A standardized method for comparing viability of O. tsugushi after purification and propagation under various conditions was established. The study presents a body of data supporting improved techniques for propagation, purification, and storage of the organism. This will be useful for clinical isolation and in vitro biology experiments.
A study investigated the safety and efficacy of the antiparasitic drug praziquel (PQ) in children aged 1-5 years, who are currently excluded from schistosomiasis control programs due to lack of P data in this age group. One hundred and four Zimbabwean children aged 1-5 were treated with P tablets, and side effects were assessed by caregiver questionnaire 24 hours post-treatment. Efficacy was determined 6 weeks post-treatment through schosome counts in urine. Pre-treatment S haobium infection in 1-5 olds was 14.6 eggs/10 ml and prevalence was 21%. Three point eight percent of children reported side effects within 24 hours of P treatment, including stomach ache, loss of appetite, lethargy, and inflammation. P treatment significantly reduced schosome levels in 1-5 olds with an egg reduction rate of 99% and cure rate of 92%. This was comparable to efficacy in 6-10 olds where egg reduction was 96 and cure was 67. P is safe and efficacious in 1-5 olds as in 6-10 olds, the drug of choice for schosomiasis control.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide functional screen in Drosophila to identify genes involved in Ras-driven epithelial tumorigenesis, a process responsible for ~30% of human cancers. The screen revealed multiple evolutionarily conserved pathways controlling Ras-driven tumorigenesis, with human orthologs of fly genes significantly downregulated in thousands of primary tumors, indicating potential prognostic markers for epithelial tumors. Among the top 100 candidate tumor suppressor genes, 80 were validated in secondary Dophila assays, including known and novel genes cooperating with Ras-driven tumenesis. Low expression of confirmed hits correlated with KRAS mutation and poor prognosis in pancreatic cancer. The top candidate, Tetrasin family member T29b, was mechanistically characterized, regulating EGFR signaling, epithelial architecture, and restraining tumor growth and invasion.
Researchers investigated the wtf gene family in Schizosaccharomyces pombe, previously linked to meiotic drivers in wild isolates, and found that wtf13 is a meiotic driver in lab stocks. wtf13 induces spore death in offspring that do not inherit it by producing a diffusible poison and spore-specific antidote. A second wtf gene, wtf-2, arose spontaneously in the lab and encodes an antidote to w13. w-2 does not indiscriminately prevent spore death, instead rescuing only spores that inherit w-2. This allows w-2 to selfishly gain transmission advantage while dampening w13 drive. The study establishes a novel paradigm for meiotic suppressors and provides insight into drive mechanisms and evolution.
Researchers have developed an algorithm to predict gene expression levels in individuals based solely on their genotype data. The algorithm uses training data from a set of individuals to predict gene expression in unseen individuals given their genotype in the genomic vicinity of the gene. Predictions are robust and consistent between training and test sets, even when individuals are from distinct populations. The number of predictable genes is relatively small due to ignoring factors like environmental and sequence variation. However, predictions are robust, indicating the degree of predictability of genes can be known in advance. An extension incorporates different types of genomic annotations to weigh importance of variants, showing higher weights for variants near genes and high GC content improve predictions. Predicted genes have higher expression and variability across individuals, providing insight into characteristics of predictable genes from cis variation.
