A study investigated the competitive interactions between virulent and avir clones of Plasmodium chaudi in immuno-competent and immuno-deficient mice using dynamical based Bayesian inference. The goal was to determine whether suppression of avir clone AS by vir clone AJ was due to clone-specific differences in immune clearance of meroites and parasitised red blood cells (RBCs), loss of meroites and parasised RBCs, RBC preference, R infection rate, burst size, or within-R interference. Mathematical models were parameterised and fitted to experimental data, revealing that only the ratio of background loss of meroites to invasion of mature RBCs was clone-specific. This ratio was the same in single-clone infections but different between clones in mixed infections. The difference was largest in immuno-compet mice and smallest in imm-def mice, explaining why suppression was alleviated in imm-def mice. Suppression occurred early in infection, before peak parasitemia. Results suggest innate immune clearance of meroites is likely mediator of competitive interactions between vir and avir clones. In mixed infections, interaction between clones and innate response induces changes in meroite clearance. This interaction is unknown, but refinement of model with other datasets may reveal it.
Researchers have proposed a new model, Origin-Dependent Inverted-Repeat Amplification (ODIR), to explain the generation of interstitial inverted duplications, a type of copy number variation (CNV) in the genome. This model suggests that replication errors at existing short, interrupted inverted repeats in genomic sequences create an extrachromosomal, autonomously replicating dimer, which integrates into the genome through homologous recombination, resulting in CNV without distal chromosomal loss. To test the feasibility of this model, a combination of in vitro and in vivo approaches were used in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. In vitro experiments showed that lagging and leading strands can be ligated to create closed forks at short inverted repeats, resulting in a hairpin linear duplex that replicates in vivo to form an inverted dimer plasmid. This plasmid integrates into the genome through homolog recombination, creating an inverted triplication. This model can explain human de novo, inverted amplicons with 2:1 mixture of sequences from homologues, a feature of plasm intermediate from one homologue integrating into other prior meiosis.
Researchers have investigated the process of translation initiation in cells infected with the influenza virus. They found that the virus can initiate translation at non-canonical start codons in response to stressful stimuli in mammalian cells. This can lead to the production of novel immune epitopes. The study analyzed the extent of alternate initiation in cells infected with influenza and found that selection against non-canonical initiation at CUG codons in virus lineages adapted to mammalian hosts. Ribosome profiling with lactimidycin was used to experimentally delineate initiation sites in human epithelial cells infected with influenza. Several alternate initiation sites in influenza mRNAs were identified, all occurring at AUG codons downstream of canonical codons. One candidate start site truncates 14 amino acids from N-terminus of N neuraminidase, resulting in loss of cytoplasmic tail and transmembrane domain. Truncated neuraminase is expressed on surface during infection, enzymatically active, and conserved in N1 lineages. No globally higher alternate initiation on host transcripts upon infection or antiviral response detected, but subset induced by antiv response enriched alternate sites.
Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHE) is a bacterial pathogen that causes severe diarrhea and potentially fatal hemolytic uremic syndrome, with no effective treatment or prophylaxis. HE and other enteric pathogens utilize type III secretion system (TSS) to inject virulence effectors into host cells, subverting cell function to promote disease and transmission. However, mechanisms of effector binding to host proteins and disrupting intestinal epithelial cell function are not fully understood. This study identifies E. coli O157:H7 Nle1 and Nle2 as TSS effectors that bind human ribosomal protein 3 (R3), a subunit of nuclear factor kappa-light-enhancer of activated cells (NF-κ) transcription complexes. N1 and N2 co-localize with R3 in cytoplasm, not nuclei. N-terminal of N1 and N2 binds N-terminus R3. N1 and N2 are autophosphorylated Ser/Thr kinases, binding R3 independent of activity. N1 reduces R3 nuclear abundance without affecting p or p65 NF-κ subunits or phosphorylation/abundance inhibitory NF-κ chaper Iα N1 represses R3/NF reporter, not R-independent reporters. In contrast, N2 stimulates R3 and AP reporter. A region N1 (40-45) is responsible for inhibitory activity N toward R3. Deleting N from E. O:H produces hypervulent phenotype in gnotic pig model Shiga toxin E infection. N may disrupt host immune responses binding cofactor host transcriptional complexes.
A novel approach to modeling protein-DNA interactions is presented, focusing on transcription factor (TF) binding to its target DNA site. The traditional position-specific scoring matrix (PSM) model assumes independence between binding positions, but this simplification does not hold in many cases. A feature-based models (FMs) are introduced, a probabilistic method for TF-DNA interactions based on log-linear models, using sequence features to represent binding specificities where each may span multiple positions. The mathematical formulation of the model and an algorithm for learning features from binding data are developed. A discriminative motif finder is devised to discover novel FMs enriched in target sequences compared to background. The approach is evaluated on synthetic and chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) dataset of Harrison et al. High-throughput TFIP data from mouse and human are analyzed, revealing features in binding specificities of mouse and human TFs, with FMs explaining TF binding better than PSMs.
Researchers investigated the regulation of the sympathetic nervous system in humans and chimpanzees, focusing on the adrenergic α2 receptor (AD2) gene, which acts as an inhibitory modulator of the sympathetic nervous system. Knockout mice lacking this gene exhibit physiological and behavioral changes associated with the fight-or-flight response, suggesting its importance in regulating stress response. Domesticated chickens show evidence of positive selection for this gene. The study found lower expression of AD2 in humans and chimpanzees compared to other primates. Three-dimensional chromatin structure analysis revealed a cis-regulatory region with accelerated in humans and chimpanze, with distinct histone marks in rhes macaque but not humanzee, and repressive marks in human brain samples. This region contains neuron-restrictive silencer factor (NRS) motifs with polymorphisms. Genotyping analysis of population data showed both polymorphic alleles fixed in humans and chimpanze but not bonob, while ancestral allele present in macaque. CRISPR/C9 genome editing and reporter assays demonstrated derived nucleotides repress AD2, likely increasing NRS binding. Additionally, signatures of recent selection for lower AD2 expression in humans were detected. The study suggests selective pressure for enhanced sympathetic nervous activity in humans and chimpanze evolution.
Researchers conducted a comparative analysis of gene expression in two independent lineages of C4 photosynthetic plants, Cleome and Zea mays, which diverged 140 million years ago. They developed a new informatics framework to compare gene expression in species lacking reference genomes and identified 3,335 conserved genes in leaf and photosynthetic development. The study found that genes encoding the C cycle are recruited into networks by photosynthesis-related genes. Despite independent origins, both species use homologous transcription factors to induce C photosynthesis and maintain specific gene expression. A core molecular signature associated with leaf photosyn and maturation is shared among angiosperms derived from the common ancestor of monocots and dicots. The analysis reveals insight into molecular convergence of complex phenotypes and parallel evolution of transactors in C photosynthesis. Exploiting natural variation in complex traits can identify regulators. Shared transcription factors in C lineages are targets for engineering C pathway in C crops like rice.
An Ebola virus (EBOV) outbreak occurred in West Africa from 2013-2016, spreading to Europe and North America, infecting several healthcare workers (HCW). Understanding EBO infection patterns in different body compartments is crucial for developing countermeasures and comprehending human-to-human transmission pathways. This study longitudinally explored EBO-specific negative sense RNA (neg-RNA) and positive RNA (posRNA), including replication (intermediate-RNA) and messenger (mRNA) molecules in upper and lower respiratory tracts compared to plasma in a HC infected with EBO in Sierra Leone, hospitalized at the National Institute of Infectious Diseases "Lazz Spallani" (INMI) in Rome, Italy. Results showed persistence of pos-R and negRNAs in longitudinally collected lower respiratory specimens after plasma clearance, suggesting local replication. This study aims to enhance knowledge on EBO features contributing to human-to-human transmissibility and develop effective interventions. Further investigation is needed to understand clinical significance of replication in respiratory tract.
Researchers investigated the attenuation of Machupo virus (MAC) and Junin virus (JUN) using a recombinant chimeric virus (rMAC/Cd1-G) expressing the glycoprotein from the Candid1 (Cd1) strain of JUN. The study aimed to determine the role of different domains of the glycoprotein in attenuation and immunogenicity. A previous study showed that rMAC with a single F1 substitution in the transmembrane domain (TMD) of glycoprotein was attenuated in a murine model, but genetically unstable, and the T mutation alone was not sufficient to fully attenuate JUN. To investigate further, the researchers rescued rMAC expressing the ectodomain glyprotein from Cd1 alone (MC1), the TMD with F1 substitution (MC2), or the T of Cd (3). All rMAC exhibited similar growth in cultured cells. In mice, MC displayed significant reduction in lethality compared to rMAC. MC was detected in brains and spleens of MC-infected mice, associated with tissue inflammation. In contrast, animals survived MC and MC infection without detectable virus in organs, producing neutralizing antibodies against Cd. The study suggests the indispensable role of each glyprotein domain in full attenuation and immunogenicity of r/Cd-G.
Researchers investigated the function of the centromere histone 3 (CH3, also known as CEN-A) in Arabidopsis, a plant species. CH3 is crucial for the proper segregation of sister chromatids during mitosis and meiosis. To understand its functional constraints, a null allele of CH was complemented with various mutant alleles, each introducing a single amino acid change in the histone domain. Many transgenic lines displayed wild-type growth and fertility on self-poll, but exhibited postzygotic death and uniparent inheritance when crossed with wild-type plants. Mutations in the histone domain of CH3 resulted in centere failure, reproducing genome syndromes with chimeric CH3 and CH3 from diverged species. A single point mutation was sufficient to generate haploidy, providing a method for identification of non-transgenic haploids in mutagenized collections. An in silico search identified a point mutation in CH in an Arabidopsis line, A86 within the histone domain. This nongenic line, fertile on selfoll, produced postg death and unarent haplo when crossed wild-type.
Researchers investigated the role of alternative splicing in the differentiation of human embryonic stem cells (hESCs) into cardiac precursors. They modified the H9 hESC line to allow for the selection of pluripotent ESCs by neomycin resistance and cardiac progenitors by puromycin resistance. Microarray data from undifferentiated ESCs and cardiac and neural precursors were used to identify isoforms with cardiac-restricted or common/neural differentiation patterns. Splice events corresponded to cytoskeletal remodeling, RNA splicing, muscle specification, and cell cycle control as well as ser/threonine kinase and helicase genes. Novel changes in protein and microRNA site architecture were predicted to affect function and expression, including isoforms opposing cell arrest in ESCs and promoting signaling and development in cardiac precursors.
Researchers investigated the role of trehalose-6-phosphate phosphatase Ots B (Ots2) in Mycobacterium tuberculosis (M. tuberculosis) as a potential target for antimicrobial therapy. They created a conditional mutant of M. tuberculosis that allowed for the regulated silencing of the oB gene, which encodes the O enzyme responsible for converting trehal-6-phosphate (TP) to trehalose. The study found that oB is essential for the growth of M. tuberculosis in vitro and during the acute phase of infection in mice, but not during the chronic phase. This suggests that M. tuberculosis remodels its trehal metabolism during infection. Blocking oB led to the accumulation of its substrate TP, which is toxic and causes cell self-poison. Blocking TP production in a mutant lacking the other enzyme in the trehal pathway, O, abrogated oB's essentiality. TP accumulation caused the upregulation of over 800 genes, likely due to increased RNA stability and neutralization of ribonuclease activity. A genome-wide screen for synthetic lethal interactions with o identified numerous genes, suggesting potential targets for combination therapies with oB inhibitors to prevent resistance.
Researchers have identified Trypanosoma cruzi proline racemase (TPR) as a potential target for improved chemotherapy against Chagas disease, a life-threatening illness affecting 11-18 million people. Current treatments have limited efficacy and safety profiles. Molecular dynamics simulations revealed conformation changes associated with substrate binding to TPR expose residues eliciting host mitogenic cell response, contributing to parasite persistence and immune evasion. However, standard simulations cannot capture long-time motions relevant to conformation characterization. Accelerated molecular dynamics extended simulation was used to capture large-scale motions of functional relevance. Conservation and fragment analysis identified conformation epitopes near transient binding pockets. Newly identified open TPR conformations and closed-open interconversion mechanism advance understanding of TPR function. This study contributes to rationalization of mitogenic cell response and provides insights for structure-based drug discovery.
Researchers have developed an inducible and reversible genetic system to study gene function in mice. The system, called iKO, enables the target gene to be turned on or off by treating mice with doxycycline. It consists of two genetically modified mouse lines: a knockout (KO) with a doxycycline-dependent transactivator replacing the endogenous gene and a line with doxycine-inducible cDNA of the gene inserted into a tightly regulated (TRE) genomic locus. This locus occurs infrequently in the genome and a method was developed to introduce genes into TRE of mouse embryonic stem (ES) cells by recombinase-mediated insertion. Both KO and TRE lines were engineered for high-throughput, large-scale and cost-effective production of iKO mice. As proof of concept, iKO mice were created in apolipoprotein (ApoE) gene, allowing sensitive and quantitative phenotypic analyses. Results showed reversible Apo transcription, plasma levels, cholesterol, and atherosclerosis progression, and regression. The i system demonstrates stringent regulation and versatility, easily incorporating other techniques and wide applications.
Researchers conducted a study to investigate the genetic response of the placenta to Trypanosoma cruzi infection in a mouse model. They infected C57/Bl6 mice with two different strains of the parasite: K98, a non-lethalotropic strain, and V, isolated from a human case of congenital infection. The study used functional genomics microarray analysis to compare the placentas of infected and uninfected mice. The results showed that the "secretory granule" pathway was downregulated in both infected groups, while "inmate immune response" and "response interferon gamma" pathways were upregulated in V but not K. Gene set enrichment analysis revealed downregulation of metabolic and macromolecular transport processes in infected placentas and opposite regulation of signaling pathways: overpresent in V and downregulated K. The study also found stronger tropism to the placenta by V strain, with detection of parasite DNA and RNA. This study is the first to describe the genetic response of placental environment to T cruz infection in a murine model and suggests a strong parasite-dependent immune response, detrimental to cellular metabolism, which may prevent congenital transmission risk.
Sindbis virus (SINV) polyarthritis, also known as Ockbo disease in Sweden and Pog disease in Finland, has been recognized in northern Europe for approximately 50 years. The virus is primarily found in tropical and subtropical regions, but has been suggested to cause recurring outbreaks in northern Europe. Seven-year cycles of SINV outbreaks have been reported, based on human cases. To identify a more objective outbreak signal, mosquito and SINV prevalence in vectors were evaluated in an endemic area in Sweden. Mosquitoes from the Riveräl floodplains were collected in 2001, 200, and 2002, and assayed for virus on cell culture. Obtained isolates were sequenced, and nucleotide sequences analyzed using Bayesian clade and joining analysis. One SINV strain was found in 200, four in 200, and 15 in 200, with increased infection rates in both enzotic and bridge vectors in 200. Maximum likelihood infection rates were 1.0/1000 in enotic Cx torrentipiens and 0.62/100 in bridge Aedes in 200, compared to 0.9/100 and 0/100 in 200 and 0/100 and 0.32 in 200. Sequence analysis showed all isolates belonged to SINV genotype I (S-I). Genetic analysis revealed four S-I clades maintained in Riveräl floodplains over years. Increased S-I prevalence in vectors constitutes a valuable marker for scrutinizing hypothesized seven-year S-I outbreaks and mechanisms.
In the locust olfactory system, dense, synchronized spike trains of neurons in the antennal lobe (AL) are transformed into a sparse representation in the mushroom body (MB), a region associated with memory. Recordings in vivo from the MB demonstrated highly specific responses to odors in Kenyon cells (KCs). Typically, only a few KCs from the recorded neurons population responded reliably to a specific odor. Different odors induced distinct responses in KCs. A biologically plausible model explored the possibility that plasticity controls synaptic weights to the MB to ensure KC specificity to familiar odors. Plasticity at synapses between AL and MB efficiently regulated tuning to selectively filter AL output and condense to sparse in MB. Activity-driven plasticity drove specificity, reliability, and persistence of odor representations, suggesting plastic role in processing and testable prediction at AL-MB synapses.
The Stockholm Atherosclerosis Gene (ST) study aimed to identify functionally associated genes involved in the development of coronary artery disease (CAD) by analyzing transcriptional profiles of liver, skeletal muscle, and visceral fat tissues from atherosclerotic and unaffected arterial walls of patients undergoing coronary artery bypass surgery. Two-way clustering of 278 transcription profiles resulted in 60 tissue clusters, with 395 genes. Atherosclerotic lesion and visceral fat clusters segregated patients into groups differing in coronary stenosis extent (P=0.008 and P=0.000). Associations with atherosclerosis were validated by carotid atheros expression profiles. One cluster relating caridosis (P=0.04) and 27 genes relating coronaryenosis were confirmed (n=16, P<−27−30). Genes in transendothelial migration leukocytes (TE) pathway were overrepresented in atherosclerosis module (A). In independent cohorts, A was enriched CAD by 1.8-fold (P0.004). Transcription-factor L domain binding 2 (L2) was identified as A regulator, supported by subnetwork, cellular and expression L2, and TE genes in L2-deficient wall. A appears important atherosclerosis development, with L2 merits CAD research.
Researchers have investigated the molecular mechanisms of the circadian clock in the cyanobacterium Synechocystis using genetic studies. They found that the KaiC protein, a central component of the circadian clock in cyanobacteria, is involved in both activating and repressing its own transcription. Over 24 hours, KaiC undergoes different phosphorylation states during the day. The study aimed to determine which phosphorylation state of KaiC promotes KaiC expression and opposes transcriptional activation. A combined transcriptional/translational feedback loop (TT/PT) model was developed, considering four phosphorylation states of Kai and transcriptional/translational feedback. Of 32 tested models, only one two-loop mechanism reproduced experimental observations, including effects of Kai gene knockout or overexpression. Phosphorylated Kai hexamers activate and unphosphorylated Kaiam suppress KaiC transcription. The model suggests that the peak ratio of positive and negative components of Kai expression is key to the two-loop model's response to Kai gene removal or overexpression. Parallels are drawn between the proposed TT/PT model and two-loop structures in the mammalian clock.
Researchers investigated the distribution of HIV-2 reservoirs in central memory CD4 T cells in individuals with attenuated HIV-2 infection. The study included 12 antiretroviral-naive individuals, 6 non-progressors and 6 progress, from the ANRS CO12 cohort. Peripheral blood mononuclear cells were sorted into monocytes and CD4 subsets: naive, central memory (TCM), transitional (TM), and effector memory (TEM). HIV-2 reactivation was tested in 30-day cultures of CD8-depleted PBMC. HIV-2 DNA was quantified by real-time PCR. HIV-2 was undetectable in monocytes from all individuals and quantifiable in TM from 4 individuals (median: 2.25 x 10^6 cells) but in TC from only 1 (1.75 x 10^6). HIV- DNA in PBs (median: 1.94 x 10^6) correlated with TM (r=0.66, p=0.01) but not TC. HIV reactivation was observed in cells from 3 individuals. CCR5 co-receptor was distributed similarly in populations from individuals and donors. TC had lower CX6 transcripts (p=0.002) and higher TR5 (p=0.004) than TM. HIV-2 reservoirs differ from HIV-1 by lack of monocyte infection and limited TC associated with lower CX6 and higher TR5.
A unifying Mechanistic Model of Selective Attention in Spiking Neurons

Researchers have long sought to understand how visual attention affects the activity and selectivity of cortical neurons. A new model, called the Attentional Routing Circuit (ARC), provides a mechanistic description of selective attention processing in the cortex. The model is mathematically implemented at the level of individual spiking neurons, with computations for selective attention mapped to specific neuron types and laminar circuitry. ARC is used to simulate studies of attention in macaques, quantitatively matching several forms of attentional modulation.

ARC demonstrates that shifts of spatial attention cause neurons to exhibit shrinking receptive fields and increased responses without changes in selectivity for non-spatial features. The effect on contrast-response is better explained as response-gain than contrast-gain. Unlike past models, ARC unifies forms of attention modulation, consistent with available data and makes specific predictions.
Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a complex and heritable arrhythmia, with over 35 genes reported to be associated with it, but most identified through small candidate gene studies with limited replication. This study aimed to investigate the contribution of coding variation to AF susceptibility using whole-exome sequencing data from a large community-based sample of 1,734 individuals with AF and 9,423 without AF from the Framingham Heart Study, Cardiovascular Health, Atherosclerosis in Communities, and NHLBI-G Exome Sequencing Project. The sample consisted of individuals aged 59-73 years, with 8,656 (78%) of European ancestry. After adjusting for multiple testing, none of the 99,404 common variants evaluated were significantly associated with AF. A common missense variant in SYN2 (rs3819, p.Pro707Leu, odds ratio 1.27, 95% CI 1.13-1.43, P6x10-5) was the most significantly associated, located at a known AF susceptibility locus and in linkage disequilibrium with a marker from prior analyses. No significant associations were observed between rare variants and AF in gene-based tests. Individuals with AF did not display statistically significant enrichment for common or rare variation in previously implicated AF genes. The study found no associations between coding variants and AF, suggesting large-effect variation is not the predominant mechanism underlying AF. A variant in SYN2 requires further evaluation to determine causality to AF. Large sample sizes or populations enriched for genetic effects may be required to identify biologically meaningful variation underlying AF.
Between 1990 and 2011, a total of 121 human alveolar echinoccosis (AE) cases were detected in Poland, with 83 (68.6%) classified as confirmed, 16 as probable, and 22 as possible. The detection rate of AE increased over the two decades. The average age at diagnosis was 47.7 years, with a male-to-female ratio of 0.86:1. The disease was fatal in 23% of patients, with an average age at death of 54.1 years. Four foci of AE were found, involving 9 patients, and 76 cases were diagnosed in an advanced stage. The liver was the primary location of AE in all cases, with spread to other organs observed in 24.8% of patients. Albendazole was used to treat 94 patients, with 73% undergoing surgery, including 15 liver transplants.
Researchers investigated the molecular mechanism of the zinc-sensing zinc uptake regulator (Zur) protein in Escherichia coli to understand how microorganisms respond to dynamic changes in zinc availability. They solved the structure of zinc-loaded Zur bound to the PnuABC promoter, revealing that the metal-regulatory protein represses gene expression by cooperative binding to adjacent dimers encircling the core of Zur-regulated promoters. Cooperativity in protein-DNA interactions requires a pair of salt bridges between Arg52 and Asp49. Analysis of the protein-DNA interface discovered a new member of the Zur-regulon, plG, which is directly regulated by Zur in a zinc-dependent manner. The plG promoter forms complexes with one or two dimers with less protein-DNA cooperativity than other regul promoters. In vitro-DNA binding affinity varies significantly across four-regul promoters, with a 10,000-fold difference in binding constants. In vivo, the degree of repression parallels this trend, with a 100-fold difference in transcript copy number between wild-type and Δur strains.
Rift Valley fever (RV) is a vector-borne zoonotic disease that causes significant morbidity and mortality in ruminants. In 2008-2009, a RV outbreak affected the whole island of Madagascar, including the Anjoabe district in the highlands. An entomological survey revealed the absence of Aedes among potential RV virus (RVV) vector species in the area, and low mosquito abundance due to unfavorable climatic conditions during winter. No serological nor virological signs of infection were observed in wild mammals, suggesting absence of RVV reservoir. However, three serological virological follow-up in cattle showed RVV circulation. A spatial deterministic metapulation model combined with cattle network was designed to reproduce local conditions using observational data. Three scenarios were analyzed: (i) RVV overwintering via direct transmission between vemic cows, vectors absent during winter, (ii) low vector circulation via residual population without direct transmission, (iii) combination of both. Multi-model inference resulted in incorporating low vector-borne transmission and direct between animals. Predictions satisfactorily reproduced observations, 84% attributed to vector-b transmission, 16 to direct. Results were robust to sensitivity analysis.
The Asian tiger mosquito, Aedes albopictus, is an invasive and aggressive daytime-biting species that poses a significant public health threat in its expanding range. To understand its historical and contemporary movements in the Indo-Pacific region, researchers analyzed 13 microsatellite loci from 911 individuals and mitochondrial COI sequences. Approximate Bayesian computation (ABC) was used to test competing invasion routes of Ae. albictus within the Southeast Asian-Australian region. Results indicate Ae. albict was introduced to New Guinea via mainland Asia, colonizing the Solomon Islands via Papua New Guinea or Asia. The incursion into northern Australia's Torres Strait was seeded from Indonesia. A recently colonized population in the Torres Islands shows rapid genetic changes, possibly due to drift or a secondary invasion from an unknown source. High genetic structure and gene flow exist between geographically distant populations, driven by human dispersal. The species' structure in the region favors dispersal by human movements. This study expands the species' native range, revealing more spatial structure than previously shown. ABC analysis provides the most probable invasion history in the Australasian region.
In a cross-sectional study conducted in the Mwanza region of North-West Tanzania, researchers investigated the impact of Schistosoma mansoni infection on the quality of life and physical fitness of 572 school-aged children. The prevalence of S. mansoni infection was 58.7% with a mean intensity of 207.3 (95% CI 169.2-245.4) eggs per gram. Most infections were light (56.5%), while 16.4% had heavy infections. Girls had significantly higher mean intensities than boys (247.4 (95% CI 189.2-305.6) vs 153.2 (110.6-195.8); P=0.004. Anemia was present in 30.1% with no sex difference. Stunting and wasting were less than 10% of the population. No association was found between S. mans prevalence or intensities and anthropometry, anemia, or spleen pathology in univar or multivar regression. However, infected children had lower emotional PQL (77.3 (74.5-80.1) than uninfected (82.7 (79.9-85.5); P=0.033) and higher VO2 (51.4 (51.0-51.8) compared to uninf (50.8 (50.3-51.3); P=0.042). In multivar regression, age, S. mans, hemoglobin, and VO max were predictors for emotional PQL, while predictors for VO max were PQL, height, age, and hemoglobin. S mans was not retained in multivar regression on VO max. S mans infection affected emotional quality of life but not physical fitness.
Leptirosis is a zoonotic disease caused by the spiroch Leptira, with wild rodents, including the brown rat (Rattus norvegicus), serving as asymptomatic reservoirs. Experimental studies on Leptira colonization in rats have used intraperitoneal inoculation, but knowledge of rat-rat transmission requires natural inoculation routes, such as mucosal or subcutaneous. This study compared the effects of subcutaneous and mucosal inoculation to intraperitoneal inoculation during Lept infection in adult rats. Infection characteristics were studied using Leptira isolation, serology, and histological analyses. Lept infection was asymptomatic via each inoculation, with similar antibody production regardless of colonization. Renal colonization rates were 8/8, 5/8, and 1/8 for intraper, mucosal, and subaneous inoculation, respectively. Mucosal inoc was more efficient for renal colonization with urinary excretion than subaneous, and induced slower infection than intraper.
Researchers have identified a novel role for Annexin A2 (AnxA) in modulating the inflammatory response during polymicrobial sepsis, a disease characterized by excessive inflammation, tissue injury, and organ dysfunction, and high mortality. AnxA is a multifunctional protein that inhibits pro-inflammatory responses by regulating reactive oxygen species (ROS) and IL-17 signaling. In a cecal ligation and puncture (CLP) sepsis models, An2-/- mice exhibited increased pro-inflammatory cytokines and neutrophil infiltration, but decreased bacterial clearance and survival. An2 deficiency also led to increased ROS and IL-17 levels. Site-directed mutagenesis revealed that cysteine 9 of AnxA is crucial for regulating ROS levels, and ROS is responsible for elevated IL-17 and exaggerated response. Depletion of IL-17 via CRISPR/Cas KO downregulated inflammation and conferred protection against seps in An2/- mice. This study reveals a previously unknown function of AnxA in inflammatory response in polymicrobial seps models via An2-ROS-IL-17 axis, providing insight into the pathophysiology of seps.
Researchers investigated the role of microRNA-155 (miR-155) in the anti-HIV-1 effects of Toll-like receptor (TLR) stimulation in macrophages. Macrophages play a key role in HIV-1 pathogenesis and progression to AIDS. Polyinosine-polycidylic acid (poly I:C) and lipopolysaccharide (LPS), ligands for TLR3 and TLR4, respectively, are known to decrease HIV-1 infection in monocyte-derived macrophages (MDMs). The study found that poly I:C and L-stimulation of MDs abrogated infection by CCR5-using macrophageotropic HIV-1 and vesicular stomatitis virus glycoprotein-pseudyped HIV-1 virions, while TLR, TLR or TLR agonists partially reduced infection to varying extent. Suppression of infection did not correlate with differential effects on CD or CCR expression, type interferon induction, or pro-inflammatory cytokine production. Integrated viruses were detected in unstimulated TLR and T9-stimulated cells, but not TLR or T4-stim MDs, suggesting alteration post-entry preintegration events. Microarray analysis and reverse transcription PCR found increased mi-155 levels in MDs upon T4 but not T-stimulation, and mi-155 inhibitor partially restored infectivity in poly I-stimulated MDs. Ectopic mi-155 expression diminished HIV-1 in primary MDs and cell lines. Poly I-stimulation and ectopic mi-155 resulted in accumulation late products and undetectable or low integrated viruses 2TR circles. Reduced mRNA and protein levels several HIV factors involved trafficking/import preintegration (AD, TN, Nup, LED/p) found poly I-stim and mi- transfected MDs, reporter suggested authentic mi- targets.
Plants use daily light-dark cycles to regulate various physiological processes, including growth. In Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings, hypocotyl growth rates peak at different times of day depending on external photoperiod and internal circadian clock. However, interactions between light, circadian clock, and growth-promoting hormone pathways in growth are not well understood. To determine transcriptional component of rhythmic growth, Arabidopsis thaliana seedling transcriptome was analyzed under multiple growth conditions and mutant backgrounds using microarrays. A group of hormone-associated genes are co-expressed when hypocotyl growth is maximal. This correlates with overrepresentation of cis-element CACG in hormone promoters, sufficient to confer diurnal and circadian patterns in vivo. Circadian and light mutants show both internal hormone signaling and external coincidence with darkness are required for wild-type growth. Data suggest circadian controls growth by permissive light hormone levels at proper time.
Researchers have developed a novel approach to control Chagas disease vectors, such as Rhodnius prolix, by genetically modifying the insect microbiota to deliver RNA interference molecules to the gut. They used Escherichia coli HT115(DE3) expressing dsRNA for Rhodni heme-binding protein (RH) and catalase (CAT) to feed nymph and adult triatomine stages. RH is an egg protein and CAT an enzyme expressed in all developmental stages. The RNA interference was systemic and temporal. Concentrations of E. coli 115(DE) above 3.35 × 10^7 CFU produced significant RH and CAT gene knockdown in nymphs and adults. RH expression in the body was reduced by 99% three days after feeding, returning to normal levels 10 days after. CAT expression was reduced 99% and 96 in ovary and midgut, respectively, five after ingestion. Mortality increased 24-30 in first instars fed RH and CAT. Molting rates reduced 100 in first and 80 in third instars fed RH or CAT RNA. Oviposition reduced 43 RH and 84 CAT. Embogenesis arrested 16 RH and 20 of eggs. Feeding 105 CF/mL natural symbion Rhodoccus rhodii express RH-specific RNA reduced RH 89 and oviposition. Modifying insect microbiota induce RNA R prolix may result paratogenic strategy sustainable control.
Fever in pregnant women attending antenatal clinics on the Thaiurmese border was investigated from January 2004 to May 2006. A total of 409 febrile episodes occurred in 5.0% (438) of 117 pregnant women. Malaria was the main cause in 55.5% (227). A cohort of 203 women had detailed investigations and follow-up. Arthrop-borne diseases, ricketial infections, and dengue and zoonotic disease leptpirosis accounted for nearly half of febr illnesses, 47.3 (96). Coinfection was observed in 3.9 (8) of women, mostly malaria and ricketia. Pyonephritis 19.7 (40) was also a common cause of fever. Once malaria pyoneph and respiratory illness were excluded, one-third of remaining febr infections were caused by ricketia or leptpi. Scrub murine typhus was associated with poor outcomes, including stillbirth and low birth weight. One woman died without laboratory confirmation.
Researchers investigated the relationship between maternal age and recombination rates in humans using a panel of 600,000 genotyped markers in 69 French-Canadian pedigrees, revealing recombination events in 195 meioses. They observed general patterns of variation in fine-scale recombination rates previously reported in humans, but found a significant decrease in recombination rates with advancing maternal age, driven by chromosome-specific effects. This effect was localized to the middle of chromosomal arms and subtelomeric regions. The study suggests that recombination protection against non-disjunction becomes less efficient with advancing maternal age, contributing to higher aneuploidy rates in older women. A model reconciles findings with associations between maternal age and recombination in trisomies.
Researchers have developed a novel immunization strategy to induce innate immunity in macrophages in vivo, which provides long-lasting protection against opportunistic infections in individuals with compromised adaptive immune systems. Unlike traditional trained immunity models, this approach generates an innate-like memory phenotype in macrophages that persists for at least 70 days post-immunization and confers complete protection against secondary challenge in the absence of adaptive immune cells. RNA sequencing analysis of IFN-γ-primed macrophages revealed rapid upregulation of IF-γ and STAT1 signaling pathways following secondary challenge. Enhanced cytokine responses were pathogen-specific, dependent on histone methylation and acetylation, and correlated with increased STAT1 binding to promoter regions of genes associated with anti-fungal immunity.
Polycomb repressive complexes (PRCs) play a crucial role in transcriptional regulation and developmental processes in both plants and animals. In Arabidopsis, depletion of different PR components causes both overlapping and unique phenotypic defects. This study investigated the molecular mechanisms determining target specificity and functional diversity of PRs. Quantitative changes of tri-methylation at H3K27 in Arabidopsis mutants of various PR components were compared. CURL LEAF (CL), a major catalytic subunit of PR2, coordinates with members of PR1 in suppression of distinct developmental programs. Expression of flower development genes is repressed in seedlings via non-redund role of CL, associated with LIKE ETCHROMIN PROTEIN1 (LHP). In contrast, expression of embryo development is repressed PR-catalytic subunits AtBMI and AtRING in common with PR-catal enzymes CL or SWINGER (SW). This context-dependent role of CL corresponds with H3me profiles and associated co-occupancy of motifs transcription factors (TFs), including M box and A-related. Different PR members regulate distinct developmental programs and specificity modulated by TFs.
Researchers have investigated the "trigger loop" (TL) of the Saccharomyces cerevisiae RNA polymerase II, a subunit that plays a crucial role in substrate selection, catalysis, and translocation. To achieve this, they quantitatively phenotyped nearly all single variants of the TL at individual residue level. The study revealed three classes of mutants with distinct phenotypes linked to transcription defects or stress, with varying distributions among TL residues. Mutations disrupting the intra-TL hydrophobic pocket, proposed to facilitate substrate-trigger TL folding through destabilization of a catalytically inactive state, showed phenotypes consistent with pocket disruption and increased catalysis. Additionally, allele-specific interactions among TL and TL-proximal domain residues supported the contribution of the funnel and bridge helices (BH) to TL dynamics. This study combines structural and phenotypic data for high-resolution dissection of transcription mechanisms and evolution, and can be applied to other essential yeast proteins.
Researchers investigated the ability of rabies virus (RV) to invade the central nervous system (CNS) through hematogenous spread, in addition to neuronal transport. They infected mice intramuscularly (i.m.) or intravenously (i.v) with dog-associated DOG or silver-haired bat-associated SB RV. Clinical signs of rabies and virus spread were monitored using immunohistochemistry and quantitative reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (qPCR). i.m. infection with both variants caused lethal encephalopathy, while i.v. infection with SB resulted in lethal infection. qPCR showed no differences in virus loads in spinal cord or brain after i.m or i.v infection of SB. Immunohisto analysis revealed i.v administered SB directly infected the brain, with earliest affected regions being hypothalamic nuclei connected by neurosecret fibers to circumventricular neurohypophysis and median eminence. The study suggests hematogenous spread of SB can lead to fatal encephalopathy through retrograde invasion of CNS at neuro interface of hypothalamus-hypysis system. This alternative mode of spread has implications for post-exposure prophylaxis of rab, particularly silver bat-associated RV.
The H1N1 subtype of the influenza A virus has caused significant morbidity and mortality in humans since the 1918 global pandemic and continues to present day. Despite its impact, the evolutionary history of H1N1 is not well understood, particularly regarding the virological basis for notable epidemics of unusual severity in the 1940s and 1950s. A study of 71 complete genome sequences between 1918 and 200 reveals segmental reassortment played a role in the evolution of H1N1 since 1918. An H1 isolate from the 1947 epidemic acquired novel PB2 and HA genes through intra-subtype reassort, which may explain the antigenic evolution of this virus. The 1951 influenza epidemic may have been associated with reassortant H1 viruses. Intra-subtype reassort appears to be a significant process in the evolution and epidemiology of HN1 influenza virus than previously thought.
A computational model of the ventral tegmental (V) circuitry and nicotinic acetylcholine (nACh) receptor function was used to investigate the mechanism of nicotine's reinforcing action. Nicotine stimulates nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nACh) and increases dopamine (DA) output from the ventral tegmental area (V). Two theories exist: direct stimulation of DA cells through ACh activation or inhibition through desensitization of ACh on GABA interneurons. The model shows that αβ2-containing ACh receptors on DA or GABA cells mediate acute nicotine effects. Both in vitro and in vivo data are accounted for, and conditions for direct or inhibition to be the origin of DA increases are predicted. Experiments are proposed to disentangle both mechanisms. Endogenous acetylcholine input crucially determines evoked DA response for both mechanisms. The ventral tegmental area mediates nicotine's acute rewarding properties through acetylcholine dependence.
A randomized, double-blinded phase II trial was conducted in Kabul, Afghanistan from 2004 to 2008 to investigate a novel treatment for anthrocutaneous leishmanias (ACL) caused by Leishmania L. trop infection. The study involved 200 patients with ACL, who were randomly assigned to two groups: one received high-frequency electrocauterization (EC) followed by moist-wound treatment (MWT) with polyacrylate hydrogel, and the other received EC without sodium chlorite (DAC-055). Patients under 5, with facial lesions, pregnancy, or comorbidities were excluded. The primary outcome was time for complete epithelialization. Biops for parasitological and immuno histological analyses were taken before EC, after wound closure, and 6 months later. The mean time for wound closure was 59.1 days in the first group and 54.2 days in the second, with no significant difference (p=0.83). In patients with Leish-positive biops, DAC-055 caused faster epithialization (37.2 vs 58.3 days, p=0.08). Superfections occurred at the same rate (8.8%) in both groups, except for one patient with ulcer (10.2 in the first, 18.5 in the second, p=0.158), confined to cases with high parasite loads after healing. DAC-055 showed lemanicidal effect on amastigotes in vitro. The EC plus M protocol led to rapid closure, lower relapse rate compared to intraional injections.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide RNAi screen in Drosophila S2 cells to identify factors impacting RAS-mediated MAPK activation, leading to the discovery of 101 validated hits, including previously known regulators of the pathway. Epistasis experiments revealed new factors acting at various points along the pathway, including a protein modulating RAF activation and others influencing MEK and MAPK expression. Unexpectedly, most hits worked downstream of ME, specifically affecting MAPK levels, primarily through constitutive splicing. Two representatives of this group were characterized, found to regulate MAPK alternative splicing. This study provides a comprehensive view of factors modulating R/MAP signaling in Dophila, indicating pathway output is not solely reliant on classical events like RAF activation, but also MAP regulation. Additionally, splicing components can impact alternative splicing.
A retrospective study of 498 Cryptococcus neoformans and C. gatt isolates was conducted in Thailand to gain a better understanding of cryptococcosis in the country. The isolates were sourced from clinical, environmental, and veterinary samples, with 485 C. neoans and 13 C. gatt strains analyzed. The majority of strains (68.9%) were from males with a mean age of 37.97 years, with 88.5% of C. neoans and 37.5% C. gatt from HIV patients. URA-RP and M PCR fingerprinting revealed C. neoans type V (94.8%) regardless of source, with types II (2.4%), IV (0.2%), I (0.2%), and II (2.4%) found less frequently. Multilocus Sequence (ML) analysis identified 20 sequence types (ST) in the C. neoans/Catt species, with Thai isolates part of the global population, ST for Catt and ST82, 83, 137, 141, 172, and 173 unique to Thailand. Most Catt isolates were ST=VGb, identical to the virulent Vancouver outbreak, indicating Thailand as a stepping stone for global spread. The study found greater diversity and range of major types amongst Thai cryptococcal isolates than previously reported.
Researchers have investigated the role of transcription factor (TF) variation in the evolution of transcriptional regulatory networks across 12 Drosophila species over 45 million years. They focused on the largest class of metazoan TFs, C2-His2 zinc finger (CH-ZF), and found that a significant fraction of CHF-1-1 orthologs exhibit variations affecting their DNA-binding specificities. Additionally, they identified diverging DNA-contact residues in 44% of shared domains between D melanogaster and other species. These diverging residues, found in 70% of D melanaster CHF genes and 26% of annotated TFs, show evidence of constraint, being conserved across phylogenetic clades and evolving slower than other residues. Variations were rarely found as polymorphisms within D melanaster population, indicating rapid fixation. Predicted specificities of these domains change across phylogen distances, suggesting stepwise evolutionary trajectories for TF divergence. Proteins with conserved CH domains are enriched in developmental functions, while those varying exhibit no enrichments. This study suggests a subset of dynamic and understudied TFs contribute to regulatory variation in Dophila and metazoa.
Researchers have developed serotype-specific PCR assays for Salmonella enterica serotypes Typhi and Paraty A, the causative agents of typhoid and paratyphoid fevers, to accelerate diagnosis and overcome the lack of typing sera and reliance on culture in some cases. The assays' sensitivity and specificity were validated on a large collection of strains representing the targeted serotypes and other bacteria causing similar symptoms. A family of repeated DNA sequences, CRIS (clustered regularly interspaced palindromic repeats), was used as a serotype target. A conventional multiplex PCR and EvaGreen-based real-time singleplex assays were developed for detection and differentiation of serotypes Typhi and Paraty A from cultured isolates. The assays achieved 100% sensitivity and specificity after validation on 188 serotype Typhi and 74 ser Paraty A strains from diverse genetic, geographic, and time origins and 70 strains of frequently encountered in bloodstream infections, including 29 Salmonella serotypes and 42 other species.
Researchers investigated the role of Notch signaling in the differentiation of CD4+ T helper 1 (Th1) cells during infection with Leishmania major, a protozoan parasite. Notch receptors Not1 and Not2 are expressed on CD4 T cells and regulate cell development, but their role in Th1 polarization is unclear. Mice with T-cell specific deletion of Not1, Not2 (Not2CD4) were infected with Leish major and developed unhealing lesions and uncontrolled parasitemia. Susceptibility correlated with impaired IFγ secretion by lymph node CD4 T cells and increased IL-5 and IL-13 cytokines. Mice with single inactivation of Not1 or Not in T cells were resistant to infection and developed a Th1 response, showing CD T cell expression Not or Not is redundant in Th1 differentiation. Notch signaling is required for IFγ secretion by Th cells, independent of CSL/RBPκ, Not major effector. Mice with RBPκ deletion in T cells developed IFγ-secre Th cells, killed parasites and healed lesions. This study demonstrates a crucial role for RBPκ-independent Notch in Th1 differentiation following Leish infection.
A study investigated the relationship between Schistosoma mansoni infection and susceptibility to systemic SHIV C infection in rhesus macaques after mucosal exposure. Individuals living in sub-Saharan Africa represent 10% of the world's population, but 2/3 of all HIV/AIDS cases, suggesting a disproportionate HIV infection rate in the region may be linked to helminthic infections. This study tested the hypothesis that parasite infection increases HIV susceptibility in a relevant in vivo model. Two groups of rhes monkeys, one normal and infected with Schosoma, were challenged intrarectally with decreasing doses of R-tropic clade sim-human immunodeficiency virus SH-C. Systemic infection occurred in parasitized monkeys at viral doses subfect in normal hosts. The 50 animal infectious SH-C dose was 17-fold lower in parasitized compared to controls. Coinfected animals had higher viral loads than controls, as well as viral replication in CD+ central cells.
Researchers have developed a biophysical model to study the effects of acetylcholine (ACh) modulation on neural excitability and its impact on cortical activity patterns. The model consists of Hodgkin-Hux-type neurons with an M-current regulated by ACh, demonstrating three distinct functional regimes: localized, asynchronous, traveling, and synchronous activity patterns. These regimes qualitatively match experimentally observed cortical activity during slow wave sleep (SWS), REM, and waking states. During SWS, traveling patterns occur in the cortex, while in other states, stationary patterns are present. The model shows that regulation of ACh level can account for dynamical changes between regimes. Reduction of A-current magnitude recreates the reduction in spike-frequency adaptation (SFA) and shift in phase response curve (RC) observed in presence of ACh. When SFA is minimal (waking or REM state, high A), patterns are localized and easily pinned by network inhomogeneities. When S is present (decreasing A), traveling activity arise. Further decrease in A leads to high synchrony within waves. The model also shows A level determines network sensitivity to synaptic heterogeneity. These regimes may have functional significance: stationary patterns may encode external input as memory, while traveling could lead to synaptic regularization.
Researchers investigated the impact of mutations in the Toll-like receptor (TLR) pathway on the development of esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC). They analyzed whole-genome sequencing data from 171 EAC patients and found that non-synonymous mutations affected the TLR pathway in 25/171 (14.6%) of tumors (p= 8.7x10-5). TLR mutant cases were associated with more proximal and metastatic disease, suggesting clinical significance. Rare mutations were identified in Barrett's esophagus samples. The findings were validated in an external EAC dataset with non-syn TLR pathway mutations in 33/149 (22.1%) tumors and other tumor microbiomes in the COSMIC database (10,318) including uterine endrioid carcinoma (188/320, 58.8%), cutaneous melanoma (377/988, 38.2%), colorectal adenocarcin (402/151, 26.5%), and stomachocarcin (151/579 26.1%). TLR4 was the most mutated gene with eleven in 10/171 (5.8%) EAC tumors. TLR mutants E439, S570, F703, and R787 had impaired reactivity to lipopolysaccharide with reduced signaling in lucifer reporter assays. The study shows TLR genes are recurrently mutated in EAC and TLR mutations may play a role in disease in a subset of patients.
Researchers investigated the development of taste cells in mice using a combination of in silico and in vivo analyses to understand the molecular regulation of the taste system. They found that taste receptor calcium signaling molecules (TRMs) colocalized within the developing circumvallate papillae (CVP) and used computational analysis to identify a common regulatory network for TRM transcription. Hes1 was identified as a likely regulatory factor and its function examined in vivo. Expression analyses showed that decreased nuclear H1 correlated with type II taste cell markers. After E18, the CVP of H1-/- mutants had 5-fold more TRM-immunactive cells than the CVP of wild-type littermates. The study suggests H1 plays a role in orchestrating taste cell differentiation in developing buds.
Researchers investigated the relationship between ethylene and auxin in regulating root growth in rice seedlings, a monocotyledonous plant differing from dicotyledonous Arabidopsis. They found that transcription activation of OsIL on YUC8 expression and indole-3-pyruvic acid (IPA)-dependent auxin biosynthesis is required for ethylene-inhibited root elongation. Using an inhibitor of YUC activity, which regulates auxin biosynthesis via conversion of IPA to indole-3-acetic acid (IAA), they showed ethylene-inhibited primary root elong is dependent on Y-based auxin biosynthesis. A rice mutant, rein-1, insensitive to ethylene, was identified with Y8RE7 truncated at C-terminus, reducing auxin biosynthesis. Overexpression of YRE7 enhanced ethylene sensitivity in roots. Y7 catalyzed IPA to IAA conversion, C-terminal truncation of Y7 reduced enzymatic activity, indicating Y7 required for IPA-dependent auxin biosynthesis and eth-inhibited elong. Ethylene induced Y7 expression and promoted auxin accumulation in roots. Low IAA concentrations rescued eth response in rein-1, demonstrating eth-in elong depends on IPA-dependent auxin biosynthesis. Genetic studies revealed Y7-mediated auxin biosynthesis functioned downstream OsIL, directly activating Y7 expression.
A nationwide epidemiological study was conducted in Saudi Arabia to investigate the trend of nontuberc mycobacterial (NT) diseases, which are reportedly increasing globally. The study collected 527 isolates over 24 months, identifying species through probe assays and 16S rRNA, 16-23S ITS, rpo, and hsp gene sequencing. Results showed 76.5% of isolates were from Saudi citizens, 34.2% were over 60 years old, and 65.3% were male. 75.1% were pulmonary, with 44.7% clinically significant. 34 NT species, including 17 rare, were identified, with M. simiae (22.6%), M. fortuit (18.1%), and M. absus (17.8%) predominant. M. riyense, a rare species, was found in 27 cases. Rare events like mycobacteremia, abscess, peritonitis, and ascites were caused by M wolii, hatic, duii, and mac respectively. Diabetes (p-0.04) and TB history (p-0.001) were risk factors for NT diseases.
Yeast cells' chronological lifespan is dependent on the accumulation of carbohydrates mediated by Yak1, Mck, and Rim15 kinases. When yeast cells are starved of glucose or other macronutrients, they exit the mitotic cell cycle and acquire characteristics specific to quiescent cells to ensure longevity. Researchers used starvation-specific reporters to screen a yeast library of genes encoding signaling proteins. Apart from previously characterized Rim15, Mck, and Yak1 kinases, the SN1/AMP complex, cell integrity pathway, and cell cycle regulators were necessary for quiescence establishment and lifespan extension. Quies entry requires integration of starvation signals via multiple pathways. Signaling mutants and single, double, and triple mutants of Rim15, Yak1, and Mck correlate with carbohydrate accumulation and cell cycle status. Removal of glycogen and trehalose biosynthetic genes, especially GSY and TPS, abolishes carbohydrate accumulation and reduces lifespan. Overexpression of GSY and T1 or trehalose supplementation ameliorates lifespan defects in Rim15y1 or Rimck mutants. Intracellular reactive oxygen levels are controlled by Yak, Rim, and Mck, and mediate TOR-regulated carbohydrate accumulation and lifespan. Data support metabolic reprogramming to accumulate energy and antioxidant systems coordinated by Yak, Rim, and Mck to ensure quies and lifespan.
Influenza A Virus Hemagglutinin Glycosylation Compensates for Antibody Fitness Escape Costs

Seasonal influenza A and B viruses persist in human populations despite widespread immunity due to rapid antigenic evolution. Understanding the mechanisms of antigenic evolution is crucial for designing durable vaccines and therapeutics. Researchers used primer error-correct viral sequencing to reveal an unexpected role of hemagglutinin (HA) glycosylation in compensating for fitness defects from anti-HA antibody escape. Antibody-free propagation of antigenic escape viruses selected mutations modulated receptor binding through N-glycans addition to the HA globular domain. These findings expand understanding of viral mechanisms maintaining fitness during antigen evolution include glycan addition. High-definition sequencing revealed novel adaptive mechanisms.
Researchers conducted a comprehensive analysis of ventricular myocyte models to investigate the possibility of forward rate dependence, a property of antiarrhythmic drugs that would theoretically overcome reverse dependence on heart rate. They simulated populations of myocytes with varying properties and analyzed results statistically to predict rate-dependent effects on multiple parameters. The study tested 40 parameters in each model and assessed action potential (AP) duration at slow (0.2 Hz) and fast (2 Hz) rates. The analysis identified various forward rate-dependent (FR) ionic perturbations and specific mechanisms, including an increase in L-type calcium current FR accompanied by indirect rate-dependent changes in delayed rectifier potassium current. Comparison across models revealed inward rectifier potassium and sodium-potassium pump as likely targets for FR prolongation. Statistical analysis showed models with minimal rate changes in AP shape have little FR potential, whereas those with large shape changes have considerable FR. This study provides insights into determinants of AP duration dependence and a strategy for designing beneficial antiarrhythmic drugs.
Phenome-Wide Association Studies (PAS) is a method used to investigate whether genetic polymorphisms associated with a phenotype are also associated with other diagnoses. This study developed a new approach to perform PW based on ICD-10 codes and biological results, using a quantitative trait as a criterion. The approach was tested on thiopurine-methyltransferase (TPM) activity in patients treated with thiopur drugs. Two methods were developed for ICD-10 codes: I-10 hierarchy and mapping to existing I-9M PW codes. Eleven biological results were analyzed using discretization algorithms. The methods were applied to patients with TP activity from a clinical warehouse of a French hospital between 200 and 201. Data after initiation of thiur treatment were analyzed and groups compared according to TP level. A total records were analyzed representing I-10 codes and biological results. Results from I-9 PW codes and I-10 codes were concord. Cross-validation with biological results validated I phenotypes. Iron-deficiency anemia and mellitus were associated with high TP activity p and respectively. An original method was developed to perform PW on quantitative using I-10 codes and biological results to identify phenotypes. In pharmacogenomics, PW allows identification of subgroups requiring personalized management.
A systematic review and meta-analysis was conducted to investigate the impact of stem cell transplantation on motor and sensory outcomes in animal models of spinal cord injury (SCI). One hundred and fifty publications using 45 different stem cell preparations met the inclusion criteria, with only one using autologous stem cells. Allogenic stem cell treatment improved motor function by 27.2% (95% CI 25.0-29.3) in 5,628 comparisons and sensory function by 26.3 (95 CI 7.9-44.7) in 473 comparisons. Heterogeneity in sensory outcomes was largely due to stem cell biology. Differentiation, implantation route, and intravenous delivery favored better outcomes. Cell implantation did not improve sensory outcomes in females, but was enhanced by isoflurane anesthesia. A dose-response relationship supported biological plausibility. Motor outcomes showed little effect from stem biology, with heterogeneity due to experimental design and outcome measures. Location, injury method, and immunosuppression impacted outcomes. Reporting bias was higher than in neuroscience, but still suboptimal. Motor studies without blinded outcome assessment overestimated efficacy. Recent preclinical literature suggests stem-cell therapies may offer promise, but internal validity and publication bias likely lower efficacy.
A systematic review and meta-analysis was conducted to assess the patterns and dynamics of soil-transmitted helminth (STH) reinfection after treatment. The review included 154 studies, with 51 providing STH infection rates pre- and post-treatment, and 42 reporting determinants of predisposition to reinfection. The results showed that Ascaris lumbricoid (A. lumic) reinfection prevalence reached 26% (95% CI: 16-43) at 3 months, 68 (95 CI 60-76) at 6 months, and 94 (95 CI 88-100) at 12 months post-treatment. Trichuris trura (T. trura) reinfection prevalence was 36 (95 CI 28-47) at 3, 67 ( CI 42-100) at 6, and 82 ( CI 62-100 at 12 months. Hookworm reinfection was 30 ( CI 26-34 at 3, 55 CI 34-87 at 6, and 57 CI 49 at 12. Prevalence and intensity of reinfection were positively correlated with pre-treatment status. STH reinfections occurred rapidly after treatment, particularly for A. lum and T. tr. The study suggests frequent anthelmint drug administrations are needed to maximize the benefit of preventive chemotherapy.
Researchers investigated the deregulation of metabolic processes in nonalcoholic liver disease (NAFLD) using a novel approach called Minimum Enrichment Analysis (MiA) applied to mouse and human omics data. NAD is a spectrum of diseases ranging from simple steatosis to complex nonal steatohepatitis. Traditional pathway analysis requires predefined maps, which can be biased due to differing annotations and cannot capture complex interactions. MiA generates minimal networks (Mi) from genome-scale metabolic networks (Gs) for any target metabolite, allowing for unbiased analysis. MiA was applied to identify deregulated Mi in NAD phenotypes, such as fatty liver and inflammation in humans and mice, using liver transcriptomics data. Key deregulations were found in cholesteryl ester, cholesterol, and hexadecate synthesis in both humans and mice. Regulators of hydrogen peroxide synthesis differed between humans and mice. Specific MiNs characterized different NAD phenotypes. MiA is applicable to any G and target metabolite, making it flexible for studying metabolism in any disease or organism.
Primacy coding, a method of encoding odor identity by the types of receptors that respond earliest, provides a compact and efficient representation that can be interpreted by the brain. A model simulations and statistical analysis show that the encoded information depends on the number of receptor types in the primacy representation, but not the size of the receptor repertoire. The representation is independent of odor intensity, and the transmitted information is useful for olfactory tasks similar to experimentally measured. Interestingly, a smaller receptor repertoire can be advantageous for discriminating odors. The model suggests overly sensitive receptors can dominate the response, making the array useless, allowing prediction of receptor adaptation to environmental changes. Primacy is more useful than binary or normalized coding, as sparsity of representation is independent of odor statistics, unlike alternatives. This efficient representation is independent of intensity, aiding odor identification in the olfactory cortex.
Researchers investigated the neutralization profiles of broadly neutralizing monoclonal antibodies (bnMA) against HIV, specifically PG9, PG16, PGT, and P152, which have shown unusual non-sigmoid slopes and plateaus at 100% neutralization. The study aimed to determine the extent of non-sigmoid slopes and plateaus 100 for bnMA in general. A panel of 278 pseudoviruses in a CD4 T-cell (87 CCR5 CX4) assay and 117 viruses in TZ-bl assay were used. Results showed that bnMA targeting various epitopes of the spike had neutral profiles at least one that plateaued 90. Across both panels, bnMA targeting V apex of Env and gp were most likely to show neutral curves plateau 100. Conversely, bn targeting high-mann epitopes were less likely to show behavior. CD binding Abs also showed this relatively infrequently. Incomplete neutralization was observed in PBMC-grown virus panel from patient swarms. Five bnMA were compared against 18-virus clones in 293 cells PBs and assayed TZ-bl. Plateaus 90 were seen both types virus with no patterns. Incomplete neutralization and nonigmoid neutral curves possible all bnMA wide viruses assayed cell lines primary cells implications use antibodies therapy vaccine design.
Cancer cells exhibit distinct metabolic traits, including aerobic lactate production from glucose (Warburg effect) and glutamine utilization, along with impaired mitochondrial electron transport. To understand how these rearrangements contribute to cancer cell proliferation, a model of human central metabolism was used for constraint-based simulations. Sampling the feasible space yielded numerous simulated cells with varying glutamine and glucose uptake rates. In a subset of proliferating cells, glucose fermentation to lactate occurred in the presence of oxygen at high glutamine rates, while glucose oxidation decreased and lactate production from glutamine increased. This phenotype emerged when carbon exceeded oxygen's oxidizable amount. Flux Analysis showed this pattern optimizes biomass and ATP production, requiring branched TCA cycle, glutamine reductive carboxylation for lipid and protein production, and redox-controlled reactions. In a K-ras cell line, glutamine metabolic changes were experimentally assessed, validating computational predictions through Flux Balance. Findings provide insight into metabolic reprogramming underlying cancer growth.
Researchers investigated the interactions of the prion protein (Pr) and its mammalian paralogs, Doppel (PrPnd) and Shadoo (Spr), in a cell culture model permissive to prion replication. They found a similar physiological environment for the prion family members in neuroblastoma cells and direct interactions between them. The study also confirmed interactions between Pr and the cell adhesion molecule laminin, Na+/K ATPases, and protein disulfide isomerases (PDI). Experiments showed that Pr interactions with PDIs extend beyond the endoplasmic reticulum and may play a role in PrSc accumulation. A hypothesis was proposed that Pr organizes its environment through binding to adhesion molecules with immunoglobulin-like domains, recognizing oligann-bearing membrane proteins.
During influenza virus infection, a robust type 1 pro-inflammatory cytokine response is typically induced, but type 2 cytokines are also produced. Type 2 cytokines are linked to asthma exacerbation, but may also provide protection. Interleukin-5 (IL-5) is a type 2 cytokine essential for eosinophil maturation and egress from the bone marrow. In a mouse model of influenza infection, IL-5 was released into airways and eosinophils accumulated in lungs, particularly during recovery. The source of IL-5 was group 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC) in lungs. Eosin accumulation after virus clearance was due to rapid expansion of c+ IL-5 producing ILC. IL-5 production by ILC was enhanced with IL-33 receptor subunit ST2 expression. NKT and alveolar macrophages (AM) produced IL-33 enhancing IL-5 from ILC.
Invasive non-typhoidal Salmonella (NT) infections are a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in children and HIV-infected adults in sub-Saharan Africa. However, the epidemiology and clinical manifestations of NT disease in Asia are not well-documented. This study retrospectively identified 102 cases of NT infections in an infectious disease hospital in Southern Vietnam between 2008 and 2013. Clinical records were accessed to evaluate demographic and clinical factors associated with NT infection and identify risk factors with death. Multi-locus typing and antimicrobial susceptibility was performed on organisms. Results showed 71% of NT patients were HIV-infected, 90% were adults, 71 were male, and 33 reported intravenous use. 26/92 (28%) patients with known outcome died, HIV was associated with death (p=0.039). Enteridis Sequence (ST) 11 (48/89) and Typhimium (ST 19,34, 44) (26/23) were most identified serovars. Tyim was common in HIV-infected (p=0.003). Isolates HIV-inf were likely exhibit reduced susceptibility trimethoprim-sulfamox than HIV-negative (p=0.037). NT disease is severe in Vietnam with high mortality. In sub-Saharan, HIV risk death factor, majority burden HIV-inf adult men.
Researchers have developed an artificial neural network (ANN) method to identify viral and phage structural proteins, which are crucial for viral survival and pathogenicity. These proteins are involved in lysogenic conversion, nutrient redistribution, and cell lysis, and their analysis provides insights into viral impact on microbial communities and human health. However, phage ORFs are diverse, with over 70% dissimilar to annotated genes in GenBank. Accurate identification is essential for disease detection, diagnosis, vaccine development, and environmental understanding. Unlike enzymes, structural proteins are challenging to detect from sequence data due to low conservation, few conserved catalytic sites, and limited data. The ANN method uses amino acid frequency to classify viral proteins, achieving high specificity and sensitivity. Adding isoelectric point as a feature improves classification, especially for major and tail proteins. Experimentally validating predictions, several ORFs with no similarities were examined by transmission microscopy, forming structures resembling virions. This ANN is a new tool for identifying phage and prophage proteins undetectable by bioinformatic analysis.
Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSH) is a oncogenic virus with a large genome encoding over 85 proteins, including unique and conserved herpesviral proteins. SH ORF20, a member of the herpesiral UL24 family, has unknown function and role in the viral life cycle. OR20 encodes three uncharacterized isoforms predominantly localized in nuclei and nucleoli. Quantitative affinity purification coupled mass spectrometry (q-APMS) identified OR20 interacting partners, including ribosomal and interferon-stimulated gene (IS) oligenylate synthase-like (OL) protein. Both endogenous and transiently transfected OL co-immoprecipitated OR20, conserved among OR20 isoforms and UL24 homologs in herpesviruses. Characterization OL partners q-MS identified similar interactome OR20. OR20 and OL copurified 40 and 60 ribosomal subunits, coexpressed associated polysomes. OR20 did not affect translation, but enhanced R-I expression endogenous OL IR-dependent IFN-independent manner. OL characterized IS antiviral activity against some viruses, role gammaherpesviruses unknown. OR20 and OL expression induced after reactivation latently infected HuLTSH.219 cells. Intriguingly, OL enhanced KSH infection. During KSH OR20 mutant, OL-dependent infectivity lost.
In a prospective study conducted at the Children's Emergency of Irrua Teaching Hospital in Nigeria, researchers investigated the prevalence of Lassa fever virus disease (LVD) in febrile children with and without convulsions in an endemic area with multiple virus lineages. A total of 913 feile children aged 1-15 years were admitted over a year, of whom 373 (40.9%) had fever, and 108 (29%) presented with convuls. The overall prevalence of LVD was 13/373 (3.5%; 95% CI 1.9, 5.7) in feile admissions, 3/108 (2.8%) in cases and 10/265 (3.8) in controls. The odds ratio of LVD in cases versus controls was 0.73 (95 CI 0.2, 2.7). Vomiting and bleeding were significantly associated with increased prevalence of L. L is an important cause of undifferentiated fever in children in endemic areas, but not significantly associated with convuls fever.
Researchers investigated the role of the karri receptor KAI2 in drought resistance in Arabidopsis thalian, a model organism commonly used to study plant biology. Drought significantly reduces crop yields worldwide, making it essential to identify new factors that regulate drought resistance. Karri (KARs) are butenol compounds found in smoke that promote seed germination and improve seedling growth under stressful conditions. Mutations in the KARRINSENSITIVE2 (KAI) gene, encoding the karri receptor, resulted in hypersensitivity to water deprivation. Transcriptomic, physiological, and biochemical analyses of k2 plants revealed increased water loss and drought-induced membrane damage, enlarged stomatal apertures, and higher cuticular permeability. Additionally, k2 plants had reduced anthocyan biosynthesis during drought and hypersensitivity to abscisic acid (ABA) in stomatal and cotyledon assays. Genome-wide transcript analysis identified genes associated with observed physiological and biochemical changes in k2 under well-water and dehydration conditions. Data suggest crosstalk between ABA and K2-dependent pathways in drought responses. Comparison to strigact receptor d14 (DWAR14) indicated stract also contributes to drought adaptation, but not cuticle development. Findings suggest chemical or genetic manipulation K2 and14 may improve drought resistance.
Researchers have investigated the role of insulin signaling in the growth, development, maturation, and egg production of adult Schistosoma japonicum parasites. They focused on the insulin receptors (SIR) of Schistosoma japonicum, which were previously cloned and partially characterized. The study found that human insulin binds to the L subdomain (insulin binding domain) of recombinant SIR1 and SIR2 (SLD1 and SLD2) produced using the Drosophila S protein system. RNA interference (RNAi) was used to knock down the expression of SIR in adult Schosoma japon in vitro, resulting in reduced transcription levels of downstream genes in the insulin pathway associated with glucose metabolism and schosome fecundity. Additionally, a decrease in glucose uptake was observed in SIR-knockdown worms compared to luciferase controls. In vaccine challenge experiments, rSLD and SLD reduced growth, intestinal granuloma density, and faecal production in Schos japon in mice with low dose infection. These findings emphasize the potential of SIR as vaccine candidates against zoonotic schosomiasis in China and the Philippines.
Lymphatic filariasis (LF) is a significant cause of disability in the Pacific region, affecting over 96% of the 1.7 million population at risk of infection. Mass drug administration (MDA) has reduced lymphatic filariasis prevalence, but vector biology complicates the MDA strategy in some regions. The goal of LF elimination cannot be attained via MDA alone in some areas. Obligate mosquitoes provide additional targets for breaking the LF cycle, but existing methods are ineffective for controlling the primary vector, Aedes aegypti, in the South Pacific. This study demonstrates that interspecific hybridization and introgression results in Aedes aegypt (CP strain) stably infected with endosymbiotic Wolbachia bacteria from Aedesalbopictus. The CP strain is bi-directionally incompatible with naturally infected mosquitoes, resulting in female sterility. Laboratory assays show CP males are equally competitive, leading to population elimination when introduced into wild Aedes aegpt populations.
A study was conducted to quantify the burden of Rhodesian trypanosomiasis (HAT) in Uram District, Tanzania, a highly endemic area for the disease. Data from 143 patients admitted in 2004 for treatment at Kali Health Centre were analyzed. Direct and indirect costs incurred by patients and health services were calculated. Disability-Adjusted Life Years (DALYs) were estimated using methods from the Global Burden Disease Project and previous H estimates, assuming 45% underreporting. The estimated DALYs for AT in Uram with and without weighting were 215.7 (95%CI:155.3-287.5) and 281.6 (95%CI:209.1-362.6) respectively.
