The regulation of the death gene reaper (pr) by the Hox protein Deformed (D) is analyzed, suggesting that activation of pr in the anterior maxillary segment is achieved through a combinatorial interaction of D with at least eight functionally diverse transcriptional regulators on a minimal enhancer. Context-dependent combinations of H proteins and other factors on small H response elements (HRE) may be responsible for spatio-temporal expression of H targets. A large number of factors are likely directly involved in H regulation in vivo.
Plants recognize and respond to pathogen attack through the recognition of pathogen-specific molecules at the cell surface and inside the cell. Pathogen effectors, or virulence factors, are monitored by intracellular nucleotide-binding leucine-rich repeat (NB-LRR) sensor proteins in plants and mammals. This study investigates the genetic requirements for defense responses of an autoactive mutant ADR-L2, an Arabidopsis coiled-coil (CC)-NB-LRR protein ADR-L2 functions upstream of salicylic acid (SA) accumulation in several defense contexts and acts as a "helper" to transduce specific activation from sensor NB-LRs. This activity does not require an intact P-loop. ADR-L2 and two related members are required for unregulated cell death in l1 mutant. ADR-L function is P-dependent in this context. An autoactive mutation A1-LD484 was generated in a homology motif M. ADR-L484 expression leads to dwarf plants with increased resistance and high SA levels. Morphology requires intact P, suggesting A-L484 phenotypes reflect NB activation. A-L484 was used to define requirements. Signaling from A484 does not require NAD oxidase and is regulated by E1 and At1 transcription. Regulation of A484 is correlated with outputs; these are SA-dependent and -independent. Requirements resemble SA-dependent signal amplification and death observed in LSD. Importantly, A484 autoactivation is controlled by E and SA separable but linked.
Researchers have identified two components of the RNA-directed DNA methylation (RdDM) pathway in Arabidopsis, SUVH and ID2, which interact with the protein MOR6 to mediate transcriptional silencing. SUV and ID2 can act in the same pathway as MOR6 or synergistically with MOR6 to silence genes. Additionally, ID2 interacts with MOR6 to silence a subset of MOR6 target loci. Other RDM components, including Pol IV, V, R2, and DRM2, are also required for silencing a subset of MOR6 loci. MOR6 was previously shown to silence genes through heterochrom condensation. The study found that the SWI/SNF chromatin-remodeling complex SW3, SW3, and SWD interact with MOR6 and SUV9, mediating silencing. These results suggest RDM components are involved in methylation and MOR6-mediated heteroch condensation. This study links methylation to heteroch condensation, enhancing silencing at methylated regions.
Heat shock protein 90 (Hsp90) plays a crucial role in modulating phenotypes in vertebrates, including flies and plants, suggesting its capacity to buffer genetic variation. In vertebrates, H90's protective function may account for variable penetrance and severity of heritable developmental malformations. Using zebraf as a model, H90 inhibition did not induce heat shock or perturb phenotype in wild-type strains. However, it increased severity of recessive eye phenotype caused by paxb mutation and decreased severity caused by su mutation. A new spectrum of severe eye malformations, anophthalmia, microphthalm, and nanthalmia, was uncovered by limited H90 inhibition. Inbreeding offspring from unaffected parents led to elevated malformation frequencies, indicating oligogenic nature. Unlike Drosoph, H90 inhibition decreased stability in zraf, shown by asymmetric anophia, microphthalm, nanthalm, and sunrise phenotypes. paxb mutation analysis suggests H90 buffering mechanism. zraf studies imply mild H90 perturbation at developmental stages underlies variable penetrance and express of anomalies where genotype and environment interact.
Researchers have identified and characterized N-terminal acetylated proteins in Drosophila melanogaster. Amino-terminal acetylation is a common post-translational modification where the N-terminus of a nascent polypeptide chain becomes acetylated after the removal of the initiating methion residue. The study analyzed amino-terminal peptides from Drosila K167 cells and detected over 1,200 mature N-termini, revealing that N acylation occurs with similar frequency in insects as in humans. A sole determinant of acylation was identified as the X PX rule, indicating acylation under all circumstances. This rule was used to genetically engineer proteins to study the biological relevance of ac presence or absence of acetyl group, creating an assay to probe functional importance of acylation. The assay was applied by expressing mutated transgenes in cell lines and flies. A strategy was developed to systematically study relevance of acylation in cells and organisms. The PX rule appears to be valid in lower and higher eukaryotes, suggesting it can be used to study acylation in all species.
Researchers investigated the termination mechanism of RNA polymerase III (RNAP III) in Saccharomyces cerevisiae, focusing on its ability to recycle from termination to initiation for abundant tRNA production during cell proliferation and cancer. Two tRNA-mediated systems were used to screen for mutants with gain and loss of termination phenotypes, resulting in 122 point mutations mapped to a 3.9 Å structure of the RN III elongation complex (EC). Mutations clustered in the active bridge helix and loop, pore, and funnel, indicating involvement of the cleavage domain of the C subunit in termination. Purified RN III from a readthrough (RT) mutant exhibited increased elongation rate, supporting a kinetic model where elongation inversely relates to termination efficiency. Mutants showed correlations in vitro and in vivo, and surprisingly, amounts of transcription in vivo. A tRNA reporter with processing defect and strong terminator was used to rule out differences in RNA decay, indicating mutants synthesized more RNA than wild-type cells, exceeding elongation rate. Increased activity was unrelated to RN III repressor M1. Results showed active center elements of III, including C, are termination determinants, and some activating overall transcription. Similar mutations in cancer suggest an unforeseen mechanism III activation in disease.
Researchers have developed a method to predict protein-protein interactions mediated by SH2 domains using the structure of SH-phosphopeptide complexes and the FoldX algorithm. This approach aims to address the limitation of current experiments, which only covering a fraction of all protein interactions. The method was compared to experimentally derived consensus and substitution matrices for known in vitro and in vivo targets of SH domains, showing similar performance. Predictions were made for a set of human SH domains with known secondary structure and phosphorylation state. Validation was done using literature-derived SH interactions and a probabilistic score from naive Bayes integration of coexpression, conservation, interaction in other species, shared partners, and functions. Predictions led to new hypothesis for SH domains role in signaling.
Researchers have identified a protein called cyclophilin 40 (Cy40) that has the ability to dissolve toxic amyloid aggregates, which are a hallmark of neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer's disease. These aggregates are formed when the microtubule associating protein (MAP) tau is abnormally accumulates into toxic oligomers and amyloid deposits. Intrinsically disordered proteins like tau are enriched with proline residues that regulate secondary structure and aggregation. The orientation of proline residues is regulated by cis peptid-proly isomerases (Pases). The study found that Cy40, a Pase, dissolves tau amyloids in vitro. Additionally, Cy40 reduced amyloid-positive oligomeric species in a mouse model of tau accumulation, preserving neuronal health and cognition. Nuclear magnetic resonance (MR) revealed Cy interacts with tau at rich proline sites. Cy40 also interacted and disaggregated other aggregating proteins with prolines. Moreover, Cy40 lacking Pase activity prevented disaggregation in vitro. A unique property of Cy40 permits disaggregation to occur in energy-independent manner.
Researchers have investigated the process of heterocyst differentiation in cyanobacteria filaments, a form of cellular differentiation in multicellular organisms, using a systems biology framework. They formulated a set of differential equations to describe the evolution of molecular concentrations in a single cyanobacter under nitrogen deprivation. This allowed them to study the behavior of a single cyanacter under different conditions and simulate cyanobacteria filaments by coupling their genetic circuits via diffusion. The results showed that including diffusion and external conditions in the model reproduces the formation and sustainment of heteryst patterns in cyanobacteria as observed experimentally. The study aimed to bridge the gap between macroscopic and microscopic processes of heteryst and nitrogen deprivation in cyanacteria. The model was able to capture the essential dynamics of heteryst formation and sustainment in cyanobacteria filaments.
Despite the success of the Community-Directed Ivermect (CDI) program in combating oncherciasis in Africa, the disease remains a significant problem in Cameroon, with prevalence above the transmission threshold in some areas. A study investigated the relationship between people's beliefs and perceptions of onchiasis and their adherence to iverectin in three regions of Cameroon. A cross-sectional survey was conducted in three districts with high onchias prevalence, with 30 participants selected per district. Adherence to iverect was similar in Bang and Bafia (55.0% and 48.8%, respectively) and lower in Yassi (40.7%). Among factors related to program and disease representations, perceptions of the program were most influential on adherence. Those with a negative opinion of iverect distribution were less compliant than those with a positive opinion (40% vs 55 in Bang, 48 vs 62 in Bafia, p 0.01). Negative appreciation of community distributors' commitment also affected adherence (22 vs 53 in Bang, 33 vs 59 Bafia, 27 vs 47 Yassi p 0.01). Misconceptions about onias transmission included lack of hygiene in Bafia and Yassi, while Bang believed onias due to sugar consumption (31 vs 5 in Bafia and Yassi p0.001). Local authorities should focus on education and community involvement to improve adherence.
Researchers investigated the relationship between DNA methylation, genetic variants, and protein biomarkers for various diseases, including cancer and cardiovascular disease. They analyzed DNA methylation data at 470,000 positions and over 10 million SNPs in relation to 121 protein biomarkers in 698-103 samples. Epigenome-wide association study (EWAS) and genome-wide association study (GWAS) analyses were performed, integrating biomarker, DNA methylation, and SNP data. The study identified 124 loci with significant associations, with effect sizes up to 0.22 units per 1% DNA methylation change and 4 units per allele copy in EW and GWAS. Most GW loci were cis-regulatory, while EWAS loci were trans. Eleven EWAS loci associated with multiple biomarkers, including NL5 with CXCL, CX9, IL-12, and IL-18 levels. EWAS signals overlapping with GWAS were driven by genetic variants, while EW signals were confounded by smoking. Cis-regulatory SNPs for biomarkers affected DNA methylation, but not vice versa. The study found associations between biomarkers and DNA methylation at numerous loci, likely reflecting genetic variants, environmental exposures, or disease pathogenesis secondary effects.
Researchers investigated the impact of varicella zoster virus (VZV) on natural killer (NK) cells, which play a crucial role in anti-viral immunity. VV productively infects NK cells, but its effect on NK function was unknown. The study found that VV impairs NK's ability to respond to stimulation in vitro, leading to loss of cytotoxic and cytokine responses. Not only VV-infected NK cells, but also V-negative NK cells exposed to VV in culture were inhibited. This impairment depended on direct contact between NK and VV-infected cells. Profiling NK surface receptors by flow cytometry showed stable expression. Inhibited cells still released cytotoxic granules when stimulation bypassed receptor/ligand interactions and signalling, suggesting V paralysed NK from responding. Examination of degranulation cascade components showed perturbation following VV. In addition to degranulation, IF-γ and TNF production were repressed by VV co-culture, most strongly in V-infected NK. Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) also infects NK in cell-associated manner and renders NK unresponsive to stimulation, but differentially cytokine production compared VV. Findings contribute to understanding pathogen inhibition of NK function and reveal VV immune manipulation strategy.
Apparent motion (AM) is a phenomenon where two stimuli presented at different locations evoke a perception of a stimulus moving between them. The neural basis of AM is thought to be increased activation of primary visual cortex (V1) neurons tuned to locations along the path. However, evidence remains inconclusive. Masking, reduced detectability of stimuli along AM path, has been taken as evidence for V1 activation. AM-induced responses interfere with physical stimuli along path, impairing perception. Masking can also be explained by predictive models, predicting responses match spatio-temporal prediction of stimulus along path.

A study found AM affects target detection, limiting performance at high contrast. Masking strongest when target identical to inducer orientation. A V-like population model of early processing was developed, based on contrast normalization. AM activation in V is too small to cause masking or perceived motion. The model predicts suppression early responses during AM, consistent with predictive coding framework.
Human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 (HTLV-1) oncoprotein Tax plays a crucial role in the transformation of CD4+ T cells by promoting cell proliferation and survival, primarily through the activation of the NF-κB pathway and induction of NF-κ target genes. To understand the underlying mechanism of HTL-1-mediated transformation, it is essential to elucidate the molecular mechanism of Tax-induced IK activation. Previous studies have proposed multiple mechanisms for Tax-induced IK activation due to the blending of primary Tax-induced IK events and secondary IK events induced by cytokines secreted by Tax-induced IK-NF-κ activation. To resolve this, Tax-stimulated IK activation was reconstituted in a cell-free system to dissect the essential components for IK activation by Tax and the underlying biochemical mechanism. Tax was found to be a putative E3 ubiquitin ligase, catalyzing the assembly of mixed-link polyubiquitin chains with Ubc2, Ubc5, or U7. These mixed-link polyubiquitin chains are responsible for IK activation by binding to the NEM subunit of IK. This study reveals the biochemical function of Tax in IK activation, utilizing minimal ubiquitination components for NF-κ activation.
A systematic review of the relationship between propagule pressure and establishment in alien species was conducted using Bayesian meta-analytical methods. The study included a broad range of taxa, including invertebrates, herbaceous plants, long-lived trees, and terrestrial and aquatic vertebrates. A positive effect of propagule pressure on establishment was found in all tested hypotheses. However, establishment was most dependent on propagule pressure in the range of 10-100 individuals. Heterogeneity in effect size was primarily associated with analytical approaches, with evidence of larger effects in animal introductions than plant introductions. No variation was accounted for by study scale (field to global) or methodology (observational, experimental, or proxy) used.
Interleukin-17 (IL-17), a cytokine implicated in chronic and severe inflammatory diseases, enhances the production of pro-inflammatory mediators by attenuating the decay of encoding mRNAs. The degradation of these mRNAs depends on proteins (AUBPs) that target AU-rich elements in the 3'-untranslated region of mRNAs, facilitating either decay or stabilization. A novel ribonucleoprotein complex forms between AUB and microRNA (miR16), leading to target mRNA degradation. Notably, IL-17 attenuates miR16 expression and promotes binding of stabilizing AUB over destabilizing AUB, reducing mRNA decay. This indicates mi16 independently of sequence directs competition between degrading and stabilizing AUB for mRNAs. Approximately 8% of the human transcriptome is affected by AUB expression, and mi16 is ubiquitously expressed. IL-17 may affect additional cellular processes beyond inflammation.
In Uganda, both chronic and acute forms of Human African trypanosomiasis (HAT) are present, with the acute form traditionally confined to the southeast and the chronic to the northwest. However, acute AT has spread to new districts, linked to infected cattle movement. Cattle are long-term reservoirs of human-infective T. rhodesiense, showing few signs of morbidity yet posing significant health risk. This study examined the relationship between T. rhodesense infection in humans and T. brucei in cattle at village level in Kaberido and Dokolo Districts, Uganda. Villages with reported cases of sleeping sickness had higher odds of T. brucei infection than non-case villages (OR:2.94, 95%CI:1.38-6). Cattle age significantly affected likelihood of T brucei infection: 18-36 months (OR:3.51,95:1.63-7) and over 36 (OR:4.20,95:2.08-8) had higher odds than under 18 months. Village sleeping status significantly affected T. rhense detection in cattle, with higher likelihood in case villages (OR:25,95:1.2-520). Higher average T bruce prevalence (>16.3) in herd associated with T. rhense detection (OR:25,95:1-520).
The study investigates the role of the NS complex in regulating housekeeping genes in Drosophila melanogaster. The complex is composed of four members: NS1, NS3, MBD2, and MCR2. ChIP-seq analysis reveals that 85.5% of NS-bound genes are constitutively expressed across cell types. Histone modifications H4ac, H3me2, H3me, and H9 are abundant in promoter regions of NS-targeted genes. These genes have well-defined nucleosome-free regions and broad transcription initiation patterns. ChIP-seq of RNA polymerase II in NS1 and NS3-depleted cells shows both proteins are required for efficient recruitment to NS-target promoters. This coincides with reduced TBP and TFIIB binding, indicating optimal pre-initiation complex recruitment. Genes losing most Pol upon NS knockdown are enriched in Replication Element (RE). The study demonstrates the MO-containing NS complex regulates housekeeping genes by modulating Pol transcription initiation.
Researchers have developed a transgenic mouse model to study facioscapulohumeral dystrophy (FD), a progressive muscular dystrophy caused by epigenetic regulation of the D4 macrosatellite repeat. Individuals with FD generally have more than 10 repeats in the subtelomeric region of chromosome 4, while the most common form FD (FD1) is caused by contraction to fewer than 10 repeats, associated with decreased epigen repression and variegated expression of DUX, a germline transcription factor encoded in the repeat. The transgenic mice carry D4 arrays from FD1 and control alleles, recapitulating epigen and D4 expression seen in patients and controls, respectively, including high D4 in germline, incomplete epigen repression in somatic tissue, and FD-specific varieg D4 in sporadic muscle nuclei with D4 chromatin relaxation. The mice also show D4 activates similar gene groups in muscle as in human muscle. These mice represent a valuable model for FD and will study molecular mechanisms and test new interventions.
Researchers have developed a malaria vaccine candidate, Apical Membrane Antigen-1 (AMA1), which provides protection against certain strains of the parasite, but not others. To overcome this limitation, they investigated the structural basis of cross-strain inhibition. A vaccine containing four diverse AMA1 proteins (3D, F, VO, HB, and Wm) elicited polyclonal antibodies that inhibited invasion of both vaccine and non-vaccine strains of Plasmodium falciparum. Comparing polyclonal anti-Q with strain-specific monoval 3D AMA, Q induced higher levels of broadly inhibitory antibodies associated with conserved domain-3 and reduced domain-2 responses. Inhibitory monoclonal antibodies (m) against Q reacted with a cross-reactive epitope at the rim of hydrophobic domain-1; this epitope mapped to conserved AMA and encompassed the 1-loop. mbs binding the 1-loop (10, 4, 8 and 4) were ~10-fold more potent than AMA-inhib m and mode of action was inhibition AMA binding to ligand R2. Unlike epit of 3D-specific m, the 1-loop inhibitory was partially conserved across strains. Another m, bound domain-3, was broadly inhibitory and blocked proteolytic processing AMA. m was weakly inhibitory but synergized with strain-transending m, which binds close hydroobic on cons and inhibits R2 binding AMA. Novel susceptible regions and epitopes identified can improve antigen breadth and inhib response AMA vaccines. Vaccination with diverse proteins provides coverage by redirecting response conserved epitopes.
Researchers have identified a mechanism that regulates the timing of mitotic spindle displacement in cells, a process crucial for unequal cell division. The mechanism involves the anaphase-promoting complex (APC), its activator Cdc20/Fizzy, its target cyclin, and cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK). In Caenorhabditis zygotes, mitotic spindle displacement begins at a precise time after chromosomes congress to the metaphase plate. Reducing proteasome function, APC, or C20/Fizzy function delays spindle displacement, while inactivating CD in metaphase causes early spindle displacement. Displacing spindle from this mechanism results in premature displacement of incompletely assembled spindle components. The study shows that in this system, spindle positioning is delayed until APC inactivates CD, ensuring spindle does not move until fully assembled. This is the first demonstration of mitotic timing spindle displacement in animal cell division. The link between cell cycle and asymmetric division might be evolutionarily conserved, as spindle displaced at similar stage mitosis in diverse systems.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide scan to investigate genetic adaptations to high-altitude hypoxia in Tibetan and Andean populations, who have lived in high-altitude regions for millennia. These populations exhibit unique physiological responses to low oxygen levels, including circulatory, respiratory, and hematological adaptations. The study aimed to identify genetic basis of these adaptations by examining genomic regions associated with altitude-related phenotypes and genes involved in oxygen metabolism. Four statistical methods were used to detect signatures of natural selection, identifying candidate genes and regions in each population separately. Results showed distinct patterns of adaptation between Tibetans and Andeans, with evidence of selection in different genes or regions. One gene, EGLN (PH2), involved in oxygen sensing, showed selection in both populations, but with differing variation patterns. Key HIF-regulatory and targeted genes were implicated in adaptation in Andans, while different chromosomal regions in Tibetans. Data suggest genetic role in high-altitude adaptation and provide basis for future studies to confirm selection-nominated genes and regions in adaptation.
Double-strand breaks (DSBs) in DNA are hazardous events that can arise from environmental stress or replication errors. Efficient repair of DSBs is crucial for cell survival, but faulty repair can lead to genetic instability, making the choice of DSB repair pathway significant. This study reveals that inverted repeats (IRs) near DSBs can channel repair into a pathway that leads to gene conversion instead of break-induced replication (BIR) pathway, resulting in instability. IRs ability to form unusual structures in single-strand DNA, formed by DSB resection, explains their effect. IRs form two types of structures, depending on spacer length separating IRs. IRs with long (1-kb) spacers are involved in intermolecular single-strand annealing (SSA), forming dimers, while IRs with short (12-b) spacers participate intramolecular SSA, forming fold-back (FB) structures. Both structures interfere with accurate DSB repair by conversion and channeling DSB into BIR, promoting genomic destabilization. Protein complexes process FB containing short (12-b) versus long (1-k) ssDNA loops differently. FB with short loops are processed by MRX-Sae2, while Rad1-Rad10 processes long loops. This study uncovers mechanisms of genomic destabilization from re-routing DSB into unusual pathways by IRs. Given IR abundance in human genome, findings contribute to understanding IR-mediated destabilization with human disease.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an opportunistic pathogen capable of causing both acute and chronic infections in susceptible hosts, with chronic infections thought to be caused by biofilms. Biofilms are structured, multicellular microbial communities encased in an extracellular matrix enabling long-term survival in the host. This study aimed to develop an animal model for in vivo study of P. aerugin biofilms in Drosila melanogaster. Drosila were orally infected with P. aerugin, and biofilms localized and visualized in dissected at 24 h post-infection. Biofilms had a characteristic structure and extracellular matrix composed of DNA and exopolysacide. P. aerugin cells from in vivo biofilms showed increased antibiotic resistance to planktonic cells. Biofilm formation was dependent on expression of exopolysacide genes, as pel:: mutant failed to form biofilms. The:: mutant was more virulent than PA1, while hyperbio strain (Z3) demonstrated less virulence than PA1, indicated by survival of flies at 14 postinfection. Bio formation by PA1 and in the crop was associated with induction of dipteric, cecin A and antimicrobial gene expression 24 postin. Infection with non-bio forming resulted in decreased gene expression. These results provide insights into host-pathogen interactions during P. aerugin infection Dila and highlight Dila as model for study P aerugin bio in vivo.
Researchers investigated the genetic factors contributing to the variation in expression of the vasopressin 1 receptor 1 (Av1) gene, which plays a crucial role in mediating vasopress-mediated behaviors. The study focused on the proximal 5' flanking sequence and polymorphic microsatellite element in the Av1 gene. Using homologous recombination in mice, they found that the proximal 5' flanking sequence modestly contributes to differences in vasopress receptor 1 (V1R) distribution. They also confirmed that variation in V1R impacts behavior in the forced swim test. Additionally, they discovered that the Av1 microsatellite structure influences Av1 expression in the amygdala, thalamus, and hippocampus, mirroring some inter- and intra-species differences in V1 patterns in voles. This is the first evidence that polymorphic microsatellites near behaviorally relevant genes contribute to diversity in brain expression, providing a mechanism for generating diversity at both individual and species levels. However, results suggest that many species-specific patterns are mediated by elements outside the 5' flanking region of the gene.
In a study on Saccharomyces cerevisiae, researchers investigated the mechanisms of genome instability caused by impairment of messenger RNA (mRNA) biogenesis and Activation-induced cytidine deaminase (A) (AID). The study focused on the transcription of switch regions of immunoglobulin genes in B cells, which generates stable-loops that are targeted by A, leading to class switch recombination (CSR) and translocations with c-MYC responsible for Burkitt's lymphomas. In yeast, stable-loops are formed co-transcriptionally in mutants of TH, a conserved complex involved in mRNA biogenesis. The researchers devised a chromosomal system based on mammalian switch regions and c-MYC to analyze chromosomal rearrangements in wild-type and TH mutants. They found that A acts on heterologous and c-M transcribed sequences, leading to double-strand breaks (DSBs), which cause chromosomal translocations via Non-homous Joining (NHE). A-induced translocations were enhanced in TH null mutants, indicating A-mediated DS depend on-loop formation. The study provides insights into the role of m bi in preventing rearrangements and A-mediated genome instability, and shows that urac residues produced by A-deamination are processed into DS and chromosomal rearrangements by conserved DNA repair functions from yeast to human cells.
In Escheria coli coordinates cell division and chromosome replication to produce viable progeny by positioning its division apparatus relative to nucleoids. However, cells lacking this positioning can still propagate. This study investigates how E. coli partitions chromosomes during asymmetric divisions. Time-lapse imaging shows DNA translocase Fts pumps 80% (3.7 Mb) of chromosome between daughters at 1700±800 bp/s, with rare pauses and no reversals. Most movement occurs at late division when ZipA dissociates from septum and septum constricts to 250 nm. Data suggests constriction enables DNA translocation by Fts.
Researchers have developed a mathematical framework for selecting the optimal set of peptides for epitope-based vaccines using integer linear programming (ILP). Epitope-based vaccines have various applications, including therapeutic and prophylactic approaches for infectious and cancer diseases. The development of an epitope-based vaccine relies on knowledge of target-specific antigens from immunogenic peptides, called epitopes, which are key components of the vaccine. Due to regulatory, economic, and practical concerns, the number of epitopes in a vaccine is limited. Major histocompatibility complex (MHC) binding epitopes are highly polymorphic, with each patient having a unique set of MHC I and II molecules. A combination effective for one person may be ineffective for another, making optimal epitope selection crucial. The framework uses IL to formulate various vaccine design problems and identify optimal epitopes from a set of predicted or experimentally determined epitopes. It selects the set with maximum likelihood of eliciting a broad and potent immune response. The IL approach allows flexible formulation of numerous design variants. Immunological requirements, such as coverage of epitopes per antigen, coverage of MHC alleles, and avoidance of high mutation epitopes, are translated into constraints or modifications of the objective function. The algorithm outperforms a greedy strategy and evolutionary algorithm with runtimes of seconds for typical sizes.
Researchers investigated the role of interleukin-7 (IL-7) in facilitating HIV-1 transmission to the cervico-vaginal tissue in an ex vivo system. IL-7 is a cytokine present in semen, and its concentration is increased in HIV-1-infected individuals. The study simulated an in vivo situation by depositing HIV-1 on cervico-vaginal tissue with IL-7 concentrations comparable to those in semen of HIV-1-infected men. Results showed IL-7 enhanced HIV-1 replication in cervico-vaginal tissue and lymphoid tissue explants. Analysis of infected cells revealed IL-7 reduced CD4+ T cell apoptosis by decreasing apoptotic marker APO2.7 and increasing anti-apoptotic protein Bcl-2. IL-7 also increased cycling CD4 T cells, as evidenced by Ki-67 staining.
Researchers studied the response of Aedes aegypt cells to Zika virus (ZIK) infection, focusing on the role of RNA interference (RNAi) pathways in controlling arbovirus infections. Two RNAi pathways, PI-interacting RNA (piRNA) and exogenous short interfering RNA (exiRNA), produce virus-derived small RNAs of 25-29 and 21 nucleotides, respectively. The exi pathway is considered key to mosquito antiviral response. In Aedes aegti cells, ZIK-specific siRNAs were produced and loaded into exi effector protein Argonaute 2 (Ago2), but Ago knockdown did not enhance virus replication. Enhanced ZIK replication was observed in D2-knockout cells, indicating exi pathway involvement in antiral response. ZIK-specific pi-sized RNAs were detected, but lacked pi signature and bound Ago3, not Pi5 or Pi6. Silencing Pi proteins showed Ago, Pi5, or Pi6 knockdown did not enhance ZIK replication, only Pi4 displayed antiral activity. ZIK capsid C protein amplified reporter alphavirus replication, unlike yellow fever protein, which inhibited exi pathway.
Researchers conducted a study in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil to investigate the species of Sporothrix associated with sporotrichosis, a fungal infection caused by Sporothrix schenii. The study aimed to determine if Sporrix brasiliensis was linked to atypical clinical manifestations of sporrichosis. A cross-sectional study analyzed 50 Sporrix isolates from patients with different clinical manifestations using phenotypic and genotypic methods. Results showed distinct clinical and therapeutic responses between Sporrix brasili (45 cases) and Spor schenii sensu stricto (5 cases). Sporrix brasili was associated with disseminated cutaneous infections, mucosal infections, and hypersensitivity reactions, whereas Spor schii presented less severe, localized disease. Patients with Sporrixili required shorter itraconazole treatment (16 weeks) compared to Sporii (24 weeks). These findings suggest Sporrix species are linked to different sporrich manifestations and Sporili is effectively treated with itraazole.
Recent studies have suggested that a significant portion of the mammalian genome is transcribed is not accounted for by annotated genes. To investigate this, researchers used single-end and paired RNA-Seq and tiling to assess the quantity and composition of Poly+ RNA in human and mouse tissues. Relative to tiling, RNASeq identified many transcribed regions outside known exons and non-coding RNAs, with most being introns, suggesting they are pre-mRNA fragments. Chromosomal locations of intergenic regions in RNASeq are near genes, consistent with alternative splicing and polyadenylation, promoter and terminator transcripts, or new exons. Reads bridging splice sites identified 5,544 new exons, affecting 3,554 genes. Remaining regions correspond to single reads with characteristics of low background noise or small transcripts (median length=111 bp) present at high levels, displaying conservation and originating from open chromatin. Bona fide intergenic transcripts exist, but their number is low compared to exons, and genome is not as pervasively transcribed as reported.
Researchers have developed a computational and experimental method to enhance the thermostability of the flavin mononucleotide-based protein Bacillus subtilis YLO domain by 31°C, expanding its applicability in thermophilic systems. A five-step approach was employed: single mutant screening to identify thermost candidates, experimental evaluation to confirm positive selections, computational redesign around thermost regions, experimental reevaluation, and multiple combination. The method is simple and effective, applicable to proteins where other methods face difficulties, providing a tool to improve thermost.
Researchers investigated the diversity of Lutzia sand flies and their infection rates by Leishmania and Wolbachia species in Barro Island, Panama. Lutzia flies are the primary vectors of leishmaniasis, a protozoan disease, in the New World. In the Panama Canal watershed, cutaneous leishias is a health threat to residents and tourists. The study aimed to determine which Lutzia species are present, their relationships, and how they are infected by Leish and Wolia to mitigate the disease impact. DNA sequences were used to determine the diversity and phylogenetic relationships of Phleominae in the understory of Barro Island. The CO1 DNA barcode gene supported morphology-based species determinations, revealing two cryptic species, Lu. sp. vespilion and Lu. gzi. ITS-1 primers detected Leish in 43.3% of Lu. trapi, 26.3% Lu. gzi, and 0% other sand species. The ITS-1 sequence from Leish Lu. trapi and Lu. gzi was 93% similar to Leish viannia in GenBank, a species unknown in Panama but recognized as cutaneous leish vector in northern and central America. Distinct Wolia strains were detected in three sand species, including Lu. trapi, co-occurring with Leish. Two species, members of separate clades, carried Leish at high frequency, likely vectors of leish to humans or mammals. A single Leish, Le. naiff, was identified in both species, known to cause cutaneous in America but not reported in Panama, suggesting its range expansion or introduction. Leish and Wolia in Lu. trap identifies a vector as potential target for Wolia population control.
Researchers have investigated the mechanisms underlying human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) reactivation in dendritic cells (DCs), which is crucial for understanding the devastating consequences of CMV infection. They found that mitogen- and stress-activated kinase (MSK) family is involved in ERK reactivation, and this response is dependent on CREB binding to the viral major early promoter (MP). CREB binding to MP serves as a target for MS recruitment. MS-mediated phosphorylation of histone H3 is required for histone demethylation, allowing CMV exit from latency. Data suggest that CRE binding to MP is necessary for MS kinase recruitment, initiating chromatin remodeling at MP for reactivation. CRE also promotes chromatin modifications conducive to viral expression and acts as a transcription factor. Inhibiting interaction between CRE and MS could be a therapeutic strategy.
Researchers have identified a crucial role for the protein NOL11 in ribosome biogenesis and craniofacial development in vertebrates. N11 is highly expressed in the developing cranial neural crest (CNC) of amphibians and mammals, and its knockdown in Xenopus results in impaired pre-rRNA processing, increased apoptosis, and abnormal craniofacial cartilage development. Inhibition of p53 rescues the skeletal phenotype but not the ribosome biogenesis defect, indicating an evolutionarily conserved mechanism for removing ribosome-impaired craniofacial cells. Excessive activation of this mechanism impairs craniofac development. The study reveals a novel requirement for N11 in craniofac development and the first model of a ribosopathy, providing insight into the relationship between ribosome proteins and cranfac cell survival.
Researchers have developed a high-density protein microarray to identify seroreactive proteins of Leptira interrogans serovar Copenhagen, the causative agent of leptospirosis, a zoonotic disease worldwide. A total of 274 individuals, including 80 acute-phase, 80 convalescent, and 114 healthy subjects from regions with high, endemic, and no transmission of leptpi were investigated. The microarray comprised 61% of the Leptira interrogans proteome. Nitrocellulose blot assay validated the accuracy of the microarray results. Sixteen antigens were found to discriminate between acute cases and healthy individuals from regions with high transmission of leptpi, and 18 antigens distinguished convales cases. Some identified antigens, such as Lip32, non-identical domains of Lig, Gro, and Lo22, are known to be recognized by human sera, validating the serodiagnostic approach. Novel antigens, including hypothetical LIC15, showed sensitivity and specificity for both acute and convalescent patients. This study is the first large-scale evaluation of immunodominant antigens associated with naturally acquired leptiral infection and novel seragnostic leptiral antigens recognized by leptpi cases. Identified antigens may be used in new test development and improvement of current assays for diagnosing neglected tropical disease. Further research is needed to assess utility in deployable diagnostic platforms.
Researchers investigated the role of melanization in the defense against the entomopathogenic fungus Beauveria bassiana in the malaria vector mosquito Anopheles gambia. Melanization, a potent effector mechanism in arthropods, was found to form on all stages of the fungus, including conidia, germ tubes, and hyphae, but did not inhibit growth. However, silencing TEP1 and CL8, key regulators of melanization in A. gambiae, abolished melanization on hypha but not germinating conidia or tubes. A layer of hemocytes surrounded germinating conidia but not hypha, suggesting melanization of early stages is cell-mediated, while late is humoral dependent on T1 and CL8. Microscopic analysis revealed T1 association with hypha surfaces and requirement of both T1 and CL8 for phenoloxidase recruitment. Fungal proliferation was rapid in T1 and CL8 knockdown mosquitoes, exhibiting increased sensitivity to B. bassiana infections.
Researchers investigated the potential of known mammalian Dengue virus host factors (DENVFs) inhibitors to block Dengue virus infection in the mosquito vector Aedes aegypt. Four compounds, bafilomycin (BAF), myopholic acid (MA), castanospermine (CAS), and deoxojirimycin (DN), were tested for their ability to inhibit DENV infection in the mosquito midgut and salivary gland. Injection of BA (5µM) and MA (25µM) prior to feeding on virus-infected blood reduced DENV titers in the midut by 56% and 60, and in the saliv gland by 90 and 83, respectively, while CAS and DN had no effect. Ingestion of BA and MA through sugar or blood meal also resulted in virus inhibition. RNA-mediated silencing of vacuolar H+-ATase (vPase) and inos-5-monophosphate degenase (IMP) genes reduced DENV infection, indicating BA and MA inhibition occurred through these DENVFs. Timing of BA and MA administration was crucial, treatment after virus exposure diminished antiviral effect. This study provides proof-of-principle that chemical or RNA-mediated depletion of DENV vP and IMP can suppress DENV in adult Aegipt, potentially reducing transmission.
Researchers investigated the role of cell volume in neuronal dynamics, particularly in the context of seizures, spreading depression, and anoxic depolarization. They developed a model that incorporates cell swelling, ion concentrations, and oxygen supply into the Hodgkin-Hux spiking dynamics, demonstrating a transition between seizure and spreading states in response to osmotic pressure changes. The study revealed a dynamical parameter that separates seizure from depression, and another that demarcates depression from anoxic depolar. The model highlights the neuroprotective role of glial buffering against seizures and depression, and provides insights into anoxic depolar and cell swelling during ischemia. The results suggest that seizures, depression, and anoxicolar lie along a continuum of neuronal membrane dynamics, requiring consideration of ion concentrations, homeostasis, and osmotic response. A unified framework is proposed for a range of neuronal behaviors, potentially relevant to understanding and developing interventions for pathological states.
Paracidioides brasiliensis, the causative agent of paracidiomycosis, a prevalent mycosis confined to Latin America, triggers an inflammatory response in murine bone-derived dendritic cells through the activation of the NLRP inflamome, a cytoplasmic multiprotein complex. This results in the release of IL-1β, a pro-inflammatory cytokine essential for host defense against opportunistic infections. However, the role of IL-1 in primary fungal infections, such as P. brasili, is not well understood. 

 Murine dendritic cells respond to P. brasili yeast cells by releasing IL-1 in a Syk, casp-1, and NLR family member NLR3 dependent manner. P. bras-induced NLR3 inflamome activation is dependent on K+ efflux, ROS production, phagolysosomal acidification, and cathepsin release. Mice lacking IL-1 receptor demonstrate that IL-1 signaling plays a role in killing P. bras by murine macrophages.
Toxoplas gondii, a brain-tropic parasite, infects nucleated cells, including astrocytes and neurons in vitro, but primarily resides in neurons in vivo. In vitro studies showed that interferon-γ-stimulated astrocytes, but not neurons, clear intracellular parasites, suggesting neurons are persistently infected in vivo due to their inability to clear intracellular parasites. A novel Toxoplas-mouse model was used to mark and track host cells interacting with parasites, even transiently. Toxoplas showed a strong predilection for interacting with neurons throughout CNS infection. This predction persisted in IF-γ depletion, infection resistant to the mechanism by which murine astrocytes clear parasites, and when parasites were directly injected into the brain. These findings, combined with prior work, indicate neurons are not incidentally infected but Tooplas's primary in vivo target.
Researchers have developed a free-boundary model to explain the behavior of cells undergoing lamellipodial motility, a type of cell movement characterized by the extension and retraction of the cell membrane. The model focuses on the interplay between actin-myosin contractility, force balance, and myosin transport. The model accounts for isotropic contraction proportional to myosin density, viscous stresses in the actin network, and constant-strength viscous adhesion. Contraction generates a spatially graded actin flow, which reinforces contraction via myin redistribution and retraction of the lamellip boundary. Actin protrusion at the boundary counters retraction, and the balance of protrusion and retraction shapes the lamipodium. The model reveals that motility initiation depends on three dimensionless parameters: myosin-dependent contractility, characteristic adhesion length, and actin protrusion rate. When contractility is strong, cells break symmetry and move steadily along straight or circular trajectories, and motility is sensitive to boundary conditions. A parameter space scan shows that contractile motility supports cell turning in conditions with short adhesion and fast protrusion, causing myos accumulation in a small region at the rear, destabilizing cell symmetry.
Researchers have developed a novel technique to assess the confidence levels of protein-protein interactions (PPI) in networks obtained from experimental studies, addressing the challenges of noise and incompleteness in these networks. High-throughput methods such as yeast-2-hybrid (Y2H) and tandem affinity purification (TAP) have generated vast amounts of PPI data, but with high false positive and false negative rates, estimated at 64% and 43-71% for YH, respectively, and comparable for T. The new approach utilizes geometric graphs as the best model for PPI networks, achieving 85% specificity and 90 sensitivity. It assigns confidence scores to physical-protein interactions in the human P network from BioGRID, predicting 251 interactions, with a significant fraction corresponding to shared Gene Ontology (GO) terms. Predicted interactions were validated in the Human Protein Reference Database (HPRD) and BioGRID's newer release.
Researchers have identified a novel mechanism contributing factor to the pathogenesis of myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1), a neurodegenerative disease caused by non-coding CT repeat expansions. In addition to the sense-expanded transcript, antisense transcripts also play a role in disease progression. A Drosila model was established to investigate the interaction between CTG and CAG repeats. Studies showed enhanced toxicity in flies co-expressing CTG and CAG repeats. Expression of both transcripts led to pathogenesis and generation of dcr-2 and ago-dependent 21-nt repeat-derived siRNAs. These small RNAs targeted C-containing genes, such as Ataxin-2 and TATA-binding protein (TBP), which have CAG repeats in both fly and human. The findings suggest that generation of triplet-derived siRNAs may enhance toxicity in repeat diseases with antisense transcription.
Researchers have investigated the phylogeny and virulence of Pectobacterium sp. SCC3, a soft rot pathogen isolated from a diseased potato in Finland in the 1980s. Genomic and proteomic analysis revealed that SCC3, previously classified as Pectacterium carotovorum, is now accurately classified as Pobacter wasiae. Phylogenetic analysis of P. carotorum and P. wasiae strains indicates that P. wasiae has been present in potato fields worldwide. A combination of genomic and in planta experiments identified features distinguishing SCC3 and P. wasiae from other soft rot bacteria, including the absence of a type III secretion system contributing to virulence in other rot species. Experimentally confirmed virulence determinants include the putative transcription regulator SirB, two redundant type VI secretion systems, and horizontally acquired clusters Vic1 and Vic2 with predicted virulence genes. The genome also revealed traits related to life in planta or specific conditions, such as a benzoic/salicylic acid carbox methyltransferase of eukary origin. This study provides a basis for further investigation of virulence distribution and phylogeny of soft bacteria and potentially other bacteria.
Researchers investigated the changes in mitochondrial protein expression in cells with depleted mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) using network analysis of gene expression data. Mitochondrial proteins are encoded by both nuclear and mitochondrial DNA, but little is known about changes in nuclear-encoded proteins (mtome) in dysfunctional states. The study analyzed mt-depleted (ρ) mitochondria using quantified proteomics data and modularized into functional networks to examine systemic properties of dysfunction. Two predominant sub-networks of upregulated and downregulated proteins were identified, exhibiting distinct biological processes. Downregulated modules involved typical mitochondrial functions, while upregulated proteins were responsible for mtDNA repair, regulation, and protein transport. Comparison of proteome and transcriptome data showed ρ cells attempted to compensate for mt depletion by modulating protein expression and transport. Results demonstrate protein composition changes remodel mitochondrial networks in response to cellular dysfunction, providing a framework for understanding how cells respond to mitochondrial dysfunctions.
Researchers have developed a method to deduce the kinetics of protein synthesis in vivo from transition rates measured in vitro. The method has two components: the kinetic distance concept, which quantitatively compares kinetics of multistep processes in different environments, and minimization of kinetic distance between in vitro and in vivo processes. The kinetic distance depends logarithmically on transition rates and can be interpreted in terms of free energy barriers. The method is applied to protein synthesis by ribosomes, a key process of gene expression, described by a cod-specific Markov model with three pathways for tRNA binding. Transition rates are determined in vitro, then in vivo rates are predicted by minimization and validated by three sets of in vivo data: cod-dependent speeds, dynamics, and missense frequencies. Agreement is found between theory and experiment without adjusting parameters. In vivo rates lead to smaller error than vitro rates, primarily due to improved tRNA selection. The method is computationally simple and can be applied to biomolecular processes with in vitro kinetics.
Researchers investigated the evolution of Helicobacter pylori during infection in hosts and families by sequencing 39,300 bp in 78 gene fragments from 97 isolates. The study included 34 pairs of sequential samples from 0.25 to 10.2 years apart and single isolates from 29 individuals (average age 45) from 10 families. Sequence diversity increased over time in a clock-like manner in sequential isolates. Approximate Bayesian computation estimated mutation, recombination rates, recombination tract length, and diversity. Results showed short-term mutation rate 1.4×10^-6 to 4.5×10^-6 per nucleotide per year, with recombination introducing three times as many substitutions as mutation. Long-term rate over millennia 5-17 lower due to non-synonymous removal by purifying selection.
Researchers have discovered that melanopsin, a pigment found in a subset of retinal ganglion cells, plays a significant role in visual perception beyond driving reflex responses such as circadian entrainment and pupillary movements. Using new reporter lines, they found melanin projections extend to the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN), the origin of thalamocortical neurons, and support physiological responses in the GN and cortex in mice lacking rods and cones. Chromatic stimuli isolated melanin responses in intact mice reveal melanin input to 40% of LGN neurons activated by light. Melanin input increases firing rate of these neurons. Melan knockout mice confirm melanin required for irradiance encoding. The study establishes melanin photoreception as a source of sensory input to the thalamocortical system, providing irradiance information, allowing responses in the absence of rods and cones. Melanin ganglion cells are a potential origin of visual perception and may support vision in retinal degeneration.
HIV-1 infection leads to a significant depletion of mucosal CD4+ T cells, which play a crucial role in regulating isotype switching and transepithelial transport of antibodies. This study investigated the impact of CD4+ cell depletion on humoral responses to mucosal antigens in HIV-1-infected individuals. A comprehensive analysis of systemic humoral responses to intestinal microbiota revealed reduced IgG responses to Proteobacteria and Firmicutes, but not Bacteroid antigens. Intestinal secretions from antiretroviral-treated HIV-1-infected individuals showed elevated IgM and decreased IgA/Ig and IgG/Ig ratios to various microbial and food antigens. These findings indicate reduced mucosal B cell competence for class recombination from IgM to other isotypes, limiting their capacity to react to gut antigens. Decreased microbiota-specific IgA and IgG may contribute to microbial translocation across the mucosal barrier and systemic dissemination, driving chronic inflammation in HIV-1-infected individuals.
Populations of species in ecosystems are constrained by the availability of resources in their environment, leading to a balance between the growth of one population and reduction of others. Traditional models of biodiversity assume incremental changes due to births and deaths of individuals. This study proposes an alternative mechanism driven by abrupt reduction in size of a single species, freeing resources for others. This may be relevant for communities with strain collapses caused by bacteriophages or infectious diseases. The emergent dynamics is characterized by 'diversity waves' triggered by collapses of dominating populations. Diversity peaks at the beginning of each wave and decreases exponentially. Species abundances have bimodal time-aggregated distribution with lower peaks of collapsed or newly introduced species and upper not yet collapsed. Most waves have multiple peaks. A self-organized peak structure has long-term memory across waves, resulting in scale-free time-aggregated distribution with exponent 1.7. The model is robust to variations in rules such as diffusion, species-specific growth and extinction rates, and bet-hging strategies.
Chemotaxis in Escherichia coli, a paradigm of simple behavior, has been extensively studied due to its significant competitive advantage and high evolution rates in bacteria. The chemaxis system is expected to be optimized as bacteria follow gradients by performing temporal comparisons of chemector concentrations along runs, an efficient strategy given their size and speed. Concentration differences are detected by a sensory system and transmitted to modulate flagellar motors, decreasing tumble probability and reorientation if perceived change is positive. Regulation of tumble probability is sufficient to explain chemactic drift up the gradient, assumed only mechanism of E coli. coli chemaxis. This study uses simulations to predict an additional navigation mechanism in E coli. Experimentally observed dependence of tumbling on motor number suggests tumble probability and reorientation also depend on swimming direction along gradient. Mean tumbling angles up and down gradient predicted by model differ, resulting in enhanced cellular velocity along gradient. A new level of coli chemaxis optimization arises from flagellar switching and tumbling angle fine-tuning. Similar strategy likely used by peritously flagellated bacteria, another level bacterial chemaxis development.
Medullary thymic epithelial (mTE) cells play a crucial role in establishing tolerance by presenting self-peptides to autoreactive thymocytes and diverting them into regulatory T cells. Activation of the NFκB pathway in TE precursors is necessary for TE maturation and medullary formation. This study reveals that Stat3 signaling also contributes to TE development and homeostasis. Constitutively active Stat3 in the TE compartment increases TE cellularity, bypassing positive thymocyte signals for medull formation. Conditional deletion of Stat disrupts medull architecture and reduces TE numbers. Stat does not affect TE proliferation, but promotes survival of immature MHCloCDlo TE precursors. In contrast, alterations in the TE compartment do not affect cortical cellularity or organization.
Researchers used an in silico approach to identify 511 small non-coding RNAs (sRNAs) in Clostridium difficile, a common cause of nosocomial diarrhea, to understand their role in physiology and pathogenesis. In parallel, RNA-seq and 5-end RNA-seq were used to identify C difficile RNAs and their transcription start sites at three growth conditions: exponential phase, stationary, and starvation. This approach identified 251 putative RNAs, including 94 intergenic trans-regulators, 91 cis-antisense RNAs, and 66 riboswitches. Expression of 35 RNs was confirmed by gene-specific approaches. Some RNs, including antisense, may control C difficile autolytic activity showed phase-dependent expression. 16 c-diMP-responsive ribwitches were expressed, with evidence for regulatory control of motility and biofilm formation. Abundant RNs encoded by C CRIS loci may be important for C survival in phage-rich gut. This study provides a basis for future characterization and identification of mechanisms of RNA-based regulation in this emergent enteropath.
The hepatitis C virus (HCV) core protein downregulates the abundance of liver-specific microRNA-122 (mi-122) by promoting its destabilization via inhibition of GLD-2, a non-canonical cytoplasmic poly(A) polymerase. This decrease in mi-122 expression results in dysregulation of its functions, including its proviral activity for HCV. High-throughput sequencing of small RNAs from human liver biopsies reveals that the 22-nucleotide (nt) prototype mi-122 is modified at its 3' end by 3'-terminal non-templated and templated nucleotide additions. The proportion of mi-122 bearing a single nucleotide tail of ribonucle decreases in liver specimens from HCV patients. Single-nucle-tailed mi-122 isomers display increased miRNA activity and stability compared to 22-nt prototype mi-122. The 3-terminal extension is catalyzed by unique nucleotidyl transfer activity of GL-2, capable of adding single ribonucle without preference adenyl to mi-122 3 end. HCV protein inhibits GL-2 and interaction with GL- in cytoplasm is responsible for mi- downregulation.
Researchers have identified a pattern of age-consistent acquired immunity against Trypanosoma brucei in Serengeti, a species of trypanosome that causes disease in humans and livestock in sub-Saharan Africa. Despite some species showing clinical tolerance to trypanosomes, there has been no evidence of acquired immunity to natural infections until now. The study found a distinct decrease in prevalence of T. brucei s. l. infection in wild lions that is consistent with an exposure-dependent increase in cross-immunity following infections with a more genetically diverse species, T. congense lat. The causative agent of human sleeping sickness, T. bruce rhodesi, disappears by 6 years of age in response to cross-immunity from other trypan, including non-pathogenic subspecies T. bruce bruce.
Researchers used mathematical modeling and sensitivity analysis to test the hypothesis that mechanistic models of human coagulation cascades, despite uncertainty, can be computationally screened for points of fragility, which could serve as therapeutic targets. A well-studied coagulation cascade model, composed of 92 proteins and 148 protein-protein interactions, was developed and validated using 21 published datasets from different in vitro coagulation models. The model simulated platelet activation and thrombin generation in the presence and absence of anticoagulants were consistent with measured values, with a mean correlation of 0.87 across trials. Sensitivity coefficients, measuring robustness or fragility of mechanisms, were calculated using Monte Carlo. In the absence of anticoagul, factor X/activated factor X (FX) and thrombin-mediated platelet activation were found fragile, while IXIX andVIII activation and activity were robust. AntiFXa and thrombin inhibitors, classes of anticoagulants, such as antiFX inhibitors, have FDA approval for prevention of venous thromboembolism following surgical intervention and initial treatment deep venous thromosis pulmonary embol. In vitro and vivo evidence supports IXIX activity robustness. These results support computationally derived fragility of human cascades as basis for target selection despite uncertainty.
Bacteriophage therapy, the use of bacteriophages as antimicrobial agents to control pathogenic and problematic bacteria, relies on understanding nonlinear kinetics of phage-bacteria interactions. This study combines experimental and modeling approaches to examine kinetics of Campylobacterium jejuni, a foodborne pathogen, and a virulent phage in an in vitro system. Phage-insensitive C. jejuni populations arise, the first phage study to test in vitro models ph-bacteria interactions with ph-insensitive bacteria. A simple model fits data well, confirming inundation and proliferation thresholds are crucial for ph therapy. The model is fit to time series data to estimate thresholds and rate constants, revealing culture-density dependent phage infectivity features.
Researchers have identified a novel Toll-like receptor (TLR) in the snail Biomphalaria glabr, which plays a crucial role in the snail's immune response to the parasitic flatworm Schistosoma mansoni. Schistosomiasis, a disease caused by S. mansoni, affects over 260 million people worldwide, primarily in tropical and subtropical regions. S. mansoni undergoes larval development in specific snail hosts, a trait shared among digene trematodes. The snail immune response is vital for protecting against S. mansoni infection, but few specific snail immune factors have been identified and functionally characterized. This study reports the first functional characterization of a snail TLR, demonstrating its importance in the snail's cellular response to S. mansoni. The TLR, named BTL, was identified in a screen of snail cell surface proteins differing in abundance between B. glabr snails with varying susceptibility to S. mans. The resistant B. glabr strain (BS-90) displayed higher BTL levels than the susceptible (M-line) strain. BTL expression increased 27-fold in BS- snails challenged with S. mans, whereas M snails showed no increase. Knocking down BTL in BS- snails via siRNA oligonucleotides altered the resistant phenotype, with 43% of normally resistant snails becoming infected, shedding S. mans cercaria 1 week before controls. This study is the first characterization of a gastropod TLR, showing BTL is an important sn receptor influencing S. mansoni infection outcome.
Researchers have developed an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) test to detect and quantify the presence of immunoglobulin G (Ig) antibodies against saliva proteins from the salivary glands of Aedes aegypt and Aedes polensis mosquitoes in human populations exposed to these species. A cross-sectional study in Tahiti and Moorea, where Aedes aegpt and Aedesynensis are present, found that 98% and 68% of individuals had IgG against Aegpt and Aynensis salivary gland extracts, respectively. In contrast, EL tests on a cohort from metropolitan France, not exposed to Aedes, showed 97% had no Ig against saliv gland extracts of either species. Analysis of cohorts from different entomological contexts showed no cross-reactivity between Aeg and Ayn saliv extracts. The Ig response to saliv extracts is a valid biomarker of human exposure to bites of Aeg and Ayn. This immunoepidological tool will enhance understanding of exposure to mosquito bites, identify areas of high disease risk, and evaluate vector control efficacy in Pacific and tropical settings.
Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the causative agent of tuberculosis, has evolved to thrive within the intracellular environment of human macrophages. To understand this adaptation, researchers investigated whether the pathogen interferes with the host cell's metabolic machinery. Temporal analysis of metabolic flux in macrophages infected with virulent mycobacterial strains confirmed this interference. Subsequent analysis identified a subset of host reactions targeted by the pathogen, revealing a goal to integrate macrophage survival pathways with mycobacterial sustenance. This convergence of host and pathogen factors defined determinants of pathogenicity. Macrophage survival sensitized TB susceptibility to glycemic status, while pathogen ensured virulence contributed to pathology.
Researchers have investigated the role of ZHP-3, the Caenorhabditis elegans ortholog of the yeast ZIP3 gene, in meiotic recombination and synaptonemal complex (SC) assembly. Z-3 is required for crossover recombination, ensuring proper segregation of homologous chromosomes during the first meiotic division. During meiotic prophase, Z-3 protein localization is dynamic, shifting from the length of the SC to asymmetric localization on the SC and eventually to foci marking crossover events. A Z-3::GFP transgene partially complements a null mutation, showing separation of function; although the fusion promotes wild-type recombination levels, aneuploidy among progeny is high, indicating defects in meiotic segregation. The bivalent structure is perturbed in this mutant, suggesting segregation defect results from inability to remodel chromosomes in response to crossovers. smo-1 mutants exhibit similar phenotypes to Z-3::G at higher temperatures, and smo-;Z-3G double mutants exhibit more meiotic defects than single, consistent with SUM role in SC assembly and bivalent differentiation.
Aedes aegyptus, a tropical mosquito species, has invaded temperate regions worldwide, including parts of Europe and the US, posing a public health concern due to its ability to transmit exotic viruses and cause nuisance through aggressive daytime biting. This study investigated eco-climatic factors affecting Aedes aegyus abundance in metropolitan and suburban areas in Rome, Italy, one of the most infested areas in Southern Europe. Longitudinal monitoring was conducted along a 70km transect across the metropolitan area, using two spatial-temporal datasets: 20m and 300 circular buffers around sticky traps to collect mosquitoes. Results showed association between anthropized habitats and high abundance in both metropolitan and suburban areas, with "green" islands" hotspots in metropolitan areas, and bimodal dynamics with a peak in autumn due to heavy rains and permissive temperatures.
Researchers have investigated the role of phthiocer dimoceros (DIM) in the invasion of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) into macrophages. DIM are major virulence factors of Mtb, particularly during the early stages of infection when the bacteria encounter host macrophages. Using Mtb mutants lacking genes involved in DIM synthesis, the study found that DIM participate in receptor-mediated phagocytosis of M and prevention of phagosome acidification. The effects of DIM on membrane fluidity were demonstrated by experiments with cholesterol-depleting drugs, which abolished differences in phagocyt efficiency and phag acidification between wild-type and mutant strains. Insertion of a cholesterol probe in living cells showed that membrane hydrophobic core polarity changed upon contact with M, while lateral cholesterol diffusion remained unaffected. This effect was dependent on DIM and consistent with observed in membrane model. The study proposes that DIM control macrophage invasion by M by targeting lipid organization in host membrane, modifying biophysical properties. DIM-induced lipid changes favor receptor-mediated phocytosis of M and phagomal pH driving bacilli in protective niche.
Researchers have developed a novel analysis method to study the dynamics of small neural networks composed of a few neurons. Mean-field approximations, commonly used to study large networks, do not accurately describe small networks, leading to differences between approximation and real behavior. Many neuroscience problems involve mesoscopic networks of tens of neurons, but methods to describe small networks are rare, hindering understanding of neural dynamics at intermediate scales. A systematic analysis of small networks of homogeneous excitatory and inhibitory neurons was conducted. Local bifurcations of neural activity were studied using an analytically tractable approach, and global bifurcations were numerically determined. For strong inhibition, networks exhibit complex dynamics due to branching of neural equations through spontaneous symmetry-breaking. This change is a finite network effect, revealing differences between mesoscopic circuits and mean-field approximation. Symmetry-breaking enables mesoscopic networks to regulate functional heterogeneity, reducing detrimental effects of noise on cortical processing.
Researchers investigated the presence and viability of Leishmania parasites in extralesional sites during dermal leishiasis. To determine the clinical and epidemiological significance of Leish DNA in extraional sites, they examined whether the DNA derives from viable parasites. Leish 7RNA was used to estimate parasite burden and viability in extraional sites of dermal leishias patients. The feasibility of discriminating parasite viability by PCR of Leish 7RNA was evaluated with luciferase activity of transfected intracellular amastigotes in dose-response cytotoxicity assays. Monocytes, tonsil swabs, and skin aspirates of 28 cutaneous and mucocutaneous leishias patients were screened by DNA amplification/Southern blot. Positive samples were analyzed by quantitative PCR of Leish 7RNA genes and transcripts. 7RNA amplification coincided with lucase activity, confirming parasite viability. Of 22 patients with extraional DNA samples, Leish 7RNA genes or transcripts were detected in one or more samples 100% and 73% respectively. Gene transcript number from extraional tissues were comparable to lesions.7RNA were detected in 13/19 (68%) monocytes, 5/12 (42%) tonsil sw, 4/11 (36%) skin aspir, and 22/25 (88%) lesions; genes were quantifiable 15/19 (79%) monocytes, 12/13 (92%) tons sw, 8/11 (73) skin.
Researchers have investigated the relationship between chromatin features and DNA replication timing in Drosophila using a comprehensive dataset of 95 chromatin-binding proteins (CBPs) and histone modifications (HMs). They found that combinations of CBPs have moderate predictive power for replication timing, while pairwise interactions between HMs lead to accurate genome-wide predictions that can be further improved by CB. Independent feature importance analysis led to a simplified, biologically interpretable model of the relationship between chromatin landscape and replication, reaching 80% of full accuracy with six terms. Pairwise HMs predict differential replication across cell types.
Researchers investigated the spread of Dengue virus serotypes 1-3 (DENV-1), 2 (DENV-2), and 3 (DENV-3) in Brazil using a statistical analysis of complete genome sequences. The study found that new lineages of all three serotypes were introduced to the country at intervals of 7-10 years. Lineages of DENV-1, DENV-2, and DENV-3 were most likely introduced from the Caribbean to the North and Northeast regions of Brazil, then dispersed at a rate of approximately 0.5 km/day. The study combined analysis of evolutionary, epidemiological, and ecological data suggests that human and/or mosquito transportation, rather than Aedes aegypti infestation rates or geographical distances determine Dengue virus spread in Brazil.
Researchers investigated how differences in the antagonistic center-surround receptive field (RF) organization across three parallel sensory maps in weakly electric fish influence correlations between electrosensory pyramidal neurons' activities. They used a model based on anatomical differences in RF center size and overlap to predict large differences in correlations across maps, but in vivo electrophysiological recordings showed identical correlations across all three segments. To explain this, they incorporated RF surround effects into the model, varying surround size relative to center, and found multiple structures gave similar correlations. Incorporating physiological RF differences between maps in the model resulted in similar correlations. The study shows RF overlap alone does not determine correlations, impacting understanding RF's influence on neural activity.
Researchers investigated the impact of correlations between neurons' responses to repeated presentations of the same stimulus, known as "noise", on the population's ability to encode the stimulus. They considered a general setting for population coding and how information varies as a function of noise, with other aspects of the problem, such as tuning curves and heterogeneity, held fixed. The study yielded insights into the role of noise, summarized in the form of theorems and illustrated with numerical examples involving neurons with diverse curves. The main contributions are: (1) a generalization of previous results proving the "sign rule" (SR): if correlations between pairs of neurons have opposite signs to their signal, performance improves compared to independent case, for three metrics and arbitrary curves levels of heterogeneity; (2) the SR is not a necessary condition for good coding; a diverse correlations can improve, many violating SR, observed experimentally; and (3) a set of necessary and sufficient conditions for performance to be as good as without noise.
Researchers investigated the impact of Pseudomonas aeruginosa on the susceptibility of Staphylococcus aureus to antibiotics in chronic coinfections. They used a panel of P aeruginosa isolates from burn and cystic fibrosis (CF) lung infections and found that P aerugin alters S aureus susceptibility to bactericidal antibiotics in a strain-dependent manner. Three interactions were identified that either antagonize or potentiate antibiotic activity against S aureus: Las endopeptidase potentiates vancomycin uptake, rhomids facilitate proton-motive-independent vancom uptake, and 2-hepty-4-hydroquinoline Noxide (HQ) induces multidrug tolerance through respiratory inhibition and ATP reduction. Production of these factors varies between isolates corresponds to their capacity to alter Sus susceptibility. Vancom treatment of S aure mouse burn infection was potentiated by the presence of Las-producing P aerugin population. These findings demonstrate susceptibility is complex and dependent on both pathogen genotype and environmental interactions.
Researchers investigated the mechanism of thrombocytopenia, a condition characterized by low platelet count, in patients with deng virus (DENV) infection, which can lead to complications such as bleeding and plasma leakage. They found that patients with deng had higher plasma concentrations of von Wille factor (VWF), a protein involved in blood clotting, and platelets bound more VWF to their surface. The amount of VWF on platelets correlated with plate count. Sialic acid, a component of plate membrane, was reduced in deng patients, as shown by binding of lectins to platelets. Sial acid on plate is neuraminidase-sensitive, but deng virus lacks neuraminidase activity. No neuraminid activity was detected in deng patients' plasma or desial of transferrin. Plate sial was not altered by exposure to DENV proteins in vitro. However, VWF binding to glycoprotein 1 on platelets using V-activating protein resulted in sial removal by translocation of neuraminase to plate surface. Neuramin inhibitor oseltiv reduced V-induced sial. The study shows V binding to platelets in deng results in neurid-mediated sial and clearance.
Researchers have identified a new regulatory mechanism in the human genome, known as bidirectional promoters, where two adjacent genes with opposite transcription start sites are controlled by a shared regulatory region. These promoters are often associated with genes involved in DNA repair and may contribute to cancer development. A comprehensive analysis of expressed sequence tags (ESTs) revealed a large collection of human genes under bidirectional promoters' control, with many functioning as alternative promoters or novel transcripts. A significant enrichment of bidirectional promoters was found in cancer-related genes, including breast and ovarian cancer. This promoter structure may regulate co-expression among groups of genes. Microarray data from 79 human tissues verified regulatory networks controlled by bidirectional promoters, with subsets containing similar transcription factor binding sites, including conserved ETS sites in ERBB, FCD, and BRCA.
Researchers conducted a whole-genome analysis of 37 species from 22 families of Diptera, including Drosophila melanogaster, to investigate the diversity of sex chromosome karyotypes. They found over a dozen different sex chromosome configurations, with the small dot chromosome being used as the sex chromosome in most species, suggesting it is the ancestral kary of Diptera. However, some species have undifferentiated sex chromosomes, others replaced the dot with a different chromosome, or incorporated up to three elements into sex chromosomes, and some have female heterogamy (ZW) sex. Transcriptome analysis showed dosage compensation evolved through upregulation of single X in males, but X chromosomes have fewer genes with male-bi expression, possibly due to sex-specific pressures.
A study investigated the presence of Zika virus (ZIK) antibodies in mothers who gave birth to babies with microcephaly and those who gave birth to healthy babies in Hawaii between 2009-2012. Blood samples from 18 mothers who delivered babies with microaly and 12 who gave birth to healthy babies were tested for ZIK IgM and IgG antibodies using a commercially available ELISA kit. Results showed that 16.6% of mothers who delivered babies with microaly tested positive for ZIK IgM and 50% tested positive for ZV IgG. There was a trend towards significance between ZV and microaly.
