Mothers with ZV IgG antibodies were more likely to deliver babies with microaly than those without (OR 11.0, 95% CI 0.8-147.9, p.0.083). Similarly, ZV IgM positive mothers were more likely to deliver babies with microaly than those without (OR 6.8, 95 CI 0.2-195.1). These findings suggest a link between Z infection and microaly and presence of Z cases in the US as early as 2009.
Researchers investigated the transmission of Mycobacterium ulcerans (MU), the causative agent of Buruli ulcer (BU), in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Despite previous associations with slow-moving water bodies, the mode of transmission remains unclear. Variable Number Tand Repeat (VN) typing was used to differentiate MU from other mycobacteria. This study aimed to track MU infections to specific water bodies by matching VN profiles of human samples to environmental samples. Environmental samples were collected from 10 water bodies in four endemic communities. Four VN loci in the MU genome were used to genotype environmental and human isolates. Sequencing confirmed polymorphism. MU was present in three types of water bodies, significantly higher in biofilm. Four genotypes, W, X, Y, and Z, were typed in both human and environmental samples. Other genotypes were only found in water. An animal was identified with characteristic BU lesion, confirmed MU infection. Findings suggest patients may have been infected from community water bodies. Further, evidence suggests small mammals within communities susceptible to MU. Infections.
This study investigates the global distribution and drivers of alien species richness, specifically focusing on birds, to understand the factors influencing the introduction and persistence of non-native species in various regions. An extensive database of alien bird species was analyzed to determine the determinants of global species richness within a taxonomic class. Results show that the origin and introduction of alien birds, as well as their identities, were primarily driven by European (mainly British) colonial activities. However, recent introductions have become more widespread, involving more species and countries, driven by increasing economic activities. Globally, alien species richness is highest at mid-latitudes and strongly influenced by anthropogenic factors, notably the number of introduced species (colonization pressure). Environmental factors also play a role, with native and alien richness being positively associated. Colonization pressure is key to understanding species richness, with areas of high native richness resistant to alien colonization at a global scale. The study highlights ongoing threats to environments from species introductions.
Upstream Binding Factor (UBF) is a multi-HMG-box protein that plays a role in RNA polymerase I (RPI) transcription. However, its poor DNA selectivity and ability to form nucleosome-like complexes suggest a broader chromatin function. Depletion of UBF reduces rRNA genes, but not synthesis or proliferation, leaving RPI transcription unclear. Mouse deletion shows UBF is essential for embryo development. Conditional deletion in cells reveals UBF is essential for rRNA transcription and chromatin conformation. Loss of U prevents SL/TIFB initiation and RPI-R3/T1 complex recruitment, accompanied by H3K9, H1, and HPα, but not DNA methylation. Genes retain H4 and H2, suggesting active state. H1 binding is U-dependent, suggesting positive role. Unexpectedly, rRNA synthesis does not suppress 5, tRNA or snRNA, or several mRNA genes in ribosome biogenesis. Loss U induces somatic nucleolar body (NPB) formation, containing synthesis factors but not r loci.
Wingless/Wnt signaling plays a crucial role in cell proliferation and fate specification in metazoans, and its overactivation is linked to the development of most colorectal cancers. In the conventional model, Wingless secretion and movement are necessary for long-range signaling in tissue patterning. However, a recent study found that replacing wild-type Drosophila Wingless with a membrane-tether form produced viable adults with normal morphology, suggesting Wingless secretion and movement are dispensable for patterning. This study investigates the role of Wingless in the adult intestine, where gradients coincide with major compartment boundaries. Results show that Wingless is essential for regulating gene activation, boundary formation, stem cell proliferation, epithelial cell specification, muscle differentiation, gut folding, and signaling with the Decapentapic pathway, all disrupted by Wing tethering. These findings support the requirement for direct, long-range Wingless action in patterning, relevant to development, tissue homeostasis, and Wnt-driven disease.
Researchers have investigated the role of urokinase plasogen activator (uPA) in the pathogenesis of Group A streptococcus (GAS), a bacterium responsible for significant morbidity and mortality worldwide. They found that uPA contributes to plasmin recruitment and invasive disease initiation in vivo. In the absence of host plasogen activators, streokinase (S) is required for surface plmin acquisition by GAS. However, in the absence of S, uPA is sufficient for surface plmin acquisition by GAS when incubated with plasogen or human plasma. GAS also activates zym pro-uPA in human plasma. To assess uPA's contribution to invasive disease, a transgenic mouse model was used. C57/BL/6 and AlbG mice expressing human plasogen were more susceptible to invasive GAS than u− mice. The decrease in virulence in u− mice correlated with decreased dissemination and reduced surface plmin by GAS. These findings have implications for understanding GAS pathogenesis and targeting plmin activation in bacterial infections.
Helicobacter pylori exploits a unique repertoire of Type IV secretion system components for pilus assembly at the bacteria-host interface. The pathogenic island (cPA) of H. pylori encodes components of a Type IV secretion system (TSS) that translocates the oncoprotein Cag into gastric epithelial cells, and Cag is a specialized component of cTSS that binds host α5β1 integrin. Mass spectrometry-based co-purification revealed Cag, C (integrin-binding protein), and C (protein with sequence similarity to C) as encoded by contiguous genes in cPA and detectable on the bacterial surface. These proteins are required for C translocation into host cells and H. pyl-induced IL-8 secretion by epithelial cells, but are not homologous to TSS components in other species. Scanning electron microscopy shows these proteins involved in pilus formation between H. pyl and epithelial cells. Δag and Δ mutant strains fail to form pilus, whereas Δ strain exhibits hyperiliated phenotype and produces elongated pilus compared to wild-type. This suggests pilus dimensions regulated by. A conserved C-terminal hexapeptide in, C, C, and is present in C, C, and C. Deletion motifs abrogates C translocation and IL-8 induction, and motifs C and are required for pilus formation. These results indicate C, C, C, and C components of T subassembly involved pilogenesis and highlight unique constituents H. pyl cTSS.
Bovine tuberculosis (bTB) is a chronic disease in cattle caused by Mycobacterium bovis, a member of the Mycobacterium tuberculosis group of bacteria. Vaccination is a potential long-term solution for controlling the disease, with a focus on developing a vaccine against bTB. Identifying biomarkers of tuberculosis remains elusive, and the goal is to identify host correlates of protection. Researchers hypothesized that studying global gene expression could identify in vitro predictors of protection to facilitate vaccine development. Cattle were vaccinated with BCG or heterologous B prime-adenoviral vectored subunit boosting. Protective efficacy was determined after M bovis challenge. challenge. RNA was prepared from PPD-stimulated PBMC from vaccinated-protected, vaccinated-unprotected, and unvaccinated control prior to Mbo challenge. Gene expression was determined by RNAseq. 668 genes were differentially expressed in vaccinated-protected compared to vaccinated-un and unacc control. Cytokine-cytokine interaction was most related to this dataset with IL22 identified as dominant of protection besides INFγ. Expression of these genes by RNAseq was evaluated by RTPCR in independent PB samples BCG vaccinated unacc. This confirmed IL as predictor of vaccine efficacy.
Researchers have investigated the role of centrosomal microtubule components in regulating microtule organization at non-centrosomal microtule organizing centers (ncMTO) in differentiated cells. They developed a tissue-specific degradation system to study the function of the γ-tubulin ring complex (γ-TRC) and AIR-1/Aurora at the apical MTO in Caenorhabditis elegans embryonic intestinal epithelial cells. Results show that G-1/G3, a core component of γ-T, is required to recruit other γ-T components to the apical MTO, including MT1/MT1, which is characterized for the first time in animal development. In contrast, AIR-1 and MT recruit γ-T to the centrosome but not centrioles or apical MTO. Surprisingly, microtules remain organized at apical MTO upon γ-T and AIR co-depletion and depletion of other microule regulators. However, loss of G-1 removes dynamic microules marked by EBP/1 and remaining microules grow faster. These findings suggest distinct microule centers use different proteins for function and apical M is composed of γ-dependent and microules competing for limited resources.
Human genomes are diploid, inheriting one set of chromosomes paternally and one homologous set maternally, but most sequencing initiatives ignore this by not delineating nucleotide content of maternal and paternal copies. To address this, 11 phasing strategies were compared using the Genome-In-A Bottle (GIAB) version of NA78 as a standard. Approaches included laboratory-based assays and computational methods reconstructing information from sequencing reads or population haplotype frequencies. Metrics used to assess performance included switch rates, haplotype lengths, proportion of fully-resolved genes, phasing accuracy, and yield between pairs of SNVs. A hybrid approach combining population phasing, genome sequencing data, and reference haplotype frequencies provided fast and accurate phasing. Population-based phasing was enhanced with genome-wide data, and inclusion of parental genotypes reduced phasing errors by up to ten-fold. A majority voting scheme for consensus haplotype construction improved performance and coverage. Regions with phasing errors were associated with low polymorphism and SNV density.
Type-III secretion systems in Gram-negative pathogens, such as Salmonella enterica, facilitate the export of virulence factors and flagellar subunits from the cytoplasm into host cells. The flagellar type-III secretion apparatus relies on the proton motive force and ATP hydrolysis to energize substrate unfolding and translocation. However, research has shown that functional flagella can form in the absence of type-III ATPase activity. Mutations increased the proton motive force and flagellar substrate levels, bypassing the requirement for the Salmonella pathogenic island 1 vir-associated type-III ATPase. This suggests a role for type-III ATPases in enhancing secretion efficiency under limited substrate concentrations. The study reveals the dispensability of ATP activity in the type-III export process.
Researchers investigated the emergence of bistability in gene regulatory networks (GRNs) using a comprehensive in silico survey of over 40,000 simple networks formed by two transcription factor (TF) genes and their associated proteins, assuming elementary biochemical processes. They found that approximately 90% of these GR models exhibit bistability, including some without cooperative interactions commonly associated with bistable systems, and most identified through subnetwork analysis. Bistable networks were topologically sorted into a family based on presence/absence of biochemical reactions, revealing 11 minimal bistable networks (i.e., bistable without smaller subnetwork). The large number of unknown bistable topologies suggests bistability arises easily and is not lost through evolution. To demonstrate applicability, they integrated protein-protein, protein-DNA, and expression data from Saccharomyces cerevisiae, identifying GRNs predicted bistable behavior.
Mutations in the HYAL2 gene, which encodes hyaluronidase 2, a protein responsible for degrading extracellular hyaluronic acid, have been identified as a cause of orofacial cleft syndrome in humans and mice. Orofacial cleft is a common birth defect with both genetic and environmental components, and the genetic etiology of this condition is not fully understood. The study found that mutations in HY2 destabilize the protein, leading to reduced levels of HY2 protein, consistent with clinical presentation in affected individuals. Investigations of Hy2- mice revealed craniofacial abnormalities, including submucal cleft palate, and coratri sinister and hearing loss in a proportion of Hy2- mice. These features were incompletely penetrant in humans. The findings identify a new genetic cause of orofacial cleft in humans and the first cause of coratri sinister in humans, highlighting the importance of HY2 and hyal turnover for normal development.
Researchers have identified the molecular composition of mechanosensory links in auditory hair cells, which are crucial for sound detection in the inner ear. These links connect stereocilia to transduction channels, allowing force to be converted into electrical signals. Previous models suggested a static composition of protocadherin 15 (PCD15) at the lower end and cadherin 23 (CD23) at the upper end. However, these links are subjected to sound-induced forces throughout life and can be disrupted, leading to hearing loss. Despite hair cells' ability to regenerate links and restore hearing, the molecular process was unknown. A novel implementation of backscatter electron microscopy allowed visualization of immuno-gold particles and stereilia, only a few nanometers in diameter, revealing two functional mechanotrans-mediating link compositions: PCD15/CD23 and PCD15PC15. During regeneration, shorter links with equal PCD15 at both ends appear first, mediating mechanotrans currents of normal amplitude but abnormal Ca2-dependent decay. The mature P15CD23 composition is re-established with complete adaptation recovery. These findings provide a mechanism for regeneration and maintenance of mechanensory function in postotic hair cells, potentially identifying components of the mechanotrans machinery.
Researchers conducted a mass spectrometry-based metabolomic analysis of sera from adult patients with deng fever (DF) and deng hemorrhagic fever (DHF) at the critical and recovery phases of infection. The study identified 29 differentially expressed metabolites between DF and DHF, including bile acids, purines, acylcarnitines, phospholipids, and amino acids. Bile acids were 5-fold higher in DH compared to DF and correlated with higher levels of aspartate transaminase (AST) and alanine transamin (ALT), indicating liver injury in DH. Uric acid, the most abundant antioxidant in blood, was 1.5-fold lower in DH compared to DF, suggesting decreased endogenous antioxidant capacity and elevated oxidative stress in DH. In the recovery phase, eight metabolites remained significantly higher or lower in DH, including chenodeoxycocholic acid, a bile acid. This indicates prolonged liver impact of DENV in DH patients. The study revealed metabolic pathways linked to DH in critical and recovery phases, providing insights into host-DENV interactions between DF and DH. The findings advance understanding of DH pathogenesis and suggest novel targets for deng management.
Researchers have identified and characterized the guanine 5'-monophosphate reductase (GMPR) enzyme in Trypanosoma brucei, the parasite responsible for African trypanosomiasis. GR catalyzes the conversion of guanine 5'-monophosphate (GMP) to inosine 5'-monosphate (IMP), a crucial for purine nucleotide interconversion and intracellular balance. The study found GR localized to glycosomes in T. bruce bloodstream forms. Recombinant protein analysis revealed distinct enzymatic differences between T. bruce GR and host GRs. T. br GR contains a unique cystathion synthase (CBS) domain insertion absent in mammalian and bacterial GRs. Recombinant T. br GR catalyzed GMP to IMP conversion with NAD, exhibiting distinct affinities for G and NAD compared to mammalian GRs. Addition of monovalent cations K+ and NH4 enhanced T. br GR activity, whereas mammalian GRs were unaffected. Monophosphate purine analog ribavir inhibited T br GR, whereas mammalian GR showed little inhibition. These findings indicate distinct GR mechanisms in T. br and host organisms. Ribavir inhibited trypanosome proliferation in a dose-dependent manner, suggesting ribavir as a potential therapeutic agent against African trypanomias.
Researchers have used molecular dynamics simulations to study the binding of benzocaine and phenyto, two sodium channel blockers, to the bacterial voltage-gated sodium channel NavAb. The study aimed to understand how these drugs interact with the channel and enter it, which is crucial for developing next-generation drugs that target specific types of sodium channels in the body. The simulations revealed two binding sites for both drugs, characterized by non-specific hydrophobic interactions: one above the activation gate and at the entrance to the lipid-filled fenestrations. Three independent methods confirmed these sites, with binding to the gate being slightly more favorable than the fenstration. The drugs were found to pass through the fenestrations with small energy barriers, suggesting this could be the hydrophobic route for entry. The study highlights the importance of specific residues in directing drugs through the fenestr and forming binding sites.
Researchers investigated the role of MyD88 signaling in the immune response to intestinal infection with the pathogen C. rodium in mice. My88-deficient mice are highly susceptible to various bacterial infections, but the specific contribution of My88 in intestinal immunity is unclear. A novel My88 knock-in model allowed cell-specific reactivation of functional My88 in My-deficient mice. My88 signaling in CD11+ dendritic cells activated dendritic cells (DC) and induced group 3 innate lymphoid cell (ILC) and colonic Th17/Th cell responses to C. rodium infection. Restricting My88 to other cells, including macrophages, T cells, or ILC did not induce effective responses. However, My88 expression in intestinal epithelial cells (IEC) partially protected against infection, associated with enhanced epithelial integrity and antimicrobial peptide RegIII and acute protein SAA expression. My88 in DC and IEC is essential for full host response to C. rodium.
Modelling Anti-Ov16 IgG Antibody Prevalence as an Indicator for Evaluation and Decision Making in Oncherciasis Elimination Programmes

Onchiasis, a parasitic disease targeted for elimination in Africa through annual or biannual iverectin mass administration (MDA), relies on immunodiagnostic tools to determine if transmission is interrupted and treatment can stop. One such tool is the detection of human IgG antibodies in blood to Onocervulus-specific antigen Ov16. A mathematical model, ONOS, was extended to include Ov antibody output, assuming seroconversion triggered by first worm establishment in host, with sero occurring before or after maturation or start of mf production. Seroconversion in children is of interest, with seroreversion ignored for simplification. Yearly MDA reduces parasite acquisition in humans, lowering sero rate in newborns and children, while those serconverted remain positive. Microfilaria prevalence in 5+ and Ov antibody in children under 10 decline with M duration. Association between indicators and predicted elimination probability is influenced by endemic levels, serconversion trigger, and diagnostic sensitivity/specificity. Baseline levels and test characteristics affect interpretation of seropre data and endpoint M estimation. The study shows endpoint depends on endemic levels, to be considered in guidelines for stopping MDA.
Researchers have discovered that prion strains can change properties when propagated in different environments. In one study, swine-sensitive prions were propagated in PK cells in the presence of swainine, resulting in drug-resistant variants emerging. This suggests that prions comprise a quasi-population of variants with different properties, with the fittest being selected in a particular environment. Even after cloning, prion populations remain heterogeneous, indicating mutation-like processes occur at the conformation level. Brain-derived 22 prions are naturally swine-resistant, so it was not surprising that prions became sensitive after propagation in cells could revert to resistance. RMLions, both propagated in brain or PK cells, are swine-sensitive. Researchers investigated whether swine-resistant variants could be selected by propagation in presence of drug. This was not possible with standard PK cells, but certain PK sublines yielded swine-resistant, even swine-dependent (i.e., propagated rapidly in presence drug) populations. These could be passaged indefinitely in PK cells, absence drug, without swine dependence. Misfolded pr protein (Pr) associated with swine variant was cleared PK cells than drug-sensitive counterpart, indicating structural differences misfold Pr underlie pr properties. Propagation pr in inhibitory drug selects drug-resistant pr, even variants efficiently propagate presence drug. Conformation changes abnormal pr protein underlie adaptations.
Researchers conducted an exhaustive analysis of a genotype-phenotype space comprising 101 central metabolisms that encode all possible subsets of 51 reactions in carbon metabolism. Using flux balance analysis, they predicted the viability of these metabolisms on 10 different carbon sources, resulting in 102 potential phenotypes. Viable metabolisms with one phenotype comprise a tiny fraction of genotype space, but their numbers exceed 10^9 for phenotypes. Metabolisms with one phenotype form a network of genotypes extending throughout genotype space, where two genotypes can be reached through single reaction changes. Minimal genotype distance between different phenotypes is small, allowing metabolisms to reach novel phenotypes on new carbon sources through few genic changes. Exceptions exist for metabolisms with complexity near minimum viability threshold. Increasing complexity enhances potential for both conservation and innovation.
Researchers analyzed the genetic variation and phylogeography of the Triatoma dimata complex, a group of triatomine bugs that transmit Trypanosoma cruzi, the parasite causing Chagas disease, across Mexico and the Neotropics. Two fragments of the ND4 gene were sequenced to determine haplog specificity. The study found lowest genetic diversity where there is most anthropic modification, and highest T cruz infection prevalence. Haplog 1 and 3 had higher T cruz prevalence than expected, while hap 2 had lower. Hap 1 and 3 had different DT and DTI frequencies, while hap 2 did not. All Neotrop haplogroups had moderate to high haplotype diversity, with greatest differentiation between hap 1 and 3. Divergence from the most recent common ancestor (MRCA) was estimated between 0.97 and 0.85 million years ago. Effective population size of hap 1 and 2 increased between 0.02 and 0.03 million years ago. This study supports the ecological origin of the complex around the Tehuantepec Isthmus and recent divergence of three dimata haplog with differential T cruz infection and DT specificity.
Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFR) is a rod-borne disease caused by hantaviruses, primarily Hanta and Seoul virus, in China. Environmental factors significantly affect the risk of contracting havirus infections through their impact on rodent dynamics and human-rod contact. This study aimed to clarify environmental factors favoring rod-to-human transmission to inform effective FR prevention and control strategies. A 10-year (2006-2015) surveillance of rod hosts, havirus, epidemiological, and environmental data from satellite and meteorological stations, and rod-to rates were analyzed to quantify relationships among environmental, rod species, and FR occurrence. 709 FR cases were included. Rod species in Chhou, havirus hotspot, comprised Rattus norvegicus, Musculus, R flavius, and others (lose and Microtus calamorum). Species played different roles across land types, all associated with transmission. Some were with FR in forest and water bodies, R norveicus and flavius in grassland, and Mculus flavi in built. Community was associated with environmental variability. Predictive models based on significant factors validated a good fit: cultivated land predicted highest FR incidence, aligning with 2014-15 statistics. Spatial FR heterogeneity may be influenced by community, associated local conditions.
Activating mutations in the HRAS proto-oncogene, specifically in codon 12, can cause Costello syndrome (CS), a rare genetic disorder. Mutations in codon 12, particularly Gly12Val, have high transforming activity and are frequent in cancers, but rare in CS, leading to a severe and lethal phenotype. A novel germline GlyVal mutation, c.35_36GC>T, was identified in a 12-year-old boy with attenuated CS. Analysis of HRAS cDNA revealed high levels of exon 2 skipping. Using wild and mutant HRAS minigenes, c.35_36>T was confirmed to result in exon 2 skipping by disrupting a critical Exonic Splicing Enhancer (SE) and creating Exonic Splicing Silencer (SS). The HR exon 2 vulnerability is due to a weak 3' splice site, making exon 2 dependent on splicing stimulatory protein, SRS, binding to critical SE. Most CS and cancer-causing mutations are located here, affecting splicing differently. Results show that CS and somatic cancer phenotypes are determined not only by mutant HRAS transforming potential, but also exon 2 inclusion efficiency from HRAS mutations. A splice oligonucleotide (SO) blocking critical SE causes exon skipping and halts cancer cell proliferation. This reveals potential for anti-cancer therapies based on SO-mediated HR exon 2 skipping.
Researchers have investigated the role of N6-methyladenosine (m6A) RNA methylation in mammalian development, specifically focusing on the function of the methyltransferase-like 3 (METTL3) enzyme in this process. MET3 is a key component of the methyltransfer complex responsible for catalyzing m6 formation on RNAs. In this study, MET3 was inactivated in the mouse nervous system to examine its effects on development. The results show that MET3 knockout (KO) mice exhibit cerebellar hypoplasia, a condition characterized by underdevelopment of the cerebellum, due to increased apoptosis of cerebellar granule cells (CGs) in the external granular layer (EGL). MET3 depletion led to loss of mA modification, resulting in extended RNA half-lives and aberrant splicing events, causing dysregulation of gene expression and premature death of CGs. These findings highlight the importance of MET3-mediated mA in regulating mammalian cerebell development.
Researchers have investigated the role of transcription factors OCT4, SOX2, and NANOG in regulating gene expression in embryonic stem (ES) cells. These factors are essential for maintaining the cells' ability to differentiate into any cell type in the developing embryo. The study found that combinatorial binding of these factors is associated with co-localization of the transcription coactivator H3 and increased expression of nearby genes in ES cells. The same loci bound by OCT, NAN, and SOX in ES cells drive expression in early embryonic development. Comparison of human and mouse ES cells revealed that less than 5% of individual binding events for OCT, SO2, and NANOG are shared between species. However, about 15% of combinatorial binding events and 53-63% of combinatorial binding at enhancers active in early development are conserved. The study suggests that combination of OCT, SO2, and NANOG is critical for transcription in ES and plays a role in embryogenesis by binding conserved developmental enhancers. Data indicate that rewiring of regulatory networks mainly affects individual events, whereas "regulatory hotspots" bound by multiple factors and active in multiple tissues early development are under evolutionary constraints.
AML/ETO, a fusion protein resulting from a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 8 and 21, is an oncogenic transcription factor that initiates acute myeloid leukemia by recruiting co-repressor complexes to DNA. It interferes with the function of its wild-type counterpart, A1, by targeting A1 binding sites. A1ETO's transcriptional regulation is complex, as it interacts with multiple transcription factors, including E-proteins, and targets other DNA sites. Genome-wide chromatin immunoprecipitation and expression profiling identified A1-dependent regulation. A1 was found to co-localize with A, demonstrating the fusion follows the binding pattern of the wild protein but does not primarily displace it. E-protein H's DNA binding profile was rearranged upon A1 expression, and the fusion co-localized with A and H on many regulated targets. H levels increased in primary and cell lines expressing A1.
Researchers investigated the role of histone acetyltransferase 2 (H2) in Leishmania donovani, a parasite that causes leishmaniasis. They found that H2 is constitutively acetylates histone H4 at lysine 10 (H4K10) in vitro and in vivo, and is essential for cell growth and survival. H2-depleted cells displayed cell cycle defects and poor survival in host cells. Real-time PCR and DNA microarray analyses revealed that downregulation of cyclins CY4 and CY9 were responsible for S and G/M phase defects in H2-depleted cells. Leish genes are arranged in unidirectional clusters, with genes coordinately transcribed as polyc units from divergent strand regions (dSRs) which initiate transcription on opposite strands. Investigating CY4 and CY9 expression in H2-de cells without other genes in polyc units being coordinately downregulated, found CY4 and CY9 have specific promoters. Chromatin immunoprecipitation with Hacetyl10 and real PCR suggested these promoters were activated cell-dependent. Nuclear-on analyses confirmed CY and CY were transcriptionally activated from own at specific stages. Two tiers of regulation exist: polyc units initiate at SR, likely constitutively, and subset have own promoters, some activated cell-dependent. Second tier sensitive H10 levels, resulting downregulation in H-de cells.
Researchers investigated the mechanisms underlying inferring others' intentions in social interactions by applying computational modeling to data from an economic game involving 16 pairs of volunteers. Participants were randomly assigned "player" or "adviser" roles, with the player performing a probabilistic reinforcement task and receiving information about a binary lottery from a visual chart. The adviser, with more information, issued a recommendation. The game's structure varied the adviser's incentives to provide helpful or misleading information over time. Using a meta-Bayesian framework, the players' behavior was best explained by hierarchical learning, inferring the adviser's intentions to optimize predictions about advice validity. Volatility estimates affected trial-by-trial variability: participants relied on estimates for choices when believing adviser intentions were stable. The model predicted players' interpersonal reactivity index (IRI) scores, adviser helpfulness ratings, and self-reported strategy. Results suggest humans employ hierarchical models to infer changing intentions, use volatility in decision-making, and integrate accuracy with non-social information.
Scrub typhus, a disease endemic in Asia, has shifted from a rural to urban setting in South Korea, particularly in Seoul, the country's largest metropolitan city. From 2010 to 2013, national notifiable disease data identified indigenous urban scrub typh in Seoul. Clinical features of patients were analyzed by comparing a hospital-reported cases to a control group. Chigger mites were collected in the city using a direct chigger-collecting trap and identified by phenic and 18 rDNA sequencing. Infection with Orientia tsutsugam was confirmed by 56-kDa antigen sequencing. Eighty cases of urban typhus were found in Seoul, with 56.8% from mountain areas, 20.5% from parks, 17% from vicinity of residence, and 5.7% from riversides. Eighty-seven chigger mites were collected in Gwan mountain, with 87.4% identified as Helenula miag and 9.2 as Leptromium scell. Pooled DNA from H miag mites yielded O tsugushi Bong strain. Twenty-six patients showed low APACHE score 3.4 ± 2.7, low complication rate 3.8%, and no hypalemia. Indigenous urban typh was identified in Seoul, with a subgroup having mild features. Chigger H miag infected O tsugushi within the city was found.
Researchers investigated the impact of the Caenorhabditis elegans HEN1 RNA methyltransferase homolog, HENN-1, on RNA interference (RNAi) pathways in the nematode. They found differential effects on two pathways that employ methylated RNA molecules: the 26 and 21 pathways. In the germline, stability of 21 RNAs, C elegans piRNAs, was mildly affected by loss of methylation, and introduction of artificial 21 target RNA did not destabilize non-methylated 21 RN. In contrast, 26 RN displayed reduced stability and responded to loss of H-1 by increased 3-uridylation. Within the 26 class, ER-bound RNAs were modified by H-, while AL-bound RN were not. Global expression analysis of mutants revealed mild effects, including downregulation of gerine-expressed genes. Data suggest apart from direct effects reduced 26 levels, effects on expression were indirect.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) and high-throughput glycomics analysis on 2,705 individuals from three populations to investigate the genetic regulation of protein glycosylation. They found that variants in the Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 1 (HNF1) and fucosyltransferase FUT6 and F8 genes influence N-glycan levels in human plasma. NF1 and its downstream target NF4 regulate the expression of fucyltransfer and fucose biosynthesis genes. NF1 is necessary and sufficient to drive the expression of these genes in hepatic cells. The study reveals NF as a master regulator of multiple stages in the fucylation process. This has implications for the regulation of immunity, embryonic development, and protein folding, as well as understanding mechanisms underlying cancer, coronary disease, heart, and metabolic disorders.
Researchers have investigated the role of single-stranded RNA in stabilizing the binding of Centromere Protein C (CPC), a key component of the kinetochore complex that attaches chromosomes to the cytoskeleton. The study found that a 122-amino acid region of CPC is responsible for DNA binding, and that this interaction is highly sensitive to single-stranded RNA. Long, single-stranded nucleic acids enhance CPC binding to DNA, and the types of RNAs that stabilize CPC binding match those present in kinetochores in vivo. Removal of the binding module with HIV integrase domain causes partial delocalization of CPC in vivo. The study suggests that centrom RNA recruits CPC to kinetore by altering DNA binding characteristics.
A genome-wide association study (GWAS) identified genetic variants associated with birth weight (BW), childhood obesity (CO), and body mass index (BMI) in children. The placenta plays a crucial role in fetal development and postnatal health. This study examined the role of the placental transcriptome and expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) in mediating genetic causes of BW, CO, and CBMI. An integrative analysis of colocalization and meta-analysis revealed that GWAS loci associated with BW, CO, and CBMI were enriched for placental eQTL (6.76, 4.83, and 2.26 folds, respectively). Compared to eQTL in adult tissues, placental eQ significantly contributed to anthropometric outcomes at birth (BW) and childhood phenotypes (CO/CBMI). Six and one transcripts colocalized with BW, CO, and CBMI risk loci, respectively. The study found that placental transcription in utero likely determines postnatal body size, suggesting new possibilities for interventions to prevent childhood obesity.
A study was conducted in Malda district, West Bengal, India to investigate the prevalence and diagnosis of Post-Kala-azar Dermatitis Leishmaniasis (PKDL) in an endemic area. PKDL is a chronic, non-fatal disease that does not require much attention, but is relevant in the context of Visceralishmanias (VL) elimination. There is no standard guideline for diagnosis and treatment. The study aimed to determine the disease burden, compare diagnostic tools, and lesion regression pattern after treatment. Twenty-six PK cases were detected, with a prevalence of 27.5% among Leishmanial antibody positive cases. Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) on skin smear showed 93.8% sensitivity, but is not used for routine diagnosis. PCR was highly sensitive (88.46%) for confirmation. Most lesions persisted after treatment, disappearing 6-12 months post-treatment. Two cases relapsed after 1.5 years milteine treatment. A significant number of PK patients remained undiagnosed without active surveys. Surveys are needed in other areas for VL elimination. PCR is helpful for diagnosis, referral at district or state level. A study with more samples is needed to determine if PK patients are parasite-free after treatment and which need longer treatment.
In the bacterium Streptococcus pneumoniae, competence is a genetic program that enables horizontal gene transfer through transformation, allowing the exchange of genetic material between cells. This process is synchronized within the entire population and relies on the exported Competence Stimulating Peptide (CSP), which generates a positive feedback loop. However, the coordination of this CSP-dependent switch is unclear. Researchers monitored competence development in real-time in four distinct pneumocococcal lineages and found that the population shift relies on a self-activated fraction that arises through a growth-dependent mechanism. CSP remains bound to cells during this event and the rate of competence corresponds to propagation between activated and quiescent cells. A two-step cell-contact mechanism was validated by measuring development during co-cultivation of strains altered to produce or respond to CSP. The membrane protein ComD retains CSP, limiting its diffusion in the medium. Competence initiator cells originate stochastically in response to stress, forming a subpopulation that transmits CSP by cell contact.
Human papillomavirus type 16 (HPV) L2 protein acts as a chaper to facilitate the transport of the viral genome (vDNA) from endosomes to the trans-Golgi network (TGN) and eventually the nucleus, where replication occurs. To reach the nucleus, the L2/v complex must cross intracellular membranes. A system was developed using subcellular compartmentalization of BirA and its substrate to detect L2 translocation from incoming virions. L trans requires transport to the TGN and is strictly dependent on mitotic entry, coinciding with mitotic entry in synchronized cells. Cell cycle arrest retains L/v at T; only release and progression G/M enables trans across the membrane and infection. Microscopy of Ed-labeled vDNA reveals a rapid shift in v localization during mitosis. At G2/phase v exits the T to pericentricular location, accumulating prometaph where it begins to associate with chromosomes. By metaphase and anaph v is bound to mitotic chromosomes, ensuring distribution into daughter nuclei. Mutations in a defined chromatin binding of L block trans, suggesting trans dependent on chromatin promet. This is the first virus to couple penetration of membranes to mitosis, explaining tropism for mitotic keratinocytes.
Researchers have developed a mathematical framework to estimate the relative transmissibility of one strain of a pathogen to another by analyzing data from competitive mixture experiments where animals are co-infected with two strains. The method involves observing the mixture in each animal over time and multiple generations. This approach is demonstrated using influenza data from ferrets. Assessing the transibility between strains is crucial in three contexts: within human populations where novel strains compete for susceptible hosts, during pandemics where a novel strain competes with existing strains, and with neuraminidase inhibitors (NAIs) which can reduce transmission but promote drug-resistant strains. The framework also estimates the size of the transmitted inoculum. The method's applicability extends beyond influenza to other viral and bacterial pathogens.
Researchers investigated the convergence of light and abscisic acid (ABA) signaling pathways in Arabidopsis thaliana to understand how plants adapt to environmental cues. They found that BBX21, a B-box protein involved in seedling photomorphogenesis, also plays a role in ABA signaling. Genetic data showed BB21 acts upstream of ABA INSENSITIVE (ABI) and ELONGATED HYCOTYL5 (HY) in seed germination control. HY5 acts as a direct activator of ABI5, and BB21 interacts with HY. BB21 negatively regulates ABI5 by interfering with HY binding to the ABI promoter. ABI was shown to activate its own expression, while BB21 negatively regulates this activity by interacting with ABI. The study indicates BB21 coordinates with HY and ABI on the ABI promoter, integrating light and ABA signaling in Arabidopsis.
The Mediator complex, a co-regulator of RNA polymerase II, is conserved across eukaryotes, has been studied in the pathogenic fungus Candida albicans. This study focused on the Med subunits Med31, Med20, and Srb/Med13. C. albicans Med shares functions with Saccharomyces cerevisiae and Schoscharomyces pombe, such as response to stresses and Med31's role in Ace2-regulated genes. However, C. albicans Med has additional roles in virulence gene transcription, including morphogenesis and pathogen-related genes like ALS. Med31,20, and Srb/M13 contribute to C. alb's virulence, filamentation, biofilm formation, and ALS1 is a target for biofilm development. Med also affects C. alb virulence in the worm model. Med31 and Srb13 regulate cell adhesion genes differently in S. cerevisiae and C. alb, repressing FLO in S. cereiae and activating ALS in C. alb. This suggests Med subunits regulate adhesion distinct between species.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilms exhibit increased antibiotic tolerance compared to their planktonic counterparts, a phenomenon known as antibiotic tolerance. To investigate the contribution of the biofilm state and its genetic determinants to this phenotype, a genome-wide functional profiling was conducted on a heterogeneous population of Pseudomonas aeruginosa MPA1 in biofilm and plankic growth conditions with tobramycin. The study aimed to quantify the contribution of each locus to antibiotic tolerance in both states, identifying sets of mutations contributing to tolerance in biofilm or plankic settings. Results revealed differences and similarities between biofilm and plankic antibiotic tolerance. A mixed population design was used to replicate the complexity of natural biofilms, unlike previous studies, showing emergence of quorum-deficient mutants. The study found a significant contribution of the bio state to antibiotic tolerance, providing a basis for novel therapeutics against P aerugin biofilm infections.
Researchers have developed a new algorithm, called Flexible and Adaptive Model (FoS), to analyze complex biological systems with numerous interacting components and limited information about their dynamics. Traditional model selection algorithms evaluate multiple models against experimental data to identify suitable structures, but often rely on pre-selected models or exhaustive searches, which can be impractical due to the vast number of possibilities. The new algorithm combines local and non-local search methods to prevent getting stuck in local minima, accounting for structurally similar processes. It was tested on simulated data, showing flexibility in handling various structures, and applied to experimental data on CD4+ and CD8 T cell proliferation under different conditions. The analysis revealed dynamic changes in proliferation potential, reduced in 3D tissue cultures compared to suspension. The algorithm's flexibility in handling diverse structures makes it applicable to various biological problems and useful for evaluating complex model spaces.
A 12-month follow-up study was conducted in Bolivia to evaluate the effectiveness of benznidazole (BN) treatment in children infected with Trypanosoma cruzi, the parasite responsible for Chagas disease. The study involved 103 seropositive children living in areas with vector control, where the National Program for Chagas was implemented in 2006, reducing infections through vector control. 73 children received BN with 3 interruptions due to side effects. Serology, conventional PCR, and real-time PCR were performed on 7 blood samples taken before and after treatment. Among 57 who completed follow-up, 6 (11%) showed both PCR+ and qPCR+ (non-reactive), 24 (42%) PCR- but q+ (ambiguous), and 27 (47%) PCR- and q- (reactive). Th1/2/Th/17 cytokines levels were determined, with IL-17 significantly higher in seropitive before treatment compared to age-matched seronegative and decreased to normal level one year after. IL-17 levels were positively related to parasite counts by qPCR. At 12 months, IL-17 levels of non-reactive were higher than reactive or ambiguous, suggesting IL-17 useful for determining BN reactivity. Plasma IL-17 might be biomarker for persistent T. cruzi infection and chronic inflammation.
Neisseria meningitidis, the primary causative agent of bacterial meningitis, has a genome rich in repetitive DNA, with approximately 2% occupied by a diminutive transposon called Coria. Bioinformatic analysis identified eight subtypes of the element with four distinct transcriptional ends. Transcriptional analysis using PCR and lacZ reporter revealed two ends encode strong promoters. The strongest promoter activity is dictated by polymorphism Y128 at the right end of the element. Examples of elements drive transcription of adjacent genes, while others express non-coding RNAs. Pairwise comparisons of three meningocococcal genomes showed more than two-thirds of Coria elements maintain subtype at any locus due to recombination switching between elements in a single strain. Upon switching, a new allele spreads through population by natural transformation. This represents a previously unrecognized mechanism for variation in meningococcus. Strain-to-strain variability of Coria and encoded promoters allows widespread effects within population. Defining strength of promoters by subtypes provides resource to predict transcription effects of subtype at locus.
Research on the maize pathogen Cochliobolus heterostus has identified two orthologs, Chae and Vel, which regulate secondary metabolism and differentiation in response to light signals in Aspergillus spp. Chae and Vel are involved in the production of secondary metabolites, including the toxin Txin, which promotes virulence in maize with Texas sterile cytoplasm (Tms). Txin production is increased in the dark in wild-type (WT) and reduced in Chae and Vel mutants. Expression of the Txin biosynthetic gene Tox1 is upregulated in the dark in WT and reduced in Chae and Vel mutants. Txin and To1 expression are increased in Vel overexpression (OE) strains in the dark and Chae in light or dark, compared to WT. Chae and Vel regulate toxin production and virulence. Mutants and OE strains show altered virulence on Tms and normal cytoplasm maize, indicating Txin mediated virulence and pathogenicity affected. Deletion of Chae or Vel reduces H2O tolerance. Expression of CAT, a catalase gene, is reduced in Vel. Chae and Vel mutants show decreased aerial growth, asexual sporulation, and sterility. Chae OE are sterile, while Vel OE are more fertile. Ch and Vel repress 8-dihydroxynaphthalene (DH) melanin biosynthesis, melanization enhanced in Ch and Vel, reduced in OE. Chae and Vel regulate Txin biosynthesis, pathogenicity, virulence, oxidative stress, development, aerial growth, and negatively melan biosynthesis asexual differentiation.
Researchers have investigated the mechanism of functional asymmetry in bacterial Nav channels, which have been characterized as functionally asymmetric but the underlying mechanism unclear. Crystal structures of several bacterial Nav channels have been published, and molecular dynamics simulations of ion permeation through these channels consistent with electrophysiological properties of eukotic channels. To address this question, non-equilibrium simulations and two-dimensional unperturbed landscapes were generated by umbrella sampling and Weighted Histogram Methods for ions traversing the selectivity of bacterial Nav channel. This provided new insight into selective permeation mechanism in Nav channels. Non-equilibrium simulations showed that two or three extracellular K ions block the selectivity of Nav in presence applied inward forces, but not outward. Block occurs in unstable minimum equilibrium unpurbed free energy of K ions can be locked by modest forces. In contrast, Na ions favor through selectivity as unit in "knock" permeation both inward and outward, no minimum two-dimensional free energy Na for block state. Predicted non-equilibrium work to break K block equivalent experimentally measured Nav to induce inward K currents.
A study compared the intracellular spread of rabies virus in the paralytic and furious forms of canine rabies at the early stages of the disease. Researchers measured viral colonization of the cerebral hemispheres, viral antigen within neuronal cell bodies, and RNA levels of cellular processes from neuronal bodies to track the spread of the virus across synapses. A cohort of naturally infected, non-vaccinated dogs (5 paralytic and 5 furious) were sacrificed shortly after illness onset. Measurements were taken at spinal cord, brain, and cerebrum levels and compared to rabies antigen in neuronal bodies. Results showed a decrease in rab viral antigen in processes in rostral direction following the pattern of rab antigen in neuronal bodies and percentage of involved bodies, with a delay in process following body involvement consistent with replication in region and transport to processes. More antigen was seen in processes in furious compared to paraly at all examined levels, even with similar amounts, percentages, and 100% positive neurons. This suggests intracellular transport may be slower in paraly, resulting in slower propagation. Possible mechanisms involve host differences in intracellular transport, potentially cytokine-mediated, given greater inflammation in paraly form.
Researchers investigated the role of the zinc-finger protein CTC in the regulation of gene expression in Drosophila melanogaster. CTC is known to act as an enhancer-blocking factor in vertebrates, but its function in Dophila has only recently been characterized. One endogenous CTC binding site was previously identified in the Fab-8 insulator at the Abdominal locus in the Bithorax (BX) complex. Chromatin immunoprecipitation coupled with microarray analysis was used to identify CTC binding sites in representative regions of the Dophila genome, including 3-M Adh, BX, and Antennedia. In vivo CTC binding enabled the construction of a CTC binding consensus sequence. CTC sites in BX mapped to known insulators Mcp, Fab-6, and Fab8, and additional presumptive insulators Fab-2, Fab-3, and Fab4. CTC is associated with all known or predicted insulators in BX except Fab7, suggesting a common CTC-dependent mechanism. Comparison with Polycomb target sites and histone modification supports BX regulation model.
Researchers have investigated the conformational changes that occur when a ligand binds to the enzyme peptidyl peptidase. This process, known as induced fit, is crucial for enzyme catalysis as it alters the local environment of the active site to align reactive groups for efficient catalysis and the transition state. The study used a slow, tight binding inhibitor-enzyme system, actin-peptidyl peidase. Crystal structures of the initial and final states were solved, as well as intermediate states captured during the process. Ligand-induced reshaping of a hydrophobic pocket led to closure of the site, which was further secured by additional interactions. Biochemical analysis of these data allowed reconstruction of the sequence of events from encounter to key binding of the enzyme. A "movie" of the process was created, which can be extrapolated to catalysis.
Researchers investigated the role of the thalamus as a gateway for sensory information transfer to the cerebral cortex, focusing on the interaction between cortical and thalamic cells during sensory processing. Using dynamic-clamp techniques in thal slices, they simulated a hybrid retino-thalamo-cortical pathway with biological cells and circuits, mimicking cortical input through stochastic excitatory and inhibitory conductances. The study found that the efficiency of sensory transmission depends on three factors: the number of thalamocortical cells, corticothalamic synaptic statistics, and correlation between thal relay cells. Counterintuitively, retocort signal efficiency increased with decreased correlation between thal cells, suggesting synchronized relay amplification by cortical feedback.
Researchers have identified a critical role for the putative DNA demethylase NM-1 in regulating meiosis in Caenorhabditis elegans. NM-1 mutants exhibit reduced fertility due to defects in prophase I meiosis, resulting in reduced embryo production and increased incidence of males due to chromosomal segregation errors. In NM-1 worms, nuclear organization is disorganized at leptotene and zygot stages, cohesin complex is mislocalized at diplot and diak stages, and chromosomes are improperly condensed or lost by end diak. RNA sequencing of NM-1 germline reveals induction of DNA replication and damage response genes during meiosis, coupled with delayed replication, impaired repair, and apoptosis of maturing oocytes. To understand NM-1 regulation of replication and repair, immunoprecipitation mass spectrometry was used to identify NM-1 binding proteins. NM-1 binds multiple proteins regulating repair and replication, including topoisomerase TOP-2, and co-localizes with TOP-2 on chromatin. Majority of TOP-2 chromatin binding depends on NM-1. These findings suggest NM- functions at replication sites to regulate DNA and repair during meiosis.
Researchers have identified adipocyte plasma-associated protein (AAP) as a novel modulator of human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) infection. CMV is a ubiquitous pathogen that can cause serious diseases in newborns and immunocompromised patients. The virus has a large genome with coding potential and complex glycoproteins that can infect various human cells. While multiple host receptors interacting with viral glycoproteins have been reported, the mechanism of CMV infection remains unclear. This study found AAP necessary for CMV infection in epithelial and fibroblasts, with knockdown of AAP significantly reducing CMV infection in these cells. Ectopic expression of AAP in cells refractory to CMV, such as MDCK and NIH3T, promoted CMV infection. Viral early (IE) gene transcription at 6 hours post-infection and nucleus translocation tegument pp65 at 4 hours post-infection were delayed in AAP-deficient but not wildtype cells. Results suggest AAP plays a role in early CMV infection. Biochemical studies of AAP and CM proteins suggest AAP interacts with g/g containing glycoprotein at low pH and mediates tegument pp translocation. Overall, AAP functions as modulator promoting CMV in multiple cell types and important in CM mechanism.
Researchers have developed a mathematical model that combines intrinsic and extrinsic factors to understand how hematopoietic progenitor cells commit to specific lineages. The model shows that cytokine-mediated receptor feedback can induce a switch-like response to external stimuli during multilineage differentiation, providing robustness to both bipotent and committed states while protecting progenitors from noise-induced decommitment. The model supports both instructive and stochastic theories of commitment: cell fates are driven by lineage-specific transcription factors, but cytokine signaling can bias lineage commitment by regulating inherently noisy cell fate decisions with complex behaviors such as ligand ultrasensitivity and multistability. The kinetics of differentiation to a mature state depend on the progenitor state as well as the route of commitment chosen. The model agrees with lineage receptor expression kinetics from microarray experiments and provides a framework to integrate classical and alternative paths in hematies observed.
Researchers have investigated the ultrastructure of Bunyamwera virus, a prototypic member of the Orthunavirus genus within the Bunyaviridae family, using electron cryo-tomicroscopy. The virus particles are pleomorphic in shape but display a locally ordered lattice of glycoprotein spikes, each protruding 18nm from the membrane. Upon introduction to an acidic environment, the spikes become disordered. Subtom averaging revealed a three-dimensional model of the trimeric glycoprotein spike at 3nm resolution. The glycoprotein consists of a putative class-II fusion glycoprotein with a unique tripod-like arrangement. Protein-protein contacts occur at membrane-proximal regions and intra-spike at membrane-dist regions. This trimer deviates from previously observed glycoprotein arrangements, suggesting a greater repertoire of viral glycoprotein oligomerization. The study provides evidence of a pH-dependent conformation change during orthunaviral entry into host cells and a blueprint for the structure of emerging pathogens.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide association study to identify genetic factors contributing to primary angle closure glaucoma (PACG), a condition characterized by shallow anterior chamber depth (AC). The study included 5,308 individuals of Asian descent and found a significant association between a variant in the ABCC5 gene (rs199) and AC depth, with a per allele effect size of -0.045mm (P=8.17×10^-9). This association was replicated in a separate case-control study of 4,276 PG cases and 18,801 controls, with an odds ratio of 1.13 (95% CI: 1.06-1.22, P=0.000). The association was strengthened when a subgroup of controls with open angles was included, with an odds ratio of 1.30 (P=7.45×10^-3, 3,458 cases vs 3,831). The study suggests that genetic variants influencing anterior chamber dimensions may contribute to increased risk of PG.
Researchers have identified conserved developmental enhancers between deuterostomes and protomes, which share a common developmental toolkit of conserved transcription factors and signaling pathways. These conserved patterning genes show similar expression and genetic interactions, suggesting a conserved regulatory apparatus. However, previous studies found no sequence conservation between the two groups. This study describes the first enhancers, called bilaterally conserved regulatory elements (Bico), which show sequence and gene synteny conservation. Bico conservation reflects conserved transcription factor binding sites. Icos are predicted to act as response elements to signaling pathways and are shown to be developmental enhancers driving transcriptional repressors in the vertebrate nervous system.
Researchers investigated the impact of vaccination on the intrahost diversity of H3N2 influenza viruses in a randomized, placebo-controlled trial of vaccine efficacy. They used next-generation sequencing of patient-derived viruses to characterize the diversity of influenza A virus and define the effect of vaccine-induced immunity within populations. The study isolated the impact of vaccination while studying natural infection. Pre-hemagglutination and neuraminase inhibition titers quantified vaccine-induced immunity and its effect on intrah populations. 166 cases of H3N2 influenza were identified over 3 seasons and 19 years, with 119 whole-genome sequences obtained for analysis. A stringent, empirically validated pipeline identified intrah single nucleotide variants ≥1% frequency. Phylogenetic analysis of hemagglutinin and neuraminase sequences showed no stratification by pre-HAI and NAI titers. The majority of intrah single nucleotide variants were rare, with few found in more than one individual. Most samples had fewer than 15 nucleotide variants across the genome, with no significant variation by day, vaccination status, or pre-antibody titer.
Researchers investigated the effectiveness of genetically modified, live attenuated Leishmania donovani parasites (LC-/-) in inducing a protective immune response against visceral leishmaniasis (VL) in mice of different ages. VL, caused by L. donovani, is a severe disease with no vaccine available for any age group. Previous studies showed LC- induced strong immune response in young mice. This study compared LC- mediated immune response in 18-month-old (aged) and 2-month-old (young) mice. Analysis of bone marrow-derived dendritic cells (BMDCs) from infected with LC- showed enhanced effector responses, augmenting CD4+ T cell function compared to wild-type (WT) BMDCs in vitro. Splenic dendritic cells from LC- infected mice also induced pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-12, IL-6, IF-γ, TNF) and downregulated anti-inflammatory IL-10. Immunization with LC- induced IgG2 antibodies, lymphoproliferative response, pro-inflammatory cytokines, and nitric oxide production in young and aged mice. Upon virulent L. donani challenge, LC- immunized mice displayed multifunctional Th1 CD4 and cytotoxic CD8 cells, reduced parasite burden in spleen and liver. Notably, LC- induced response in dendritic cells was similar in aged and young mice, but T and B cell activation was reduced in aged, correlating with less protection. LC- immunization induced significant but diminished response in aged mice compared young.
Researchers investigated the differences in biophysical properties between enteric and respiratory enteroviruses (EVs) by generating chimeras at the capsid level between EV-D68 (respiratory) and EV-D94 (enteric). They found that some chimeras were nonfunctional, but viable constructs with the capsid 2 protease of EV68 and caps of EV94 were viable. Functional assays showed that caps proteins determine acid sensitivity and tropism in cell lines and tissues, including respiratory and intestinal and neural. Caps genes also participate in determining optimal growth temperature, as EV94 adaptation relied on VP1 mutations, while EV68 capsid constructs could not adapt to higher temperatures. Additionally, EV68 maintained binding capacity after acid treatment despite loss of infectivity, whereas nonstructural proteins modulated the immune response in tissues.
Herpes Simplex Virus 1 (HSV-1) glycoprotein gE1 (gE) is a transmembrane receptor found on the surface of infected cells and virions that binds human immunoglobulin G (Ig). It also participates in antibody bridging (ABB), a process where antigen-binding fragments (Fab) of IgG bind viral antigen while Fc binds to gE. IgFc binds gE at basic, but not acidic pH, suggesting Ig bound extracellular surface gE would dissociate and degrade in acidic endosomes/lysosomes if endocytosed. The fate of viral antigens with gE-bound Ig was unknown: they remain surface or endocyt with Ig. An in vitro system for ABB was developed to investigate trafficking of ABB using 4-D confocal imaging of complexes with transferrin epidermal growth, characterized intracellular markers. Data showed cells expressing gE and viral HSV-1 antigen endocyt antiD Ig g in gE-dependent, resulting lysosomal localization.
Researchers have investigated the transcriptome of the protoscoleces (PS) of Echinococcus granulosus, a parasite responsible for cistic hydatid disease, using Roche 454 sequencing and in silico analysis. The study generated 26,514 non-reduant sequences, of which 22,910 (86.4%) were mapped to the published E. granus genome and 17,705 (66.8%) were within coding sequence (CDS) regions. From the 2,280 predicted excretory-secretory proteins (ESPs), 138 were involved in carbohydrate metabolism, 124 in protein metabolism, and 11 intracellular enzymes regulating glycolysis/glucone (GL) pathways. Additionally, 44 antigenic proteins, 25 molecular chaperones, and 4 proteases were identified. Many proteins were enriched in development-related pathways such as TGF receptor and insulin pathways. This research provides insight into the parasite's metabolic adaptation to hosts, aiding in the development of novel intervention targets for hydat treatment and control.
In the fungus Aspergillus nidans, the transcription factor NirA plays a crucial role in regulating the assimilation of nitrate, a key nitrogen source in soil. When nitrate is absent, NirA accumulates in the nucleus and becomes transcriptionally active due to the disruption of its interaction with the export protein Kap/CRM. Mass spectrometry analysis revealed that in the absence of nitrate, NirA is predominantly cytosolic and methionine 169 in its nuclear export sequence (NES) is oxidized to methion sulfoxide (Metox). This oxidation is dependent on Fmo, a flav-containing monooxygenase that uses methion and cystine as substrates, but not glutathione. Fmo cannot be replaced by alternative F proteins in A. nidans. Exposure to nitrate leads to rapid reduction of Nir-Met169 to Met, independent of thiorexin and methion sulfox reductases. Replacing Met169 with isoleuc, a sterically similar but not oxidizable residue, results in partial loss of Nir activity and insensitivity to F-mediated export. In contrast, replacing Met with alanine transforms the protein into a permanently nuclear and active factor. Co-immoprecipitation of Nir-Kap interactions and subcellular studies of Nir mutants lacking parts of the protein show that Met oxidation leads to Nir conformation change.
Researchers have investigated the constraints that shape the evolution of voltage-gated sodium channels in mammals. These channels are crucial for the propagation of action potentials, as proposed by Hodgkin and Hux's mathematical models, which suggest that sodium channel properties must be tightly constrained for this to occur. There are nine mammalian genes encoding voltage-gated sodium channels, with over 90% sequence similarity, implying functional similarity. However, the multiplicity of genes raises the question of why there are so many. The study demonstrates that theoretical constraints on sodium diversity, specifically membrane excitability and resting potential uniqueness, directly constrain channel properties. Data from 172 sets of mammalian channel measurements, including wild-type and mutant, under various conditions, show that all channels obey the excitability constraint. In contrast, channels expressed in muscle obey the unique resting potential constraint, while those in neuronal tissue do not. Excitability distinguishes sodium channels into four groups consistent with phylogenetic analysis. Calculations suggest functional differences between these groups.
Researchers have identified the endonuclease domain of the influenza A/H1N1/2009 polymerase as a potential target for novel antiviral drugs due to its crucial role in viral replication and transcription. The heterotrimeric polymerase, comprising subunits PA, PB1, and PB2, has been a focus of recent structural and functional studies, revealing opportunities for structure-based optimization of viral replication inhibitors. Specifically, the cap-snatching mechanism of transcription can be inhibited by targeting the PB cap-binding or endonuc domains. This study presents high-resolution X-ray crystal structures of the 2009 pandemic H1N1 PA enduc domain in complexed with a series of specific inhibitors, including diketo compounds and green tea catechin, which chelate two manganese ions in the enzyme's active site. The binding modes of the compounds and mononucleotide phosphate were compared, highlighting how substituents on the metal binding scaffold can orient in distinct subockets within the active cavity and the site's plasticity, resulting in induced binding. These findings will inform the design of more potent inhibitors targeting the capatching enduc activity of the virus polymerase.
Researchers have developed an effective immunization protocol to produce polyspecific antiven against three medically important viper species in Thailand and neighboring countries: Cryptelytrops alabris (White-lipped viper), Caloselasma rhodoma (Malayan viper), and Dabo siamensis (Russell's viper). The goal was to create an antivenom that could neutralize venom from any of these species, eliminating the need to identify the culprit snake. Four horses were immunized with a mixture of the three venoms using a low-dose, low-volume immunization protocol. The antiseras showed a rapid increase in ELISA titers against the venoms, reaching a plateau at 8 weeks post-immunization. In-vitro neutralization potency of the antiser against CA, CR, and DS venoms was 10.40, 2.42, and 0.76 mg/ml, respectively, exceeding the minimal limits set by the Queen Saab Memorial Institute. Corresponding values for monospecific antiserum against CA, CR, and DS ven were 7.28, 3.12, and 1.50/ml. The polyspecific antiser also neutralized procoagulant, hemorrhagic, necrotic, and nephroxic activities of the venoms. This immunization protocol may be useful for producing polyspecific antiven and equine antiserum against tetanus, diphtheria, and rabies.
Salmonella enterica, a bacterium that causes systemic infections, can persist in the body for long periods despite a strong immune response. Chronically infected individuals remain asymptomatic and transmit the disease to uninfected hosts through fecal shedding, serving as a reservoir for the disease. The effector protein SI, translocated into host cells by the Salmonella Pathogenic Island 2 (SPI) type III secretion system, is necessary for Salmonella typhim to maintain long-term systemic infection in mice. In vitro, S inhibits normal migration of primary macrophages and dendritic cells, requiring host IQGTPase activating protein 1 (IQAP), a regulator of cell migration. S binds IQAP and localizes with this factor at cell periphery. The C-terminal of S is similar to PMTxA, a toxin containing cysteine residue critical for activity. Mutation of corresponding in S (C178) eliminates S function in vitro and vivo, but not IQAP binding. Infection with wild-type S typhur suppressed migration to spleen in S-dependent manner. Examination of spleens from infected with WT tyur revealed fewer DC and CD+ lymphocytes compared to infected ΔS tyur. Results demonstrate S inhibits host migration, counteracting ability to clear bacteria.
Community-acquired methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (CA-MRSA) is a pathogen that causes severe disease in healthy individuals and is more virulent than hospital-acquired MRSA (HA-MRSA). The mechanism behind CA-MRSA's high virulence is unknown. The p-mec gene, located in the mobile element SCCmec of HA-MRSA, but not CA-MRSA, suppresses phenol-sol-soluble modulin (PSM) expression, a cytolytic toxin of S. aureus. This study found p-m RNA inhibits agr gene translation, encoding transcription factor for PSM via specific binding to agr mRNA. 25% of 325 MRSA isolates had p-m promoter mutation attenuating transcription and 9% had no p-m. Most p-mutated or p-deleted HA-MRSA had increased PSM compared to intact p-m and some produced high P comparable to CA-MRSA. Deletion p-m from HA-M with p increased Agr and PSM and virulence in mice. p-m suppresses MR virulence via agr inhibition and absence in CARSA causes high virulence.
Researchers investigated the phenomenon of antibody-mediated disease enhancement (ADE) in type I interferon-deficient mice, which occurs when maternal antibodies from a previous dengue infection enhance the severity of a subsequent heterologous or homolog deng virus (DENV) infection. Epidemiological studies have shown that babies born to deng immune mothers are at higher risk of developing severe disease upon primary infection with heterolog or homolog DENV serotype. To replicate this in a mouse model, previously, DENV-infected 5-week-old type I interferon receptor-deficient (IFN) mice (129) born to D1-immune mothers displayed enhanced disease with increased virus titers and vascular leakage leading to death. This study aimed to reproduce ADE in a less immunocompromised background. Five-week 129 mice born to D1-imm mothers succumbed to D2 infection within 4 days, whereas those born to naïve mothers survived. Clinical manifestations included hepatocyte vacuolation, vascular leakage, lymphopenia, and thrombocytopenia. Anti-TNF therapy protected mice and correlated with healthy hepatocytes, while blocking IL-6 had no impact on virus titers or outcome. This A129 model of ADE may elucidate mechanisms in deng pathogenesis and evaluate vaccine/therapeutic efficacy.
A systematic review and meta-analysis was conducted to identify factors associated with Leishmaniasis infection in the Americas, a disease that has urbanized over 30 years ago. Fifty-one studies were reviewed from various databases, reference lists, and expert consultations. Meta-analysis was used to pool information on each variable, with Q and I2 statistics assessing heterogeneity. Male sex was associated with visceral leishiasis in studies using the leishman skin test, but not with serological diagnosis. Younger individuals were less frequently infected, but more prone to illness. Presence of dogs at home, higher seropositivity nearby, lower socioeconomic status, and vegetated areas were associated with L infantum infection. Chicken presence in the house and nutritional status were not associated. Studies had susceptibility to bias and limitations in analysis and description. Results showed consistent patterns for some factors, to be considered in control measures. New studies are needed in areas with improved methodological quality, prioritizing patterns and causes, and variables with poor knowledge.
Inhalation of Francisella tularens (Ft) causes acute and fatal pneumonia, characterized by excessive bacterial replication in the lung tissue. Research on the sequential host response to tularemia reveals that an innate cellular response, rather than cytokine production, drives tissue damage and mortality. Immature myeloid cells and myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) are recruited to the lungs, fail to mature, and die, causing necrotic lung damage, loss of function, and host death. This process is partially dependent on Ly6+ cells. In contrast, sub-lethal infections elicit a mature neutrophil and monocyte response, required for protection, suggesting a threshold for lethal infection. Mature phagocytosis provides transient, but significant protection against Ftu4. The study suggests the nature of myoid cell response is the primary determinant of host mortality versus survival following Francisella infection.
Aedes albopictus, the Asian tiger mosquito, is an invasive species that poses a global concern due to its rapid spread and potential for infectious disease transmission. As a vector of medically important arboviruses such as CHIKV, DENV, and ZIKV, understanding its colonization pattern is crucial for mitigating its spread and disease risks. Population genetics and Approximate Bayesian computation (ABC) approaches were used to disentangle the demographic history of Aedesopopus populations from Southeast Asia and recently colonized areas. In Southeast Asia, low differentiation and high co-ancestry values among China and Thailand indicate native populations maintain genetic connectivity, revealing a common origin. China is the oldest population. Outside Asia, invasion in La Réunion, America, and the Mediterranean is supported by chaotic propagule distribution, maintaining high diversity in adventive populations. Independent transcontinental introductions of Aedesopus facilitated rapid establishment through admixture of unrelated genomes, resulting in intra-population variability. This variability may extend to genetic controlling vector competence. In the invasion context, ancestry and admixture create conditions for efficient arvirus transmission and outbreak.
Researchers investigated the genetic factors contributing to the fitness of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in chronic wounds, a type of infection that is difficult to treat. They found that clinical isolates from human wounds often lacked virulence functions and biofilm formation capabilities, which are typically associated with bacterial pathogenicity. In experimental mouse models, virulence and biofilm genes were not necessary for bacterial fitness. Instead, genes involved in anaerobic growth, metabolism, energy production, and membrane integrity were crucial. These findings suggest that bacteria in chronic wounds face anaerobic, oxidative, and membrane stress conditions, which can be represented by high-density bacterial growth in the absence of a host.
A prospective study was conducted at the Center for Teaching, Research, and Referral for Bancrofilariasis (NEF) to evaluate the occurrence of intrascrot lymphangiectasia, gross consistency of the testis, and efficacy of excision of hydrocele sac in patients with bancrofilariasis. A total of 968 patients with unilateral or bilateral hydrocele (Group 1) and 218 patients from the same area who had undergone hydrocele-sparing hydrocelectomy elsewhere (Comparison Group) were enrolled. Twenty patients from Comparison with hydrocele were reoperated at NEF and constitute Group 2. In Group 1, 1128 hydrolectomies were performed with a mean age of 30.3 years and mean follow-up of 8.6 years (range 5-12). Hydrocele rates in Group 1 and Comparison were 0.3% and 19.3 respectively (p<0.001). There was no hydrocele in Group 2 with a mean age of 25.1 and follow of 6 years (5-6). Surgically leaking or dilated lymphatic vessels were seen on the inner or outer surface of hydrocele wall or surrounding tissue in 30.9 and 46.3 of patients in Group 1 and 2 respectively (p=0.081). Testicles were abnormal in shape, volume, and consistency in 203/128 (18%) and 10/28 (35.7%) of Group 1 and 2 respectively (p=0.025). Lymph fluid from ruptured dilated lymphatic is a component of chronic hydrocele fluid threatening test integrity in adult bancfilariasis population. To prevent hydrocele, authors advise excision of hydro sac when leaking or dilated vessels should be suture or excised.
Trichella spiralis, a zoonotic nematode parasite, causes trichlosis, a disease found on all continents except Antarctica. During chronic infection, T. spir larvae infect skeletal muscles, disrupting their differentiation. An activity-based probe, HA-Ub-V, identified deubiquinating (D) enzyme activity in T. spir L larvae lysate. Immunoblot and immunoprecipitation identified multiple Ds. Immunoprecipitated proteins were subjected to LC/MS, yielding peptides with homology to conserved D: UCH5, U3, HAP, OT6, and Atin-3.
