The gene encoding putative UCH5 homologue, Ts37, was cloned and recombinant protein expressed and purified. Deubitinating activity was verified by Ub-AM assay. Coipitation of recomant Ts37 showed association with putative T proteome components, including yeastpn hom ADR1. Inhibitor LD-44 exhibited specific inhibition recomant Ts37 and reduced cultured L viability. This study reports first T spir D, cystine protease orthologous to human U5. Results suggest interaction with proteome conserved throughout evolution. Inhibitors may elucidate U role in spir infection and as therapeutic targets trichlos.
Cysteine protease cruzain is a validated target for therapeutic intervention in the treatment of Chagas disease, a parasitic infection caused by the protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi. Researchers investigated the anti-tryosomal activity of nitrile-based cystine protease inhibitors against the CLner strain of T. cruzi. Three compounds, based on scaffolds associated with cathepsin inhibition, showed anti-tryosomal activity in the 0.1-1 μM range. The two most potent compounds had EC50 values of 0.12 μM and 0.25M against the trypanosome, significantly lower than Ki values against cruzain, a recombinant form of cruzain in an enzyme assay. This suggests the anti-tryosomal activity is not solely due to cruzain inhibition, indicating a polypharmacological profile towards cystine proteases.
Researchers have constructed a physical map of the maize genome, covering 93.5% of the genome, which aligns with 86.1% of the genetic map. The map contains 25,908 genetic markers, enabling 73% of the genome to be anchored to the rice genome. Sequence tags correlate with recombination patterns, with 1 kb in rice corresponding to 3.2 kb in maize. Maize has a 6-fold larger genome size due to regions corresponding to two in maize from polyploid origin. Inversions account for most structural variations during diploidization. Ancient duplications occurred before divergence of maize and rice progenitors.
Researchers have investigated the de novo generation of infectious prions in vitro to understand the etiology of sporadic prion disease. Prions are proteinaceous infectious agents responsible for transmissible spong encephalopathies, composed of misfolded prion protein (PrPSc) that replicates in the body without nucleic acids by inducing misfolding cellular prion (Pr). The most common human prion disease is sporadic, originating from spontaneous misfolding to PrSc particle propagation. This study aimed to mimic sporadic disease etiology by generating PrSc in vitro using protein misfolding cyclic amplification (PM) procedure. Under standard PM conditions, de novo PrSc generation was not observed, supporting diagnostic applications. However, modified PM generated PrSc in absence pre-existing PrSc in different species at low rate. De novo PrSc was infectious in wild-type hamsters, producing unique clinical, neuropathological, and biochemical features. Results support prion hypothesis and provide model for sporadic disease mechanism.
Researchers have developed a novel neural model to estimate angular velocity (AV) in the bee brain, capable of quantitatively reproducing experimental observations of visual odometry and corridor-centering in free-flying honeybees. The model is based on electrophysiological data and tested with behavioral data. The model suggests that AV can be considered an extension of the optomotor response. The model was tested behaviorally in silico with the corridor-center paradigm, where bees navigate a corridor with gratings (square or sinusoidal) on walls. When combined with existing flight algorithm, the model reproduces invariance of flight path to spatial frequency and contrast of gratings, including deviations from centering behavior found in real bees. Additionally, response of model to unit movement along corridor is constant for large grating frequencies, demonstrating it can be used as visual odometer.
Untreated Infections by Trypanosoma brucei gambense Are Not 100% Fatal: A Long-Term Follow-Up of 50 African Trypanosomiasis Patients

A cohort of 50 patients with African trypanosomiasis (AT) from the Ivory Coast, diagnosed with Trypanosoma brucei gambense, the causative agent of sleeping sickness, were followed for 15 years. Eleven patients refused treatment after initial diagnosis, and 10 continued to do so despite repeated visits. Parasite clearance was observed using microscopy and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) in all 10, and serological responses decreased in 7, becoming negative to trypanosome antigens Liat 1.3, 1.5, and 1.6. Two alternative progressions of AT were identified: aparasitemic and asymptomatic infection with long-lasting serological responses, and spontaneous resolution with negative parasitological and PCR results and decreasing antibody titres. This study does not estimate the frequency of these courses, but notes that field programs encounter subjects with positive serological results but negative parasitological tests, indicating some display these courses. Recognizing trypanotolerance in humans, accepted in animals, is a step for future HAT research.
Researchers investigated the relationship between ionizing radiation and the selection of p53-deficient hematopoietic progenitors in mice. p53 is a tumor suppressor gene, and its loss can provide resistance to genotoxic stimuli, including radiation. p53 null mice develop T-cell lymphomas with high penetrance, and irradiation accelerates lymphoma in p53 heterozygous mice. The study hypothesized that increased p53-deficient cells contribute to the link between irradiation and lymphoid malignancies. Using mouse models, they found that p53 disruption does not provide a selective advantage in an unstressed hematopoietic system or previously irradiated BM allowed to recover. However, upon irradiation, p53 confers a selective advantage, leading to long-term expansion of p53-deficient clones and increased lymphoma. Selection for p-def cells is attributed to several factors: protection from irradiation-induced ablation of progenitor cells, prevention of irradi-induced loss of clonogenic capacity for stem and progenitor, improved maintenance of progenitor fitness, and elimination of competing p wild-type progenitors.
Researchers investigated the role of Schistosoma mansoni SmKI-1 serine protease inhibitor in parasite development and its potential as a regulator of inflammatory diseases. They found that recombinant Sm-1 and its Kunit domain, but not the C-terminal region, possess inhibitory activity against trypsin and neutrophil elastase (NE). Molecular docking studies revealed that Sm-1's Kunit domain blocks NE's active site. Sm-1 also inhibited NE's capacity to kill schistosomes. To investigate Sm-1's role in the parasite, specific siRNA was used to knockdown Sm-1 in S. mansoni. Sm-1 suppression in the larval stage of S. mansoni significantly impacted parasite development in vitro and in vivo. Sm-1's ability to interfere with neutrophil function was tested in murine models of inflammatory diseases. Treatment with Sm-1 rescued acetaminophen (AP)-mediated liver damage, reducing neutil recruitment and elast activity. In a model of gout, Sm-1 reduced neutil accumulation, IL-β secretion, hyperiception, and pathological score. Sm- was also shown to inhibit early neutil recruitment in pleural cavities of mice in response to carrageenan. The study concludes that Sm-1 is a key in S. mans survival and has potential as a therapeutic against inflammatory diseases.
Researchers have developed a novel method for accurately modeling transmembrane helix (TM) protein structures from distant homologues with distinct loop and TM conformations. This method was tested on adenosine A2A and chemokine CX4 receptors, ranking first in the GPCR Dock prediction contest in the receptor category. A benchmark of 50 TM protein homolog pairs with diverse topology (5-12 TM), size (183-420 residues), and sequence (15-70%) was used to evaluate the method. The method outperformed starting templates, achieving near-atomic accuracy in membrane-embedded regions. Unlike templates, the models were suitable for computer-based engineering, redesigned and X-ray structures showed similar native interactions. This method is useful for atom-level modeling and design of structurally uncharacterized TM proteins from a range of homologues.
Listeria monocytogenes, the causative agent of listeriosis, a foodborne disease, poses significant risks to fetuses, newborns, and immunocompromised individuals. This intracellular pathogen proliferates in the host cytos and exploits the actin polymerization machinery for cell-to-cell spread and dissemination. During infection in human hepatocytes or trophlast cells, L. monocogen switches from active motile to a persistent vacuolar lifestyle. Bacteria stop producing actin nucleating protein Act and become trapped in lysosome-like vacuoles, termed Lister-Containing Vacoles (Lis). Subpopulations resist degradation in Lis and enter slow-replicative state. In host cells harboring Lis, bacteria cycle between vacolar and act-based motility stages. Act absence, as in ΔAct mutants, vacolar bacteria parasitize host in "viable but noncult" (VB) state, undetectable by colony methods. High gentamicin exposure does not trigger Lis formation but selects vacolar VB. These results reveal L monocogen ability to persist in epithelial cells, favoring asymptomatic carriage, prolonged incubation, and survival during therapy.
Researchers have developed a neuromechanical model to study auditory bistability, a phenomenon where sequences of higher and lower frequency tones in an A-BA pattern are perceived as either a single or separate streams. The model combines neuromechanical and psychoacoustic experiments to investigate persistent alternations between these percepts during long presentations. Unlike previous models, it includes neuronal units with sensory-dependent inputs mimicking pulselike responses to tones and a computation for competition in primary auditory cortex. Mutual inhibition, adaptation, and noise are implemented, along with slow NMDA recurrent excitation for temporal memory. Percepts are identified in firing patterns of units. The model predicts that manipulating frequency difference between tones affects dominance of percepts, with stronger percepts lasting longer than weaker ones, a property established in visual bistable paradigms. Psychoac experiments confirm this prediction and further constrain the model, achieving quantitative agreement between results. The model provides a platform to extend to other conditions, including context and volition.
Researchers have developed a method to assess the allergenicity of Schistosoma mansoni proteins using a humanized Ratophil Leukemia (RSAT8) cell line. This approach aims to identify molecular targets of the IgE response in S. mansoni infection, which could lead to a better understanding of anti-parasite immunity and the development of safe and efficacious vaccinations against helthic parasites. The method involves cell-free translation of S. mans proteins using wheat germ lysate, followed by assessment of potential allergity with the RSL reporter line. Cell translation is completed within 90 minutes, generating sufficient protein for rapid screening without purification. Antigen integrity is confirmed using Western blotting. After incubation with individuals' serum, the RSL reporter line is challenged with wheat translation and luciferase activity measured, indicating cellular activation by the allergen. This method is demonstrated using characterised parasitic allergens such as Par 2, SmAL-1 and IgE factor SE/alpha, expressed in wheat lysate or E coli. coli. SmAL-1, but not SmAL2, activates the basophil reporter line. The system is suitable for medium to high-throughput studies using infected sera and study of helthic protein allergity.
Researchers investigated the effects of transposable elements (TEs) on gene expression in Drosophila, specifically in the context of hybrid dysgenesis, a form of genomic incompatibility that arises when TE abundance differs between parents. They found that when TEs inherited from the father are absent in the mother's genome, they become activated in progeny, causing germline damage and sterility. In Drosila, dysgenesis occurs when paternal TEs are not matched with a pool of corresponding silencing PI-interacting RNAs (piRNAs) provided by the female germl. The study used D. virilis hybrid dysgenesis as a model to characterize effects of TE divergence between parents on offspring. Results show that divergence in TE landscape is associated with persisting differences in germl TE expression in genetically identical females of reciprocal crosses, transmitted to next generation. Chronic and persisting TE expression coincides with increased levels of genic piRNAs associated with reduced gene expression. Gene expression is idiosratically influenced by differences in genicRNA profile of parents arising from polymorphic TE insertions. These results support a model where early germl events in dysgenesis establish a stable state of TE and gene expression in germl maintained through adulthood and transmitted to generation. Divergence in TE is associated with piRNA-mediated transgener effects on expression within populations.
Fragile X Tremor Atax Syndrome (FXT) is a neurodegenerative disorder caused by a CG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the 5′UTR of the fragile X syndrome (FX) gene, FMR1. The expanded CG repeat is thought to induce toxicity and FXT patients have high levels of FMR1 mRNA. Despite FMR's critical role in disease, the basis for increased F1 expression is unknown. Researchers found that overexpressing histone deetylases (HD3, 6, or 11) suppresses CG repeat-induced neurodegeneration in a Drosophila FXT model. This is due to selective repression of the CG repeat-containing transgene. Chromatin immunoprecitation showed increased acetylation of histones at the F1 locus in preutation carriers compared to control FX lines. This correlates with elevated F1 mRNA in preutation lines. Histone acetylase (H) inhibitors reduced F1 to control levels in preutation lines and extended lifespan in CG-expressing Dophila. These findings support a model where the CG expansion promotes chromatin remodeling, increasing toxic F mRNA. Additionally, H or HD inhibitors might selectively repress the locus.
Researchers investigated the role of host genetics in controlling CD8 T cell function and immunopathology during chronic viral infection. Effective CD8 T cell responses are crucial for controlling chronic viral infections, but factors contributing to maintaining effector CD8 cell responses versus exhaustion during chronic infection are not fully understood. Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) alleles and degree of MHC heterogeneity are associated with enhanced CD8 cell function and viral control during human infection. To examine the impact of M heterogeneity versus non-MHC host genetics on chronic infection development, F1 cross of B10.D2 and B6 (DBF1) and BAL.B x BAL/C (B1) mice were infected with clone-13 (Cl-13) lymphocytic choriomening virus (LCV). Following Cl-13 infection, H-2D2DBF and B1 mice demonstrated increased viral control compared to homozygous mice. Notably, H-2D2DB mice on C57 genetic background exhibited mortality following Cl-13 infection. CD8 cell depletion prevented mortality in Cl-infected DBF mice, indicating mortality was CD T-cell dependent. DBF mice maintained CD8 cell effector cytokine production and reduced expression of T exhaustion marker PD-1. Additionally, DBF mice induced larger Th1 response than B1 mice Cl-13 mortality in DBF mice was dependent CD4-cell IFN production. Following chronic infection, increased CD8 cell functionality allowed rapid viral clearance at cost of immunopathology dependent on M diversity and host genetic background.
A study on the genetic characteristics of Bacillus anthracis isolated in northwestern China from 1990 to 2016 was conducted. Anthrax is a re-emerging zoon disease and endemic in China, particularly in rural areas. The study described the general characteristics of human anthrax outbreaks in northwestern China over the past decade and analyzed the genetic of Bacillus anthracis using single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) and multilocus-number tandem repeat analysis (MLVA) with 15 markers. Five sublineages/subgroups, A. Br.001/002, A. Br. Voll, A. Br94, A. Ames, and A. Br.008/009, were detected using 13SN sites. All subgroups were found in Xinjiang, one in Shaanxi, two Gans, three Qinghai, and four Inner Mongolia. Geographical distribution of B. anthrac populations exhibited different SNP characteristics from strains before 1990 in China. A. Br Ames was observed scattered from Inner to other provinces. All 106 strains assigned 36 MLVA genotypes, 21 first observed this study. Strains anthrax recent decade classified subgroups A. Br.001 and A. Ames genotypes MLVA-28, ML-30, ML-31 ML-38 ML-CH3 ML-18. By SNP and MLVA, divers ML genotypes and B anthrac populations distribution becoming balanced northwestern China. This study preliminary results population B. anthrac China, prevention control important disease.
Researchers investigated the role of goblet cell-derived RELMβ in defending against intestinal infections caused by enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli, a food and waterborne pathogen that attaches to the apical surface of intestinal epithelial cells, leading to severe diarrheal disease. Studies using Citrobacter rodium, a related mouse pathogen, suggested that hosts rely on immune-mediated changes in intestinal epithelial cells, including goblet cells, to defend against pathogens. These changes include increased CD4 T cell-dependent intestinal epithelial cell proliferation and altered goblet cell mucin production. RELMβ, a goblet mediator, is strongly induced during Citrobium infection and detected in stool and serum, but its role in defense is unclear. Wild-type and RELβ deficient mice were orally infected with Citrobium. RELβ deficient mice showed increased mortality and mucosal ulceration due to pathogen penetration of colonic crypts. Immunostaining revealed impaired infection-induced epithelial proliferation in REL deficient mice. RELβ did not directly increase epithelial proliferation, but acted as a CD4 cell chemoattract. Deficient mice showed impaired CD4 cell recruitment and reduced interleukin-22, a multifunctional cytokine increasing epithelial proliferation. REL delivery to deficient mice restored CD4 recruitment, interleukin-22, and epithelial proliferation, reducing mucosal pathology. RELβ and goblet cells play a critical role in recruiting CD4 cells to protect against enteric pathogen via increased epithelial proliferation.
Researchers have identified a crucial interaction between the C-terminal motif of norovirus VP protein (VPg) and the HEAT domain of eukary initiation factor 4 (eIF4) that is essential for translation initiation of the positive-sense single-stranded RNA genome of norovirus, a major cause of gastroenteritis in humans. Norirus RNA lacks a 5 mG cap and internal ribosome entry site (IRES), instead relying on interactions between VPg attached to the 5-end of the RNA and host eary initiation factors. In murine norirus (MNV), VP was previously shown to bind the middle fragment of e4 (residues 652-113). This study used pull-down assays, fluorescence anisotropy, and isothermal calorimetry (ITC) to demonstrate a 20 amino acid stretch at the C-terminus of MN VP mediates direct and specific binding to HE-1 within the fragment of e. Analysis revealed the MN C-termin binds e-HE-1 via a motif conserved in all norirus. Mutagenic mapping suggested the MN VP Ctermin interacts e in a helical conformation. NMR spectroscopy defined the VP binding site on e-HE-1, confirmed by mutagen and binding assays. The site is non-overlapping with binding for eA on eHE-1, indicating norirus VP can form ternary VP-e-e-eA complexes. Functional significance of the VP-e interaction was shown by fusion proteins containing the C-terminal of MN VP inhibiting in vitro translation of norirus but not cap or I-dependent.
Researchers investigated the evolution of gene clusters in bacterial genomes, where genes encoding proteins in a common pathway are often found near each other on the chromosome. Several theories have been proposed to explain this phenomenon, including natural selection favoring clusters through mechanisms such as co-regulation efficiency and the selfish operon model, which suggests clusters are more easily transferred to other species, enhancing survival prospects. The persistence model proposes genes in proximity are less likely disrupted by deletions. This study developed computational models to examine cluster evolution conditions. The selfish operon model was re-implemented and simulated under various conditions. A Moran process was introduced with natural selection for clustering and rearrangement by inversion events. A model was developed with selection and inversion, tracking rearrangement fixation. Surprisingly, clusters failed to evolve under various conditions. Factors promoting cluster evolution include low pathway genes, high population size, and selfish model high transfer rate. Computational analysis showed cluster evolution under direct and indirect selection with certain conditions. The operon remains viable under these conditions as cluster explanation.
Malaria, caused by Plasmodium falciparum, is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in tropical regions worldwide, with pregnant women being particularly vulnerable to severe consequences due to parasite-infected erythrocyte adhesion in the placenta. This adhesion is mediated by a variant of PfEMP1, a parasite-encoded, hyper-variable antigen on the surface of infected cells, specifically VARCS, which binds chondroit sulfate on syncyotrophoblasts in the intervillous space of placent. VARCS is only expressed in the presence of placenta, suggesting its expression is repressed in men or non-pregnant women, but the mechanism is not understood. Researchers used cultured parasite lines and gene constructs to show the VARCS gene contains an upstream reading frame that represses translation of mRNA, a novel form of regulation in malaria parasites. The mechanism is reversible, allowing high protein levels upon selection, enabling parasites to upregulate this antigen in host tissue.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide microarray analysis of blood samples from 34 children infected with dengue virus (DENV) in Nicaragua, collected on days 3-6 of illness, to investigate the pathophysiology of severe versus non-severe manifestations. The study identified distinct gene expression patterns between clinical subgroups, particularly between deng patients with and without shock, showing increased expression of mitochondrial ribosomal proteins associated with protein synthesis. In deng hemorrhagic fever patients, a subset of differentially expressed genes encoded neutrophil-derived anti-microbial peptides associated with innate immunity. A meta-analysis with previously published datasets confirmed DENV infection is associated with changes in protein and nucleic acid metabolism. In vitro infection led to an interferon signature, not observed in vivo samples, suggesting a transient interferon response by days 3-6 of illness. The study highlights differences in severity manifestations during DENV infection and identifies commonalities.
Murine Herpesvirus-4 (MuHV-4), a lymphotropic herpesvirus related to Kaposi's Sarcoma-associated Herpesvirus, targets the olfactory neuroepithelium for entry. In vivo studies, Mu-4 virions spontaneously targeted the olfactory neuroepithelium, a previously unexplored site for herpesvirus entry. Like other herpesviruses, Mu-4 binds heparan sulfate (HS), and virions unable to bind HS showed poor entry. The respiratory epithelium expressed basolateral HS and was bound poorly by incoming virions, whereas the neuroepithelium displayed apical HS on neuronal cilia and bound strongly. Incoming virions tracked the neuronal cilia, either infecting neurons or reaching the microvilli of adjacent glial sustacular cells and infecting them. The olfactory neuroepithium provides an important site of HS-dependent herpesirus uptake.
Salmonella enterica, a pathogenic bacteria, requires the expression of genes in the pathogenic island (SPI-1) to invade epithelial cells. SPI-1 expression is tightly regulated and activated under specific conditions. A new regulatory circuit involving CRP, a metabolic regulator, silences SPI-1 under non-permissive conditions. CRP-deficient strains show strong upregulation of SPI-1 in mid-logarithmic growth phase. Genetic analysis reveals CRP modulates HilD, master regulator of Salmonella invasion, at post-transcription level. This regulation requires a newly identified motif within Hil 3'UTR. CRP also represses Hfq-dependent sRNA Spot42. When repression relieved, Spot42 positively affects Hil expression. In vivo and in vitro assays show Spot42 targets Hil 3'UT through unstructured region. Results highlight Hil 3'UT as postcription control hub for Salmonella invasion expression.
Researchers investigated the relationship between CAG repeat instability, chromatin structure, and transcription in the context of Huntington's disease (HD) using R6 and R2 transgenic mouse lines. These mice express a similar transgene, integrated at different sites, and recapitulate tissue-specific instability. Results show increased instability in R2 tissues compared to R1 samples. High transgene expression and chromatin accessibility correlated with increased CAG instability in R2 mice. Transgene mRNA and H3K4 trimylation at the HD locus were increased, whereas H3K9 dimethylation reduced in R2 tissues relative R1. Levels of transgene and histone marks similar in striatum and cerebellum, two tissues with different CAG levels. Elongating RNA II at HD locus, not initiating form II, tissue-specific correlated with CAG levels. H3 trimylation, associated with elongation, increased at HD locus in striatum not cerebellum. Data suggest transcription modulates somatic CAG in vivo, specifically elongation regulated tissue-dependent contributing to tissue-selective instability.
Researchers investigated the genetic features of Enterovirus 71 (EV71), a highly virulent enterovirus, to understand its ability to disseminate in humans. They analyzed five full-genome sequences from immunocompromised patients with disseminated disease at different infection sites: respiratory, gastrointestinal, nervous, and blood. Three nucleotide changes occurred within five days: a non-conservative amino acid change in VP1 within the BC loop (LR), a region considered immunogenic and important in poliovirus host adaptation; conservative amino substitution in protein 2 (AV); and silent mutation in protein 3 (L). Infectious clones were constructed using BrCr (A) and clinical (C) lineages with one or both non-syn mutations. In vitro tropism and competition assays showed VP1 Leu to Arg substitution within BC conferred replicative advantage in SHY5Y neuroblastoma cells. This mutation was associated with second non-conservative (EG or EA) in VP1 loop in neuroblast cells. Comparative models of EV71 VP variants were built to determine substitutions' effects on VP structure and host interactions. No significant structural changes were observed, but substitutions may alter host receptor interactions. Results indicate VP1 BC region of EV plays critical role in tropism independent of lineage, contributing to dissemination and neurotropism in immunocomised patients.
Bacteria of the genus Streptoccus have the ability to acquire new traits through natural transformation, a process mediated by the uptake of extracellular DNA. This process is regulated by quorum sensing (QS) through peptide pherones, such as the ComRS system. ComS is processed into ComX, secreted, and imported into the cytoplasm, where it binds ComR, activating transcription and a positive feedback loop for ComS and SigX expression. ComRS is present in most Streptoccus species, but ComS and ComX sequences diverge, suggesting species-specific communication. To study cross-talk between Streptoc species in competence regulation and ComX interaction, an interdisciplinary approach was undertaken. A test assay was developed to measure Com activity in response to cognate and heterologous X peptides in vivo, revealing strict, intermediate, and promiscuous specificity classes among species. The X-ray structure of Com from S suis was solved to understand XIP interaction and identify structural features in Com that explain X recognition. Directed mutagenesis probed the apo conformation of the X-binding pocket site in test and biochemically in vitro. Com proteins from other species align with the pocket lined by a variable and conserved face, with conserved residues contributing to ligand binding and variable discriminating X peptides. Results provide a model for X recognition and specificity, predicting novel X peptides inducing Com activity.
Researchers have investigated the epigenetic inheritance of centromeres in the pathogenic yeast Candida albicans using a genome-wide replication timing analysis. They found that each centrom is associated with a replication origin that fires first on its respective chromosome. Epigenetic formation of ectopic centromeres (neocromeres) was accompanied by shifts in replication timing, where neocere became the first to replicate and associated with origin recognition complex (OR) components. Changes in centrom-specific histone H3 isoform led to concomitant changes in ORC association with centrom regions, supporting the idea that centrom proteins determine origin activity. Analysis of centrom-associated DNA revealed a replication-dependent pattern characteristic of constitutively active origins. This pattern is conserved with centrom position among strains and species, independently of DNA sequence. Inheritance of centrom position is correlated with constitutively active replication that fires early.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) meta-analysis of chronic back pain (CB) in 158,025 adults of European ancestry from 15 cohorts in the Cohorts for Heart and Aging in Genomic Epidemiology (CHARGE) consortium and the UK Biob interim release. CB cases were defined as those reporting back pain for ≥3 months, while non-cases were included as controls. Each cohort used commercially available arrays followed by imputation. GW used logistic regression models with genetic effects, adjusting for age, sex, study-specific covariates, and population structure. The threshold for genome-wide significance was p<5×10^-8. Suggestive (p<5×10^-7) and genome significant (p<5×^-8) variants were carried forward for replication in 283,752 UKob participants not in the discovery. A genome significant association was found for the intronic variant rs10519 in SOX (OR 1.08, p7.2×10^-10). This was replicated in 50,915 cases (OR 1.06, p.3×10^-11) and exceeded genome-wide significance in joint-analysis (1.07 p.4.5^-19). Suggestive associations were found at three loci in the sample, two of which exceeded genome-wide in joint-analysis: intergenic rs317, between CC26 and GSD (1.05 p4.4^-13) and intronic rs438 in D (0.97 p.2^-10).
Taenia solium cysticosis is a significant zoonosis in developing countries, with neurocystercosis being an important cause of epilepsy in regions where the parasite occurs. However, it is underreported, and there is a lack of data on the disease burden. A study was undertaken to calculate the impact of this zoonosis in Cameroon, using Disability-Adjusted Life Years (DALY) estimations. Parameters were collected and imported into software, with different distributions used according to type of information. Prevalence of epilepsy was 3.6%, estimating 50,326 (95%CI 37,299-65,924) people with neurocystercosis-associated epilepsy, 1.0% of population, and 15,961 (95%CI 12,320-20,044) pigs with cysticosis, 5.6% of pig population. Annual costs in Cameroon were 10,255,202 (95%CI 6,889,048-14,754,044), 4.7% losses in pig husbandry, 95.3 direct and indirect. Monetary per case 194 (95CI 147-253). Average DALs lost 9.0 per thousand per year (95CI 2.8-20.4). This study estimates costs using country-specific parameters, human and animal burden of zoon disease. Comparison with South Africa indicates salaries influence monetary burden. Knowing salary and prevalence allows rapid indication of total cost. Additional studies could estimate global burden. Estimated DALs higher than other neglected diseases.
Researchers have identified a non-coding RNA in Staphylococcus aureus, designated as Rsa, which plays a crucial role in regulating the bacterium's persistence and virulence. Rsa contains a C-rich sequence, suggesting it functions at the post-transcriptional level. The study found that Rsa represses the synthesis of the global transcriptional regulator Mgr by forming a duplex with the Shine-Dalg sequence and loop interaction within the target mRNA's coding region. These interactions are necessary for repression, leading to increased biofilm production and decreased capsule synthesis in various strains. This results in reduced susceptibility to phagocytic killing by polymonuclear leukocytes compared to strains lacking Rsa. In animal models, Rsa reduced the severity of acute infections and enhanced chronic catheter infections. R is part of a regulatory network influencing S interactions with the host, moderating invasiveness and chronic infections. This is the first example of a conserved RNA in S functioning as a virulence suppressor of acute infections. S aureus is a human commensal, suggesting R has evolved to support commensal and saprophytic interactions with the host.
Researchers have developed a novel method to visualize the process of HIV-1 uncoating, a critical step in the virus's entry into host cells, using a fluorescently tagged form of a capsid-binding protein cyclophilin A (Cyp-DRed). This protein is packaged into virions through high-affinity binding to the capsid (CA) and remains associated with cores after membrane permeabilization. In vitro and in living cells, Cyp-D and CA are lost concomitantly from cores. The rate of loss is modulated by core stability and accelerated upon reverse transcription initiation. Single particle tracking reveals that most cores lose C-D shortly after fusion, while a small fraction remains intact for several hours. Late post-infection single particle tracking shows gradual C-D loss dependent on reverse transcription. Unating occurs in cytoplasm and at the nuclear membrane.
Researchers investigated the relationship between oligonucleotide usage and various properties in archaeal and bacterial genomes, including codon usage, DNA base stacking, and DNA structure. They analyzed oligonucleotide frequencies in coding and non-coding regions to assess the statistical potential of different DNA word sizes and how oligonucle frequencies differ. The study found that prokotic chromosomes can be described by hexanucle frequencies, indicating prootic DNA is short-range correlated, with information encoded in oligonucle. Oligonucle usage varied more in AT-rich and host-associated genomes than GC-rich freeiving genomes, mainly in nonoding regions. Bias in tetranucle usage correlated with GC content, coding regions more biased than nonoding. Nonoding regions were 5.5% more AT-rich than coding, on average, in 402 chromosomes. Pronounced compositional differences were found within and between AT-rich GC genomes. GC genomes were similar in tetranucle usage nonoding than AT genomes. Differences between AT-rich GC may be attributed lifestyle, tetran usage host-associated more dissimilar less freeiving.
Meiotic recombination is a critical process that ensures the correct segregation of homologous chromosomes during gamete formation and contributes to genetic diversity through large-scale reciprocal crossovers and localized gene conversion events, also known as nonrosso. While factors such as PRDM9 and SNP variants influence recombination initiation at hotspots, little is known about factors acting downstream. This study analyzed both types of recombinant molecules in sperm at six active hotspots and identified disparity in allelic variants indicative of cis-acting influences. Two hotspots showed a novel biased transmission exclusive to noncrosso recombinants, arising from differences between crosso and nonrosso heterodup formation and mismatch repair. This biased conversion does not influence hotspot activity as SNPs do, but constitutes a previously undetected source of recombination-driven meiotic drive, potentially affecting thousands of hotspots genome-wide. Interestingly, both hotspots favor (G/C) over (A) pairs, consistent with established correlations between GC content and recombination in mammalian genomes.
Researchers have developed a comprehensive protein-protein network that integrates toxicology and systems biology to better understand the molecular mechanisms of environmental chemicals and drugs on human health. This computational model reveals uncharacterized connections between compounds and diseases, enabling the prediction of potential health risks associated with exposure. The network can also identify unexpected associations between chemicals and proteins. 

The model was applied to chemicals linked to breast cancer, lung cancer, and necrosis, and identified potential targets for diethylhexylphthalate, 2,3,7,8-tetrachloribenzo-dioxin, pirix acid, and permethrin. Associations were supported by recent studies, demonstrating the power of integrating toxicogenomics with other data.
Researchers have re-examined the receptive fields of primary auditory cortical neurons by fitting a nonlinear feedforward network model to their responses to natural sounds. This approach reveals that these neurons are sensitive to a broader range of spectrotemporal features than their standard spectrotemporal receptive fields suggest. A parsimonious network of 1-7 sub-receptive fields, interacting nonlinearly, better predicts neural responses to auditory stimuli than standard receptive fields. The network field consists of separate excitatory and inhibitory subfields with distinct properties, and their interaction gives rise to operations such as gain control and conjunctive detection. Conjunct effects, where neurons respond to specific features together, enhance selectivity for complex spectrotemp structures and may be crucial in sound recognition.
Researchers have identified a crucial role for casein kinase 2 (CK2)-mediated phosphorylation of BMAL1 (BMAL-P) in regulating the mammalian circadian clock. Using a novel CK2-targeting peptide, they demonstrated that CK2 phosphorylates BM1 at serine 90 (S90) in central and peripheral clocks. Further analysis revealed a novel function of RY as a repressor kinase. Co-immunoprecipitation and real-time monitoring of protein-protein interactions showed that RY-mediated binding of CK2 to BM1 inhibits BM1-S90 phosphorylation by CKα. The FAD domain of R1, C-terminal BM1 domains, and BM1-lysine 537 acetylation/deacetylation by CLOCK/SIRT were critical for RY-mediated BM1-CKβ binding. Conversely, BM1-S90 phosphorylation is necessary for BM1lys 537 acetylation. The study proposes a negative feedback model where RY-dependent CK-driven post-translational BM1-P1-BM1 loop is integral to the core oscillator.
Salmonella enterica, a bacterium, adapts to survive in the presence of bile by employing multiple mechanisms to counteract its antibacterial activity. Bile salts disrupt cell membranes, denature proteins, and damage DNA, but the bacterium adapts to lethal concentrations of sodium deoxycholate (DOC) bile. Adaptation involves changes in gene expression, including upregulation of the Rpo-dependent stress response and other stress responses. The general stress response is crucial for adaptation, as Rpo mutants are sensitive to bile. Adaptation is a population-level response, but individual cells can become resistant without adaptation. Non-adapted Salmonella cultures plated on lethal bile-containing medium yield resistant colonies at frequencies of 10^-6 to 10^-7 per generation. Fluctuation analysis shows these derive from pre-existing resistant cells. A fraction of isolates are stable, indicating resistance can be acquired through mutation. Genome sequencing of resistant mutants reveals lipopolysaccharide transport alterations as a common cause of mutational resistance. However, lethal bile selection also yields non-mutant isolates. These likely derive from cells in a physiological state permitting survival upon bile encounter. Single-cell analysis of gene expression supports this, as Salmonella cultures activate stress genes in DOC absence. This highlights phenotypic heterogeneity in bacterial populations and adaptive value of gene fluctuations.
The E. coli chromosome is organized into 400-500 supercoiled domains through both active and passive mechanisms, such as transcription and DNA-protein association. Prophage Mu is organized as a stable domain bounded by its termini L and R, which are 37 kbp apart on the genome. The formation and maintenance of the Mu domain is dependent on a gyrase site (SGS) at the center of Mu, Mu end MuB protein, and E. coli proteins IHF, F, and H. The domain was observed at two chromosomal locations. In contrast, prophage λ does not form an independent domain. The establishment and maintenance of the Mu domain is promoted by low-level transcription from phage promoters, one of which is domain-dependent. The domain confers transposition readiness to Mu by topological requirements of reaction and proximity of ends. The benefits the host from a subset proteins expressed by prophage may help its long-term stability.
Primaquine (PQ) is the only licensed antimalarial that prevents Plasmodium vivax (Pv) relapses and clears Plasium falciparum (Pf) gamocytes, reducing post-treatment transmission. A randomized treatment-to-infection cohort study in Papua New Guine children investigated Pv and Pf gamocyte carriage after radical cure. Children received radical cure with Chloroquine, Artemether-Lumeftrine plus PQ or placebo. Blood samples were collected 2-4 weekly over 8 months. Gamocytes were detected by reverse transcriptionPCR targeting pvs and pfs. PQ reduced Pv gamocyte incidence by 73%, comparable to PQ effect on blood-stage infections. 92% Pv and 79% Pf gamocyte infections were asymptomatic. Pv gamocyte and Pf positivity density were associated with high-stage parasite densities. Multivariate analysis showed reduced gamocytes in mixed-species compared single-species for both Pv and Pf (ORv 0.39 [0.25-0.62], Pf 0.33 [0.18-0.60], p<0.001). No difference between PQ and placebo arms was observed in Pv gamocyte density or Pv infections carrying gamocytes. First-stage infections after placebo likely caused relapse hypnoite were gamet likely than PQ first after infective bite. Pv relapses and new infections had similar gametemia. Relapses contribute to Pv reservoir highlighting anti-hypnoite treatment for control.
Researchers have investigated the role of Rho family GTPases in cellular processes such as migration, cytokinesis, and endocytosis, which involve actin remodeling. The primary members of this family, Rho, Rac, and Cdc42, have distinct effects on actin reorganization, but share a common mechanism of targeting the plasma membrane and activation by GTP binding. A computational framework was developed to analyze experimental data on GTP cycling between the membrane and cytosol, revealing details of GDI-mediated cycling and distinguishing between GDI-dependent and -independent mechanisms, including vesicle trafficking and dissociation of Gase with membrane molecules. Analysis of Rac membrane cycling showed lower affinity of G for RacGTP compared to RacDP due to faster dissociation from the membrane. Non-steady-state solutions for membrane fraction Gase were presented in multidimensional charts. This methodology was applied to glucose-stimulated cycling in pancreatic β-cells, illustrating effects of Gs/Gs and affinities between Gases and membrane/GDI on bound GTP. Similar charts were used to assess targeted modifications compensating Gase-G balance in disease scenarios.
Monitoring and evaluation (M&E) programmes for schistosomiasis collect data to assess the impact of interventions and progress towards World Health Organization (WHO) goals for morbidity control and elimination as a public health problem. Typically, prevalence and intensity data are collected from school-aged children (SAC) as they are easy to sample and likely to be infected with schosome parasites. However, adults are also likely infected. This study investigates how the age distribution of infection impacts mathematical recommendations for preventive chemotherapy levels to achieve WHO goals using three different intensity profiles of Schistoma mansoni infection: low, moderate, and high burdens in adults. Results show that in moderate prevalence regions, regardless of adult burden, treating SAC may achieve WHO goals. In high prevalence regions with high adult burden, adult treatment is required to meet goals. Optimal strategy for a region requires consideration of adult burden, not solely based on SAC prevalence. Past epidemiological data informed models for schosome transmission control, but more detailed data from M&E are needed to determine optimal strategy. Collecting prevalence and intensity from broader age range, including adults at baseline and throughout treatment, rather than SAC, is crucial for accurate strategy. Additional data, such as individual adherence, should be collected in M&E.
Researchers developed a computational model of temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE) using structural connectivity data from diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) of 22 individuals with TLE and 39 healthy controls. The model was validated by comparing patient-control differences in seizure onset time and location. The study investigated the model's potential for predicting surgery by simulating resections and comparing post-surgery to pre-surgery seizure likelihood. Results showed that patients transitioned from non-epileptic to epileptic states more often than controls. Regions in the left hemisphere, particularly temporal and subcortical, were frequent seizure starting points in patients. Contralateral frontal regions implicated in seizure spreading or resistance. The model predicted patient-specific resection areas led to better outcomes than routine clinical procedure.
Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) employs various strategies to evade the host's innate antiviral defenses, including interference with interferon and apoptotic signaling pathways. Four viral interferon regulatory factors (vIRFs 1-4) function in a dominant-negative manner to block cellular IR activities and target IRF-induced proteins such as p53 and TGF-β-activated Smad transcription factors. This study identifies vIR-1's direct targeting of Bim, a pro-apoptotic Bcl-2 family member, to its inactivation via nuclear translocation. Immunofluorescence and western analysis of fractionated cell extracts revealed vIR-1-mediated localization of Bim in infected cells. Co-localization of vIR-1 and B was detected in nuclei of lytically infected endothelial cells. Co-precipitation assays using purified v-1 and B revealed a direct interaction between the proteins. B-binding residues of v-1 were mapped by deletion and mutagenesis. Generation of B-refactory v-1 variants demonstrated the importance of v-1:B interaction in prolication and anti-apopt activity. Blocking the interaction with a cell-perme peptide corresponding to the B-binding region of v- confirmed the relevance v-1:B association to v- prolication. This is the first report of an IR protein interacting with a B-2 family member and sequestration of B or any member as a means of inactivation. The study reveals a novel mechanism used by a virus to control replication-induced apoptosis and targeting v-1:B interaction may provide an antiral strategy.
Epithelial Integrin Regulates the Amplitude of Protective Lung Interfer Responses against Respiratory Pathogens

The lung maintains a state of immune readiness to rapidly respond to injury, with integrins playing a crucial role in setting this state. Epithelial-restricted αβ integrin, specifically, is upregulated during injury and modulates acute lung injury (ALI). Research reveals that upregulation of αβ during influenza infection is involved in disease pathogenesis. Mice lacking β (β KO) exhibit increased survival during infection due to limited viral spread into alveolar spaces, resulting in reduced ALI. Despite normal lung morphology, β KO mice harbor constitutively activated CD11+ alolar macrophages (AM) and elevated type IFN activity, attributed to loss of β-activated growth factor (TGF). Administration of exogenous TGF to β KO mice reduces CD11+ AM, type IF activity, and protective phenotype during infection. Protection extends to other pathogens Sendai virus and bacterial pneumonia. Studies demonstrate loss of epithelial protein αβ integrin alters lung microenvironment during homeostasis and infection, reducing injury and improving survival.
Researchers conducted a retrospective analysis of 733 cases of cutaneous leishmaniasis at a reference center in Argentina from 2006-2015 to evaluate the usefulness of the Leishman Skin Test (LST) as a diagnostic tool. Leishmania Viannia braziliensis is the most common species causing cutaneous and mucosal leishiasis in the Americas. Diagnosis is typically based on identifying amastigotes in lesions, but this is limited by low parasite burden. ST is a delayed hypersensitivity test to Leish antigens injected intradermally, used in endemic areas as a complement to diagnosis. The analysis included 93% localized cutaneous, 7% mucosal, and <1% disseminated cases. Confirmation was reached in 65% through smears from skin or muc lesions, with only 6 having negative ST. Among negative smear cases, 190 were also negative ST, but 69 ST positive. Sensitivity ratios between smear and ST were similar across age groups. Lesions >21 days old correlated with positive results for both smear and ST significantly more than younger. These findings support ST as a diagnostic complement for cutaneous leishias across age groups in endemic areas. Correlation with smear was high. Standardization and research into protocols will aid management of suspicious cases.
Genome-wide association studies have identified over 40 loci associated with coronary artery disease (CAD) risk, but the mechanisms underlying most of these loci remain unknown. Recent studies suggest that many GWAS variants influence disease through altered transcriptional regulation in disease-relevant cell types. This study investigated transcriptional changes during a key CAD pathophysiological event, the lipid-induced transformation of macrophages to lipid-laden foam cells. A combination of chromatin mapping with formaldehyde-assisted isolation of regulatory elements (FA-seq) and enhancer transcription mapping using chromatin immunoprecipitation (IP) was used in primary macrophages before and after exposure to atherogenic oxidized low-density lipoprotein (oxLD), resulting in foam cell formation. Oxid-induced cell formation was associated with changes in a subset of chromatin and enhancers that correlated with expression of nearby genes. Ox-regulated enhancers were enriched for transcription factors, including CEB-beta, previously uninvolved in foam formation. Ox exposure upregulated CEB expression and increased genomic binding, most around genes in inflammatory pathways. Variants at CAD loci were enriched in subset chrom sites altered by ox exposure, including rs643 in ox-induced enhancer at PP2 locus. Ox increased CEB binding to site and C binding and enhancer activity were stronger with protective allele rs643. Additionally, PP2 protein product L3 was present in human atherosclerotic plaques and ox exposure upregulated L3 in macrophages, increasing pro-inflammatory mediators.
A study was conducted in Malawi to evaluate the effectiveness of a single round of azithromycin mass drug administration (MDA) in districts with trachoma follicular inflammation (TF) prevalence of 5.0-9.9% in children aged 1-9 years. The World Health Organization recommends three rounds of azithycin treatment in districts with TF prevalence ≥10%, but this may not be practical due to the large number of endemic districts and resource constraints. In 8 Malawi districts with baseline TF prevalence of 5.0-9%, a single round of azithycin was administered to the entire district, achieving 80% coverage. Population-based trach surveys were conducted in 18 evaluation units of the treated districts 6 months post-MDA, using standardized methodologies conforming to WHO recommendations. Each evaluation unit had TF prevalence <5.0%. The study found that in Malawi districts with TF 5.0-9%, one round of azithycin MDA with 80% coverage resulted in TF prevalence <5%.
Arabidopsis thaliana NLR immune signaling is mediated by Ca2+-dependent protein kinases. Nucleotide-binding leucine-rich repeat (NLR) protein complexes sense infections and trigger immune responses in plants. Activation of plant resistance (R) proteins by pathogen effectors launches convergent immune responses, including programmed cell death (PCD), reactive oxygen species (ROS) production, and transcriptional reprogramming. Functional genomic and biochemical screens identified six Arabidopsis Ca2-dependent kinases (CPs) mediating bifurcate immune responses by NLR proteins R2 and RPM1. Dynamics of CP2 activation by pathogen effect controls cell death onset. Sustained CP4/5/6 activation phosphorylates WR transcription factors WRKY28/48, regulating transcriptional reprogramming for N-dependent pathogen restriction. CP2/4/11 phosphorylate plasma membrane NAD oxidases for ROS production.
Researchers conducted a retrospective study on the time-series forecasting of Schistosoma haematium in the district of Nion, Mali, from 1996 to 2004. The study aimed to develop a parsimonious forecasting system for public health programs in developing countries to manage parasitic diseases. Generalized exponential smoothing methods, encapsulated in a state-space framework, were used to accommodate seasonal and inter-annual fluctuations in the time-series. Results showed mean absolute error values of 25% for 1-5 month forecasts. The state-space framework produced accurate forecasts for Schos haematium-induced hematuria incidence, capturing non-linear interactions between disease dynamics and exogenous covariates such as climate, irrigation, and health interventions. This method obviated the need for more complex forecasting methods in the district. The study suggests the framework can assist in managing and assessing Sch haemat transmission and intervention impact in the district, and potentially in the Sahel region.
Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) has evolved a mechanism to restrict its replication in host cells by utilizing the tegument protein pp150, which binds to cyclin A and prevents viral gene expression during the S/G2 cell cycle phase in permissive cells. To investigate the physiological relevance of this restriction during productive CMV infection, a cyclin-binding deficient pp150 mutant virus was employed. Unrestricted viral expression in S2 led to G2 arrest, but not mitotic cells supported viral replication. Cyclin destabilization by viral product p21 was required to maintain permissive G2 arrest. An HCM double mutant with both pp and p21 disabled in cyclin interaction forced mitotic entry of infected cells, severely impacting cell and virus growth viability.
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a neurodegenerative disease characterized by progressive degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. Approximately 10% of ALS cases are familial, with the remaining 90% being sporadic. Genetic studies in familial ALS have identified causative mutations, with some mutations also linked to sporadic cases. However, the cause of 30% familial and most sporadic cases remains unknown. Sporadic ALS represents an underutilized resource for genetic information. A targeted sequencing of 169 ALS candidate genes in 242 sporadic cases and 129 controls was conducted to identify novel variants linked to ALS. A significant enrichment of novel and rare variants in cases versus controls was found, indicating disease association. This study demonstrates the utility of next-generation sequencing with functional and rare variant analysis to elucidate sporadic disease etiology.
Researchers investigated the role of Interleukin-6 (IL-6) in the development of T cell memory to influenza virus. IL-6 is a cytokine that regulates T cell proliferation and survival, and its levels increase after influenza infection. The study compared virus-specific T cell activity in wild-type and IL-6 deficient mice. The results show that IL-6 is crucial for CD4+ but not CD8 T cell memory to influenza. IL-6 suppresses CD4+CD25+ regulatory T (Treg) cells, limiting their activity and facilitating virus-specific CD4 T cells. Influenza-induced IL-6 reduces virus-specific Tregs, allowing virus-specific CD4 cells to function. This suggests IL-6 ensures that during acute infection, antigen-specific Tregs do not downregulate the immune response, promoting pathogen clearance and host survival.
Researchers have identified a new function for the enzyme enolase in the parasite Entamoeba histolytica, a glycolytic enzyme that converts 2-phosphoglycerate to phosphoenpyruate. Enase was found to have both cytoplasmic and nuclear localization in the parasite and was shown to interact with the Dmt2 protein, a DNA and RNA methyltransferase. This interaction was discovered through a yeast two-hybrid screen. Enase was found to inhibit Dmt activity, and this inhibitory effect was antagonized by 2-P, suggesting that glucose metabolism controls enase's non-glytic function. Glucose starvation caused enase to accumulate in the nucleus, leading to the formation of an enase-E histtica DN2 homolog (Ehm) complex and a reduction in tRNA methylation in the parasite. The role of enase as a Dmt inhibitor was also demonstrated in E histolytica expressing a nuclear localization signal (LS)-enase. These findings establish enase as the first Dmt interacting protein and reveal an unexpected role for a glyytic enzyme in modulating Dmt activity.
Researchers have identified microRNAs (miRNAs) in the saliva of mosquitoes for the first time, which play a crucial role in the transmission of Chikungunya virus (CHV) infection. Mosquito saliva is a complex mixture of secretions that modulate the feeding process to enhance pathogen establishment. Previous studies have identified salivary proteins that enhance pathogen infection. The study used next-generation sequencing to identify 103 exogenous miRNAs in mosquito saliva, 31 of which were novel. Several miRNAs were expressed only in CHV-infected mosquitoes. Five miRNAs were tested for their potential to regulate CHV infection, demonstrating a functional role in transmission and establishment during feeding on the host.
Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) encodes proteins essential for cellular respiration and deletions in the genome have been linked to maternally inherited diseases and cancers. Most deletions in human cells are flanked by short repetitive sequences, suggesting recombination events. This study investigated the role of double-strand break (DS) repair proteins Rad51, Rad52, and Rad59 in mtDNA repair in Saccharces cerevisiae. Rad51 and Rad59 were localized to the mitochondria and Rad51 bound directly to mtDNA. A mitochondally-targeted restriction endonuc (mt-KI) was used to create a double-strand break (DSB) in the genome, allowing analysis of DSB repair in vivo. Loss of these proteins decreased spontaneous deletions and loss of Rad51 and Rad impaired mtDSB repair.
A systematic review examined the role of social determinants of health in the risk and prevention of Group A Streptoccal infection, acute rheumatic fever, and rheumatic heart disease. Rheumatic heart disease (RHD) poses a significant burden among disadvantaged populations, resulting from acute rheumatic fever (AR), a complication of Group A Streptoc (GAS) infection. The study aimed to determine the association between social determinants of health and GAS, AR, and RHD, and the effect of interventions targeting these. A systematic review of PubMed, Cochrane, and Embase databases included observational and experimental studies measuring crowding, dwelling, characteristics, education, employment, income, socioeconomic status, and their relationship with GAS, AR, or RHD. 1,164 publications were identified, 90 met criteria, comprising 91 studies, 49.5% were poor quality. The proportion of studies reporting associations between socioeconomic determinants and risk of GAS was 57.1%, AR/RHD 50%. Crow was most assessed (14 studies GAS, 36 AR/RHD) followed by socioeconomic (6, 36). Studies assessing crow, dwelling, characteristics, education, employment, parents, nutrition reported positive association risk GAS, AR/RHD. Crow, socioeconomic met criteria causal association. Heterogeneity across all aspects. Literature examining social determinants lacks quality, mostly observational, not interventional. Crow cause GAS, AR/RHD presents prevention target.
A single mutation in the phosphatase activity of the sensor kinase Pho in the Pho/Pho bacterial signaling network results in a striking change in phenotype. The mutant responds to stimuli in a bistable manner, whereas the wild-type exhibits a graded response. Mutant cells exhibit distinct morphologies in on and off states, with the state being inherited over generations. External conditions that repress signaling in the wild-type drive the mutant to the on state. Mathematical modeling suggests bistability is due to positive autoregulation of Pho and PhQ. The mutant state has lower fitness in stationary cultures in rich medium, but due to inheritance, a population can be epigenetically trapped in a low-fitness state.
Primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM), caused by the free-living amoeba Naegleria fowleri, is a rare but potentially life-threatening infection with a high mortality rate and limited treatment options. Due to the lack of economic incentives for pharmaceutical companies to develop anti-AM drugs, research relies on drug repurposing, applying known treatments for rare diseases. N. fleri requires ergosterol, a plasma membrane component, and disrupting sterol biosynthesis is a validated strategy against fungal pathogens. The N. fleri genome encodes sterol-demethylase CYP51, sharing 35% sequence identity with fungal orthologs, suggesting repurposing antifungal drugs. This study assessed the impact of antifungal azoles, conazoles, on N. fleri sterol biosynthesis and viability, identified the endogenous C51 substrate by mass spectrometry, and analyzed interactions between recombinant C51 and conoles. Results validated C51 as a druggable target in N. fleri and conazoles as candidates for AM treatment.
Researchers investigated the role of interleukin-4 receptor alpha (IL-4α) in the maintenance and recall of protective immunity against nematode infection. Nematodes trigger a type 2 immune response via IL-4α, but its role in maintaining this response after polarization was unknown. A mouse model with temporally controlled IL-4α deletion was used to determine its function. Sustained IL-4α expression was required for maintaining type 2 responses and protective immunity after Nippostrongylus brasiliensis infection. Temporal deletion of IL-4α before secondary infection with N. brasiliensis showed efficient recall type 2 responses and parasite clearance. This study demonstrates sustained IL-4α signaling is necessary for anti-nemat type 2 immunity, a novel function distinct from its role in polarization.
A global analysis of the distribution of Bartonella bacteria in mammals reveals the impact of human activity on disease risk for humans, commensal animals, and wildlife. The study examined the largest collection of Bartonella glA genotypes, including 67 new genotypes, to understand the evolution and transmission patterns of this pathogenic genus. Results indicate that Bartonella likely originated as an environmental bacterium infecting insects before transitioning to mammals. Rodents and domestic animals serve as reservoirs or primary hosts for most Bartonella genotypes in humans. The study also found evidence of Bartonella exchange between phylogenetically distant domestic and wildlife animals due to increased contact.
Long noncoding RNA MALAT plays a crucial role in regulating cell cycle progression by modulating the expression of oncogenic transcription factor BMYB. MALAT is upregulated in cancer tissues and associated with hyperproliferation, but its underlying mechanism is poorly understood. Genome-wide transcriptome analysis in human diploid fibroblasts reveals MALAT modulates expression of cell cycle genes required for G1 and mitotic progression. Depletion of MALAT leads to activation of p53 and its target genes. Cell cycle defects in MALAT-depleted cells are sensitive to p53 levels, indicating p53 is major mediator of MALAT activity. MALAT-depleted cells display reduced expression of BMYB, oncogenic factor in G progression due to altered splicing of BMY preRNA and aberrant splicing. In cells, MALAT promotes proliferation by modulating expression and preRNA of cycle transcription factors.
Juvenile hormone (JH), a sesquiterpen produced by the corpora all, plays a crucial role in coordinating insect growth, metamorphosis, and reproduction. While J's action in repressing larval metamosis has been well studied, the molecular basis of J in promoting adult reproduction has not been fully elucidated. Methop-toler (Met), the J receptor, has been shown to mediate J action during metamosis as well as vitelogenesis, but the precise mechanism underlying the latter has been lacking. Researchers used RNA interference (RNAi) to phenocopy J-deprived in migratory locusts, demonstrating that J stimulates DNA replication and increases ploidy in preparation for vitelogenesis. Mc4 and Mc7, genes in the DNA replication pathway were expressed in presence of J and Met. Depletion of Mc or Mc inhibited de novo synthesis and polloid, resulting in reduction of vitelin mRNA as well as impaired oocyte maturation and ovarian growth. Luciferase reporter and electrophoretic mobility assays showed Met directly regulates Mc and Mc by binding upstream sequences with E-box or E-like motifs. The study suggests J-receptor acts on Mc and Mc to regulate replication and ploidy vitelogenesis and oocyte maturation.
A randomized controlled trial, the "Treatment of Early Neuropathy in Lepros" (TENL), investigated the effectiveness of 20-week versus 32-week prednisone treatment in patients with recent nerve function impairment (NFI) due to leprosy. The study included 868 patients, 429 in the 20-week arm and 439 in the 32-week arm, who received prednisone at 45-60mg/day based on body weight, tapered over 20 or 32 weeks. Nerve function was assessed by muscle testing and monofilament at baseline and week 78. The primary outcome was the proportion of patients with improved or restored function at week 78. Secondary outcomes included Reaction Scale, SAL Scale, Participation Scale, and Serious Adverse Events. At week 78, the proportion of patients with improved or restored nerve function did not differ between groups: 78.1% in 20-week and 77.5 in 32-week (p=0.821). No differences were found in secondary outcomes, except a higher Serious Adverse Events in the 32-week arm. A 20-week predone course was as effective as 32-week in improving and restoring NFI in lepro patients. Twenty weeks is the preferred initial duration for lepro neuropathy, with a minority requiring individualized treatment.
Researchers studied the vocalizations of male Rocky Mountain elk (Cervus elus nelsoni) and European Red Deer (Cervus elus scus) to understand how sound production relates to anatomy and physiology. A finite element model of the larynx and wave model of vocal tract, based on elk morphology and biomechanics, simulated sound production. The model produced a wide range of fundamental frequencies. Low frequencies required low vocal fold strain, high lung pressure, and glottal flow for sound levels over 70 dB at 10m. High-frequency bugles needed large muscular strain, high pressure, and 10 dB more intensity. Glottal efficiency, ratio of radiated power to aerodynamic at glott, was higher in elk, suggesting high-pitched signaling advantage. This was due to lower aerodynamic power and acoustic radiation at higher frequencies. Both types were used by males during mating, serving as honest signals. Low-frequency (Red call) related to body size, high-frequency (bugle) to muscular endurance.
Researchers have developed a new approach to analyze chromatin immunoprecipitation followed by high-through sequencing (ChIP-seq) data, a technique used to map transcription factor binding sites and chromatin modifications, by incorporating reads that map to multiple locations on the genome (multi-reads). Current methods using only uniquely mapping reads (uni-reads) can miss up to 30% of alignable reads. The new approach allocates multi-reads as fractional counts using a weighted scheme. Using STAT1 and GATA1 IP-seq datasets, the incorporation of multi-reads increases sequencing depth, detects novel peaks not identifiable by uni-reads, and improves peak detection in mappable regions. Genome-wide characteristics of peaks detected by multi-reads are similar to uni-read, except most reside in segmental duplications. Validation of GATA multi-read peaks by quantitative ChIP confirms novel targets. The study demonstrates multi-read importance for transcription factor binding in repetitive regions with IPq experiments.
The World Health Organization (WHO) has set targets to control or eliminate four neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) by 2020, including African trypanosomiasis, lepro, visceral leishmanias, and Chagas disease, through innovative and intensified management (IDM). A study estimated the socioeconomic benefits of achieving these targets by analyzing productivity loss and out-of-pocket payments (OPPs) related to these diseases, combined with projections of people affected individuals and countries from 2011-2020 and 202-203. The study compared an ideal scenario where WHO targets are met with a counterfactual scenario assuming no change from 1990. Economic benefits were calculated as the difference between scenarios, discounted at 3% from 2010. Probabilistic analyses quantified uncertainty around the base estimate. The global productivity gain for IDM-NTs was $23.1 (15.9-34) billion in 201-202 and $35.9 (25-51.9) in 202-203, corresponding to $10.7 (7.4-15.7) and $16.6 (11-24) in OPP reduction. The study faced limitations, including no data for lepro, combining data from various sources with heterogeneous quality. Despite this, the benefits of achieving targets are considerable, exceeding investments by endemic governments and partners. The frequency of NTDs among the poorest households makes these investments valuable for improving well-being and reducing inequity.
In the auditory cortex, the relationship between neuronal selectivity and population coding accuracy has been widely accepted as neurons with higher selectivity carrying more information about sensory inputs. However, this notion is challenged by a study that found population conveys similar information about sound across two response epochs, despite selectivity differences. Initially, neurons respond to a broad range of inputs, then become highly selective in sustained response. The prevailing theory suggests first epoch encodes presence, second encodes content. Contrary to this, population conveys similar information in both epochs. The amount of encoded is dependent on total population spikes in read window. Inhomogeneous Poisson spiking accounts for this property.
Researchers investigated the role of the co-stimulatory molecule O40 (CD134) in controlling persistent viral infections. Unlike acute viral infections, where the pathogen is cleared by anti-viral T cells, chronic infections require sustained T responses to control replication and prevent spread. While inhibitory signals, such as PD-1, are known to limit T activity, little is understood about stimulatory signals that maintain antiiral cells. O40 was found to be critical in controlling LCMV 13 infection. Antiiral cells expressed high levels of O40 in the presence of cognate antigen, while cells lacking O40 receptor failed to accumulate. Germinal center T responses and LV-specific antibodies were severely impaired in O-deficient mice. Consequently, these mice failed to control LV 13 over time, highlighting the importance of this pathway in persistent infection.
Convergent Evolution of Mechanically Optimal Locomotion in Aquatic Invertebrates Vertebrates

Convergent evolution of mechanically optimal locomotion in aquatic invertebrates and vertebrates refers to the independent evolution of similar traits in different species despite the absence of the trait in their common ancestor. This phenomenon is observed in cases such as the wing and camera-type eye in vertebrates and invertebrates. However, instances of convergent evolution of locomotory patterns that quantitatively agree with mechanically optimal solutions are rare. A study on a diverse group of aquatic animals reveals that a mechanically optimal method of swimming with elongated fins has evolved independently at least eight times in vertebrate and inverte swimmers across three phyla.

The study measures the length of undulation along an animal's fin during swimming and divides it by the mean amplitude of undulations along the fin, resulting in a consistently around 20. This value is called the optimal wavelength (OS). The OS maximizes the force generated by the body, also maximizing swimming speed. A mechanical basis for this optimality is hypothesized and reasons for its repeated emergence through evolution are suggested.
Researchers investigated the role of condens, a class of evolutionarily conserved protein complexes, in neural stem cell (NS) divisions during cerebral cortex development. They found that two types of condens complexes, condens I and II, are essential for NS survival in mice. Simultaneous depletion of both condens leads to severe chromosome assembly and segregation defects, causing DNA damage and p53-induced apoptosis. Individual depletion of condens I or II results in slower loss of NS, with distinct mitotic defects: chromosome missegregation in condin II-depleted NS and mitotic delays in condin I-depleted NS. NS depleted of condin II display hyperclustering pericentric heterochatin and nucleoli, indicating condin II's role in interphase architecture. These defects persist in postmitotic neurons.
Researchers investigated the molecular mechanisms of sex determination and differentiation in Schistosoma mansoni, a species of hermaphroditic trematode with gonochorism. The parasite's sex is determined by a female heterogetic system, but phenotypic sexual dimorphism appears only after infection of the vertebrate host. The study analyzed the transcriptome of S. mansoni in a stage and sex-comparative manner, performing RNA-seq on males and females at five developmental stages: cercaria, larvae, three schistosulum stages, and adults. A total of 7,168 genes were differentially expressed between sexes in at least one stage, with 4,065 functionally annotated. Transcript data were complemented with H3K27me3 histone modification analysis using ChIP-seq before (cercaria) and after (adults) phenotyp sexual dimorphism. The study identified candidate determinants of sexual differentiation, sex-based players of interaction with vertebrate host, and dynamic of H3K27me3 histone mark between sexes as illustration of sex-based epigen landscapes. Results show sexual differentiation in S. mans is accompanied by distinct male and female transcription landscapes of host-parasite cros, genetic determinants and epigen regulators. This combination could lead to sexual dimorphism of parasitic species. S. mans is pathogenic for humans, this study provides therapeutic targets, data on parasite interaction with vertebrate and reproductive function.
Researchers have developed an approach to address disagreements among experts in large-scale annotation efforts by assigning a confidence value to each annotation, representing the probability of correctness. This confidence level is calculated based on individual annotator-specific parameters estimated from data. Two probabilistic models were created to perform this analysis, and their performance was compared through simulation and testing on a dataset generated by human annotators for this study. Results show that even when all annotators disagree, this approach significantly increases the probability of selecting the correct annotation. A corpus of 10,000 sentences was annotated by eight experts, with a 1,000 further annotated by five, representing a specialized curation task. However, the modeling is applicable to most annotation studies.
Researchers have developed a DNA vaccine platform using geese to produce antiviral biologics, specifically polyclonal neutralizing antibodies, to protect against hantavirus pulmonary syndrome (HPS), a deadly disease caused by Andes virus (AND) and AND-like viruses in South America. The availability of convalescent plasma from survivors is limited, prompting the exploration of alternative treatments. Geese were vaccinated with a DNA vaccine encoding AND virus envelope glycoproteins, resulting in high levels of neutralizing antibodies after the second vaccination and maintained over a year. A booster vaccination led to exceptionally high levels of neutralizing antibodies. Analysis of the antibodies showed high reactivity to specific amino sequences of AND envelope glycoprote. The protective efficacy of goose-derived antibodies was tested in a hamster model of lethal HPS, where sera or Ig/IgFc from vaccinated geese were passively transferred subcutaneously 5 days after challenge with AND (25LD50). Both immune sera and egg-purified Ig/IgFc protected 8/8 and 7/8 hamsters, respectively. In contrast, hamsters receiving IgFc from non-vaccinated ge or no-treatment developed HPS. This demonstrates the DNA/goose platform can produce a candidate antiral product preventing lethal disease post-exposure.
Changes in DNA methylation patterns have been implicated in the development of human cancers. The Dn3 enzyme is crucial for establishing normal methylation patterns, and mutations in D3 have been linked to leukemias. Deletion of D3 in a K-ras-dependent lung cancer model promoted tumor progression, suggesting it may suppress cancer by stabilizing DNA methylation. This study used whole-genome bisulf sequencing to characterize methylomes of D3 wildtype and D3-deficient lung tumors. Results showed profound methylation changes in K-r-induced lung cancer. D3 wild-type tumors had large hypomethyl domains corresponding to lamina-associated regions. In contrast, D-deficient tumors had uniformly hypomethyl genome. Further analysis revealed D is required for efficient methylation of active chromosome domains and D-deficient showed moderate deregulation in these domains.
