Researchers have identified mesoscopic patterns of neural activity in the premotor cortex of songbirds that support the generation of cortical sequences. These sequences of neural activity are found in various vertebrate species and contexts, including the hippocampus of rodents, where they control movement and temporal generation are integral to learned behavior. However, the underlying mechanisms of sequence generation are not well understood. This study describes the spatial and temporal organization of the premotor cortical microcircuit in songbirds that supports sequences of neural activity. Multi-channel electrophysiology and calcium imaging reveal that activity in premotor cortex is correlated at a scale of 100 micrometers. Within this scale, basal ganglia-projecting excitatory neurons, on average, fire at a phase of a 30 Hz rhythm. These results show premotor activity is inhomogeneous in time and space, and a mesoscopic pattern underlies the generation of sequences controlling song.
Researchers investigated the role of evolutionarily conserved genes essential for growth and development in regulating lifespan in Caenorhabditis elegans. They screened 2,700 genes essential for development and identified 64 that extend lifespan when inactivated post-development. These candidate regulators are conserved from yeast to humans. Classification into functional groups revealed insulin and metabolic pathways, but also enrichment for translation, RNA, and chromatin factors. Many essential inactivations extend lifespan as much as strongest regulators of aging. Early inactivation of these genes caused growth arrest at larval stages, and some arrested live longer than wild-type adults. d-16 is required for survival of arrested larvae, suggesting increased longevity a physiological response to inactivation. Results suggest insulin-signaling plays role in aging regulation at any life stage.
Researchers conducted a forward genetic screen to identify mutations that impair the formation of the epidermis during zebraf fin regeneration. They identified a temperature-sensitive allele of laminin beta 1 (lamba) that blocks fin regeneration. Lamin beta 1, but not its paralog lamin beta 1, is induced in a subset of epithelial cells after amputation and is required to establish a polarized epithelial layer. Expression of morphogenetic factors shha and lef, basolateral positioning of phosphorylated Igf1, patterning of osteoblasts, and regeneration of bone are facilitated by lamin 1. In contrast, lamin 1 is dispensable for juvenile growth, homeostatic tissue, adult maintenance, repair of fins, or renewal of genetically ablated osteoblast. Mutations or transgenic receptor inhibition disrupt lamin 1 expression, linking growth to epithelial maturation during regeneration.
Researchers compared the performance of several linear mixed models (LMM) approaches and software packages, including EMM, GenABEL, FaSTMM, Mendel, GEMMA, and MMM, in a genome-wide association study of visceral leishmaniasis in 348 families with 362 individuals. The study aimed to evaluate the differences between newly-proposed and previously-proposed methods and investigate sensitivity to user-chosen options such as the method and number of SNPs to estimate kinship matrix. The results showed strong concordance between LMM approaches in controlling genome-wide error rate, except for some approaches applied to longitudinal data with repeated measures. LMM results were compared to traditional family-based tests and alternative approaches in MQL, ROADIPS and MAST, showing high correlation between LMM and alternative approaches except transmission-based for SNPs with small or non-existent effects. The study concluded that LMM perform well compared to competing approaches, with choice of implementation based on considerations such as speed and ease-of-use rather than power I error.
Researchers have developed a high-throughput screening assay to identify compounds that inhibit the infection of mammalian cells by Trypanosoma cruzi, the parasite responsible for Chagas disease. A 200-compound library was screened using a recombinant T. cruzi strain expressing β-galactosidase. Three compounds, P1, NT, and CX, were selected for their high activity against T. cruz and low toxicity to host cells in vitro, with IC50 values of 54, 190, and 23 nM, respectively. Each compound has a distinct mechanism of action on intracellular T. cruzi proliferation: CX shows trypanocidal activity, essential for chronic stage treatment, NT has tryostatic effect, and P1 affects division. These compounds also exhibit activity against intracellular T. cruz from Y strain and related species Leishmania major and amazonensis. Characterization of anti-T. cruz activity led to selection of two compounds with IC values 2M, P6 and CX, approximately 100 times lower than current medicines.
Researchers have developed a novel point-of-care diagnostic platform for detecting Brugia parasites in mosquitoes, which is crucial for lymphatic filariasis molecular monitoring. Current methods rely on PCR or real-time PCR detection of Brugia malayi, Brug timori, and Wuchereria bancrofti in vectors, but DNA extraction using silica-based technologies is time-consuming and costly, and testing requires expensive thermal cyclers or real-time instruments. To address this, a rapid NaOH-based DNA extraction method was coupled with a portable, battery-powered PCR and strip-based detection assay. This proof-of-concept study demonstrates the backpack PCR platform's feasibility for filarial parasite detection, adaptable to W bancroft and other mosquito-transmitted pathogens. A rapid NaOH extraction method was compared to silica-based DNA extraction from parasite-spiked mosquito pools, showing similar performance. The strip-based assay was compared to real-time PCR and conventional PCR with gel electrophoresis, demonstrating sensitive and specific detection. A miniaturized PCR was compared to laboratory-based cycling, showing potential for point-of-collection use. This platform eliminates reliance on expensive instrumentation without compromising detection sensitivity or specificity, offering an alternative to column-dependent extractions requiring infrastructure. This field-ready system increases molecular monitoring feasibility in B. malayi-endemic areas, and provides a framework for W bancft detection.
Researchers have studied the self-assembly of elastomeric proteins, which are proteins that have evolved independently multiple times to form polymeric structures with elastic properties. These proteins are composed of alternating domains of elastomeric and cross-linking elements, where the former provide elasticity and drive assembly, and the latter stabilize the polymer. Changes in the number and arrangement of these domains impact assembly and mechanical properties. A theoretical study used a model of diffusion-limited aggregation to simulate the self-assembly of rod-like particles with different architectures, generating various aggregates analyzed by graph-theoretic metrics. The results show that the length and number of elastom and cross-link domains significantly affect the morphology and integrity of the polymeric structure. Highly connected polymers were formed from rods with large cross-link elements interspersed with smaller elastom domains. This study provides insights into the evolution of elastom proteins and may be useful for designing new biomaterials with tunable properties.
Researchers have investigated the functions of the 5' untranslated regions (UTRs) in the genome of the Zaire ebolavirus (EBOV), a highly lethal zoonotic pathogen. The 5-UTRs were found to lack internal ribosomal entry function, but differentially regulate cap-dependent translation when placed upstream of a reporter gene. The 5-UT from the viral polymerase (L) mRNA strongly suppressed translation compared to the beta-actin 5-UT. The L 5-UT contains four upstream AUGs (uAUGs), and ablating each uA enhanced translation of the open reading frame (ORF), most notably in the L5-UT. The uA was sufficient to initiate translation, surrounded by a weak Kozak sequence and suppressed ORF in a position-dependent manner. Under conditions of eIFalpha phosphorylation, the uOR maintained translation of LOR, indicating the u modulates translation in response to cellular stress. A recombinant EBO was generated with the uA mutated to UCG, resulting in a 10-100 fold lower titers than wild-type in Vero A549 cells. The mutant exhibited decreased RNA synthesis as early as 6 post-infection and enhanced sensitivity to thapsargin.
Researchers have developed a method for precise genome-wide mapping of double-strand breaks (DSBs) in human chromosomes, revealing non-random and fragmented DS hotspots. These hotspots are scattered along chromosomes and limited to 50-250 kb DNA domains. Approximately 30% of these domains possess co-expressed genes. PARP1 and HNRPA2B specifically bind DNA sequences at domain termini. The study suggests a novel gene regulation mechanism: coordinated transcriptional silencing of gene clusters by DS hotspots and PAR1/HPA2B binding sites.
Researchers conducted a study in the Atlantic Forest of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil to investigate the presence of Trypanosomatidae in bats in two areas with different levels of degradation: Reserva Ecológica Guçu (REG) and Estação Florestal Mata Atlântica (EFMA). The study aimed to evaluate the diversity of Trypanomatids in relation to bat diversity and preservation levels in the region. The results showed no influence of preservation level on bat species richness, with 15 species found in REG and 14 in EF, including common fruit-eating species Carollia persillata and Artibe litatus. Of 181 bat specimens analyzed, 24 (13%) were infected, including one Sira individual positive by blood examination. Molecular characterization using PCR targeting 18S rRNA gene showed similar Tryosid infection rates in both areas, 15% in REG and 11 in EF (p=0.46). Trypanosionii was the most detected parasite (54%), followed by T cruzi DTI and TIV and Tryos sp, in Neotropical phlost bats RN63 and RN56; mixed infections Tionii/cruz TIII and dionii/cruzTI were observed. T cruz DTI and IV are genotypes involved in acute Chagas disease in Brazil, and dionii was found in heart tissue of infected child. Crithia mellae, a putative monoxen parasite from insects, infecting vertebrate in Americas, was described for first time.
Ticks are the primary arthropod vectors of human and animal diseases in Europe, with the Ixodes ricinus species transmitting a range of bacteria, viruses, and parasites. This tick species can be co-infected with multiple pathogens, increasing the likelihood of co-transmission to humans or animals. However, data on co-infection prevalence is limited, focusing on well-known pathogens. Ticks also harbor symbionts influencing tick biology and pathogen transmission. This study evaluated the prevalence of 38 pathogens and symbionts, co-infections, and interactions between pathogens and symbion. 267 Ix ricinus females were collected in the Ardennes and analyzed by high-throughput real-time PCR for 37 pathogens, rRT-PCR for Tick-Borne encephalitis virus, and nested PCR for symbion. Results showed 45% co-infection with up to five pathogens. Adding symbion prevalence, all ticks were infected with at least one microorganism, up to eight in one tick. Pathogen interactions suggested association between Borrelia garini and B afii, no symbion-pathogen interaction. This study reveals high co-infection rates in ticks, raising co-transmission concerns to humans, animals, and health consequences. Symbion coexistence with pathogens opens avenues for pathogen transmission research.
Researchers have developed a computational model to understand the hematopoietic eryth-myeloid lineage decision, which is governed by a genetic switch involving the genes PU.1 and GATA-1. Prior to lineage commitment, genes are primed at low expression levels, and the underlying molecular circuitry governing both primed and committed states is crucial for hematopoiesis and developmental systems. The model is based on known interactions between master genes, including mutual antagonism and autoregulation, making the system bistable, a feature for robust lineage determination. A new mechanism involving a cofactor regulated by one of the master genes binds to antagonistic partner is necessary for bistability and switch-like behavior. Suppression of cofactor through external means leads to loss of cooperativity and primed state PU.1 and GATA. The PU.1-GATA switch interacts with another antagonistic pair, FO-G, inheriting state of upstream genes and reinforcing decision through feedback, leading to irreversible commitment. The eryth-myoid lineage switch is an example of network implementing prim and committed by cooperativity through cofactor recruitment. Perturbing feedback between regulators and targets suggests reprogramming strategies. This approach provides a framework for lineage studies and lineage-determining genes.
Enterococcus faecalis, an opportunistic pathogen, exhibits intrinsic resistance to lysozym, a key effector of the innate immune system, due to a complex network of transcriptional regulators and genes (A, pgA, dA, and sigV) that inhibit lyso's enzymatic and antimicrobial activities. To identify novel modulators of this resistance, a quadruple oat/pgA/dlt/sig mutant was subjected to random transposon mutagenesis, leading to the identification of insertions in the enteroccal polysacchar antigen (EPA) region, located downstream of conserved epA-ep genes. The epA region was proposed to encode a synthetic machinery for EPA decoration, but its role was unknown. This study reveals EPA's contribution to resistance against antimicrobials and virulence in a zebraf infection model by conferring phagocytosis resistance. Results indicate that EPA modification of the polysacchar backbone is essential for E. faalis pathogenesis.
Researchers have developed a new method called RER (Regression of Combined Expression) to analyze gene regulation in Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML). This method combines data from the Encyclopedia of DNA Elements (ENCODE) and The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) to understand how genes are expressed. ENCODE provides data on genetic and epigenetic factors such as copy number variation (CN), DNA methylation (DM), transcription factors (TF), and microRNA (mi) post-transcription regulation, while TCGA provides genome-wide signals. RER uses these data to infer sample-specific regulatory activities of TFs and miRNAs, which are then used to infer TF-mi-gene interactions. This two-stage framework overcomes difficulties in integrating EN data with sample-specific TCG measurements. AML data from TCG and TF binding data from K562 in EN were used as a case study. The model was verified with 10-fold cross-validation predicting gene expression. RER was also evaluated for recovering regulatory interactions and detecting mi/TF targets, showing superior power over existing methods. A feature selection identified 18 regulators whose activities clustered with cytogenetic risk, including miR-548, whose targets were enriched for leukemia-related pathways, implicating its role in AML pathogenesis. Survival analysis using inferred activities as a potential AML prognostic marker. This framework integrated TCG and EN data revealing AML regulatory program at a global level.
Researchers investigated the role of RNA interference (RNAi) in the ascomycete fungus Colletotrichum higginsum, a pathogen of various crops worldwide. Knockout mutants were generated for three RNAi-related genes: RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RDR), Dicer (DCL), and Argonaute (AGO). No growth defects were observed in mutants on complex or minimal media. However, Δcl1, ΔclΔcl2, and Δago mutants showed conidiation and conidia morphology defects. Total RNA and small RNA populations were analyzed in parental and mutant strains, revealing greatest effects in Δcl, ΔclΔcl, andago strains. A previously uncharacterized dsRNA mycovirus, Colletum higginsum nonsegmented RNA virus 1 (ChV1), was derepressed in these strains. Phylogenetic analysis showed close relationship between ChV and segmented Partitiviridae, despite nonsegmented genome. Immunoprecipitation of RNAs with AGO1 showed 5U-containing siRNA loading. Parental and Δcl strains cured of ChV showed conid and spore morphology defects caused by ChV. RNAi involving CL and AGO in C is proposed antiv mechanism.
Researchers investigated the role of histone acetyltransferase MOF in meiotic expansion of H2AX phosphorylation during spermatogenesis in mice. Three waves of H2 phosphorylation were observed in meiotic prophase I: ATM-dependent at leptotene, ATR-dependent at zygotene and pachene, and a third wave marking unsynapsed chromosomes. MOF was found to be involved in all three waves of HAX phosphorylation. Germ cell-specific deletion of MO in spermatocytes led to loss of H4acetylation in leptene and zygot spermatocytes, resulting in reduced HAX signals along chromosomal axes and chromatin-wide HAX phosphorylation. In early-mid pachene spermatocytes, HAX and MDC1 were detected along unsyn axes, but failed to expand, causing meiotic sex chromosome inactivation failure. RAD51 was recruited to double-strand break sites, but DSB repair and crossover defects were observed, indicating MO facilitates meiotic DSB repair after RAD51 recruitment. MO regulates meiosis and expands all three HAX waves from leptene to pene stages initiated by ATM and ATR.
Researchers investigated the effects of Human T-cell leukemia virus 1 (HTLV-1) infection on human T-cell development using the "Immune System" (HIS) Rag-2/-γ- mouse model. These mice were infected with HT-1 at a time when three subpopulations of thymocytes have been detected. In all inoculated mice, HT-1 provirus was found in thymocytes, and proviral load increased with infection length. In HT- infected mice, alterations in T development were observed, correlating with proviral load. Mature single-positive (SP) CD4 and CD8 cells were more numerous at expense of immature double-positive (DP) thymocytes in th of HT- infected HIS- mice. These cells also accumulated in spleen. Lymphocytes from thym and spleen were activated, shown by CD25 expression, correlating with tax mRNA and increased NF-κB dependent genes such as bfl-1, anti-apopt gene in thym. Hepatosplenomegaly lymphadenopathy and lymphoma/thymoma were observed in HT- mice several months after infection.
In Sudan, schistosiasis remains a significant public health concern, particularly due to Schistosoma haematium infection. An integrated control program was implemented in Jabal locality, White State, Sudan from 2009-2011, targeting 78,615 primary school students out of a total population of 482,902. Urine and stool specimens were examined using sedimentation and Kato-Kato-Katz methods to assess prevalence. Baseline prevalence of S. haematium and S. mansoni was 28.5% and 0.4%, respectively. After 6-9 months post-treatment, S. haematium prevalence reduced to 13.5% (95%CI=0.331-0.462), with higher reduction in girls (20%) and rural residents compared to boys (40%) and urban. Health education increased awareness and water supply at Alida village reduced infection rate compared to a neighboring village. No significant change in S. mansoni prevalence between baseline and follow-up (95%CI=0.9336.891). At project end, S haematium prevalence reduced by 50% compared to baseline. Approximately 200,000 received praziquantel, education, or clean water.
Researchers have investigated the role of nuclear-cytoplasmic trafficking of the Nip virus (NiV) matrix protein in viral budding. NiV is a highly pathogenic paramyxirus that causes encephalitis in humans and is classified as a Biosafety Level 4 (SL) pathogen. During infection, Ni-M was first detected in the nucleus at early stages before localizing to the cytoplasm and plasma membrane. Mutations in the putative bipartite nuclear localization (LS) and leucine-rich nuclear export (NES) in Ni-M impaired nuclear-ctoplasm trafficking and abolished Ni budding. A conserved lysine residue in LS mediated nuclear import and was also a site for monoubiquination regulating export. Overexpression of ubiquitin enhanced Ni budding while depletion via proteas inhibitors resulted in Ni retention and blocked budding. Live Ni was sensitive to proteas inhibitors: bortomib, an FDA-approved for multiple myeloma, reduced titers with IC 2.7 nM, 100-fold less than achievable in humans.
Researchers have developed an imaging assay to study the early events of poliovirus (PV) infection in live cells. The assay tracks the viral capsid and genome simultaneously with an infectivity-based RNA release assay to characterize the mechanisms of genome delivery. The study reveals that PV genome release is highly efficient and rapid, not limiting overall infectivity or infection rate. PV binds to cell surface receptors and enters through a clathrin, caveolin, flotillin, and microtubule-independent, tyrosine kinase and actin-dependent endocytic mechanism. After internalization, genome release occurs from vesicles or sealed invaginations within 100-200 nm of plasma membrane. This resolves debate on whether PV breaks plasma membrane or relies on endocyt to deliver genome into cell.
Dengue fever remains a significant public health concern in Cambodia, particularly affecting children. The National Dengue Control Program (NP) utilizes health education as a primary means of prevention and control, delivering it to communities and schools. An ethnographic study conducted in eastern Cambodia from 2003-2004 collected data on approaches used in health education and their effectiveness in controlling deng. Community health education provided by the NP's outreach activities and campaigns is not systematically evaluated, underfunded, and irregular; school-based education is limited in time and lacks follow-up on practical prevention activities. As a result, adherence is partial. The study suggests the need for sustained education in deng prevention and control, and approaches to translate knowledge into practice.
Researchers investigated the presence of microRNAs (miRNAs) released by filarial nematodes in the bloodstream of infected hosts. Using miRNA sequencing and bioinformatics, they identified over 200 mature miRNA sequences of nematode origin in Dirofilaria imis-infected dog plasma and Onchocerca volulus-infected human serum. Two miRNA candidates, mi-71 and mi-34, were detected in D. imis-infected dog plasma using stem-loop RT-qPCR assays. Brugia pangi-infected dog samples were also analyzed, as these miRNAs were previously detected in extracts from this species. The presence of mi-71 and mi-34 discriminated infected from uninfected samples, with no mi amplification in uninfected samples. However, miRNA copy numbers were not correlated with microfilaria for either parasite. This may be due to imprecision in mf counts or mi contributions from unknown adult worms. Parasite-derived miRNAs were found in plasma/serum for species not living in bloodstream.
Tyrosine kinases of the Src family are allosteric enzymes that play a crucial role in cellular signaling. The conversion of the kinase from an inactive to an active state is accompanied by substantial structural changes. A coarse-grained model of the catalytic domain was constructed incorporating experimental structures of the two stable states, and dynamics of conformation transitions were simulated. The transition landscapes were explored by constructing a network among clusters of conformations from simulations. Two major pathways for activation were identified. The first pathway involved a coordinated mechanism among the α-helix, activation loop, and β-strands in the N-lobe of the catalytic domain. The second pathway conformation change was coupled to partial unfolding of the N-lo region of the catalytic domain. The switching mechanism of α-helix and loop was characterized in detail. A Markov model was tested and its ability to account for structural in the context of conformation changes. The results provide a framework for understanding the features of conformation taking place upon activation.
Researchers have investigated the molecular mechanisms underlying lethality in F1 hybrids between diverged parents, specifically focusing on crosses between diploid and tetraploid individuals of Arabidopsis thaliana. They found that dosage incompatibility plays a role in polyploid speciation and identified genetic variation in F lethality in interploidy crosses via QTL mapping. A single-effect QTL, DRANGEVE1 (DSL), and two QTL with epistatic relationships to DSL were identified. DSL affects postzygotic lethality via maternal expression in the sporophyte. Fine mapping placed DSL in an interval encoding the maternal transcription factor TT2. Maternal parents carrying loss-function in TT2 suppressed F lethality caused by paternal interplo crosses. Cellularization in the endosperm was affected by natural and tt2 loss-function mutants. The genetic basis of natural variation and single-gene mutations suggests F leth in polloids could evolve rapidly. The sporophytic TT2 gene in interplo crosses indicates developmental programming regulates viability of interplo offspring.
Researchers conducted a comparative host-pathogen coevolution analysis of Bartonella and Leptira bacteria in bats and rodents using genetic data from 51 Bartonella genotypes from 24 bat species, 129 Bartonella from 38 rodents, and 26 Leptira from 20 bats. Maximum likelihood and Bayesian phylogenies were generated for hosts and bacteria, and coevolution congruence was tested using ParaFit, PAC, and Jane. Results showed significant coevolution between Bartonella and bats (ParaFit=1.970, P≤0.001, m value=7.332, P0.000) and between Bartonella and rodents (Para=102.440, P.001, m=86.532, P.000). In contrast, Leptira and bats showed no coevolution (Para=0.004, P.84, m=4.631, P.562). Event-based phylogeny analyses reconstructed evolutionary histories for each group, revealing Leptira bats had the most host switches (0.731) and Bartonella rodents the fewest (0.264). Bartonella exhibited coev with minimal host switching, while Leptira lacked congruence with host and had high host switches. Separate analyses of New and Old World datasets yielded congruent results. The study highlights variable coevolution patterns between pathogens and hosts, attributed to differences in disease transmission and host ecology. Understanding coev patterns and host-switching frequency will predict spillo between mammal reservoirs and humans.
A forced oscillation framework is applied to a chain model of undulatory swimming to investigate how forcing leads to deformation and movement. The study aims to understand how muscle contractions (active swimming) or fluid forces (passive swimming) cause movement. Results show that forcing triggers the first deformation modes of the body, leading to translational motion. Simple forcing patterns can trigger complex kinematics leading to movement. The frequency of muscle activation relative to the natural frequency of the damped oscillator is crucial for emergent deformation characteristics of the body. The approach provides a qualitative understanding of optimal kinematics for fast swimming. Computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations confirm results from the chain model.
Genetic recombination between pathogens from humans and animals has the potential to create novel pathogen strains, as seen in the case of the H1N1N09 influenza pandemic, which originated from a reassortment of swine and avian and human influenza viruses. This study investigates whether genetic recombination between subspecies of the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma brucei from humans and animals can generate new strains of the human pathogen T. b. rhodesiense (Tb), responsible for sleeping sickness (African Trypanosomiasis, HAT) in East Africa. The trait of infectivity in T is conferred by a single gene, SRA, which is transferable to the pathogen Tbb by sexual reproduction. The study tracked inheritance of S in crosses of T and Tbb by co-transmitting genetically-engineered fluorescent trypanosome lines through tse flies. S was transferred into new genetic backgrounds by reproduction between T and T, creating new strains of the path T. There was no evidence of diminished growth or transmissibility of tryosomes carrying S. Expression of S is critical to survival of T in the host, but the gene exists as a single copy in representative of T strains. S was found on homologue chromosome IV in majority of T isolates, but Ugandan T had S on homologues. Mobility of S by recombination explains observed variability of T in Africa. New strains of path T are generated by recombination with animal-infect trypanosomes. Recombinants present risk future outbreaks of H.
Researchers investigated the role of gap junction coupling in the dysfunction of β-cells in Neonatal Diabetes Mellitus (NDM), a condition characterized by disrupted insulin secretion and glucose homeostasis. Gap junction-mediated electrical coupling between β-cells is crucial for coordinating pulsatile insulin response to elevated glucose and suppressing basal insulin secretion. A previous study showed that a critical number of inexcitable cells can suppress overall islet response due to gap coupling, using a murine model of NDM with ATP-insensitive K channels and a multi-cellular islet model. This study examined mechanisms of gap coupling in NDM dysfunction. A computational model was verified against [Ca2] and insulin measurements in islets with ATP-ins K channels under different gap coupling levels. The model predicted how K channel mutations in N suppress [2 and gap role in suppression. Stochastic and insulin dynamics were added to the model. Experimentally and computationally, reduced gap coupling allowed greater glucose-stimulated [2 and insulin with ATP-ins K channels. The model matched suppression [2 clinical N mutations. Significant [2 and insulin recoveries were predicted for many mutations with reduced gap coupling, where noise played a role in recoveries.
Researchers have developed a framework for analyzing gene transcription networks that accounts for retroactivity, a phenomenon where modules' behavior is influenced by their connections to other modules. The framework uses three matrices: internal, scaling, and mixing retroactivity, which can be computed from macroscopic parameters such as dissociation constants and promoter concentrations. Internal retroactivity measures the effect of intramodular connections on a module's dynamics, while scaling and mixingactivity quantify how intermodular connections affect connected modules' dynamics. Based on these matrices and modules' dynamics in isolation, the framework predicts how loading affects an arbitrary interconnection of modules' behavior. This is demonstrated on recurrent motifs, including autoregulation, combinatorial regulation, two-gene clocks, toggle, and single motif. A metric is provided to determine a module's robustness to interconnection with other modules, applicable for evaluating natural networks' modularity and designing synthetic systems to minimize retroactivity.
Researchers have investigated recombination in the pseudoautosomal region 1 (PAR1), a region of homology between mammalian X and Y chromosomes, which has undergone rapid evolution. Crossover in PAR is essential for proper disjunction of X and Y chromosomes in meiosis, and deletion results in male sterility. The human PAR1 has an exceptionally high crossover rate, 17-fold higher than the genome-wide average. To understand this, researchers constructed a fine-scale genetic map of crossovers in African-American pedigrees, leveraging recombination rates from linkage disequilibrium in populations and DNA evolution signatures. They also identified PRDM9 binding sites using ChIP-seq in human cells. Contrary to mouse findings, PRDM does not localise recombination in human PAR1. Instead, recombination is a rapid and intense driver of evolution in PAR1, differing from autosomes. PAR hotspot activities vary among human populations and have changed between human and chimpanzee, with no shared hotspots.
Researchers have identified a new isoform of the histone demethylase JMJD2/KDM4, referred to as Δ-JJD2, which plays a crucial role in skeletal muscle differentiation. In proliferating myoblasts, muscle genes are silenced through epigenetic modifications, including histone H3 methylation at their promoters. The promoter of the gene encoding myogenic factor myogen (My) is key for muscle initiation of differentiation. The mechanism of H3 demethylation at My promoter is unclear. Δ-J2 increases during differentiation of C2 myoblast into myubes. Genome-wide expression and exon-specific siRNA knockdown indicate Δ-J is necessary for myube formation and muscle-specific expression. Δ promotes MyD conversion of NIH3T cells into muscle. ChIP-chip analysis shows Δ binds genes involved in transcriptional control, linked to activation. Δ is recruited to My promoter at onset differentiation. This binding promotes demethylation H3me and H3. Induction of Δ is crucial for muscle by removing repressive chromatin marks at My promoter, promoting transcription activation My and muscle-specific expression.
The Guinea Worm Eradication Programme (GWEP) is in its final stages, with only 25 cases reported in 2016, but global eradication requires certification by the World Health Organization (WHO) of absence of transmission in all countries. This study evaluates the cost-effectiveness of the GWEP when the number of cases is lower and cost per case is higher than any time. Using data from GWEP, the cost of implementation, pre-certification, and certification stages are estimated. The cost-effectiveness is modeled for 1986-203. The GWEP is compared to two scenarios: doing nothing (no intervention since 1986) and control (only surveillance and response 201-203). The cost per case averted, disability-adjusted life year (DALY) averted, and cost at-risk year averted are reported. Cost-effectiveness is assessed against a threshold of one GDP per capita (less than $500 in low-income countries). The GW cost an estimated $11.95 (95% interval, 4.70-12.49) per case averted 198-203. The pre-cert and certification phases cost $0.004 and $0.001 per capita year. The DAL averted by GW relative doing nothing is $222 (118-372) 198-203. GW is more cost-effective control by 203. GW more cost-effective control if willing to pay one life without risk GWD $0.10. Even if costs twice financial estimated 202, GW still cost-effective doing. Whether GW most-effective beyond 201 depends on horizon.
Researchers investigated the function of the BB32 protein from Borrelia burgdorferi sensu stricto and its orthologues in the Lyme disease-causing Borrelia burgorferi sensu lato complex. They found that the carbox-terminal domain of BB32 (BB32-C) inhibits the initiating serine protease of the classical complement pathway, C1, by binding to it with high affinity. The study focused on the BB32 orthologs from Boria afii PG and Bor garin, and found that Bor afii BAD-C exhibited similar activity to BB32 in assays, including high-affinity binding to C1 protease and complex and inhibition of the classical pathway. Borin B19-C also bound C1 and Cr with high-affinity, but showed reduced in vitro inhibitory activity compared to BB32 and BAD. However, Borin B19 weakly recognized C1 and did not confer protection from serum killing. Site-directed mutagenesis created a chimeric protein BB32 with Borin B19 residues, which mimicked Bor B19's properties. The structure of BB32 was solved to 1.7Å resolution, revealing an anti-parallel four-helix fold with a protruding alpha-helix. The structure showed surface-exposed residues targeted in the chimer, supporting C1 binding and inhibition. Additional assays showed BB32 recognized C1 fragments containing the serine prote domain.
Candida albicans, an opportunistic human pathogen, undergoes morphological and transcriptional adaptation from commensalism to pathogenicity. Previous gene knockout studies have identified factors involved in this transformation, but how they are regulated remains unclear. Investigating post-translational phosphorylation regulation has provided insights, focusing on cyclin-dependent kinase Cdc28. The Fkh transcription factor is a target of Cdc and cell wall biosynthesis kinase Cbk, distinct from its conserved cell cycle function. In stationary yeast cells, 2D gel electrophoresis shows diverse F2 phosphoisoforms. A window before hyph induction, phosphorylation transforms to yeast profile. This does not occur in stationary cells reinoculated into fresh medium. Mass spectrometry and mutational analyses identified C28 and C1 phosphorylated residues. Substituting with nonosphory alanine altered phosphorylation and abated hyal profile. Transcript profiling revealed hyal phosphorylation required pathogenesis, host interaction, and biofilm genes. These changes resulted in pathogenic defects. F2 interacts chromatin modifier P3 phosphorylation, regulating specificity. A cell-independent phosphoregulatory event subverts cycle component to commal pathity.
Trypanosoma brucei, a human pathogenic parasite, possesses both de novo and salvage pathways for pyrimidine nucleotide biosynthesis, rendering it non-reliant on salvage pyrimines for growth. Thymidine kinase (TK) catalyzes the formation of dTMP and dUMP, one of several enzymes redundant to the de novo pathway. Unexpectedly, TK is essential for growth and infectivity in a mouse model, with a catalytically active enzyme required for function. Unlike humans and other kinetoplasts, T. bruce lacks dCMP deaminase (DD), an alternative route to dUMP formation. Ectopic expression of human DD rescues the RNA growth phenotype, allowing viable TK null cells. Metabolite profiling reveals a buildup of deoxyrim nucleotides in TK depleted cells. Knockout of cytidine deaminase (DA), converting deoxycidine to deuridine, results in thym/deuridine auxotrophy. This suggests T. br encodes an unidentified 5'-nuclease converting deoxyrim nucleides to nucleosides, leading to buildup in TK cells at expense of dTP pools. Bioinformatics identifies potential genes encoding 5-uclease activity, including an HD protein phosphorylating deoxyonucle 5-monophosph. TK is essential for thym nucleotide synthesis, regardless novo or salvage.
In prokary systems, translation initiation requires interaction between the ribosome and an mRNA sequence upstream of the initiation codon, known as the Shine-Dalgarn sequence. However, a significant number of genes lack Shine-Darn sequences, and the mechanism of start cod recognition in these mRNAs is unknown. A genome-wide searches in various proaryotes identified elements and RNA structural motifs that mediate translation in mRN lacking Shine-Darn sequences. Results show mRN without Shine-Darn are less structured in their initiation region and exhibit minimal folding at the start cod. Reporter gene constructs in bacteria support local unfoldedness determining start cod recognition in Shine-Darn-dependent translation. AUG codons reside in single-stranded regions, whereas internal codons are in structured mRNA regions. Bioinformatics and experimental data suggest absence of secondary structure is necessary and sufficient for Shinearn-dependent translation initiation.
A study was conducted in Bihar, India, a region endemic for Leishmania donovani, to investigate the occurrence of Post-Kala Dermal Leishiasis (PKDL) in patients treated with liposomal amphotin B (Ambisome) for visceral leishmaniasis (VL). Between July 2017 and August 2012, 874 patients received 20mg/kg intravenous Ambis as first-line treatment with a high cure rate (99.3%) and low default rate (0.3%). Patients received health education on PK symptoms and were advised to return to the programme if symptoms developed. Of 831 patients completing VL treatment, 24 (0.3%) returned with symptoms confirmed PKDL, diagnosed by clinical history, appearance, and slit-skin examination. 89% had macular lesions with a median (interquartile range) of 1.2 (0.8-2.2) years post-treatment. Demographic and clinical characteristics of VL patients treated with Ambis who developed PKDL were compared to those who did not, and no significant factors were identified. However, time to PKDL was shorter with Ambis in a subset with previous stibogluconate VL treatment. In a large cohort of VL patients in Bihar treated with 20/kg Ambis, PKDL appears infrequent with no predictive factors. Time to PKDL was shorter with Ambis compared to conventional treatments.
Researchers investigated the re-infestation dynamics of Triatoma infestans, the primary vector of Chagas disease, in three villages in northwest Argentina after community-wide insecticide spraying in 1992. Continuous and discrete-time models were fitted to patch-level infestation data to elucidate aspects of re-establishment. The study found a 6-month lag between detection of new infestation and dispersal events, confirming previous results. Analysis revealed a higher establishment of new bug populations from May to November compared to November to May, coinciding with an increase in dispersal distance. The probability of new establishment increased with time since last infestation in the models. These findings challenge current understanding of T. infans ecology and highlight gaps in knowledge. Experiments are necessary to close these gaps.
Researchers investigated the effects of polyomavirus SV40 (SV40) microRNA on the pathogenesis of viral infections in Syrian hamsters, a commonly used animal model for studying SV40. Young adult hamsters were inoculated with 1×10^7 plaque-forming units of four different SV40 variants via the intracardial route and sacrificed at 3-270 days post-infection. Viral loads in tissues were determined by quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction. All strains established persistent infections with slow clearance, displaying broad tissue tropism in liver, kidney, spleen, lung, and brain. Liver and kidney had higher viral loads than other tissues, with kidneys being the primary site for long-term infection. Expression of SV40 microRNA was detected in wild-type infected tissues, while micro-negative mutants showed higher DNA loads in liver and kidney. Viruses with complex regions had modestly higher loads in kidney than simple regions. Early transcripts were higher than late in liver and kidney. Infectious virus was infrequently detected. Clearance of micro-deficient viruses was limited. Wild-type and micro-negative SV showed similar transformation rates in vitro and tumor induction in vivo. This study demonstrated broad tissue tropism for SV in hamsters and first evidence of SV microRNA expression and function in vivo. MicroRNA dampened DNA levels in infected SV strains with simple or complex regions.
This study presents the most comprehensive genome-wide examination of positively selected genes (PSGs) in mammals to date, utilizing six high-coverage assemblies of eutherian mammals. The increased phylogenetic depth of this dataset enhances statistical power, allowing for new lineage and clade-specific tests to be applied. Approximately 16,500 human genes with high-confidence orthologs in at least two species show significant evidence of positive selection (FDR < 0.05) according to a likelihood test. An additional 144 genes exhibit positive selection on lineages or clades. Identified PSGs are enriched in defense/immunity, chemosensory perception, and reproduction, but also in specific functions such as complement-mediated immunity and taste. Several pathways are enriched PSG, suggesting co-evolution of interacting genes. A Bayesian analysis indicates PSG have switched multiple times between selection and non-selection, suggesting positive is often episodic. Affymetrix exon array data shows PSG are expressed lower, in a tissue-specific manner than non-PSGs. Genes in spleen, testes, liver, breast are enriched PSG, but not in brain.
Staphylococcus aureus, an opportunistic pathogen that colonizes mammalian skin and mucosal surfaces, often forms persistent infections through surface-associated biofilms. Researchers have identified a novel extracellular fibril structure that enhances S. aureus biofilm stability. Biochemical and genetic analysis revealed that these fibers exhibit amyloid properties, composed of small peptides called phenol soluble modulins (PSMs). Mutants unable to produce PSs are susceptible to biofilm disassembly by matrix-degrading enzymes and mechanical stress. Prior research linked PSs to biofilm disassembly, this study shows soluble PS disperse biofilms while polymerized do not. This suggests PS aggregation into amyloid fibers modulates their biological role in biofilms.
Researchers have developed a novel antibody biomarker, Ab3, to monitor the persistence of Trypanosoma cruzi, the parasite causing agent of Chagas disease, in infected individuals. Chagas affects over 6 million people in 20 countries. Monitoring parasite persistence is crucial for evaluating treatments and controlling the disease. Current methods, such as serological assays and PCR, have limitations due to low parasitic load in blood. A multiplex serology assay was designed with 15 T cruzi antigens to evaluate 165 serum samples from chronic Chagas patients. One antibody, Ab3, showed strong correlation with T cruzi persistence determined by PCR results. High Ab3 levels were associated with PCR positivity in untreated patients, while decline in Ab signals were observed in benznidazole-treated patients with cleared parasitemia. Ab3 is a surrogate biomarker for parasite persistence in chronic benidazole-treated Chagas patients. It is hypothesized that Ab3 is induced by incessant immune stimulation from tissue-based parasites undetectable by PCR. A simple immunoassay of Ab3 could monitor infectious status of seropositive patients.
Chikungunya virus (CHV) is an arthrogenic alphavirus that causes fever and severe joint and muscle pain, with chronic musculoskeletal pain persisting in a fraction of patients for months to years after initial infection. Researchers sought to identify cells contributing to pathogenesis during chronic phase by developing a recombinant CHV expressing Cre recombinase (CHV-3-C). CH-C replicated in myoblast and fibroblasts, inducing arthritis in mice during acute phase and chronic disease, including persistent RNA and myitis synovitis. Infection of tdato reporter mice resulted in tdato cells persisting at least 112 days. Immunofluorescence and cytometry revealed td cells were predominantly myofib and dermal muscle fibbl. Treatment with antibody against Mra, a host receptor for CHV, reduced td cells and chronic RNA levels, implicating as reservoir of chronic RNA. Isolation and cytometry sorting td fibbl from skin and ankle analysis revealed td cells harbored persistent CHV RNA. The CH-C and tdato mouse system identifies cells surviving CHV in vivo and enriched CHV RNA, a tool for studying path in acute and chronic disease stages.
Recent studies have applied dimensionality reduction methods to understand the multi-dimensional structure of neural activity in the brain. However, it is unclear how these results generalize to larger numbers of neurons and trials or relate to the underlying network structure. This study addresses these questions by applying factor analysis to recordings in the visual cortex of non-human primates and spiking models that generate irregular activity through excitation and inhibition. The study compares the scaling of two dimension reduction outputs, shared dimension and percent variance, with neuron and trial count. Results show that networks with clustered and non-clustered connectivity differ, and in vivo recordings align with clustered networks. Recordings of tens of neurons are sufficient to identify dominant variability modes that generalize to larger portions of the network.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa-regulated molecule 2-aminoacetophen (2-AA) modulates host immune responses in a manner that increases host's ability to cope with the pathogen. Mice treated with 2-AA prior to infection had a 90% survival rate compared to 10% survival in non-treated mice. 2-AA activates innate immune pathways involving mitogen-activated protein kinases (MAPs), nuclear factor (NF)-κ, and pro-inflammatory cytokines, but attenuates response upon pre-treatment by upregulating anti-inflammatory cytokines. Pretreatment with 2 is characterized by transcriptional block of c-J N-terminal (JNK) and NF-κ activation, with preserved extracellular regulated kinase (ER)1/2 activation. These changes lead to CA/enhancer protein-β (c/EBβ) activation and c/EBβ-p65 complex formation, preventing NFκ activation.2 dampens inflammatory processes while increasing survival and pathogen persistence.
Mammalian genomes contain numerous active and fossilized retroelements, including LINE-1 (L1) elements, which can integrate into host genomes and provide opportunities for retroelement domestication, leading to innovations in genome defense and adaptation. The L1-DT1 gene is a domesticated gene whose protein-coding sequence is entirely derived from a LINE-1 element, and has been shown to play a role in pluripotency maintenance. To investigate its role, the origin and evolution of L1-D1 was traced. L1 originated in the common ancestor of eutherian mammals, but was lost or pseudogenized multiple times during mammalian evolution. L1-D1 evolved under positive selection in primate and mouse evolution, and prosian L1-D1 acquired a recent L1 ORF from the prosian genome. This suggests L-D1 has been selected for novelty, potentially for genome defense. L-D1 loss is associated with extinction in several lineages, but not sigmodine rodents. The study highlights the role of retroelement domestication in mammalian biology, and domesticated genes can adopt different functions in lineages.
A highly conserved bacterial protein, RNase Y, plays a crucial role in the processing of the 3' end of 16S rRNA and 70 ribosome quality control in Escherichia coli. Although it is not essential in E. coli, loss of RNase Y severely sensitizes it to multiple stresses. In Vibrio cholera, RN Y is an endoribonuclease and essential for virulence, stress regulation, RNA processing, and ribosome quality control, and part of a core set of RNases in most pathogens. Analysis of RNA and ribosome profiles of V. cholera partially depleted of RN Y and other RN associated with 16 rRNA processing show Y is also crucial for 16 r 3 enduration in V. cholera and impedes subunit assembly into 70 ribosomes. Y's importance to V cholera pathogenesis is demonstrated by loss of colonization, biofilm formation, reduced cholera toxin production, and altered expression of virulence small RNAs of V. cholera depleted Y. The Y genes of several distantly related pathogens complement E. coli ΔY under stress, showing conservation of Y's activity in regulation. This study provides comprehensive exploration of Y's role in human pathogen, conserved across species in cellular processes.
Researchers investigated the relationship between the topological properties of transcription factor networks (TF) and the robustness of their gene expression phenotypes to genetic and environmental perturbations. They focused on assortativity, a measure of the tendency of nodes with similar numbers of edges to connect, and its four distinct components that form the assortativity signature. Theoretical studies suggested that increasing one component of TF's assortativity leads to increased phenotypic robustness, but biological context is limited due to lack of characterization of real-world TFNs' assortativity. This study used DNase-seq data to measure genome-wide TFNs assortativity in 41 human cell and tissue types and found a common assortativity signature that confers phenotypic robustness to TFNs. They determined the contribution of each assortativity component to this robustness.
Researchers investigated how populations of inhibitory (IN) and excitatory (EX) neurons in the neocortex encode stimulus-related information. They recorded the activity of ensembles of up to 74 neurons in anesthetized rat somatosensory barrel cortex using 128-channel multi-electrode arrays. Two whisker stimuli (location and frequency) were used to classify IN and EX neurons based on their extracellular spike waveforms. IN neurons discriminated between 6 stimulus classes better than EX neurons in granular and infragran layers. Ensembles of IN cells provided as much information as ensembles of the 20 most informative EX neurons, with less redundancy. This was consistent with information measurements and linear discriminant analysis. The study suggests a consortium of IN neurons dominates neocort information processing, efficiently processing sensory activity.
Researchers have engineered a fundamental arithmetic unit for binary addition in living cells using de novo riboregulation, a process that allows for the computation of two bits of information encoded in molecular concentrations. The circuit, based on post-transcriptional control and allosteric transcription factors, robustly performs the intended computation and encodes the result as fluorescence amplitudes. This achievement demonstrates the potential of regulatory RNAs as key players in synthetic biology and paves the way for more complex RNA-based biocomputers using this circuit as a building block.
Researchers have investigated the inhibition of cytosolic 5'-nucleotidase II (c-II) by ribonucleotide 5'-monophosphate analogues to understand its role in resistance to cytotoxic nucleide analogues during cancer therapy. c-II regulates intracellular nucleotide pools by dephosphorylating 6-hydroxypine nucleide 5'-monosphates. High c-II expression is linked to poor patient outcomes in cytotoxic therapy. A class of compounds, ribonucle phosphates, were screened as potential c-II inhibitors, featuring chemically stable phosphorus-carbon linkages instead of regular phospho bonds. Six compounds were identified as better ligands than natural substrate inosine 5-monophosphate (IMP). Study of purine and pyrimidine analogues and phosphon chain modifications defined rules for ligand affinity. Binding was analyzed in silico and attributed to van der Waals, highlighting c-II residues Phe 157, His 209, and Tyr 210. Docking predictions were confirmed by experimental nucleotase activity measurements with best phosphon analogues. These induced total inhibition of c-II activity at 2mM. This study emphasizes importance of non-hydroable phosphon bond in new c-II inhibitors and hydrophobic stacking by protein residues.
Researchers have found evidence of prion infectivity in milk and colostrum from sheep incubating scrapie, a transmissible spongiform encephalopathy (TSE). This is the first reported case of prion presence in dairy products from SE-affected ruminants entering the animal and human food chain. Prions were detected in mammary secretions from scrap-affected ewes in a previous study. This study found consistent levels of infectivity in colostr and milk from sheep with natural scrapie several months before clinical onset. Abnormal Pr was detected by immunohistochemistry and PET in lactal ducts and mamary glands. PrSc accumulation was found in ewes with mammary ectopic lymphoid follicles due to Ma lentivirus infection. However, bioassay showed prion infect was present in milk and colostr from ewes with lymph-proiferative mastitis and those with lesion-free mam glands. Infectivity was recovered in cellular cream and caseinhey fractions of milk and colstrum. Using a T 338 mouse model, the highest infectious titre was equivalent to 6g of posterior brain from terminally scrap ewe. These findings indicate colstr and milk from ruminants with T could contribute to T transmission, either through milk-derived material in animal feed or directly. This raises concern for human T exposure with ovine and T-susceptible dairy products.
An outbreak of Ebola virus disease (EVD) occurred in Liberia from March 2014 to January 2016. Epidemiological data on EVD cases were collected and managed nationally, but data collection and management were challenging due to malfunctioning surveillance and reporting systems. Laboratory data, however, systematically recorded demographic and clinical information on patients. This study presents data on 16,370 laboratory samples tested between April 4, 2014 and March 29, 2015. A total 10,536 individuals were traced, of whom 3,897 were confirmed positive for Ebola RNA. Confirmed cases differed significantly from suspected cases tested negative for RNA by sex, age, and place of residence. Young children and elderly, and rural areas were risk factors for death. The case fatality rate of confirmed cases decreased from 80% to 63 during the period.
Tyrosinase (EC 1.14.18.11), a copper-containing monooxygenase, catalyzes the conversion of phenol to orthoquinone. The Streptomyces tyin forms a complex with the Cie protein, facilitating copper ion transport into the active center. A previous study identified Tyr98 in Cie, accommodated in tyrosin active pocket, converted to quin through μ2:2-pero-dopper (II) and CuII-dasiquin intermediates. Despite extensive studies, catalytic mechanism unclear at atomic level. Cryo-crystal structures (1.16-1.70Å) reveal new step: hydroxylation triggered by Cu movement, inducing syn-anti rearrangement copper ligands after μ2:2-pero-dopper formation. Rearrangement places hydroxyl substrate equatorial, enabling electrophil attack aromatic Cu2 oxidant.
Researchers have investigated the early stages of ribosome biogenesis, specifically the production of the large ribosomal subunit, in yeast. The first precursor to the large ribosomal subunit, the pre-60S particle, contains 30 assembly factors (AFs), including RNA helicases, which drive conformational rearrangements. However, the mechanisms by which these helicases are targeted to their substrates within pre-ribosomal particles and their precise roles remain unknown. The Dbp helicase, essential for normal accumulation of pre-60 preribosomal in S. cerevisiae, associates with a complex of four AFs: N1, N2, N8, and R3. Tand affinity purifications show N forms the backbone of the complex. N and N directly bind Dbp. N is essential for insertion of Dbp within 90 preribosomal particles. In vivo cross-linking analysis maps N binding sites on 25 rRNA adjacent to root helices of first and last secondary domains. This suggests N and Dbp function in formation of root helices of largeunit rRNAs, creating core of ribosomal structure. N also crosslinks snoRN in decoding and peptid transfer center and vicinity of binding sites on 25 r. Data suggest Dbp and play key roles in compaction of core 25 r and control sno-rRNA interactions.
Researchers investigated the role of catecholamines in regulating learning rate in a dynamic environment. They found that the P3 component of the EEG, an electrophysiological index of phasic cateolamine release in the cortex, predicted learning rate and mediated the effect of prediction error on learning. P3 amplitude also mediated the effects of unexpectedness of outcome and uncertainty of existing belief on learning. Pharmacological manipulation of cateolamine activity affected learning following task changes in a way dependent on baseline rate.
In Senegal, a syndromic surveillance system called EPIC was implemented to monitor infectious diseases using data from two Point-of-Care (POC) laboratories in rural villages. From 2010 to 2016, two POC laboratories were established in the Salm region of Senegal. EPIC was used to analyze data from the Timone hospital laboratory in Marseille, France. This study describes the implementation of EPIC using data from two POC laboratories in Senegal. After implementation, 15 pathogens were monitored in two POC using the same methodology as France. In 5 years, 2,577 patient samples from 775 patients were tested in Diel and Ndi POC, with 739 positive for at least one pathogen. Analysis with EPIC generated 443 alarms. In Niak P laboratory, 316 samples from 298 patients were processed, with 56 positive for at least pathogen. EPIC analysis generated 14 alarms.
Researchers have investigated the role of cellular architecture in collective signaling and contractility in multicellular systems, specifically in the context of vascular endothelial cells. Using a combination of computational modeling and micro-patterning techniques, they examined how the arrangement of endothelial cells affects calcium signaling and contractility in response to histamine stimulation. The study found that endothelial cells self-assembled into microengineered networks, but not individual monolayers, exhibited calcium oscillations under histamine stimulation. Pharmacological inhibition and computational modeling revealed that calcium oscillations depend on the number of neighboring cells coupled via gap junction intercellular communication, providing a mechanistic basis for architecture-dependent signaling. Furthermore, calcium oscillations attenuated histamine-induced cytoskeletal reorganization and contraction, resulting in architecture-dependent cell responses. The study suggests that endothelial cells can sense and respond to chemical stimuli according to vascular architecture via collective signaling.
Researchers investigated the role of antigenic sites on the respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) attachment protein outside the conserved cysteine domain (CCD) in immunity. Previous studies identified antibody responses to RSV in infants using whole-genome phage display libraries, revealing epitopes on the N and C-termini of the ectodomain and CCD. This study examined the contribution of antigenic regions outside the CCD to RSV immunity by evaluating the immunogenicity, neutralization, and protective efficacy of RSV antigen sites following primary infection using recombinant E. coli expressed ectomain (REG), CCD-deleted ectomain (REGΔD), N and C-terminal subdomains, and antigen peptides. Results showed that REGD, N-terminal subdomains, and peptides generated antibody titers in rabbits and mice that bound glycosylated recombinant mammalian ectomain (RM) and intact RSV particles, but minimal in vitro neutralization titers compared to intact ectomain. Vaccinated mice were challenged intranasally with RSV-A Line 19, and viral replication in nasal cavity and lungs was reduced in vaccinated animals compared to unimmun controls. Control viral loads post-R challenge correlated with serum binding to particles. Additionally, low Th2/Th cytokine ratios were found in lungs of REGD vaccinated mice after challenge. These findings demonstrate multiple protective sites on RSV protein outside CCD contributing to a vaccine against R disease.
In Drosophila melanogaster, the specification of the FMRFamide neuropeptide neurons in the ventral nerve cord (VNC) is a complex process involving both intrinsic transcriptional and extrinsic cues. Target-derived signals, denoted as retrograde signals, play a critical role in this process. One such signal is the BMP (Bone Morphogenetic Protein) received by Tv4 neurons from their target cells, which triggers the activation of the FMRF gene. A genetic screen identified several genes involved in Tv4 specification, including components of the U5 subunit of the spliceosome: b2 (72)Ab and Pr8. This study focuses on the role of RNA processing in target-derived signaling. b2 and Pr8 are crucial for FMa expression in Tv neurons of the VNC. Analysis of b2 reveals two mechanisms: proper axonal targeting to receive BMP ligand and proper splicing of genes in the BMP pathway: thickve (tk) and Medea. These results demonstrate RNA processing in diversifying neuronal identity within the central nervous system.
Researchers have identified a novel mechanism for regulating the abundance of F-box proteins, a key components of the SCF (Skp-cullin-RING ubiquitin ligase complex, which plays a crucial role in various cellular processes including cell cycle regulation and response to stress. In yeast, the F-box protein Met30 is targeted for ubiquitination and degradation through a pathway independent of Skp1, a central component of the SC complex. This pathway requires the cullin component Cdc/Cul1, but not other SC components. The study shows that this non-canonical degradation pathway is essential for maintaining chromosome stability and protecting against heavy metal stress.
Kinesin-3 motors, specifically KIF1, play a crucial role in transporting synaptic vesicles and membrane-bound organelles in neuronal cells. In the absence of cargo, Kines motors are inactivated to prevent motility and ATP hydrolysis. Current models propose that KIF1 is monomeric in the inactive state, becoming active upon concentration-driven dimerization on the membrane. Contrary to this, native and expressed K1 are dimeric in the inactive state. K1 motors are not activated by cargo-induced dimerization, but rather autoinhibited by two distinct mechanisms. This suggests a model for activation of dimer K1 by cargo binding. Successive truncations yield monomeric and dimer motors capable of one-dimensional diffusion along microtubule lattice. However, only dimer motors undergo ATP-dependent processive motility. This indicates K1 may utilize both diffuse and processive motility for long-distance transport in neuronal cells.
A study was conducted to investigate the regulation of seed metabolism in a collection of 76 homozygous tomato introgression lines (ILs) grown in the field over two consecutive seasons. Metabolic profiling and network analysis revealed 30 quantitative trait loci (QTL) associated with metabolite variation. Amino acid contents showed high variability across the population, while sugars exhibited seasonal fluctuations. Factorial ANOVA identified genotypic background as the primary factor influencing metabolic polymorphism, rather than environment or tissue. Analysis of variance indicated greater phenotypic plasticity in ILs compared to M82 tomato cultivar. Heritability estimates suggested different modes of inheritance for metabolite traits in seed versus fruit. Correlation-based network analysis comparing seed and pericarp metabolite data showed seed displayed tighter metabolic interdependence than fruit. Amino acids in seed network played a central role, interacting with sugars and organic acids. Six highly regulated amino acids, Gly, Ser, Thr, Ile, Val, and Pro, were identified. Strong interdependence confirmed by QTL mapping.
Vibrio cholera, a bacterial pathogen that colonizes both the chitinous exoskeleton of zooplankton and the human gastrointestinal tract, utilizes a protein called N-acetylucosamine binding protein (Gbp) to mediate attachment to marine chitin and mammalian mucin. Research reveals that Gbp has an elongated, four-domain structure with domains 1 and 4 showing structural homology to chitin binding domains. Glycan analysis shows Gbp binds GlcNA oligosaccharides, while structure-guided Gbp truncation mutants demonstrate domains 1 and 4 interact with chitin in vitro, and domain 1 is crucial for mucin binding and intestinal colonization in vivo. Bacterial studies show domains 2 and 3 bind V cholera surface. Mouse virulence assays indicate only first three domains Gbp are required for colonization.
Chronic activation of T cells is a hallmark of pulmonary tuberculosis (TB), a disease characterized by an imbalance between effector (Te) and regulatory (Treg) cells. Research has shown that circulating Treg cells in adults with TB retain their suppressive function, but Te cells are resistant to Treg suppression. This resistance is attributed to the expansion of an activated Te subset expressing Human Leukocyte Antigen (HLA)-DR. Depletion of this subset restores sensitivity to suppression. Comparative transcriptome analysis of Te cells with and without HLA-DR identified mechanisms linked to IFN-γ, IL-17, IL-22, PD-L, and chemokines CCL3, C4 expression. Blocking experiments confirmed HLA-DR Te cells are resistant to Treg suppression via CCR5 and PD1 pathways. HLA-DR cells activate NF-κB downstream of C5 and PD1, and express higher Th1/17 cytokines, which counterbalance Treg function.
Researchers investigated the propagation of prions in mice expressing prion protein (PrP) devoid of a glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor, a molecule that typically links Pr to the cell membrane. Mice lacking the GPI anchor (tg- mice) are susceptible to prion infection, but accumulate anchorless prion (PrSc) outside the cell. The study aimed to determine if tg mice could propagate prions despite the deviant structure and location of anchorless PrSc. Results showed that RML and ME, but not 22 prions propagated in tg mice developed novel tropisms, as determined by Cell Assay. Unexpectedly, levels of proteinase-resistant PrSc (PrPres) in R- or ME-infected tg brain were 25-50 times higher than wild-type. When returned to wild brain, ME pr recovered original properties, but R pr gave rise to novel strain S, which remained unchanged after three passages in wild mice. Both RPrSc and SSc are stably propagated in wild mice, suggesting two conformations separated by high energy barrier abated in tg mice.
In Drosophila, the BMP signaling pathway plays a crucial role in dorsal-ventral axis patterning during embryonic development, mediated by the transcription factor Mad and the repressor Brinker. A study combining RNA-seq and Br ChIP-seq, the BMP-responsive transcription network underlying dorsal-vent axis patterning was deciphered. Multiple BMP target genes, including positive and negative regulators of EGF signaling, were identified. EGF signaling was found to negatively regulate embryonic BMP transcription. The BMP network exhibits self-regulation, balancing its activity with antagonistic EGF signaling to facilitate patterning. Key transcription factors Zelda and Zerküll establish the expression domain, while insulator proteins bind to Mad and Brinker genomic regions. In embryos lacking BE-32, transcription of a BMP target gene and amniosa cells were reduced, specified by BMP signaling. A model for Mad-dependent activation was proposed, relevant to vertebrate BMP interpretation.
In Tunisia, cases of zoonotic cutaneous leishmaniasis caused by Leishmania major have been increasing and spreading from south to new areas in the center. To improve knowledge on L. major evolution and dynamics, a multi-locus microsatellite typing of isolates from Tunisian governorates where the disease is endemic (Gaf, Kairan and Sidi Bouid governorates) collected during 1991-1992 and 2008-201 was performed. Analysis of genotyping results of isolates in Sidi Bouid 199-199 and 200-201 using F-statistics and Bayesian-based approach shows that over two decades, Leish parasites evolved generating genetically differentiated populations. Genetic patterns of 200-201 isolates from three governorates indicate L major did not spread from south to center Tunisia according to geographical gradient, suggesting human activities source of disease expansion. Bayesian model and F-stat genotypes between governor and districts indicate human activities, reservoir and environmental dynamics explain disease progression. This study provides insights into evolution and spread L in Tunisia, improving understanding parasite between geographically and temporally distinct populations.
Researchers conducted a study to evaluate the effectiveness of anthelmint chemotherapy and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) interventions in reducing helminth infections among HIV-infected adults in Kenya. A total of 701 stool samples were analyzed, with approximately 22% showing helmin infections, mostly of low to moderate intensity. Treatment with albendazole significantly reduced the odds of infection with any helmin species (OR: 0.11, 95%CI: 0.05,0.20, p<0.001), adjusting for age and sex. While WASH showed minimal benefit, access to safe flooring offered additional protection (OR:0.34, 95%:0.20,0.56, p<0.001) against any helmin species. For schistosiasis, treatment with prazantel was protective (OR:0.30,95:0.14,0.60, p=0.001). Among those not treated with albazole or prantel, the most protective package was safe flooring (OR:0.34,95:0.20,0.59, p<0.001) and latrine access (OR:0.59,95:0.35,0.99 p=0.05). No synergy or antagonism was found between anthint chemotherapy and W resources. Deworming reduced helmin infections in HIV-infected adults, with W offering minimal additional benefit except for flooring.
Lectin-like bacteriocins are proteins produced by plant-associated bacteria that selectively kill closely related species, including phytopathogens such as Pseudomonas syringae and Xanthomonas. The crystal structure of LlpW, a prototype lectin-like bacteriocin from Pseudomon putida, reveals a two-domain architecture consisting of a monocot mannose-binding lectin (MBL) domain and a C-terminal β-hair extension. The C-terminal MB domain (C-domain) adopts a fold similar to MB domains in plant lectins and contains a mannose-binding site. Mutational analysis indicates an intact sugar-binding pocket in this domain is crucial for bactericidal activity. The N-terminal MB (N) domain adopts the same fold but is structurally divergent and lacks mannose-binding site. Differential activity of engineered N-domain chimeras from Lp homologs with distinct killing spectra disclosed the N-domain determines specificity. This bacteriocin is assembled from two structurally similar domains evolved towards dedicated functions in target recognition and bacterotoxicity.
Bacillus subtilis undergoes sporulation, a complex developmental process involving two coordinately regulated programs. During late sporulation, the forespore, a developing spore, resides within the mother cell. The regulation of the forespore transcription factor σG has remained enigmatic. σG requires eight proteins encoded by the spoII operon and the foresore protein SpoQ. Several SpoII proteins share similarity with components of specialized secretion systems, one resembling an ATPase. We found that ATP motifs are required for σ activity. SpoII proteins and SpoQ reside in a multimer complex spanning two membranes surrounding the foresore. In their absence, the foresore develops invaginations and collapses. Maintenance of foresore integrity does not require σ. These results support a model where SpoII-SpoQ form a novel apparatus allowing the cell to nurture the fores, maintaining fores physiology and σ during spore maturation.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide association study to identify genetic variants associated with bipolar disorder (BD), a highly heritable and disabling disease. The study included 1,190 cases and 401 controls, with additional samples from a total of 2,191 cases and 1,434 controls. No genome-wide significant associations were detected for individual loci, but a significant association was found between the power to detect effects from a previous genome-wide association study and evidence (P=1.5×10−7). To rule out a false positive result, replication was analyzed in a meta-analysis of height, showing associations replicate as a function of power, approaching a linear relationship. Within BD, SNPs near exons exhibited greater replication probability, indicating enrichment of reproducible associations near functional regions. This suggests common genetic variation near exons (±10kb) could be identified in larger studies, providing a framework for assessing replication combining results from multiple studies.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide systematic analysis to identify predictive proliferation signatures of cancerous versus non-cancerous cells. They developed a Cancer Prolation Index (cPI) to quantify the association between gene expression levels and growth rates across 60 cancer cell lines. Results showed that genes essential in cancer knockdown screens had positive PI values, while tumor suppressors had negative PI. Cell cycle, DNA replication, splicing, and protein production processes were positively associated with cancer, while migration was negatively associated. This aligns with the "grow or die" dichotomy. Analysis of non-cancer proliferation (nPI) across lymphoblast cell lines revealed differences between cancerous and nonancer proliferation, highlighting translation and splice machinery as cancer-associated proteins. Cross-species comparison showed cancer proliferation resembled microorganisms, nonancer did not. Combining cancer and nonancer signatures improved patient outcome prediction and gene essentiality in cancer.
A retrospective case series of 11 patients with cardiac and vascular cistic echinoccosis (CE) was followed over a 15-year period (1995-2009). Clinical manifestations included thoracic pain and dyspnea, with 2 patients being asymptomatic. Cysts were primarily located in the right atrium and inferior vena cava. Nine patients had disseminated CE. Echocardiography was the diagnostic method of choice, with serology, electrocardiogram, chest-ray, computed tomography/magnetic imaging, and histology aiding diagnosis and follow-up. Nine underwent cardiac surgery and received long-term antiparas for a median 25 months (4-93). One died intra-operatively due to cyst rupture and vascular dissemination. Two died 10 and 14 years post-diagnosis due to pulmonary embolism (PE) and failure, respectively. One was lost to follow. Patients with cardiac involvement had no complications post-surgery and were cured. One recurrence required second operation. Vascular involvement developed PEs and multiple complications.
Researchers have identified a novel mechanism by which Staphylococcus aureus uses to modulate the host immune response, through a protein called Tir, a Toll/interleukin receptor mimic. This protein inhibits the activation of the NF-kB pathway, a key component of the innate immune response, by downregulating TLR2, TLR4, TLR5, and TLR9 receptors. In a mouse model, skin lesions caused by a mutant S. aureus lacking Tir were more severe than those caused by the wild-type strain, despite similar bacterial loads. Tir was also associated with reduced neutrophil and macrophage activity, indicating its role in attenuating virulence through inflammatory responses. Tir is encoded within the staphlococcal chromosomal cassette SCC, which also contains the fusC gene for fusidic acid resistance, but not the mec gene. Fusidic acid sub-inhibitory concentrations increased Tir expression. Epidemiological studies found no link between Tir and clinical presentation, but a selective advantage with the SCCmec element containing SCC/tir.
Researchers have identified distinct embryonic patterning mechanisms in fruit flies (Drosophila melanogaster) and mosquitoes (Anopheles gambiae) by analyzing gene expression data during embryonic development. The study focused on whole-genome changes in gene expression underlying differences in their respective embryonic morphologies. Orthologous gene pairs were clustered based on coincident discordances in temporal profiles. One cluster contained genes specifically expressed in mosquito serosa, redeployed later in cuticle synthesis. Maternal genes exhibited sharp reduction at maternal-zyotic transition in Dophila, sustained in Anophe. Gene clustering by temporal discord can identify batteries underlying morphological diversity.
