Researchers conducted a cross-sectional study in rural villages on Lih Island, Papua New Guinea, during a yaws elimination campaign to investigate the presence of Haemophilus duyi and Treponema pallidum subsp pertue DNA in asymptomatic individuals and their environment. Participants were recruited from households with and without cases of ulcers. Skin swabs from asymptomatic individuals, flies, and environmental surfaces were collected and tested by PCR for H. duyi and T. pertue DNA. Of 78 asymptomatic participants with adequate specimens, 16% had H. duyi PCR positivity and 1% T. pertue positivity. In subgroup analysis, H. duyi PCR did not differ in exposed or not exposed to case in household (24% vs 18%; p=0.76). Of 17 cultures, 2 yielded definitive H. duyi skin colonization. Of 10 flies, 90% had H duyi and 50 T. pertue DNA. Of 6 bed sheets, 33 had H duyi and 17 T. pert DNA This is the first demonstration of H duyi on asymptomatic skin and H du and T. pertue in flies and fites. Ubiquity of du in environment contributes to spread.
The International Society for Computational Biology (ISCB) Education Committee's Curriculum Task Force has developed a set of bioinformatics core competencies to provide a framework for training and curricula across various user groups and programs. The competencies were based on surveys of employers and training programs and refined through a multi-year community engagement process. This report presents the current status of the competencies and illustrates their application in diverse training contexts. The competencies are intended to address the wide range of populations in need of bioinformatics training with divergent backgrounds and application areas. They cover essential knowledge and skills in areas such as data management, analysis, visualization, and interpretation, and communication. The competencies are organized into three categories: foundational, technical, and application, and professional. Foundational competencies include understanding of bioinformatics concepts, data types, and tools. Technical competencies cover data management, analysis, and visualization. Professional competencies include communication, collaboration, and project management. The competencies are being applied in various training programs and contexts, including undergraduate, graduate, and continuing education. The use cases demonstrate how the competencies can be integrated into existing curricula and programs. The report concludes with consideration of remaining challenges and future plans for the competencies refinement and application.
Researchers conducted a deep-sequencing study of the polyadenylated transcriptome of the parasitic nematode Strongyloides stercalis to investigate the mechanisms of its developmentally arrested third-stage larva (L3) formation. The study aimed to determine if homologous pathways present in Caenorhabditis elegans, a free-living nemode with a similar developmental arrested larval form, the dauer, are involved in L3 arrest and activation. The study generated 2.3 billion paired-end reads from seven developmental stages and constructed expression profiles for S. steralis homologs of C. elegans dauer genes. Intriguingly, genes encoding cyclic GMP (cG) pathway components were coordinately upregulated in L3. In contrast to C. elegans, S. stalis has a paucity of genes encoding insulin/IG-1-like (IS) ligands, several of which have abundance profiles suggesting involvement in L3 development. Seven S. stalis genes encoding homologs of C. elegans dauer transforming factor β (Tβ) ligand were identified, three of which are expressed in L3. Dachronic acid biosynthetic genes did not appear to be coordinately regulated in L3 development. The study suggests that dauer pathway genes are present in S. stalis and may play a role in L3 development, with significant differences between the two species.
Researchers investigated the effects of Cytothal distending toxin (CDT) and colibactin, bacterial toxins secreted by pathogenic bacteria, on nuclear remodeling in the context of cell survival. Helicobacter infected mice, co-culture with CDT and colibin-secreting bacteria, hepatic, intestinal, and gastric cells, and xenograft mouse models were used to assess nuclear remodeling in vitro and in vivo. Results showed that CDT and colibin induced nuclear remodeling associated with formation of cytoplasmic invaginations in the nucleus of cells. These structures, observed in vivo and vitro, correspond to nucleoplasmic reticulum (NR). The NR core contained ribosomes, proteins involved in mRNA translation, polyadenylated RNA, and components of complex CR involved mRNA turnover. These structures were active sites of translation, correlated with high ploidy, and MAP and calcium signaling. Data showed insulation and concentration of ribonucleoproteins within nucleus were dynamic and transient, protecting cells until genotoxic stress relieved. Bacterial genotoxin-induced NR was a gateway for mRNA to be transported for local translation.
Researchers conducted a quantitative evaluation of maxillary bone deformation in patients with leprosy using three-dimensional computed tomography (3-CT). They reconstructed three-dimensional images of the maxilla in 10 patients with lepro and 5 controls, and measured the anterior-posterior length of the maxilla (MA). The difference in MA between patients and controls was evaluated after compensating for individual skull size. The findings were compared to previous paleopathological studies. Three patients with lepromatous leprosy showed marked atrophy of the maxilla (-8.6, -11.1, and -17.9mm), consistent with visual appearance of maxillary deformity and paleopathological findings. The study confirmed maxillary regression in paleopathological studies.
Researchers investigated how the auditory system represents sounds in a way that is invariant to background noise, which is a significant challenge in identifying relevant sounds amidst noise. To address this, the system may represent sounds in a noise-invariant fashion by adapting to stimulus statistics altered by noise. The study examined adaptation to mean and contrast of auditory stimulation along the auditory pathway by presenting synthetic and natural sounds, recording responses in inferior colliculus and primary auditory cortex of anaesthetized ferrets, and comparing with a model of auditory nerve. Adaptation to both forms increased along the pathway. To determine if adaptation to statistics contributes to noise-invariant representations, complex sounds in noise were embedded and a decoding approach used to assess population noise tolerance. The code for complex in periphery was more affected by noise than cortical. Noise tolerance was correlated with adaptation to statistics, with strongest adapting populations being most tolerant. The increase in adaptation from nerve to cortex is a stage in constructing noise-invariant representations in higher brain.
Researchers investigated the reorganization of the yeast protein-protein interaction network (interactome) in response to heat shock stress using Saccharomyces cerevisiae as a model organism. The study analyzed changes in interaction weights of the interactome from mRNA expression levels upon heat shock and found that heat induced a significant decrease in overlaps and connections of interactome modules. The diameter of the interactome increased 4.9-fold in response to heat. Key proteins of the heat response became centers of heat-induced communities and provided residual connections after shock. The changes resembled a "stratus-culus" transition of interact structure, with unstressed interact having a global organization like stratus clouds and shocked interact having multifocal like cumulus. Results showed heat induced partial disintegration of global interact organization. This may occur in other stresses and complex systems, including proteins, social networks, and ecosystems, which decrease intermodular links, form compact modules, and disintegrate globally in initial crisis phase.
A systematic review and individual patient data meta-analysis was conducted to assess the effect of amiodarone in patients with Chagas cardiomyopathy, a chronic condition caused by Trypanosoma cruzi prevalent in Latin America. Nine studies (3 before-after studies, 5 case series, and 1 randomized trial) were included, with 2 providing full datasets for individual patient-level analysis. Amiodarone significantly reduced ventricular tachia episodes by 99.9% (CI 99.8-100%), ventricular beats by 93.1 (82-97.4%), and ventricular couplets by 79% (RR 0.21, CI 0.11-0.39) in 24-hour Holter. Studies not included in individual data analysis showed similar reductions in ventricular beats, tachia, and couplets. Meta-analysis pooled incidence of adverse effects associated with amarone included corne microdepos 61.1 (19-91.5), gastrointestinal 16.1 (6-34.23), bradycardia 12.7 (3-35.6), dermatological 10.6 (4-21.93), and discontinuation 7.68 (4-13.75). Quality evidence ranged from moderate to low. Amiodone is effective in reducing ventricular arrhythmias but lacks evidence for hard endpoints (sudden death, hospitalization).
A study was conducted to investigate the seasonal patterns of deng fever in rural Ecuador from 2009-2016 using medical records from two hospitals. Poisson generalized modeling was used to determine short and long-term patterns of deng fever, as well as the effect of day of the week and public holidays. A subset analysis examined the impact of school schedules on school-aged children, and a separate model evaluated the effect of climate on diagnosis. Results showed that annual sinusoidal fluctuations in disease, long-term trends, day of the week, and hospital were significant predictors of deng fever. Seasonal trends peaked in mid-March, with more cases diagnosed on Tuesdays and Thursdays, and fewer on Saturdays and Sundays. Public holidays were not significant predictors except for an increase on the day after Christmas. School schedules did not impact deng diagnoses in school children. Climate variables included total precipitation, interaction between precipitation and minimum temperature, interaction between precipitation and days, and three-way interaction between temperature, precipitation, and days.
Researchers have explored the potential of the innate immune system as an alternative to adaptive immunity in combating emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases, which can take years or decades to develop. They found that expressing a picornavirus RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRP) in the absence of other viral proteins can activate the innate immune system without triggering autoimmunity or chronic inflammation. RRP-transgenic mice showed long-term upregulation of interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs) and resistance to lethal viral challenge. The mechanism operates through MDA and MAVS and is independent of the adaptive system. Human models recapitulated the findings with RRP inducing an IS network and blocking HIV-1 infection. The RRP mechanism does not depend on secondary structure but operates at the protein level and requires catalysis. Despite massive IS elevations, RRP mice are healthy with normal longevity. The study provides a foundation for augmenting innate immunity to achieve broad-spectrum antiral protection.
Effective population size (Ne) plays a crucial role in determining the strength of genetic drift and frequency of co-infection by multiple genotypes in viral evolution. However, estimates of Ne for plant viruses have yielded diverging results. The independent action hypothesis (IAH) proposes that each virion has a probability of infection, and virions act independently during the infection process. A corollary of IAH is that Ne must be dose-dependent. To test IAH for a plant virus, a study was conducted using Tobacco etch virus (TEV) variants carrying GFP or mCherry fluorescent markers in Nicotiana tabum and Capsicum plants. The number of primary infection foci increased linearly with dose and followed a Poisson distribution. At high doses, primary foci containing both genotypes were found at low frequency (<2%). The probability of a genotype infecting the inoculated leaf systemically infecting the plant was near 1, although rare genotypes could be trapped in the inoculated leaf by surrounding other genotypes. The frequency of mixed-genotype infection was predicted by the mean primary foci using the independent model. Independent action holds for TE, and Ne is dose-dependent for this RNA virus. The number of virions causing systemic infection can be small, approaching 1 at low doses.
Researchers have developed a new statistical framework for analyzing gene expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) in multiple tissues simultaneously, addressing a limitation of previous studies that focused on single tissues or cell types. This Bayesian approach, called Sparse Regression for eQTL, enables joint analysis of gene expression across tissues with genetic variants. In a study of 2,000 genes across four tissues, the method outperformed traditional approaches in revealing the complexity of the QTL landscape at the systems-level. A previously undetected cis-QTL for the Hopx gene was experimentally validated, demonstrating the method's power. Approximately 27% of transcripts showed common regulation across tissues, resulting in a 5-fold increase in QTL detection compared to single-tissue analyses at 5% false discovery rate. This study provides new insights into complex genetic control of gene expression and the generality of the approach makes it adaptable to other models and humans, enabling analysis of multiple and whole-body phenotypes.
Researchers have developed a mathematical model to understand how extrinsic apoptosis, a type of programmed cell death, is controlled. Extrinsic apoptosis is triggered by tumor necrosis factor (TNF) or TN-related apoptosis-inducing ligand (TRAIL), which activates initiator caspases, enzymes that then activate downstream effector caspases to dismantle the cell. This process is controlled by a variable-delay, snap-action switch, allowing cells to choose between life and death. The model, based on mass-action representation of reaction pathways, was trained with data from live-cell imaging, flow cytometry, and immunoblot of cells with protein depletion and overexpression. The model accurately reproduces normal and perturbed cells exposed to TRAIL, enabling detailed study of switching mechanisms. Analysis and experiments show that initiator casp-8 activity and reaction rates downstream of TR receptor determine delay duration to effector caspase activation. Sudden effector caspase activation is achieved by mitochondrial membrane permeabilization and Smac relocalization. Bcl-2 family interactions, Smac partition from XIAP, and pore assembly mechanics are critical for snap control.
During pregnancy, the placenta acts as a protective barrier against maternal immune responses, bacterial, and viral pathogens. Listeria monocytogen, a bacterial pathogen, has evolved mechanisms to breach this barrier, providing an opportunity to study the placenta's protective function. The L. monocytogen protein Internalin (InP) is a secreted virulence factor critical for placental infection. This study shows InP binds to afadin, a protein associated with cell junctions, but not the similar L. monocogenin Lmo7. The InP structure features an extended leucine-rich repeat (LRR) domain with a Ca2+-binding site. Despite af's role in cell junction formation, MDCK cells expressing InP exhibit decreased traction on substrates, similar to AF-6 knockout MDCK cells. L monocogenΔinP mutants are deficient in actin protrusions from polarized epithelial monolayers, necessary for transcytosis. A similar phenotype is observed in bacteria with an in-frame InP deletion (InPΔRR) disrupting interaction with af. However, af deletion in host cells does not rescue transcyt defect. Secreted InP targets cytosolic af to promote L monocogen transcyt across epithelial monolayers, contributing to crossing the basement membrane during placental infection.
Researchers characterized the proteome of Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis, using complementary mass spectrometry techniques. A total of 603 peptides were detected, corresponding to 557 unique proteins at a high confidence level, representing 54% of the predicted proteome. This is the most comprehensive description of the T. pallum proteome to date. The study used multidimensional separation and identification via matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization-time of flight (MALDI-TOF/TO) and electrospray ionization (ESI-TQ-Orbit) tandem mass spectrometry on T. pallum subspecies pallum DAL-1 strain isolated from rabbits. Detected proteins were annotated according to predicted function and localization, with half categorized into various functional groups. One hundred and fourteen proteins were previously annotated as hypothetical or uncharacterized, with this being the first identification at protein level. Proteins with unclear annotations were subjected to bioinformatics analysis for further characterization. A hundred and sixteen potential membrane proteins were identified, of which 16 had outer membrane localization evidence. Eight proteins related to the paralog tpr gene family were found. Protein abundance was semi-quantified using label-free counting methods. Low correlation was found between microarray data and protein abundance. The study provides valuable insights into in vivo T. pallum protein expression and pathogenicity.
Protein kinase A (PKA) is a key receptor for the secondary messenger cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) in eukaryotes. AMP binds to two tandem AMP-binding domains (CBD-A and -B) within the regulatory subunit of PKA (R), unleashing the activity of the catalytic subunit (C). The study investigated the dynamics of the two-domain construct RIα (91-379) in its apo, cAMP, and c-bound forms using Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy. Comparative NMR analyses revealed a double conformation selection model where each CBD samples both active and inactive states independently of the adjacent CBD within a degenerate free energy landscape. This degener is critical for the gate function of CBD-B, which modulates the control exerted by CBD-A. Binding of cAMP eliminates degener, stabilizing the active conformation within CBD and inter-C contacts, which require cAMP. The inter-C interface is dispensable for intra-C conformation selection but indispensable for PK activation as it occludes C-sub sites within CBD-A. Structurally homolog c-bound CBDs exhibit marked differences in residual profiles, suggesting conservation of structure does not imply dynamics.
Researchers investigated the role of interferon-stimulated gene 15 (IS15) in the function of macrophages following vaccinia virus infection. They compared the proteomes of IS15- and IS+ bone marrow-derived macrophages (BMD) after vaccinia virus (V) infection. The results showed that mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative phosphorylation pathways were altered in IS- MD treated with interferon. Mitochondrial respiration, adenosine triphosphate (ATP) and reactive oxygen species (ROS) production were higher in IS+ MD than IS- MD following interferon treatment, indicating IS-dependent mechanisms. IS depletion led to a change in macrophage polarization. IS- macrophages showed a pro-inflammatory cytokine pattern typical of M1 phenotype, but blocked nitric oxide (NO) production and arginase activation. Following interferon treatment, NO release was higher in IS+ macroph than IS- macro concomitant with decrease in viral titer. IS- macroph were permissive for VV replication following interferon treatment. The study demonstrates that IS governs mitochondrial function, specifically oxidative phosphorylation and mitagy, broadening its role as antiv agent.
HIV-1 protein Vpu plays a crucial role in viral replication by degrading the cellular receptor CD4 and enhancing viral particle release. V binds CD4 and recruits the βTr subunit of the SCβCP ubiquitin ligase complex through its constitutively phosphorylated DS52XX56 motif, escaping degradation while inhibiting βTr targets such as β-caten and Iκα. This study investigated V's inhibitory function on Em1 and Cdc25, β substrates in cell cycle progression. Phosphorylation of V at serine 61, adjacent to βTr-binding motif, triggers β-independent degradation. Mutation V S61 in HIV-1 extends protein half-life and increases particle release from HeLa cells. The S determinant is conserved in HIV-1 isolates. Phosphorylation of V determines fate as adaptor or substrate of ubiquinases. Conservation of V degradation, despite negative effect on release, suggests role in overall HIV fitness.
Researchers investigated the relationship between tissue patterning and whole-body development in Drosophila larvae to understand how robustness against environmental and physiological perturbations is achieved. Two hypotheses were proposed: tissue pattering is coordinated with whole-body development over time, and patterning aligns at developmental milestones. A staging scheme for wing imaginal discs was developed using canonical patterning genes linked to whole-body events: moulting, larval, and pupation. The scheme was used to explore pattern progression changes when development time was altered by temperature or hormone synthesis. Results showed pattern alignment at moul and pupation, indicating these events represent milestones. Between milestones, pattern showed variability in response to temperature and physiological changes. Discs from wandering larvae showed greater variability in patterning, suggesting it is not a milestone. Findings indicate patter remains robust against perturbations by aligning at milestones. This work provides insight into how individual tissue development is coordinated with the body as a whole.
In polarized cells, such as fungal hyphae, endosomes play a crucial role in both endocytosis and long-distance transport of various cargoes, including mRNA and protein complexes. However, the interplay between these processes is not well understood. This study demonstrates that the ESCRT regulator Did coordinates endosomal transport in hyphae of Ustago may. Loss of Did results in defective vacuolar targeting, reduced long-distance transport, and abnormal shuttling of early endosomes. The late endosomal protein Rab7 and vacuolar protease P1 exhibit increased shuttling on these aberrant endosomes, indicating defects in endosomal maturation and identity. Molecular motors fail to attach, explaining disturbed processive movement. Additionally, the endosomal RNP linker Up1 is absent from endosomes, leading to defects in long-distance mRNA transport.
Researchers conducted a comparative study on the adenine riboswitches of Bacillus subtilis and Vibrio vulnus, two types of ligand-binding elements that regulate bacterial mRNAs at the transcriptional or translational level. While both bind adenine, the riboswitches differ in their regulatory mechanisms, with B. subtilis controlling transcription and V. vulnus translation. The study revealed differences in ligand binding properties and operating regimes between the two riboswitches. The B. subtil ribwitch relies on co-transcriptional binding of adenine for function, whereas the V. vulus ribwitch can bind adenine post-transcriptionally and still regulate translation. Further investigation showed that transcription rate is crucial for B. subtil ribwitch efficiency, consistent with co-transcription regulation. The findings suggest that the nature of regulation, transcription or translation, plays a significant role in ribwitch mechanisms.
Researchers have identified a conserved pattern of primer-dependent transcription initiation (PDI) in Escheria coli and Vibrio cholera using high-throughput sequencing of RNA 5' ends (5 RNA-seq). PDI is a process where a 2-4 nucleotide oligonucleotide primer is used to initiate transcription, previously shown to be prevalent at promoters of genes during stationary phase growth in E. coli. coli. This study establishes a physiological role for P in E. coli as a regulatory mechanism modulating biofilm formation and demonstrates its occurrence in the pathogenic bacterium V. cholera. A comparative analysis of P in V. cholera and E. coli reveals a striking similarity in the pattern of P. P is detected in stationary phase, not exponential, and preferentially at promoters with sequence T-1+1 or G-1+ (position 1 corresponding to de novo initiation). The study demonstrates a physiological role for P and suggests it may be widespread among Gammaprotebacteria. P in both E. coli and V. cholera occurs through a growth-dependent process leading to preferential generation of dinucleotides 5'-UA-3 and 5'-GG-3.
Researchers investigated the effect of parental genome imbalance on the expression of imprinted genes in Arabidopsis, a plant species. Imprinted genes are expressed by a single parental allele and play a crucial role in regulating growth and development. The parental conflict theory proposes that genome imbalance is mirrored by antagonistic regulation of imprinted genes, with maternal growth inhibitors and paternal enhancers. However, these hypotheses were not directly tested. This study examined the impact of genome imbalance on expression of Arabidopsis imprinted genes FERTIZATION INDEPENDENT SE2 (FIS) and FLOW WINGENING (FW) controlled by DNA methylation and MEA (ME) and PES (P1) by histone methylation. Results showed that genome imbalance deregulated expression of IS and P in an antagonistic manner, with increased dosage of inactive alleles causing loss of imprinting of IS and ME. IS controls histone methylation, repressing ME and P expression, but changes in P and ME could not be fully explained by fluctuations in IS expression. Parental dosage deregulates imprinting mechanisms independent of known regulators. The complexity of regulations between expressed and silenced imprinted genes in response to dosage does not support simple models from parental hypothesis.
Researchers have investigated the hierarchical organization of brain rhythms in the brain using electroencephalography (EEG) and magnetoencephalography (MEG) recordings, which exhibit oscillations of specific frequencies over a non-oscillatory background. These oscillations appear in the power spectrum as a collection of frequency bands evenly spaced on a logarithmic scale, preventing mutual entrainment and cross-talk. The study focuses on what brain rhythms reveal about functional connectivity, rather than how they emerge or are necessary for neural function. By constructing "virtual" brains" with dynamics similar to EEG/ME recordings, researchers found that these networks share structural and topological features with real brains. Mathematical techniques were used to reverse-engineer network architectures generating characteristic of brain dynamics, including spindles and sharp waves. Reconstructed networks display similar topological features and dynamics. Diseased brains (epileptic and schizophrenic) with altered oscillatory activity were also reverse-engineered, showing consistent alterations in connectivity and dynamics. Complexity, quantified by Tononi and Sporns Edelman, is a good indicator of brain fitness, as diseased brains display lower complexity than normal.
Researchers conducted a population structure analysis of 1,374 Hispanic individuals from the Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis (MESA) using 60,000 SNPs selected for linkage disequilibrium. The study included individuals from Central America (n=93), Cuba (n=50), the Dominican Republic (n=203), Mexico (n=708), Puerto Rico (n=192), and South America (n=111). Principal components (PCs) of ancestry from Hap phase and Human Diversity Panel (HGDP) were used to quantify Caucasian, African, and Native American origins. The third and fourth PCs revealed an axis aligning with South-to-N geographic location of HGDP Native samples, separating MESA Mexican from Central/South American samples. K-means clustering from four PCs defined four subgroups in the ESA cohort, aligning with self-identification: Dominican/Cub, Mexican, Central/South, and Rican. A pooled and stratified analysis of triglycerides SNPs in LPL and TR1 regions, previously reported in Caucasians but unconfirmed in Hispanics, showed significant association in both genes. The study highlights the importance of considering population structure and genetic heterogeneity in genetic studies in the US Hispanic population.
Elongator, a histone acetylase complex, interacts with proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) to modulate transcriptional silencing and sensitivity to DNA damage. The Elong complex, composed of six subunits, is involved in histone deposition onto replicating DNA during PCNA-dependent nucleosome assembly. This process is crucial for maintaining transcriptional silencing and genome stability. However, the regulation of these pathways is not well understood. This study reports an interaction between Elong and PCNA. Cells lacking El3, the catalytic subunit of Elong, exhibit partial silencing loss of reporter genes at telomere and HMR, and increased sensitivity to hydroxyurea (HU) and methanesulfonate (MS). Deletion of El3 or mutations in other El subunits compromise Elong formation and result in sil loss and HU sensitivity. El3 is required for S-phase progression in H presence. Epasis analysis shows el3 mutant sensitive to MS exacerbates MS cells lacking histone chaperone As1, C-1 and H3 acetylase R109. el3 has specific interactions with POL30 encoding PCNA, which binds Elong in vivo and vitro. Results uncover novel Elong role in transcription silencing and genome stability, linked to replication and repair PCNA.
Researchers have developed a machine-assisted literature triage method to improve the process of manually curating biomedical knowledge from publications. The traditional query-based method of retrieving relevant publications from PubMed often yields unsatisfactory results and is difficult to generate optimal queries. To address this, a deep learning-based method was proposed, trained on a gold-standard dataset of curated publications from UniProt/SwissProt and NHRIEB GWAS Catalog. The trained models classify and rank new publications for curation. The method was applied to the real-world curation of UniProt/SissProt and GWAS, outperforming current query-based methods in efficiency and enriching content. Precision was 1.81 and 2.99 times higher than query-based methods for UniProt/Siss and GWAS, respectively, without compromising recall. The method retrieved additional publications not found by query Uni/SProtiss. Results show the machine-assisted triage process is more efficient, allowing human curators to focus on quality improvement.
A gain-of-function mutations in the KCNJ2-encoded Kir2.1 channels underlie variant 3 (SQT3) of the short QT syndrome, which is associated with atrial fibrillation (AF). This study investigated the mechanistic link between QT3 mutations and atrial arrhythmogenesis and potential channel targets for treatment of QT3 using physiologically-detailed human atrial computer models. A model of the atrial action potential (AP) was modified to recapitulate functional changes in IK due to heterozygous and homozygous forms of D172 and E299 Kir2.1 mutations. Wild-type (WT) and mutant formulations were incorporated into multi-scale and heterogeneous models. Effects on AP duration (AP), conduction (CV), refractory period (ERP), tissue excitation threshold and rate-dependence, as well as wavelength re-entry (WL) were quantified. The D172 and E299 Kir.1 mutations produced distinct effects on IK and AP shortening. Both mutations decreased WL through reduction in ERP and CV. Stability of reentrant excitation in 2D and 3 tissue was mediated by changes tissueability and AP in conditions. Combined block of IK and IK was effective in terminating re-entry with heterozygous D172, whereas IK block alone may be safer for E299. Combined of IK and IK produced synergistic antiarrhythmic in both forms QT3. This study provides mechanistic insights atrial prohythm with QT2.1 mutations and highlights pharmacological for management of QT-linked AF.
Researchers investigated the potential of adipose-derived mesenchymal stromal cells (ASC) in treating Chagas disease, caused by the protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi (T. cruzi), in a mouse model of chagasic cardiopathy. ASC were injected intraperitoneally at 3 days post-infection (dpi) and tracked by bioluminescence, showing they remained in the abdominal cavity for up to 9 days, with most migrating to abdominal subcutaneous fat, an early parasite reservoir. ASC injection significantly reduced parasitemia, followed by decreased cardiac tissue parasitism and fibrosis at 30 dpi. Cytokine analysis in heart cells exposed to T. cruzi antigens showed an anti-inflammatory response in ASC-treated animals, while splenocytes produced a pro-inflammatory response, crucial for parasite control in placebo and ASC groups. However, splenocytes from ASC released higher IL-10 at 60 dpi. Magnetic resonance imaging revealed right ventricular (RV) dilation prevention in ASC-treated mice. Early ASC injection after T. cruz infection prevented RV remodeling through immune response modulation, promoting parasite control and heart protection from damage.
Researchers investigated the effectiveness of structurally optimized analogs of Retro-2, a retrograde trafficking inhibitor, in limiting Leishmania infections in mammalian cells. Leish parasites reside in parasitophorous vacuoles (LPVs), and previous studies showed that Retro-2 reduced LP size and parasite numbers in L. mexicana infections. This study aimed to determine if analogs of Retro-2 with superior potency in inhibiting retrograde-dependent phenomena, such as polyavirus infection and Shiga toxin trafficking, were more effective against Leish infections. In addition to LP effects, analogs DHZ36 and DHZ36.1 limited Leish infection in macrophages with EC50 13.63±2.58μM and 10.57±2.66M, respectively, lower than Retro-2's 40.15M EC50. These analogs also reversed Leish induced IL-6 suppression by infected cells after LPS activation. Unlike Retro-2, analogs killed Leish parasites in axenic cultures, a desirable for treating Leish infections. Studies validated and extended the structure-activity relationship of Retro-2.
Researchers have developed a computational method to evaluate the sensitivity of nucleosomes to transcription factors along a given stretch of the genome. The method identifies sensitive factors as those with binding sites preferentially within nucleosome boundaries and lacking 10 base pair periodicity. Using this approach, the Acute Myeloid Leukemia-1 (AML-1) transcription factor, a regulator of immune gene expression, was predicted to be sensitive to nucleosomal regulation within the Ly49 gene family. This prediction was confirmed in an RMA cell line with natural expression of Ly49, using MNase-Seq to generate a nucleosome map of chromosome 6, where the Ly49 family is located. Analysis of this map revealed a specific depletion of nucleosomes at AML-1 binding sites in expressed Ly49 compared to silent Ly genes. The study suggests nucleosome regulation contributes to Ly gene expression. The method of predicting nucleosome sensitivity is proposed to aid in dissecting the role of nucleosomes in general.
Cyclin-dependent kinases (CDs) play a crucial role in orchestrating cell cycle progression, including genome duplication. CD activation depends on phosphorylation of their T-loop by CD-activating kinase (CAK). In animals, the known CA for CD2 and CD1 is cyclin-HCD7, which is constitutively active. The critical step is dephosphorylation of inhibitory sites by C25 phosphatases rather than T-loop phosphorylation. Homolog CD4 and CD6 bound cyclins are integrators of mitogenic signaling cascades by inactivating the oncosuppressor p and cycle at the restriction point. Unlike CD1 and CD2 cyclin complexes, constitutive T phosphorylation of CD6 is weak, whereas T-loop phosphorylation at172 of CD4 is highly regulated. CD4 and CD6 phosphorylations are catalyzed by CD7 unclear. To answer, we used chemical-genetics with analogue-sensitive CD7 (as) mutant H116 cells, inhibited by adenine analogs. CD7 inhibition prevented phosphorylations CD6, but CD4 was partly dependent on p21. In response CD7 inhibition, p-binding CD increased conitantly with disappearance of phosphorylation p, localized S130 catalyzed by CD and CD2. S130 mutation p prevented CD phosphorylation and inhibited CD6 and CD2 phosphorylations p and p-bound CD. CD7 inhibition revealed crucial indirect CD7 involvement in CD4 phosphorylation and existence CD-activating other than CD7 and novel CD-dependent feedback by p phosphorylation CD and CD2 sustain activation p and restriction passage.
Researchers have identified a protein called DUET/M1 that plays a crucial role in the process of meiosis in Arabidopsis, a plant species of flowering plant. Meiosis is a process that produces haploid cells essential for sexual reproduction. The study found that DUET1 binds to a protein called H3me2 and this interaction is necessary for its function during meiosis. Additionally, DU1 is required for proper microtubule organization during meiosis, stage II, independently of its role in meiosis I. The protein shows stage-specific expression, being confined to diplotene. Two genes, TDM1 and JAS, are critical for cell cycle and spindle organization in meiosis and are targets of DU1, with T1 being a direct target. DU regulates microtub organization and cell transitions during meiosis and activates the meiotic gene T1. Expression analysis showed reduced expression of 12% of known meiotic genes in du mutant. The study reveals DU as transcriptional regulator during meiosis in plants and suggests that meiotic gene expression is stage-wise in plants, unlike yeast.
Fragile X-associated tremor ataxia syndrome (FXTAS) is a neurodegenerative disorder caused by the expansion of CG repeats in the Fragile X mental retardation 1 (FMR1) gene. Previous studies have shown that CG repeats are sufficient to cause neurodegeneration and that CG-binding proteins α and hnRNP A/B can modulate CG-mediated neurotoxicity. To investigate the role of α in CG-mediated neurodegeneration, a proteomic approach was used to identify over 100 proteins that interact with α. Notably, R62, the Drosophila ortholog of p68 helicase, was found to modulate CG-mediated neurodegeneration. This study found that CG repeats decrease R62 transcription, leading to the accumulation of H70 and additional mRNAs involved in stress and immune responses. The accumulation of these mRNAs, likely due to impaired export, may contribute to FAS pathogenesis.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a bacterium that forms environmentally and clinically relevant biofilms, has been studied as a paradigm for biofilm development. The extracellular matrix of P. aerugin biofilm is a complex mixture of polysaccharides, nucleic acids, and proteins. Researchers have directly visualized the product of the polyschar synthesis locus (Psl polyschar) at different stages of biofilm development. During attachment, P is anchored on the cell surface in a helical pattern, promoting cell-cell interactions and matrix assembly, holding bacteria in biofilm on surface. Chemical dissociation of P from bacterial surface disrupted P matrix and bio structure. During bio maturation, P accumulates on periphery of 3-D microcolonies, forming P matrix-free cavity in microcol center. At dispersion stage, cells appear in matrix. Dead and extracellular DNA (eDNA) concentrated in P-free area. Deletion of genes controlling cell death autolysis affected matrix and microcol formation dispersion. Data provide mechanism P. aerugin builds matrix and cavity for cell seeding. Visualization reveals P key matrix component.
Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is a malignancy with poor prognosis, necessitating improved therapeutic strategies. Patient-derived xenografts (PDX) and patient-derived organoids (PDO) are promising tools for identifying drugs with therapeutic potential in PDAC. To be effective, these preclinical models must recapitulate PDAC molecular heterogeneity and validate patient-specific sensitivities. A comprehensive assessment of 16 whole-genome pairs of tumours and PDX from PD and metastasis was conducted, including a unique cohort of 5 'triplets' of primary tumour, PDX, and PDO. A pipeline was developed to score concordance between PD models and paired tumours for genomic events, including mutations, structural variations, and copy variations. Tumour-model comparisons showed single-gene concord across major PD driver genes, but poor agreement across mutational load. Genome-wide chromosome analysis of structural (SV) events highlighted concordance across chromosomes with clustered SV. Ploidy presented a challenge in assessing copy changes; however, ploidy-correct copy states showed agreement between donor pairs. This study highlights PDX and PDO as transplantable systems for probing PD molecular properties, but may serve selective analyses across genomic complexity levels.
A genome-wide association study was conducted in 19,091 breast cancer cases and 20,606 controls of East-Asian descent, including Chinese and Japanese women, to identify genetic susceptibility loci for breast cancer. The study analyzed 690,947 SNPs in 2,918 cases and 2,324 controls, then evaluated 5,365 SNPs in 3,972 and 3,852, followed by 94 SNPs in 5,203 and 5,138. The top 22 SNPs were investigated in 17,423 additional subjects (7,489 and 9,934). The study found a significant association between SNP rs9482, near TGF-β activated kinase 2 (TAB) gene on chromosome 6q25.1, with breast cancer risk, with a P-value 3.8×10^-12 in combined analysis. Adjusted odds ratios (95% CI) were 0.89 (0.85-0.94) and 0.80 (0.75-0.86) for A/G and A genotypes, respectively, compared to GG. SNP938 (P=1.9×10^-6) in ESR gene intron 5 and rs7107 (P=4.6×10^-7) at 11q24.3 also showed consistent association. This study provides evidence for novel breast susceptibility locus rs948 near TAB (6.25) and possible loci in ESR and 11.24.
Researchers conducted a study on a cohort of 230 Cryptococcus neoformans (C) isolates from HIV-positive patients in South Africa to investigate the relationship between genetic diversity and clinical outcomes of cryptococcal meningitis. The study used multi-locus sequence typing and in vitro virulence assays to correlate genetic data with clinical markers of disease in patients. Results showed high genetic diversity and variability in South African isolates compared to global types, with 50 sequence types grouped into main types VNI, VNII, and VNB, and 72% into 7 high-frequency types. Spatial analysis found no geographical clustering of patients' cryptococcal genotypes, suggesting reactivation of latent infection rather than recent acquisition. Comparison of MLST data with clinical parameters revealed a relationship between genetic lineage and outcome, with VNB lineage associated with worse survival (HR 3.35, CI 1.51-7.20, p=0.003), maintained after adjusting for prognostic indicators and treatment. In vitro assays on 89 isolates showed lineage-associated virulence, with VNII increased lacc activity (p=0.001) and ex vivo CSF survival (p0.000). Findings indicate Cryptoccus neoans is phenotypically heterogeneous and lineage plays role in cryptococcal virulence during human infection. Detailed understanding genetic diversity in Africa supports investigation of diversity across environments and risks posed to infection.
Researchers have identified the transcription factor Tec1 as a key component of a newly evolved signaling pathway that regulates the pheromone response in the white phenotype of Candida albicans. This discovery provides a comprehensive understanding of the pherone response pathway in the white phenotype of C. albicans and sheds light on how signaling pathways may evolve. The pherone response in C. albicans involves three distinct portions, each derived from different ancestral processes. The upstream components, including receptors, trimeric G protein, and MAP kinase cascade, are from the mating pathway. Tec1, a transcription factor targeted by the MAP pathway, is from filamentation, and white-specific downstream genes from biofilm. This evolution of the pherone pathway serves as a model for how signaling pathways evolve.
Researchers investigated the variation in genomic GC content among bacteria, which ranges from less than 20% to over 70%, attributing it to differences in mutation patterns. They analyzed synonymous polymorphism datasets from 149 species to test this hypothesis. A significant excess of GC→AT mutations over AT→GC mutations was found in all but the most AT-rich bacteria, across diverse species. This excess is inconsistent with mutation bias, as it would imply GC-rich bacteria decreasing in GC content, which is unsustainable. Translational selection and gene conversion are also ruled out, as optimal codons are AT-rich and excess GC→SNPs observed in recombination-free datasets. Therefore, selection for increased GC-content is present in many species. Since GC-content is correlated with genomic-content, selection on base composition is also present in bacteria.
Researchers have developed a new approach to map the prevalence of soil-transmitted helminth (STH) infections in Kenya using observed data from 106,370 individuals in 945 cross-sectional surveys between 1974 and 2009. Ecological and climatic covariates were extracted from high-resolution satellite data and matched to survey locations. Bayesian-time geostatistical models were developed for each species and used to interpolate the probability of infection exceeding 20% across the country for 1989 and 2009. Maps for each species were integrated to estimate combined STH prevalence using the law of probability and a correction for associations. Population data were combined with models to estimate the population at risk and requiring treatment in 2009. In 2009, high endemicity was below 20% in most areas, with ≥20% around Lake Victoria and coast. Comparison of 198 and 200 show STH prevalence decreased over time. The model estimated 2.8 million school-age children in districts warrant treatment. Bayesian-time models can estimate STH prevalence and suggest a quarter of Kenya's school children live in high areas warranting mass treatment.
Researchers investigated the role of innate lymphocytes in immunity against Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection. They established an in vitro system to study the interaction between innate and adaptive immune responses. Interferon-γ production was observed when splenocytes from uninfected mice were cultured with M-infected macrophages, resulting in suppressed bacterial replication. This control was dependent on CD1-restricted invariant NKT (iKT) cells, which required CD1 expression by infected macrophages and IL-12 and IL-18. iKT cells, even in small quantities, restricted M replication. To assess in vivo contribution, iKT cells were adoptively transferred into mice. Primary splenic iKT from uninf mice significantly reduced bacterial burden in lungs of mice infected with virulent M by aerosol route. iKT had direct bactericidal effect without synthetic ligand α-galactosceramide. iKT protected mice against aerosol M infection, demonstrating CD-restricted N cells mediate protection against M in vivo.
Researchers investigated the regulation of Bacillus subtilis spore coat transglutaminase (Tgl), an enzyme responsible for cross-linking proteins in the bacterial endospore coat. Unlike other transglutases, Tgl is produced in an active form and catalyzes amine incorporation and cross-linking in vitro with no additional requirements. To understand how T's activity is controlled during spore assembly, they found that substrates assembled onto the spore prior to T production govern T's localization to the surface. T's residues for substrate recognition are crucial for its localization, with glutamyl (Q) and lys (K) docking sites identified. The first reaction step, interaction with substrates and acyl-enzyme formation, determines T's localization. In solution, T forms a hexamer that cross-links into high molecular weight forms, and becomes part of cross-products during reaction. This suggests T's dependency on substrates controls time, location, and extent of activity, directing covalentification of pre-assembled complexes at sp surface.
A cross-sectional parasitological and questionnaire survey was conducted in 51 villages in Champasak province, Lao PDR, in the first half of 2007. The study aimed to map the distribution of Opisthorchis viverrin, a foodborne trematode species causing biliary diseases and cholangiocarcinoma, identify underlying risk factors, and predict prevalence at non-survey locations. Data on demography, socioeconomic status, water, sanitation, and behavior were combined with remotely sensed environmental data into a geographical information system. Bayesian statistical models were employed to identify factors and investigate spatial pattern of Opisthoris vivin infection. Bayesian krig was utilized to predict risk at non-survey locations. The prevalence of Opistis viv among 3,371 participants with complete records was 61.1%. Statistical models identified age, Lao ethnic group, educational attainment, occupation (farmer, fisherman, animal breeder), and unsafe water source as risk factors. History prazant treatment, access sanitation, and distance to freshwater were protective. Spatial patterns Opis were governed by environmental factors, predictive identifying two risk profiles: low in mountains and high in Mekong corridor. A risk map of Opis infection in Champak province was presented, important for targeting control efforts. Infection Opis associated with exposure intermediate host, human behavior, culture, transmission sustained lack sanitation.
In Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, the presence of Anopheles and Cule mosquito larvae is common, contributing to the transmission of lymphatic filariasis and malaria. A study investigated the importance of drains as larval habitats, using data from the Urban Malaria Control Program (UMCP) and a special survey conducted in 2006. The study found that more than 70% of larval habitats in Dar Sala were human-made, with aquatic habitats associated with agriculture having the highest proportion of Anophe larvae and Cule presence. However, the majority of aquatic habitats were drains (42%), with 43% (1,364/3,149) of all culicine and 33% (320/976) of anopheline habitats being drains. Compared to drains with flowing water, the odds of Anophe and Cx larvae were 8.8 and 6.3 (p<0.001) times larger in stagnant water. There was a positive association between vegetation and mosquito presence (p<0.001). The proportion of habitats with larvae was spatially correlated. Restoring and maintaining drains in Dar Sala has the potential to eliminate more than 40% of mosquito larval habitats treated with laricides by UMCP. The study highlights the importance of human-made larval habitats for lymphatic filasis and malaria vectors, underscoring the need for synergy between control efforts.
Dengue virus (DENV) infection leads to changes in lipid metabolism within the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) of infected cells, favoring viral replication. Previously, it was found that DENV inhibits HMG-CoA reductase (HMGCR) phosphorylation, creating a cholesterol-rich environment for replication. This study investigated the relationship between HMG activity and AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) in DENV-infected cells. Enzymatic assays, ELISA, and Western blotting revealed increased HMG activity in DENV-infected cells, associated with AMPK inactivation. Metformin, an AMPK activator, decreased HMG activity, suggesting AMPK mediates HMG activity. AMPK phosphorylation was reduced in DENV-infected cells at 12 and 24 hours post-infection. HMG and cholesterol co-localized with viral proteins NS3, NS4A, and E, indicating HMG and AMP activity in replicative complex formation. Metform and lovastatin, an HMG inhibitor, altered co-localization and replicative formation, supporting active HMG in replicative complexes. Metform showed dose-dependent antiviral effect in DENV-infected cells, while compound C, an AMP inhibitor, increased viral genome copies and infected cells. PP2, HMG phosphatase, was unaffected by DENV infection. Elevated HMG in DENV cells is due to AMPK inhibition, not PP2 activity. PP inhibition showed antiral effect in HMG-independent manner. DENV infection increases HMG through AMPK inactivation, raising ER cholesterol for replicative complexes.
Researchers used all-atom molecular dynamics simulations of the 70S ribosome to investigate the kinetics and energy landscape of tRNA translocation. The simulation spanned 2.1 million atoms and 1.3 microseconds, allowing for a detailed examination of specific conformational events during the process. Starting from a pre-translocation configuration, the study identified sets of residues undergoing rotary rearrangements implicated in ribosome function. Diffusion coefficients along collective coordinates of translocation were estimated to convert between experimental rates and energy measures of the landscape. This analysis, combined with previously reported rates of translocation, provided an upper-bound of free-energy associated with trans. The study focused on a particular kinetic scheme of translocation, but the framework is general and can be applied to energetic and kinetic descriptions with any number of intermediates and states.
Researchers investigated the genetic landscape of medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) by analyzing formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tumor tissues from 84 sporadic MTC patients and 36 paired normal thyroid tissues using the Ion AmpliSeq Cancer Panel. They identified 101 mutations in 18 genes in MTC samples, with the most common being in the RET proto-oncogene (47 cases), followed by mutations in HRAS (14), STK11 (11), KIT (6), MLH1 (4), KIT (3), and MET (3). Anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) rearrangement was evaluated by immunohistochemistry and break-ap fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH), with 2 of 98 cases positive for ALK. Targeted sequencing of DNA from two patients' tumor samples revealed glutamine-fructose-6-phosphate transaminase 1 (GF1)-ALK and echinoderm microtubule-associated protein 4 (E4)-ALK fusions. PCR and Sanger sequencing confirmed GF1-ALK, indicating an intra-chromosomal translocation or deletion. A metastatic M case with E4ALK showed response to AL inhibitor crizotinib. The study found several mutations in MTC and first identified AL fusions in M, suggesting E4ALK may be a driver and target for AL inhibitors, and GFALK a candidate for molecular therapy.
In Malda district, West Bengal, India, a study was conducted to evaluate the role of asymptomatic Leishmaniasis in the transmission of Visceral Leishiasis (VL) and Post Kala-azar Dermal Leishias (PKDL) in an endemic areas. A total of 289 individuals were screened for antileman antibody using K39 rapid diagnostic kits, out of which 185 were positive, 96 had a history of VL/PKDL and 89 did not. 79 were classified as asymptomatic Leishias and 10 as active VL with a ratio of 7.9:1. Among asymptomatic cases, 2 were lost to follow-up as they moved to other places. Disease transformation in 8/77 (10.39%) and seroconversion 62/77 (80.52%) were noted in asymptomatic individuals. 7 (9.09%) remained ser-positive after 3 years. Progression to disease among asymptomatic individuals occurred up to 3 years after baseline. In areas with no VL/PK cases for 2 years, it does not mean free from Leishias as sympt VL/PK may appear after 3 if asymptomatic. Asympt individuals need attention for VL elimination programme initiated by adjoining countries.
Researchers used Multiplex Ligation-Dependent Probe Amplification (MLPA) to analyze genome rearrangements in Saccharomyces cerevisiae caused by the presence of the retrotransposon Ty. They found that the distribution of translocations induced by Ty was nonrandom and majority were mediated by six targets on four chromosomes, despite 254 potential targets in the genome. Most Ty-mediated translocations resulted from RAD-dependent recombination, but some were mediated by RAD-independent recombination between Ty elements. RAD-independent trans did not require Rad51 or Rad59 homolog pairing or Rad1-10 endonuc complex. Defects in ASF1-dependent acetylation of histone H3 lysine 56 resulted in increased genome rearrangements and aneuploidy, which often occurred with rearrangements. MLPA is a technique for rapid analysis of rearrangements, facilitating study of pathways that prevent and promote rearrang and aneupidy.
Researchers have developed a new method for protein docking, called semi-definite programming underestimation (SD), which uses a quadratic function to underestimate a set of local energy minima in the space of rigid body motions (SE(3) while accounting for flexibility of the interface chains. The method minimizes funnel-shaped energy functions in the space of rigid motions, driven by favorable interactions in the neighborhood of the native state. A strategy is introduced to separate variables for side-chain optimization, center-to-center distance of two proteins, and five angular descriptors of relative orientations. This improves efficiency by turning the five-dimensional space into a well-behaved energy surface for underestimation. The algorithm explores the energy surface spanned by encounter complexes corresponding to local energy minima, similar to macromolecular association through collisions. Results show that the energy landscape is a funnel in a broad neighborhood of the native and SD generates predictions with less than 5Å ligand interface root-mean-square deviation, achieving a 20-fold efficiency gain over Monte Carlo methods.
